summary: Hong Kong shares edged down in early trade on Friday, dipping 0.05% to 24,288.52, despite a positive lead from Wall Street and improving Chinese factory activity. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, down 0.12% and 0.65%, respectively. Investors appear to be brushing off recent market uncertainty, including US President Trump's threats, and focusing on the positive economic indicators.

site_title: Japan inflation registers first back-to-back rise since 2015
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.2% in February, marking the first back-to-back gains since 2015. This slight increase follows a 0.1% rise in January. The jobless rate dropped to 2.2%, the lowest level since 1994. The inflation rate was in line with forecasts. This uptick in prices and low unemployment rate may signal a potential economic recovery in Japan.

site_title: Australia shares edge down as materials, financials fall; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Friday, closing at 5,883.3, due to losses in basic materials and financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for its best week since November. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 14.61 points, marking its fourth consecutive day of gains. The ACCC denied banks' collective bargaining with Apple and placed limits on interest-only loans to reinforce sound mortgage lending practices. Telecom and utility sectors rose, with Telstra and AGL Energy gaining nearly 1%.

site_title: Broker's Take: US policy uncertainty still dogs S-Reit sector, says OCBC Research
summary: OCBC Research notes that the S-Reit sector's recent 2.7% gain should be viewed against US policy uncertainty. The FTSE ST Reit Index outperformed the Straits Times Index, driven by a dovish Fed statement and unchanged expectations for three rate hikes this year. Despite this, OCBC maintains a "neutral" stance on the sector and recommends selective investing, highlighting Keppel DC Reit, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust as top picks.

images.alt_text: The recent trading momentum for the S-Reit sector must be matched against the policy uncertainties in the US, said an OCBC Investment Research report.

site_title: Opportunities beckon in Malaysia residential properties
summary: Malaysia's residential property market is slowing down due to weak economic conditions and government policies. Transactions and total value have dropped 11.9% and 16.4% year-on-year, respectively, in Q1-Q3 2016. Prices are expected to fall, but there's little indication of distress sales. Completed but unsold units are being offered at substantial discounts, making it a relatively affordable time to buy. Popular areas like Kuala Lumpur City Centre and Penang offer opportunities, while Iskandar Malaysia's market shows signs of weakness due to oversupply.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.56% and the Topix index rising 0.59%, driven by a weaker yen and solid US growth data. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: From palace to prison: South Korea's Park goes behind bars
summary: South Korea's former President Park Geun-Hye has been arrested and sentenced to prison after a court ordered her arrest as a criminal suspect in the corruption and influence-peddling scandal that led to her impeachment. She will be held in the Seoul Detention Centre, where prominent figures stay in one-person facilities due to safety concerns. Park faces multiple charges, including bribery and abuse of power, and will have to adjust to a simple lifestyle, including eating $1.30 meals and doing her own washing.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.13% to 3,177.39 on Friday, driven by gains in Keppel Corp, UOB, and DBS. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 4.15 points higher. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid a global stocks rally, with the Nasdaq setting a record close. Investors brushed off new US trade threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Win-win scenario in HDB resale market
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore has become increasingly attractive, with stabilising prices and increased Central Provident Fund (CPF) Housing Grants. Resale flat prices have fallen from their peak in 2013, and prices are unlikely to drop further. With the increased grants, buyers can now afford more affordable options, and the number of resale transactions is expected to increase 10% this year. Sellers can also benefit from the current market, with prices still higher than the 2005-2013 average. The market is considered a win-win for buyers and sellers, with no perfect timing to enter or exit.

site_title: Promising 2017 for luxury condo market
summary: The luxury condo market in Singapore's Core Central Region (CCR) is expected to continue its promising trend in 2017. The market experienced a turnaround in 2016, with a 54.5% year-on-year increase in non-landed private residential transactions. Key factors contributing to the market's revival include the relaunch of OUE Twin Peaks with a deferred payment scheme, bulk sales, and improved supply-demand balance. Ultra-sophisticated buyers are drawn to the market, and the government's tweak to the seller's stamp duty and enhanced deferred payment schemes may have uplifted sales in certain projects. Prices may still eke out a 1-3% price gain in 2017.

site_title: China March service sector growth fastest in nearly 3 years
summary: China's services sector growth accelerated in March, reaching the fastest pace in nearly three years with a 55.1 non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI). This marks the highest reading since May 2014, driven by rising wages allowing consumers to shop, travel, and eat out more. The services sector accounts for over half of China's economy and contributed to its 6.7% growth last year. China's policymakers are counting on growth in services and consumption to rebalance the country's economic model.

site_title: Australia regulator tightens loan curbs to cool home prices
summary: Australia's banking regulator has tightened lending curbs to cool home prices, restricting interest-only loans to 30% of total new residential mortgages. This move aims to curb "quite high" interest-only loans, which account for almost 40% of residential mortgages. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (Apra) says this is "quite high" by international and historic standards, amid concern of a housing bubble. The new restrictions aim to slow down runaway home-price growth and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Apple scores victory over Australian banks in Apple Pay spat
summary: Apple has won a battle with Australian banks over the introduction of Apple Pay, a mobile payments technology. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) upheld its preliminary decision to refuse the banks' request to negotiate collectively, citing concerns that the proposed conduct would reduce competition in the market. The banks, which have invested in their own mobile technology, had hoped to negotiate as a group to boost their bargaining power. The ruling allows Apple to proceed with the introduction of Apple Pay in Australia, where Australians are the world's biggest users of contactless payment technology.

site_title: A global rallying cry is needed for these uncertain times
summary: The UK's official letter to the EU, triggering Brexit negotiations, marks a significant milestone in global progress since World War II. However, the move is seen as a rebuke to the post-war Bretton Woods system and a setback to international cooperation. Fears of economic uncertainty and nationalist sentiment are on the rise, with some politicians seizing on these sentiments to gain political mileage. In response, Singapore's leaders emphasize the need for openness and cooperation, warning against a "world of uncertainties" and urging continued multilateralism to achieve win-win outcomes.

site_title: Xiaomi billionaire CEO is doubling smartphone bet on India
summary: Xiaomi Corp. CEO Lei Jun announced the company is doubling its smartphone bet on India, with an additional investment of $500 million over the next three to five years. This follows a $500 million investment since its debut two years ago. Xiaomi expects to double revenue in India to $2 billion this year and plans to expand its business beyond hardware. The company has seen healthy growth after a challenging few years, with $1 billion in revenue from its mobile apps and services last year. This move aims to rejuvenate the brand, which once ruled China but has been eclipsed by local rivals.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Keppel Corp, Plastoform
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) may explore commercial tie-ups or acquisitions rather than a merger with market operators. Keppel Corp's CEO Loh Chin Hua expressed confidence in the long-term fundamentals of the offshore business sector. Plastoform Holdings faces a material uncertainty due to significant net loss and operating cash flow issues, raising concerns about its ability to remain a going concern.

site_title: AA Reit makes board changes
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) announced changes to its board, effective immediately. Non-executive lead independent director Tan Kai Seng will step down after nine years, and Norman Ip Ka Cheung will succeed him as lead independent director and chairman of the audit, risk and compliance committee. Peter Heng, with over 30 years of investment management experience, has also been appointed as an independent director.

site_title: Boeing renting out 747s to cargo carriers
summary: Boeing is renting out its 747 jumbo jets to cargo carriers in countries such as Russia and Azerbaijan, increasing exposure to potential defaults on payments. The move comes as the Export-Import Bank's shutdown and leasing companies' hesitation to finance the plane have reduced sales. Boeing has provided financing valued at $1.26 billion to 747 customers, with 747-related loans and operating leases accounting for one-quarter of Boeing Capital's portfolio. The strategy may pay off as the air-cargo market recovers, with a recent order from United Parcel Service Inc.

site_title: Oil hits 3-week highs as Opec deal extension seen likely
summary: Oil prices rose for a third day, reaching their highest in three weeks, after Kuwait backed an extension of Opec production cuts to reduce a global glut. Brent crude oil settled at $52.96 a barrel, while US crude oil rose to $50.35 a barrel. Analysts see a significant chance of a short-term bottom, but concerns about the glut remain. Opec has reduced production by 1.2 million barrels per day, and other oil exporters, including Russia, have also reined in output.

site_title: Fed's Dudley says fiscal stimulus outlook shifts risks to upside
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley said the government's fiscal stimulus may boost the economy and potentially lead to higher inflation rates. The outlook has shifted to an upside risk, with Dudley citing a modest economic growth above the sustainable pace and rising inflation closer to the Fed's 2% target. This shift in views may lead to faster interest rate hikes and a reduction in the Fed's $4.5 trillion balance sheet. Dudley favors gradual and predictable reduction of reinvestments to avoid an abrupt rise in long-term interest rates.

site_title: Trudeau looks to make Canada 'world leader' in AI research
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced plans to make the country a "world leader" in artificial intelligence research, investing C$40 million in a new Toronto center and C$50 million from the Ontario provincial government. The Vector Institute, led by renowned cognitive psychologist Geoffrey Hinton, will focus on deep learning and neural networks. Trudeau aims to boost education and research in AI, with a long-term goal of driving breakthroughs and collaborations that can shape industries and create jobs. The move follows a decade of accelerated interest and investment in AI.

site_title: Streaming now makes up most US music industry revenue
summary: US music industry revenue reached $7.7 billion in 2016, with streaming accounting for 51% of the total revenue, up from 9% in 2011. The industry experienced its fastest growth in nearly 20 years, with overall revenue increasing 11.4% from the prior year. However, digital downloads and CD sales declined by 22% and 21% respectively, leading to calls for legal changes to ensure fair compensation for artists. Major record labels hail streaming as a new way to boost the industry, but some artists complain of low earnings.

site_title: Keppel CEO takes 10% base pay cut; total remuneration falls 11.6%
summary: Keppel Corporation's CEO, Loh Chin Hua, took a 10% base pay cut, reducing his monthly base salary to S$1.06 million, and his total remuneration fell 11.6% to S$5.29 million. The company's offshore and marine division faced uncertainties, resulting in a Q4 net loss of S$138 million, but the group as a whole delivered a net profit of S$784 million after impairments for FY16. The pay cut was part of the company's efforts to demonstrate solidarity and maintain a flexible cost structure.

site_title: Trump predicts 'very difficult' China summit
summary: US President Donald Trump predicted a "very difficult" meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping ahead of their summit, citing massive trade deficits and job losses. Trump stated that American companies must be prepared to look at other alternatives. The statement sets an adversarial tone for the meeting, which is scheduled to take place next week.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump predicted an upcoming meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping would be "very difficult" Thursday, laying out an adversarial tone ahead of a high-profile summit.

site_title: For hawkers to go cashless, tax is food for thought
summary: Singapore's weak progress in adopting a cashless society has raised concerns, particularly among hawkers who rely heavily on cash transactions. The country's cash in circulation accounts for 8.8% of GDP, higher than Australia and Sweden. Taxing hawkers to encourage a cashless shift has been proposed, but the issue remains unaddressed. The government's slow pace in implementing a cashless economy has sparked debate about the impact on the city-state's economy and society.

images.alt_text: Singapore's weak progress in going cashless is somewhat mind-boggling, considering the small size of the city-state, and a society that is so plugged into the digital economy.

site_title: Soymeal leads China charge into commodities derivatives
summary: China's Dalian Commodities Exchange is launching a soymeal option, the country's first exchange-traded product of its kind in commodities, worth US$7 billion. The derivatives aim to hedge price swing risks for traders, pig farmers, and soya bean processors. China's growing appetite for commodities and its expanding futures market are driving its push into global investment hub status. The move is seen as a step towards prising open China's long-closed futures markets to foreign investors, with regulators considering reforms.

site_title: Pot business is smoking hot in US, despite Trump
summary: US pot businesses continue to thrive despite President Donald Trump's administration, with hundreds of people visiting medicinal marijuana dispensary Brett Vapnik's in Los Angeles daily. The industry's strength is attributed to its growing popularity and strong demand. However, the impact of the new administration's policies and potential changes in regulations remain uncertain.

site_title: Freed Malaysians arrive home from Pyongyang after Kim row
summary: Nine freed Malaysians, including embassy staff and family members, arrived home in Kuala Lumpur after being held by North Korea following the assassination of Kim Jong-Nam, the half-brother of North Korea's leader. The diplomatic crisis was resolved after Malaysia agreed to send back Kim's body, ending a bitter feud between the two countries. The Malaysians were released after Kuala Lumpur lifted its travel ban on North Koreans, following a deal announced by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and confirmed by North Korean state media.

site_title: Cenovus buys Conoco's Canadian assets for C$17.7b
summary: Cenovus Energy Inc has agreed to purchase ConocoPhillips' Canadian assets for C$17.7 billion, doubling its reserves and output. The deal includes oil sands and conventional assets, and will make Cenovus the third-largest oil-sands producer. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter and will be financed with C$14.1 billion in cash and shares. Cenovus will become Conoco's largest shareholder with a 25% stake, and Conoco plans to use the proceeds to reduce debt and double its share repurchase program.

site_title: Dreamscape where nightmares loom
summary: A Singaporean musical, "Itsy - The Musical," by playwright Chong Tze Chien, received world-class staging and puppetry effects but struggled with a forgettable plot and too many story strands. The musical, about a boy and an evil spider, tackles real-life issues like depression and dementia, but its message becomes lost in the lengthy play. The production features excellent puppetry, costume design, and performances, but the story's muddled nature prevents it from becoming a Singapore theatre classic.

site_title: DAX nears record high as European shares march on
summary: European shares rose 0.5% to nearly 16-month highs, driven by gains in industrials and commodity stocks. Germany's DAX climbed 0.4% to 12,256 points, within 1.1% of its record high. Investors are optimistic about the region's economy, despite political uncertainty ahead of elections in France, Germany, and Britain's EU exit. The Stoxx 600 index reached its highest level in nearly 16 months.

site_title: Lloyd's of London picks Brussels for post-Brexit EU headquarters
summary: Lloyd's of London has announced plans to establish a European Union (EU) hub in Brussels, following the UK's decision to leave the bloc. The office is expected to be operational by early 2019. The move aims to maintain business with European clients and navigate the implications of Brexit. Other companies, such as American International Group and Hiscox, are also considering similar moves to maintain EU presence. The EU hub will enable Lloyd's to continue underwriting insurance business in Europe despite the UK's withdrawal.

site_title: NTUC launches initiative to meet startups' labour needs
summary: NTUC launched its U Startup initiative to support local startups and meet their labor needs. The initiative, introduced last year, provides help in four key areas: business networking, talent attraction, and connections with domain experts and funding partners. NTUC Secretary-General Chan Chun Sing officiated the launch and emphasized the need to support the startup ecosystem and its future workforce. The initiative aims to attract talent, boost startups, and create a win-win situation for both the Labour Movement and the startups.

site_title: Centurion to build student housing in Australia
summary: Centurion Corporation plans to acquire a site in Adelaide, Australia, for A$3.5 million and develop it into a 280-bed student accommodation, dwell Adelaide. The project is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and will be Centurion's second asset in Australia. The company aims to expand its student accommodation business in Australia, with a total of almost 3,500 beds across three tertiary education hubs in Australia, Singapore, and the UK by the end of 2018.

site_title: McDonald's to use fresh beef on some US burgers
summary: McDonald's announced plans to switch from frozen to fresh beef in its US-made-to-order Quarter Pounder hamburgers by mid-2018, a move aimed at boosting sales in the US market. The change follows a successful trial in 400 US restaurants in Texas and Oklahoma, where customers and employees praised the new product. The company, seeking to revamp its offerings, also plans to test other customer-friendly changes such as home delivery and mobile ordering. This shift is seen as a response to rivals like Wendy's, which has already introduced fresh beef burgers.

images.alt_text: McDonald's announced Thursday it will shift to fresh beef in its new made-to-order Quarter Pounder hamburgers in most US restaurants as it seeks to beef up sales in its home market.

site_title: A refreshing effects-driven diversion from reality
summary: Scarlett Johansson stars as The Major, a cyborg law-enforcer, in a live-action remake of the popular manga series Ghost in the Shell. The film, directed by Rupert Sanders, stays true to the original while creating its own identity, featuring a visually-arresting world and impressive action scenes. With nods to films like RoboCop and Blade Runner, the movie follows Major as she pursues a rogue robot and uncovers a deadly secret involving her own origins. Johansson brings her character to life with conviction, making for an entertaining and refreshing effects-driven diversion from reality.

site_title: Beijing confirms Xi meeting Trump in Florida
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will meet US President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago in Florida on April 6-7, marking the first official summit between the two leaders. The meeting aims to address pressing issues such as North Korea, the South China Sea, and trade disputes. The two sides are expected to work together to foster mutual interests and improve trade relations, with Lu Kang, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, stating that "the market dictates that interests between our two countries are structured so that you will always have me and I will always have you."

site_title: SGX files complaint in China for first time against an S-chip boss
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has filed a complaint against China Fibretech's CEO, Wu Xinhua, in China for alleged offences under the Chinese Penal Code. This is the first time SGX has taken such action against an S-chip boss. The complaint was made through lawyers appointed in both Singapore and China, and SGX has also referred the matter to the Singapore authorities. The allegations relate to payments made by China Fibretech to three customers who claimed to have suffered damages and financial losses due to products processed by the company.

site_title: Aussie govt intervenes in sugar row; Wilmar to back down
summary: The Australian government intervened in a sugar row, forcing Singapore-listed miller Wilmar International Ltd to end a two-year dispute with cane growers in Queensland. Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce introduced a mandatory code of conduct requiring millers to allow farmers to choose who sells processed sugar. The move came after growers feared lower prices and a slump in Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government. Wilmar had refused to back down, but ultimately agreed to the new code, with Deputy Prime Minister Joyce saying it was a "win for the little guy against a multinational behemoth."

site_title: Mercedes hastens electric-car shift as combustion era fades
summary: Mercedes-Benz is accelerating its electric-car shift with a 10 billion euro project to release 10 new electric vehicles by 2022, three years ahead of its initial target. The move comes as European buyers turn away from fuel-efficient diesel cars due to a backlash against the technology, sparked by Volkswagen's cheating scandal. Combustion engines will continue to be refined for a "transitional period." Mercedes aims to shape the industry's transformation and remains committed to meeting increasingly stringent emissions rules.

site_title: Fullerton Health issuing US$175m perpetual bond
summary: Fullerton Health, a Singapore-based healthcare solutions provider, has issued a US$175 million perpetual bond to fund bigger acquisitions and expand into new markets. The bond, which received over US$525 million in orders, has a 7% coupon rate and will be used to fund acquisitions in Singapore, Australia, and other fast-growing markets. The issuance is also seen as a step towards diversifying the company's funding structure, with a rated bond and potential initial public offering (IPO) on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: BOA shakes up Merrill Lynch leadership
summary: Bank of America Corp has made significant changes to its Merrill Lynch leadership, reorganizing the unit into six divisions and promoting Mike Adornetto to chief operating officer. The changes, announced by new wealth management chief Andy Sieg, aim to make the business more efficient and client-focused. At least four regional deputies will leave or seek new positions, while several other executives have been granted new or expanded roles. The overhaul is part of Sieg's efforts to improve the organization's performance, following his appointment as head of Merrill Lynch at the start of this year.

site_title: Bellamy's to miss China regulatory deadline
summary: Bellamy's Australia, a leading infant formula maker, will miss the 2018 deadline to register some of its products for sale in China due to a change in ownership at its supplier's manufacturing plant. The affected products account for 14% of Bellamy's total sales, resulting in a 7.5% drop in shares. The company has struggled with regulations in China, where sales have been impacted by a supply glut, leading to a 63% decline in shares since December. Bellamy's has cut its revenue forecast and dumped its CEO.

site_title: Singapore SMEs slightly more optimistic: index
summary: Singapore small-and-medium enterprises (SMEs) have shown a slight improvement in sentiment, with the SBF-DP SME Index rising to 50.4, indicating a state of optimism. Despite lower sales and profit expectations, the index suggests some growth in the next six months. Industry sectors have improved their outlook, with the retail, F&B, and business services sectors expecting turnover growth. Capital investment expectations have also improved, with a focus on boosting productivity through automation and innovation.

site_title: McKinsey, A*Star's ARTC to train workers on Industry 4.0 (Amended)
summary: McKinsey's Digital Capability Centre in Singapore will open in April, focusing on helping local firms adapt to Industry 4.0, a set of emerging technological changes. Industry 4.0 includes increased data availability, AI, advanced human-machine interactions, and 3D printing. The centre, led by McKinsey's South-east Asia managing partner Oliver Tonby, aims to assist local companies in harnessing these changes.

images.alt_text: McKinsey & Company's new Singapore Digital Capability Centre (DCC), opening on April 11, will help local companies harness emerging technological changes - collectively known as Industry 4.0 - that are disrupting industries around the world, according to Oliver Tonby, McKinsey's South-east Asia managing partner.

site_title: For investments into India, focus on five states: Pillai
summary: Singaporean officials recommend investing in five Indian states: Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, and Tamil Nadu, citing their competitiveness and infrastructure development. These states rank among the top 10 most competitive in India, according to an Asia Competitiveness Institute study. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi aims to build 100 smart cities, with Singapore involved in masterplanning Andhra Pradesh's capital city. The country's special envoy to Andhra Pradesh, Gopinath Pillai, is exploring opportunities for Singapore companies to invest in infrastructure and construction.

site_title: US dollar at 2-week high, break of technical barrier prompts euro sales
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high against the euro, breaking a technical barrier at US$1.07, as traders sold euros in response. The euro fell to its lowest level since March 15, while the US dollar index rose to 100.52, its highest level since March 16. This move added to the US dollar's gains against a basket of major currencies, driven by strong US economic data and potential euro zone weakness.

site_title: Toshiba's nuclear woes a hot ticket for Wall Street bankruptcy financiers
summary: Toshiba's nuclear division, Westinghouse Electric Co, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to billions of dollars in cost overruns. The company is seeking $800 million in bankruptcy financing from Apollo Global Management, drawing lenders eager for high yields. Toshiba's shareholders approved splitting off its prized NAND flash memory unit, paving the way for a potential sale of a majority stake. This move underscores the scarcity of "debtor-in-possession" (DIP) loans in the restructuring sector, with only 12 such loans totaling $7.47 billion in 2016.

site_title: RM3b in 1MDB debts cleared over 2 years, says Najib
summary: Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) has cleared over RM3 billion in debt over the past two years, amid ongoing money-laundering probes. The sovereign wealth fund, founded by Najib, is being investigated in several countries for alleged misappropriation of funds. Najib denies all allegations of corruption, claiming that the funds transferred to his personal bank accounts were gifts. The government is expected to call an early general election this year to put the scandal to rest.

site_title: Kim's body to be sent to North Korea; Malaysians freed
summary: Malaysia and North Korea have reached a deal, with the body of Kim Jong-Nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un, to be returned to North Korea. Nine Malaysians barred from leaving Pyongyang will also be allowed to return home. The killing of Kim Jong-Nam with the lethal nerve agent VX in February triggered a bitter row between the two countries, with Malaysia expelling North Korea's ambassador and Malaysia's citizens barred from leaving. Two women have been arrested and charged with the murder, and Malaysia has officially confirmed Kim Jong-Nam's identity using DNA evidence.

images.alt_text: A van believed to be carrying the body of Kim Jong-Nam, half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un, leaving the forensics wing of the Hospital Kuala Lumpur on Thursday. The van headed for Kuala Lumpur International Airport's cargo terminal.

site_title: Homebuyers shrug off Brexit as UK market remains buoyant
summary: The UK real estate market has remained buoyant despite the Brexit referendum, with homebuyers regaining confidence in the market. Prices rose 6.2% in the 12 months to January, outpacing the 1.6% increase in the previous year. Despite predictions of a significant drop, the market has shown no discernible impact from the triggering of Article 50. Research companies, such as Savills and Capital Economics, have revised their forecasts upwards, with some predicting a gentle increase in sales volumes. The market's resilience has been attributed to record-low mortgage rates and a lack of new homes being built to meet demand.

site_title: Q4 GDP revised higher, boosted by consumer spending
summary: US economic growth in the fourth quarter revised higher to 2.1% annualized rate, driven by robust consumer spending and the largest increase in imports in two years. Consumer spending rose at a 3.5% rate, while corporate profits increased at a 2.3% rate. The economy grew at a 3.5% rate in the third quarter. Despite the moderation in economic growth, the labor market remains strong, with initial claims for unemployment benefits falling to 258,000.

images.alt_text: US economic growth slowed less than previously reported in the fourth quarter as robust consumer spending spurred the largest increase in imports in two years.

site_title: Samsung goes big with Galaxy S8 phones
summary: Samsung launched its Galaxy S8 smartphones in Singapore on March 30, 2017, following the ill-fated Samsung Note 7. The new phones feature larger screens, measuring 14.7 cm and 15.7 cm, while remaining thin and lightweight. The launch comes after a year of experience with the previous model.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singaporean companies are under review for potential buys: Mapletree Logistics Trust, with a target price of S$1.28, and CapitaLand, with a target price of S$3.93. Raffles Medical Group is also recommended for a buy with a target price of S$1.70. Analysts expect these companies to benefit from supportive market conditions, acquisition opportunities, and growth in key markets.

site_title: In Julie Wee's Hew, a classic hero rises and falls
summary: Actress Julie Wee shines in the revival of Faith Ng's play Normal, directed by Claire Wong. Wee portrays Miss Hew, a young teacher tasked with uplifting the morale of students in the Normal stream, a track for academically-weak students. As Miss Hew struggles to connect with her students, she faces an incident that puts lives in jeopardy, leading to her downfall. Wee's performance brings nuance and vulnerability to the character, transforming her into a "classically tragic hero." The play's themes of self-esteem, friendship, and the school system's rigidity remain relevant in this revival.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Defending Internet privacy after rule repeal
summary: The US Congress voted to repeal internet privacy regulations, allowing internet service providers (ISPs) to share customers' personal data without consent. Broadband providers argue that they should be able to monetize consumer data like Google and Facebook, citing the value of targeted ads. Consumer-privacy advocates are outraged, citing a lack of opportunity for consumers to abstain from data collection and the fact that ISPs have been tracking and selling customer activity since dial-up days. The repeal may raise awareness about the marketing of personal data by ISPs.

site_title: Amazon plans mass layoffs at parenting products unit after losses
summary: Amazon plans to terminate 263 Quidsi employees in New Jersey this summer as part of a business restructuring due to significant losses. Quidsi, the company's parenting products unit, has struggled financially. The layoffs are part of a broader effort to restructure and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc plans mass layoffs at its money-losing parenting products subsidiary Quidsi as part of a business restructuring, the company said in a document filed with the state of New Jersey on Wednesday.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises, aided by US growth data; Nasdaq ends at record
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, led by financial shares and a stronger-than-expected economic growth report. The Nasdaq Composite closed at a record high, while the S&P 500 gained 0.29% to 2,368.06. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.33% to 20,728.49, driven by a 1.2% surge in financial shares. The energy sector also rose for a third straight day, with ConocoPhillips gaining 8.8%. Investors are looking ahead to the first-quarter earnings season, which is expected to see a 10.1% rise in S&P 500 earnings estimates.

site_title: Black holes in corporate governance ecosystem
summary: The corporate governance ecosystem is plagued by "black holes" - anomalies that hinder effective governance. Key issues include: (1) directors chosen by controlling shareholders being considered independent, (2) nominating committees (NCs) facing conflicts due to all members being incumbent directors, (3) management-controlled boards with a majority of non-independent directors, and (4) remuneration committees (RCs) recommending pay to directors and executives without sufficient shareholder oversight. To address these issues, alternative election processes for independent directors, shareholder-led NCs, and more transparent board assessments are proposed.

site_title: New Hermès timepiece a stopwatch for the soul
summary: Hermès unveiled the Slim d'Hermès L'heure Impatiente, a watch that combines timekeeping with poetic themes, at the Baselworld watch fair. The watch's name, which translates to "Impatient Hour" in French, reflects the passing of time. This unique approach sets it apart as one of the most notable timepieces introduced this year, offering a lyrical take on the traditional watchmaker's job of marking time.

site_title: Chaos and beauty in wall of sound
summary: Veteran Singaporean band The Observatory ended its prolific creative phase with a loud and chaotic farewell concert, "Vibrational," at the University Cultural Centre. The 30-member-strong NUS Guitar Ensemble and NUS Talents joined the band for a sonic assault, with Leslie Low and Dharma conducting on stage. The concert featured songs from their rawest and most experimental albums, "Oscilla" and "August is the Cruellest," and marked the closing show of this year's NUS Arts Festival.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Resurgent Russia joins 'great game' in S Asia
summary: Russia is increasing its presence in South Asia, seeking to counter US influence and establish itself as a power broker in the region. Russia has revamped its South Asia policy, reviving its long-standing relationship with Pakistan and strengthening ties with China. This shift has strained ties with India, a long-time ally of Russia, and has led to a complex web of alliances and rivalries. Russia's efforts to checkmate US influence in the region have sparked concerns about the future of global security, with implications for the entire South Asian region.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to open eight new properties in Mid-East and Africa
summary: Frasers Hospitality Group plans to expand its presence in the Middle East and Africa with eight new properties, including the 396-unit Fraser Suites West Bay Doha in Qatar and properties in Saudi Arabia. The group aims to increase its footprint to over 1,500 units in the two regions, with openings also planned in Nigeria and the Republic of Congo. This expansion is part of Frasers Hospitality's global portfolio of 140 properties, which is expected to reach 23,400 keys by end-2019.

site_title: Domino's will begin using robots to deliver pizzas in Europe
summary: Domino's Pizza will begin using robots to deliver pizzas in Europe, specifically in Germany and the Netherlands, with six-wheeled self-driving delivery robots from Starship Technologies. The robots can carry up to eight pizzas and have a maximum speed of four miles per hour. Domino's formed a group to oversee the project, citing a need for more delivery drivers due to growth plans. The company has tested autonomous vehicles in Australia and New Zealand and previously delivered a pizza by drone in New Zealand.

site_title: China firms' going global gives Singapore major hub role
summary: China firms' going global significantly increased in 2016, with over $225 billion in acquisitions abroad, more than double the 2015 total. This shift from basic resources to brands and technology reflects China's growing focus on catering to an affluent consumer society. Chinese companies are now investing in various sectors, not just infrastructure, providing Singapore with a major hub role in their global expansion.

site_title: Mitigating associated risks from using artificial intelligence
summary: Artificial intelligence is poised to revolutionize businesses, but it also poses significant risks that must be mitigated. A global retail brand saw a 300% ROI increase and 30% customer base growth after adopting an AI platform, but a chatbot's launch was shut down after just 16 hours due to inappropriate comments. To manage AI risks, businesses should consider six steps: setting boundaries and limits, adopting creative testing methodologies, keeping detailed logs and monitoring them, establishing clear process and operational governance, conducting regular performance reviews, and planning for emergency scenarios. By taking these steps, organizations can harness the benefits of AI while minimizing its risks.

site_title: Q1 gains spur hopes of bull market for KL
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur stock market achieved a 6.4% gain in the first quarter, boosting hopes of an impending bull market. Trading volume increased significantly, with a new record of 6 billion shares traded on Monday. Foreign buying has been a major catalyst, with net inflows reaching RM4.7 billion. Analysts attribute the market's improvement to expected stronger earnings growth from corporations and the "Alibaba Effect," which has boosted logistics counters. Market sentiment remains positive, with some predicting the FBM KLCI could breach the 1,800 mark by year end.

site_title: Five new members appointed to Singapore Accountancy Commission (Amended)
summary: The Singapore Accountancy Commission (SAC) has appointed five new members for a two-year term, starting April 1, 2017. The new members include Steven Phan from EY, Magesvaran Suranjan from Procter & Gamble, Pang Yang Hoong from Singapore Management University, Sushil Nair from Drew & Napier, and Ong Khiaw Hong from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority. This appointment aims to enhance the SAC's capabilities and oversight of the accounting profession in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Toyota recalls 2.9m vehicles globally over airbags
summary: Toyota recalls 2.9 million vehicles globally due to potentially faulty airbag inflators made by Takata Corp. The recalls affect vehicles in Japan, China, Oceania, and other regions. At least 16 deaths have been linked to exploding Takata inflators, mainly in the US. The Japanese carmakers are part of a wider recall ordered by global transport authorities last year, with 1.16 million vehicles in Oceania, 750,000 in Japan, and 240,000 in the domestic market. Takata is seeking a financial sponsor to cover recall costs, which total around $1 billion.

site_title: Trump Hotels on the hunt for 2nd Washington DC hotel site: sources
summary: Trump Hotels is exploring a second location in Washington D.C. for its new Scion brand, with over 30 signed letters of intent. The company is considering converting a medium-sized hotel in downtown Washington, and has inquired about purchasing the Beacon Hotel and Corporate Quarters for around $65 million. Trump Hotels' CEO Eric Danziger stated that the company is looking to expand its Scion brand into the nation's capital, aiming to attract travelers seeking less expensive accommodations and a modern design.

site_title: Ackman is 'profoundly' sorry for US$4b Valeant 'mistake'
summary: Bill Ackman, the founder of Pershing Square Holdings Ltd, has apologized for his firm's $4 billion loss on its investment in Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc, calling it a "huge mistake". Ackman blames the investment's downfall on Valeant's overpaying for Salix Pharmaceuticals in 2015 and misjudging the company's management. Ackman acknowledges that he learned lessons, including the importance of flawless capital allocation and operational execution. He now believes that Valeant has been stabilized under its new management and has sufficient resources to recover.

site_title: US judge extends order against Trump travel ban
summary: A US judge has extended a temporary restraining order against President Donald Trump's revised travel ban, turning it into a preliminary injunction with no set expiration date. The order bars the enforcement of the ban in Hawaii, where 20 refugees have been accepted since 2010, and applies to all affected Muslim-majority countries. The US Justice Department plans to appeal to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, while Hawaii's attorney-general praises the ruling, citing reduced uncertainty for residents and travelers.

site_title: Katrina spices up as it partners HK firm
summary: Katrina Group, a Singapore-based F&B operator, has entered into a non-binding agreement with Hong Kong-listed restaurant chain operator Ajisen (China) Holdings. The collaboration aims to open "So Pho" restaurants in Hong Kong and China, with a definitive agreement expected to be finalized by mid-2017. The partnership is expected to increase Katrina's overseas presence and diversify its revenue stream. Shares of Katrina Group rose 11.6% to close at S$0.24 after the announcement.

site_title: China dealmakers leave Wall St for upstarts
summary: Veteran China dealmakers at major Wall Street banks and Western buyout firms are leaving for smaller, more lucrative funds. Three senior bankers from Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, and Lazard have resigned for senior roles at fledgling investment funds, citing higher remuneration and greater independence in decision-making. The moves highlight the challenges big banks face in retaining talent amid tighter regulations and shrinking fees, with smaller funds offering higher internal rates of return and bigger shares of deal fees.

site_title: A generic wartime tale of tears and triumph
summary: The 2017 film "The Zookeeper's Wife" is based on the true story of Antonina Zabinski, a Polish zookeeper who helped hide Warsaw Ghetto's Jews in her zoo during World War II. Alongside her husband Dr. Jan Zabinski, they converted their zoo into a pig farm as a front, smuggling 300 Jews to freedom. The film, directed by Niki Caro, stars Jessica Chastain as Antonina, but lacks dramatic urgency and a sense of suffering, instead focusing on a generic inspirational wartime tale of tears and triumph.

site_title: STI stumbles along with weak Wall Street
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.33 points to 3,173.24 on Thursday, largely due to Jardine Matheson's 2.6% drop. The index had risen 58 points on Tuesday and Wednesday to reach a 19-month high. Traders are cautious of "window-dressing" ahead of the first-quarter end, while OCBC Investment Research maintained a "buy" on CapitaLand, citing its diversified asset portfolio and robust recurring income streams.

site_title: Petronas to be first to export LNG from floating production unit
summary: Malaysia's Petronas is set to export the world's first liquefied natural gas (LNG) produced from a floating production unit, beating rivals such as Royal Dutch Shell. The Petronas Floating LNG Satu (PFLNG Satu) is loading LNG into the Seri Camellia tanker, which will depart within the next day or two, marking a milestone in the use of floating production units. This achievement is expected to save developers billions of dollars.

site_title: iPhone on sale again in Argentina from April
summary: Apple's iPhone will be sold widely in Argentina for the first time in several years starting April, following the removal of regulatory hurdles. The devices will be more expensive due to import taxes, making them at least 25% pricier than locally assembled phones. Carriers will offer iPhones in installments to make them more accessible, despite the higher costs. Apple reseller Hector Goldin expressed happiness about the return of iPhones, which will be sold starting April 7.

site_title: Singtel launches low latency service for enterprises
summary: Singtel has launched a low latency service for enterprises, providing secure, reliable, and high-quality internet connectivity between offices worldwide. The ConnectPlus Optimised Internet Service allows enterprises to access cloud applications up to 10 times faster than conventional internet connectivity. This new service aims to support the growing demands of businesses for fast and reliable internet connectivity.

images.alt_text: ConnectPlus Optimised Internet Service allows enterprises to access cloud applications by up to 10 times faster than conventional Internet connectivity.

site_title: German inflation data pushes euro lower
summary: German inflation data released on Thursday pushed the euro to nine-day lows against the US dollar, amid low readings of 1.2%. This decline follows the collapse of the "Trumpflation" trade and a weaker yen against 111 yen. The euro's drop is also attributed to a struggling dollar, still recovering from recent losses.

images.alt_text: Low readings for German inflation drove the euro back to nine-day lows against the US dollar on Thursday.

site_title: Decent French fare with affordable wine
summary: Ginett Restaurant & Wine Bar in Singapore offers decent French fare at affordable prices, despite unpolished service and a lackadaisical approach to details. The restaurant's bar is popular for its drink deals, but the main dining area can be chaotic. However, the food is surprisingly good, with standout dishes including mussels, pasta carbonara, and lamb chops. A charming French manager helps turn the dining experience around, and the restaurant's rough charm grows on visitors. Rating: 6.5/10.

images.alt_text: La Joue de Boeuf (S$32), nicely gelatinised wagyu beef cheek simmered for 12 hours.
The restaurant interior.
Pan-fried, breadcrumb-coated frog legs with spaghetti (S$30).
Left: Organic Lamb Chop (S$42) which comes with béarnaise sauce. Right: Profiteroles (S$13) filled with homemade pecan ice cream and Lemon Tart (S$8).
Mussels Mariniere (S$30).

site_title: Growth opportunities for SMEs still exist despite challenges, say firms
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in the market, but growth opportunities still exist. Panelists from Sing Lun Holdings and Love Bonito shared their experiences of venturing overseas, citing the US, Europe, and China as key markets. Attracting the right talent and innovating to stay competitive are key to success, according to the SMEs. The Enterprise 50 Awards, recognizing the top 50 most enterprising privately owned local companies, aims to find companies that will set benchmarks and inspire others to rise to the challenge.

site_title: Tokyo extends US$850m in loans to Mongolia as part of bailout deal
summary: Japan has pledged $850 million in loans to Mongolia as part of a $5 billion multilateral and bilateral bailout package to support the country's struggling economy. Japan and South Korea will provide up to $3 billion in aid, while the IMF has agreed to make $440 million available. The bailout aims to restore economic stability and create conditions for strong, sustainable growth, with Mongolia's economy stagnating due to high debt and low foreign-exchange reserves. The package is part of Mongolia's "Third Neighbour" policy, aimed at easing dependence on Russia and China.

site_title: SGX files complaint in China against China Fibretech executive chairman
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has filed complaints with Chinese authorities against Wu Xinhua, executive chairman and CEO of China Fibretech, related to several alleged offences under the Chinese Penal Code. SGX has also referred the matter to Singapore authorities.

site_title: En primeur: Don't ignore lesser vintages
summary: The Bordeaux en primeur campaign, which opens in May, allows buyers to purchase previous year's vintage wine at lower prices, with the advantage of securing allocations to sought-after Châteaux. This system, unique to Bordeaux, raises revenue before the wines are ready for bottling and delivery. While buying en primeur in great vintages is worthwhile, those with lesser vintages can still benefit by buying in smaller quantities, acquiring serial vintages of their favorite Châteaux, and gaining a more comprehensive understanding of the Château's quality.

images.alt_text: Vieux Château Certan 2004 is splendid to drink now. A lovely wine, just the faintest suggestion of brownish tints in the medium-dark red colour, a seductive aroma of black and red berries and a hint of cedar and blackcurrants.

site_title: Indonesia widens crackdown on tax cheats as amnesty closes
summary: Indonesia is cracking down on tax evaders as its tax amnesty program comes to an end. The government has collected about $13.3 billion in revenue and plans to scrutinize credit-card data to identify those who didn't participate. Non-participants could face penalties of up to 200% and heavy fines. The tax amnesty was successful in raising revenue, but repatriations were limited by investment curbs, with Singapore being the top destination for undeclared assets. The government aims to boost tax compliance and increase the tax-to-GDP ratio.

site_title: Two fintech firms slated to launch major IPOs in HK
summary: Two major fintech companies, ZhongAn and Lufax, are expected to launch initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong this year. ZhongAn, China's first online-only insurer, has reportedly denied scrapping its IPO plans despite recent reports suggesting otherwise. Lufax, a key player in peer-to-peer lending and wealth management, has also been tight-lipped about its IPO details. The listings are seen as significant for Hong Kong's fintech sector, with both companies backed by prominent investors such as Ping An, Alibaba, and Tencent. The exact timing and terms of the IPOs remain unclear.

site_title: WeChat aims to expand, win advertisers in Europe, US
summary: WeChat, China's most popular social media and messaging service, is expanding into Europe and the US to develop its payments offering and win new advertisers. The platform aims to encourage Western brands to sell products on WeChat, focusing on business-to-business and targeting high-value brands in the UK, Italy, and other countries. WeChat is courting luxury brands such as Burberry and Chanel, and hopes to tap into the growing market of Chinese tourists visiting Europe. The move is seen as a strategic attempt to compete with global competitors like Facebook and Alipay, and to capitalize on the expected 220 million Chinese tourists traveling overseas by 2025.

site_title: Weekend set to get loud
summary: The Singapore International Jazz Festival (Sing Jazz) kicks off this weekend, featuring 30 hours of music from 180 artists across various genres. Headliners include Corinne Bailey Rae, Esperanza Spalding, and Gilles Peterson. The festival also includes local favorites like Aaron James Lee and Ernesto Enriquez. Additionally, #vinyloftheday, a mobile app for buying and selling vinyl records, launched its marketplace app, and AudioStretch, a music-transcription app, recently won the Best Tools for Schools award. The festival runs until Sunday, with various shows and performances scheduled throughout the weekend.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Musical on Stamford Raffles for SIFA 2019
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) will feature a musical about Stamford Raffles, the founder of Singapore, as part of its 2019 lineup. Festival director Gaurav Kripalani aims to curate works that explore Raffles' life and legacy, given the 2019 centennial of Singapore's founding. Kripalani, who previously worked on award-winning musicals, plans to commission and develop works over a two- to three-year horizon, and has expressed interest in collaborating with renowned artists such as Yukio Ninagawa and Peter Brook.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: CWG to build Suzhou integrated development
summary: CWG International has acquired 60% of Suzhou Xinglun Tourism, owner of the Suzhou Ferris Wheel Theme Park, for 197.18 million yuan (S$40 million). The company will build an integrated development with serviced apartments, premium residential units, and retail space on two plots of land, with expected completion by 2019 and 2021. The acquisition is expected to boost CWG's FY2016 net profit and the company's stock rose 4.7% to S$0.178 on the stock market.

site_title: When the past returns to taunt and threaten
summary: A play "Fundamentally Happy" by Haresh Sharma explores the complex relationships between two Chinese individuals, Habiba and Eric, who have a shared past but keep their true feelings hidden. Eric accuses Habiba's husband of molestation and rape, but Habiba turns the tables, accusing Eric of seducing her husband. The play's director, Nelson Chia, tackles the sensitive topic of paedophilia from multiple perspectives, but the script's cryptic silences and unreliable memories leave the audience questioning the truth, making it a challenging play to direct and perform.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Kim body to be sent to Pyongyang, Malaysians freed: Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that the body of Kim Jong-nam will be sent to Pyongyang, and nine Malaysians detained in connection with the assassination will be released. North Korean citizens in Kuala Lumpur will also be allowed to return home. The decision follows the completion of the autopsy and a request from Kim Jong-nam's family to return his remains to North Korea.

site_title: HK, China: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, ending a two-day winning streak, due to concerns about liquidity. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.37%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.96% and 1.97%, respectively. The declines followed a global trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: China says "no such thing" as man-made islands in South China Sea
summary: China's Defence Ministry denied the existence of man-made islands in the South China Sea, stating that any construction was for civilian purposes. China claims the region, which is also claimed by several other countries, and has built airports, harbours, and other facilities on islands in the Spratly archipelago. The ministry's comments came after a US think tank reported that China had completed major construction of military infrastructure on artificial islands in the South China Sea, which China denies. China claims the islands are its inherent territory.

site_title: WeChat expands in Europe in bid for global advertisers, payments
summary: WeChat, owned by Tencent Holdings, has launched a new bid in Europe and the US to expand its payments offering and win new advertisers. The company aims to establish offices in the UK and another European country, targeting fashion and luxury brands, as well as encouraging Western brands to sell products on the WeChat platform. With over 889 million users in China, WeChat hopes to attract high-profile brands to its platform, leveraging China's growing tourism market, where 220 million Chinese tourists are expected to travel abroad by 2025.

images.alt_text: WeChat, China's most popular social media and messaging service, has launched a new bid in Europe and the US to develop its payments offering and win new advertisers.

site_title: Toshiba execs under fire as loss forecast balloons
summary: Toshiba executives faced criticism from investors after warning of annual losses exceeding $9 billion, primarily due to its troubled US nuclear power unit Westinghouse Electric. The company agreed to sell its prized memory chip business to turn itself around, despite a record annual loss projected at 1.01 trillion yen. The sale was approved by shareholders, but the company's reputation was damaged by previous scandals, including a cover-up of weak results and an unwavering employee loyalty. Toshiba shares jumped 4% following the announcement, but have lost over half their value since December.

site_title: H&M launches new upmarket brand as profits slow
summary: Hennes and Mauritz (H&M) launched its eighth fashion brand, ARKET, amid slowing profits due to tough market conditions in the US and Central Europe. The company reported a 3.4% drop in net profit in the December to February period, with turnover up 8% to 46.98 billion kronor. ARKET, set to launch in the third quarter, will offer more upscale clothing and household products, with the first store opening in London. Despite the new brand launch, H&M's share price dropped 5.7% due to the disappointing profit report.

site_title: The seven year itch
summary: Singaporeans' attraction to investing in property has waned over the past seven years due to successive cooling measures. Despite viewing property ownership as a good discipline for saving and a tangible asset for future generations, many have lost interest. This decline is attributed to the measures, which have made it more challenging for buyers to purchase property. As a result, the "seven year itch" – the initial excitement and desire to invest in property – has largely faded, with many opting for alternative investments.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: The art of living
summary: A new generation of art collectors is redefining the art market with their eclectic tastes and assured confidence. The Business Times' Weekend magazine features a new collection of art aficionados, while exploring various topics including storytelling, retrenchment, and zero-waste living. The magazine also covers lifestyle, entertainment, and business news, with features on Mercedes-Benz, BMW, and the rise of mod-Indian cuisine. The publication provides insights into the lives of successful entrepreneurs and offers advice on various aspects of life, including art, finance, and sustainability.

site_title: US Q4 economic growth revised higher, boosted by consumer spending
summary: US economic growth in the fourth quarter was revised higher to 2.1% from 1.9%, driven by robust consumer spending that rose at a 3.5% annualized rate. Imports surged 9.0% and inventory investment increased, while exports declined, contributing to a 1.82 percentage point trade deficit. The revised growth rate suggests a stronger economy, but the moderate expansion poses a challenge to President Trump's goal of boosting annual growth to 4%.

site_title: Britain to demand tech firms to do more to tackle extremism
summary: Britain will summon tech giants Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Microsoft to demand they take more action against extremism on their platforms, including blocking extremist content and using encrypted messaging services to plan attacks. The move comes after the attacker in the recent British parliament attack sent encrypted messages before the attack. The government wants tech firms to stop offering a "secret place for terrorists to communicate" and urges them to do more to remove extremist material. The US internet giants have agreed to create a shared database to help identify and remove extremist content, but experts warn that backdoors into encrypted systems will weaken security.

site_title: Manhattan developer to build more condos despite slowdown
summary: Manhattan developer Harry Macklowe is shifting his plans for a Wall Street office building from a largely rental conversion to a condo project, despite a slowdown in the market. The building, initially planned for 65% rentals, will now be mostly condos, with the developer investing more equity and taking on less debt. Macklowe attributes the shift to the oversaturated market and the reduced demand for high-end rentals, with prices ranging from $2,000 to $3,000 per square foot. The project will also include retail space and a Whole Foods Market.

site_title: Maiden flight of China-built amphibious aircraft set for May
summary: China's domestically developed AG600, the world's largest amphibious aircraft, is set to make its maiden flight in late May from Zhuhai. Developed by state-owned Aviation Industry Corp of China (Avic) over almost eight years, the aircraft is designed for marine rescues and forest fire battles. It has a maximum flight range of 4,500 km and a maximum take-off weight of 53.5 tonnes, with 17 expressions of interest received so far.

site_title: PetroChina profit plunges 78% to record low
summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil producer, reported a record-low profit of 7.86 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) for 2016, a 78% decline due to global oil price weakness. The company cited a "complicated and severe domestic and international economic environment" and a severe oversupply of refined products. PetroChina expressed caution optimism for 2017 if the global economy recovers. This marks a contrast with Sinopec, another state-owned energy major, which reported a 44% profit rise in 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.16 points to 1,749.25. Volume reached 3.22 billion lots worth RM2.56 billion, with 465 gainers outnumbering 420 losers.

site_title: CWG buys land near Suzhou amusement park to build integrated development
summary: CWG International has acquired 60% of Suzhou Xinglun Tourism, owner of the iconic Suzhou Ferris Wheel Theme Park, for 197.18 million yuan. The acquisition includes two plots of land for an integrated development featuring serviced apartments, residential units, and retail space. The project is situated near the Jinji Lake and within walking distance from the Ferris Wheel Amusement Park. CWG plans to build a 75,797 square-meter integrated development, marking a significant expansion into the tourism sector.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: S i2i, a mobile prepaid card and handset distributor, will hold a dialogue with shareholders in collaboration with the Securities Investors Association (Singapore). The company is on Singapore Exchange's watch-list and may be delisted if the status is not cured by March 2018. Two Swiber Holdings subsidiaries, Swiber International Pte Ltd and Equatoriale Services Pte Ltd, have filed for liquidation. Plastoform Holdings' auditor expressed concerns about the company's ability to remain a going concern due to significant losses and negative cash flow.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) announced plans to extend the Woodlands Checkpoint at the Old Woodlands Town Centre. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange is exploring potential tie-ups as deal-making becomes increasingly challenging. The government also set up a centre for sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific and established a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses. Additionally, Deputy Prime Minister Gan will visit the US for trade talks, and a study suggests Singapore has the opportunity to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: ConocoPhillips jumps on Canada deal; US stocks open flat
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday after ConocoPhillips surged on news of a $13.3 billion deal to sell Canadian oil and gas assets to Cenovus. Analysts describe sentiment as cautious due to uncertainty over President Trump's policy agenda and Brexit negotiations. US growth in the fourth quarter was revised to 2.1%, up from 1.9%. Despite this, stocks continue to rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records, driven by investor optimism.

site_title: Swiber subsidiaries file for liquidation
summary: Two wholly-owned subsidiaries of Swiber Holdings, Swiber International Pte Ltd and Equatoriale Services Pte Ltd, have filed for liquidation. The liquidation commenced on March 27, 2017, as part of efforts to streamline corporate structure and restructure group operations. The appointed provisional liquidators will oversee the liquidation process. The move comes after the subsidiaries were deemed dormant.

images.alt_text: TWO wholly-owned subsidiaries of Swiber Holdings have filed for liquidation.

site_title: 49% of HR managers in Singapore have not hired returning women in past year: survey
summary: In a survey of over 2,200 clients and female professionals in Singapore, 49% of HR managers reported not hiring returning women in the past year. Despite 72% of women in Singapore taking a career break, the lack of hiring opportunities remains a significant issue. Experts emphasize the need for a level-playing field to unlock the full potential of returning women in the workforce.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality expands in Middle East and Africa
summary: Frasers Hospitality Group is expanding its presence in the Middle East and Africa with eight new properties, increasing its units to over 1,500 in the region. The first property, Fraser Suites West Bay in Doha, Qatar, will open soon, followed by properties in Saudi Arabia, including Jeddah, Khobar, and Riyadh. This expansion marks the group's entry into the Saudi Arabian market and its fifth property in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Vibrant subscribes for 31% stake in Chongqing Pucheng Logistics
summary: Vibrant Group and its subsidiaries entered into a joint venture agreement with Chongqing Pucheng Logistics, subscribing for 31% and 20% stakes in the company. The deal values Pucheng at approximately 91.7 million yuan, with a premium of 9.05% over its net asset value. The investment is funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, and is expected to have minimal impact on Vibrant's earnings per share and net asset value for the current financial year.

site_title: Hong Kong Feb retail sales fall 5.7% y-o-y
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales declined 5.7% year-over-year in February, despite a modest recovery in tourist arrivals. This is similar to the fourth quarter of 2016. The government attributes the decline to constrained tourist spending, which will depend on the recovery pace of inbound tourism and external uncertainties. Local consumer sentiment remains favorable due to favorable job and income conditions.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish lower; STI's loss led by Jardine Matheson
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 11.33 points to 3,173.24, led by Jardine Matheson's 2.6% drop to US$64.4. The decline follows a 19-month high reached earlier in the week, partly due to a weak Wall Street performance. Turnover was 3.2 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 233 rises versus 230 falls.

site_title: Petronas to export world's 1st LNG from floating production unit
summary: Malaysia's Petronas is set to export the world's first liquefied natural gas (LNG) from a floating production unit, the Petronas Floating LNG Satu (PFLNG Satu), to South Korea. The facility, estimated to have cost up to $10 billion, beats rival Royal Dutch Shell in a race to develop the technology. This milestone boosts Petronas' credibility as a firm capable of executing cutting-edge projects, but comes as the LNG industry faces an oversupply of new supply, leading to a 70% fall in Asian spot LNG prices.

site_title: UK-EU deal 'in all our interests', May tells European press
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May published columns in seven European papers, stressing that a Brexit deal is "in all our interests." She reiterated that Brexit is not an attempt to harm the EU, but warned that failure to reach a trade deal would harm security ties. May emphasized close cooperation on foreign policy and security matters, including counter-terrorism and global threats. The conciliatory tone aims to strike a balance between the UK's departure from the EU and maintaining strong relationships with its European partners.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead in opening trade
summary: Europe's main stock markets experienced tentative gains on Thursday, following Britain's formal triggering of its EU divorce. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 7,377.40 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 also advanced 0.1% each. Analysts expect markets to become more volatile as Brexit negotiations begin, with the EU exit set for late March 2019.

site_title: Asia's first family office robo adviser platform due for launch
summary: Asia's first licensed robo adviser platform for family offices is set to launch in the third quarter of 2017 by Marvelstone Capital, in partnership with Smartfolios. The platform is regulated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and will provide digital financial advice based on mathematical rules and algorithms. This move aims to cater to the growing demand for online financial services in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares down; Toshiba jumps on chip sale approval
summary: Tokyo shares declined 0.80% due to a 154.26-point drop in the Nikkei 225 index, while the Topix index fell 0.94%. However, Toshiba's shares jumped 5.6% after shareholders approved the sale of its memory chip unit to cover losses from its nuclear business.

site_title: H&M profit beats estimates as retailer unveils new store brand
summary: H&M reported a pretax profit of 3.21 billion kronor (S$504.83 million) in its first quarter, beating analyst estimates. The Swedish retailer's store openings offset higher purchasing costs, primarily due to the strong US dollar and inflation. H&M also unveiled a new store brand, Arket, set to launch in London this fall with online shopping in 18 European markets. The new label will sell clothing and home items at a premium price.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges down on stronger US dollar, stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won ended at a near one-week low on Thursday, closing at 1,117.2 to the US dollar, down 0.3% from the previous day's close. Local shares also dipped, but foreign investors limited losses with continued stock purchases. The decline was attributed to the stronger US dollar.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won ended at a near one-week low on Thursday as gains in the US dollar slightly pressured the local currency.

site_title: Australian shares cheered by households' wealth surge; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose for a third-straight day, driven by a record high in households' net worth, which is expected to boost spending. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4%, its highest close since April 2015. Improving global growth prospects, including a steadying China and US stimulus expectations, also supported the market.

site_title: SpaceX poised to launch first recycled rocket
summary: SpaceX is set to launch its first recycled rocket, a Falcon 9 booster that previously carried supplies to the International Space Station, on Thursday. The rocket will send a Luxembourg-based communications satellite into a distant orbit. The launch aims to demonstrate reusable rocket technology, with SpaceX aiming to slash launch costs by 30%. The company has successfully landed its boosters eight times, including on land and in the ocean, and plans to make rocket parts as reusable as cars or bicycles.

site_title: Hot stock: Katrina surges on tie-up with HK's Ajisen
summary: Katrina Group shares rose 9% on Thursday after the company entered a non-binding MOU with Hong Kong-listed Ajisen (China) Holdings to open "So Pho" restaurants in Hong Kong and China.

site_title: Volkswagen says it has EPA approval to sell repaired diesels
summary: Volkswagen has received EPA approval to sell repaired diesel cars in the US, marking a significant milestone in the company's efforts to recover from the emissions scandal. The 2015 model year diesels will be sold after updating the vehicles' emissions software, with changes to diesel engine hardware also included. The approval is a step towards reviving diesel sales, but it's largely symbolic, as the sales are limited to about 67,000 vehicles. The company has also put aside $24 billion to cover costs and fines related to the scandal.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG will soon do what's been impossible since its emissions crisis began: sell diesel-powered cars in the US.

site_title: Hawaii judge extends order blocking Trump travel ban
summary: US District Judge Derrick Watson has extended his order blocking President Trump's revised travel ban, turning his original temporary restraining order into a preliminary injunction. The Justice Department is expected to appeal the decision. The travel ban, aimed at restricting travel from several predominantly Muslim countries, was initially put on hold by Watson in March 2017.

site_title: ICA to extend Woodlands Checkpoint
summary: The Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) plans to extend the Woodlands Checkpoint at the Old Woodlands Town Centre to meet growing traffic needs and ensure immigration clearance remains secure. Two private land lots within the town centre will need to be acquired, with the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) working closely with affected owners and tenants. The acquisition process is expected to proceed smoothly, with the ICA aiming to upgrade the checkpoint and improve immigration clearance.

site_title: GSK's new CEO gets short-term win from generic Advair delay
summary: GlaxoSmithKline's new CEO Emma Walmsley has won a short-term reprieve from generic Advair with a delay in US approval for Mylan's copy of the blockbuster lung inhaler. Mylan received a complete response letter from the FDA, potentially pushing back approval by up to two years. However, analysts believe generic Advair is likely to be introduced in the US market in the near future, and the delay is seen as a short-term cash-flow benefit to GSK. The company had forecast a decline in Advair's US sales if generics arrive by mid-2017, but maintains its leadership position in lung disorder treatments.

site_title: China's Xi will meet Trump in US April 6-7
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will meet US President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago in Florida from April 6 to 7. The meeting comes after a rocky start to US-China relations, with Trump criticizing Beijing's trade policies and North Korea's nuclear program. The visit is seen as crucial in setting the tone for the relationship between the world's two largest economies. Diplomatic sources say the meetings will focus on getting to know each other, with tough issues reserved for future talks, and may include economic gift-giving and strategic discussions.

site_title: Broker's take: Wilmar's sugar mills hit by Cyclone Debbie in Queensland, says DBS
summary: Wilmar International's sugar mills in Queensland, Australia, were severely impacted by Cyclone Debbie, according to a DBS Group research report. The cyclone's path led to a drop in sugar production, with pre-tax contribution from sugar milling expected to be minimal. DBS has maintained its forecasts, but warns of potential damage to the mills, which could take time to repair. The brokerage has a "hold" rating and a target price of S$3.90 on the stock.

site_title: iPhone is legit again after years on Argentina's gray market
summary: Apple's iPhone will be sold widely in Argentina for the first time in several years, starting April 7, after President Mauricio Macri lifted regulatory hurdles to import the device. The phone will be available through carriers and can be paid for in installments, making it more accessible. However, the devices will be at least 25% more expensive due to import taxes. Local reseller Hector Goldin expressed excitement, saying he's already receiving new iPhones and has reservations from clients.

site_title: Saudi Aramco formally appoints banks to advise on share sale
summary: Saudi Aramco has formally appointed JPMorgan Chase & Co, Morgan Stanley, and HSBC as international financial advisers for its initial public offering, aiming to sell up to 5% of shares to raise cash for diversifying away from oil exports. The Saudi authorities plan to list shares in Riyadh and at least one foreign exchange.

site_title: Updated: Samsung goes big with Galaxy S8 phones
summary: Samsung unveiled the Galaxy S8 and S8+ phones in Singapore, featuring larger screens, curved displays, and thin designs. The phones boast 10nm processors, 4GB RAM, and 64GB internal storage, with options for expanding memory. Samsung's Bixby personal assistant makes its debut, offering voice, touch, and text commands. The phones also feature facial recognition, iris scanners, and water resistance. The launch comes after last year's Note 7 recall, and the S8 phones will be available on April 29, 2017, starting at $1,148.
