images.alt_text: AFTER the ill-fated introduction of Samsung Note 7 last year, which cost the company US$5.48 billion of profit according to Reuters, Samsung launched the Galaxy S8 in Singapore on Thursday.

site_title: Train derailment in northern India injures 25
summary: A train derailment in northern India's Uttar Pradesh state injured 25 people when eight carriages of the Mahakoshal Express derailed at 2am on Thursday. Rescue operations are underway, with a disaster management team rushed to the scene. The cause of the derailment remains unknown, with police investigating whether it was an accident or a planned attack. This incident is the latest in a series of railway accidents in India, which have resulted in 27,581 railway deaths in 2014, with most victims falling from or being struck by moving trains.

site_title: New president to take charge at ST Kinetics from April 1
summary: ST Kinetics president-designate Lee Shiang Long will take charge from April 1, replacing Ravinder Singh, who will remain as president of ST Electronics. Lee joined ST Kinetics in March 2016, bringing expertise from the Institute of Infocomm Research, where he focused on research and innovation for Singapore's Smart Nation ambitions. He holds degrees from Cambridge University, Nanyang Technological University, and the National University of Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia to widen crackdown on tax cheats as amnesty closes
summary: Indonesia is cracking down on tax cheats as its tax amnesty program comes to an end. Authorities plan to scrutinize credit-card data to identify those who evaded taxes, with penalties of up to 200% for large taxpayers. The program, which closed on Friday, raised about $13.11 billion in revenue, exceeding its goal. Singapore was the top destination for undeclared assets, with Singaporeans stashing $13.11 billion. The government aims to boost revenue to fund infrastructure projects, with tax compliance remaining a low priority for the country.

site_title: Toyota recalls 2.9m vehicles globally over airbags
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is recalling approximately 2.9 million vehicles globally due to potentially faulty airbag inflators made by Takata Corp. The recalls affect vehicles in Japan, China, Oceania, and other regions, including the Corolla Axio sedan and RAV4 SUV crossover. At least 16 deaths have been linked to exploding Takata inflators. The Japanese automakers are part of a wider recall ordered by global transport authorities, which also includes 240,000 vehicles from Fuji Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Motors, and Hino Motors.

site_title: Japan looks to curb 23.3t yen spent on pachinko gambling
summary: Japan is considering restrictions on pachinko parlours and other gambling establishments to tackle addiction ahead of the legalization of casino resorts. The government plans to restrict individual access to pachinko on request of relatives and regulate the machines to make them less addictive. Other measures include banning credit-card machines that offer instant cash loans and setting up an independent body to oversee progress. The goal is to ensure the long-term survival of the industry, despite potential short-term costs.

site_title: Stylish dogs rule the catwalks of Shanghai's streets
summary: In Shanghai, pet owners frequently dress their dogs in fashionable outfits, making the city's sidewalks resemble catwalks. At least 40% of pet merchants sell dog clothing, contributing to China's massive pet industry, valued at around $17 billion annually. The industry is expected to grow 20% annually, driven by millennials with increasing consumer power. For some, pet ownership serves as an escape from interpersonal relationships, and dog ownership rates have risen with China's growing middle class, with an estimated one million pets in Shanghai.

images.alt_text: Poodles in pink dresses, Pekinese wearing blouses, a Pomeranian in sneakers and a raincoat - Shanghai's sidewalks can sometimes seem like fashion catwalks gone to the dogs.

site_title: Hong Kong activists appear in court
summary: Nine Hong Kong democracy activists appeared in court Thursday, charged in connection with the Umbrella Movement mass protests. The group, including students and lawmakers, criticized the case as political persecution, coming amid concerns that Hong Kong's freedoms are under threat from Chinese authorities. The charges follow Carrie Lam's selection as city leader, which many see as a pro-Beijing move. The activists' case is the latest in a series of crackdowns on dissent in Hong Kong, raising fears about the city's autonomy and democratic freedoms.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 0.13 points to 3,184.44. The US markets closed with a mixed session, and 87.9 million shares worth S$100 million changed hands. The STI had previously risen 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Australians sitting on mountains of cash as wealth outpaces debt
summary: Australian households' wealth reached a record A$11.7 trillion in the last quarter, driven by a 3.6% increase in net worth and a A$247 billion rise in home and land values. This surge in wealth is expected to boost spending despite stagnant wages growth. The country's GDP is A$1.7 trillion.

site_title: Scoot flight 'came into contact' with Emirates plane at Changi Airport
summary: A Scoot flight, TZ188, had to be returned to bay after its left wing came into contact with an Emirates plane at Changi Airport in Singapore on Thursday. The flight was taxiing before take-off, heading to Tianjin, and all 303 guests on board are safe. The incident occurred when Scoot flight TZ188 made contact with the Emirates plane.

site_title: Singapore Exchange said to mull tie-ups as deals grow harder
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering potential tie-ups with overseas exchange operators, including Nasdaq and CME Group, amid industry consolidation. SGX has held exploratory talks, ranging from collaborations to mergers or stake sales, but no formal decisions have been made. Regulators' scrutiny of cross-border deals has complicated an outright sale, but partnering with or acquiring a stake in SGX could strengthen a US or European exchange's presence in Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange, which runs Southeast Asia's largest stock and derivatives market, has in recent months held exploratory talks about possible tie-ups with overseas exchange operators, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Najib says 1MDB has cleared 3b ringgit in debts
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that the state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad has cleared over 3 billion ringgit (S$948.15 million) in debt over the past two years. This comes as the fund faces ongoing money-laundering probes in at least six countries. Najib denied allegations of corruption, stating that most funds transferred to his personal bank account were gifted by a Saudi royal family member and returned. The government is expected to call an early general election this year to put the scandal to rest.

site_title: Seoul: Won weakens; Samsung Electronics up 1% after Galaxy S8 launch
summary: The South Korean won declined 0.1% to 1,115.9 against the US dollar, driven by rising oil prices supporting emerging market currencies. Despite this, offshore investors remained net buyers of Kospi shares for the fourth straight session. Tech giant Samsung Electronics rose 1% after launching its Galaxy S8 smartphone, while SK Innovation increased 1.8% following the global oil price rise. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.3% to 2,161.33 points.

site_title: Australian dollar at 1-week high, NZ dollar stuck in range
summary: The Australian dollar reached a one-week high of US$0.7676, driven by foreign funds flowing into the equity market and a bounce in commodity prices. The New Zealand dollar remained in a range. Technical analysts see chart resistance around the current levels and strong support at 76 US cents. The Australian share market surged to a near two-year high, rising for a third straight session. Currency strategist Rodrigo Catrill attributed the Aussie's positive trend to recent equity flows and commodity price increases.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar hit a one-week high on Thursday after two straight winning sessions, in part led by foreign funds flowing into the equity market and a bounce in commodity prices.

site_title: Big China banks cut bad loans as profits beat forecasts
summary: China's two largest banks, China Construction Bank and Agricultural Bank of China, cut their bad-loan ratios, with Construction Bank's ratio falling to 1.52% and Agricultural Bank's to 2.37%, beating forecasts and indicating the banking industry may withstand slowing economic growth. The banks' improved profits also came from reduced expenses, while analysts note that tighter regulations and liquidity conditions will help stabilize asset quality. The results may signal an earlier-than-expected stabilization in bad-loan formation and potentially lead to higher dividend payouts for the banks.

site_title: Unilever, Lazada sign deal to tackle online sales in region
summary: Unilever and Lazada Group signed a deal to build the region's first "end-to-end" e-commerce alliance, aiming to boost growth in Southeast Asia by 2020. The partnership will focus on category development, supply chain, data, marketing, social commerce, and talent development. Unilever will work closely with Lazada on innovative solutions to tackle online sales challenges in the region, including high delivery costs. This alliance builds on Unilever's recently launched exclusive store on Lazada Singapore. The partnership is expected to drive significant growth in the region through 2020.

site_title: Philippine lawmaker pushes for Duterte impeachment over 'defeatist' China stance
summary: A Philippine lawmaker, Gary Alejano, has filed supplementary charges against President Rodrigo Duterte, accusing him of taking a "defeatist stance" by failing to challenge China's activities in the South China Sea. Alejano claims Duterte's inaction proves he has no intention to protect Philippine sovereignty and has alienated key allies. The complaint adds to a list of alleged impeachable offenses, including abuse of power and betrayal of public trust. Duterte's recent charm offensive to encourage China to invest in the Philippines has contrasted sharply with his open hostility towards the US.

site_title: South Korea's ousted president Park appears in court
summary: South Korea's ousted President Park Geun Hye appeared in court for a hearing on whether to arrest her over corruption and abuse of power allegations. Park, who was impeached by parliament in December, faces charges including bribery, leaking government information, and abuse of power. Prosecutors have submitted 120,000 pages of documents against her, and if arrested, she would become the third former Asian leader to be arrested on corruption charges. A decision is expected by the end of the day.

site_title: Australia shares up for third day helped by materials, energy stocks; NZ higher
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to 5,898.1, its third consecutive gain, driven by gains in basic materials and energy stocks. Commodity and oil prices contributed to the increase, with miners such as Fortescue Metals Group and Rio Tinto rising 2% and 1.3%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.3% for the third session.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up, oil gains boost energy firms
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.15% on Thursday, extending gains from the previous two days, driven by energy firms boosted by a rally in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index rose 37.07 points to 24,429.12, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.21%. The gains come despite uncertainty from US trade policies, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Australia job vacancies rise again, highest since mid-2011
summary: Job vacancies in Australia rose for the third consecutive quarter to 185,600 in the December-February period, the highest since May 2011. This represents a 1.8% increase from the previous quarter and a 7.3% rise from the same period in 2016. Private sector vacancies climbed 1.5% to 167,500, while public sector vacancies rose 4% to 18,100, the highest since 2009. Analysts value the vacancies series as a reliable leading indicator of labour demand and turning points in employment growth.

site_title: Centurion to build student housing in Australia for A$45.5m
summary: Centurion Corporation plans to acquire a site in Adelaide, Australia, for A$3.5 million and develop a 280-bed student accommodation for A$45.5 million. The project, expected to be completed in 2018, will cater to the 2019 academic year and mark Centurion's second asset in Australia. The site is located near the University of Adelaide and Rundle Mall shopping strip, within walking distance to several universities.

site_title: South Korea department, discount store sales fall in Feb on holiday distortion
summary: South Korea's department and discount store sales in February declined due to distortions from the Lunar New Year holiday. Department store sales fell 1.3% from last year, while discount store sales plummeted 19.5%, the largest drop since 2014. The holiday's timing this year and in 2015 led to data distortions. Despite this, demand for women's apparel and luxury products at department stores offset declines, while sales for all categories fell at discount stores.

site_title: Australian government intervenes in Wilmar sugar row
summary: The Australian government has intervened in a long-standing dispute between sugar growers in Queensland and Singapore-listed miller Wilmar International Ltd. Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce announced a mandatory code of conduct forcing Wilmar to allow farmers to choose their marketer, effectively ending the two-year dispute. The move comes as growers face pressure from the government and cyclone damage, with hundreds of hectares of sugarcane crops flattened. The intervention is seen as a win for small growers against the multinational company, with one lawmaker praising the move as a "long drawn-out battle" won by the little guy.

site_title: China said to push talks to create 1.66t yuan power giant
summary: China's state-owned enterprise regulator has asked coal mining giant Shenhua Group Corp and power generator China Datang Corp to discuss a possible merger. The potential deal would create a utility giant with approximately 1.66 trillion yuan in assets. The merger would align with China's supply-side reform policies and help reduce the nation's industrial overcapacity. A successful merger could also serve as a model for China's coal and power industry reforms, maintaining reasonable profits in various circumstances.

site_title: Brazil enacts bigger-than-expected spending freeze to meet fiscal goal
summary: Brazil's government has enacted a spending freeze of 42.1 billion reais (S$18.8 billion) to meet its fiscal deficit target, exceeding initial expectations. The freeze, combined with minimal tax hikes, aims to regain the country's investment-grade rating. The decision was made despite pressure to adopt pro-growth reforms to snap the economy out of a deep recession. The freeze will impact dozens of sectors, including urban passenger transportation companies, while tax breaks for big employers will be maintained. The measure needs congressional approval to become effective.

site_title: BofA shakes up Merrill Lynch leadership under new chief Sieg
summary: Bank of America's new wealth management chief, Andy Sieg, has announced a leadership shakeup at Merrill Lynch, cutting divisions from 10 to 6. Mike Adornetto is promoted to COO, while at least four regional deputies will leave or seek new positions. The reorganization aims to make the business more efficient and client-focused. Sieg, 49, has over 20 years of experience and has already implemented changes, including clearer fee disclosure. The move is part of a broader effort to improve the firm's performance, which saw 7.9% growth last year.

site_title: Oil stable on falling Libyan output, but bloated US market still weighs
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Thursday, supported by falling Libyan crude output and declining US gasoline stocks, but bloated US inventories still weighed on markets. Libyan oil output fell to about 500,000 barrels per day, while US crude inventories rose to a record 534 million barrels. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) aims to cut output by almost 1.8 million barrels per day during the first half of the year, with compliance expected to be 95% this month, but non-Opec members, including Russia, have been questioned on their commitment to cuts.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after Toshiba warns of huge loss
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on March 30, 2017, after Toshiba warned of a potential US$9 billion annual net loss, mainly due to its nuclear business. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.35% and the Topix slipped 0.30% in the first few minutes of trading. The losses followed a decline in New York markets.

site_title: Canada seeks more trade with post-Brexit Britain: Trudeau
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has assured that the country will seek to bolster trade with post-Brexit Britain, calling the UK a "friend and ally and economic partner". Trudeau expressed a desire to create closer trade ties and opportunities for better jobs and economic growth that benefits both countries. Canada will engage with the UK as they navigate their transition out of the European Union.

site_title: Waymo took legal action against engineer before suing Uber
summary: Waymo, a self-driving unit of Alphabet Inc, took legal action against former engineer Anthony Levandowski in private arbitration, alleging he betrayed the company and stole trade secrets before suing Uber for theft. Levandowski, now head of Uber's self-driving division, was accused of downloading 14,000 confidential files before resigning in 2016. Waymo sued Uber and Otto, a self-driving startup formed by Levandowski, over patent infringement and trade-secret theft claims, with Uber seeking to move the allegations into arbitration. The case intensifies Alphabet's rivalry with Uber and reflects a talent war in the autonomous-driving arena.

site_title: Two Fed officials signal possible need for faster rate-hike path
summary: Two Federal Reserve officials, Eric Rosengren and John Williams, signaled the possible need for a faster pace of interest-rate increases than initially mapped out by the US central bank. Rosengren argued for four hikes in 2017 to guard against economic overheating, while Williams suggested up to three increases total. This stance contrasts with the median estimate of three quarter-point rate increases in 2017 and may influence the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee.

site_title: S i2i to hold talk with shareholders
summary: S i2i Ltd will hold a dialogue session with shareholders on April 3, in collaboration with SIAS, amid pressure from activist Blue Ocean Capital to present a plan to exit the regulator's watchlist. The company faces a deadline of March 2018 to remove itself from the list. Shareholders have suggested an orderly winding down of the company via asset disposals and a board revamp, with Blue Ocean Capital proposing a voluntary general offer by majority owner and chairman Bhupendra Kumar Modi.

site_title: Mexican president says seeking 'new relationship' with US
summary: Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto announced a "new relationship" with the US, amid strained relations due to US President Donald Trump's anti-immigration policies and commitment to build a border wall. The two countries have a $60 billion trade surplus, with Mexico relying on US exports. Pena Nieto expressed optimism about reaching a positive understanding, while leaders from Central America and Colombia also discussed regional cooperation and challenges, including climate change and migration flows.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Centurion, S i2i, Raffles Education
summary: Centurion Corporation plans to acquire a site in Adelaide, Australia for A$3.5 million to develop a new 280-bed student accommodation, with a total development cost of A$45.5 million. S i2i Ltd will hold a dialogue session with shareholders to address concerns about being removed from the regulator's watch-list. Raffles Education has had a deal to acquire a US university terminated, citing unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Tiny Florida city faces big housing shortage
summary: Apalachicola, Florida, a small Gulf Coast city, faces a significant housing shortage with 28% of residents paying 40% or more of their income for housing. A proposed multifamily development, Denton Cove, has been met with resistance due to concerns over gentrification and displacement of low-income residents. Instead, local residents are advocating for a plan to train job-seeking residents in home construction through the rehabilitation of historic shotgun homes, which are historically significant and a part of the city's architectural legacy.

images.alt_text: Mr Brown (above) devised the plan to rehabilitate the abandoned cottages. Mr Simmons and his remodelled shotgun home.
Mr Brown devised the plan to rehabilitate the abandoned cottages. Mr Simmons (above) and his remodelled shotgun home.

site_title: Battle lines drawn for tough Brexit talks: analysts
summary: Britain has begun Brexit talks with the EU, sparking a two-year process that analysts predict will be "very bumpy." The UK's Prime Minister Theresa May has called for parallel talks on the terms of the divorce and future relationship, but EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, are insisting on determining Britain's exit before discussing a new relationship. Key issues include the UK's multi-billion-euro exit bill, European citizens' rights, and the border in Northern Ireland. Analysts warn that finding a good Brexit deal will be challenging, with potential flashpoints on security cooperation and trade agreements.

site_title: Malaysia in 'sensitive' talks with North Korea after Kim murder: PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak announced "very sensitive" talks with North Korea regarding nine Malaysians stranded in Pyongyang after the assassination of Kim Jong-Nam, a half brother of North Korea's leader. The assassinated Kim was poisoned at Kuala Lumpur airport on February 13, damaging bilateral ties. Three Malaysian embassy staff and six family members remain in North Korea, barred from leaving after both countries recalled their ambassadors. The talks aim to resolve the situation and secure the release of the stranded Malaysians.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak said Wednesday his government was engaged in "very sensitive" talks with North Korea over nine Malaysians being prevented from leaving Pyongyang after the assassination of Kim Jong-Nam

site_title: Oscars keep accountants behind best picture fiasco
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has decided to continue working with accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) despite the biggest mix-up in Oscars history. PwC took responsibility for the error, which saw the wrong movie announced as best picture, and has implemented new measures to avoid similar mistakes. The company's accountants, Brian Cullinan and Martha Ruiz, will not return, and electronic devices will be banned backstage. The Academy has also added "improvements to onstage envelope category verification" and will participate in rehearsals next year.

site_title: Ivanka Trump takes unpaid job as White House adviser
summary: Ivanka Trump, the first daughter of US President Donald Trump, will take on an unpaid role as a White House adviser, joining her husband Jared Kushner as an unpaid senior aide. The announcement was made by the White House, stating that Ivanka's choice is in support of the president.

site_title: Iata criticises laptop ban on planes, calls for alternatives
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has criticized the US and UK's laptop ban on planes, calling it an unacceptable long-term solution to mitigate a potential threat. The ban, which affects flights from certain airports, has created commercial distortions and concerns about effectiveness. Airlines are exploring alternative solutions, such as loaning passengers government-approved laptops or providing free Wi-Fi. IATA's director-general, Alexandre de Juniac, emphasized the need for better information sharing and coordination on security measures among governments and the industry to effectively prevent terrorism.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US diplomat arrested over contacts with Chinese spies
summary: US diplomat Candace Marie Claiborne, 60, was arrested and charged with lying to investigators over contacts with Chinese spies. She allegedly took tens of thousands of dollars in cash and gifts from Chinese intelligence agents in exchange for US secrets. Claiborne, a State Department office management specialist, had significant financial problems and used her position to share sensitive diplomatic data for personal profit. She pleaded not guilty in her first court appearance. The charges include obstructing the investigation and lying to agents, and the Department of State called the offenses a breach of the public trust.

site_title: London real estate targeted by fund running Lego wealth
summary: A US$12 billion fund managed by the billionaire family behind Lego A/S plans to invest more in London's real estate market, betting that Britain's departure from the EU will make it more accessible. The fund has almost US$1 billion in its existing real estate portfolio, and CEO Soren Thorup Sorensen sees opportunities for attractive prices due to Brexit-related uncertainty. Other institutional investors have also taken an opportunistic approach to London's property market following Brexit.

site_title: Amazon shutting down unprofitable Quidsi unit
summary: Amazon is shutting down its Quidsi unit, which operates Diapers.com and Soap.com, due to persistent lack of profitability. Quidsi was an Amazon rival before the online retailer acquired it in 2010 for $545 million. Despite efforts, Quidsi failed to turn a profit, and its software development team will focus on AmazonFresh, a grocery shopping platform. The move follows Quidsi co-founder Marc Lore's creation of Jet.com, which was bought by Walmart for $3 billion in 2024.

images.alt_text: Amazon on Wednesday confirmed that it is shutting down its Quidsi unit, which runs websites Diapers.com and Soap.com, due to a persistent lack of profitability there.

site_title: US: Energy, consumer shares lift S&P 500 to slight gain
summary: The S&P 500 rose slightly, driven by gains in the energy and consumer sectors, despite declines in financial shares. The benchmark index ended at 2,361.13, supported by stronger oil prices and a 2.1% surge in Amazon.com. Investors are awaiting first-quarter earnings to support lofty valuations, with earnings expected to rise 10.1% according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. Despite concerns over tax reform and interest rate hikes, economic data remains solid, with the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike expectations increasing.

site_title: US dollar rises after Trump selloff, helped by Fed comments, ECB report
summary: The US dollar rose to its highest in over a week against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, driven by European Central Bank comments and a report that policymakers were wary of changing their policy message. The euro fell to its lowest since March 21, boosting the US dollar index to 100.130. Chicago Fed President Charles Evans' comments supporting further interest rate hikes this year also contributed to the dollar's gain. Analysts say the initial selloff in the dollar was an overreaction, and the underlying faith in the reflation trade is returning.

site_title: Spain to host southern EU leaders Brexit meeting
summary: Spain will host a gathering of southern European Union leaders on April 10 to discuss the Brexit negotiations. The meeting will include Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy and leaders from France, Italy, Portugal, Greece, Cyprus, and Malta. The event aims to forge a common front on Brexit challenges and counter the influence of northern European nations. This is the third meeting of the group, following gatherings in Athens and Lisbon.

images.alt_text: Spain will host a gathering of southern European Union nations on April 10 to discuss Britain's negotiations to leave the bloc, the Spanish government said Wednesday.

site_title: Cyclical markets likely to do better over next 6 months: asset manager
summary: A Hong Kong-based asset manager, Sean Taylor, predicts that cyclical markets, including Singapore's banks, may perform well over the next six months. Despite being underweight on the Singapore market, Taylor is more positive on banks due to their potential for growth. However, he notes that Singapore is a lower-growth market compared to other Asian markets.

site_title: Jackie Kennedy's intimate letters with UK diplomat sold at auction
summary: Jackie Kennedy's intimate letters to British diplomat David Ormsby Gore, written in 1968, were sold at a London auction for £100,000. The letters, part of a larger cache of papers, reveal her reasons for rejecting his marriage proposal years after her husband's assassination. Kennedy explained that she couldn't marry due to her past losses and her desire to move on. The letters also show her deep affection and respect for Ormsby Gore, whom she considered a "beloved brother" and mentor. The sale of the letters highlights the enduring bond between Kennedy and Ormsby Gore.

site_title: EtonHouse invests S$110m in China campus project
summary: EtonHouse International Education Group is investing S$110 million in its largest campus project in Deyang, Sichuan, China, to accommodate 5,000 students. The project, expected to be completed in five years, will feature three campuses. Founded by Ng Gim Choo, the company aims to cater to the growing demand for high-quality education in China, particularly in tier 2 and 3 cities. The project includes standalone kindergarten, primary and secondary school campuses, as well as residential facilities and a teacher training center.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise in "relaxed" reaction to Brexit day
summary: European shares rose 0.4% to 378.5 points, their highest level in nearly 16 months, in a "relaxed" reaction to Britain's formal announcement of leaving the European Union. Despite concerns about Brexit's impact, economists predicted fluctuations but no sudden market downturns. German stocks, particularly automotive and merger talks, also showed gains, while banks underperformed. The Stoxx 600 index consolidation followed brightening economic prospects in the region after years of sluggish growth.

site_title: China biggest offender in surge of counterfeit ICT goods, says OECD
summary: China is the primary source of counterfeit ICT goods, with nearly one in five mobile phones and one in four video-game consoles being fake, according to a report by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The estimated annual value of global trade in counterfeit ICT goods is US$143 billion, with 6.5% of global trade in ICT goods being in counterfeit products. Counterfeit goods pose risks to consumer trust, health, and safety, as well as eroding brand value and lost revenue for manufacturers.

site_title: Melania Trump makes case for women's 'empowerment'
summary: First Lady Melania Trump emphasized women's empowerment at a US State Department ceremony honoring 13 women activists who fought for human rights despite facing great odds. She called for diversity, challenging old fears and standing up against injustice. Trump's vocal support appears to contrast with her husband's administration's "America first" worldview, which has often viewed outsiders as a threat. The event highlighted the work of women like Sharmin Akter, who defied her family's plan to marry her at 15, and Sister Carolin Tahhan Fachakh, who runs a nursery school and tailoring workshop in war-torn Syria.

site_title: Australia and China find common ground on trade
summary: Australia and China have found common ground on trade during Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's recent visit, with both countries rejecting "America First" protectionism and advocating for free trade. However, the two nations differ on security and extradition issues, with Australia maintaining its security alliance with the US and resisting China's push for a One Belt One Road (OBOR) infrastructure initiative. Despite this, China has offered to lift restrictions on chilled beef exports, a valuable gift to Australia, and the two countries have agreed to deepen economic ties.

images.alt_text: Australian premier Malcolm Turnbull with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang at Parliament House in Canberra last Friday.

site_title: Ford plans to invest US$1.2b in US facilities
summary: Ford plans to invest $1.2 billion in US facilities, primarily to upgrade its assembly plant in Wayne, Michigan, to build new Ranger pickup and Bronco SUV models. The decision is driven by competitive pressures to keep pace with the surging market for trucks and SUVs, rather than economic policies. The investments are in line with the industry's shift towards larger, more utilitarian vehicles, with three out of five new vehicles sold in the US being trucks and SUVs.

site_title: Muslims plan rally against Jakarta governor on Friday
summary: Indonesian Muslims plan to hold a rally against Jakarta's Christian governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, on Friday, calling for his impeachment due to suspected blasphemy. The rally, expected to draw 20,000 participants, comes ahead of the April 19 election, where Purnama is running against a Muslim candidate. The event is part of a series of protests testing Indonesia's religious and ethnic tolerance, with many Muslims believing Purnama insulted Islam with his comments on the Quran last year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International upgraded to "hold" by UOB Kay Hian Research due to recent share price weakness, citing weakening commodity prices. The company's core businesses are expected to grow steadily in 2017. Avi-Tech Electronics initiated with a "buy" rating and target price of S$0.52, citing stable year-on-year net profit growth and undemanding valuation. Ezion Holdings maintained an "add" rating and target price of S$0.45, following the acquisition of a 50% stake in a joint venture.

site_title: Big four Aussie banks still face risks: Fitch
summary: Australia's "Big Four" banks have raised home loan interest rates to help cool lending growth, but still face risks due to high household debt and an overheated property sector. Despite the Reserve Bank of Australia keeping the cash rate low, banks have implemented out-of-cycle rate hikes. Fitch Ratings attributes these actions to potential APRA regulation and increased funding costs from US interest rate hikes. The banks' stable AA-minus ratings remain, but risks persist due to unsustainable housing prices and high household debt levels. This may impact affordability if lending rates increase.

site_title: Vietnam's economy takes knock in Q1 as Samsung production drops
summary: Vietnam's economy grew at a slower pace in Q1 with a 5.1% increase in GDP, lower than economists' estimates and the previous quarter's 6.68% growth. Samsung Electronics' reduced smartphone production, a 10.7% contraction in phone and parts exports, and a global trade slowdown contributed to the decline. Despite this, the World Bank forecasts Vietnam's economy to expand over 6% this year and next, with a strong export sector and loose monetary conditions expected to support growth.

site_title: Profits before legacy for family businesses in Singapore: survey
summary: A survey by KPMG and CPA Australia found that 93% of Singapore family business founders prioritize continued profitability over preserving legacy, with 46% citing professionalizing the business as a pressing issue. Despite this, 40% emphasized the importance of retaining family control. The report also highlighted challenges such as succession planning, talent attraction, and managing conflict, with many business owners advocating for formal learning processes and empowering successors to make independent decisions.

images.alt_text: Chiu Wu Hong, head of enterprise at KPMG in Singapore said: "Informal governance structures that may have worked well for the founders of the business may not meet the needs and interests of a new generation.

site_title: Siam Commercial Bank plans digital revamp
summary: Siam Commercial Bank plans to launch a lifestyle app that allows customers to search and pay for entertainment options, aiming to compete with fintech companies. The bank is working with Accenture, Microsoft, and IBM on the project, with a long-term goal of transforming its digital platform into a comprehensive lifestyle app. The move is part of a wider effort to streamline operations and control costs as technology advances, and to fend off competition from fintech providers.

site_title: Pawnbroker cashes in on branded goods
summary: Maxi-Cash, a pawnbroking chain in Singapore, has launched LuxeSTYLE, a one-stop shop for pre-owned designer leather bags, luxury watches, and fine jewelry. The store offers around 1,000 watches, 600 pieces of branded jewelry, and 500 designer bags, with prices averaging 30% lower than new prices. Maxi-Cash sources the items from its own trade-ins, distributors, and owners in Japan and Europe, with strict quality and authenticity checks in place. The launch aims to attract younger customers and promote the environmentally friendly aspect of buying pre-owned goods.

site_title: Newest Texas refineries plan to turn shale into fuel for Mexico
summary: Texas refineries, Raven Petroleum LLC and MMEX Resources Inc, plan to process local shale oil into fuel for Mexico. The refineries will join existing oil refineries in the US, with most of the gains in Texas, where crude oil is abundant. Mexico's fuel demand is outpacing local supply, forcing the nation to increase imports, which grew 3% year-on-year in 2016. The fuel will be shipped on existing rail lines to Mexico, where the government has opened the market to foreign competition.

site_title: Has Warburg Pincus's S-Reit game plan only just begun?
summary: Warburg Pincus, a private-equity firm, has been quietly building its presence in Singapore's S-Reit sector, potentially planning to restructure the small-cap space for efficiency. This systematic approach suggests a larger agenda, with more acquisitions likely in the coming months. The firm's goal appears to be combining managers and portfolios, a common strategy in private-equity firms, to optimize performance. If successful, this could have significant implications for the S-Reit sector and Warburg Pincus's overall investment strategy.

site_title: Evidence that robots are winning the race for American jobs
summary: A new study by economists Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo of MIT and Boston University finds that robots are displacing American jobs at an alarming rate, particularly in manufacturing. For every robot installed, up to six workers lose their jobs and wages fall by as much as three-quarters of a percent. The study concludes that even if overall employment and wages recover, there will be significant losers, especially blue-collar men without college degrees, and it will take a long time for these communities to recover.

site_title: River revamp
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) plans to revamp the Kallang River precinct in Singapore. This project aims to revitalize the area. No specific details or timeline are mentioned.

site_title: URA to revitalise Kallang River precinct
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is planning to revitalize the 10-kilometer stretch of Kallang River in Singapore, aiming to add 100,000 new dwelling units and enhance connectivity along the river. Proposed developments include waterfront housing, renewed industrial estates, and a sports and recreational venue at Kallang Basin. The URA invites public feedback on its ideas, which also include improving accessibility, enhancing biodiversity, and incorporating the river's heritage into its development plans.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is looking to revitalise areas along Kallang River, and wants the public's and private sector's ideas on how the 10-kilometre stretch from Lower Peirce Reservoir to Kallang Basin can be transformed.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UOB Kay Hian restricted trading in Alliance Mineral Assets due to the counter's rapid run-up, while Lim & Tan Securities imposed buy and sell limits on the stock. EMS Energy signed a non-binding deal to raise S$10 million through convertible notes. Raffles Education canceled its plan to acquire the Santa Fe University of Art and Design due to regulatory concerns. Katrina Group entered into a non-binding agreement with Ajisen (China) Holdings to open "So Pho" restaurants in Hong Kong and China.

site_title: Samsung launches Galaxy S8 and dreams of recovery from Note 7
summary: Samsung unveiled its Galaxy S8 flagship smartphone, marking its first new premium phone since the Note 7 debacle in October, which lost the company $5.48 billion in profit. The S8 features a 6.2-inch or 5.8-inch curved screen, artificial intelligence service Bixby, and facial recognition application. The design update aims to revive sales and restore Samsung's credibility as a maker of reliable mobile devices. Initial sales may be slow, with some analysts predicting a smaller initial sales spike due to potential safety concerns.

site_title: Wells Fargo reaches US$110m fake accounts settlement
summary: Wells Fargo has agreed to a $110 million settlement with US customers over claims of employees opening over two million unauthorized accounts to boost pay. The bank eliminated sales targets and fired senior managers amid a scandal that prompted sweeping changes. This deal, part of a larger $185 million settlement, must be approved by a judge and doesn't admit wrongdoing. Wells Fargo still faces regulatory and criminal probes, as well as lawsuits by investors and former employees.

site_title: EU blocks Deutsche Boerse's US$14b takeover of rival LSE
summary: The European Union has blocked Deutsche Boerse's $14 billion takeover of the London Stock Exchange (LSE), citing concerns that the deal would create a monopoly in bond clearing and repurchase agreements. The decision, made by EU regulators, comes after the UK voted to leave the EU and amid concerns over the combined firm's headquarters location. The EU's antitrust commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, said the merger would have harmed competition in the soon-to-be 27-nation EU, and LSE will not proceed with the sale of its French clearing unit.

site_title: Prudential introduces new pricing approach to control excessive claims
summary: British insurer Prudential is introducing a new pricing approach for customers in Singapore, aiming to control excessive claims. The new approach will offer a 10% savings on standard level premiums for customers who haven't claimed in the last three years under the PRUshield Extra A Premier plan. Renewal premiums will be affected by claims at private hospitals, but not public hospitals. Existing customers with severe health conditions or recent claims will be excluded. A co-pay rider option is also available for customers who want to pay lower premiums.

site_title: Brexit to change UK's world role
summary: The British government has triggered Article 50, starting formal exit talks with the European Union. Prime Minister Theresa May aims to rediscover the UK as a great global trading nation, with informal talks underway with 12 countries and discussions with the World Trade Organization. The UK seeks to replicate its current WTO commitments and negotiate new trade agreements, but faces challenges due to the uncertainty of bilateral trade deals and the US administration's "America First" stance. The UK will continue to play a significant role in international security, including NATO, and cooperation with EU partners is expected to remain strong.

site_title: Top Global jumps 54.5%, overshoots offeror's final price by a cent
summary: Top Global, a Singapore property developer, saw its shares jump 54.5% to close at 34 Singapore cents, surpassing the offeror's final price by a cent. The company's chairwoman, Oei Siu Hoa, had offered 33 Singapore cents per share to take the company private, valuing it at about S$106 million.

site_title: HK Land, banks lift STI to 19-month high
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) reached a 19-month high of 3,184.57, driven by buying in banks and Jardine's Hongkong Land, with Jardine's Hongkong Land contributing 7 points and gains in DBS, UOB, and OCBC adding 12 points. The index's optimism was fueled by a strong overnight US Wall Street and statements from US Federal Reserve governor Stanley Fischer, who suggested two more interest rate hikes this year.

site_title: Sotheby's sets up luxury home unit in Singapore
summary: Sotheby's International Realty has opened a luxury home unit in Singapore, positioning it as its South-east Asia headquarters. The office, which opened on March 27, plans to grow its staff to 30, with more than half specializing in advisory and brokerage services. The move aims to capitalize on Singapore's status as a global financial hub and the growing affluent population in the region.

site_title: A dramatic comeback for Europe
summary: The Dutch election outcome has sparked a potential swing back to the centre in continental Europe, following the unexpectedly weak performance of Geert Wilders' Freedom Party. This could suggest a reversal of populist movements in France and Germany, with voters moving away from xenophobia and protectionism. A centre hold in Europe would imply a rejection of populist ideology, which could prevent a paradigm shift towards protectionism and climate-change denial. If centrist forces win in France and Germany, it could lead to a more cooperative relationship between the two countries, easing EU austerity and promoting a more sustainable economic recovery.

site_title: SCCCI aims to strike balance between firms' concerns and current economic transition
summary: Singapore's Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) is reorganizing itself to help smaller, older companies navigate the economic transition. President Roland Ng aims to strike a balance between firms' concerns and government restructuring efforts. Many firms, particularly those from the early years of Singapore's development, are facing a survival crisis due to disruptions and lack of succession planning. SCCCI is stepping up efforts to help firms internationalize, explore new markets, and adopt digital technology to refine business processes. The chamber is also reorganizing itself to provide more resources and support to its members.

site_title: US$ climbs on Fed talk, sterling under pressure
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% to 99.854 after solid data backed expectations of more interest rate hikes this year, while sterling dropped as Britain moved to exit the EU. The dollar index surpassed its 4-1/2-month low of 98.858, which was hit earlier in the week following President Trump's failed healthcare bill.

site_title: Paramount ups star power at CinemaCon
summary: Paramount Pictures presented its upcoming movies at CinemaCon in Las Vegas, featuring a star-studded lineup including George Clooney, Matt Damon, and Dwayne Johnson. The presentation included comedic moments from Suburbicon and a surprise appearance by former VP Al Gore to promote An Inconvenient Sequel. Paramount also announced a tie-in with Nickelodeon for the animated movie Amusement Park. The event marked the studio's most star-studded presentation yet, with a mix of serious and lighthearted moments.

site_title: Be scared - very scared - by climate change, says development specialist
summary: Climate change specialist Vinod Thomas's book "Climate Change and Natural Disasters" warns of catastrophic consequences if climate change is not addressed. The book chronicles a growing list of natural disasters, including floods, heatwaves, and droughts, which are increasingly linked to climate change. Thomas argues that human action contributes to the making of disasters and that climate change mitigation is within human capacity. He urges a shift towards sustainable growth and green accounting, citing the Asia-Pacific region's need to invest in infrastructure to combat climate change. The book is a call to action, urging world leaders, including US President Donald Trump, to acknowledge the reality of climate change and take responsibility for its mitigation.

site_title: Quadriplegic regains use of arm in medical first
summary: A 56-year-old American man, paralyzed from the shoulders down after a bike crash in 2007, has regained the use of his arm with the help of a medical prosthesis. The device, developed by researchers at Case Western Reserve University, uses electrodes implanted in his brain to read his brain signals and instruct his muscles to move. This is the first instance of a person with severe paralysis using their own brain activity to move their arm and hand. The study, published in The Lancet, marks a significant medical breakthrough, but further improvements are needed before the technology can be widely used.

site_title: Imperium Crown may sell 3 properties for 3.3b yen
summary: Imperium Crown, a Singapore-based property developer, has received letters of intent worth 3.3 billion yen (S$41.5 million) for the sale of three Japanese properties. The company is taking steps to finalize agreements for the sale of Green Forest Kuramae, New City Apartments Kuramae, and New City Apartments Minowa. This sale is part of Imperium Crown's plan to divest its Japanese portfolio and reallocate capital to new projects in the Australian and Chinese markets.

site_title: Former PM Valls endorses Macron for French presidency
summary: Former French Prime Minister Manuel Valls has endorsed centrist Emmanuel Macron's presidential bid, providing a significant boost to Macron's reformist liberal campaign. This endorsement is a blow to Socialist candidate Benoit Hamon, who has struggled to unite the party. With the first round of the election set for April 23, polls suggest Macron and far-right leader Marine Le Pen will likely proceed to the second round run-off. Macron's support from prominent Socialist figures like Valls and Defence Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian has raised concerns about the party's centrism, but Macron aims to "renew the faces" in French politics.

site_title: Lendlease eyes more urban regeneration projects in Singapore, KL
summary: Lendlease, an Australian developer, plans to expand its urban regeneration projects in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, with a focus on smart cities and sustainability. The company has identified Singapore as a key market, with a master-developer approach for new precincts, and Kuala Lumpur as a priority due to its existing projects and understanding of the local market. Lendlease aims to secure three to four new projects in the next five years, taking its development pipeline to over A$15 billion. The company believes urban rejuvenation projects offer higher returns and greater alignment of outcomes for cities, environments, and societies.

images.alt_text: Mr Lombardo notes Singapore does not have a separate zoning for retirement use.

site_title: Australia: Push towards inner-city living
summary: Australia's housing market continues to be a popular investment destination for Singaporeans and other foreign investors, driven by its consistent economic growth, transparent financial system, and favorable regulatory environment. The country's natural hedge between resource-dependent and service-oriented states helps mitigate downturns, and the housing sector is filling the gap left by mining investment. However, policy makers are taking steps to temper the housing market, which could lead to a decline in dwelling investment and support for the economy. Despite these risks, Australia remains an attractive place to live, with strong indicators for health, education, and housing, making property a long-term investment opportunity.

images.alt_text: According to data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the rise in the country's average property prices is slowing down amid modest economic growth.

site_title: Bottomline - 40 years of top business stories in BT
summary: The Business Times (BT) launched its 40th anniversary book, "Bottomline", which compiles the biggest business stories from each year of its existence. The 280-page book was sponsored by Citi Singapore and supports the BT-BAF, which provides arts education to children and youths. The book's editor, Kenneth Lim, praised the project, saying it highlighted the development of Singapore as a financial hub and the work of BT journalists over four decades. All proceeds from book sales will be donated to the BT-BAF.

site_title: Deal to buy US university by Raffles Education's unit is terminated
summary: A deal to acquire Sante Fe University of Art and Design in the US by Raffles Education's unit, Joshua Education, has been terminated due to regulatory approval issues. The acquisition, conditional on approvals from the Higher Learning Commission and US Department of Education, was set to close by April 3. Both parties will receive US$5 million each, plus agreed-upon interests, following the termination.

site_title: With Brexit triggered, Britain and EU make leap into the unknown
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has signed the letter triggering Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, marking the formal start of Britain's exit from the European Union. The two-year negotiation process will cover a range of issues, including trade, immigration, security, and law enforcement. The UK's "hard Brexit" stance, favoring a new and equal partnership with the EU's freest possible trade, is set to be negotiated against EU officials' resistance to Britain cherry-picking from EU membership. A "divorce bill" of up to £50 billion is also expected to be settled before negotiations begin in May.

site_title: Hedge fund Oasis wants 144-year-old Japanese firm to reinvent itself
summary: Activist hedge fund Oasis Management Co is pushing Japanese firm Katakura Industries Co to reinvent itself by focusing on profitable businesses, citing the company's diverse ventures as unsustainable. Oasis has proposed three plans to improve profitability, including setting a target for return on equity and exiting unprofitable units. The proposals, aimed at increasing transparency and efficiency, have been met with resistance from Katakura, which fears abandoning its traditional businesses. The move is seen as a test case for Japan's corporate reforms under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

site_title: In Brooklyn's Kosher pizza war, modern tastes battle ancient law
summary: A kosher pizza war has erupted in Brooklyn's Hasidic neighborhood, pitting modern tastes against ancient law. The dispute centers on a pizza shop's decision to introduce non-kosher ingredients, sparking outrage among local residents who adhere to traditional Jewish dietary laws. The conflict has drawn attention to the challenges of balancing modern tastes with cultural and religious traditions in a diverse city like New York.

site_title: Brexit trigger: Market reaction muted, as serious talks start only in May
summary: The UK has officially triggered Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, beginning a two-year countdown to its exit from the European Union. Despite Brexit, the sterling pound and stock market fell only slightly due to delayed negotiations. Initial talks will focus on exit payments, estimated at 60 billion euros, and residential rights for EU citizens living in the UK. The UK's Brexit Secretary, David Davis, disputed the figure, citing the country's assets in the EU. Prime Minister Theresa May emphasized the need for a fair deal for all citizens, including EU citizens, in her letter to the EU president.

images.alt_text: In her Brexit letter, Mrs May said the British government wanted 'a deep and special partnership between the UK and the EU'.

site_title: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta takes 23% pay cut in 2016
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta took a 23% pay cut in 2016 due to the bank's net profit decline and rising non-performing loan rates. His total remuneration fell to $8.441 million, from $10.935 million in 2015. The bank's annual report highlighted the need for better understanding of hedging contracts and revisiting credit policies. Despite the challenges, DBS continued to grow its digital business, acquiring 25% of its wealth customers and 60% of small and medium business customers through digital channels.

site_title: Buyer of Trump's childhood home in Queens, NYC, said to be from China
summary: A buyer from China purchased Donald Trump's childhood home in Queens, New York for $2.14 million, more than double the price of comparable homes in the area. The buyer, through a limited liability company, remains unknown, but a lawyer associated with the company is also linked to a Chinese buyer of a $3.6 million mansion in Old Westbury, New York. The buyer's identity has sparked curiosity, with some speculating that they may be a Trump supporter from China, drawn to the president's business acumen and popularity in the country.

site_title: Second Chance Q2 bottom line bolstered by gain on financial assets
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 79% increase in net profit for the second quarter, driven by a gain on financial assets. Revenue declined 9.4% to S$7.65 million, while earnings per share rose to 0.26 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to lower revenue from its apparel business, which suffered a 33% drop due to the weakening ringgit and poor consumer spending. Despite this, the group expects its gold business to remain profitable.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indonesia pays price of protectionism as commodity exports sink
summary: Indonesia's economy is losing out on commodity gains due to protectionist policies, resulting in a decline in commodity exports from 60% to 40% of total exports over the past five years. The country's coal output is expected to increase, but production of key mineral exports will still be behind the commodity cycle's peak. The government's efforts to stimulate domestic demand and accelerate economic growth to 7% may be complicated by the lack of a replacement sector for lost commodity income, with economists warning that manufacturing is not yet supported.

site_title: Feb pending home sales surge to 10-month high
summary: Pending home sales in the US surged 5.5% in February to a 10-month high of 112.3, driven by strong demand ahead of the spring selling season despite higher prices and mortgage rates. Economists had forecast a 2.4% increase, and the gains reversed January's 2.8% drop. The labor market's wage increases and near-full employment are driving demand, but tight inventories are constraining sales activity.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi edges up 1.5% in February
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore saw a 1.5% increase in passenger traffic to 4.67 million in February, driven by the Chinese New Year holidays. India posted the strongest growth, with a 14% increase in traffic. Aircraft takeoffs and landings declined 1.7%, while cargo shipments rose 7.9%. The airport expects Terminal 4 to open in the second half of the year, boosting annual capacity by 16 million passengers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Police open fire after driver strikes cruiser near US Capitol
summary: US Capitol Police officers opened fire after a driver struck a cruiser near the Capitol and attempted to run over officers. The suspect was arrested without injury. The incident occurred at the base of Capitol Hill. No one was injured, and the motive behind the attack is unclear.

site_title: Tencent pays US$1.78b for 5% stake in Tesla
summary: China's Tencent Holdings Ltd has invested US$1.78 billion for a 5% stake in US electric car maker Tesla Inc, providing the company with a deep-pocketed ally as it prepares to launch its mass-market Model 3. The investment may aid Tesla in selling or building cars in China, the world's largest car market. Tesla's shares rose 2.7% after the deal, and the company's CEO Elon Musk welcomed the investment, citing potential collaborations in emerging technologies such as self-driving vehicles and automated ride-sharing services.

site_title: Wine grapes worth discovering
summary: Wine grapes worth discovering have expanded significantly over the past 35 years, with obscure varieties like Assyrtiko and Frappato now firmly established in US restaurants. A list of 12 lesser-known grapes, including Vermentino and Moscato, has been compiled, offering readers a chance to explore new flavors and possibilities. These grapes may not be household names, but they are worth getting to know, potentially becoming more mainstream by 2020.

site_title: Second Chance Properties reports higher profit for Q2
summary: SECOND Chance Properties reported a 79% year-over-year increase in net profit to S$1.98 million for the second quarter ended Feb 28, 2017. Revenue declined 9.4% to S$7.65 million, while earnings per share rose to 0.26 Singapore cent. For the half year, net profit fell 10.9% to S$3.24 million, mainly due to lower revenue contributions from most business segments except for gold.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Offshore ringgit trading down 70% after NDF curbs
summary: Malaysia's efforts to curb offshore currency speculation in the ringgit have led to a 70% drop in non-deliverable forwards (NDFs) trading since November. The crackdown resulted in over RM35 billion (S$11 billion) withdrawn from Malaysian sovereign bonds. Officials are now considering easing rules on short-selling government debt. The move has made it harder for some offshore investors to hedge their risk, but the ringgit has recovered from a 19-year low in January, trading near a four-month high.

site_title: Ageing demands fresh thinking on pensions
summary: Singapore's pension system, managed by the Central Provident Fund (CPF), faces the challenge of maintaining living standards as the population ages. The CPF has balanced adequacy, coverage, and cost, and has implemented features such as high contribution rates, individual responsibility, and a basic guaranteed income stream in retirement. With the luxury of time running out, the CPF must adapt and innovate to ensure the long-term sustainability of the pension system.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Wednesday, closing 4.01 points down at 1,750.41 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. Volume was 3.40 billion lots worth RM2.63 billion, with 522 gainers and 402 losers.

site_title: Lendlease staff to experience co-working space
summary: Lendlease, a Singapore-based developer, is piloting a co-working space concept ahead of its relocation to Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ) in 2018. About 100 of its 150 Singapore-headquartered staff will use The Work Project co-working space to experience the needs of startups, while the rest will move to a site office. The pilot aims to inform Lendlease's future space needs. CEO Tony Lombardo believes the Singapore office market will remain challenging, but expects an uptick in residential demand in the next 12 months, driving growth for its Park Place Residences development at PLQ.

site_title: Wall Street flat; Fed officials in focus
summary: US stocks remained flat on Wednesday, awaiting comments from Federal Reserve officials on interest rate hikes this year. Chicago Fed President Charles Evans expressed support for one or two hikes as the US economy improves. The dollar rose after Britain notified the EU of its intention to leave the bloc, while gold prices increased due to trade policy uncertainty. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 32.26 points, or 0.16%, at 20,669.24, while the S&P 500 was down 2.21 points, or 0.09%.

site_title: Car COE prices rise in 4th straight bid exercise
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose for the fourth consecutive bidding exercise, with Cat D motorcycle COE premium hitting a record high of S$8,081. Car COE premiums rose S$976 to S$51,765 for Cat A, S$700 to S$54,000 for Cat B, and S$1,500 to S$54,501 for Cat E. Industry experts attribute the rise to artificial demand, citing possible participation from private-hire companies, while others point to hoarding of older bike COEs.

site_title: Highest customer satisfaction levels recorded in 2016
summary: Singapore achieved its highest recorded customer satisfaction level of 71.8 points in 2016, up 1.69 points from the previous year, driven by improvements in the finance & insurance and healthcare sectors. The finance & insurance sector, particularly banks, saw significant increases, with DBS Bank scoring the highest at 73.1. However, customer loyalty to banks dropped to 70.3 points, attributed to the shift towards digital capabilities. The study also highlighted the importance of qualities such as responsiveness, empathy, and assurance in differentiating companies.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Kushner, Anbang end talks to redevelop Manhattan office tower
summary: Kushner Companies has ended talks to redevelop its Manhattan office tower with China's Anbang Insurance Group. The two companies agreed to mutually discontinue discussions about the 60-year-old 666 Fifth Avenue building. Plans for redevelopment are still ongoing with other investors. Kushner Companies remains in advanced negotiations with multiple potential investors.

site_title: Airlines warn of disruption if no quick Brexit aviation deal
summary: Airlines warn of potential major disruption to air travel if Britain fails to secure a quick Brexit aviation deal. With the UK set to leave the EU in March 2019, airlines must renegotiate access to the single aviation market or develop an alternative system. UK-based low-cost carriers, such as EasyJet, are particularly affected as they rely on EU rights to fly between member states. The UK has just two years to resolve the issue to avoid flight disruptions between the UK and Europe.

site_title: BlackRock to cut jobs, fees in revamp of unit
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is revamping its struggling stock-picking unit by cutting jobs, reorganizing funds, and lowering fees. The company will shift $8 billion from traditional stock pickers to cheaper offerings, with some fees cut by up to 56%. Over 30 employees, including fund managers and analysts, were let go. The move aims to adapt to fee compression and the success of index-tracking exchange-traded funds, which benefits BlackRock's ETF business. The company expects to reduce annual revenue by $30 million.

site_title: Westinghouse Chap 11 a key stage in meltdown of nuclear industry
summary: Toshiba's struggling US nuclear-power subsidiary Westinghouse has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, marking a key stage in the "meltdown" of the global nuclear-power industry. The move, approved by Toshiba's board, aims to renegotiate construction contracts and ease liabilities. Westinghouse's huge financial losses and construction delays have put parent company Toshiba into crisis, with the company seeking domestic or foreign buyers for its stake in the US nuclear contractor. The bankruptcy filing could also face opposition from the Trump administration over national security concerns.

images.alt_text: According to Greenpeace Japan, Toshiba is "scrambling to find a buyer to take the Westinghouse anvil from around its neck".

site_title: Thailand holds key rate in rebuff to IMF call for easing
summary: Thailand's central bank held its key interest rate at 1.5% despite IMF calls to ease monetary policy and inject a fiscal stimulus. The bank predicted faster economic growth this year and next, citing rising exports and a large current-account surplus. Policymakers also raised their 2017 economic growth forecast to 3.4% and cut inflation forecast to 1.2%. The decision was seen as a rebuff to IMF recommendations, with economists predicting the central bank will not hike rates anytime soon, citing the potential for higher volatility in the baht.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise as Britain braces for Brexit
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose in cautious trading, driven by anticipation of Britain's Brexit departure. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4% ahead of the formal delivery of the Brexit letter, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 also rose. The move follows the activation of Article 50 by Prime Minister Theresa May, marking the start of the UK's exit from the EU in 2019.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) plans to rejuvenate a 10-kilometre stretch of Kallang River areas in Singapore. COE premiums for passenger cars rose for the fourth straight bidding exercise, with the motorcycle premium hitting an all-time high. Singapore's customer satisfaction index increased to 71.8 points in 2016, led by improvements in the finance and healthcare sectors. Changi Airport handled 4.67 million passenger movements in February, a 1.5% increase from last year.

site_title: To become a better cook, sharpen your senses
summary: A multisensory approach to cooking can enhance culinary skills, particularly for those with visual impairments. Experienced cooks use all five senses, including hearing, touch, and smell, to gauge doneness, texture, and flavor. For visually impaired cooks like Christine Ha, who won MasterChef, touch has become a primary guide. Research by neurobiologist David Linden confirms that the brain adapts by increasing sensitivity in hearing and touch when sight is lost, but not in taste and smell. Multisensory cooking is gaining popularity, with chefs incorporating sounds, textures, and aromas into their dishes, and even using ASMR to enhance the culinary experience.

images.alt_text: Ms McDermott, who describes the sound a pie makes when it's perfectly baked as "the sizzle-whump", at her home in Port Angeles, Washington.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to consider new home lending for settlement
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering new home lending for subprime borrowers as part of its settlement with the US over its role in the 2008 housing crisis. The bank needs soured US mortgage debt to fulfill its obligations, but financing agreements with other firms have become too expensive. Instead, Deutsche Bank may lend to companies that offer government-backed mortgages to borrowers with weaker credit, providing indirect funding for new loans. This move could increase home ownership and provide relief to low-income borrowers.

site_title: Dual payment system creates risks for India wind-energy projects
summary: India's wind-energy projects face uncertainty due to the government's shift from feed-in tariffs to auctions to buy clean power. The change threatens the economic viability of projects, as developers are now required to match lower auction costs. Utilities are pushing developers to renegotiate contracts, and projects may be halted if the policy uncertainty persists. India aims to install 175 gigawatts of renewables by 2022, but the policy transition may impact wind capacity, which is expected to double to 60 gigawatts by then.

site_title: Katrina Group enters into MOU with Ajisen China
summary: KATRINA Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage business, has entered into a non-binding MOU with Ajisen China to collaborate on opening "So Pho" restaurants in Hong Kong and China. The partnership aims to increase Katrina's overseas presence and diversify revenue streams. Ajisen China, a listed Hong Kong company, operates a large fast casual restaurant chain. The definitive agreement is expected to be finalized by mid-2017, with negotiations on franchise or joint venture terms to be conducted.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher, STI at new 19-month high
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reached a new 19-month high of 3,184.57 on March 29, 2017, after banks and Jardine stocks surged 26.75 points. Jardine's Hongkong Land led the gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC contributing 12 points. The rally came despite Dow futures slipping into the red and mixed European markets.

site_title: Changes in board appointments at four economic agencies
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry announced changes to the boards of four economic agencies, including the Agency for Science, Technology & Research (A*Star), Energy Market Authority (EMA), JTC Corporation, and Sentosa Development Corporation. The largest changes occurred at JTC, with five new board members taking effect April 1, including Ng Chee Keong, Kwa Kim Li, and Vincent Chong. A*Star also introduced five new board members, replacing existing members. The changes are aimed at strengthening the agencies' leadership and governance.

site_title: Google Translate app now unblocked in China
summary: Google has released a new version of its Google Translate app in China, allowing users to access the service without using virtual private network (VPN) software, which is required to bypass the country's online censorship. This move is seen as a step forward for Google, whose main search engine, Gmail, and other services are blocked in China. The app, version 5.8, adds instant visual translation between English and Korean and offers an improved experience for Chinese users. The exact reason for the app's availability remains unclear, but it could potentially pave the way for other Google services to enter the Chinese market.

site_title: Britain launches EU exit process
summary: Britain formally launched its exit process from the European Union on March 29, 2017, triggering Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty. This marks the first country to seek a divorce from the EU, sparking uncertainty and concern about the bloc's future. The two-year countdown to leaving the EU has begun, with negotiations on outstanding bills, immigration, and trade ties set to be a major challenge. Prime Minister Theresa May has called for unity, but the country remains deeply divided over the Brexit decision.

site_title: Improving workplace health and safety requires collaboration
summary: Singaporean businesses are working together to improve workplace health and safety, with the five-step bizSAFE programme credited for progress. Private sector organisations, including the General Insurance Association of Singapore, have collaborated with various stakeholders to enhance workplace safety and health. This collaborative approach is crucial in a business environment with numerous challenges and changes, and is essential for creating healthy and sustainable workplaces.

site_title: Two senior Sinopec oil traders quit, one joins private e-platform
summary: Two senior oil traders at Sinopec Corp, Xu Qing and another, have resigned. Xu Qing, vice president of Sinopec Fuel Oil Sales Co, is joining private e-commerce commodity platform ChinaYIE, while the other trader's new employer was not disclosed. ChinaYIE, a Shanghai-based online commodity platform, recorded annual trade turnover of 167.4 billion yuan last year. The departures come amid a significant shift in the Chinese energy market, with private companies increasingly competing with state-owned refiners.

site_title: Mercedes hastens electric-car rollout as combustion era fades
summary: Mercedes-Benz accelerates its electric car rollout, aiming to introduce 10 new battery-powered vehicles by 2022, three years ahead of its original target. The move reflects the growing urgency to shift away from combustion engines as European buyers turn away from diesel cars due to the Volkswagen scandal. Mercedes aims to meet tighter emissions rules and reduce carbon-dioxide emissions, with the goal of achieving a level of 100 grams per kilometre by 2021. The company's parent, Daimler AG, is also investing in autonomous driving technology to remain successful in the industry's transformation.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges up, gains capped as ex-dividend adjustment weighs
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 0.1% to 19,217.48, but gains were limited by ex-dividend share price adjustments. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 declined 0.2% each. Strong US shares overnight also had a muted impact.

site_title: China's Agricultural Bank in talks for more debt-to-equity deals
summary: Agricultural Bank of China Ltd, the country's third-largest listed lender, is in talks for more than 20 debt-to-equity deals valued at approximately 70 billion yuan (S$14.166 billion). The bank reported an 8.7% profit growth in the fourth quarter, but its net interest margin dropped to 2.25%. The bank's non-performing loan ratio eased to 2.37% as it sees a "turning point" in its loans business. This follows agreements with eight companies, which the bank's president, Zhao Huan, said was a positive development.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators block Deutsche Boerse, LSE merger
summary: EU antitrust regulators blocked the merger of Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange, citing concerns over the combined market power of the two companies. The European Commission deemed the deal would have created a de facto monopoly in fixed income markets, harming competition. The merger was the fifth attempt by the companies to create Europe's biggest exchange, but they failed to offer required remedies to address competition concerns. As a result, the Commission prohibited the merger.

images.alt_text: EU antitrust regulators blocked the proposed merger of Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange on Wednesday as expected, saying that the deal would have harmed competition because of the companies' combined market power.

site_title: Australian meat industry licks lips at post-Brexit Europe
summary: Australia's meat industry is optimistic about the potential for increased exports following the UK's exit from the European Union. With the EU imposing quotas and taxes on Australian beef imports, the country is expected to gain better deals. The UK's decision to sign free-trade deals globally could lead to a boost in exports, particularly to Japan, the US, and South Korea. Meanwhile, the European Union's tainted meat scandal has created an opportunity for Australian producers, with 20 countries, including the EU, closing their doors to Brazilian imports.

site_title: South Korean media slam govt over ferry 'remains'
summary: South Korean authorities faced criticism for announcing human remains had been found from the sunken Sewol ferry, only to correct themselves hours later after discovering the remains were animal bones. Relatives of the missing were put through "heaven and hell" as they were informed of the supposed human remains, only to be told they were animal fragments.
