The maritime ministry's mistake has reignited concerns about the government's handling of the disaster, which resulted in the deaths of 304 people nearly three years ago.

site_title: Seoul: Won flat as US dollar recovers, stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won eased 0.1% to 1,114.2 to the US dollar on Wednesday, as the US dollar regained strength on upbeat US economic data. South Korean shares edged up 0.2% to 2,167, despite foreign investors and institutions selling local equities. The gains were capped as institutions sold 32.5 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Bank of Korea board member says monetary policy could diverge from US if needed
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea board member Cho Dong Chul stated that monetary policy decisions should prioritize local economic conditions, potentially diverging from the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The BOK's inflation target is 2%, currently at 1.9%, and policymakers are debating whether to end the easing cycle amid uncertainties, including the presidential election and US interest rate increases. The bank has maintained its policy rate at 1.25% since June 2016.

site_title: Japan to extend US$850m bailout loan to Mongolia
summary: Japan has agreed to provide a $850 million bailout loan to Mongolia as part of a broader $5.5 billion bailout package to help rescue the country's struggling economy. The loan, part of a three-year IMF Extended Credit Facility, comes in addition to a $440 million IMF loan and a $3 billion aid package from Japan and South Korea. Mongolia's economy grew just 1% last year, its lowest in seven years, and the country is struggling to maintain its currency and manage debts. A vote on the bailout legislation is expected when Mongolia's parliament reconvenes on April 5.

images.alt_text: Japan has committed US$850 million in loans to Mongolia as part of a bailout to help rescue the country's struggling economy, Mongolia's finance ministry said on Wednesday.

site_title: 'Pink Star' diamond set to fetch record price in Hong Kong
summary: A 59.60-carat "Pink Star" diamond, the largest in its class graded by the Gemological Institute of America, is expected to break the world record for a gemstone at an auction in Hong Kong on April 4. The previous record sale in 2013 saw the diamond fetch US$83 million, and Sotheby's predicts it will sell for a record price above US$60 million. The flawless diamond was discovered in Africa in 1999 and had previously sold in Geneva for US$83 million before being bought back by Sotheby's.

site_title: Philippines, China to hold direct talks on sea row
summary: China and the Philippines will hold direct talks in May on their maritime dispute, following a UN-backed tribunal's rejection of Beijing's claims to the South China Sea. The talks, proposed by China, aim to resolve issues related to the sea row without involving all six claimants. President Rodrigo Duterte, seeking stronger economic ties with Beijing, has downplayed the tribunal's ruling and pushed for rapprochement. The direct talks, which will be the "platform" for the Philippines to raise issues like China's artificial island construction, are seen as a means for China to exert its economic and political leverage.

site_title: HK stocks end higher; China sinks
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.19% on Wednesday, following a Wall Street rally and broad gains across Asia. The Hang Seng Index ended at 24,392.05, while China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.36%. This contrasted with China's decline in the Shenzhen Composite Index. The gains in Hong Kong were attributed to optimism about the world's top economy, following a jump in US consumer confidence.

site_title: Singapore's customer satisfaction index up in 2016 (Amended)
summary: Singapore's customer satisfaction index rose to 71.8 points in 2016, up 1.69 points from the previous year, driven by improvements in the finance and healthcare sectors. The finance sector scored 72.9 points, up 1.75 points, while the healthcare sector scored 71 points, up 1.4 points. The increase was attributed to better services perceived at hospitals and higher scores for perceived quality and value in the finance sector.

site_title: Hong Kong convicts two for ivory on radiocarbon dating
summary: A Hong Kong court has convicted two men for illegally possessing ivory chopsticks, which were found to be produced after 1990 through radiocarbon dating. The conviction comes as Hong Kong aims to phase out ivory sales by 2021. The men were purchased from a crafts shop in Sheung Wan district during an operation last August. The case highlights the ongoing issue of ivory trade in Hong Kong, a key hub for the industry.

images.alt_text: A Hong Kong court has convicted two men for illegal possession of ivory chopsticks after radiocarbon dating proved it was produced after 1990 and therefore unlawful, local media reported.

site_title: Mercedes, VW recall million vehicles in China
summary: German automakers Mercedes Benz and Volkswagen are recalling nearly one million vehicles in China due to concerns over ignition circuitry overheating and panoramic sunroof leaks. Mercedes Benz will recall 400,000 vehicles from May 2015 to February 2017, while Volkswagen will recall 572,000 vehicles due to potential problems with the panoramic sunroof. The recalls are related to quality issues in China and the companies are working to address the problems and prevent potential safety risks.

site_title: The illegal deliveryman who became one of China's richest men
summary: Wang Wei, the 46-year-old founder of SF Express, has become one of China's richest men after his courier service listed on the Shenzhen stock exchange, making him a billionaire twenty times over. The company, which started as an "illegal" delivery service in the 1990s, has grown into the top courier in China's booming e-commerce market, with an 80,000-strong staff and $23.3 billion in wealth. Wang's secretive nature has drawn media and investors, but his company's success has solidified his position as the fourth wealthiest man in China.

site_title: Car COE premiums continue to rise
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose for the fourth consecutive bidding exercise, with Category A increasing to S$51,765, Category B to S$54,000, and Category E to S$54,501. Motorcycles saw a record high with a S$8,081 premium, while goods vehicles fell to S$47,036. The increases are attributed to a surge in demand and limited supply.

site_title: Australia: Shares at near 2-yr closing highs, financials support; NZ up
summary: Australian shares reached a near two-year closing high, finishing 0.9% higher at 5873.5 on the S&P/ASX 200 index, driven by optimism over financial sector earnings. The gains were led by big four banks, which rose between 1% to 1.3% after Deutsche Bank analysts increased their future cash earnings forecasts. New Zealand's benchmark index also gained nearly 1% to its highest close in over a week, with Air New Zealand rising 3.8% to touch its highest level in nearly a year.

site_title: Australia holds emergency meet with China after extradition treaty failure
summary: Australia's foreign minister, Marise Bishop, held an emergency meeting with China's ambassador, Cheng Jingye, after cancelling a parliamentary vote to ratify an extradition treaty with China. The treaty, signed 10 years ago, was blocked due to opposition over China's humanitarian record. China expressed "disappointment" at the cancelled vote, while the Chinese Foreign Ministry reiterated that ratifying the treaty would aid both countries in fighting cross-border crime. The failure to enact the treaty is a rare diplomatic blow to Sino-Australia relations, which have improved in recent months.

site_title: Duterte offers authoritarianism as Philippine panacea
summary: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has proposed a return to authoritarian rule, citing the need for martial law to combat crime and terrorism. This echoes the rule of former dictator Ferdinand Marcos, who was overthrown in 1986. Duterte's authoritarian tendencies have raised concerns among human rights lawyers and critics, who fear the erosion of democratic institutions. Despite this, many Filipinos support his approach, and he plans to change the constitution to create a federal system, which he believes will address corruption and inequality.

site_title: Toshiba board approves bankruptcy for Westinghouse, Nikkei says
summary: Toshiba's board has approved a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in the US for its Westinghouse Electric unit due to a possible $6.2 billion writedown on the nuclear energy business. The company has been grappling with delays at nuclear projects in Georgia and South Carolina, leading to the significant writedown. Westinghouse, which Toshiba purchased in 2006 for $5.4 billion, has faced increased costs and decreased nuclear generation demand due to stricter safety standards and falling natural gas prices. The bankruptcy filing is expected to book a 712.5 billion yen (S$8.644 billion) writedown.

site_title: Samsung faces 'biggest test' with Galaxy S8 launch
summary: Samsung will unveil its Galaxy S8 in New York, marking its "biggest test" since last year's Galaxy Note 7 recall crisis. The company faces challenges in regaining consumer trust and credibility amid ongoing corruption scandal and billions in lost profit. The S8 features a larger curved display, fingerprint scanner, and iris scanner, with a debut of Samsung's voice-powered digital assistant Bixby. The phone is expected to be available in late April with a price range of around $900-$1,000.

site_title: China facing heightened financial risks from property downturn: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that China's financial risks have grown due to a potential property downturn, exacerbated by record lending and a less able government to mitigate risks. China's record 12.65 trillion yuan in loans in 2016, with half being household loans, has led to new home prices reaching five-year highs. Policymakers face the prospect of a property market crash, which could damage the economy. Moody's notes that the Chinese authorities' scope to mitigate risks through fiscal and monetary policy has become limited, and expects China to increase its deficit to 3.3-3.5% of GDP over the next few years.

site_title: Goldman forms new equities team to improve hedge fund services
summary: Goldman Sachs has formed a new team to improve collaboration between its hedge fund services and derivatives trading, aiming to offer competitive pricing and stay competitive in the market. The team, led by Puneet Malhi and Cyril Goddeeris, will formalize joint ventures and enhance communication to better understand the firm's total risk. The move comes as Goldman seeks to efficiently use its balance sheet and address a decline in revenue from its equities business, which fell 12% in 2016. The new team aims to improve pricing and competitiveness in prime brokerage.

site_title: Gold slips on technicals as US dollar firms on US rate hike cues
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,248.32 per ounce due to technical resistance and positive economic data supporting the US dollar and equities markets. The US consumer confidence index hit 125.6 in March, surpassing expectations, and US Federal Reserve vice-chairman Stanley Fischer hinted at two more interest rate hikes this year. A strong US dollar makes gold more expensive for holders of other currencies, decreasing demand.

site_title: New guide to help investors identify risks, understand audit opinions
summary: A new guide is available to help investors identify risks and understand audit opinions in listed companies' financial statements. Jointly produced by ACRA, ISCA, and SIAS, it aims to assist investors in identifying significant risk areas and understanding the audit process. The guide focuses on enhanced auditor reporting standards, audit opinions, and key audit matters. It provides relevant questions for investors to raise at annual general meetings, available for free download on the SIAS website.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Britain to launch EU exit process Wednesday
summary: Britain formally launches the process for leaving the European Union on Wednesday, triggering Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, which sets a deadline for the UK's departure in 2019. Prime Minister Theresa May will deliver a speech to MPs, stating that the country must come together to make a success of the result. The move has sparked divisions within the country, with Scotland's parliament voting in favor of holding a fresh referendum on independence from Britain. Negotiations with the EU over outstanding bills, immigration, and future trade ties are expected to be monumentally difficult.

site_title: Japan scientist eyes energy burst from 'typhoon turbine'
summary: A Japanese scientist, Atsushi Shimizu, is developing a bladeless wind turbine that can harness the power of typhoons to generate electricity. The turbine, which uses the Magnus effect to spin, can withstand strong winds and is designed for Japan's unique wind patterns and hilly terrain. Shimizu hopes to mass-produce the turbine by 2020, with a capacity of 10 times the current prototype, and believes it could help Japan reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and nuclear power.

site_title: Cyclone-ravaged Australia like 'a war zone'
summary: A powerful cyclone ravaged northern Australia, bringing destructive winds and devastating tourist hotspots in Queensland state. The category four storm, downgraded to a tropical low, left towns cut off and without power, with scenes likened to a "war zone." The Bureau of Meteorology warned of damaging wind gusts and intense rain, sparking flood fears. The cyclone's impact was significant, with battered yachts washed ashore and roofs ripped off houses, highlighting the region's vulnerability to extreme weather events.

images.alt_text: Towns were cut off and without power in northern Australia Wednesday after being pummelled by a powerful cyclone that washed battered yachts ashore and ripped roofs off houses in scenes compared to "a war zone".

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.820 points to 1757.460. Gainers outnumbered losers 202 to 41, and trading volume was 88.04 million lots worth RM27.05 million.

site_title: World's first Asia ex-Japan Reit ETF lists on Singapore Exchange
summary: The world's first Asia ex-Japan Reit ETF, NikkoAM-StraitsTrading Asia ex-Japan Reit Exchange Traded Fund (ETF), was listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on March 29, 2017. The ETF, managed by NikkoAM, tracks the FTSE's EPRA/NAREIT Asia ex-Japan Reits Net Total Return SGD index, covering 70% Singapore-listed Reits and 30% Hong Kong and Malaysian Reits. The fund offers investors diversification across geographical markets and high-growth Reit sub-sectors, with units gaining 1.012% at listing.

site_title: Singapore's family businesses say profits take priority over legacy: survey
summary: Singapore family businesses prioritize profits over legacy, with 8 in 10 believing continued profitability should not be compromised for family legacy. Only 13% of family businesses survive to be passed on to the third generation. Experts warn that informal governance structures may hinder business growth and overlook non-family members' value.

site_title: Singapore Changi Airport's passenger movements up 1.5% in Feb
summary: Singapore Changi Airport saw a 1.5% increase in passenger movements to 4.67 million in February 2017, driven by strong growth from India and steady increases from Indonesia and Vietnam. Aircraft movements dropped 1.7% and cargo shipments rose 7.9%. With over 100 airlines operating at Changi, it connects to 380 cities worldwide, offering over 7,000 weekly scheduled flights.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Kansai Electric jumps as court paves way for restarts
summary: Kansai Electric Power Co., Japan's second-largest utility, saw its shares jump 9.9% after an Osaka High Court overturned a ruling that barred the operation of two of its nuclear reactors. The decision, the third time a high court has ruled in favor of utilities seeking to restart reactors, is expected to boost profits by 7 billion yen per month. The company forecasts a 6% decline in net profit for the year, but analysts see the decision as a positive for the credit strength of the electric utility sector.

site_title: EMS Energy, HK's Titan sign MOU on S$10m convertible notes issue
summary: EMS Energy has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Hong Kong-listed Titan Petrochemicals Group to raise up to S$10 million through convertible notes. The funding will be used to complete the construction of EMS Energy's shipyard in Tuas, Singapore. The agreement, subject to a restructuring exercise, allows Titan Group to convert debt into equity 24 months after the first disbursement. The conversion price will be negotiated in a definitive agreement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open after Wall St lead
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.22% at the open on Wednesday, following a rebound on Wall Street fueled by strong US data, particularly in the energy sector. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,398.51, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index saw minimal changes. The rally was driven by a rally in oil prices and positive US economic data.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slightly down; Taiwan dollar hovers near 29-month low
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% on Wednesday, erasing early gains, as the Taiwan dollar hovered near a 29-month low of NT$30.115. Asian shares were mixed, while the US dollar and commodities rallied after investors focused on a positive global growth outlook. The breach of the NT$30.000 psych level may lead to momentum sellers, according to analysts.

site_title: Tencent emerges as Musk's China whisperer with Tesla stake
summary: Elon Musk's electric-car company Tesla has received a significant investment from Tencent Holdings Ltd, a Chinese internet giant. Tencent purchased a 5% stake in Tesla for $1.8 billion, with Musk referring to the company as an adviser. The move is seen as a vote of confidence in Tesla's future and may help the company access the Chinese market. Analysts believe Tencent's involvement could provide valuable insights into China's auto market, which is crucial for Tesla's expansion plans.

site_title: Hot stock: China Everbright Water rises on project wins
summary: China Everbright Water's shares rose 2.5 Singapore cents to S$0.49 after the company inked deals for multiple projects worth 956 million Chinese yuan (S$195 million) in central China. The projects include wastewater treatment, landscape restoration, and pipeline construction in prefectures and counties. The partnership agreement involves financing, designing, constructing, operating, managing, and maintaining the projects for 13 to 25 years. The deals are expected to boost the company's revenue and growth prospects.

site_title: US dollar pushes on in Asia after Wall St gains, equities cautious
summary: The US dollar rose in Asia after a strong consumer confidence survey, with the dollar at 111.30 yen, well up from previous days. The survey's high reading reinforced the view of a strong US economy, supporting gains in the dollar and US equities, including the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq. Asian markets were less certain, with Hong Kong and Sydney up, while Shanghai fell. Energy firms benefited from a Libya outage easing supply concerns.

site_title: Paramount rolls out A-listers at CinemaCon
summary: Paramount Pictures unveiled its 2017 film lineup at CinemaCon, featuring A-list presenters such as George Clooney, Matt Damon, and Dwayne Johnson. The presentation included prepared jokes and trailers for upcoming movies like Baywatch, An Inconvenient Sequel, and Suburbicon. The event also included a surprise appearance by former Vice President Al Gore and a discussion on the studio's technological advancements for Transformers: The Last Knight. Paramount's presentation was the most star-studded of the conference, with several high-profile actors and directors taking the stage to promote their films.

site_title: Ringgit trading shrivels offshore as crackdown deters investors
summary: Malaysia's central bank has successfully cracked down on currency speculation in the ringgit, with offshore non-deliverable forwards trading plummeting 70% since November. The crackdown led to a $35 billion withdrawal from Malaysian sovereign bonds. To revive interest in debt, the bank is considering easing rules on short-selling government bonds. Despite this, the ringgit's volatility remains, with one-month implied volatility at its lowest level since 2014. The central bank aims to stabilize the market within a three-to-six-month timeframe.

images.alt_text: After sliding to a 19-year low in January, the ringgit has clawed back, trading near a four-month high as swings abate.

site_title: URA announces plans to rejuvenate Kallang River areas
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced plans to rejuvenate a 10-kilometre stretch of the Kallang River in Singapore, inviting public and private sector feedback on proposed developments. The plans include adding waterfront housing, renewing old industrial estates, improving connectivity, and developing the Kallang Basin as a sports and recreational venue. The government aims to inject 100,000 new dwelling units and enhance biodiversity along the river. The proposals are part of a series of exhibitions showcasing the government's plans for other areas, including the Jurong Lake District and Rail Corridor.

site_title: Teenager planned school shooting in US: police
summary: An 18-year-old US student, Nichole Cevario, was arrested and charged with possessing explosive and incendiary material intended to create a destructive device after her family reported her planning a school shooting at Catoctin High School. Authorities say the plot was foiled when Cevario's father noticed worrisome comments in her diary. The Frederick County Sheriff's Office credited the parents for stepping forward and preventing the attack, which was set to occur on April 5. Cevario is undergoing psychiatric evaluations and will face arraignment if released.

site_title: Roche MS drug Ocrevus approved by FDA after 3-month delay
summary: The US FDA approved Roche's multiple sclerosis drug Ocrevus, becoming the first US-approved medicine for primary progressive form of the disease. The approval was delayed by three months due to manufacturing issues. Ocrevus, an immunosuppressive drug, reduces the immune system's assault on the body's own neurons and has shown a 47% reduction in disease progression in patients. Analysts forecast annual sales exceeding $3 billion by 2021, helping offset declining revenue from Roche's top-selling cancer drugs.

site_title: China's yuan falls as rate talk buoys US dollar
summary: China's yuan fell against the US dollar on Wednesday, weakening to 6.8915 per dollar, as strong consumer confidence data backed expectations of US interest rate hikes this year. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate, which was lower than the previous fix, and the yuan was 97 pips weaker in the spot market. The rate talk is seen as a sign of a strengthening US economy, which may lead to more interest rate hikes and a stronger dollar.

site_title: Seoul: Won steady as exporters offset stronger US dollar
summary: The South Korean won remained steady against the US dollar, trading at 1,114.0, despite the US dollar's rise due to a surge in US consumer confidence. Exporters offset the dollar's increase with month-end selling. South Korean shares were flat, with the Kospi index at 2,164.13 points, and foreign investors purchased Kospi shares worth 17.3 billion won. Chipmaker SK Hynix rose 2.5% on hopes of strong quarterly earnings, while Hyundai Motor and Hyundai Mobis declined.

site_title: Australia shares soar to near 2-year high; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to their highest in almost two years, driven by strong US consumer confidence data and stabilisation in commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,862, with cyclical sectors leading the way. Materials and energy stocks also gained, while gold stocks fell due to lower gold prices. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.6%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.07% and the Topix index down 0.11%. The gains were offset by concerns over US and European political uncertainty. The US shares had rallied earlier, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: British PM signs letter for Brexit with calls for UK unity
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May signed the historic letter triggering Brexit, a two-year process to leave the European Union, on Tuesday. The letter, signed in a photo released by her office, will be delivered to EU President Donald Tusk on Wednesday, formally notifying the EU of Britain's intention to leave the bloc. May called for unity, acknowledging the divisive nature of the Brexit vote, while Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced plans for a new independence referendum, citing the need for Scotland to maintain ties with the EU.

site_title: Pound falls more than 1% against Singdollar on Brexit fears
summary: The British pound fell over 1% against the Singdollar on Tuesday night after British Prime Minister Theresa May signed the country's divorce papers to exit the European Union. The move, which is expected to take effect on Wednesday, has left markets nervous as no country has ever activated Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty. The pound's decline is a sign of the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, with investors anticipating the potential economic and financial implications of the UK's departure from the EU.

images.alt_text: The British pound slumped after British Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday night signed the country's divorce papers to exit the European Union.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.28% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.95 points, or 0.28%, to 3,166.77 as of 9am on Wednesday, driven by gains in financial and energy shares. US stocks also ended higher, snapping an eight-day losing streak, amid soaring consumer confidence. Top gainers included DBS, Jardine C&C, and Top Global, with 82.4 million shares changing hands.

site_title: North Korea could be in final preparations for nuclear test: report
summary: US-based analysts say satellite images suggest North Korea is in final preparations for a new nuclear test at the Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site. Equipment trailers and communications cables have been spotted, indicating the installation of instrumentation for data collection and processing. This comes after similar conclusions reached by the US military last week. North Korea has continued its nuclear program despite UN sanctions, aiming to develop a long-range missile capable of hitting the US mainland with a nuclear warhead.

site_title: GIC in talks to buy stake in US clinical trials firm: sources
summary: GIC is in advanced talks to buy a minority stake in US clinical trials firm Pharmaceutical Product Development (PPD) alongside Abu Dhabi Investment Authority. The deal would value PPD at over $9 billion, with Carlyle Group and Hellman & Friedman continuing to control the company. Negotiations are ongoing, and an alternative deal is still possible after a previous offer from Pamplona Capital Management was rejected. The sale would underscore the growing demand for PPD's services in the pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Japan's tepid retail sales raise concerns about consumption, growth
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 0.1% in February, below the median estimate of a 0.5% annual increase, as consumers cut back on food and durable goods amid low wage growth. The sluggish figures raise concerns about private consumption and sustained wage growth, contradicting the government's "Abenomics" policies. Spending on food, durable goods, and daily goods declined by 1.5%, 2.2%, and 5.1% respectively, with most major companies offering their lowest base pay increase in four years, exacerbating consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: Japanese retail sales were effectively flat in February as consumers cut back on food and durable goods after employers offered the lowest spring wage increases in four years.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Top Global, Wee Hur, China Everbright Water
summary: Top Global's executive chairwoman Oei Siu Hoa is launching a privatisation offer to avoid paying penalties for failing to sell Singapore residential units within a regulatory timeframe. The offer is to buy up the rest of the property and education group she does not own for 33 Singapore cents per share. China Everbright Water has entered into an agreement to embark on multiple projects worth 956 million Chinese yuan (S$195 million) in central China. Wee Hur Holdings is looking to buy an office warehouse building in Adelaide, Australia, for A$5.995 million (S$6.36 million) plus GST.

site_title: US launches anti-dumping probe against Chinese aluminum foil
summary: The US has launched an anti-dumping investigation into Chinese aluminum foil imports, citing dumping and unfair subsidies. US companies filed a complaint alleging Chinese companies sell aluminum foil in the US at prices lower than production costs. The Commerce Department will review the case by April 24, and if harmed, could impose punitive tariffs of up to 140.2% on Chinese imports. This is the latest in a series of trade cases against China, which could result in punitive duties.

site_title: Trump moves to roll back Obama climate measures
summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order to review Obama-era climate measures, declaring an end to the "war on coal" and easing restrictions on coal production. The move aims to curb emission limits for coal-fired power plants and federal leasing for coal production, potentially undermining America's commitment to cut carbon emissions by 26-28% by 2025. Critics warn that the rollback will have limited economic benefits and could hinder the US's ability to meet its climate targets, while some experts suggest it could be a precursor to the US withdrawing from the Paris Climate Accord.

site_title: US: Wall Street posts sharp gains, fuelled by strong consumer data
summary: US stocks surged sharply on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 reaching a 16-year high, driven by strong consumer confidence and optimism. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.73% to 20,701.5, while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.6% to 5,875.14. The financial and energy sectors led the gains, with Apple hitting an all-time high. The data suggests that investors are focusing on President Trump's promise of tax reform, despite recent setbacks.

site_title: US dollar up as Brexit fears contrast with solid US data, Fed speakers
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% against a basket of major currencies, its strongest one-day gain since March 1, as a top Federal Reserve official expressed expectations of more US rate hikes and a solid US consumer confidence reading. Brexit fears and European currency fluctuations also contributed to the dollar's strength. Analysts, however, note that the US dollar's long-term trajectory may still turn lower due to ongoing political uncertainty and potential economic impacts from the UK's exit from the EU.

site_title: BlackRock cuts fees and jobs; stockpicking goes high-tech
summary: BlackRock is overhauling its actively managed equities business, cutting jobs and fees, and increasing its reliance on technology to pick stocks. The company is removing traditionalist portfolio managers, cutting revenue by $30 million, and taking a $25 million charge for severance. BlackRock aims to boost its active fund business, which represents nearly a third of its assets but an outsized 50% of its fees. The overhaul is part of the company's efforts to engineer a turnaround after facing active stock fund withdrawals and increased competition from lower-cost index-tracking funds.

site_title: Wife of France's Fillon also charged in fake jobs affair
summary: French presidential candidate Francois Fillon's wife, Penelope, was charged with complicity in the abuse of public funds, specifically for allegedly fictitious jobs and a salary from a literary magazine. Penelope Fillon received hundreds of thousands of euros, despite claiming she never worked at the magazine. Francois Fillon has also been charged with failing to declare a 2013 interest-free loan and has faced intense media scrutiny over the scandal, dubbed "Penelopegate." The charges come less than four weeks before the French presidential election on April 23 and May 7.

site_title: Trump tax plan faces rockier road after bruising healthcare loss
summary: US President Donald Trump is moving forward with a tax reform plan, with a target date of August, despite the recent failure of a healthcare bill. The White House will take the lead in crafting legislation, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin suggesting a tax bill could be passed by August. However, getting a broad tax bill passed by Congress is challenging, particularly after intra-party differences torpedoed the healthcare legislation. Analysts predict a watered-down version of current proposals, and Democrats may be open to discussing tax legislation if it benefits the middle class.

site_title: Hot stock: Top Global jumps on privatisation bid
summary: Shares of Top Global surged 10.5 Singapore cents to 32.5 Singapore cents after its majority owner, Oei Siu Hoa, launched a privatisation bid to avoid paying penalties for failing to sell Singapore residential units within a regulatory timeframe. The offer values the company at about S$106 million, representing a 50% premium to its pre-announcement closing price. Oei Siu Hoa secured irrevocable undertakings for 77.4% of Top Global's total issued share capital, making the offer final and non-revisable.

site_title: Oil jumps on Libyan disruption, Opec deal extension hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Tuesday due to a disruption in Libyan oil supplies, with Brent crude rising to $51.33 per barrel and WTI crude reaching $48.37 per barrel. The closure of Sharara and Wafa oilfields reduced output by 252,000 barrels per day. Officials suggest an extension of the Opec and non-Opec production cut deal beyond June, with Russia and Iran likely to comply. However, resurgent US oil production and record domestic crude inventories continue to pressure oil prices.

site_title: Wary of Trump, China launches EU charm offensive: diplomats
summary: China has launched a charm offensive with the European Union since US President Donald Trump took office, shifting its stance on trade negotiations and signaling closer cooperation on various issues. The EU envoys in Brussels and Beijing see a greater urgency from China to find allies willing to stand up for globalization amid fears Mr. Trump could undermine it. China has dropped its public campaign to be recognized by the EU as a market economy, and is seeking to bring forward its annual summit with the EU to a lower date. However, European companies doing business in China say they have yet to see the change of style translating into less protectionism from Beijing.

site_title: Fed's Fischer says two more 2017 rate hikes seem about right
summary: Federal Reserve Vice-Chairman Stanley Fischer stated that the Fed's decision to raise interest rates two more times this year "seems about right." This forecast aligns with his personal view and the Fed's median estimate. Fischer emphasized the importance of watching fiscal policy negotiations without prejudging the outcome, as proposals may change during the legislative process. He also expressed concerns over rising protectionism and low investment in the economy, but noted that the risks of more aggressive or gradual rate hikes are balanced. Fischer's term as vice-chairman expires in June 2018.

site_title: Company warrants - new features worth noting
summary: Company warrants have evolved with novel features, deviating from the standard template of being part of a rights issue, detachable, and having a five-year life span. New instruments include warrants with shorter life spans, such as Second Chance's three-year instrument, and longer life spans, like KrisEnergy's seven-year instrument. Others feature non-standard characteristics, like Abundance International's European-style warrant and the AsiaPhos "plain vanilla" warrant. These changes reflect a shift towards more flexible and structured warrants to remain relevant in the market.

site_title: Online competitors take on global banks in securities research shake-up
summary: Online portals are poised to gain market share in the securities research industry, driven by new regulatory rules, such as MiFID II, which require investment banks to charge clients explicitly for research rather than bundling the cost into trading commissions. Major "bulge bracket" investment banks, like Standard Chartered and Jefferies, have retrenched staff or pulled back from equity research and sales businesses. Analysts estimate that only 0.1% of research reports are read by investors, highlighting the need for efficiency in the industry. Online platforms, such as Smartkarma, are filling existing gaps rather than snatching market share.

site_title: S'pore's tertiary bodies revamp courses to meet needs of future economy
summary: Singapore's tertiary institutions are revamping courses to meet the needs of the country's future economy. Over 12 revamped programmes and new majors will be introduced in the upcoming academic year, focusing on data analytics, fintech, digital innovation, and entrepreneurship. The move aims to equip students with skills required to tackle challenges mentioned in the Committee on the Future Economy report. Institutions such as NUS, SMU, and SUSS are launching new degree programmes in business analytics, data science, and smart city management. The revamped programmes are expected to produce graduates with practical and innovative solutions for businesses and society.

site_title: Beijing urges France to protect Chinese community after police shooting
summary: China has urged France to protect its citizens after a police shooting in Paris, killing a 56-year-old Chinese man, Shaoyo Liu. Protests erupted, with 35 people arrested, as hundreds of Chinese community members and anti-racism supporters gathered outside a police station. Beijing has filed an official complaint, calling for France to guarantee the safety and rights of Chinese citizens in France. The French interior minister condemned the violence and said the security forces had his full support, as the victim's family disputes the police version of events.

site_title: Decoupling is hard to do for Japan stocks still tied to the yen
summary: Japan's stock market, Topix, remains tied to the US economy and yen, despite Bank of Japan stimulus. A recent selloff of over 1% was triggered by Donald Trump's healthcare overhaul failure, sending the yen surging and Topix near erasing its 2017 gain. Analysts question the market's ability to chart its own course, with forecasts of 17% earnings growth unable to break the yen's advance. The Topix is now at its seventh-worst performance among 24 developed markets this year, leaving investors at a crossroads as they reassess US economic prospects.

site_title: China can deploy warplanes on artificial islands: US think tank
summary: China has completed major construction of military infrastructure on artificial islands in the South China Sea, including naval, air, radar, and defensive facilities, according to a US think tank. Satellite images show new radar antennae on Fiery Cross and Subi reefs, suggesting China can now deploy combat planes and military hardware at any time. China has denied militarizing the area, but its military capabilities in the region are increasing tensions and counterproductive to peaceful dispute resolution, a Pentagon spokesman said.

site_title: Japan court gives green light for Kansai Electric to restart reactors in wake of Fukushima meltdown
summary: A Japanese high court overturned a lower court's order to shut two reactors operated by Kansai Electric Power, allowing the utility to restart operations. The decision, made six years after the Fukushima nuclear disaster, may help Kansai Electric cut fuel costs. However, it is unlikely to speed up the national process of getting reactors back online.

site_title: Trump's modest boyhood home in Queens sells for US$2.14m
summary: US President Donald Trump's childhood home in Queens, New York, has been sold for $2.14 million to an overseas Chinese buyer, facilitated by a lawyer representing a limited liability corporation. The sale price is more than double the average value of comparable homes in the area, with the property's value attributed to its association with the US president. The buyer's identity remains undisclosed, and plans for the property's future are unclear, with no confirmation of a presidential library or museum.

site_title: It's time to reconcile Americans to the need for choices
summary: The Trump administration's 2018 budget proposed deep cuts in agency spending, sparking outrage from critics. However, the proposed cuts reveal a deeper issue: the need for limited government and a focus on agreed-upon boundaries. The US government has grown significantly since World War II, with federal spending increasing from 3% of GDP to 21%. The government's reliance on debt to finance spending has eroded spending discipline, with deficits in every year since 1963, except for one. To address this, the author suggests reverting to a budget role as an exercise in political choice, rather than an instrument of economic policy, and promoting a more limited government focused on agreed-upon boundaries.

site_title: Fed speakers halt US$ slide with talk of rate rises
summary: US dollar steadied after its worst week since Trump's election, with promises of more Federal Reserve interest rate rises this year helping to recover from multi-month lows. The yen gained 4% in nine days due to eroding faith in the Trump White House's ability to deliver tax reform. Analysts point to the prospect of more US interest rate hikes and the potential for the next hike to be accelerated to June, which has supported the dollar's recovery.

site_title: Earnings, deal talk drive European share rebound, DAX stands out
summary: European shares rebounded 0.6% on Tuesday, driven by strong results and deal-making. The Stoxx 600 index rose, with basic resource stocks and auto stocks leading the gain. Tenaris, Wolseley, and EDP were top gainers, with Tenaris citing a possible earnings upgrade and Wolseley posting a 25% profit rise. Portugal's stock index outperformed peers, while Credit Agricole rose 3.8% after Barclays switched its preference to it from Societe Generale. Recordati fell 0.9% after Goldman Sachs cut its rating to "sell."

site_title: After healthcare bill's failure, next battle may shut down US govt
summary: US Republicans face a looming government shutdown as a spending bill to keep the government running after April 28 is being negotiated. Despite controlling Congress and the White House, the House Freedom Caucus, which opposed the failed Obamacare repeal bill, is pushing for defunding Planned Parenthood. The group's demands could lead to a bipartisan agreement, but the odds of a shutdown remain high, with President Trump and some Republicans willing to consider it. Lawmakers have limited time to reach a deal before the funding deadline, and the outcome could have implications for future legislative priorities, including a tax overhaul.

site_title: China's biggest lenders poised for windfall from rising rates
summary: China's largest lenders are expected to benefit from rising interest rates, with larger banks benefiting from higher borrowing costs as net lenders in the interbank market. This has led to a surge in their stocks, with large bank shares returning double that of smaller counterparts this year. Meanwhile, smaller banks struggle with soaring money-market rates, with some reportedly defaulting due to tight liquidity.

site_title: Multi-business strategy bolsters sustainable dividends
summary: Keppel Corporation, a multi-business company focused on sustainable urbanisation, has implemented a strategy to bolster sustainable dividends. The company has distributed an average of 40-50% of annual net profit as dividends over the past five years. For FY 2016, a total cash dividend of S$0.20 per share was declared, with a 46% payout ratio. Keppel aims to improve earnings quality and recurring income to sustainably fund capital spending and dividends in the long term.

site_title: Head of Australian sandalwood firm readies bid for own company
summary: Quintis Ltd, an Australian sandalwood plantation group, is preparing a potential takeover bid for the company after its managing director resigned amid a 24% share price drop following a negative report by short-seller Glaucus Research Group. Managing director Frank Wilson, who owns 13% of the company, plans to make the offer with an international group. Shares jumped 10% on the news, and chairman Dalton Gooding stated that the company's fundamentals remain strong despite issues affecting its share price.

site_title: China outbound M&A may reach US$275b in a decade
summary: China's outbound mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are expected to reach $275 billion annually in the next decade, despite capital outflow restrictions. White & Case's John Reiss attributes this growth to confidence in the stock market and President Donald Trump's pro-business agenda. Despite snags, HNA Group and Zhonghong Zhuoye Group have made significant deals in the US, with HNA spending $30 billion on US assets since last year. Market volatility and challenges to Trump's agenda may impact dealmaking in the US.

site_title: Trump's modus operandi puts US credibility on the line
summary: US President Donald Trump's tendency to make unsubstantiated claims and exaggerate facts is eroding the country's credibility, both domestically and internationally. This modus operandi, exemplified by his repeated false claims, including the alleged "wiretapping" of his predecessor Barack Obama and the size of his inaugural crowds, undermines the trust of world leaders and American citizens. This behavior may explain Trump's low approval ratings and obstacles to advancing his policy agenda, highlighting the importance of credibility in national leadership, particularly when it comes to issues of war and peace.

site_title: Medisave allowed in hospitals overseas
summary: Singaporeans can use their Medisave funds to cover overseas hospital bills, including elective procedures, since March 2010. The scheme was initially limited to emergency procedures but was extended due to grassroots feedback. Conditions apply, ensuring quality of care and preventing abuse, and were initially offered by two providers: Health Management International and Parkway Holdings.

images.alt_text: Medisave funds were at first allowed only for emergency procedures overseas, but feedback from the grassroots led to the scheme being extended to cover elective hospitalisation abroad as well. The move was aimed at giving Singaporeans a wider choice, which could translate into cost savings.

site_title: Malaysian central bank sees inflation exceeding 8-year high
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, expects inflation to exceed 4.5% this month, its highest in over eight years, due to higher fuel costs. However, there's no evidence of price pressures spreading to the broader economy. The bank's director, Fraziali Ismail, notes that the economy is operating close to its potential and doesn't see signs of exceeding it. This complicates the bank's efforts to keep interest rates low enough to support the economy, with the benchmark rate remaining unchanged at 3%.

site_title: Cheaper street lights put Romans in a dark mood
summary: Rome's mayor, Virginia Raggi, has installed about 100,000 LED lamps across the Italian capital, aiming to save millions in electricity bills. However, critics claim the modern glow of the LED lamps dims the city's old-world charm, with many residents complaining about the harsh light and loss of historic ambiance. The decision was made before Raggi's tenure, but the new bulbs have sparked controversy, with some petitioning to reverse the change and others defending the environmental benefits and cost savings. Experts argue that the aesthetic impact is a significant issue, particularly in historic cities like Rome.

site_title: Asia to turn elsewhere in next 5 years as Middle East fails to meet oil demand: IEA
summary: Asia will need to turn to other regions, including Latin America, Africa, Russia, and Central Asia, to meet its growing oil demand in the next five years due to Middle East producers being unable to meet the region's vast appetite. Asia will need to import 25 million barrels of oil a day in 2022, up from 21 million barrels last year. The International Energy Agency (IEA) also emphasizes the need for continued investments in deepwater oil projects to meet future demand.

site_title: Rooftop shanties top once-iconic Casablanca buildings
summary: Historic Casablanca buildings are being overrun with makeshift shelters on rooftops due to Morocco's housing crisis. Once-iconic buildings from the 1910s and 1920s are deteriorating under neglect, while tenants are forced to pay low rents and landlords are unwilling to maintain the properties. The city's economic hub is experiencing a boom, but it's not translating to quality housing for its residents, leading to a rise in squatters and makeshift homes. Authorities are now upgrading the city centre, and gentrification is bringing in wealthier Moroccans, but the issue remains a pressing concern.

site_title: Cyclone Debbie pounds Australia's northeast
summary: Tropical Cyclone Debbie made landfall in Australia's northeast, causing widespread damage and power outages. The storm brought wind gusts over 260 km/h, damaging homes, jetties, and disrupting transportation. Thousands of people were evacuated, and airlines suspended flights to and from the region. Authorities reported one injured person and concerns about potential loss of life. The cyclone weakened to a category one storm overnight, but forecasters warned of continued high winds.

site_title: UK retail giant Tesco to pay £214m over accounting scandal
summary: Tesco, the UK's largest retailer, agreed to pay £214m in fines and investor compensation for a 2014 accounting scandal, where it overstated profits by £326m. The company has provisionally agreed to pay £129m under a deferred prosecution agreement with the Serious Fraud Office. Tesco also agreed to pay £85m to compensate investors, with eligible shareholders set to receive 24.5p per share. The settlement comes as Tesco's £3.7 billion bid for food wholesaler Booker was opposed by shareholders, who urged the company to focus on its recovery rather than acquiring Booker.

site_title: Ezion acquiring Swissco's JV stakes, assets for more than US$60m
summary: Ezion Holdings has acquired full control of two joint ventures with Swissco Holdings for more than US$60 million. The move comes after Swissco's joint-venture firms failed to meet their obligations due to S&E's financial situation. Ezion will also acquire assets from one joint venture. Swissco's interim judicial managers are assessing five indicative bids, with a court hearing adjourned.

site_title: Wealthy Venezuelans seek haven in Madrid
summary: Wealthy Venezuelans are fleeing economic chaos in their home country by investing in Madrid, Spain, where they can shield their assets. The number of Venezuelans arriving in Spain has risen over 50% in 2015, with many investing in luxury real estate, particularly in upscale neighborhoods like Salamanca. With Spain's stable politics and property market, Venezuelans are seeking a safe haven, with some buying properties for over 1 million euros and securing private security and concierge services. The crisis in Venezuela, marked by hyperinflation and food shortages, is driving these wealthy Venezuelans to seek alternative investment opportunities in Spain.

site_title: Fearless Girl statue to stay in New York's financial district (for now)
summary: The Fearless Girl statue, created by Kristen Visbal, will remain in New York's financial district until early 2018, after originally being scheduled for removal next week. The statue, erected to celebrate International Women's Day, has become a symbol of female empowerment and has drawn crowds. Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the decision, calling the statue a powerful symbol of standing up to fear and power. The statue's extension has sparked mixed reactions, with some praising it as a symbol of empowerment and others criticizing it as a marketing stunt.

site_title: Australia can manage risks of shift to renewables: market operator
summary: Australia can effectively manage its transition to renewable energy by controlling rooftop solar output and demand management, according to Audrey Zibelman, the new head of the country's electricity market operator. Australia is at the forefront of integrating renewable energy into its existing grid. Zibelman's expertise in rebuilding New York's grid after Hurricane Sandy highlights the country's ability to adapt and manage risks associated with a rapid shift to renewables.

site_title: SWFs weigh 'safety nets' to spur cross-border capital flows
summary: Sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) are considering greater cooperation with international institutions to encourage cross-border capital flows and foster sustainable growth in emerging markets (EMs). This move aims to increase the reliability of cross-border finance, add to regional "safety nets," and promote open capital markets. SWFs see this cooperation as a way to boost investment returns and enhance market resilience in the face of global uncertainties. The initiative is driven by Asia's desire for greater autonomy from Western institutions and its own economic resilience, following past crises such as the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: ECB's 'free money' has supported banks more than the economy
summary: The European Central Bank's targeted lending programme, known as TLTROs, has failed to increase bank lending to companies and households, with a mere 0.42% increase in corporate loans since 2014. However, lending to households has fared better, increasing 4.2% over the period. The programme has instead become a subsidy for banks, helping to alleviate negative circumstances such as weak profitability and regulatory uncertainty. The ECB may end up paying banks to take its cash, and the programme's success is being reevaluated.

site_title: Too early for S'pore to shrug off Indonesia tax amnesty
summary: Singapore's wealth, estimated at S$279 billion, remains largely untouched by Indonesia's tax amnesty programme, which is set to expire. Despite the programme's goal of encouraging Indonesians to repatriate their assets, only 12% of declared assets were repatriated as of September 2016. Analysts expect even lower numbers to repatriate funds in the programme's final phase, which will continue until the end of March. The programme's limited effect is attributed to its flaws, including preferential rates requiring investment in government-backed vehicles and risks of attracting Singapore authorities' attention.

site_title: Ex-Taiwan leader found not guilty in leaks case
summary: A Taiwanese court found former president Ma Ying-jeou not guilty in a political leaks case, acquitting him of leaking secrets and defamation. Ma was not present when the verdict was announced, having denied any wrongdoing throughout the trial. The case, filed by lawmaker Ker Chien-ming, accused Ma of leaking confidential information about a judicial probe in 2013. Ma will face a new trial after state prosecutors brought fresh charges against him earlier this month. Ma's lawyer vowed to appeal the verdict.

images.alt_text: Throughout the trial, Mr Ma had denied any wrongdoing. He faces a new trial over fresh leaks charges.

site_title: Softening of medical tourism nudges health groups overseas
summary: Singapore's medical tourism industry is experiencing a decline due to rising standards and lower treatment costs in neighboring countries. To stay competitive, local private hospital groups are investing in medical facilities abroad, such as Raffles Medical Group in Hong Kong and Shanghai, and IHH Healthcare Berhad in Asia, central and eastern Europe. Despite this, some hospitals remain confident in Singapore's ability to attract medical tourists, citing the country's high-quality care and differentiated capabilities. However, the industry's growth is expected to be hindered by the strength of the Singapore dollar and rising costs, with Thailand and Malaysia emerging as alternative destinations for medical tourism.

site_title: Slowdown in positive data to test market's faith in reflation trade, say strategists
summary: US investors betting on economic reflation may face an unexpected economic surprise as strategists warn of a slowdown in positive data, potentially testing the market's faith in the reflation trade. A growing chorus of experts, including Julian Brigden and Willem Buiter, predict that the market's obsession with growth speed and acceleration may lead to a vicious circle, with failed expectations of pro-growth US policies and waning price increases.

site_title: Amazon to buy largest Mid-East e-retailer Souq.com
summary: Amazon will acquire Souq.com, the Middle East's largest online retailer, in a deal expected to be finalized this year. The acquisition value was not disclosed, but Amazon had previously offered $650 million. Souq.com, which attracts 45 million monthly visits, will expand Amazon's e-commerce presence in the region, with Souq.com CEO Ronaldo Mouchawar stating the deal will improve delivery capabilities and customer selection.

site_title: Japan unveils plan to raise pay, tackle overtime
summary: Japan's government has unveiled a plan to raise pay for contract employees and limit overtime to 100 hours a month, aiming to narrow the wealth gap and make it easier for more women and the elderly to join the workforce. The plan, part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's labour reforms, will eventually eliminate the pay gap between regular and non-regular employees doing the same work. The government will also shoulder costs for workers to settle claims of unfair pay out of court, and limit overtime in certain industries for the next five years.

site_title: Japan loans Manila military planes to patrol sea lanes in South China Sea
summary: Japan has loaned two military surveillance aircraft to the Philippines to patrol the South China Sea, despite the country's conciliatory stance towards Beijing's claims over the disputed waters. The planes, leased from Japan, will be deployed over Benham Rise and the South China Sea to bolster Manila's defense capabilities. This move comes as Japan strengthens ties with other countries to contain China's regional influence, following its territorial disputes in the East China Sea.

site_title: Credit Suisse revamp progress buys CEO breathing room on capital
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG has made significant progress in its restructuring efforts, including $1.9 billion in cost cuts and a higher capital ratio. CEO Tidjane Thiam stated that this progress has given the firm breathing room to consider alternative capital-raising options beyond a plan to list part of its Swiss bank unit. Thiam also signaled that the worst may be over for job cuts, but warned of further reductions this year and next.

site_title: China Everbright Water consortium seals 956m yuan deal
summary: A consortium led by China Everbright Water has sealed a 956 million yuan (about S$195 million) deal with the Construction Bureau of the Suizhou Hi-Tech Industry Zone in central China. The partnership involves multiple projects, including the landscaping of the Fuhe River, industrial waste water treatment, and park restoration, spanning 13 to 25 years. China Everbright Water will hold an 78.4% stake in the project company, with the remaining consortium members holding 1.6% and Suizhou High-Tech holding 20%. The deal is expected to enhance long-term returns for shareholders.

site_title: Local crowdfunding platform to tap 'mass affluent' with easing of MAS rules
summary: FundedHere, a Singapore-based crowdfunding platform, plans to expand its services to "mass affluent" investors earning at least S$100,000 a year, after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased rules. The platform, which currently targets accredited investors, aims to attract professionals and individuals with a moderate income who can understand the risks of crowdfunding. FundedHere plans to acquire crowdfunding platforms in Malaysia and Indonesia and is seeking funding for the acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Local crowdfunding platform FundedHere, which has been offering crowdfunded equity and loans to wealthy "accredited investors" in Singapore, wants to open up its platform to professionals earning at least S$100,000 a year, partner Daniel Lin said on Tuesday.

site_title: China's Zhengzhou Yutong ceding potential US sales of buses to Buffett's BYD
summary: China's Zhengzhou Yutong Bus Co, the world's largest bus maker, will cede potential US sales to Warren Buffett's BYD Co due to strained US-China relations. Chairman Tang Yuxiang cited a lack of harmonious business settings in the US, where Yutong has vehicles in over 130 markets outside the country. Yutong's revenue increased 15% last year, driven by strong sales in countries like Singapore, Russia, and Saudi Arabia. BYD aims to boost brand awareness in the US via bus sales before expanding into the passenger-car market.

site_title: Brookfield makes bold move into solar with TerraForm acquisitions
summary: Brookfield Asset Management Inc, one of the largest owners of hydropower, is making its first major move into solar power by acquiring TerraForm Global Inc and TerraForm Power Inc, valued at $2.94 billion. This marks a strategic shift as solar power becomes cost-effective, with Brookfield already owning 10,700 megawatts of clean-energy plants worldwide. The acquisition will grow Brookfield's clean-energy portfolio 37% and expand its footprint globally, bringing resource and geographic diversification.

site_title: UOB to expand board from 9 to 12 members
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) plans to expand its board from 9 to 12 members to address the increasing complexity of managing a bank. The bank is recruiting four new directors to replace the retiring non-executive and non-independent director Wong Meng Meng. The decision was made to enhance the board's skill-set and expertise in areas such as finance, technology, and strategic planning. The expansion aims to provide a more diverse and experienced board, with all directors having professional, gender, geographical, and ethnic diversity.

site_title: Hey, you! Get Ofo, MoBike
summary: Venture capitalists are investing heavily in Chinese bike-share companies, such as Mobike, despite questionable business models. Backers include Matrix Partners, Citic Private Equity Funds Management Co, and Sequoia Capital Operations LLC, with Didi Chuxing and Temasek Holdings Pte also participating. This trend has raised concerns about the sustainability of the global ride-hailing wars, with investors seemingly driven by a fear of missing out.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain "hold" ratings on Yoma Strategic Holdings, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings), and Jumbo Group despite mixed quarterly results. Yoma's strong business model and diversified operations are seen as a long-term structural uptrend, while Yangzijiang's investment in a venture fund and Jumbo's overseas franchising efforts are viewed as strategic moves. Analysts adjust target prices, with Yoma's price reduced to S$0.78 and Yangzijiang's to S$0.96, and Jumbo's to S$0.67.

site_title: Pimco, Gross settle row over his ouster; proceeds from suit to go to charity
summary: Pimco and former CEO William Gross have settled a lawsuit over his ouster in 2014. Gross's lawyer filed a request to dismiss the lawsuit in California state court. The proceeds from the suit will go to charity. The bitter legal dispute between Gross and Pimco is now over, marking a resolution to the row.

site_title: Learning the art of implementing analytics
summary: A scientific and data-driven approach to problem-solving, known as analytics, can help organizations make better decisions and increase productivity. However, many analytics projects fail due to poor science, art, or both. Successful analytics involves combining science and art, and organizations should focus on understanding the problem deeply and combining tools, rather than just relying on analytics. Integrating design thinking, analytics, and behavioral insights can produce better solutions. Building a multi-disciplinary team, structuring it to report to a central executive, and empowering whole-of-government analytics can also improve outcomes. A conservative approach to breaking down silos and fostering collaboration among government agencies can also lead to successful analytics initiatives.

site_title: STI rises 1% as Wall St avoids collapse
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 3,157.82 on Tuesday, driven by a minor "relief rally" after Wall Street avoided a major blowout on Monday. The rebound was led by large-cap names, including banks and Jardine stocks. Analysts attribute the rise to early window-dressing or buying in anticipation of similar moves on Friday, when blue chips are expected to be "window-dressed" ahead of the end of the first quarter.

site_title: New McLaren 720S goes faster - but costs less
summary: The McLaren 720S has been unveiled with a lower price tag of S$990,000 compared to its predecessor, the 650S, at S$1.1 million. The new model features an all-new design, engine, and dihedral doors, and boasts impressive performance with a 0-100km/h time of 2.9 seconds and a top speed of 341km/h. The 5-year model life cycle without mid-life upgrades is expected to boost resale value, with McLaren aiming to release a Spider variant in a couple of years.

site_title: Saudi Aramco valuation seen topping US$1 trillion after government cuts tax
summary: Saudi Aramco's tax cut is expected to increase its market value to over $1 trillion, with analysts Sanford C Bernstein & Co and Rystad Energy AS estimating a valuation of $1 trillion to $1.5 trillion. The 50% tax reduction will boost after-tax income by 300%, allowing for higher cash returns to shareholders. The Saudi government is preparing for a potential record IPO, with Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman valuing the company at $2 trillion.

site_title: Citigroup to seek bids for non-life insurance partnership in Asia-Pac: source
summary: Citigroup plans to seek bids from global insurers for a non-life insurance partnership in its Asia-Pacific markets, expected to be worth at least $500 million. The 15-year deal, which will be one of the largest in the region, will give insurers access to 15 million Citibank customers in 12 markets. Citi will kick off the process in a few days and expects to choose a partner in a few months. The deal is part of a trend of banks leveraging their networks to generate assured revenue as demand for insurance grows in the region.

site_title: Manhattan landlords resorting to tenant freebies
summary: Manhattan landlords are offering tenant-improvement allowances, such as interior redesigns and moving expenses, to keep storefronts from emptying after record rent increases. These concessions, previously uncommon in the Manhattan retail market, are becoming a key component in new leases for large, flagship stores in high-profile areas like Madison Avenue and Fifth Avenue. This shift in the balance of power signals that landlords are trying to avoid big price cuts, instead opting for more flexible terms to maintain occupancy.

site_title: Impact investors need better data
summary: Impact investors face a critical weakness in their analysis due to limited data on a company's real-world impact. Current ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) models focus on company operations but lack data on products, services, and environmental effects. This bias leads to inconsistent scoring, with some companies scoring well despite high greenhouse gas emissions and others poorly despite sustainable practices. Efforts to standardize and collect data are underway, allowing for more accurate analysis of companies' green shares and enabling impact investors to make informed decisions.

site_title: Gleneagles brand spreads its wings worldwide
summary: IHH Healthcare's parent company has expanded the Gleneagles brand globally, opening its first tertiary hospital in Hong Kong and building two more under the brand in China. The company has a presence in five regions, with 16 Gleneagles hospitals, and aims to bring the brand to the rest of Greater China. The brand's success is attributed to IHH's ability to deliver high-quality healthcare services, with a brand valuation assessment suggesting it has the potential to become a leading global brand.

site_title: Japan probes avalanche deaths of instructor, 7 students
summary: A massive avalanche in central Japan killed eight people, including seven high school students and an instructor, on Monday. The incident occurred during a winter climbing training camp in Nasu, Tochigi prefecture, where a group of 48 people were training. An avalanche warning was in place, but the students were not adequately equipped with safety gear, raising questions about why they were sent into the area despite the warnings.

images.alt_text: Firefighters and rescue workers using a drone to investigate at the site of an avalanche in Nasu town, north of Tokyo, Japan, in this photo taken by Kyodo.

site_title: Rebound for Trump possible if he learns
summary: US President Donald Trump may consider a legislative rebound if he learns to form coalitions with both Republicans and Democrats on policy issues. A bill's passage is often misunderstood as a simple process, but it actually involves complex negotiations and can take a long time. Most bills introduced by lawmakers never reach the president's desk for signature, emphasizing the need for bipartisan cooperation.

site_title: HK to focus on talent and economic development, says Carrie Lam
summary: Hong Kong's new chief executive-elect, Carrie Lam, has emphasized her administration's focus on boosting economic development, investing in talent, and addressing housing problems. Her top priorities also include tackling sociopolitical divisiveness.

site_title: Malaysia extends bauxite mining ban until mid-2017
summary: Malaysia has extended the bauxite mining ban until June 30, 2017, to clear remaining stockpiles and mitigate environmental damage. The country had initially imposed a three-month ban in January 2016 due to concerns over water contamination and pollution. As of February 28, only 3.25 million tonnes of bauxite had been exported, with 2.15 million tonnes still remaining in the Pahang region. The government aims to give industry players time to clear existing stockpiles and implement pollution measures.

site_title: Dow-DuPont shows how innovation is EU's new M&A battleground
summary: The European Union has approved the $77 billion merger between Dow Chemical and DuPont, requiring the sale of DuPont's pesticide business to ensure the continued development of new products. The EU's antitrust chief, Margrethe Vestager, emphasized the importance of preserving innovation in the global agrochemicals industry, stating that it's crucial for future competition and food security. The approval marks a trend of regulators focusing on protecting innovation in mergers and acquisitions, rather than just focusing on the products themselves.

site_title: Viacom counting on new chief to save Paramount
summary: Viacom has appointed James Gianopulos as chairman of Paramount Pictures, aiming to revive the struggling studio. Paramount lost $445 million in its last fiscal year and has been plagued by poor film releases. Gianopulos, a seasoned Hollywood executive, previously ran 20th Century Fox and will bring immediate stability to the studio. However, analysts question whether Paramount has enough top-tier intellectual property to turn its business around, and a turnaround is likely years away. Gianopulos has a history of revitalizing struggling studios, but the challenges facing Paramount are significant.

images.alt_text: In some ways, Mr Gianopulos may take comfort in Paramount's long-term history: The studio has battled its way back from the brink before.

site_title: China chipmaker Unigroup secures 150b yuan to expand globally
summary: China's chipmaker Unigroup has secured 150 billion yuan ($30.4 billion) in financing from the China Development Bank and a national chip fund to expand globally. The company will receive 100 billion yuan from the China Development Bank by 2020 and 50 billion yuan from the national chip fund. This funding will support Unigroup's aggressive expansion, including a $30 billion memory chip production complex in Nanjing and upgrades to its technology. The move is part of China's $150 billion 10-year plan to achieve a leading position in semiconductor design and manufacturing.

site_title: Ericsson to take large provisions as new CEO sets out strategy
summary: Ericsson's new CEO, Borje Ekholm, is implementing a cost-cutting strategy to address contract losses and revenue declines. The company will book up to 15 billion Swedish kronor (S$2.4 billion) in extra costs in the first quarter. Ekholm plans to narrow the company's focus, explore options for its media business, and reduce top management layers from 10 to 5 geographical business areas. This move aims to improve Ericsson's financial performance in leaner times.

images.alt_text: Mr Ekholm has already slashed Ericsson's dividend as he tries to reverse a sales plunge caused by fierce competition amid a slowdown in spending by wireless carriers.

site_title: Offer to delist Top Global as QC penalties loom
summary: Singapore's Top Global, a property and education group, is facing penalties for failing to sell residential units within a regulatory timeframe. Chairwoman Oei Siu Hoa has launched a privatisation bid through SW International at S$0.33 per share, valuing the company at S$106 million. The offer aims to avoid 8% QC charges and 10% buyer stamp duty. If successful, Top Global may delist and avoid further financial strain, with Oei intending to secure at least 90% stake to achieve this.

site_title: Goods trade deficit narrows, consumer confidence soars
summary: The US goods trade deficit narrowed 5.9% to $64.8 billion in February, driven by a decline in imports outpacing a drop in exports. Inventories increased 0.4% to $616.1 billion. Consumer confidence soared to its highest level in over 16 years, with the Conference Board's index reaching 125.6, driven by optimism about the short-term outlook for jobs and personal income. The strong consumer sentiment could prompt economists to raise their estimates for first-quarter GDP growth, now forecast at a 1.0% annualized expansion rate.

site_title: Sony kicks off CinemaCon with array of exclusive footage
summary: Sony kicked off CinemaCon with a star-studded presentation, showcasing exclusive footage from upcoming movies including Blade Runner 2049, Spider-Man: Homecoming, and The Dark Tower. Director Edgar Wright shared behind-the-scenes stories from Baby Driver, while Marvel chief Kevin Feige introduced footage from Spider-Man: Homecoming. Sony movies chief Tom Rothman revealed stunning new scenes from Blade Runner 2049, which is expected to be one of the year's most anticipated movies. The presentation also featured comedic moments with Dwayne Johnson and Jack Black.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Mining International plans to buy a 40.15% stake in Sino Feng Mining International for its rights to a 10% share of profit in a Henan, China project. The deal involves acquiring shares worth 1.56 million yuan, with a one-year deadline. Meanwhile, China International Holdings faces a court claim for loan repayment, and Joyas International Holdings seeks an extension for its annual general meeting.

site_title: Top Global chairwoman launches privatisation bid at S$0.33 per share
summary: Top Global chairwoman Oei Siu Hoa is offering to buy the company for 33 Singapore cents per share, a 50% premium to its pre-announcement closing price. The offer, made through private investment vehicle SW International Holding, values the company at approximately S$106 million. Oei Siu Hoa intends to delist Top Global if she secures a stake of at least 90%. The bid aims to avoid listing-related costs and obtain greater management flexibility, following concerns about meeting regulatory deadlines.

site_title: Diamond industry's 'hungry crocodile' chart just doesn't cut it
summary: The diamond industry's "hungry crocodile" chart, a long-standing industry staple, has failed to materialize a predicted shortage and price rises due to oversimplification of the industry's 15,000 categories of diamonds. In reality, lower quality stones have seen a 20% decline, while top producers like De Beers have been forced to offer concessions to customers. The industry's reliance on aging mines and varying market segments has led to a need for more granular analysis to accurately model demand and supply.

site_title: CapitaLand inks first mall management contract in Singapore
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property and retail giant, has signed its first third-party mall management contract in Singapore, overseeing the pre-opening and retail management for the SingPost Centre mall. This is the third mall management contract the company has inked in Asia, following similar agreements in China. The deal expands CapitaLand's network in Singapore to 20 shopping malls and demonstrates its asset-light expansion strategy.

site_title: Fewer ships in trouble these days, but salvage firms are still indispensable
summary: The International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation (ITOPF) reported a decline in large oil spills from tankers, averaging 1.7 incidents per year since 2010, with only one major incident in 2016. In contrast, 25 such incidents occurred annually in the 1970s. Salvage companies, members of the International Salvage Union (ISU), provided 213 services to vessels carrying over 2.5 million tonnes of cargo, highlighting their value in protecting the marine environment. Despite improvements in shipping and safety measures, the need for salvors remains, with a debate ongoing over their compensation and the role of coastal states in subsidizing tug services.

site_title: British novelist and playwright David Storey dies at 83
