The company has been in crisis since 2015, but recently resolved a shareholding dispute with Baoneng Group, allowing Shenzhen Metro Group to become its largest shareholder and paving the way for normal operations. Net profit for 2016 rose 16% to 21 billion yuan, with revenue increasing 24% year-over-year.

site_title: Uber halts tests of self-driving cars after its SUV crashes in Arizona
summary: Uber has halted tests of its self-driving cars after an SUV crashed in Arizona, with no serious injuries reported. The incident occurred when another vehicle failed to yield, and an Uber spokeswoman confirmed the vehicle was in self-driving mode. The company has suspended test vehicles in Arizona, Pittsburgh, and San Francisco pending an investigation. This crash raises questions about the safety of autonomous driving technology and its interaction with human drivers.

site_title: Gender-bending fashion hits the runway in Tokyo
summary: In Tokyo, Japan, gender-bending fashion is thriving, with designers blurring the lines between masculinity and femininity. The trend is exemplified by Japanese men who dye their hair and wear makeup, not to pass themselves off as women, but to create a new standard of beauty. Tokyo Fashion Week showcased designs that were "half-dressed, half-undressed" with interchangeable clothes and accessories. The trend is seen as a reflection of Japan's "genderless" culture, where men and women often wear women's brands.

site_title: EU stalls Russian gas pipeline, but probably won't stop it
summary: The European Union (EU) has stalled the construction of a Russian gas pipeline, the Nord Stream 2, but it's unclear if the decision will ultimately halt the project. The pipeline, which spans the Baltic Sea, has sparked divisions within the EU, with some countries like Poland and the Baltic states opposing it due to concerns over Russia's growing influence. However, Germany, the main beneficiary, prioritizes economic benefits over security concerns, fueling the ongoing debate. The EU's decision may not be a decisive blow to the project, and its future remains uncertain.

site_title: New arrest over London attack as govt eyes WhatsApp
summary: British police have made a new arrest in connection with the deadly attack on parliament in London, where four people were killed and 50 wounded. The 30-year-old suspect, believed to have prepared terrorist acts, was detained in Birmingham. The investigation is now focusing on accessing WhatsApp, the messaging service used by the attacker. The attack occurred four days ago, and officials are working to uncover more information about the assailant's plans and motivations.

site_title: Startup offers data analytics to detect internal fraud at banks
summary: A Singapore-based startup, TrustSphere, is offering data analytics to detect internal fraud at banks by analyzing internal communication data, such as email flows, without accessing the content. The startup's relationship analytics can identify patterns and strength of communication networks, helping banks detect potential insider threats. TrustSphere's tool can also be used to understand sales networks and track customer relationships. The startup charges a subscription fee for its services, with organizations controlling the data.

site_title: Lull in economic, earnings data in week ahead
summary: US stocks are expected to remain stable this week as the conversation in Washington DC shifts from healthcare reform to tax reform. President Donald Trump's effort to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act was abandoned, bringing an end to a two-week selloff in stocks. Analysts predict that investors will be relieved to move on to tax cuts and infrastructure spending, which could drive cyclical stocks higher in the short term. The best hope for bulls is that Republicans can make a convincing argument for a credible plan to pass corporate and consumer tax cuts, potentially boosting confidence in the stock market.

site_title: Formula One: Vettel wins Australian Grand Prix
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Australian Grand Prix, finishing 9.9 seconds ahead of Lewis Hamilton. Vettel overtook Hamilton during the first set of pit stops, securing Ferrari's first victory since 2015. Valtteri Bottas completed the podium on his Mercedes debut. The win marked Vettel's fourth time winning the Australian Grand Prix.

site_title: Win could fuel anger over election system
summary: Former Hong Kong Chief Secretary Carrie Lam won the election without leading in opinion polls, sparking concerns over the credibility of the city's election system and Beijing's interference. Lam secured more than twice the number of votes than rival John Tsang, despite trailing him in polls. Analysts say this outcome could fuel anger and lead to calls for a fairer system, while Tsang's popularity casts doubt on Lam's reign. The opposition has condemned the election results, pledging to resist authoritarianism, and Lam faces a challenge in winning back trust with her lack of popular support.

site_title: Singapore Corporate Awards to recognise board diversity
summary: The Singapore Corporate Awards will recognize board diversity as a key attribute of a well-functioning and effective board under the Special Recognition category. The awards, jointly organized by The Business Times, Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants, and Singapore Institute of Directors, aim to promote corporate governance practices. Nominations for the awards will close on April 30, 2017, and the event will feature a guest of honour, Second Minister for Finance and Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong. The recognition of board diversity aims to spur companies to be more conscious and forthcoming about their board composition.

site_title: Sports leagues race to give fans optimum interactivity
summary: Sports leagues are increasing interactivity with fans through technology, allowing for greater engagement and a sense of ownership. The Salt Lake Screaming Eagles, an American football team, polled fans on strategic decisions during its first game, while the NBA has included virtual reality games in its streaming service. Leagues are also exploring holograms, which could enable fans to watch events in the comfort of their homes. The coming of 5G technology may facilitate the development of holograms, and sports media are expanding coverage of events with more expansive coverage and access to statistics.

site_title: Singapore, France hail close bilateral relations
summary: Singapore and France reaffirmed their close bilateral relations during a state banquet hosted by President Tony Tan Keng Yam for visiting French President Francois Hollande. The two countries have deepened economic cooperation, with bilateral trade valued at S$16 billion in 2016. France is also a significant investor in Singapore, with total foreign direct investment at about S$14.8 billion. Hollande's two-day visit will focus on strengthening ties, including the launch of a joint venture and the inauguration of the Singapore-France Innovation Forum. The visit aims to further enhance strategic partnership between the two nations.

site_title: At Ultra festival, finding 'best energy' through EDM
summary: At the Ultra Music Festival in Miami, 165,000 revellers gathered to celebrate electronic dance music (EDM) and its booming scene. The event, featuring top DJs like Tiesto and Martin Garrix, drew attendees from around the world, who showcased their creativity with elaborate costumes and hairstyles. The festival's energy was described as "the coolest time you can possibly have" and "a place where everybody gets together and there's no hate, there's no differences." The EDM industry has grown significantly, with analyst Kevin Watson estimating a $7.1 billion global industry, and is now accessible to fans through streaming, despite high-profile detractors like Perry Farrell.

site_title: Britain to review security at parliament, may deploy more armed guards
summary: Britain will review security at parliament after a gate was left open during a deadly attack that killed four people, including a policeman, in central London. The attack, carried out by British-born Khalid Masood, was the fifth terrorist attack in the UK in 2017. The review aims to address criticism of the security measures in place.

site_title: Shell to start cleaning up 2008 Nigeria oil spills in April, says official
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will begin cleaning up 2008 oil spills in a Nigerian Delta community in April, after a £55 million settlement was reached in 2015. The clean-up process, which will take several years, involves removing oil from water surfaces and restoring damaged landscapes. The Bodo Mediation Initiative, led by Inemo Samiama, facilitated the agreement between Shell and the community, and international contractors have been appointed to carry out the work. Shell's Nigeria subsidiary, Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria, remains committed to the clean-up effort.

site_title: Trump vows to develop 'great' health plan after stinging defeat
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to develop a "great" healthcare plan after his bill to repeal and replace Obamacare failed, citing the program's "imploding" state. Despite the setback, it's unclear when Republicans will return to healthcare reform, as the party's conservative bloc remains stubborn and Democrats refuse to cooperate. Trump declared himself "disappointed" but blamed Democrats and Washington's "arcane" ways for the defeat, while his vice-president Mike Pence urged both parties to come together and end the "Obamacare nightmare."

site_title: Few foreigners in eastern Germany, but chill of xenophobia persists
summary: In eastern Germany, particularly in Frankfurt an der Oder, xenophobia persists despite having few foreigners. The region's economic struggles, high unemployment, and resentment towards migrants have contributed to the AfD party's success, with its deputy chairman running for a national seat. A social worker feels isolated due to her colleagues' unfriendly attitude towards foreigners. Experts attribute this to a "structural" problem of racism stemming from the former East Germany's authoritarian regime and the economic gap with western Germany.

images.alt_text: Snow on the streets of Frankfurt an der Oder in this picture taken in January. Migrants face an equally cold reception in this eastern German city where unemployment is far above the national average.

site_title: UK minister seeks a way around encryption in wake of attack
summary: British interior minister Amber Rudd calls for technology companies to cooperate with law enforcement and stop providing encrypted messaging services to terrorists, citing the recent attack in London. Rudd appeals to WhatsApp and other encrypted messaging apps to help law enforcement agencies, rather than introducing new legislation. Experts argue that banning end-to-end encryption would not have prevented the attack, and that companies have a responsibility to engage with government and law enforcement.

site_title: Trump setback casts doubt on US reflation play
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration failed to pass a healthcare bill, casting doubt on its ability to deliver on election promises, including a fiscal plan with tax cuts and infrastructure spending. This setback may impact the administration's ability to pass other key agenda items, including tax cuts and infrastructure spending. The collapse of the healthcare vote has led to a decline in Trump's poll numbers and power, and Wall Street's confidence is rattled, potentially leading to a volatile period for markets.

images.alt_text: The failure of the Donald Trump adminstration on Friday to convince US lawmakers to repeal Obamacare and pass new healthcare legislation will undoubtedly cast doubt on the administration's ability to deliver on its election campaign promises.

site_title: NY skyscrapers adapt to climate change
summary: The American Copper Buildings in Manhattan, a 764-apartment complex, is being built with climate change in mind, featuring resilient architecture to withstand future natural disasters. The project was planned after Hurricane Sandy in 2012, reflecting the evolving real estate industry's response to global warming. The construction comes as luxury real estate drives up financial stakes, with the city's exorbitant prices. This design shift highlights the growing need for climate-resilient architecture in densely populated urban areas.

site_title: Carrie Lam will find it hard to mend rifts
summary: Hong Kong's new Chief Executive-elect Carrie Lam faces challenges in mending the city's growing divisions, particularly over political reform. Despite pledging to unite Hongkongers and address the issue, Lam's campaign strategy focused on "easier subjects" like education, housing, and healthcare. Critics argue that her approach contradicts her promise to heal the divide, and her reluctance to discuss political reform may hinder her ability to bring about other policy changes. Lam's determination and courage to carry out her pledge remain to be seen as she takes office in July.

site_title: New ways to pay
summary: Singapore should promote cashless transactions to encourage electronic payments, given its tech-savvy population and high smartphone penetration. Managing Director Axel Pannes of BMW Group Asia believes in the future of cardless transactions, stating that Singaporeans can adopt this reality. The city-state can achieve this by implementing measures to encourage the use of electronic payments, but the extent of these measures is unclear.

site_title: Businesses hope for revival in fortunes after Sewol's salvage
summary: South Korea's ferry salvage operation three years after the Sewol disaster may revitalize local businesses devastated by the tragedy. The ferry sank in 2014, killing over 300 people, including most schoolchildren, and had a significant impact on the local economy. Tourist businesses, such as guesthouses and seafood vendors, suffered greatly due to the negative publicity and loss of customers. However, recent efforts to raise the wreck and promote the area's natural beauty may lead to an increase in visitors, potentially revitalizing the local economy.

site_title: Director purchases rise sharply
summary: Singapore buyback activity saw a rise in director purchases for the first time in three weeks, with 15 companies recording 30 purchases worth S$2.7 million. Selling activity remained flat, with five companies recording nine disposals worth S$2.5 million. Key buyback transactions included OCBC Bank, Chasen Holdings, and Vibrant Group, with the latter seeing a 9% rebound in its share price since December 2016. Other notable transactions involved EC World Reit, Sunningdale Tech, Union Steel Holdings, and Wee Hur Holdings.

site_title: La Liga moves to our doorsteps
summary: La Liga, Spain's top football league, has opened its fourth office in Asia, in Singapore, to increase its fan base and engage with local football enthusiasts. The move aims to promote Spanish football and its top clubs, including Real Madrid and Barcelona, through exhibition matches, player visits, and grassroots programs. La Liga president Javier Tebas stated that the league has 300 million fans in Asia, and Microsoft will provide social media analytics to help engage fans. This expansion follows a successful migration of English clubs to Asia in the 1970s, which paved the way for La Liga to tap into the Asian market.

site_title: Key markets of Brazil meat resume imports
summary: Brazil won a major victory in its fight to restore credibility amid a tainted meat scandal, with key markets China, Egypt, and Chile lifting their bans on its products. China fully reopened its market for Brazilian meat imports, while Egypt and Chile lifted their bans except on imports from 21 plants under investigation. Other countries, including the European Union, Japan, and Mexico, have announced bans on imports from the affected businesses. The scandal has rocked Brazil's meat export industry, with over 30 people arrested and three plants closed.

site_title: Carrie Lam selected as Hong Kong's next leader
summary: Carrie Lam was elected Hong Kong's next leader by a 1,200-election committee stacked with Beijing loyalists. The election, which took place on March 26, 2017, marked the first time Lam would serve as the city's leader. Most of Hong Kong's 7.3 million voters have no say in the choice of leader, as the city returned to Chinese rule in 1997.

site_title: Traditional media stands a chance to gain advertising market share
summary: Traditional media, including TV and radio, have a chance to regain market share in the global $525 billion advertising market as major advertisers withdraw ads from Google and Facebook due to ineffective content controls. Despite Google and Facebook's promises of self-regulation, concerns remain over the spread of hate and offensive content online. GroupM estimates that digital's share of global ad expenditure will rise from 31% in 2016 to 33% in 2017, while TV's share remains at 42%. Analysts predict a shift towards more targeted and content-driven advertising, potentially benefiting traditional media.

site_title: Are dividends good?
summary: A debate on the merits of dividends has long been a topic in corporate finance and investing. Dividends are payments made by companies to shareholders, representing a portion of their profits. While some argue that dividends are beneficial, providing a regular source of income, others claim that they can be detrimental, as they may divert funds from future growth initiatives. The "bird in the hand" theory suggests that dividends are preferred over reinvested profits, as they are risk-free and provide immediate cash. However, critics argue that withholding dividends can lead to higher returns in the long run. Ultimately, the value of dividends depends on the company's industry, cash flows, and management's priorities.

site_title: EU powerhouses fire Brexit warning shots
summary: EU leaders France and Germany have warned Britain that it will not receive any concessions on Brexit negotiations, which begin next week. British Prime Minister Theresa May will formally notify Brussels of the UK's intention to leave the EU. German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Britain's departure would not undermine the free movement of goods, people, and services within the European single market. French President Francois Hollande acknowledged the need for an amicable divorce, but warned that some pain is inevitable, and the EU will ensure Britain pays the consequences.

images.alt_text: EU powerhouses France and Germany on Saturday warned Britain to expect no favours from Brussels once negotiations on the terms of Brexit finally get under way next week.

site_title: Update: Hong Kong's divisive new leader faces tough task
summary: Hong Kong's new leader Carrie Lam, a 59-year-old career civil servant, faces a challenging task in calming the city's divided society. Voted in as chief executive by a Beijing-weighted committee, critics say she will only further polarize the city. Lam has a tainted image among activists due to her association with her former boss and promotion of a Beijing-backed reform package. She has promised to build consensus and "restore faith and hope" in Hong Kong, but her commitment to revisiting the political reform debate remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's new leader Carrie Lam, seen as tough and capable by supporters but hated by the pro-democracy camp, faces a difficult task in calming political tensions in the divided city.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: Ivan Choong, a Business Development Manager, shares his weekend routine, which involves a morning gym session at Fitness First, followed by a coffee at Costa Coffee. He enjoys dinner at Tanuki Raw for its Japanese fusion menu and excellent service, and also recommends Asanoya Bakery's matcha salted egg croissant. Choong is also an avid theatre enthusiast, often participating in acting workshops, watching performances, or acting in plays, including a current role in "Itsy," a musical by The Finger Players.

site_title: British Airways starts scanning faces for faster boarding
summary: British Airways has started using facial recognition technology to speed up boarding at London Heathrow Airport. The system, which is initially used for domestic routes, captures a traveller's features along with their boarding pass and verifies their identity at the gate, eliminating the need to show documents. Three gates are currently using the equipment, with 33 more planned for the coming months. The airline aims to expand the system to international flights in the future, joining other airports such as Paris Charles de Gaulle and Amsterdam Schiphol in testing facial-recognition technology.

site_title: Platform collapse at power plant in China kills 9
summary: A platform collapse at a power plant in Guangzhou, China's Guangdong province, has killed 9 people and injured 2. The accident occurred at the No 7 Thermal Power Plant, which is still under construction. The government has launched an investigation into the incident, amid growing anger over lax safety standards in industrial plants. This is one of many accidents in China, which has seen a surge in incidents over the past three decades of rapid economic growth. Authorities have vowed to improve safety measures.

site_title: Banks, telcos, e-commerce players hurt the most by fraud: report (Amended)
summary: A report by Experian highlights the growing threat of fraud in financial services, telecommunications, and e-commerce industries in the region. Credit card fraud is a major concern in Singapore and Australia, while credit application fraud is a problem in Indonesia. The report estimates that 200 billion records have been breached in the past four years, with 8.5% of the Australian population over 15 affected by fraud. The economic cost of fraud is projected to rise, with Australia's economy expected to lose A$1.6 billion annually. Experts warn that the increasing use of the Internet, mobile, and e-commerce, as well as the Internet of Things, will create more opportunities for fraudsters.

site_title: Singtel, Telkomsel launch mobile money transfer service to Indonesia
summary: Singtel and Telkomsel have launched a real-time mobile remittance service to Indonesia, allowing Singapore customers to send money to Indonesian bank accounts through cash-out points. This service, offered under SingCash and Singtel Dash, is expected to enhance the current facility and cater to the 200,000 Indonesians living and working in Singapore who remit over $409 million yearly. The telcos plan to expand cash pick-up points to GraPARI Telkomsel service centres and PT Bank BRI branches in the second half of the year, offering a complete mobile wallet-to-mobile wallet experience.

site_title: Europe: Stocks post weekly decline as risk aversion reigns
summary: European stocks declined for the fourth time in five days, falling 0.2% as investors questioned US President Donald Trump's ability to deliver on growth policies. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index slipped 0.5% for the week, moving away from a 15-month high. Energy shares fell the most, while manufacturing and services data from Germany and France showed strength in the euro-zone economies. Despite this, strategists at Deutsche Bank expect the Stoxx 600 to rise 15% in the next five years.

site_title: Ferrari prancing as Vettel wins in Australia
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Australian Grand Prix for Ferrari, securing his 43rd race victory with a 9.9-second gap to Lewis Hamilton. The win marked Ferrari's first podium since 2015 and ended Mercedes' hopes of a fourth consecutive championship season. Vettel's teammate Valtteri Bottas finished third, and Red Bull's Max Verstappen took fourth place. The victory marked a significant leap in performance for Ferrari, with Vettel praising the team's new car and its reliability.

site_title: Spain's textiles sector dons new colours in rebound from crisis
summary: Spain's textile sector is recovering from a crisis sparked by cut-throat competition from Asia, with the number of firms stabilizing at around 3,500 companies after a decline since 2008. The sector, led by brands like Zara and Mango, has benefited from Spain's economic rebound and the disappearance of less-competitive firms. With a focus on international sales, major retailers have increased their use of Spanish suppliers, and the sector has diversified into higher-value activities such as technical fabrics and clothing production for non-fashion sectors.

site_title: French jobless total falls in February, down 3.2% over one year
summary: France's jobless total decreased by 3,500 to 3,464,400 in February, a 3.2% drop over the past year. This marks a gradual recovery in the labor market, following a stop-and-go trend over the last year. The positive outcome comes ahead of surveys showing a near-six year high growth in the French private sector, suggesting 0.6% economic growth in the first quarter.

site_title: EU takes road to Rome for 60th anniversary
summary: European Union leaders gathered in Rome for the bloc's 60th anniversary, renewing their vows despite Britain's looming divorce from the EU. The 27 leaders, minus Britain, endorsed a declaration of intent for the next decade, amid concerns over migration, eurozone debt, and terrorism. Pope Francis urged the EU to focus on solidarity and social justice, warning that the bloc "risks dying" without a new vision. The summit was marked by divisions over the Rome Declaration, with Poland and Greece pushing for references to social policies and the eurozone, respectively.

site_title: Stephen Hawking appears as hologram in Hong Kong
summary: Renowned physicist Stephen Hawking appeared as a hologram in Hong Kong, discussing his career and answering questions about life on other planets and the impact of Brexit. The 75-year-old spoke to an audience of hundreds, criticizing the "right-wing successes" that threaten scientific innovation. Hawking, who suffers from ALS, communicated via a computer speech synthesiser. This event showcased the growing reach of hologram technology, which has also been used by French presidential candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon and other celebrities.

site_title: China to open more to foreign investment
summary: China plans to reduce the number of sectors closed to foreign investment, aiming for fairer treatment for Chinese firms abroad. Central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan made the announcement during the Boao Forum for Asia. Beijing is waiting for the new US administration's stance on trade and investment negotiations. The move is seen as part of China's efforts to boost overseas investment.

images.alt_text: China will substantially cut the number of sectors not open to foreign investment as it seeks fairer treatment for Chinese firms investing overseas, China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Sunday.

site_title: Laptop ban hits Dubai for 1.1m weekend travellers
summary: Dubai International Airport and Emirates began enforcing a laptop ban on direct flights to the US, affecting 1.1 million weekend travelers, as part of a US ban on electronics larger than a smartphone on flights from eight Middle Eastern countries. The ban, which covers 10 airports, is expected to last until at least October 14. Travelers are subject to increased security checks, with some flights delayed due to thunderstorms. The ban has sparked criticism for targeting majority-Muslim countries, with some travelers shrugging it off as a necessary measure for security.

site_title: Giving back to society through skills development and education
summary: Keppel Corporation, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has been actively giving back to society through skills development and education. The company commits up to 1% of its annual net profits to worthy causes, supporting local communities through initiatives such as education and financial literacy programs. Since its inception, Keppel has disbursed S$25 million in aid for sustainable projects, including a new wetlands center and a hospital's health endowment fund. The company's corporate giving also extends globally, with a recent donation in the Philippines aimed at lifting families out of poverty.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: North Korea crimes to be documented for prosecution someday: UN
summary: The UN Human Rights Council has agreed to document alleged crimes against humanity in North Korea, paving the way for potential prosecution. The resolution, adopted without a vote, calls for North Korea to cooperate with UN investigators and allows for a strengthened human rights office in Seoul to collect testimony and evidence. North Korea has rejected the resolution, labeling it a product of US hostile policy. The move comes amid increased international pressure on the country over its nuclear tests and human rights abuses, with the US imposing fresh sanctions on foreign companies and individuals.

site_title: Keystone approval spells headache for Canada's Trudeau
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau welcomed US President Donald Trump's approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, which will move oil from Alberta to US Gulf Coast refineries. The approval reverses a decision made by former US President Barack Obama and has sparked a feud between environmental activists and the energy industry. Trudeau's government faces a political headache as it struggles to balance its commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions with its support for the oil and gas sector. The approval is expected to boost Trudeau's support among center-right voters and a fledgling progressive government in Alberta, but will likely face opposition from the left.

site_title: Uber self-driving vehicle involved in Arizona crash
summary: A self-driving Uber vehicle was involved in a crash in Tempe, Arizona, with the Volvo SUV on its side. The incident occurred while the car was carrying passengers and may have resulted in injuries. This is the latest setback for Uber, which is facing multiple crises, including a sexist workplace scandal and allegations of stealing autonomous driving designs. The crash contrasts with Waymo's self-driving car tests, which have mostly resulted in minor incidents. An investigation is pending to determine the cause of the crash and its potential impact on Uber's self-driving car program.

site_title: My favourite book
summary: Cheryl Strayed's book "Tiny Beautiful Things" is a compilation of advice on love and life, compiled from her work as an Internet agony aunt. The book received praise for its "brilliant, moving, and humane" advice. The article does not provide further details on the book or its impact.

site_title: Madrid turns down offer to build 2.2b euro entertainment project
summary: Madrid has rejected a 2.2 billion euro entertainment project proposal from US real estate developer Cordish Companies, citing high public costs and economic uncertainty. The 134-hectare complex, dubbed 'Live! Resorts Madrid,' would have created over 50,000 jobs but required 340 million euros in public infrastructure investment. This is the second failed project of its kind in Madrid, following Las Vegas Sands' abandoned 2013 plans for a US$3 billion 'Eurovegas' resort due to government demands.

site_title: US judge grants Amos Yee's asylum request
summary: A US immigration judge granted asylum to Singaporean blogger Amos Yee, citing persecution for his political opinions. Yee, 18, was jailed twice in Singapore for online comments critical of the government. The judge ruled Yee's prosecution and maltreatment by authorities constituted persecution on account of his political opinions, supporting his right to free speech. Yee is now eligible for release after being held in US immigration detention since December 2016. The decision is seen as a victory for free speech and an independent judiciary, with Yee's attorney praising the ruling as a safeguard against government censorship.

site_title: South Korea's Sewol ferry lifted onto salvage ship
summary: South Korea's sunken Sewol ferry has been successfully lifted onto a semi-submersible ship, a major step towards returning the vessel to port. The salvage operation, nearly three years after the ferry sank, killing over 300 people, is believed to be one of the largest recoveries of a wreck in one piece. The 145-meter ship is expected to be docked at Mokpo port in early April, where divers will search for bodies. The investigation into the disaster, which was largely man-made, concluded that an illegal redesign, overloaded cargo, inexperienced crew, and a questionable relationship between ship operators and state regulators contributed to the tragedy.

site_title: Tillerson to meet Nato members next week
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will meet with Nato members on March 31 in Brussels, after initially planning to skip the meeting. The meeting comes after his trip to Ankara, Turkey, and may replace a planned foreign ministers' meeting on April 5 and 6. The move has raised questions about the US commitment to its allies, following his refusal to attend the long-planned talks.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips in dramatic session as health bill pulled
summary: US stocks declined in a dramatic session on Friday as the Republican healthcare bill was pulled due to a lack of votes. Despite initial fears that the bill's failure would negatively impact President Trump's economic agenda, some analysts believe the bill's demise could pave the way for tax reform. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.29%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.19%.

site_title: New York launches immigrant defence initiative
summary: New York state has launched an immigrant defense initiative with $1 million in funding, providing legal assistance and representation to immigrants threatened by recent changes in immigration policies. The statewide coalition will offer services including deportation proceedings, lawful permanent residence, and work permits, regardless of residency status. The initiative, led by the state's Office for New Americans, aims to ensure all New Yorkers have access to their full rights under the law, following actions by President Donald Trump. Over 200 attorneys will volunteer their time to reach out to immigrants and provide greater access to representation.

images.alt_text: "New York is a beacon of hope and opportunity for all, and immigrants have always been part of the fabric of this great state," Governor Andrew Cuomo said.

site_title: Britain's poorest, excluded from banking, turn to high-cost credit
summary: Britain's poorest are being excluded from the financial system, relying on high-cost credit products such as payday loans and rent-to-own schemes. 1.7 million adults lack a bank account, and 2.6 million struggle with severe debt. The poor pay a "poverty premium" for credit, with those in the lowest income brackets defined as £130-£240 per week being particularly at risk. A report calls for banks to have a duty of care towards customers and for regulation of high-cost credit, but data on the impact of 2014 guidelines on basic bank accounts is not yet available.

site_title: Naked people slaughter a sheep at Auschwitz death camp
summary: Fourteen people, aged 20-27, in their twenties, desecrated the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp in Poland by slaughtering a sheep, stripping naked, and chaining themselves together in front of the infamous "Arbeit macht frei" gate. They draped a white banner with the word "love" over the gate and used a drone to film the incident. Those involved, including Poles and foreigners, have been detained and are expected to be charged with desecrating a monument. The act has sparked outrage and is seen as a reprehensible attempt to use the memorial site for a protest.

site_title: Risk tolerance in your investment strategy
summary: An investor's ability to take risk in their investment strategy is determined by factors such as investible assets and cashflow needs. A clear investment objective allows for firm decisions during volatile markets. Investors should choose investments that fit their risk profile, and consider their time horizon when selecting investments. A properly diversified and managed portfolio can reduce risk, but may not achieve desired financial goals if recovery time is inadequate. Investors should discuss their risk with an adviser and adjust their portfolio as needed to match their expected return with risk taken.

site_title: Trump gets his own boulevard in Albania
summary: A town in central Albania, Kamza, has renamed a boulevard in honor of US President Donald Trump, calling him "a revolutionary model" for the world. The move comes after Trump's election victory last year, where he was made an honorary citizen. The town's admiration contrasts with that of the Socialist Prime Minister Edi Rama, who preferred Hillary Clinton. The renaming has sparked mixed reactions among the town's 100,000 inhabitants, with some expressing enthusiasm and others criticizing the decision.

images.alt_text: A town in central Albania has renamed a boulevard in honour of Donald Trump, calling the US president "a revolutionary model" for the world.

site_title: How to cope with being sidelined at work
summary: A person being "sidelined" at work, meaning they're no longer involved in crucial projects or valued by their team, can be distressing. Warning signs include being passed over for projects, given mundane tasks, and being excluded from meetings. To address the issue, employees should objectively evaluate their situation and consider seeking feedback from their boss or peers. It may be due to performance issues or politics, and employees should be prepared to discuss their performance and any misalignments with their supervisor. If the issue persists, employees may need to consider looking for a new job or seeking advice from trusted senior management.

site_title: French Mercedes owners take legal action after German emissions probe
summary: Three French Mercedes owners have filed complaints against Daimler, alleging consumer fraud over diesel engine emissions, following a German investigation. The owners claim their vehicles were affected by a partnership deal with Renault, which supplied diesel engines to Mercedes. The complaints come after a German investigation into allegations of fraud and misleading advertising over vehicle emissions. The French authorities are considering action against Daimler and other carmakers involved in the testing program. This move is part of a broader investigation into vehicle emissions and consumer protection in France.

site_title: SingPost launches trial of mail delivery e-vehicle
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal service provider, has launched a trial of a mail delivery e-vehicle, developed in collaboration with TUMCREATE. The three-wheeler, powered by an electric drive, aims to improve delivery efficiency, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and enhance rider experience. The trial will take place on two delivery routes and will run until April 7, 2017, with postmen providing feedback for further development. The vehicle features a specially designed storage system that can reduce delivery time by up to 40 minutes and is made from environmentally sustainable materials.

site_title: ST Engineering to enter new phase of growth: CEO

The defense business will remain core, while the firm will focus on research and development to ensure its future success. Chong aims to strengthen the workforce and enhance innovation culture, citing recent achievements such as developing Singapore's first commercial Earth Observation Satellite and a cybersecurity research lab.

site_title: STI drops 0.85% over week ahead of US healthcare vote

summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the country's citizens to remain resilient and united in the face of potential terror attacks, warning that no protection is fool-proof. He stressed that Singaporeans must be aware of the threat and be prepared to rally together in the event of an attack, while also carrying on with their lives.

These companies plan to roll out thousands of shared bicycles and expand operations in the next year. summary: The JW Marriott Hotel Singapore South Beach has implemented new technologies to improve efficiency and guest experience, following the government's Hotel Industry Transformation Map (ITM). site_title: They used to smash banks for Pol Pot. Now they're founding them

Led by Tep Khunnal, a devoted former personal secretary to Pol Pot, the community has established a thriving agricultural export industry, with many ex-Khmer Rouge officials owning businesses, including a microfinance bank and a joint-stock company running the local market. The country's exclusive islands, such as Dolphin Island and LikuLiku Lagoon Resort, offer unique experiences like over-water bures and stunning coral reefs. Fiji's tourism industry has grown steadily since 2010, with a five percent increase in 2016, thanks to the introduction of direct flights from Singapore. However, the industry faces challenges, including the impact of cyclones and the need to balance tourism with environmental conservation. To maintain its unique culture and ecology, Fiji is shifting towards a boutique tourism model, emphasizing its natural charms and Fijian hospitality.

site_title: S'pore-based hedge fund startups break the norm to reel in investors
summary: Asian hedge fund startups are challenging the traditional 2% management fee and 20% profit-sharing model, aiming to attract investors wary of high fees. Kit Trading Fund, Noviscient, and Gordian Capital Singapore Pte are among firms that have restructured their fees, offering lower costs and more favorable profit-sharing terms. This shift is a response to investor pressure following years of subpar returns, with some funds even absorbing losses to protect investors.

site_title: The Chef Recommends...
summary:
Four expat chefs from Austria, Peru, Venezuela, and Ireland share their favorite eateries and dishes. 

In Peru, Daniel Chavez recommends OLA Cocina del Mar for its fusion cuisine and Majado de Yuca dish. In Ireland, Andrew Walsh suggests Mitchell's Seafood Restaurant for its seafood chowder and Anton's Cafe for its warm fish pie. In Venezuela, Gisela Salazar Golding recommends La casa del llano for its arepas and El Mercado De Conejeros for its empanadas. In Austria, Stephan Zoisl recommends Steirereck for its seasonal menu and Schweizer Haus for its pork knuckles and beer.

site_title: Grab raising over US$1.5b in new funding round
summary: Grab, the ride-sharing company, is raising over $1.5 billion in new funding backed by SoftBank Group Corp, potentially setting a record for South-east Asia. This round, led by SoftBank, could give Grab a valuation of over $3 billion, eclipsing its previous $750 million raise. The company is expanding into new markets and developing its payments platform, competing with Uber and Go-Jek Indonesia.

site_title: Hong Kong likely to choose Beijing's pick for leader amid economic malaise
summary: Hong Kong is set to select Beijing's preferred candidate for its leader, despite a lack of democracy and widespread discontent among middle-class residents. The election committee, stacked with Beijing loyalists, will choose between Carrie Lam and John Tsang, with Lam expected to win due to Beijing's backing. Critics say Beijing's interference in the election violates the city's autonomy, and the outcome may further divide the city, exacerbating economic hardship and high property prices.

site_title: Pan-United regroups forex translation differences in FY16 results
summary: PAN-UNITED Corporation has filed a corrigendum for its FY2016 financial statement, grouping foreign currency translation differences of S$4.3 million with the disposal of its tug and barge business, now reporting a total loss from discontinuing operations of S$10.3 million. This change aims to better reflect the transaction's nature and present it in accordance with accounting standards FRS 21.

site_title: February factory output growth beats 10% analyst forecast
summary: Singapore's factory output growth exceeded analyst expectations, posting a 12.6% increase in February, beating a 10% forecast. Economists are closely monitoring the Monetary Authority of Singapore's upcoming April statement, speculating it may hint at a potential interest rate tightening move later this year. The strong manufacturing sector data has sparked interest in the MAS's policy stance, with economists eager to gauge the likelihood of future monetary adjustments.

images.alt_text: Friday's data showed that factory output in February continued to grow. It grew by 12.6 per cent from a year ago, beating economists' expectations of a 10 per cent increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares closer lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.250 points to 1,745.750 on Friday, closing lower. The index was influenced by a higher volume of 3.697 billion lots worth RM2.527 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 590 to 312.

site_title: Pennsylvania town with a population of 60 up for sale
summary: Pennsylvania's one-time company town, Reduction, is up for sale with a $1.5 million asking price. The town, home to 60 residents, was built in the 1930s to house workers at a long-shut garbage-processing plant. The town's 19 brick houses were purchased by the Stawovy family in the 1940s, and they are now looking to sell the town to fund their retirement. The sale includes a one-room schoolhouse that was converted into a duplex residence, and the foundation of the processing plant is the only remaining structure from the original operation.

site_title: Two non-exec directors at S i2i quit, CEO appointed exec director
summary: Two non-executive directors at S i2i Ltd have resigned, citing "personal preoccupations", amidst shareholder pressure for the company to exit the regulator's watch-list. The CEO has been appointed as an executive director, indicating a shift in the board's composition. Shareholder activist views the resignations as a collaborative posture prioritizing shareholders' interests, suggesting a possible resolution to the company's regulatory issues.

site_title: Robots seen taking 30 percent of UK jobs with women at lower risk: study
summary: A UK study by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP found that up to 30% of British jobs could be taken over by robots by 2030, affecting 10 million people. However, women are less likely to face redundancy due to their presence in sectors requiring social skills like education and health. Men are more at risk, particularly in jobs requiring lower education levels. Researchers suggest that jobs may change rather than disappear, presenting an opportunity for men and women to break down traditional gender gaps and progress in careers, provided they upskill or access training opportunities.

site_title: Nam Cheong 'confident' of restructuring existing debt
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singapore-based offshore support vessel builder, expressed confidence in restructuring its existing debt. Despite auditors' concerns about the company's ability to stay in business, Nam Cheong stated it's in discussions with major lenders and stakeholders. The company has engaged a financial adviser and disclosed sufficient information to the public for orderly trading. Shares remained flat at 2.8 Singapore cents, having lost 40.4% of their value in a week.

site_title: Fight nights galore
summary: The Singapore Indoor Stadium will host three major events in a month: One Championship on May 26, UFC on June 17, and WWE, no date specified. This marks a significant boost for the city's entertainment scene. The UFC's return to Singapore comes after a relatively low-key debut three years ago, and the WWE event is expected to draw a large audience. These events will take place in the same venue, showcasing the stadium's versatility and capacity to host a range of events.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: More opportunities for S'pore to work with Vietnam: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said during his recent visit to Vietnam that the country's growth will open more doors for investments, particularly in industrial parks. The success of the seven Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Parks (VSIPs) has attracted US$9 billion in investments and employed 174,000 people. Lee expressed his country's interest in building more VSIPs, including a feasibility study in Quang Tri province and a high-tech software park in Da Nang. Bilateral trade between Singapore and Vietnam stood at S$19.8 billion last year, and Singapore is the top investor in Vietnam among Asean member states.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Malaysia small caps may be too hot now, says fund manager
summary: Malaysia's small-cap stocks may be overvalued, according to fund manager Gan Eng Peng. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Small Cap Index has surged 18% since November, outpacing the large-cap benchmark. The government's plan to invest RM3 billion in the sector has fueled the rally, but Gan warns it's getting harder to find undervalued stocks. Foreign investors are returning, with US$1 billion pumped into Malaysian stocks this year, and Credit Suisse is optimistic on the country's stocks, citing positive earnings revisions and an undervalued ringgit.

site_title: Avoid buying Malaysian small caps now, top manager says
summary: Malaysia's small-cap stocks have surged 18% since November, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Small Cap Index more than doubling its performance compared to the large-cap benchmark. Despite this, top manager Gan Eng Peng of Affin Hwang Asset Management advises investors to avoid buying many small-cap stocks due to high valuations and the recent rally. The government's plan to invest 3 billion ringgit in small and mid-sized companies and promote research is contributing to the sector's growth, but it's not driving gains at the moment.

site_title: Yangzijiang picks up 30% of Chinese investment fund
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, a Chinese shipbuilding company, has acquired a 30% stake in the Jiangsu Nantong Yantai Emerging Investment Fund, a Chinese investment fund focused on small and medium-sized private enterprises in emerging industries. The fund has an authorized share capital of up to 300 million yuan and a seven-year operating term. The investment will make Nantong Yantai an associate of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding.

site_title: Confusion and fear: Theresa May's London attack escape
summary: Theresa May narrowly escaped an attack on parliament in London, where a lone assailant killed four people. The Prime Minister was seen fleeing the scene, looking lost, as she searched for her car. She was escorted by her security team, who eventually apprehended the attacker, Adrian Russell Ajao, who was within three unlocked doors of May. The incident raised questions about the security measures in place around parliament.

site_title: Don't assume all old HDB flats will become eligible for Sers, cautions Lawrence Wong
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong has cautioned that not all old HDB flats will automatically qualify for the Selective En bloc Redevelopment Scheme (Sers), despite initial assumptions. Only 4% of HDB flats since its launch in 1995 have been identified for Sers. The Government will maintain strict selection criteria for eligible blocks.

site_title: London landlords are hoisting for sale signs on office towers
summary: London landlords are selling office towers to investors in the Asia Pacific region, driven by record sales such as the Cheesegrater tower. Demand from Asian investors has remained strong despite the Brexit vote, with yields in London providing resilience against negative headlines. The market is focused on income rather than development risks, with Blackstone Group and Axa SA among those seeking to sell investments that have risen in value. Properties valued at over £2 billion have been offered to investors in the past month, with a strong chance of Asian buyers.

site_title: Free WiFi and meditation as airlines grapple with laptop ban
summary: Turkish and Gulf airlines are offering free WiFi and better in-flight connectivity in response to the US laptop ban, which could impact their business. Etihad and Turkish Airlines plan to roll out 3G data roaming on mobile phones and free WiFi on some aircraft. The restrictions, set to begin in August, will affect high-volume transit passengers and business-class flyers stopping over in Dubai or Doha. Airlines aim to mitigate the ban's impact on their business and maintain connectivity for passengers.

images.alt_text: Turkish and Gulf airlines are touting free WiFi and better in-flight connectivity for smart phones as they scramble to mitigate the impact of a ban on laptops in plane cabins bound for the United States.

site_title: Putin meets France's Le Pen in Moscow
summary: President Vladimir Putin met with Marine Le Pen, the far-right presidential candidate from France, in Moscow on Friday. The meeting came less than a month before the French election, with Putin stressing that Russia does not meddle in French politics. Le Pen, who has called for closer ties with Putin and approved of Moscow's annexation of Crimea, visited Moscow for the first time, meeting with Putin and other Russian officials. The meeting was seen as an attempt to strengthen ties with a European politician who has expressed support for Putin's policies.

images.alt_text: President Vladimir Putin met France's far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen as she visited Moscow on Friday, with the Russian leader stressing that the Kremlin does not meddle in French politics.

site_title: US gives final approval for Keystone XL pipeline
summary: The US government has granted final approval for the Keystone XL pipeline, a 1,900-kilometer oil pipeline from Canadian tar sands to US Gulf Coast refineries. The decision, made by President Donald Trump's administration, reverses the halt imposed by his predecessor, President Barack Obama. The pipeline's construction has sparked environmental concerns, citing the potential risks of oil spills and health impacts from the tar sand oil it will carry. The State Department concluded that the project serves the national interest, paving the way for TransCanada to begin construction.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump's administration said Friday it has granted a permit for TransCanada to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline, giving final approval to a project his predecessor had halted over environmental concerns.

site_title: Connecting the dots
summary: Singapore-based institutions are investing in artificial intelligence (AI) and digital innovation. The Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) has launched an AI and Digital Innovation office to develop design AI skills in students. Meanwhile, National Institute of Education (NIE) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) have partnered to create an AI-focused innovation hub for education technology research. Mining giant BHP and other companies, including Oracle, Grab, and PwC, have also established AI Hubs in Singapore to drive innovation and growth in the sector.

site_title: German private sector growth strongest in 70 months in March
summary: Germany's private sector experienced its strongest growth in 70 months in March, driven by demand for manufactured goods from the US, China, Britain, and the Middle East. The Markit PMI index rose to 57.0, exceeding the consensus forecast and a 50-point threshold separating growth from contraction. This suggests that economic growth will accelerate in the first quarter, with companies accelerating hiring and inflationary pressures rising due to cost pressures. Output expectations strengthened, and sentiment in the services sector was the strongest in over six years.

site_title: Singapore shares close 16 points higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 15.97 points to 3,142.9 on Friday, reducing its weekly loss to 27 points or 0.85%. The index was largely cautious due to US market direction, but a 50-point rise in Dow futures lifted it. Liquidity fell 42% from the previous week to S$1.1 billion.

site_title: Asean's green finance takes root
summary: Asean's green finance market is slowly taking root, with global green bond issuance volumes expected to top $100 billion in 2017. In 2016, the market saw a record $86 billion worth of issuances, with developing markets in Asia, particularly China and India, driving volumes. Asean regulators recognize the importance of green finance in supporting sustainable growth and are encouraging issuers to tap the market. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has introduced a Green Bond Grant Scheme to incentivize more issuers, and other Asean economies are in varying stages of transitioning to low-carbon economies, creating a potential catalyst for growth.

site_title: EU's Juncker says UK's Brexit bill will be around £50b
summary: EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warned that the UK will have to pay a bill of around £50 billion (S$87.3 billion) when it leaves the European Union, citing scientific calculations of the UK's commitments. This estimate is in line with Austrian Chancellor Christian Kern's prediction of 60 billion euros. The size of the exit bill will be a contentious topic in negotiations, with British ministers disputing the large sum. The formal start of the UK's exit process is set to begin on March 29, triggered by Prime Minister Theresa May.

site_title: Turkish minister visits Switzerland as Europe row simmers
summary: Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu visited Switzerland, amid strained relations between Turkey and Europe. The visit came after Turkey was blocked from campaigning on the continent for a referendum on boosting President Erdogan's powers. Swiss Foreign Minister Didier Burkhalter expressed concern over Turkey's human rights record, citing the post-coup purge of alleged Gulen supporters. The visit aimed to address tensions and underscore the validity of Swiss law on Swiss soil.

site_title: China's selfie app Meitu reports smaller loss in 2016
summary: Meitu Inc, a Chinese photo app and mobile phone maker, reported a narrower net loss of 540.5 million yuan (S$109.8 million) in 2016, down 24% from the previous year. Revenue grew to 1.58 billion yuan, driven by smartphone sales accounting for 93% of its revenue. The company's shares have gained 80% since its Hong Kong IPO in December, but analysts warn of potential market volatility due to cross-border speculation. Meitu plans to launch a fashion-focused social e-commerce platform in the first half of 2017.

site_title: LTA scuppers national bicycle-sharing plans as privately-funded firms emerge
summary: The Singapore government has cancelled plans for a national bicycle-sharing system due to the emergence of privately-funded dockless bicycle-sharing services. Chinese firms Mobike, ofo, and local venture oBike have launched operations in the country, rendering a government-run system unnecessary. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) had issued a tender for a 2,300-bicycle system but decided not to award it, citing the private operators' proposals as sufficient alternatives. The LTA will continue to monitor the market and introduce new plans if necessary.

site_title: Hong Kong property agents won't accept China UnionPay cards
summary: Hong Kong property agents have stopped accepting China UnionPay cards for home purchases after receiving a verbal notice from banks. The move follows China's crackdown on capital flight, as the country seeks to stabilize its currency. This ban affects Chinese buyers who use UnionPay cards to transfer money to Hong Kong property agents. The decision is the latest in a series of measures to curb capital outflows, with record-high home prices in Hong Kong.

site_title: Lung Kee's net profit leaps to HK$191.7m for 2016
summary: Lung Kee, a Hong Kong-based mould maker, reported a 50% increase in net profit to HK$191.7 million for 2016, driven by cost control, production efficiency, and other income. Revenue decreased slightly to HK$2.213 billion. The company's directors will recommend a final dividend of 12 HK cents per share, up from last year's 8 cents. This follows the deregistration of a subsidiary in China.

site_title: Quick take: Singapore manufacturing sector seen growing at a more gradual pace
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output rose 12.6% in February, driven by growth in the semiconductor and precision engineering space. Excluding the volatile biomedical segment, output increased 17.1%. This growth indicates a more gradual pace for the sector, contrasting with previous expectations.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Europe: Shares inch lower before US healthcare vote; Credit Suisse up
summary: European shares fell slightly, down 0.2% on the Stoxx 600, as investors awaited a US vote on President Trump's healthcare bill, which has been delayed. Traders expect a negative reaction if the bill is rejected. Credit Suisse rose 0.8% after releasing its report and AGM agenda, while Smiths Group gained 3.7% on positive earnings. The UK's FTSE and Germany's DAX remained flat and down 0.1%, respectively. Markets are cautious ahead of US-EU trade talks and the potential impact on fiscal plans.

site_title: Gold slips as markets await US healthcare vote
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,242.31 per ounce, as markets awaited the outcome of US President Donald Trump's healthcare reforms. A failure to pass the healthcare plan could impact Trump's ability to cut taxes and boost infrastructure, potentially driving investors to gold as a safe haven. This could lead to a second straight week of gains for the metal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on cheaper yen, Toshiba soars
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, driven by a cheaper yen and a surge in Toshiba shares. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 0.93% to 19,262.53, while the Topix index gained 0.88%. Toshiba's stock soared 5.4% after the company expressed renewed optimism about resolving huge losses at its US nuclear unit. The gains were despite US President Trump's latest threats to stocks, which traders are brushing off.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output rose 12.6% in February, driven by growth in the semiconductor and precision engineering space. A bilateral project with China, Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City, broke ground for a neighbourhood centre development and launched a platform for businesses and start-ups. Meanwhile, the Singapore government scrapped plans for a national bicycle-sharing system due to the emergence of privately-funded dockless bicycle-sharing services. Grab is raising over $1.5 billion in new funding, and StarHub announced senior management changes. The Straits Times Index rose 15.97 points to 3,142.9 on Friday.

site_title: Huishan Dairy sinks 85% in Hong Kong
summary: Huishan Dairy Holdings Co's Hong Kong shares plummeted 85% in a single day, wiping out $4.1 billion in market value, before the company halted trading. The sudden crash was attributed to allegations made by Muddy Waters Capital LLC, which shorted the stock, claiming the company overstated its spending and transferred a subsidiary to an undisclosed related party. This is the second major Hong Kong stock to experience a significant decline, following Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd's 47% drop in 2015.

site_title: China-Singapore project making progress
summary: China and Singapore's Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City project made progress with the groundbreaking ceremony for a neighbourhood centre development. The centre, expected to be completed by 2018, will provide government and commercial services, along with a library, theatre, and cultural activity centre. The Ascendas-Singbridge International Launch Pad was also initiated, offering business services, a business lounge, innovation centre, and collaboration centre.

site_title: BOJ chief Kuroda says "no reason" to withdraw stimulus now
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated there's "no reason" to withdraw stimulus now, citing Japan's slow economic recovery and inflation still below the 2% target. Despite global economic growth and US President Donald Trump's administration, Kuroda played down the risk of protectionism, saying the BOJ won't increase interest-rate targets just because overseas long-term interest rates rise. The central bank will maintain its ultra-easy monetary policy stance, and Kuroda emphasized the need to look at underlying inflation trends when making policy decisions.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said there is "no reason" to raise the bank's bond yield targets now with inflation so far from its two per cent target, offering his strongest denial to date of the chance of withdrawing its massive stimulus any time soon.

site_title: Hong Kong charges ship captain over Singapore's Terrex vehicles
summary: Hong Kong charged a ship's captain, Pan Xuejun, over transporting nine Singapore armoured troop carriers without a proper licence, sparking a diplomatic dispute between Hong Kong, Singapore, and China. The vehicles were detained in Hong Kong in November and released in January, following a months-long row over military cooperation with Taiwan. Beijing had protested Singapore's ties with Taiwan, while Singapore had long trained its troops in Taiwan due to land constraints. The incident highlighted strained ties between China and Singapore, with Beijing controlling Hong Kong's foreign affairs.

site_title: Banks lift Australian shares; NZ posts biggest weekly loss of 2017
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Friday, with financials accounting for half of the gains, as banks hiked mortgage rates to cool a hot housing market. The S&P/ASX 200 Index climbed to 5,753.50 points, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 1.2% for its biggest weekly loss of 2017. The out-of-cycle rate hikes come despite the central bank holding rates steady for an eighth straight month, citing risks in home prices and household debt.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won subdued; Samsung group shares slip
summary: South Korean shares and the won remained relatively unchanged on Friday, as investors awaited the outcome of the US healthcare bill vote. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 0.2% at 2,168.95 points. Samsung group shares declined, with Samsung Electronics down 0.7%, Samsung C&T down 7.3%, and Samsung SDS down 8.5%. Foreign investors sold a net 89.4 billion won worth of Kospi shares, despite the won rising 0.7% for the week and Kospi shares gaining 0.2% for the week.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tick up; Huishan Dairy plummets
summary: Hong Kong stocks saw a 0.1% gain, reaching 24,358.27 points, on Friday. Investors are awaiting corporate earnings and a US healthcare bill vote, with analysts expressing concerns about President Trump's ability to deliver on promises if the bill fails. Most sectors declined, except for CNOOC Ltd, which jumped 4% after reporting above-estimate profits. China Huishan Dairy Holdings shares plummeted 85% before trade was halted due to a short-seller report questioning the firm's profits.

site_title: Poll finds unprecedented uncertainty among French voters before presidential election
summary: A poll conducted by Odoxa for franceinfo radio found that 43% of French voters are uncertain about who to vote for in the upcoming presidential election, marking an unprecedented level of indecision. Opinion polls suggest Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen will lead in the first round, with Macron likely to win the May 7 run-off. The uncertainty reflects voter hesitation between several candidates, with 60% of Le Pen's and Fillon's potential voters having made up their minds, compared to 47% for Macron. The poll highlights the volatility of the election campaign.

images.alt_text: Opinion polls show independent centrist Emmanuel Macron(left) and far-right leader Marine Le Pen likely to lead in the first round of the election on April 23 and that these two candidates would go through to a May 7 run-off that Macron would win easily.

site_title: London attacker Khalid Masood was a criminal with militant links
summary: Khalid Masood, the 52-year-old London attacker who killed at least four people in the deadliest attack on British soil since 2005, was considered a low-risk individual by intelligence officers before the attack. Despite having previous convictions for assaults and possessing offensive weapons, Masood was not under investigation for terrorism-related offenses. He was a former teacher and Muslim convert who had lived in Birmingham, a hotbed for British Islamists, but had no known links to the Islamic State. The attack was claimed by the Islamic State, with authorities assuming Masood was inspired by international terrorism.

site_title: Lexus set to enter India to target increasingly affluent buyers
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is set to introduce its luxury brand Lexus to India, marking its entry into the second-most populous country after China. The move comes as India's growing affluent population and "Make in India" program encourage investments in local manufacturing. Lexus will face competition from established luxury brands such as Audi, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz. Toyota is also exploring manufacturing partnerships with Suzuki Motor Corp and plans to export vehicles from India, following similar initiatives by Volkswagen AG and PSA Group. The company's move aims to tap into India's growing luxury car market.

site_title: Global gas market riven by glut gets eager buyer in Thailand
summary: Thailand is set to boost its liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports by over 70% this year, driven by a decline in domestic production. The country aims to increase its LNG imports to 5 million tons, with plans to expand terminals and consider investing in upstream projects. Despite a global LNG glut, Thailand sees opportunities to buy more fuel, with spot prices having fallen 60% over the past three years. Analysts predict Thailand's LNG imports will rise to 7.4 million tons by 2020 and 11.5 million by 2025, making it a key market for LNG sellers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars at 1-week lows as US reflation trade falters
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell to one-week lows on Friday due to investor concerns about US fiscal stimulus. The Australian dollar dropped 0.7% for the week, its largest decline since December, as traders unwound carry trades on fears of a healthcare bill failure affecting President Trump's other fiscal measures. The New Zealand dollar also fell 0.3% to a 17-month low. The declines were attributed to a drop in iron ore prices and a delay in US fiscal stimulus, rather than a complete halt.

site_title: Deutsche Bank commits to London with new UK headquarters
summary: Deutsche Bank has entered into exclusive talks to relocate its UK headquarters to a building under construction at 21 Moorfields in London's financial district. The bank will lease the building for 25 years, with staff expected to start moving in 2023. This move comes amid a decline in corporate demand for office space in London following the Brexit vote. The bank's overhaul plan, announced earlier this month, will result in additional job losses.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG is in exclusive talks to move its UK headquarters to a building being constructed at 21 Moorfields in the City of London financial district.

site_title: Credit Suisse says CEO Thiam paid 11.9m swiss francs in 2016
summary: Credit Suisse's CEO Tidjane Thiam received 11.9 million Swiss francs in 2016, a significant increase from 4.57 million francs in 2015. The bank reported a 2.71 billion franc net loss in 2016, mainly due to a settlement in a residential mortgage-backed securities case. In contrast, UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti received 13.7 million francs for 2016.

site_title: Effissimo says expects long-term price gains with Toshiba stake purchase
summary: Singapore-based fund Effissimo has purchased an 8% stake in Toshiba Corp, giving it a 944 billion yen market value, with shares soaring 7.6% following the announcement. Effissimo expects long-term price gains from its investment, despite Toshiba's financial woes, including a US$6.3 billion writedown and potential sales of its US nuclear unit and memory chip unit. The fund's purchase is seen as a rare vote of confidence for the embattled conglomerate, bringing some stability to shareholders.

site_title: Grab raising US$1.5b in new funding round
summary: Grab, the largest rival to Uber in South-east Asia, is raising over US$1.5 billion in a new funding round backed by SoftBank Group Corp, Tiger Global Management, and GGV Capital. This funding could be a record for South-east Asia, surpassing Grab's previous US$750 million round. SoftBank is pledging about US$1 billion in the funding, which will give Grab a valuation of over US$4 billion. The new funding round is part of a larger US$1.5 billion raise, with Grab previously raising US$750 million in September.

site_title: Singapore industrial output up 12.6% in Feb
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output rose 12.6% in February compared to the previous year, driven by growth in the semiconductor and precision engineering sectors. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output increased 17.1%. The electronics cluster saw a 39.8% year-on-year increase, with semiconductors rising 63.6%.

site_title: Asia: Traders on edge ahead of key US healthcare vote
summary: Asian investors are on edge ahead of a delayed US healthcare vote, which is seen as crucial to President Donald Trump's growth-drive agenda. The bill's failure would threaten infrastructure spending, tax cuts, and deregulation, key drivers of the markets' surge. Despite the delay, many analysts believe the bill will pass, with Tokyo and other markets showing positive signs. A vote on the reforms is now set for Friday, with the White House warning that failure would keep Obamacare in place.

site_title: Japan PM Abe denies he or wife made donations to principal of scandal-hit school
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and his wife Akie have denied making donations to the principal of a scandal-hit school, Moritomo Gakuen. The school is at the center of a controversy over a land deal in which the school bought property for a fraction of the appraisal price. Abe has said he would resign if evidence was found that he or his wife intervened in the land deal. The scandal has chipped away at Abe's support, with his approval rating falling 10 points to 56% in a recent poll.

site_title: StarHub announces senior management changes
summary: StarHub has announced senior management changes, effective April 3. Chong Yoke Sin will become chief enterprise business group, replacing an unnamed person. Mock Pak Lum will become chief business development officer, taking over from another unnamed person. Chong Siew Loong will head the network engineering division, replacing the current chief technology officer. Kevin Lim will retire by the end of 2017 as chief commercial officer.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,128.56 on Friday, with 47.6 million shares changing hands. The most actively traded counter was Chasen, which rose S$0.007 to S$0.057. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 37, marking a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: South Korean group in advanced talks to buy stake in AirAsia leasing unit
summary: A South Korean group, Kotam, is in advanced talks to acquire a majority stake in AirAsia Bhd's aircraft leasing unit, Asia Aviation Capital, valued at approximately $900 million. The deal, if successful, would mark South Korea's largest entry into the global aircraft leasing sector, valued at $256 billion. State lender Korea Development Bank is reportedly providing funding for the deal. AirAsia has been seeking buyers for its leasing unit since last year, and negotiations with Kotam are ongoing, with a Chinese bidder still in the mix.

site_title: Australia: Teenager pleads guilty to Anzac Day terror plot
summary: A 16-year-old Australian teenager pleaded guilty to planning a terrorist attack at an Anzac Day service in Sydney. He was arrested last year and charged with plotting to harm others. The guilty plea was made in a Parramatta Children's Court, with the case set to resume next month. The incident is the latest in a series of cases involving radicalised youth in Australia.

site_title: Samsung apologises to shareholders for involvement in scandals
summary: Samsung Electronics Co apologized to shareholders for its involvement in scandals that led to the ouster of South Korea's president and the recall of its Note 7 smartphones. Vice Chairman Kwon Oh Hyun delivered the apology, citing the company's failure in trying new technology and promising to improve governance. Samsung denies wrongdoing, particularly in relation to the trial of heir Jay Y Lee, who faces bribery and embezzlement charges. The company is reviewing its options, including a potential stock split, and is under pressure from investors to address corporate governance concerns.

site_title: Malaysia Feb inflation rate at 4.5% y-o-y, highest in 8 years
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index rose to 4.5% in February, the highest rate in 8 years, driven by increased costs of transport and food. This surpasses the previous high of 5.7% in November 2008.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won subdued, Samsung group shares weaken
summary: Seoul shares experienced subdued movement on Friday, with the Samsung group shares weakening. Samsung Electronics dropped over 1%, while Samsung C&T Corp and Samsung SDS Co Ltd plummeted by over 8%. Investors are waiting to see the outcome of US President Donald Trump's efforts to pass a healthcare bill. The broader market is influenced by uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff policies.

images.alt_text: Most South Korean shares and the won showed subdued movement early on Friday, but Samsung group shares fell, some sharply, after Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said it was difficult to adopt a holding company structure at this time.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise 1%, investors eye US healthcare vote
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Friday, driven by gains in financials and healthcare stocks, recovering from earlier losses amid speculation about a US healthcare vote. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 56.85 points to 5,764.80. CSL Ltd and Cochlear Ltd led the healthcare index, while iron ore miner Fortescue Metals and "big four" banks also saw gains. The US House of Representatives delay on the healthcare bill vote helped to boost Australian stocks, with gold stocks losing some ground.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat after govt unveils stimulus package
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Friday, closing 0.1% lower at 9,925.43, amid uncertainty from US-China trade tensions and a stimulus package announced by the government. The electronics subindex declined 0.1%, while TSMC dropped 0.8%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.498 per US dollar, near a two-year high. Investors remained cautious due to high valuations, with the stock index rising 7% this year.
