However, the article suggests that Trump is not torn between the two groups, but rather between his electoral base and the Republican Establishment, with the latter prioritizing free markets and corporate interests. As a result, Trump's economic policies may benefit businesses and the middle class, but not necessarily the voters who elected him.

site_title: Natural Cool appoints directors to new roles
summary: Natural Cool Holdings, a Singapore-based air-conditioning firm, has appointed two directors to new roles. Independent non-executive chairman Goh Teck Sia, 67, will advise the company on law enforcement matters for a three-month period, while executive director Wong Leon Keat, 42, has taken on the role of chief corporate officer, overseeing finance, human resources, and business development. The appointments come after a shareholder revolt in February, which led to the installation of a new board.

site_title: Keen competition keeping S'pore motor premiums steady
summary: Singapore's motor insurance premiums remain steady this year due to keen competition, with new players FWD and Auto & General entering the market. Insurers posted an underwriting profit of S$87.4 million, down 27.7% from 2015. The motor portfolio accounted for 31.5% of gross premiums, with the loss ratio falling to 53.9% from 55.9% in 2015. Big 3 insurers NTUC Income and AXA have maintained their premium rates, while AIG's premium decreased by 11.5%. The General Insurance Association advises underwriting prudence and careful claims handling to sustain healthy underwriting results.

site_title: First Origin to buy HK Life Insurance for HK$7.1b
summary: First Origin International Ltd, a Hong Kong-based investment firm, has agreed to acquire Hong Kong Life Insurance Ltd for HK$7.1 billion, marking the latest insurance deal in the territory. The deal involves five Hong Kong-based financial institutions, with OCBC Wing Hang Bank being the largest shareholder with a 33% stake. Hong Kong Life Insurance, founded in 2001, is one of the last remaining independent life businesses in the financial centre.

site_title: Mapletree eyeing greater expansion across Vietnam
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based real estate developer, has officially opened its first office development in Vietnam, the 17-storey Mapletree Business Centre in Ho Chi Minh City. The office space features international Grade A specifications and has attracted local and international firms from various industries. The development is part of the US$360 million Saigon South Place Complex, which also includes a mixed-use development, residential component, and serviced apartment. Mapletree's regional CEO, Wendy Koh, says the project's success is an "endorsement" of the company's credibility in the region, and the company is planning to expand its portfolio in Vietnam, including greenfield projects and investments in other cities.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Grab pools taxis and private cars on dynamic fares into JustGrab
summary: Grab is launching a new service called JustGrab, merging its private-hire car fleet with taxis to offer a single platform with dynamic fares. Over 10,500 taxis will join the service, which will debut among the general public on March 29. Exclusive tie-ups with taxi firms and a streamlined fare structure are expected to give Grab market dominance. The new service will replicate GrabCar's fare structure, capping the maximum fare at S$100, and may lead to a snowball effect in helping Grab achieve dominance in the transport market.

site_title: Apple's next big thing is augmented reality
summary: Apple is investing heavily in augmented reality (AR) technology, forming a team of experts from hardware and software veterans, digital-effects wizards, and Hollywood professionals. The company aims to bring AR to the masses, with plans to release digital spectacles that could connect wirelessly to an iPhone and beam content to the wearer. Apple believes AR will be an easier sell than virtual reality (VR) due to its less intrusive nature. The global market for AR products is expected to surge 80% to $165 billion by 2024, making it a key area for the company to dominate the next generation of gadgetry.

site_title: Continued yen slide will have some negative side effects: BOJ deputy chief
summary: Japan's continuously falling yen is not beneficial to its economy, according to Bank of Japan (BOJ) deputy governor Kikuo Mr. Iwata. A weak currency has negative side effects, such as higher import costs and reduced competitiveness. The BOJ aims to achieve 2% inflation, but not through a weak yen, but rather through wage and productivity increases. The yen has fallen 17% since 2013, but Japanese consumer prices remain below the 2% target, prompting concerns about the BOJ's policy.

site_title: Share prices drift in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended 7.13 points lower at 3,158.57 on Tuesday, with low trading volume and few market-moving events. The O&G sector stabilized despite Ezra Holdings' US Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing over the weekend. Local banks fell slightly, while commodity firm Noble Group and coffeeshop operator Kimly saw gains. M1's substantial shareholders are reviewing their stake, potentially leading to a sale, which could impact the telco's valuation.

site_title: Philippines to protest China's planned construction on disputed shoal
summary: The Philippines plans to file a strong protest against China's planned construction on Scarborough Shoal, a disputed shoal in the South China Sea. The move comes after China announced preparatory work for an environmental monitoring station, which the Philippines considers an invasion of its sovereignty. The Philippines will renew its ties with the US, which has warned Beijing against carrying out land reclamation work on the shoal. The dispute has escalated tensions in the region, with China having already installed missiles and radar on some of its man-made islands.

site_title: Want to buy a new car online? You almost can - through a dealer
summary: A new wave of vehicle finance startups is emerging, catering to US car dealers rather than bypassing them. These startups aim to simplify financing and insurance processes, but the underlying economics remain unchanged. They partner with dealers to provide digital financing solutions, replacing tedious paperwork with a few taps on a smartphone. The startups make money by charging dealers and lenders a fee once a sale goes through. This approach allows consumers to test drive cars and dealers to maintain their role in the sales process, despite the rise of e-commerce.

site_title: Macron's bid for French presidency gets a boost
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron received a boost after a junior minister from President Francois Hollande's government, Biodiversity Minister Barbara Pompili, backed his campaign. Pompili's endorsement comes after Macron performed well in a TV debate, with 24% of viewers finding him the most convincing candidate. Opinion polls also show Macron leading in the election, with 29% of viewers having a better opinion of him after the debate. Macron's centrist views are seen as more representative of the Socialist Party's views, and some see him as a better candidate to defeat far-right leader Marine Le Pen.

images.alt_text: Several opinion polls found Mr Macron, a former investment banker, was the most convincing performer in a three-hour TV debate on Monday evening watched by over a fifth of the French electorate.

site_title: Meat giants rush to reassure Brazilians amid latest scandal
summary: Brazil's meat giants, JBS and BRF, have taken measures to reassure consumers that their meat is safe to eat amid a corruption probe. The probe alleges producers bribed officials to approve the sale of spoiled meat, with some products containing animal parts like pig heads and cardboard, and others adulterated with acid. Both companies have run full-page ads and TV spots to deny the allegations and claim their products are safe, but critics say the strategy should have been faster and more precise to avoid image damages.

site_title: EU set to make UK wait before starting Brexit talks
summary: The European Union has announced it will delay starting Brexit talks with the UK, citing a need for a more detailed negotiation framework. EU leaders cancelled a planned summit on April 6, instead scheduling a meeting for the end of April or early May. This move leaves the UK's two-year negotiation period at risk, with EU policymakers warning the British government to have realistic expectations. The EU will initially respond to the UK's Article 50 notification within two days, but actual discussions cannot begin until more detailed directives are approved by the European Commission.

site_title: US bans carry-on large electronics from 10 airports, mainly in M-E
summary: The US has banned carry-on large electronics from 10 airports mainly in the Middle East and North Africa in response to unspecified terror threats. The affected airports include those in Jordan, Egypt, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and others. Passengers will be required to check in devices larger than cell phones, such as laptops and tablets, for flights to the US. The decision does not target specific nations, but rather relies on evaluated intelligence. The restrictions will be in place indefinitely and apply to US citizens traveling on foreign carriers, but not to crew members.

site_title: Merkel ally says Erdogan 'not welcome' in Germany
summary: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan's comparison of Berlin's government to the Nazis has sparked rebuke from German officials, with Vice-Chancellor Volker Bouffier stating that Erdogan and his government are "not welcome" in Germany. Chancellor Angela Merkel has also called on Turkey to stop making such comparisons, warning that future visits by Turkish officials could be blocked if they violate German law. EU officials have also condemned Erdogan's comments, with EU Commissioner Johannes Hahn stating that Turkey's prospects for EU membership are becoming increasingly unrealistic unless it changes its path.

site_title: Prosecutors interrogate ousted South Korean leader
summary: Prosecutors questioned ousted South Korean President Park Geun-hye about corruption and abuse of power, following her impeachment and dismissal from office. Park apologized to the public as she arrived at the prosecutors' office, stating she would undergo the investigation sincerely. She faces multiple charges, including abuse of power, coercion, and bribery, and is accused of letting her secret confidante Choi Soon-sil abuse her presidential ties for personal gain. The questioning marks a key step in South Korea's judicial process before a suspect is charged.

site_title: Banksy's West Bank hotel opens doors to first guests
summary: Banksy's Walled-Off Hotel, located near Israel's separation wall in the West Bank, welcomed its first guests on Monday, two weeks after its surprise launch. The hotel, which features Banksy's largest new collection of artwork in years, has nine rooms with prices ranging from $30 to $965 per night. Guests, who paid a $1,000 deposit to prevent theft of the artwork, arrived from six different countries, with nearly all rooms booked for the next three months. The hotel aims to support the local community, with profits going back into the community, and is seen as a unique opportunity for tourists to experience the conflict firsthand.

site_title: Singapore's ties with Vietnam prospering: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that Vietnam is prospering and ties between Singapore and Vietnam are also growing. During a dinner reception, he mentioned that there are over 900 Singapore projects in Ho Chi Minh City alone, with nearly 3,000 Singaporeans living in Vietnam. Lee emphasized the need for Singapore firms to venture abroad and seize opportunities, citing the country's strong economic cooperation and regular high-level visits. The visit comes as bilateral relations are in excellent shape, with Singapore being the third-largest foreign investor in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

PM Lee and Mrs Lee with Singaporeans at Hotel Intercontinental Asiana Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City on Tuesday. Latest figures peg the number of Singaporeans living in Vietnam at nearly 3,000; an estimated 1,300 of them are in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Cost-efficiency key demand driver for self-storage spaces in Singapore: Knight Frank
summary: Self-storage spaces in Singapore are in high demand due to cost-efficiency, with about half of business users opting for them as a cheaper alternative to renting shops or warehousing space. The industry has seen a significant increase in operators, from 8 to 27 facilities, over the past five years. The projected growth of Singapore's e-commerce sector is expected to support steady demand for self-storage space in the next five to 10 years. The industry is expected to grow by another 5-10% in the next 12 months, with operators looking to reinvent their business models to stay competitive.

site_title: Path to a new Scots independence vote will be arduous
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's government has been caught off guard by a surge in support for a new Scottish independence referendum following her decision to pursue a "hard Brexit" without ties to the single market. The move has been seen as a betrayal by pro-EU Scots, who fear the UK's exit from the EU will harm their economy. The Scottish National Party (SNP), led by Nicola Sturgeon, is now pushing for a second referendum, which could take place by spring 2019, but May has ruled out holding one until later. The path to a new independence vote is expected to be arduous and complex.

site_title: BA to pay UK staff £400 sweetener as bonuses shrink
summary: British Airways will provide a £400 (S$694) bonus and a free return flight to UK staff due to missed bonus payments, as the carrier struggled to meet customer service and punctuality goals. The airline's earnings fell short of a £1.5 billion threshold, and measures to boost margins include cutting jobs and increasing seat density. Despite this, the airline's CEO, Alex Cruz, needs staff support to implement a four-year programme to improve margins.

site_title: Indonesia nets US$330b from tax amnesty
summary: Indonesia has collected at least $330 billion in assets through its tax amnesty program, with President Joko Widodo aiming to boost infrastructure spending and growth. However, critics argue that the program has mainly benefited the wealthy, and that the country needs to improve its tax collection ratio, which is currently below many peers. To achieve this, Indonesia's finance minister has set up a special tax reform team and is considering draft legislation to overhaul the tax system, including giving tax collectors wider access to bank data.

images.alt_text: Dr Sri Mulyani (above) has set up a special tax reform team to boost collection. The team aims to increase the tax ratio to 15 per cent of GDP in 2020 from about 11 per cent now. That compares with a global average of 14.8 per cent in 2014, according to the World Bank.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Neo Group has subscribed for 416,327 shares of Hi-Q Plastic Industries Sdn Bhd for RM1.6 million, representing 51% of the enlarged capital. The purchase is funded by internal sources and aligns with Neo Group's expansion strategies. Meanwhile, Rickmers Maritime Trust has been given until April 15 to present a restructuring plan for its debt, which includes S$100 million of unsecured medium-term notes maturing in May 2017. SPH Radio has been fined S$7,000 for breaching the Free-To-Air Radio Programme Code, while Libra Group has secured three contracts worth S$22.4 million.

site_title: Japan looks for answers to flood of Chinese fuel
summary: Japan's top oil specialists are struggling to find a solution to the country's energy crisis, as Chinese refiners push their way into the Asian market with stricter fuel standards. Japan's oil refiners, including JX Holdings Inc and Idemitsu Kosan Co, face declining demand at home and rising competition from China. The taskforce aims to save oil refiners from the crisis, but its efforts have been met with limited success, with refiners opting to slash processing capacity instead of upgrading to produce higher-quality products.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust's current liabilities exceed assets by US$179 million: auditors
summary: First Ship Lease Trust reported a full-year net loss of US$31 million for the period ended Dec 31, 2016, with current liabilities exceeding assets by US$179.4 million, casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. Despite this, management believes the company has sufficient cash resources to meet its obligations and secure refinancing for its syndicated loan facility, which matures at the end of 2017. The trustee-manager has prepared a cash flow projection and expects the refinancing to be successful, but the group's counter has fallen 14.5% from the start of the year.

site_title: World Bank lobbies for capital boost despite Trump budget cuts
summary: World Bank President Jim Yong Kim lobbies for a capital boost despite US President Donald Trump's proposed cuts to foreign aid. Trump's "America First" doctrine prioritizes US interests, and his budget outline includes deep cuts to international institutions, including the World Bank. The US had committed $2.3 billion to development banks in 2016, but Trump's proposals could lead to a $650 million cut over three years. The World Bank needs a capital increase to bolster its funds, which lend to middle-income nations, as it aims to eradicate extreme poverty by 2030.

site_title: Bayer reports record Asia-Pac sales for 6th straight year on rising, ageing population
summary: Bayer reported record Asia-Pacific sales for the sixth consecutive year, driven by a rising and ageing population. Pharmaceuticals sales rose 8.6% to €4.8 billion (S$7.25 billion) in 2016, with top markets including India, Vietnam, and South Korea. Bayer attributes its success to innovation, citing its portfolio of medicines addressing unmet medical needs in the region. The company expects global pharmaceutical sales of over €17 billion for 2017, driven by growing demand and increasing investment in research and development.

site_title: Petrobras expected to post Q4 profit on higher oil prices, lower writedowns
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil company, Petrobras, is expected to post a profit in the fourth quarter due to higher oil prices and lower writedowns. The company likely earned 3.701 billion reais (S$1.69 billion) in the last quarter, reversing a net loss of 16.458 billion reais in the third quarter. Petrobras' CEO Pedro Parente is reining in costs and implementing fewer asset write-downs, helping the company weather the fallout from a bribery probe. The company is also expected to forego dividend payments for another year due to a net loss for the full year.

site_title: Piracy hasn't gone away
summary: Piracy remains a significant threat to shipping, particularly in the Gulf of Aden and western Indian Ocean. The recent hijacking of a bunker tanker by Somali pirates highlights the need for joint efforts among regional governments, enforcement agencies, and the industry to combat piracy. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has called for the application of best-management practices to prevent piracy attacks. Despite a decline in piracy off Somalia since 2012, the reality is that piracy has not been eradicated, and attacks continue to occur in other regions, including west Africa.

site_title: Japan PM in Brussels, pushes for EU trade deal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to seal a European Union-Japan trade deal as early as possible to counter protectionism, following US President Trump's recent comments. Abe met EU officials in Brussels, emphasizing the importance of cooperation between Japan, the EU, and the US. The deal, which includes a Japanese dairy sector reform, aims to abolish tariffs on Japanese cars once Tokyo meets EU demands. EU officials believe the agreement is necessary for free, fair, and rules-based trade, citing the combined GDP of the EU and Japan.

site_title: Where the surf's up, the economy is too
summary: A new study by an economist at the University of Sydney found that the discovery of high-quality surf spots can drive up economic growth by 2.2 percentage points a year in the surrounding area. The research analyzed satellite images of night-time light emissions from areas near surf breaks and population gains, and found that surf breaks can attract workers and entrepreneurs, leading to growth in recreational industries and tourism. The study cites examples of successful surf breaks in countries such as Brazil, Indonesia, and Costa Rica, and suggests that policymakers could use surf breaks to create jobs and reduce poverty, particularly in developing countries.

site_title: Adidas speeds up response to customer demand with in-store knitting machine
summary: Adidas has launched a pop-up store in Berlin where customers can design and knit their own merino wool sweaters using a state-of-the-art machine within four hours. The "Knit for You" store is part of a research project to speed up the design-to-store process, aiming to cut production time to 50% by 2020. This initiative is part of Adidas' goal to increase full-price sales and adjust to fickle fashion trends, similar to rival Nike's operating profit margin.

site_title: Buy greenback before Round 2 of French elections: UBS
summary: UBS analysts recommend buying the US dollar against the Singapore dollar for a short period of two months, citing a 40% chance of Marine Le Pen's eventual victory in the French presidential election. This would occur after Le Pen makes it past the first round but fails in the second round. After the election, the euro is expected to rebound strongly against the US dollar, potentially weakening the US dollar.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge buys Shanghai building
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group acquired a 14-storey commercial building in Shanghai's Huangpu District for an undisclosed amount. The 24,883 square meter building, located near the city center, will be renovated and upgraded to cater to emerging enterprises and knowledge-intensive industries. The acquisition is part of the company's plan to grow its portfolio in China's tier-1 cities. Ascendas-Singbridge plans to create a lively and connected environment to support innovative enterprises and contribute to China's knowledge economy.

site_title: Modi's contentious pick to lead UP favours Trump's ban
summary: India's new Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, a firebrand Hindu nationalist, has been appointed to lead the state of Uttar Pradesh, a Hindu-majority state of over 200 million people. The move has sparked concerns about the potential for divisive politics to eclipse promises of economic development, given Adityanath's past remarks on Muslims and his support for building a Hindu temple at the site of the destroyed Babri mosque. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's elevation of Adityanath has raised questions about the direction of India's "new India" and whether economic development will take a backseat to appeasing the country's majority Hindus.

site_title: Interpol alert for three Sinopec execs linked to fraud in Indonesia
summary: Indonesian authorities have issued a request to Interpol for the arrest of three Chinese executives from Sinopec, suspected of embezzling over $800 million from a stalled oil terminal project. The executives, Zhang Jun, Feng Zhigang, and Ye Zhijun, were issued red notices, the closest to an international arrest warrant, due to their alleged failure to cooperate with local police investigations. This is the second major Chinese state oil firm to face allegations of corruption in Indonesia, with the country consistently ranking as one of the world's most corrupt nations.

site_title: Cheaper funerals to stop Japanese elderly driving
summary: A funeral service company in central Japan is offering a 15% discount to elderly drivers who give up their licenses, as part of efforts to reduce accidents caused by ageing motorists. The discount, worth a minimum of $695, applies to altars used during funerals and can be passed on to close family members. This is part of a growing trend, with police in Aichi prefecture previously offering a ramen noodle discount to elderly drivers who surrender their licenses. The aim is to encourage elderly drivers to give up their licenses before they die, reducing the risk of accidents.

site_title: Fed's rate hike a positive for Asia
summary: The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike in March has boosted Asian markets, signaling the end of the taper tantrum risk. The Fed's decision, which raised rates to 1.375% and expects 2.1% growth in 2018, was met with a rally in the S&P 500 and a depreciation of the US dollar. This reduced the risk of a sudden change in Fed policy, benefiting emerging market equities and allowing them to claw back losses from 2015. The US dollar's weakness also benefits Asian currencies, making it a positive environment for Asian markets.

site_title: Laundered Russian cash went through world's biggest banks: report
summary: A money laundering network known as the Global Laundromat involved laundered Russian cash passing through major world banks, including HSBC, RBS, Stanchart, and Citigroup. The network, which operated between 2010 and 2014, moved at least $20 billion out of Russia, with $740 million of that amount passing through UK-based banks. The banks, which have strict money-laundering controls, declined to comment on the transactions. Authorities in Russia, Moldova, and Latvia have cracked down on money laundering, with the head of Russia's central bank leading a purge of banks suspected of violating money-laundering laws.

site_title: Success of Modi-backed fund may boost ETF sales in India
summary: India's exchange-traded fund (ETF) market is expected to experience robust growth due to the government's success in raising assets through the Central Public Sector Enterprises ETF. Investors poured 92 billion rupees into the fund, three times the targeted amount, with retail investors contributing over 35 billion rupees. This success may boost ETF sales in the country, driven by structural shifts in asset-class preference and slowing inflation.

site_title: Temasek sees more India deals as companies sell assets
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte, a Singapore state investment company, expects Indian companies to continue selling assets to pare debt as corporate balance sheet stress rises. Heavily indebted companies have announced up to $20 billion in divestments in the last year, with banks forcing delinquent borrowers to repay loans by selling assets. This trend has attracted investors like TPG, which plans to invest more in India, and is expected to help resolve the country's bad debt crisis.

site_title: Hugh Lim appointed new BCA chief exec
summary: Hugh Lim, deputy secretary of the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, will take over as CEO of the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) on June 1, 2017, succeeding John Keung. Lim, 51, previously held positions in the Singapore Armed Forces and Ministry of Law, and co-chaired the Vision 2030 Implementation Committee. The BCA expects a surge in public sector construction in 2017, with estimated contracts worth S$28-35 billion.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corporation is novating five Super B jack-up rigs to Borr Drilling at a discounted price of US$216 million per rig. CIMB Research upgrades Keppel to "hold" with a higher target price of S$7.24. Tat Hong Holdings acquires 23,000 shares, increasing its effective interest to 84.61%. Jefferies Singapore warns of asset quality issues and uncertainty in the credit cycle, advising against paying a premium to trailing book. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer is oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Rival drilling tycoons betting on offshore oil-rig recovery
summary: Billionaire John Fredriksen and his former top adviser Tor Olav Troim are backing a recovery in the offshore oil-rig market by investing in rigs at bargain prices. Borr Drilling Ltd, founded by Troim, has acquired Transocean Ltd's entire fleet of jack-up rigs for $1.35 billion, while Fredriksen's Northern Drilling Ltd has acquired a floating rig for $365 million and an option for another at $400 million. The investments signal optimism among investors, with analysts predicting rising deal-making in the industry.

images.alt_text: Mr Troim's Borr Drilling Ltd, which announced its first rig deal after setting up three months ago, is now buying Transocean Ltd's entire fleet of jack-up rigs for US$1.35 billion.

site_title: Toshiba's Westinghouse seeks US bankruptcy financing: sources
summary: Westinghouse Electric Co LLC, a nuclear power plant developer owned by Toshiba Corp, is seeking a US$500 million financing package to help it avoid bankruptcy. The company is reviewing proposals from financial institutions and investment firms to carry it through a potential bankruptcy. If it files, the funding would allow Westinghouse to continue paying employees and building four nuclear power plants in Georgia and South Carolina, commissioned by local utility companies. Toshiba has said it would take a US$6.3 billion write-down related to Westinghouse.

site_title: Blackstone sends a warning to illiquid debt funds
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, has closed a $3 billion distressed-debt hedge fund that allowed clients to withdraw money periodically. The firm cited a 6.5% annualized return since 2005, compared to 17% in a similar 2007 fund, as a reason for its decision. This move serves as a warning to open-ended funds that bill themselves as high-yield bond strategies but may actually be distressed-debt funds, which can freeze up during times of withdrawal. Blackstone's decision highlights the risks of this type of investing and the need for investors to rethink their approach to liquidity.

site_title: Job focus shifting from UK to Hungary, Poland
summary: Central and eastern European countries, particularly Poland and Hungary, are attracting top talent from the UK and other Western countries, reversing a long-standing brain drain. Companies like BlackRock, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase are setting up hubs in the region, creating over 1 million jobs in finance, legal, and other sectors by 2025. This shift is driven by higher salaries, improved quality of life, and government initiatives to lure workers back home, with some countries expecting to attract up to 30,000 British jobs.

site_title: Major market Hong Kong bans Brazilian meat imports
summary: Hong Kong has suspended imports of frozen and chilled meat and poultry from Brazil due to concerns over the quality of the meat. This move follows China's suspension of imports, as Brazil is the second-largest supplier to the city. The decision was made by Hong Kong's Centre for Food Safety, citing the need to ensure the quality of imported meat.

site_title: FBI confirms probe into Moscow-Trump link during elections
summary: The FBI has confirmed an investigation into potential ties between Donald Trump's presidential campaign and Russia during the 2016 US election. Director James Comey stated the probe, which began in July, is ongoing and could last for months. He also challenged Trump's claim that former President Barack Obama wiretapped his campaign headquarters, saying there's no evidence to support it. Comey stated Russia's goal was to help Trump win, not just hurt Clinton. The investigation is part of several congressional inquiries into Russian interference in the election.

site_title: Asean a key stabilising factor amid big-power rivalry: Mahbubani
summary: ASEAN is a key stabilizing factor in the face of big-power rivalry, according to Kishore Mahbubani, dean of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy. The region is expected to be the 4th largest economy in the world by 2050, driven by China and India's growth. Despite its differences and disputes, ASEAN has managed to come together, and its genius lies in living with and managing these differences. With a strong leadership and favorable geopolitical circumstances, ASEAN has achieved remarkable growth and prosperity, with intra-ASEAN trade expected to continue to drive the region's growth.

site_title: Next financial crisis may be triggered by a cyberattack, says MAS chief
summary: Singapore's MAS chief Ravi Menon warns that the next financial crisis may be triggered by a cyberattack, as emerging technologies like fintech accentuate risks and create new ones. He notes that cyberattacks are a growing threat, and the financial sector's reliance on digital payments and big data increases security concerns. Menon advocates for a balanced approach to regulation, encouraging innovation while addressing emerging risks, and emphasizes the importance of financial institutions fostering a culture of responsible risk-taking and ethical behavior.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Texas leads hotel building boom in US
summary: Texas is experiencing a hotel building boom, with dozens of new properties expected to open in 2017, surpassing New York and Los Angeles. The state's development-friendly attitudes, low environmental regulations, and affordable land have fueled the growth. Major hotel chains, including Marriott and Hilton, plan to open 92+ hotels in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, 92 hotels in Austin, and 75 hotels in Houston. The hotel industry has benefited from a strong national economy, with revenue per available room experiencing 83 straight months of year-over-year growth. However, concerns about overbuilding and environmental impact remain.

images.alt_text: The herds are coming.

site_title: Discipline needed when applying to delay AGMs
summary: SGX has expressed concerns over issuers' lackadaisical attitude towards compliance with listing and regulatory requirements. Rule 707(1) requires issuers to hold AGMs within four months of financial year-end. Some issuers apply for waivers, which are typically approved by SGX with conditions, but also require approval from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra). In some cases, Acra has rejected the application, indicating a stricter approach in granting waivers. Poor disclosure of waivers is part of a broader issue, highlighting the need for stricter compliance among issuers.

site_title: Make it fare for all in new taxi-ride pricing system
summary: Grab introduces JustGrab, a taxi-ride pricing system that pools all taxis and private cars together, charging rides on the same fare structure. The system includes surge pricing, which was previously only available in Grab's private-car service. JustGrab aims to make fares more affordable by widening the supply base, but critics argue that it's unclear how surge pricing will be tabulated. The system is designed to provide upfront quoted fares, but metered fares will still be available for those who prefer them. The move is seen as a response to market forces, with commuters preferring upfront fares and taxi drivers seeking to quote fares themselves.

images.alt_text: Ride-hailing app Grab has introduced a new service that pools all taxis and private cars together, charging rides made in any of them on the same fare structure.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end the day 5 points higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.26 points to 1,754.670 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 4.57 billion lots worth RM3.2 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 496 to 477.

site_title: Tillerson to skip Nato meeting
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will miss his first meeting with Nato foreign ministers, instead attending President Donald Trump's talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping in April. The decision has unsettled European allies, who fear it reopens questions about the US commitment to the alliance. Tillerson's absence also raises concerns about US interest in the former Soviet bloc and its relationship with Russia. US Under-secretary Tom Shannon is expected to represent the US at the Nato meeting, and Trump is set to attend a Nato summit in May.

site_title: Taxi-hailing app Grab hits the road in Myanmar
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing firm, launched a trial service in Yangon, Myanmar, becoming the first international company to enter the country. The service, which uses a small group of local taxi drivers, aims to gradually scale up operations. Grab is the first international company to enter the largely untapped market, beating rival Uber, which is in talks to launch in Yangon. The move follows a growing trend in Southeast Asia's rapidly expanding market, expected to reach $13.1 billion by 2025.

site_title: New York to roll out broadband for every household by 2018
summary: New York aims to provide broadband to every household by 2018 under the "Broadband for All" initiative, making the state the first to achieve this milestone. The program, led by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo, aims to improve rural access to high-speed internet, enabling businesses and residents to participate in the digital economy. The state has partnered with private companies to expand broadband coverage, with towns like Halcott, NY, already benefiting from the initiative. The program has shown promise, with rural businesses experiencing increased economic growth and access to online services.

site_title: Ireland well placed to attract financial services post-Brexit: finance minister
summary: Ireland is well-positioned to attract financial services post-Brexit, according to Irish Finance Minister Michael Noonan. The country's strong financial services industry, eurozone membership, and common law system make it an attractive alternative to London. Over 120 banks and insurers are reportedly in talks to relocate to Ireland, and Noonan is hopeful for a win-win trade deal between the EU and UK. Despite US concerns over a potential border tax, Noonan believes it is unlikely to materialize, and Ireland's economic relationship with Singapore will be dominated by trade.

site_title: US: Stocks higher with technology plays
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite hitting a record high, driven by technology shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.21%, and the S&P 500 increased 0.24%. Apple's new iPad tablet boosted the stock, while investor optimism was fueled by Emmanuel Macron's strong performance in a TV debate, potentially leading to his presidential election win. This sentiment also positively impacted European stock markets, which saw broad gains across sectors.

site_title: Europe: Stocks nudge ahead on opening
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.4%. This followed broad gains in Asia, including Hong Kong and Shanghai. However, Tokyo stocks fell 0.3% due to a strengthening yen against the dollar. The dollar has been under pressure since the Federal Reserve raised borrowing costs last week, with investors awaiting further interest rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore shares finish lower in thin trading
summary: The Singapore stock market closed 7.13 points lower at 3,158.57 on Tuesday, with low trading volume and few market-moving events. The Straits Times Index barely broke out, and the downturn followed news of Ezra Holdings' US Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. Turnover decreased to S$909.3 million, with 239 rises and 225 falls.

site_title: Funeral discounts for elderly Japan drivers who quit
summary: Japan is offering funeral discounts to elderly drivers who give up their licenses as part of efforts to prevent accidents caused by aging motorists. The discounts, which can save up to 56,000 yen ($500), are being offered by a funeral service company in central Japan to drivers aged 75 or older who pass cognitive tests. This initiative comes after a fatal accident in November involving an 87-year-old driver in Yokohama, and follows a similar discount offered by local police in Aichi prefecture. The goal is to encourage elderly drivers to surrender their licenses and reduce the risk of accidents.

site_title: Auditors flag going concern issues with First Ship Lease Trust
summary: Auditors of First Ship Lease Trust have flagged going concern issues due to a full-year net loss of US$31 million and a significant gap between current liabilities and assets of US$179.4 million. The auditors express doubt on the trust's ability to continue as a going concern, but the management believes it has sufficient cash resources to meet its obligations. The group expects to receive financial support from lenders and successfully refinance its bank loan, mitigating the concerns.

site_title: To achieve high income status, Malaysia needs institutional reform
summary: Malaysia's goal to achieve "high income status" by 2020 appears uncertain due to a challenging global economic backdrop. The US decision to abandon the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade deal may hinder the country's competitiveness. To escape the "middle-income trap," Malaysia needs institutional reforms, including a sea change of mindset, human and physical capital, and strengthening of public sector agencies. The country's focus on economic challenges has been incomplete, and rising competition has pushed it down to 25th spot in the Global Competitiveness Report 2016-2017.

site_title: Libra Group wins three new contracts worth S$22.4m
summary: Libra Group won three new contracts worth S$22.4 million. The contracts include supplying and building air-conditioning systems and electrical installations for commercial office towers at Paya Lebar/Sims Avenue, and altering an existing factory at Yishun Industrial Park. The projects are scheduled to be completed by April 2018 and December 2017, respectively.

site_title: Reddit rolls out user profiles amid site makeover
summary: Reddit has rolled out public profiles for users as part of its site makeover, allowing users to post content directly to their profile pages and follow other individuals' pages. This change, similar to social networks like Facebook and Twitter, aims to boost engagement on the site. The feature is a result of Reddit's efforts to address users' struggles to share personal content due to rules banning self-promotion. The move is part of a broader effort to modernize the platform.

site_title: Winners and losers from Kimly's IPO
summary: Kimly Limited, a coffeeshop operator, made a significant debut on the Singapore Stock Exchange, closing at S$0.44, 76% above its IPO price of S$0.25. In contrast, Jumbo Group, a chilli crab restaurant chain, saw a 36% increase. Kimly's IPO price was undervalued, with a 12x pro forma earnings multiple, and a small public tranche of shares. This has raised concerns about the lack of opportunities for retail investors, with only S$1 million of shares available. The Singapore Exchange is set to introduce a 5% retail allocation for mainboard listings from May 2, which may lead to changes in the IPO landscape.

site_title: World stocks seen as most overvalued in 17 years: BAML survey
summary: World stocks are their most overvalued in 17 years, according to a Bank of America Merrill Lynch survey. A net 48% of fund managers are overweight the market, with 34% thinking equities are overvalued, the highest proportion since 2000. The biggest risk to the equity bull market is higher interest rates, with 35% of respondents citing this as a concern. A bear market is unlikely to occur until the 10-year US Treasury yield rises above 3.5%, which has not happened since 2011.

site_title: HK, China: Stocks extend gains to four days
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, reaching their highest level since summer 2015, driven by expectations that US interest rates would rise more slowly than expected. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.37% to close at 24,593.12, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The gains were attributed to a boost in property firms, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid uncertainty.

site_title: CCS uncovers 5 firms involved in F1 tender bid-rigging
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has issued a proposed infringement decision against five companies - Cyclect Group, HPH Engineering, Peak Top Engineering, Chemicrete Enterprises, and Cyclect Electrical Engineering - for allegedly rigging a Formula 1 tender bid. The firms were involved in tender bid-rigging for electrical services for the 2015-2017 Singapore Grand Prix. CCS found that Chemicrete and Cyclect Electrical colluded to win the tender, and HPH and Peak Top were pressured into submitting higher bids to facilitate the win. The firms have six weeks to respond to the decision.

site_title: Apple unveils updated iPad with lowest-ever price
summary: Apple unveiled an updated iPad with a brighter screen, available for $329, marking the lowest price for a full-sized tablet. The new iPad starts at 32 GB of storage and replaces the iPad Air 2, offering incremental hardware updates. Additionally, Apple announced a new app called Clips for creating and sharing videos with friends, featuring voice-added captions and speech bubbles. The updates come ahead of expected iPhone releases this fall, which may include features like wireless charging and 3D facial recognition.

site_title: Goldman building robo-adviser to tap mass affluent client segment
summary: Goldman Sachs is building a robo-adviser to target mass affluent clients, who have less than $1 million in investable assets. The platform will be part of the bank's rapidly growing investment management division, which has posted a record $1.38 trillion in assets under supervision. Goldman has been trying to expand its customer base beyond the super wealthy, and the robo-adviser is seen as a way to tap into the mass affluent segment without diluting its private wealth business. The move follows similar efforts by other large firms, including Charles Schwab and Vanguard.

images.alt_text: Goldman has for years grappled with how to tap the mass affluent, without diluting the brand of its private wealth business.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore employers plan salary increases of 3 to 6% for the next pay review, according to a survey by recruiter Hays. Pharmaceutical company Bayer reported an 8.6% increase in drug sales in the Asia-Pacific region in 2016. Singapore's industrial production is expected to have returned to growth in February after contracting more than expected the previous month, according to a Reuters poll.

site_title: IRA fighter turned peacemaker McGuinness dies: Sinn Fein
summary: Martin McGuinness, a former IRA commander and Northern Ireland's deputy First Minister, has died at 66 due to a rare heart condition. McGuinness, who resigned from politics in January, was a key figure in the peace process, sharing power with his former foe Ian Paisley in 2007. His death has raised concerns about the future of Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, potentially leading to direct rule from the British government. Sinn Fein, McGuinness' party, has made major gains in local elections, but the two parties remain deadlocked.

site_title: Mapletree closes US$1.3 billion private trust for student dorms
summary: Mapletree Investments has closed a private trust worth US$1.3 billion to hold student-accommodation assets in the UK and US. The trust, Mapletree Global Student Accommodation Private Trust, has an 8,363-bed US portfolio and a 5,910-bed UK portfolio. Mapletree plans to launch an IPO for student-housing assets when its portfolio reaches S$4-5 billion. The trust has a five-year term and pays an annual yield averaging 6-7%. The move is part of Mapletree's strategy to scale up its student-housing portfolio, with plans to acquire more assets and launch additional private trusts.

site_title: 'Skyscraper curse' claims new victim in Lotte's 4t won tower in Seoul
summary: The Lotte World Tower in Seoul, South Korea, has been delayed in its opening due to an elevator malfunction, adding to the building's already troubled history. The tower's opening coincides with a series of crises for the Lotte Group, including corruption charges against its founder and family members, Chinese consumer retaliation over a US missile-defence system, and a slowdown in the country's economy. The "skyscraper curse," a phenomenon where record-setting skyscrapers are often built during economic downturns, may be exacting a toll on the Lotte Group.

images.alt_text: Visitors taking photographs from the glass-bottomed observation deck at the Lotte Corp World Tower in Seoul. The building boasts some record-setting amenities: highest glass floor at the top of a building and highest swimming pool.

site_title: Neo Group to acquire stake in Hi-Q Plastic Industries
summary: Neo Group has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Malaysia-based Hi-Q Plastic Industries for RM1.6 million, subscribing for 416,327 new shares at RM3.855 apiece. The acquisition is part of Neo's expansion strategies and growth plans, aiming to vertically integrate its business into the supply chain. Hi-Q, a manufacturer of plastics and packaging products, reported a profit after tax of RM240,000 in the 2015 financial year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Seoul: Stocks surge, closing at a near 6-yr high
summary: South Korean stocks reached a near six-year high, closing at 2,178.38 points, a 1% gain. This is the highest close since July 8, 2011. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended a four-day winning streak for the South Korean won, which closed at 1,120.1 to the dollar, little changed from Monday's close. Strong first-quarter earnings expectations are believed to have driven the surge in shares.

site_title: Indonesia police say Interpol issues red notices for 3 Sinopec execs
summary: Indonesian police say Interpol has issued red notices for three Chinese executives suspected of fraud related to a US$800 million Sinopec oil terminal development in Indonesia. The three executives, Zhang Jun, Feng Zhigang, and Ye Zhijun, are accused of embezzlement from the West Point Terminal project. The red notices were issued after Indonesian authorities filed a request for Interpol assistance, as the executives had left the country and failed to cooperate with local police investigations.

site_title: Tycoon shuns investment banks in US$23b Vodafone deal
summary: Indian billionaire Kumar Mangalam Birla's mobile arm, Idea Cellular Ltd, is merging with Vodafone Group Plc's Indian operations to create the largest Indian wireless carrier with a US$23 billion enterprise value. Birla personally led talks with Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao, bypassing investment banks to avoid leaks and maintain confidentiality. The deal was finalized after two months of intense negotiations, with Birla's internal team handling the process, and he will serve as chairman of the combined business.

images.alt_text: Indian billionaire Kumar Mangalam Birla just pulled off the biggest deal of his career. There won't be any investment banks sharing in the glory.

site_title: Taiwan launches submarine project in face of China threat
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen launched the island's first home-grown submarine project, amid growing military threats from China. The move comes after China's Liaoning aircraft carrier passed through the Taiwan Strait in January. Taiwan has warned of increased invasion risk and pledged to boost its military in response. This development marks a significant step in Taiwan's military modernization efforts, with China's increasing aggression in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower as banks, exporters struggle
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Tuesday as banks and major exporters, including Sony and Panasonic, struggled under the strong yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.34% to 19,455.88, while the Topix index slipped 0.16% to 1,563.42. The decline was attributed to the banks and exporters' struggles, which negatively impacted the market.

site_title: China says number of "terror attacks" down, but threat remains high
summary: China reports a decrease in violent attacks by "terrorist cells" in 2016, but an expert warns the threat remains high due to foiled attacks and growing influence of overseas groups. The majority of suspects were born in the 1980s and 1990s, and many cells were formed among family members. Authorities have increased security measures, including mass parades and rallies, helicopter patrols, and satellite tracking, in response to threats from separatist groups in Xinjiang, where hundreds have been killed in recent years.

site_title: US, UK ban laptops, tablets from cabins on flights from Middle East
summary: The US and UK have banned carrying laptops, tablets, and portable game consoles onto flights from 10 Middle East airports due to a threat from extremist groups. The ban applies to direct flights to the US and affects nine airlines from eight countries, including Royal Jordanian, EgyptAir, and Emirates. Passengers on 50 flights per day will be required to stow these devices in checked baggage. The restrictions are based on evaluated intelligence and are intended to secure the safety of the travelling public, particularly after successful attacks on passenger jets and airports in recent years.

site_title: Indonesia tax amnesty nets US$330b - now for reform
summary: Indonesia is wrapping up its successful tax amnesty program, which has seen 745,000 taxpayers declare over $330 billion in assets. However, the government faces a challenge in increasing tax revenue, with a tax collection ratio below the global average. A special tax reform team has been set up to boost collection, and draft legislation aims to overhaul the corrupt tax institution. The team plans to increase the tax ratio to 15% of GDP by 2020 and introduce measures to access bank data and create a social security number system to boost the tax base.

site_title: Australia: Shares close weaker on Wall Street softness
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower, mirroring Wall Street's decline due to concerns over President Trump's tax plan timeline. The materials sector was the main drag, with BHP Billiton and South32 Ltd falling 1% and 2.2% respectively. Real estate stocks were also affected by the central bank's warning on the housing market. However, Spotless Group surged 49% after a buyout offer, while A2 Milk rose 4.5% after China backed down on e-commerce laws affecting its exports.

site_title: BMW aims for slight increase in profit in 2017
summary: BMW aims to achieve a slight increase in profit in 2017 by ramping up production of sports utility vehicles to fund investments in electric cars. The company targets a 8-10% return on sales in the automotive segment, with a record sales volume, revenues, and earnings. BMW plans to integrate its electric cars into its core brands, with a separate production line for low-volume models. This move is part of the company's efforts to overhaul its production system and meet growing demand for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: BMW aims to achieve record sales volume, revenues and earnings this year by ramping up production of highly profitable sports utility vehicles to help fund investments to overhaul its production system for fully electric cars.

site_title: Japan land prices edge up in 2016 on tourism boom
summary: Japan's nationwide land prices rose 0.4% in 2016, the first two-year increase since 2015, driven by a tourism boom. Commercial land prices rose 1.4%, with major cities seeing a 1.1% increase, while residential land prices remained flat. Foreign tourism, particularly in regional cities, boosted demand for hotels and shops, contributing to the growth. The number of foreign visitors to Japan reached a record 24 million, with prices in cities like Osaka and Fukuoka increasing significantly.

site_title: Headaches for traders with NYSE glitch near market close
summary: The NYSE Group experienced a technical error on Monday, causing confusion among traders. NYSE Arca, the largest US listing venue for exchange-traded funds, shifted to backup methods for calculating closing prices, resulting in an early closure of its after-hours session. Only 53 out of 1,230 listed securities were closed through normal auctions, leaving major ETFs like the SPDR S&P 500 ETF and SPDR Gold Shares ETF unaffected. The glitch highlights the importance of closing auctions in the growing passive investing market.

site_title: Emirates, Etihad say not advised of new US flight restrictions on electronics
summary: Middle East airlines Emirates and Etihad say they have not received any notification of new US flight restrictions on carrying electronic devices. The US Department of Homeland Security is expected to announce a ban on electronic devices larger than a cell phone on certain US-bound flights in response to an unspecified terrorism threat. The ban is expected to affect around 8-10 foreign airlines, including those based in Jordan and Saudi Arabia, and will apply to 10 airports in 8 countries in the Middle East and North Africa.

images.alt_text: Emirates Airline and Etihad Airways have not been advised of any new restrictions on carrying electronic devices on US flights, the Middle East airlines said on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.09% to 24,524.47, as investors ignored a weak US lead. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down. The gains come despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Google to revamp policies, hire staff after UK ad scandal
summary: Google has revamped its policies and plans to hire more staff after several major companies pulled their adverts from its YouTube site due to hate-filled videos. The internet giant apologized and introduced measures to give advertisers more control over their ads. Google's review was launched after companies such as supermarkets and banks removed their ads from the platform. The company aims to improve its ability to police its websites.

site_title: Hackers try to steal Baidu's driverless car secrets
summary: Baidu Inc reported that a group of hackers-for-hire attempted to steal its driverless car technology, prompting the company to bolster its cybersecurity team. The attackers were likely hired through underground markets, and Baidu has teamed up with rival tech firms Tencent and Alibaba to counter the shared threat. The company is supporting "white hat" student hackers at Tsinghua University to help prevent future attacks. Baidu's head of cybersecurity, Ma Jie, emphasized the need for cooperation against the growing underground industry.

site_title: SPH Radio fined S$7,000 for breach of radio programme code
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) fined SPH Radio Pte Ltd S$7,000 for breaching the Free-To-Air Radio Programme Code after deejays on Kiss92FM made remarks stereotyping certain races and offending listeners in January. The remarks were later apologized for on the station's Facebook page. The incident contravened the Code's obligation to avoid racial and religious stereotyping and ensure content does not offend sensitivities of any racial or religious group in Singapore.

site_title: Rickmers has until April 15 to give bankers a plan
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust has until April 15 to submit a debt restructuring plan to HSH Nordbank, its largest senior lender. The plan must ensure higher total recoveries than a trust winding-up scenario. Rickmers is trying to restructure $100 million in unsecured notes and $270.8 million in secured bank debt. HSH Nordbank is willing to consider debt forgiveness if certain preconditions are met, but has not yet confirmed the plan.

site_title: Singapore industrial output seen rising in February: poll
summary: Singapore's industrial production is expected to have returned to growth in February, rising 0.4% from January on a seasonally adjusted basis. The growth is attributed to strong electronics exports, but analysts believe production will slow in coming months. On a year-on-year basis, industrial production is seen up 10.8%. The government has warned that the trade outlook remains cloudy due to the risk of US trade protectionism, while Singapore's central bank is likely to keep its exchange-rate based policy unchanged next month.

site_title: UK small businesses urge government to avoid Brexit cliff edge
summary: British small businesses urge the UK government to avoid a "cliff edge" in Brexit negotiations by securing a transitional arrangement with the EU to minimize the impact of tariffs on trade. A quarter of companies with fewer than 250 employees would be deterred from trading with the EU if tariffs are introduced, while 33% would be put off by tariffs of 2-4%. The Federation of Small Businesses and other business lobbies are calling for a phased implementation arrangement to ensure free trade with the EU and a new customs agreement with the remaining 27 EU members.

site_title: Freeport Indonesia resumes copper concentrate production
summary: Freeport McMoRan Inc's Indonesian unit has resumed copper concentrate production at its Grasberg mine after a one-month stoppage. The production halt was caused by Indonesia preventing the export of the material and its sole domestic buyer halting operations due to a strike. The company began resuming operations in stages, with copper concentrate production starting on Tuesday.

site_title: Republicans revamp Obamacare bill as Trump moves to promote overhaul
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to promote his healthcare overhaul bill to Congressional Republicans on Tuesday, amid concerns about the bill's future. The bill, which aims to replace Obamacare, has undergone significant changes, including a proposed $85 billion fund for tax credits to help people aged 50-64 get health insurance. The revised bill also addresses Medicaid, allowing states to implement work requirements and block grants for certain populations. However, the bill still faces opposition from Democrats and some conservative Republicans, and the Congressional Budget Office is expected to update its analysis of the bill's impact.

site_title: Samsung's S8 gets its own AI assistant to vie with Apple's Siri
summary: Samsung's upcoming Galaxy S8 smartphone will feature a digital assistant called Bixby, which studies user activity to offer helpful tips and information. The assistant will be activated by a side-button and will work in tandem with apps such as Pinterest and Amazon. Bixby aims to compete with Apple's Siri and other digital assistants, and its development was done in-house by Samsung rather than through an acquisition. The S8 is expected to help Samsung bounce back from last year's Note 7 debacle and reclaim its global lead in smartphones.

site_title: Asia: Shares at 15-month high, US dollar soft on less hawkish Fed
summary: Asian shares hit 15-month highs as the US dollar softens on less hawkish Federal Reserve policy expectations. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index rose 0.4% to a 15-month high, driven by tech-heavy Seoul and Taipei shares. Japan's Nikkei dropped 0.3% due to lower US yields and a stronger yen. The US dollar fell to three-week lows near 112.26 yen, while the euro ticked up to $1.0758. Lower US bond yields also undermined the greenback's allure, supporting high-yielding currencies like the Australian dollar, which rose 2.0% since the Fed's policy meeting last week.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit nearly 2-year highs as TSMC climbs; currency strengthens
summary: Taiwan's stocks reached a near two-year high on March 21, 2017, driven by a 7% increase this year and foreign buying expectations of Apple's new iPhone benefiting Taiwanese suppliers. The main Taiex index rose 0.3% to 9,944.96 points, with TSMC, the world's largest contract chip maker, jumping 0.8%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$30.448 per US dollar, making it one of the strongest currencies in Asia.

site_title: Adobe, Microsoft team up to share sales and marketing data
summary: Microsoft and Adobe Systems Inc are teaming up to share sales and marketing data, creating a seamless experience for customers. The partnership will allow Adobe's Experience Cloud and Microsoft's Dynamics to work together, overcoming current software silos. This collaboration aims to compete with Salesforce.com and Oracle Corp offerings, particularly in business-to-business marketing software. By sharing data, customers can expect a smoother experience, and companies can retain brand equity by remembering customer information.

site_title: Tillerson plans to skip Nato meeting, visit Russia in April: sources
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson plans to skip a NATO meeting in April and instead attend President Donald Trump's talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping. Tillerson also intends to visit Russia in April, a move seen as prioritizing big powers over smaller nations. This decision may fuel concerns that the Trump administration is playing with Russia, undermining the security of NATO allies.

site_title: Close to half of Singapore employers plan salary increases of 3 to 6%: Hays
summary: Singapore employers plan salary increases of 3 to 6% during the next pay review, with 46% of employers opting for this range and 34% offering up to 3%. Two-thirds of employers plan to give bonuses to all employees, with bonuses worth 11-50% of staff salary being the most common. However, the accountancy and finance sector is expected to face a tougher year ahead, with hiring levels at junior to mid-level positions and replacement hiring only.

images.alt_text: Some 46 per cent of Singapore employers are planning salary increases of 3 to 6 per cent during the next pay review, said recruiter Hays on Tuesday.

site_title: Gold slips on technical selling; Fed stance caps fall
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,227.50 per ounce as it failed to break a key resistance level. The Chicago Federal Reserve's President Charles Evans stated the US central bank will likely wait until at least June to decide on interest rate hikes. This news capped gold's gains, which had reached two-week highs of $1,235.50 on Monday.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged down on Tuesday as it failed to break a key resistance, but held near two-week highs hit in the previous session after the Chicago Federal Reserve's president said the US central bank would not rush to hike interest rates.

site_title: Aussie runs into resistance at 4-month top, NZ dollar awaits dairy sale
summary: The Australian dollar reached a four-month high of US$0.7748, driven by weakness in the US dollar after the Federal Reserve emphasized further rate hikes. However, the Reserve Bank of Australia's warnings about an overheating housing market led investors to pare the chance of a rate cut. The New Zealand dollar was also slightly softer, on a "slow-grind-higher trajectory," as the country's dairy auction may see another drop in prices. Rate futures now price in virtually no chance of another Australian rate cut and some possibility of a hike next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 2.98 points to 1,752.390. The index saw 350.8 million lots traded worth RM115.5 million, with 242 gainers outnumbering 85 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 4.78 points to 3,170.48. About 44 million shares worth S$44 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 78 to 39. The market is ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: Distraught Hong Kong villagers battle to save their homes
summary: Hong Kong villagers face eviction to make way for 4,000 public housing units in the rural community of Wang Chau, which has been a home to residents since the 1950s. Despite government claims of relocation and compensation, many residents refuse to leave, citing a lack of consultation and concerns about corruption and displacement. Critics argue that the government's approach benefits private developers and powerful rural elites at the expense of the public. Villagers plan further protests ahead of a vote for Hong Kong's new leader, calling for their communities to be preserved.

site_title: Bayer's drug sales in Asia-Pac up 8.6% in 2016
summary: Bayer reported an 8.6% increase in Asia-Pacific drug sales to 4.8 billion euros (S$7.21 billion) in 2016, its sixth consecutive year of growth. The company attributes its success to its portfolio of innovative medicines addressing unmet medical needs. Bayer expects global pharmaceutical sales of over 17 billion euros for 2017. This growth is a result of nearly doubling sales from 2.6 billion euros in 2010.

images.alt_text: Pharmaceutical company Bayer reported an 8.6 per cent increase to 4.8 billion euros (S$7.21 billion) in drug sales in the Asia-Pacific region in 2016.

site_title: David Rockefeller, banker, philanthropist, heir, dies at 101
summary: David Rockefeller, the 101-year-old billionaire and philanthropist, has died from congestive heart failure at his home in Pocantico Hills, New York. As the world's oldest billionaire, Rockefeller was the youngest and last-surviving grandson of Standard Oil founder John D Rockefeller. He spent his career in the corporate world, rising to CEO of Chase Manhattan Bank, and was a confidant of world leaders. Rockefeller was also known for his philanthropy, donating millions to institutions such as the Museum of Modern Art and Rockefeller University. His death closes a chapter in the storied history of the Rockefeller family.

site_title: PBOC to inject 80b yuan via reverse repos -traders
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), will inject 80 billion yuan into money markets on Tuesday through reverse repos, following a net drain of 120 billion yuan last week. The injection includes 50 billion yuan for seven-day repos, 20 billion yuan for 14-day repos, and 10 billion yuan for 28-day repos. This move aims to stabilize the money market and is seen as a response to the recent rate hike. The volume-weighted average of the seven-day repo rate is at 2.45 percent, down 46.96 basis points from the previous closing average rate.

site_title: First Origin acquires Hong Kong Life Insurance for HK$7.1b
summary: First Origin International Ltd, a Hong Kong-based investment firm, has acquired Hong Kong Life Insurance Ltd for HK$7.1 billion. The acquisition, subject to regulatory approvals, marks the latest insurance deal in the territory. Hong Kong Life Insurance, founded in 2001, is one of the last remaining independent life businesses in the financial centre. The deal is seen as attractive to new entrants in the market, which is expected to see premiums grow 9.2% in 2016.

site_title: New Zealand's 'green' image under threat: OECD
summary: New Zealand's strong economic growth is threatening its "clean, green" reputation, according to the OECD. The country's farm-reliant economy is putting pressure on the environment, with elevated nitrogen levels in rivers, species extinction, and rising greenhouse gas emissions. The OECD recommends strengthening the country's emission trading scheme and expanding it to agriculture, which accounts for half of the country's emissions. Environment Minister Nick Smith welcomed the report, stating the government is already working on the issues, and plans to double agricultural exports by 2025 may worsen the problems.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.56% and the Topix index down 0.38%, due to a strong yen. The selling pressure was influenced by Wall Street's decline in banking shares.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won jump to multi-month highs; Park eclipsed
summary: South Korean shares reached multi-month highs on Tuesday, driven by optimistic hopes for upbeat first-quarter earnings and a strong won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.9% to 2,177.04 points, its highest level since April 24, 2015. Ousted President Park Geun-Hye's questioning as a criminal suspect had little impact on the market, with analysts attributing the rally to market players' disregard for the scandal. Hyundai Motor Co shares surged, and the won reached a five-month high against the US dollar.

site_title: Two in five Americans say they'll need US$1m to retire
summary: A recent survey by the Employee Benefit Research Institute found that 27% of workers believe they'll need at least $1 million to retire comfortably, up from 19% a decade ago. Only 41% of workers have even attempted to calculate their retirement savings needs. The survey also found that retirees tend to underestimate healthcare costs, with 39% expecting costs to be about what they expected, but 27% and 13% expecting costs to be somewhat higher and much higher, respectively. The survey's results highlight the challenges Americans face in planning for retirement.

images.alt_text: Setting a retirement savings goal can feel like a crap shoot. How can you calculate your expenses, especially for health care, five, 10, 50 years from now?

site_title: Formula One: All change as new owners steer F1 into fast lane
summary: Formula One is set to begin its revamped era under new American ownership, with Liberty Media's takeover and changes to technical regulations aiming to attract a younger, global audience. The sport has overhauled its rules to create 'fatter and faster' cars with broader tyres, which are expected to provide more noise and spectacle. Mercedes remains the dominant team, but Ferrari and Red Bull are expected to mount a challenge. Despite changes, old fears persist about the sport's decline in fan base, and a five-year plan is needed to level the playing field in terms of financial resources.

site_title: RBA warns over housing risks, debt as global reflation emerges
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has warned of housing risks and high debt levels in the country, despite global economic reflation. The central bank noted a build-up of risks in the housing market, with household debt growing faster than income. Despite this, the RBA left interest rates unchanged at 1.5% to avoid fueling the property market. The warning comes as house prices surge in cities like Sydney and Melbourne, while the US dollar was little changed following the report.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip from 15-month highs as oils, banks fall
summary: European shares retreated 0.2% from 15-month highs as oil stocks and Deutsche Bank fell, weighed down by lower crude prices and rising US drilling activity. The Stoxx 600 index hit its highest level since December 2015, but caution prevailed after world leaders failed to yield a compromise on global trade. The oil and gas index fell 1.1%, with major oil majors like Total and Royal Dutch Shell down between 0.7 and 2.4%. Deutsche Bank fell 3.7% ahead of its cash call, while Vodafone shares dropped 0.4% after agreeing to merge with India's Idea Cellular.

site_title: Trump's daughter Ivanka to get West Wing office
summary: President Donald Trump's daughter, Ivanka Trump, is getting a West Wing office in the White House, stepping up her advisory role. She will have access to classified information and a government phone but won't have an official title or salary.

site_title: Scottish lawmakers debate new independence referendum
summary: Scottish lawmakers begin a two-day debate on a potential new independence referendum, as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon pushes for a second vote after the 2014 referendum in which Scots voted to stay in Britain. The Scottish parliament is expected to endorse Sturgeon's campaign on Wednesday, putting pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May as she prepares to launch Brexit negotiations. The move is seen as a major hurdle for May ahead of the UK's expected departure from the EU in 2019.

site_title: China Premier Li says will further open services, industries: Xinhua
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang announced plans to further open China's services, manufacturing, and mining sectors to the outside world, aiming to promote free trade. He vowed to streamline administrative procedures and ensure a level playing field for foreign investments. Li also invited foreign companies to invest in China and cooperate with local enterprises. The move contrasts with recent restrictions on market access, which a senior minister said was crucial for domestic growth. The comments were made at a meeting in Beijing, attended by prominent business leaders, including HSBC's Stuart Gulliver and Apple's Tim Cook.

site_title: South Korea's Park apologises, promises cooperation in graft probe
summary: South Korea's ousted President Park Geun-Hye apologized to the country as she arrived at prosecutors' offices for questioning as a criminal suspect in a corruption investigation. She denied wrongdoing, but faces over 10 years in jail if convicted of receiving bribes. Park, 65, was dismissed from office on March 10 and lost her presidential immunity. The investigation, which has cost her the presidency, has also raised tensions with North Korea and China. Park will cooperate with questioning and is expected to face more charges, with a presidential election scheduled for May 9.

images.alt_text: Ousted South Korean President Park Geun Hye apologised to the country on Tuesday as she arrived at prosecutors' offices for questioning as a criminal suspect in a widening corruption investigation that has already cost her the presidency.

site_title: Oil prices rise on talk that Opec could extend supply cut
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as expectations grew that an Opec-led production cut could be extended, potentially rebalancing the market. Prices for Brent crude futures rose 0.3% to $51.76 per barrel, while WTI crude futures increased 0.1% to $48.28 per barrel. The Opec-led production cut, aimed at 1.8 million barrels per day from January to June, has not yet had the desired effect due to patchy compliance and increased production from other countries, including the US. Traders believe healthy oil demand will support prices and help rebalance markets.

site_title: UK banks 'handled' US$740m in laundered Russian money: reports
summary: British banks, including HSBC, Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), Barclays, and Coutts, allegedly processed nearly $740 million in laundered Russian money between 2010 and 2014. The money was part of a multi-billion dollar operation called "The Global Laundromat," involving over 500 people, including oligarchs and Russian criminals linked to the government and KGB. The operation involved 1,900 transactions worth $740 million at British banks and 373 operations worth $63 million at US banks. The banks denied raising the alarm on suspicious transfers, stating they only processed laundered money.

site_title: Natural Cool appoints adviser, chief corporate officer
