summary: Natural Cool Holdings, an air-conditioning firm, has appointed two existing directors as adviser and chief corporate officer. Independent chairman Goh Teck Sia will oversee law enforcement matters, while Wong Leon Keat will handle finance, human resources, and business development. This appointment comes after a shareholder revolt and a February announcement of potential irregular transactions at some subsidiaries in its paint division. The company's stock last traded at S$0.12.

site_title: Goldman Sachs set to hire developer to work on new robo-adviser
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to hire a software developer to create a robo-adviser platform for mass-market wealth clients, covering the mass affluent market with automated digital advice. The platform will provide detailed financial portfolio information and analytics. The move is part of the bank's expansion into mass-market consumers, following its recent online bank and internet lender launches. The robo-adviser will be housed in Goldman Sachs' investment-management division, which oversees $1.4 trillion in client assets.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc plans to hire a software developer to help open an automated investing service for mass-market wealth clients.

site_title: G20 rift divides markets
summary: G20 finance ministers failed to renew a pledge to reject protectionism, citing US President Donald Trump's "America First" push, causing global markets to wobble. Investors took profits from last week's gains, swapping risky equities for safer assets. The move follows Trump's warnings to impose levies and revise trade agreements, with analysts predicting a more aggressive position on international trade. This has raised concerns about protectionism, trade wars, and the impact on the global economy.

site_title: US to ban some airline passengers from carrying larger electronics
summary: US authorities plan to ban passengers on certain foreign airline flights from carrying larger electronic devices in the cabin due to an unspecified terrorism threat. The ban, expected to be announced by the Department of Homeland Security, affects nearly a dozen foreign airlines and 10 airports in eight Middle Eastern and North African countries. Passengers will be allowed to carry larger devices in checked luggage, but devices larger than a cell phone will be prohibited. The ban is a response to a threat learned several weeks ago, and no American carriers are affected.

site_title: China's HNA said in US$2.21b deal to buy NYC office tower
summary: China's HNA Group Co is set to acquire Manhattan's 245 Park Ave office tower for $2.21 billion, one of the highest prices paid for a New York skyscraper. The 158,000-square-metre building, home to JPMorgan Chase & Co, will be sold by Brookfield Property Partners LP and the New York State Teachers' Retirement System. The deal brings Chinese ownership to the heart of midtown Manhattan's financial core. This is the latest in HNA's string of acquisitions, totaling over $30 billion since last year.

site_title: Beijing shuts last coal power plant in switch to natural gas
summary: Beijing has shut its last large coal-fired power plant, switching to natural gas to meet its electricity needs. The move comes as the city faces severe smog, with PM2.5 levels exceeding the World Health Organization's recommended maximum. The closure of the Huangneng Beijing Thermal Power Plant marks the end of coal power in the city, replacing it with gas thermal power centers. This switch is part of China's 2013 clean air action plan, aiming to reduce coal emissions by nearly 10 million tonnes annually.

site_title: Hacked websites on the rise: Google
summary: Google reports a 32% increase in hacked websites last year, with no signs of slowing down. Most hacked sites can be cleaned up, but 61% are not verified by Google and therefore not notified. The company warns of evolving hacking patterns, including inserting "gibberish" or Japanese text linking to fake sites. Google advises a preventative approach to securing websites rather than dealing with the aftermath, citing the phrase "a chain is only as strong as its weakest link."

images.alt_text: Google painted a bleak picture of cybersecurity trends Monday, saying the number of websites hacked rose 32 per cent last year, with little relief in sight.

site_title: Ninth grandchild on the way for Trump
summary: President Donald Trump is set to become a grandfather for the ninth time as his son Eric and wife Lara Trump announce the upcoming birth of their first child, a boy, in September. Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, and Donald Trump Jr are the children of Trump's first marriage to Ivana Trump. This marks the addition to Trump's existing eight grandchildren, with Eric's wife Lara Trump, a former producer for "Inside Edition", involved with animal charities. The news was met with congratulations from the president, who is now awaiting the arrival of his 19th great-grandchild.

site_title: Toshiba's Westinghouse seeks US bankruptcy financing: sources
summary: Westinghouse Electric Co. LLC, a nuclear power plant developer owned by Toshiba Corp, is seeking US$500 million in financing to help it go through US bankruptcy. The financing package, if secured, would allow Westinghouse to continue paying employees and building four nuclear power plants in Georgia and South Carolina. Toshiba has previously stated it would take a US$6.3 billion writedown related to Westinghouse, and the company is reviewing proposals from financial institutions and investment firms.

images.alt_text: Westinghouse Electric Co LLC, the nuclear power plant developer owned by Japanese electronics company Toshiba Corp, is taking offers for a financing package to help it go through US bankruptcy, people familiar with the matter said on Monday.

site_title: China appears to violate trade agreements, says South Korea minister
summary: South Korea's trade minister has complained to the World Trade Organization (WTO) about China's retaliation against South Korean companies over the deployment of a US anti-missile defense system, Thaad. China claims the powerful radar could penetrate its territory, but South Korea says it's intended to guard against North Korean missile launches. The WTO complaint may lead to a trade dispute, and South Korea's government is strengthening communications with Beijing to resolve the issue.

site_title: Wal-Mart to launch investment arm in e-commerce push
summary: Wal-Mart is launching its first investment arm, Store No 8, to expand its e-commerce business in partnership with retail start-ups, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs. The venture will focus on emerging technologies such as robotics, virtual reality, and artificial intelligence. Based in California's Silicon Valley, Store No 8 will operate separately from Wal-Mart to avoid affecting the retailer's bottom line. The plan is being spearheaded by Marc Lore, Wal-Mart's e-commerce chief, who previously led Jet.com before its acquisition by Wal-Mart. A timeframe for the launch has not been announced.

site_title: Swiss bank UBS to be tried in France over tax fraud
summary: Swiss banking giant UBS will face trial in France for allegedly establishing a tax fraud scheme totaling billions of euros. The bank and five top managers, including Raoul Weil, will be charged with illegal banking practices and dissimulating tax fraud. The scheme allegedly involved setting up dual bookkeeping to hide capital movement between 2004 and 2012, affecting at least 38,000 French clients and 9.76 billion euros in unreported income. UBS has denied any wrongdoing, but the trial will offer the bank the chance to respond to the accusations.

site_title: US: Wall Street drifts lower; investors worry about tax-cut delay
summary: US stocks drifted lower on Monday as investors worried about the delay in President Donald Trump's tax-cut plan, which could hinder the market's record-setting spree since his election. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average ended lower, while the Nasdaq Composite edged up slightly. Investors are concerned about the lack of clarity on tax reform and the potential impact on the economy.

site_title: Le Pen under attack in first French presidential debate
summary: French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen faced intense scrutiny over her stance on security and Islam during a TV debate, a month before the country's April 23 first-round voting. Le Pen's proposal to restrict religious garb in public spaces was criticized by opponents, including Emmanuel Macron, who accused her of trying to divide the French. Meanwhile, former economy minister Fillon struggled to regain support after being embroiled in scandals. The debate marked a crucial moment in the election, with Macron currently leading in polls for the second round on May 7.

site_title: And the world's happiest country is... Norway
summary: Norway has been named the world's happiest country by the World Happiness Report 2017, surpassing Denmark and Iceland, which ranked second and third respectively. The report attributed Norway's high ranking to its strong social support, good governance, generosity, honesty, health, income, and caring environment. Other top countries included Finland, The Netherlands, Canada, and Australia. The report found that mental illness is a major source of misery, but that money is not the only factor for happiness, particularly in affluent countries.

site_title: Money doesn't buy happiness - at least not in America
summary: The US ranked 19th in happiness among 34 countries in the 2016 World Happiness Report, down from third in 2007. Despite an economic turnaround with rising income and low unemployment, Americans are becoming less happy. The report found that money does not buy happiness in the US, and improvements in GDP would have a limited impact on overall happiness. Instead, social change is needed, including reducing income inequality, improving social trust, and addressing issues like corruption and access to education.

site_title: UK to trigger Brexit on March 29; two years of talks ahead
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May will trigger Brexit on March 29, starting two years of negotiations with the EU. The talks will focus on trade, immigration, and lawmaking, with the UK seeking to regain powers without derailing trade with its largest market. The EU is preparing to focus on the exit fee, estimated at 60 billion euros, and will not offer generous terms, fearing it would encourage exit campaigners elsewhere. The negotiations are expected to be complex and potentially "vicious," with the UK's economy facing uncertainty and higher trade tariffs if no agreement is reached.

site_title: Looking at US election campaign from a business perspective
summary: The US election campaign of Donald Trump has sharply divided the country, with a significant portion supporting him and a larger portion opposing him. From a business perspective, Trump's campaign strategy was effective due to its focus, priorities, and communication. The Republican Party successfully targeted a core demographic, prioritized a resonant message, and communicated effectively to that audience. This approach can be applied to both private and public sectors, but the US needs a multi-party system to meet the diverse demographics and preferences of its population, allowing for more nuanced policy-making and representation.

site_title: Virgin Australia unveils Australia-Hong Kong flights, opening China route
summary: Virgin Australia has announced five return flights a week between Melbourne and Hong Kong, marking its entry into the Chinese travel market. The airline, 10% owned by Richard Branson, aims to tap into Australia's fastest-growing inbound travel market. A proposed alliance with HNA and Hong Kong Airlines will allow customers to connect via Hong Kong to 13 mainland Chinese destinations. Virgin Australia will compete with Qantas Airways and Cathay Pacific Airways on the Melbourne-Hong Kong route, with plans to expand flights to mainland China in the longer term.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd, the country's No 2 airline, said it would run five return flights a week between the city of Melbourne and Hong Kong, making good on previously disclosed plans to tap the lucrative Chinese travel market.

site_title: How to spot Switzerland's truly rich? Look at their car plates
summary: In Switzerland, a unique system of licence plates has become a status symbol, with rare numbers selling for thousands of francs. The two-letter code indicating the canton followed by a number has been in place since 1933, and buyers are willing to pay for low-digit numbers to showcase their wealth and prestige. The system, which assigns numbers to individuals rather than cars, has become synonymous with old money, with some owners even attaching the plates to their children's cars as a family heirloom.

site_title: Valuetronics plans 1-for-10 bonus share issue
summary: Valuetronics, a Singapore-based electronics manufacturing services provider, plans a 1-for-10 bonus share issue to reflect its business growth and expansion. The company, which has seen its stock price surge 50% year-to-date, will issue up to 38.5 million bonus shares out of its 384 million existing shares. The move aims to improve trading liquidity and attractiveness, with no expected impact on shareholder wealth. A special general meeting will be held to approve the issue.

site_title: Before investing in a social media firm, use its platform
summary: A recent seminar by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) emphasized the importance of understanding a social media company's valuation and growth prospects before investing. The seminar distinguished between early-stage, growth-stage, and late-stage companies, highlighting the use of metrics such as monthly active users and revenue. Notable examples include Snap's IPO, which saw its stock price skyrocket before being deemed overvalued, and the varying market capitalizations of Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn. Experts advised investors to focus on a company's business model, scalability, and revenue potential, and to be users of the platform themselves to gain a deeper understanding.

site_title: Singapore dividend plays still a draw
summary: Singapore-listed dividend yield plays remain attractive despite the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, with Reits, telcos, tech companies, and banks emerging as top picks. Analysts point to sectors' strong dividend yields, such as Reits (6.3%), telcos (4.5-5%), and technology (over 4%), as reasons for optimism. Experts advise investors to focus on stocks with strong balance sheets, growth drivers, and sustainable dividend payments, with some analysts recommending specific counters like Keppel DC Reit, Singtel, and Venture Corp.

site_title: China defends plan to boost its high-tech industries
summary: China defends its plan to boost high-tech industries through "Made in China 2025," a $300 billion program providing government aid to promote domestic production. The plan aims to increase Chinese companies' ownership in specific markets to 80% in eight years. Senior Chinese official Miao Wei acknowledged that the plan may need adjustments, but emphasized that foreign companies are still welcome in China. The program has raised concerns about protectionism and potential restrictions on Western technology, prompting criticism from Western companies and governments.

site_title: France, Japan back free navigation in Asia-Pacific, Abe says
summary: French President Francois Hollande and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed on the importance of a "free and open maritime order" in the Asia-Pacific region, aimed at China's growing military presence in the South China Sea. Japan plans to dispatch its largest warship on a three-month tour through the sea, while France and Japan will conduct joint naval exercises. The two countries also signed an agreement on reinforced cooperation on nuclear energy and expressed support for a free-trade pact with the European Union.

images.alt_text: France and Japan support a "free and open maritime order" in the Asia-Pacific region, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said after talks with French President Francois Hollande on Monday.

site_title: Overseas M&A like a rose with thorns: China FX chief
summary: China's foreign-exchange regulator, Pan Gongsheng, warned Chinese companies investing overseas to be cautious and invest rationally due to potential risks. He compared overseas mergers and acquisitions to grasping sand at the beach, as deals can easily fall through. Investment by Chinese firms in January tumbled 84.3% for offshore properties and 35.7% for overseas direct investment. Pan advised against irrational investments, such as buying a food company by a steel factory or an online gaming company by a restaurant business, and urged companies to exercise due diligence.

site_title: Armed with US$11b, Thailand oil giants hunt for investments
summary: Thailand's PTT Exploration & Production (PTT E&P) and its parent company, PTT Pcl, are set to invest $11 billion in oil and gas projects, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) plants, to rescue declining reserves. With reserves expected to last only five years, PTT E&P is eyeing early-life producing assets and mergers and acquisitions to maintain growth. The company is also looking to expand LNG imports to meet growing domestic demand. PTT Pcl will support these investments, and the companies are optimistic about finding common ground in the market despite volatility.

site_title: FBI confirms probe of Trump team ties to Russia
summary: The FBI has confirmed a probe into potential ties between the Trump campaign and Russia, with FBI chief James Comey stating that the investigation began in July 2016. Comey denied President Trump's claim of being wiretapped by former President Barack Obama, stating that there is no evidence to support the claim. The probe is focused on investigating links between Trump campaign aides and the Russian government, and whether there was coordination with Russia's efforts to influence the 2016 election.

images.alt_text: FBI chief James Comey dealt Donald Trump a double blow Monday by confirming a probe into his election campaign's links to Russia last year while repudiating the president's claim that he was wiretapped by Barack Obama.

site_title: Connecting with customers: Keep it short and simple
summary: Companies struggle to effectively communicate their value proposition, often resulting in lengthy and unclear messages. Neuroscience suggests that the human mind can only digest so much information, and emotions play a significant role in decision-making. To overcome this, companies should focus on the core benefits they offer to customers, such as saving money, increasing convenience, or reducing risk. Developing a simple and powerful tagline can be an effective way to distill this message, as seen in successful examples like Ajax, Subway, and L'Oreal. By prioritizing simplicity and brevity, companies can create a lasting impact and differentiate themselves from competitors.

site_title: China bans Brazil meat in health scare: Brasilia
summary: China has suspended imports of Brazilian meat over allegations that exporters bribed health inspectors to certify tainted products. The move comes amid a scandal threatening Brazil's reputation as the world's largest beef and poultry exporter. At least 30 people have been arrested, and over a dozen processing plants have been raided. Brazil's agriculture minister will hold a videoconference with Chinese authorities to offer clarifications, and other countries including Chile and the European Union are also imposing temporary bans on Brazilian meat imports.

images.alt_text: Brazil said Monday that China had suspended imports of meat from the South American country over police claims that Brazilian exporters had sold tainted products.

site_title: Porsche gears up its profit machine to net US$17,250 a car
summary: Porsche reported an operating profit of 3.9 billion euros (S$5.9 billion) in 2016, a 14% increase from 2015, resulting in a net profit of around US$17,250 per vehicle. This is significantly higher than its competitors Daimler AG and Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW), which netted about US$5,000 and US$5,000 per vehicle, respectively. Porsche's profit margin is largely due to its premium pricing, with the company selling vehicles for nearly US$99,000 each, and offering various add-ons that can increase the price by thousands of dollars.

site_title: Chinese billionaire who toppled Apple in China
summary: Chinese billionaire Duan Yongping, founder of Oppo and Vivo, has credited his success in toppling Apple in China to the company's failure to adapt to local competition. Duan, who has invested heavily in Apple and is a fan of its CEO Tim Cook, said Apple was too stubborn to match Oppo and Vivo's tactics, such as offering cheaper devices with high-end features. This strategy allowed Oppo and Vivo to leapfrog Apple in China's smartphone market, shipping over 147 million units in 2016. Duan, dubbed China's Warren Buffett, believes Apple's flaws make it vulnerable to local competition, and he is now gaining momentum beyond China.

site_title: US dollar steadies near 6-week low as Fed rate outlook continues to weigh
summary: The US dollar hovered near a six-week low against a basket of currencies on Monday due to the Federal Reserve's less "hawkish" interest-rate guidance. The Fed raised interest rates but stopped short of predicting a sharper pace of monetary policy tightening. This led to a decline in the dollar index, with sterling falling against the dollar following news that Prime Minister Theresa May would trigger Britain's divorce proceedings with the European Union. Analysts attribute the dollar's sluggishness to the Fed's dovish stance, with some citing comments from Chicago Fed President Charles Evans as supporting the greenback's rebound.

site_title: Polls: left-leaning alliance could oust Merkel's conservatives in Saarland
summary: In the German state of Saarland, a left-leaning "red-red-green" alliance of the Social Democrats, the Linke party, and the Greens is likely to emerge after the March 26 state election, potentially foreshadowing a federal election upset for Chancellor Angela Merkel. National polls suggest the coalition could achieve a majority in the Bundestag, and the SPD's new leader, Martin Schulz, hopes to oust Merkel. A three-way leftist alliance would be the third at state level, with potential implications for the federal election in September.

site_title: In Beijing, 2 wheels are only a smartphone away
summary: In Beijing, a surge of shared bike-sharing services has flooded the city since last year, with over two dozen technology startups offering affordable, smartphone-controlled bikes that cost as little as 7 US cents per half-hour. The bikes have transformed urban living, offering commuters flexibility and freedom, and may influence where people choose to live and work. Analysts attribute the sudden surge to a combination of private investment, a good product, and government support. As the city's population grows and traffic jams worsen, shared bikes are seen as an environmentally friendly solution to the "last mile" problem.

images.alt_text: A commuter riding off on an Ofo bike. Thanks to about two dozen technology startups, brightly coloured shared bikes have flooded Beijing since last year, dotting a normally drab cityscape with flashes of bumblebee yellow, kingfisher blue and tangerine.

site_title: Malaysia retail sales sputter amid steadier but still weak ringgit
summary: Malaysia's retail sales have stagnated, growing by a negligible 0.3% in the last quarter of 2016, amidst a weak ringgit and bleak job prospects. The country's central bank has taken steps to stabilize the currency, but it remains depressed at 4.4 to the US dollar. Consumer demand has been severely impacted, with retailers expecting a 0.9-1.5% growth in the first quarter of 2017. The economy's sluggish growth is attributed to the diminished value of the ringgit, rising prices, and the impact of the 1MDB scandal on investor confidence.

site_title: 2 Japan life insurers to raise green investments
summary: Two major Japanese life insurers, Meiji Yasuda Life and Nippon Life, have announced plans to diversify their credit investments, focusing on socially responsible debt and sustainability products. Meiji Yasuda aims to increase foreign credit investments to 800 billion yen, while Nippon Life will invest 200 billion yen in ESG-principled bonds. This move is expected to expand global appetite for yen products and boost the international yen market, with bankers welcoming the increased sums earmarked for sustainability investments.

site_title: Helping S'pore SMEs stay agile in the digital economy
summary: Singapore aims to support small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the digital economy through the SMEs Go Digital Programme. The programme, launched in 2017, provides multi-pronged guidance, funding support, and sector-specific expertise to help SMEs upgrade their digital capabilities. The government recognizes the digital economy's potential for growth, with the digital economy expected to generate 53,000 new jobs in Singapore by 2018. However, many SMEs struggle to invest in digital initiatives due to limited resources, and the government is considering tax incentives to support their digital transformation.

site_title: Kampung in Jakarta goes green to fight eviction
summary: Residents of Tongkol kampung in Jakarta, Indonesia, have transformed their riverside community into a model of clean and green living after facing the threat of eviction due to annual flooding. The community, comprising 260 families, has implemented a major clean-up, built new walls and painted their houses in bright colors, cultivated gardens, and fitted septic tanks to reduce sewage into the river. Despite some residents still littering, the kampung has made significant progress in reducing the risk of flooding and has become a testament to the power of community-led initiatives in fighting eviction.

site_title: PM Lee on four-day official visit to Vietnam
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is on a four-day official visit to Vietnam, reaffirming Singapore's long-standing ties with the fellow Asean member state. The trip includes stops in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi, marking Lee's first official trip this year. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral relations and cooperation in various areas.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Vodafone and Idea Cellular to merge and create new India market leader
summary: Vodafone Group and Idea Cellular agreed to merge their Indian operations, creating the country's largest telecom business with 400 million customers and a 35% market share. The combined entity will have an implied enterprise value of $17.7 billion for Vodafone and $17.2 billion for Idea. The merger aims to contest the brutal price war sparked by Reliance Jio Infocomm, which has forced India's three biggest operators to slash prices and accept lower profits.

images.alt_text: Aditya Birla chairman Kumar Mangalam Birla (left), with Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao. Vodafone will own 45.1 per cent of the merged entity, Aditya Birla will own 26 per cent, while other shareholders will own the remaining 28.9 per cent.

site_title: Moscow's dividend yield is highest among markets but investors are not biting
summary: Moscow's dividend yield is the highest among markets, but investors are hesitant to invest due to concerns about US sanctions easing on Russia. The strong emerging market rally since 2012 has left Russian stocks behind, with investors instead focusing on more attractive dividend yields in other markets.

images.alt_text: Dividends on Russian stocks are blooming, but investors are dumping Moscow-listed shares on concerns that the US won't ease sanctions on Russia as quickly as previously expected. Investors are watching the oil-price outlook and the contours of the US-Russian relationship.

site_title: Permanent Government's fight back can restore status quo
summary: US President Trump's administration is launching a "drain the swamp" effort, aiming to reduce the power and influence of the "permanent government" in Washington, which includes bureaucrats, politicians, and interest groups. The opposition to Trump, known as the "resistance," is seen as a rear-guard action by those who feel threatened by the new administration's assault on their power and control. The permanent government, comprising affluent Washingtonians, has been trying to derail Trump's campaign since 2015, and the president's budget plan calls for significant cuts to government departments and programs, benefiting interest groups like military contractors and environmental organizations, while harming those promoting environmental causes.

site_title: Dollar weak for 4th day after G-20 trade concerns
summary: The US dollar weakened for the fourth consecutive day against a basket of currencies, following the G-20 summit dominated by the Trump administration's protectionist stance. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike did not deter the dollar's decline, with markets expressing concern about the US's global trade relations. The dollar index fell 0.3% in early trading before recovering some ground. Analysts suggest that the Trump administration's protectionist policies may lead to a weaker dollar, but doubts remain about the speed and passage of border tax reform in Congress.

site_title: First clash of G-20 sets the stage for battle of trade ideas
summary: The G20's first meeting with the Trump administration has left a "fault line" in global economic diplomacy, with the absence of a reference to resisting protectionism. The communique toned down its stance on trade, with some officials expressing concerns that the US will implement campaign rhetoric on trade. The Hamburg summit in July has become crucial in gauging the administration's intentions, with participants calling for a concerted effort to defend free trade and avoid protectionism. The shift in tone raises concerns about a potential increase in trade protectionism, which could overshadow global economic diplomacy for months or years.

site_title: Abe's approval rating falls sharply over land scam
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's approval rating has dropped 10 percentage points to 56% due to a land scandal involving a nationalistic school operator. Abe has denied any connection to the scandal, but new twists keep emerging, including allegations of a $12,400 donation from Abe to the school. His defence minister, Tomomi Inada, is also facing criticism over a parallel scandal related to Japan's peace-keeping unit in South Sudan. The scandal marks the biggest monthly fall in Abe's approval rating since he took office in 2012.

site_title: 'Bubbly' Australia housing market may lead to more lending curbs
summary: Australia's housing market is facing a period of "heightened risk" due to rising prices, record household debt, and slow wage growth, according to Australian Prudential Regulation Authority chairman Wayne Byres. The regulator warned that the combination of factors could lead to further lending curbs to cool the market. House prices in major cities, such as Sydney and Melbourne, are "out of whack" with historic metrics, with median prices exceeding 10 times average earnings. Regulators are preparing to take action, with Treasurer Scott Morrison stating that "pressures have built up again" in the housing market.

site_title: Keppel signs deal with Borr Drilling for Transocean rigs
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has signed a heads of agreement with Borr Drilling to novate construction contracts for five jackup rigs currently under construction for Transocean. The deal is expected to be completed before May 2017, with Borr Drilling taking over the contracts and undertaking the remaining payment instalments. The price for each rig is US$216 million, down from US$219 million, and Keppel aims to improve cash flow and minimize risks.

site_title: Once a musician's haven, the Bronx is pricing out its sidemen
summary: The Bronx, once a hub for musical talent, is experiencing a crisis as rising rents and gentrification are pricing out its sidemen. Many musicians, including Grammy-winning flutist Dave Valentin, struggle to find affordable housing, with some having to rely on relatives or crowdfunding to make ends meet. A proposed set-aside for older musicians in a new development was rejected due to fair housing laws, leaving the community without a solution. Advocates argue that the issue is fixable, but the lack of affordable housing options for aging musicians threatens the borough's rich musical heritage.

site_title: Jumbo to open first Beijing restaurant in Q3 of this year
summary: Jumbo Seafood, a Singapore-based F&B group, announced a joint venture agreement to open its first restaurant in Beijing, China, slated for the third quarter of 2017. The new restaurant will be located in Beijing SKP, a high-end luxury shopping mall, with Jumbo holding a 51% stake. This marks Jumbo's expansion plans to other major Asian cities and strengthens its market position. The group's CEO, Ang Kiam Meng, stated that the location will allow them to target the affluent segment of the market in Beijing.

site_title: Cambodia to revise deal with KrisEnergy, paving way for first oil production
summary: Cambodia is revising a 2002 production sharing contract with KrisEnergy to develop its first oil field, the Cambodia Block A, in the Khmer Basin. The deal, expected to be signed in March, includes revised fiscal terms after KrisEnergy became the sole stakeholder last year. The project, valued below $200 million, aims to produce 8,000 barrels of low-sulphur oil per day by the early next decade, with potential partners including state-owned companies or small-scale explorers. The project's timeline may be delayed due to challenges facing KrisEnergy.

site_title: Bangladesh wants Singapore investors
summary: Bangladesh is seeking to attract Singapore investors, particularly in the energy and technology sectors. Despite a large population of skilled workers returning from overseas, the country remains eager for foreign investment to drive growth. Bangladesh has a strong track record of GDP growth and a declining poverty rate, making it an attractive market for investors. The country's government has developed 100 special economic zones and is investing in major projects, including power plants, roads, and bridges. Standard Chartered Bangladesh CEO Abrar Anwar assured that the country's skilled workers can competently work in various areas, including infrastructure development and power plants, making it an attractive destination for investors.

site_title: MoneyGram offers to give Euronet confidential info to firm up bid: sources
summary: MoneyGram International Inc has offered to share confidential information with Euronet Worldwide Inc, a US$1 billion acquisition offer that could surpass a previous deal with China's Ant Financial Services Group. Euronet, which made the offer, will conduct due diligence on MoneyGram before firming up its bid. If MoneyGram declares Euronet's bid superior, Ant Financial will have four business days to improve its offer. The deal is being reviewed by the US government's Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States due to national security concerns.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: M1, a neutral broker, predicts a target price of S$2.05 for NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer, which was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warns of potential revenue and operating loss for the second half of 2025. Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while MAS and PBOC plan to deepen green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: Perennial appeals against High Court decision related to Capitol project
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has filed appeals against the High Court's decision to dismiss winding-up applications for three joint entities, including those involved in the Capitol integrated development project. The court ruled that since Perennial has an exit mechanism available, it should abide by the agreement and use it, rather than seeking winding-up. Perennial will make further announcements as material developments occur, and its stock price dropped 1 cent to S$0.825 on the market.

site_title: Offices of Volkswagen and Audi chiefs searched in raid
summary: German authorities have searched the offices of Volkswagen and Audi chiefs, including CEO Matthias Muller and Audi head Rupert Stadler, as part of a broader investigation into emissions fraud. The warrant, signed by a judge in Munich, allows investigators to seize documents and other items from the executives and numerous employees. The investigation, which focuses on Audi's role in the scandal, portrays a much broader probe than previously known, with 47 people whose property is subject to seizure. Volkswagen has pleaded guilty to charges related to the emissions scandal, acknowledging that the fraud involved numerous employees and departments.

site_title: Vera Lynn turns 100 with White Cliffs of Dover tribute, new album release
summary: Vera Lynn, the renowned World War II singer, celebrated her 100th birthday on March 20, 2017, with a special tribute: her portrait was projected onto the iconic White Cliffs of Dover. The British singer expressed her gratitude for the unique honor, calling it a "wonderful gesture."

site_title: NTU, Schaeffler set up joint research lab
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and the Schaeffler Group have established a joint research lab in Singapore, funded by S$5 million over three years. The lab aims to study personal urban mobility and intelligent transportation systems for mega cities, developing next-generation personal mobility devices. Schaeffler, a leading global automotive supplier, will collaborate with NTU to tackle transportation challenges in Singapore, aligning with the city-state's goal of a car-lite society.

site_title: Healthway Medical reviews Lippo's loan, Gateway's proposal
summary: Healthway Medical Corp (HMC) is reviewing a S$10 million loan from Lippo China Resources (LCR) to pay doctors and nurses, with terms including a 5% interest rate and secured by a master debenture. The loan is part of HMC's efforts to address a cash crunch after writing off doubtful loans. HMC is also reviewing an alternate proposal from Gateway Partners to meet immediate liquidity requirements, which includes removing a coupon from convertible notes and changing redemption terms. The company must review definitive documentation before deliberating further.

site_title: Gamemaker Netmarble seeks as much as 2.7 trillion won in IPO
summary: Netmarble, South Korea's largest mobile game maker, filed for an initial public offering (IPO) to raise up to 2.7 trillion won (S$3.4 billion). The company, which owns 22% of Netmarble, is capitalizing on rising demand for mobile games. Netmarble plans to spend 1 trillion won on deals and investments, with 897 billion won to repay debt. A successful IPO would value the company at 13.3 trillion won, the largest in South Korea since 2010.

site_title: Keppel O&M gets new chief
summary: Keppel Corp announced the appointment of Chris Ong as the new acting CEO of Keppel Offshore & Marine, effective April 1, 2017. Ong, 42, replaces Chow Yew Yuen, who will retire after 36 years of service. Ong, who joined Keppel FELS in 1999, has held various key roles, including managing director of engineering and deputy managing director. His appointment comes after Chow Yew Yuen's retirement on March 31, 2017.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CNMC Goldmine to pay RM2.5 million to acquire KelGold's gold exploration rights in Kelantan. Singapore Airlines Cargo may provide S$111.8 million for a European Commission fine related to air cargo competition law. Global Logistic Properties' unit, GLP Financial Lease (Chongqing), set up a subsidiary in China for 500 million yuan.

site_title: Scottish independence is bad for both Scotland and UK
summary: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon criticized UK Prime Minister Theresa May's refusal to allow a second Scottish independence referendum before the UK leaves the EU. Sturgeon argued that Scottish independence would harm both Scotland and the UK, undermining international influence and weakening alliances with England, Northern Ireland, and Wales. The article highlights the economic and diplomatic implications of independence, including potential budget cuts, military reductions, and erosion of the UK's voice in international forums. Sturgeon's pathway towards a second referendum is also questioned, citing uncertainties and potential economic drawbacks.

images.alt_text: A supporter of the "Yes" campaign in the 2014 referendum. The dangers to Scotland's economy from independence were reportedly highlighted by the country's own Growth Commission, set up by Ms Sturgeon.

site_title: Hedge fund Titan's sure-fire bet turns into US$4b loss
summary: Hedge fund manager William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management incurred a $4 billion loss on Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, a beleaguered drug company. Ackman initially praised Valeant's acquisition strategy, but the company's shares plummeted from $262 to $11. A lawsuit alleges that Ackman and his firm secretly acquired a stake in Allergan based on non-public information. The case may result in $2 billion in damages, with Ackman's lawyers disputing the figure. Ackman's firm has generated billions of dollars in profits, but his investment in Valeant has led to significant losses, wiping out his $2.2 billion profit from Allergan.

site_title: OCBC Wing Hang sells stake in insurer for HK$2.3 billion
summary: OCBC Wing Hang Bank has agreed to sell its one-third stake in Hong Kong Life Insurance to First Origin International for HK$2,366.7 million (about S$426 million). The sale is conditional on regulatory approvals and will result in Hong Kong Life ceasing to be an associated company of OCBC Wing Hang Bank and OCBC Bank. Upon completion, OCBC Wing Hang Bank will distribute Hong Kong Life's products in Hong Kong under a distribution agreement. The sale price was determined after arm's length negotiations following an auction process.

site_title: Taipei frets ahead of expected Trump-Xi meeting
summary: Taipei is urging the US and China to not use Taiwan as a pawn in their diplomatic efforts ahead of an expected meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Taiwan's government is concerned about being pressured to concede its sovereignty to China, which has never renounced the use of force to take back the island. The Taiwanese government is emphasizing the need to protect its own interests and avoid being used as a bargaining chip in the US-China relationship.

site_title: KSH bags S$146m contract from NUS
summary: KSH Holdings secured a S$145.7 million contract from the National University of Singapore to build a 16-floor research building, expected to start on April 1, 2017 and complete within 24 months. The project is expected to positively contribute to the company's financial performance from FY2018. The contract lifts KSH's order book to over S$360 million, and the executive chairman remains optimistic on the construction industry's outlook.

site_title: SGX given 6-point action plan for market outages
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has given the Singapore Exchange (SGX) a 6-point action plan to fortify the market following a 2016 outage. The plan includes implementing clearer continuity plans and maintaining coordination with the industry and service providers. SGX has already implemented three recommendations, including establishing a master record of data and adopting a protocol for assuming trades. The remaining three recommendations are expected to be implemented within 18-24 months. MAS has also lifted a moratorium on fee increases for SGX, citing improvements related to two 2014 outages.

site_title: SGD bonds hit new highs, investors take Ezra default in stride
summary: Singapore bond prices reached new highs, driven by investors seeking yield despite the weekend bankruptcy filing of Ezra Holdings, which had SGD 150 million bonds outstanding. The Markit SGD corporates total-return index rose to 119.9029, influenced by dovish remarks from US Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen. Despite interest rate hikes and the company's default, investors remain confident, citing liquidity and low USD-SGD exchange rates. The SGD bond market has benefited from a drop in rates and a lack of supply, with returns driven by rate movements.

site_title: Uber rivals from Dubai, China tie up for ride-hailing alliance
summary: Uber faces another alliance of rivals as Dubai-based Careem Inc partners with China's Yidao Yongche to share resources and coordinate fleets. The partnership will use London-based Splyt Technologies to enable passengers to travel abroad using drivers from other services. This move aims to negate Uber's single-app advantage, while Splyt's technology connects partners to show available cars and charges a commission on currency exchange. The alliance comes as Yidao faces local media reports of struggling to pay suppliers, and follows a similar four-way partnership between Didi, Lyft, Grab, and Ola in 2015.

site_title: SIA Cargo may make provision in current financial year due to fine
summary: SIA Cargo may provision S$111.8 million in its current financial year due to a 74.8 million euro fine imposed by the European Commission, following the re-adoption of a decision in a European Union air cargo competition law case involving 11 carriers, including SIA Cargo. The company will study the decision and consider an appropriate course of action.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Kimly closes first day of trading at S$0.44
summary: Kimly, a Singaporean food outlet operator, made its stock market debut on Monday with a 120% surge from its IPO price of S$0.25 to close at S$0.44. The company received strong demand, with 108 million shares traded and a public offer subscribed 336 times. Net proceeds will be used for acquisitions and business expansion, with a market capitalization of S$508 million. Despite a 20% drop from its opening price, Kimly's closing price is still 76% above its IPO price.

site_title: New ministerial-level group to raise game in planning, executing digital tech policies
summary: Singapore is establishing a ministerial-level group, the Smart Nation and Digital Government Group (SNDGG), to oversee the development of digital technology policies. The group's priorities include a digital identity system, a nationwide electronic payments system, and an island-wide wireless sensor network. The move aims to drive the Smart Nation initiative more effectively, with Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean and Minister Vivian Balakrishnan expressing support for the consolidation. The group will be led by a ministerial committee and will work to create foundational digital platforms for digital identity, e-payments, and sensors.

site_title: Limited upside for M1, analysts say, amid talk of possible sale
summary: Analysts predict limited upside for telco M1 amid takeover speculation, with valuations ranging from S$1.58 to S$2.74. The intense competition in Singapore's saturated market and potential merger with StarHub are discussed as key factors. Some analysts believe a sale could lead to a general offer for minority shareholders, while others think sector consolidation is unlikely due to regulatory efforts to introduce more competition. M1's stock closed down 0.9% to S$2.17, with some analysts maintaining a "sell" call on the stock.

site_title: G-20 heads give an amiable Mnuchin scope to define Trump's trade agenda
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's amiable approach to Trump's trade agenda has reassured G-20 finance officials, yielding ground to his push for abandoning protectionism and deleting climate change language. Mnuchin's polite demeanor has contrasted with Trump's bluster, providing a voice of reason. The G-20 leaders' concessions come as the US announces new tariffs, sparking concerns for the global economy. Mnuchin's leadership style has eased tensions, but the long-term implications of Trump's trade policies remain uncertain.

site_title: MM2 Asia unit lodges preliminary prospectus for spin-off, Catalist listing
summary: THE Unusual Group, a unit of MM2 Asia, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a spin-off and listing on the Catalist board. This comes after an extraordinary general meeting on March 20, 2017, where the proposed spin-off was approved. The spin-off will be a separate entity, and its shares will be listed on the Catalist board. No further details on the spin-off have been disclosed.

site_title: Singapore's efficiency even extends to its bankruptcy laws
summary: Singapore has introduced changes to its Companies Act to enhance its bankruptcy laws, allowing firms to halt claims from creditors and suppliers, and enabling them to borrow money for operational purposes. The new framework, set to take effect on March 31, provides a restructuring solution for companies like Ezra Holdings, which filed for Chapter 11 protection in the US. The changes also make Singaporean court decisions extra-territorial, making it a more attractive option for international companies seeking debt workouts. This move aims to position Singapore as the preferred center for debt workouts in Asia.

site_title: Meeting on Isis without Russia, China, Iran would be incomplete
summary: The US is hosting a two-day meeting on the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq (Isis) from March 22-23, with 68 nations and international organisations invited. The meeting aims to cut off Isis's sources of fighters, weapons, and funds. This coalition, led by the US, differs from the 2014 Brussels coalition, which focused on funding and military support. The meeting's outcome is unclear, and it's uncertain how it will differ from previous efforts to combat Isis.

site_title: Perennial appeals against Court's decision to dismiss winding-up application for Capitol entities
summary: PERENNIAL Real Estate Holdings (PREH) has filed appeals against the High Court's decision to dismiss winding-up applications for Capitol entities, which developed the Capitol integrated development project. PREH will make further announcements as material developments arise. The company's stock price ended a cent lower at S$0.825 on Monday.

site_title: China prepares to counter any US trade penalties
summary: China is preparing for potential US trade penalties, including tariffs on steel and furniture, and may respond with countermeasures on agriculture, machinery, and consumer electronics. The country's government has been seeking advice from think-tanks and policy advisers on how to mitigate the impact, including stepping up imports from the US and boosting investment there. China has expressed a desire to resolve issues through cooperation and consultation, but is also preparing contingency plans in case of a trade war.

site_title: STI takes a breather, loses 4 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 3.68 points or 0.12% lower at 3,165.7 on Monday, following a data-light week and last Friday's modest losses in US equities. Other regional markets showed mixed results, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 0.8% and China's Shanghai Composite up 0.4%. Singapore's oil and gas stocks fell, while Nam Cheong's shares tumbled 31% after its auditors cast doubts on the firm's ability as a going concern.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: BCA names new chief executive
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has appointed Hugh Lim, Deputy Secretary (Community, Youth and Sports) at the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, as the new chief executive officer, replacing John Keung. Lim will assume duties on June 1, 2017, after being appointed as CEO-designate on April 1.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Bill Gates again world's richest man; Trump slips
summary: Bill Gates has topped Forbes' list of the world's richest billionaires for the fourth straight year, with an estimated net worth of $86 billion. US President Donald Trump slipped 220 spots to number 544, attributed to sluggishness in the Manhattan real estate market. The global billionaire population increased by 13% to 2,043, with the US leading with 565 billionaires, followed by China with 319 and Germany with 114. The required net worth to make the list increased to $3.7 billion.

site_title: As part of Asia pivot, Netanyahu pushes Israeli high-tech in China
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is on a three-day visit to China as part of the country's Asia pivot, aiming to boost high-tech trade and investment between the two nations. Netanyahu seeks to enlarge Israel's presence in China, where infrastructure and construction projects are growing, and encourage Chinese investment in Israel. Bilateral trade has tripled to $3.3 billion in 2016, with technology leading the way. Netanyahu sees China as a strategic partner for technology development, with China's leadership seeking to learn from Israel's high-tech innovation.

images.alt_text: Mr Netanyahu reviews the guard of honour during a welcome ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Monday.

site_title: China Shenhua in biggest rise since 2008 on special dividend
summary: China Shenhua Energy Co, the world's largest coal miner, surged 20% after announcing its first profit growth in four years and a special dividend of 2.51 yuan per share. The company's net income rose 41% to 24.9 billion yuan, driven by a 3.4% revenue expansion and coal prices that surged over 70% last year. The special dividend payout, the largest since 2008, is seen as a positive signal for China's state-owned enterprises, with analysts predicting a "lack of investment opportunity" in the coal industry.

site_title: Freezing N Korea's nuclear programme is best bet for now
summary: North Korea's nuclear and missile programs continue to defy international sanctions, with the country making significant progress despite biting penalties. The US is considering a tougher stance, including a preemptive strike, but Secretary of State Rex Tillerson suggests negotiations can be achieved only through denuclearization. China proposes a freeze on North Korea's nuclear and missile programs in exchange for a halt to US-South Korean military exercises, but the US considers this unacceptable. The US and China are working together to bring North Korea to a different place for dialogue, but time doesn't favor the US, with North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un stating his country is close to testing an intercontinental ballistic missile.

site_title: No, not everyone online shops like you
summary: Affluent US states are faster in adopting online shopping, with states near the coasts and with higher median incomes showing significant growth in e-commerce spending. According to Adobe's Digital Price Index, states like Maryland and Virginia saw 7-8% increases in online spending, while states like Idaho and South Dakota saw declines or steady growth. Affluent consumers, particularly those in urban areas, are driving the growth, with cities like Washington D.C. and New Hampshire showing higher per-person online spending. This suggests that online shopping is not a universal trend, and retailers must adapt their strategies to attract different types of shoppers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.21 points to 1,749.41. The index saw 6.02 billion lots traded worth RM3.02 billion, with 546 gainers and 421 losers.

site_title: Beauty And The Beast clobbers record with US$170m opening
summary: Beauty And The Beast broke Hollywood records with a US$170 million opening in North American theatres, surpassing Batman v Superman: Dawn Of Justice. The film, directed by Bill Condon, also collected an additional US$180 million overseas, aiming for US$1 billion worldwide ticket sales. The movie's success validates Disney's decision to remake classic animated films as live-action event movies and reflects the enduring appeal of its characters, including the inclusion of a gay character in the film. The movie's strong reviews and broad appeal to families and women, with 84% of US parents recommending it for families, contributed to its massive opening.

images.alt_text: Beauty And The Beast ollected an additional US$180 million overseas, placing the movie on a path towards US$1 billion in worldwide ticket sales by the end of its run.

site_title: HK, China: Stocks start week with another rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged to their highest level since summer 2015, rising 0.79% to 24,501.99, as the Federal Reserve signaled a slower pace of interest rate hikes this year. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also gained, with the Hang Seng Index building on last week's rally. The rally follows recent global market momentum and traders' confidence despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Chalking up more Mileage
summary: Mileage Communications, a Singapore-based PR and communications firm, has weathered 25 years of ups and downs without relying on government grants or bank loans. Founded by chairman and founder Yap Boh Tiong in 1992, the company has expanded regionally, establishing offices in nine countries, including India, Malaysia, and South Korea. Yap attributes the firm's success to self-reliance, diversification of clients, and calculated risks. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining strong networks and adapting to industry changes, including the evolution of digital marketing and data analytics.

images.alt_text: Says Mr Yap (seen here with colleagues at a product launch meeting) about the early days of setting up his firm: "Right from the start, we learnt to be self-reliant."

site_title: Healthway Medical reviewing terms of Lippo's loan offer, Gateway's new proposal
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation has received non-binding terms for a S$10 million, 12-month loan from Lippo China Resources to pay doctors and nurses. The company is reviewing the brief loan terms and cannot deliberate further until definitive documentation is received. Meanwhile, Healthway is also reviewing an alternative proposal from Gateway Partners, which is related to a convertible bonds deal. The company is facing a cash crunch after writing off doubtful loans from its books.

images.alt_text: Healthway Medical Corporation has received non-binding terms for proposed interim financing from Lippo China Resources, the company said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Monday.

site_title: US: Stocks waver on oil retreat, protectionism fears
summary: US stocks wavered on Monday, influenced by declining oil prices and concerns over trade protectionism. The Dow Jones fell before edging higher, with petroleum-linked equities, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, experiencing a retreat. Analysts attributed uncertainty in US policy debates and unease over G20 ministers' stance on protectionism to market pressure.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge buys commercial building in Shanghai
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group announced the acquisition of a 24,883 sqm commercial building in Shanghai's Huangpu District. The 14-storey building is near Shanghai's core business district and is home to local and foreign corporations in various industries. The company plans to rename and upgrade the building, providing flexible and intelligent workspaces to support growing enterprises and contribute to China's knowledge economy. No purchase consideration was disclosed.

site_title: Britain's Johnson says Jeremy Fleming to head GCHQ spy agency
summary: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson announced that Jeremy Fleming, the deputy director general of MI5, will become the new head of GCHQ, the UK's intelligence eavesdropping service, replacing Robert Hannigan. Fleming will take over around Easter and has been the deputy director of MI5 since 2013. Johnson praised Fleming's skills and ingenuity in defending the UK from cyber threats and terror plots.

site_title: UK to formally trigger Brexit on March 29
summary: The UK will formally trigger its exit from the European Union on March 29, 2017, marking the beginning of a two-year negotiation process. This follows the country's vote to leave the EU nine months prior. The trigger for Brexit, Article 50, was informed to EU President Donald Tusk by the UK's permanent representative. The UK's exit is expected to be completed by 2019.

site_title: Saudi king's Asia tour signals Aramco's move downstream
summary: Saudi King Salman's Asia tour has signaled a shift in strategy for the kingdom, focusing on the downstream sector of oil refining and petrochemicals. The tour included deals with Malaysia, Indonesia, Japan, and China, aiming to increase Saudi leverage in refined product and petrochemical markets. Aramco, the state oil company, has signed deals worth billions of dollars, including a $7 billion investment in a refinery and petrochemical project in Malaysia. This move is seen as part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 policy to diversify its economy beyond crude exports and increase its influence in the region's energy market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government is forming a ministerial-level group to coordinate digital technology strategies and responses. This comes after offshore and marine firm Ezra Holdings filed for bankruptcy protection in the US, causing shockwaves in the local banking and O&G sectors. The Securities industry group also made recommendations for the Singapore Exchange to adopt clearer continuity plans. Meanwhile, construction firm KSH Holdings secured a S$145.7 million contract to build a research building for the National University of Singapore, and electronics manufacturing services provider Valuetronics announced a bonus share issue.

site_title: IBM launches blockchain service
summary: IBM has launched IBM Blockchain, a service allowing businesses to build enterprise-grade applications using Hyperledger Fabric blockchain code. The Fabric blockchain can process over 1,000 transactions per second, making it suitable for large enterprises. IBM is working with SecureKey Technologies and Canadian banks to build a digital identity network, set to launch later this year, and is increasing investment in the technology to help reduce complexity and costs in processes such as securities settlement and international payments.

site_title: Emas Offshore warns against 'going concern issue' after Ezra's Chapter 11 filing
summary: EMAS Offshore has expressed concerns over the potential negative impact of Ezra's Chapter 11 filing, which may affect the group's financial obligations and working capital facilities. The company is seeking advice and reviewing options to continue its refinancing efforts. EMAS Offshore will work closely with its principal bankers to assess and address the situation.

site_title: Jumbo in JV deal to open first Beijing restaurant (Amended)
summary: Jumbo Group has entered into a joint-venture agreement to open its first Jumbo Seafood restaurant in Beijing, with the new restaurant slated for opening by the third quarter of 2017. The restaurant will be located within Beijing SKP, a high-end luxury shopping mall, and will be the company's fourth restaurant in China. Jumbo will hold a 51% stake in the JV, while Beijing Hualian will hold 49%. The location is expected to cater to the affluent and cosmopolitan segment of the market.

site_title: C&G Environmental Protection declares special divdend after sale of businesses (Amended)
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings has declared a special dividend of 10.3 Singapore cents per share for the 2017 financial year. The company received the balance payment for the sale of its businesses, including 187.7 million yuan from New Sky Energy and HK$344.71 million from Ahead Auto, after agreeing to sell its main operating subsidiary and other group companies for 38 million Singapore dollars and 108 million Singapore dollars, respectively. The sale of businesses was completed after the group received the remaining payment of 500 million yuan from New Sky.

site_title: Indonesia plans to sue Thailand's PTTEP over 2009 oil spill
summary: Indonesia plans to sue Thailand's PTTEP over the 2009 Montara oil spill, which released 30,000 barrels of oil into the Timor Sea. The Indonesian government and state prosecutors are compiling evidence and have invited 50 expert witnesses to support the case. The spill was Australia's worst offshore drilling accident, and an Australian inquiry blamed it on systemic shortcomings at PTTEP. The case relates to Indonesian sovereignty and poor communities whose lives depend on the maritime sector.

site_title: PM Lee to make official visit to Vietnam this week
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will make an official visit to Vietnam from Tuesday to Friday, reaffirming the long-standing ties between the two Asean member states. During his visit, Lee will meet with Vietnamese leaders, attend receptions and business events, and visit Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. His delegation includes various senior government officials, while Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean will act as Acting Prime Minister during Lee's overseas trip. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral relations and promote economic cooperation between Singapore and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Several O&M counters take beating from Ezra fallout
summary: Ezra Holdings' Chapter 11 filing on Sunday sent shockwaves through the offshore and marine (O&M) sector, with several peers experiencing a significant decline. Shares of DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank fell up to 0.41% due to their exposure to Ezra. The move follows Swiber Holdings' insolvency, making Ezra the second Singapore-listed stockmarket darling to declare insolvency. Punters and analysts may need to reassess their bets on the O&M sector bottoming out.

site_title: Germany's economic advisers reject criticism of current account surplus
summary: Germany's economic advisers rejected criticism of its large current account surplus, stating it doesn't signal a macroeconomic imbalance. They instead recommended making Germany more attractive for private investment to reduce the surplus. The advisers also criticized US President Trump's protectionist stance as a threat to the global economy. They called for the European Central Bank to wind down its bond-buying program due to perceived risks for financial stability. The panel revised its growth forecast for this year to 1.4% and predicts 1.6% growth for 2018.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower; NZ dragged by Fletcher Building
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, sliding 0.4% or 20.75 points to 5,778.90, due to worries over global trade protectionism. The benchmark snapped a four-session gain after US leaders dropped a pledge to keep global trade free and open, sparking concerns of a shift towards protectionism.

site_title: French presidential candidates face off in first TV debate
summary: French presidential candidates, including centrist Emmanuel Macron and far-right leader Marine Le Pen, are set to face off in a TV debate ahead of the April 23 opening round of the election. Macron and Le Pen are expected to come under attack, with Le Pen's campaign focusing on Macron's "globalist" program and Macron's campaign criticizing Le Pen's far-right views. The election, marked by low turnout and high volatility, could hinge on undecided voters and the candidates' ability to sway them.

site_title: Securities industry group completes review of market disruptions, makes recommendations
summary: A securities industry working group has completed a review of market disruptions and made recommendations to Singapore Exchange (SGX) to improve the resilience of Singapore's securities market. The group's six recommendations include establishing a master record of trade data, industry trade management and recovery standards, and clearer guidelines on market closure and resumption. SGX has accepted all recommendations, with three implemented immediately and the remaining three to be implemented over the next 18-24 months.

images.alt_text: A securities industry working group that was convened after a July 2016 market outage is recommending that Singapore Exchange (SGX) adopt clearer continuity plans and maintain closer coordination with the industry and service providers.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks give up early gains on profit-taking
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.4% to 9,869.35 after initially reaching a two-year high of 9,916.18. The broader market has jumped 7% this year on foreign buying driven by expectations of an iPhone model benefiting Taiwanese suppliers. Investors locked in profits, reversing early gains.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.12% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.12% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,165.70. Trading saw 1.75 billion shares worth S$1.04 billion, with 274 counters down and 218 up. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: GLP sets up new China subsidiary; its another unit ups stake in GLP-MC Tianjin
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has established a new subsidiary, GLP Financial Lease (Chongqing), in China, with an initial investment of 500 million yuan. Meanwhile, another GLP unit, CLH (54), acquired a 50% stake in GLP-MC Tianjin Logistics Property Development for 35.1 million yuan, resulting in CLH owning all of GLP-MC Tianjin. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on GLP's financial performance for the 2017 financial year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: Europe's stock markets fell at the opening on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.3% to 7,406.47 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.4% to 12,050.81 points, and Paris' CAC 40 down 0.4% to 5,008.08 points. The decline followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and came despite positive shares in mining and healthcare sectors. US stocks also reached fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China considers ways to speed up time to market imported drugs
summary: China's China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA) considers shortening the time to market for imported drugs, aiming to address the shortage of such medicines. The proposed changes would eliminate prior foreign approval requirements for international multi-centre clinical trials. Imported drugs would then be allowed to directly apply for market authorization after completing these trials. This move aims to reduce the average 3-4 year review time to 16 months, similar to the US, and alleviate high drug costs and limited access to recent treatments in China.

site_title: Malaysian PM Najib says central bank will keep supporting ringgit
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak stated that the central bank will continue to support the ringgit currency, citing measures already taken to stabilize its decline. The Bank Negara Malaysia has implemented steps such as limiting foreign banks' trading in the offshore non-deliverable forwards market and encouraging domestic trade. Najib expressed confidence that these efforts have successfully stabilized the currency.

site_title: Malaysia February inflation data delayed to March 24
summary: Malaysia's Statistics Department has announced that the release of February consumer price inflation data will be delayed to March 24 instead of the previously scheduled March 22. No reason was given for the change.

site_title: Vodafone to merge India operations with Idea Cellular
summary: Vodafone Group will merge its Indian subsidiary with Idea Cellular within two years. Vodafone will own 45.1% of the merged entity after transferring 4.9% to Idea's promoters for $827.96 million in cash. Idea will appoint the chairman and shares rose 14.25% before settling 3.8% higher.

site_title: Seoul: Won firms to 5-month high, shares slip on profit-taking
summary: The South Korean won reached a 5-month high at 1,120.1 to the dollar, driven by the Federal Reserve's decision to stick to a gradual pace of monetary policy tightening. This move disappointed investors who had expected a rate hike. In contrast, South Korean shares declined 0.4% due to profit-taking, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing at 2,157.01 points. The decline follows the shares' near 2-year high reached last week.

site_title: Keppel Fels MD to concurrently serve as acting CEO of Keppel O&M
summary: Keppel Corp announced Chris Ong, currently managing director of Keppel Fels, will serve as acting CEO of Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) starting April 1, 2017. Ong, 42, will replace Chow Yew Yuen, 62, who will retire after 36 years of service. Ong has held key roles in Keppel Fels, including managing director, and also serves as chairman of several external companies. He will oversee Keppel O&M, which is undergoing significant changes.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corp on Monday announced a new head honcho for Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M).

site_title: Hot stock: Ezra's bankruptcy filing in US sends new shock waves through local banks, O&G stocks
summary: Ezra Holdings, an offshore and marine firm, filed for US Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing difficulties in raising funds due to the prolonged challenges facing the oil and gas industry. The bankruptcy filing sent shockwaves through Singapore's banking and oil and gas sectors, with local banks' shares declining. DBS, OCBC, and UOB saw significant falls, while Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries also fell. The news sparked concerns of further defaults in the local bond market, particularly in the oil and gas sector.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: East Timor votes in presidential poll seen as sign of stability
summary: East Timor held a presidential poll, with former guerrilla fighter Francisco Guterres, known as "Lu-Olo", favored to win. His unified candidacy with the largest party, Fretilin, and independence hero Xanana Gusmao's CNRT party is seen as a sign of stability for Asia's youngest nation. The election comes after a challenging 15 years since independence, with oil reserves running dry and disputes with Australia over energy fields. The result is expected to boost stability and may lead to a unity government following parliamentary elections later this year.

site_title: South Korea's Lotte family owners go on trial for graft
summary: South Korea's Lotte family members, including chairman Shin Dong Bin and his family, went on trial for embezzlement, tax evasion, and fraud. The trial comes as the company faces condemnation from China due to its provision of land for a US missile defense system and the subsequent closure of nearly 90% of its Chinese stores. The proceedings are part of a broader crackdown on corruption in South Korea's fifth-largest conglomerate.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte calls European critics 'crazies'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has described European critics of his deadly drug war as "crazies" and vowed to continue killing traffickers, despite criticism from human rights groups and lawmakers. The European Parliament condemned "extrajudicial killings" in the war, which has resulted in over 7,500 deaths, with Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch warning of crimes against humanity. Duterte has insisted he is targeting both big-time drug lords and small-time street peddlers, and warned that many more people will be killed.

site_title: IBM launches enterprise-ready blockchain service
summary: IBM has launched its enterprise-ready blockchain service, IBM Blockchain, allowing businesses to build applications on its cloud using Hyperledger Fabric code. The Fabric blockchain can process over 1,000 transactions per second, making it suitable for large enterprises. This is the first service to utilize Hyperledger Fabric, a cross-industry open-source group led by the Linux Foundation. The launch aims to provide developers with a scalable and secure platform for building enterprise-grade blockchain technology.

images.alt_text: International Business Machines Corp has launched a service that will allow businesses to build applications on its cloud using blockchain code from the Hyperledger Project, the cross-industry group led by the Linux Foundation.

site_title: "Don't use Taiwan", Taipei frets ahead of Trump-Xi meeting
summary: Taiwan's government is urging the US and China to avoid using the island as a pawn in their diplomatic negotiations, amid concerns that a Trump-Xi meeting could harm Taipei's interests. The US is considering a major arms package for Taiwan, which China views as a threat. Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen's independence-leaning party has been pressuring the US to provide more military aid. A Trump-Xi meeting could lead to increased pressure on Taiwan, prompting the island to take steps to protect its own interests.

site_title: North Korea rocket-engine test shows "meaningful" progress: South Korea
summary: North Korea's latest rocket-engine test showed "meaningful" progress, according to South Korea's defense ministry. The test, conducted at the rocket launch station, demonstrated significant advancements in engine function. However, further analysis is needed to determine exact thrust and possible uses. The successful test was hailed by North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un as marking "a new birth" of its rocket industry.

images.alt_text: North Korea had conducted a test of a new high-thrust engine at its rocket launch station and leader Kim Jong Un said the successful test marked "a new birth" of its rocket industry, the North's official media reported on Sunday.

site_title: Singapore's looming debt wall fuels concern after Ezra stumbles
summary: Singapore's corporate debt is set to peak by 2020, with S$38 billion in maturing bonds due. Default fears resurface as six firms have defaulted on S$1.2 billion worth of notes since 2015. The US bankruptcy filing of Ezra Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-based engineering firm, highlights lingering pain despite economic recovery. The Singapore government has enacted changes to its Companies Act to make it easier for firms to restructure debt at home, but experts warn of ongoing distress and potential further defaults in the local bond market.

images.alt_text: Default fears are resurfacing in Singapore ahead of a wall of maturing corporate debt, as a US bankruptcy filing of a firm from the city flags lingering pain despite economic recovery.

site_title: Gold hits 2-week high as Fed rate hike guidance weighs on US dollar
summary: Gold prices surged 0.4% to a two-week high of $1,233.60 per ounce on Monday, driven by the US Federal Reserve's conservative guidance on rate hikes. The US dollar weakened, holding near five-week lows, and investors are bracing for a packed week of Fed messaging. The outlook for gold appears more positive, with concerns of a more hawkish Fed easing.
