site_title: Malaysia to introduce steps to develop forex, bond markets: PM Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced the central bank will introduce new measures to develop the foreign exchange and bond markets, allowing businesses to manage currency exposure. The moves aim to meet market demand and support local businesses. The statement was made in response to a parliamentary question.

site_title: Hot stock: Nam Cheong down 22% after auditor comments
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singapore-based offshore support vessel shipbuilder, plummeted 22% in value after auditors expressed concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The stock price fell to S$0.038 as of 9:14 am on Monday. This move comes after auditors highlighted material uncertainties in the company's financial situation.

site_title: Italy's struggling economy has the world's healthiest people
summary: Italy is ranked the healthiest country in the world according to the Bloomberg Global Health Index, with a life expectancy of 82 years. Despite its struggling economy, with high unemployment and debt, Italians have lower rates of obesity, high blood pressure, and mental health issues compared to the US, Canada, and the UK. Factors contributing to Italy's health include its diet rich in vegetables and olive oil, and an abundance of doctors. The top five healthiest countries are Italy, Iceland, Switzerland, Singapore, and Australia, with the US ranking 34th.

site_title: South Korea complains to WTO over China's response to anti-missile system-minister
summary: South Korea has complained to the World Trade Organization (WTO) about China's retaliation against South Korean companies due to the deployment of a US anti-missile defence system in the South. Trade Minister Joo Hyung Hwan stated that China imposed restrictions on South Korean companies in the tourism and distribution sectors, which Seoul considers a potential trade agreement violation. The complaint was made last week, following China's reaction to the Thaad system deployment.

site_title: Kimly enjoys 120% IPO pop
summary: Kimly, a food outlet operator, made its public debut with an initial offering price of S$0.25, but its stock opened at S$0.55, a 120% increase. This was based on 3.8 million shares offered to the public and 170 million shares placed out. By 9:11am, almost 30 million shares had been traded, with the stock price 27.4 times its earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Coffeeshop master leaseholder and food outlet operator Kimly opened trading at S$0.55, 120 per cent above its initial public offering price of S$0.25.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars gain as greenback sputters
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar on Monday, with the Australian dollar increasing 0.25% to US$0.7719 and the New Zealand dollar rising 0.33% to US$0.7036. The gains were driven by the US dollar's weakness and investors unwinding bets on aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The Australian dollar's gains were also fueled by high commodity prices, while the New Zealand dollar benefited from strong steel prices. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike last week did not alter its forecast for three rate increases this year.

site_title: Asking prices for UK homes show solid gain in Feb-March: Rightmove
summary: Asking prices for homes in England and Wales rose 1.3% in February to March, the second strongest increase since 2007, with prices up 2.3% in annual terms. The housing market has proven resilient to Brexit, defying forecasts of a sharp hit. Economists expect house prices to rise 2.5% this year, slower than previous years but still in positive territory. The shortage of properties for sale is cited as the main factor behind the price increases.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down after rally, dollar weakens
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, following a recent rally, with the US dollar weakening after the Federal Reserve hinted at slower interest rate hikes this year. Investors were cautious due to uncertainty over Donald Trump's tax plan and potential global trade tensions. The dollar dropped against most currencies, including the yen, euro, and Australian dollar, while Hong Kong and Shanghai edged up 0.1% and Sydney shed 0.4%. Market strategist Greg McKenna said positive catalysts for further gains appear lacking, citing a risk to stocks if US data disappoints.

site_title: Singapore govt to form ministerial-level group for digital tech strategies
summary: The Singapore government is forming a ministerial-level planning group, the Smart Nation and Digital Government Group (SNDGG), to coordinate digital technology strategies and responses starting May 1. The group will oversee efforts to improve citizens' lives, grow economic value, and drive digital transformation for the public service. It will be chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean, with Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim as deputy chairman, and led by Permanent Secretary Ng Chee Khern. The group aims to leverage digital and smart technologies to enhance the lives of citizens and drive economic growth.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% down on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.2% lower on Monday, retreating 5.41 points to 3,163.97. About 90.9 million shares changed hands, with Kimly being the most active counter. Despite this, the market still saw a net gain of 28 points, with 86 gainers outnumbering 58 losers.

site_title: Hot stocks: Keppel T&T, SPH rally on potential stake sale in M1
summary: Shares of M1, Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), and Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) surged on Monday after the trio resumed trading amid plans to sell their stakes in the telco. SPH and Keppel T&T have appointed Morgan Stanley as financial adviser to assist with the strategic review. M1, owned by Malaysian telco Axiata, saw its shares rise 1.37%, while SPH and Keppel T&T shares increased 0.85% and 3.23%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Valuetronics plans bonus issue of one share for every 10
summary: Valuetronics plans a bonus issue of one share for every 10 existing shares to improve trading liquidity. The move marks the 10th anniversary of its listing and the 25th anniversary of its principal operating subsidiary Honor Tone Limited. A special general meeting will be held to approve the issue, following a last trading price of S$0.765.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, extending last week's gains. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.16% to 24,349.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.11% to 3,241.11. However, the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.09%. These gains come despite global market uncertainty, with the US and EU in talks over trade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.090 points to 1744.070. The market saw 214 gainers and 38 losers, with a total volume of 172.3 million lots worth RM40.78 million.

site_title: Merkel, Abe call for swift deal to stem trade barriers
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for a swift deal to defend free trade, saying global markets can be open and fair. Following inconclusive talks between Merkel and US President Donald Trump, the two leaders emphasized the importance of trade agreements between Japan and the European Union. Merkel and Abe expressed concerns over "America First" economic policies, urging fair markets without barriers. Talks on an EU-Japan accord began in 2013, aiming to lower trade barriers and investment on both sides.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine acquires Kelantan rights
summary: CNMC Goldmine announced the acquisition of KelGold's rights to explore gold, iron ore, and other minerals in Kelantan for RM2.5 million. The rights are set to expire in 2019 and include a 15.5 sq km site. CNMC also has rights to explore another 8.7 sq km site in Kelantan. The company has a net liability position of RM50,000 and last traded at S$0.40.

site_title: Oil prices drop on rise in US drilling
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday as US drilling activity rose, putting pressure on already-bloated markets. Front-month Brent crude futures fell 20 cents to $51.56 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 28 cents to $48.50 per barrel. US drillers added 14 oil rigs, increasing total production to over 9.1 million barrels per day. Despite OPEC's pledge to cut output, analysts expect the cuts to start biting in mid-April, leading to inventory draws and tighter markets.

site_title: SpaceX cargo ship returns to Earth
summary: SpaceX's reusable cargo ship, Dragon, successfully splashed down in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday, ending a nearly month-long mission to supply astronauts on the International Space Station. The ship, carrying over two tonnes of food, water, and scientific equipment, returned with 4,000 pounds of research samples. After a six-hour journey, the capsule landed off the coast of Mexico, with three giant parachutes slowing its final descent. This marked the first successful return of a Dragon cargo ship, showcasing SpaceX's reusable technology capabilities.

images.alt_text: A SpaceX reusable cargo ship splashed down in the Pacific Ocean safely on Sunday, ending a mission to supply astronauts on the International Space Station, the company said.

site_title: New Zealand performance of service index 58.8 in February: BNZ
summary: New Zealand's services sector experienced a slight slowdown in February, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's performance of services index (PSI) falling to 58.8 from 59.5 in the previous month. The reading above 50 indicates expansion in activity, making it the second-highest level of expansion since November 2015.

site_title: US dollar on defensive for packed week of Fed speakers
summary: The US dollar remained under pressure in Asia, near two-week lows at 112.68 yen, amid the Federal Reserve's less hawkish rate guidance. The dollar was little moved against a basket of currencies, while the euro held firm at US$1.0741. A packed week of Fed speakers, including Chair Janet Yellen, is expected to influence market sentiment. Analysts predict a potential two-month hiatus before the next overt signaling on a Fed rate hike, and some speculate the European Central Bank may raise deposit rates before ending quantitative easing.

site_title: Uber president Jeff Jones quits as turmoil continues
summary: Uber Technologies Inc has lost its president, Jeff Jones, in a move amid company turmoil. Jones, a marketing expert, left the company less than seven months after joining, amid the departure of other high-level executives. The reasons for Jones' departure were not immediately clear. His role was put into question after Uber launched a search for a chief operating officer. The move comes as the company faces multiple controversies, including allegations of sexual harassment and the use of a secret technology program to evade authorities. Uber's CEO Travis Kalanick's leadership is being questioned.

site_title: Seoul: Won advances to 5-month high on US dollar weakness; stocks slip
summary: The South Korean won strengthened to a five-month high, reaching 1,126.7 as of Monday morning, due to the US dollar's weakness following the Federal Reserve's less hawkish comments. The won's gains were attributed to foreign investors' demand for local equities. Meanwhile, South Korean shares edged down, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) down 0.5% at 2,153.26 points. Netmarble Games Corp plans an initial public offering worth up to 2.66 trillion won, and market heavyweight Samsung Electronics dropped nearly one percent.

site_title: French airport attacker 'had drunk and taken drugs'
summary: A 39-year-old man, Ziyed Ben Belgacem, was shot dead at Paris's Orly airport after attacking a soldier, who was under the influence of drugs and alcohol at the time. Ben Belgacem had a history of armed robbery and drug-dealing, and investigators are trying to understand his motivations. His father denied that he was a terrorist, blaming his son's actions on drink and drugs. The attack came as France remains on high alert following a wave of jihadist attacks.

site_title: Chinese police boss jailed for buying Australian property with graft money
summary: A Chinese police officer was sentenced to 17 years in prison for accepting bribes totaling 6.8 million yuan, used to buy two Australian properties. The bribes were part of a larger scandal involving construction projects. The case comes amid an Australian crackdown on foreign investors skirting overseas investment rules, prompting concerns about unaffordable homes and money laundering. The officer, Wang, used the bribes to buy properties for his daughters and distribute construction projects in return.

site_title: Germany says Erdogan has 'gone too far' with Nazi jibe
summary: Germany has strongly criticized Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan after he accused Chancellor Angela Merkel of using "Nazi measures" in a diplomatic feud. Merkel had refused to allow some Turkish ministers to campaign for a referendum on expanding Erdogan's powers, prompting the Turkish president to make the provocative comments. Germany's Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel called Erdogan's remarks "shocking," and the European Union's bid for Turkey's membership appears to be in jeopardy. The crisis has also raised questions about Turkey's relations with other EU countries and its own domestic politics.

site_title: Billionaire Fredriksen builds new rig unit amid Seadrill woes
summary: Billionaire John Fredriksen is planning to register a new offshore rig company, Northern Drilling, amid efforts to restructure Seadrill Ltd's debt. Fredriksen has raised US$230 million in capital for the company and plans a full public listing on the Oslo stock exchange later this year. The new company will purchase a semi-submersible rig from Hyundai Heavy Industries Co Ltd, and Fredriksen is seeking other units at a discount due to an industry downturn. This move comes as Seadrill faces a 95% decline in market value and is struggling to meet a deadline for talks with banks and bondholders.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares dampened by Fletcher Building, Wall Street
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Monday due to concerns over global trade protectionism and a decline in Fletcher Building stocks. The company cut its full-year earnings forecast, leading to a steep fall. The outcome of the G20 summit and the performance of US stocks also impacted the markets, with Wall Street ending flat. The G20 finance ministers and central bankers made a token reference to trade, breaking a decade-long tradition of endorsing open trade.

site_title: Brazil says exports safe despite rotten meat scandal
summary: Brazil's meat industry, the world's largest exporter, has been embroiled in a scandal after allegations of corruption and unsanitary practices. At least 30 people have been arrested, and over a dozen processing plants have been shut down. Despite claims of tainted products, authorities say there have been no reports of people falling ill. The government is working to reassure clients and maintain exports, with President Michel Temer holding crisis talks with industry representatives.

site_title: Uber rivals from Dubai, China team up for ride-hailing alliance
summary: Dubai-based ride-hailing service Careem Inc has partnered with China's Yidao Yongche to form an alliance, sharing resources and coordinating fleets and payments. The partnership aims to allow passengers to travel abroad using drivers from other companies without downloading new software. This move comes as Uber faces competition from rival alliances, including a 2015 four-way partnership between Didi, Lyft, Grab, and Ola. The partnership also brings Splyt Technologies into the fold, which connects with partners to help clients see available cars and charge a commission on currency exchange.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc is facing another alliance of rivals as smaller operators team up across different regions for ride hailing services.

site_title: British, big brands boycott forces Google to change ad policies
summary: Major British brands, including O2, Royal Mail, and Domino's Pizza, have boycotted Google after ads appeared alongside offensive content, such as videos promoting terrorism and anti-Semitism. The UK government and The Guardian newspaper also pulled ads from YouTube. In response, Google announced changes to its advertising policies, giving clients more control over ad placement and removing nearly 2 billion offensive ads. The company will review its policies and make changes to help prevent ads from appearing on objectionable websites or against offensive videos.

site_title: Tennis: Federer beats Wawrinka for fifth Indian Wells title
summary: Roger Federer claimed his record-equalling fifth ATP Indian Wells Masters title, defeating Stan Wawrinka 6-4, 7-5. The win marks Federer's 18th Grand Slam title, following his Australian Open victory in January. Federer joined Novak Djokovic as the only men to win five Indian Wells titles, adding to his previous wins in 2004, 2005, 2006, and 2012.

images.alt_text: Roger Federer claimed a record-equalling fifth ATP Indian Wells Masters title on Sunday, continuing his career resurgence with a 6-4, 7-5 victory over Stan Wawrinka.

site_title: Scottish leader softens stance on possible independence vote timing
summary: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has softened her stance on a possible independence referendum, saying she could delay it until after Brexit if it's not too long after the UK's EU exit in late March 2019. Sturgeon had initially called for a referendum between autumn 2018 and spring 2019, but now believes a vote in 2021 would be too late due to potential divergence in regulations. The move comes after Prime Minister Theresa May rejected her call for a pre-Brexit vote.

site_title: Yellen's shadow looms large over policy at China's central bank
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) raised borrowing costs in response to the Federal Reserve's March 15 rate hike, marking a subtle shift towards aligning with global counterparts. This move is seen as supporting the yuan by controlling interest rate differentials and taming financial risk. PBOC Governor Zhou Xiaochuan stated that monetary policy is neutral and won't be altered due to interest rate differences, but economists believe the PBOC must move in line with global counterparts to address domestic drivers such as a housing price bubble and accelerating debt.

site_title: Man arrested after claiming bomb at White House gates
summary: A 29-year-old man, Sean Patrick Keoughan, was arrested near the White House on Saturday after claiming he had a bomb in his car. He falsely stated "There's a bomb in the trunk" and added "This is a test" while being arrested. Keoughan, of Roanoke, Virginia, was charged with false bomb threats and unauthorized use of a vehicle. The incident occurred just hours after another person jumped over a bike rack in front of the White House, and it marks the second security scare at the presidential residence in less than a week.

site_title: 'Sesame Street' to tackle autism with new muppet
summary: "Sesame Street" introduces a new muppet, Julia, who has autism, in a bid to tackle the growing issue of autism awareness among children. The character, created after extensive research with educators, child psychologists, and autism organizations, will be featured in a special episode. Julia's behaviors, such as ignoring Big Bird and becoming excited during play, will be portrayed in a way that normalizes autism for non-autistic children, aiming to reduce fear and promote understanding. The character's introduction is seen as a significant step in addressing the rising diagnoses of autism among US children.

site_title: Amgen discounts cholesterol drug, but payers want more
summary: Amgen has discounted its cholesterol-lowering drug Repatha by 30% to $9,800 per year, but pharmacy benefit managers are seeking lower prices after new data showed the treatment cuts heart attack and stroke risk. Industry discounts average 30-35%, and Amgen believes the discounted price represents good value. The company plans to offer additional contracting options, including refunding the cost of the drug for patients who suffer a heart attack or stroke.

site_title: Security, regulatory concerns addressed, US financial firms embrace cloud
summary: US financial firms have increasingly adopted cloud services, shifting away from concerns about security and regulatory compliance. Providers like Amazon, Microsoft, and Google have taken steps to assure financial firms of the cloud's reliability and security. As a result, the industry is saving billions of dollars, with the biggest global banks predicted to save $15 billion by 2019. By 2020, two-thirds of global financial firms are expected to use cloud services in a significant way, with benefits including faster deployment times and cost savings.

site_title: 'No evidence of collusion' between Trump campaign, Russia: US lawmaker
summary: US Congressman Devin Nunes stated that there is "no evidence" of collusion between Donald Trump's campaign and Russia during the 2016 election. This finding comes ahead of FBI Director James Comey's testimony on the US president's potential Russia ties. Nunes made the remarks in an interview with Fox News, contradicting earlier speculation about close ties between Trump aides, associates, and Moscow.

site_title: Market, client knowledge paves way for SPACG
summary: Singapore-based interior design consultancy SPACG Studio has successfully expanded into China, operating in Shanghai, Macau, Hong Kong, and Malaysia. The company's market research and analysis of its competitors helped it navigate the local market. With a presence in China since 2013, SPACG provides exchange programs for staff to learn market requirements and shares resources with its branch offices to maximize cost efficiency. The company aims for steady growth and explores new ventures, employing 40 staff and achieving a 2016 annual turnover of S$15 million.

images.alt_text: Maintaining very close communication with clients via quick responses is seen as being professional, said Mr Pan.

site_title: World Bank announces US$57b in financing for Africa
summary: The World Bank announced a $57 billion financing package for sub-Saharan Africa over three fiscal years. The package includes $45 billion from the International Development Association, $8 billion from the International Finance Corporation, and $4 billion from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. This investment aims to expand programs in education, healthcare, infrastructure, and institutional reform, with a focus on 448 ongoing projects in the region. World Bank President Jim Yong Kim described the commitment as an "unprecedented opportunity" to change Africa's development trajectory.

site_title: Thai tourism to food sectors seek halal gold
summary: Thailand is targeting Muslim tourists by introducing halal food options and accommodations, such as segregated swimming pools and seaweed-based products. The move aims to attract Muslim visitors from the Islamic world. This strategic initiative is part of Thailand's efforts to expand its tourism industry.

site_title: Duterte dismisses threat of ICC trial, says 'brutal' war on drugs to go on
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has dismissed the threat of an International Criminal Court (ICC) trial, stating he will not be intimidated and his anti-drugs campaign will continue "brutally". Over 8,000 people have died since his campaign began, with rights groups accusing police complicity in extrajudicial killings. Duterte denies ordering such killings, but warns that those who resist arrest will be shot. He expects a self-confessed assassin to file a case at the ICC, accusing him of crimes against humanity, but remains unrepentant.

site_title: Kim killing: KL police hunting more suspects, including an 'important person'
summary: Malaysia is pursuing more suspects, including at least one "important" person, in connection with the murder of Kim Jong-nam, the half-brother of North Korea's leader, who was poisoned with VX nerve agent at Kuala Lumpur International Airport in February. Two women, one Vietnamese and one Indonesian, have been arrested and charged with the murder, and Interpol has issued an international arrest warrant for seven North Korean suspects. Experts are struggling to understand how VX was deployed without harm to the assailants, and some have proposed a theory that the killing was carried out using a binary version of VX.

site_title: Bizarre 'Abegate' affair due to climax in Parliament this week
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing a potentially major challenge after allegations surfaced that he and his wife Akie made donations to a nationalist school in Osaka, which could be linked to a dubious land deal. The principal of the school, Yasunori Kagoike, is set to testify to Parliament this week, and if confirmed, could lead to calls for Abe's resignation. The scandal has the potential to overshadow Abe's bid for a third term in office and push through constitutional reforms, with no clear challenger to his leadership within his party.

images.alt_text: Mr Kagoike, administrator of Moritomo Gakuen, the academic organisation linked to a land-sale controversy that has engulfed Mr Abe and his wife, speaking to the media in Toyonaka, Osaka prefecture.

site_title: Late US billionaire's record land gift lays Chile row to rest
summary: US billionaire Douglas Tompkins has donated a 407,000-hectare tract of land to Chile, the largest national park donation in history. The land, roughly the size of Rhode Island, was donated to the Chilean government after Tompkins's death in a kayaking accident. His widow hopes the donation will lay to rest controversy surrounding his land purchases in Patagonia, which included accusations of preparing a nuclear waste site or launching a Jewish state. Chilean President Michelle Bachelet accepted the donation, praising Tompkins's generosity and love of nature.

site_title: Canada Goose vaults Dani Reiss from aspiring writer to millionaire
summary: Dani Reiss, an English literature graduate, joined his father's Toronto shop 20 years ago to finance his travel plans, not to run a clothing empire. He later became the CEO of Canada Goose, transforming it into a billion-dollar company. Reiss initially wanted to be a short-story writer, but his father's business took off, and he eventually turned the company into a global brand.

images.alt_text: "We're going to open stores in the best and biggest and most vibrant cities in the world," says Mr Reiss.

site_title: Keppel Land ups stake in Vietnam's Saigon Centre
summary: Keppel Land has acquired an additional 16% stake in the joint venture entities for Saigon Centre in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, for S$53.5 million. The company's aggregate interest in the project now stands at 53.5% for Phases One and Two, and 76.2% for subsequent phases. CEO Ang Wee Gee stated that the increased stake reflects Keppel Land's confidence in sustainable urbanisation in Vietnam and commitment to the project. The Saigon Centre retail mall opened last August, and Phase Two will feature 55,000 sqm of retail space and 195 luxury serviced apartments.

site_title: In Berlin, a grass-roots fight against gentrification
summary: In Berlin, a grassroots movement is fighting against gentrification in the Kreuzberg neighborhood, where rising rents and real estate speculation threaten the area's diverse social and cultural makeup. Hundreds of demonstrators protested against forced evictions and crowded out long-time residents, carrying signs that read "We're all staying" and "Say no to crowding out". The protesters aim to preserve the neighborhood's alternative culture and independent arts scene, which has been a hub for radical politics and underground nightlife for decades.

images.alt_text: Prices have soared in fashionable districts such as Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg, where rents rose in the past decade by more than 80 per cent, according to data from the Empirica Institute.

site_title: Uniqlo betting on speed and customer focus to overtake Zara
summary: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing Co plans to shorten the time from design to delivery to 13 days, comparable to Zara, to gain a competitive edge. The company aims to increase total revenue by 70% to 3 trillion yen ($37 billion) by 2021, with a focus on selling products that meet consumers' daily needs. Fast Retailing will expand its direct-to-consumer sales and same-day delivery in the Tokyo area, with plans to open 100 new stores in China and South-east Asia annually. The company's new design and delivery centre in Tokyo will house over 1,000 employees and improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Raw sugar pares losses after slide to 9-month low
summary: Raw sugar futures pared losses after slumping to a 9-month low, settling down 0.08 US cents at 18.17 US cents per lb. Cocoa futures also fell, while coffee prices rose. A Chinese investigation into sugar imports delayed a potential decision on punitive tariffs. Dealers attributed the market's volatility to favourable crop conditions in Brazil and oversold sentiment. The Thomson Reuters CoreCommodity Index fell, while the May white sugar premium rallied to US$114.76.

site_title: Vietnam a viable market for overseas expansion: IE S'pore
summary: Singapore maintains its status as Vietnam's third-largest foreign investor, with registered cumulative investments of US$37.9 billion in 1,786 projects. The country is also the top investor among Asean member states, accounting for 60% of total foreign direct investment. Manufacturing remains a viable opportunity for Singapore firms, with a young and skilled labor force, abundant natural resources, and proximity to China. Seven Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Parks have attracted over US$9 billion in investments, with around 600 companies providing jobs for over 170,000 workers.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The strong numbers are proof that Vietnam remains one of the key South-east Asian markets for Singapore companies big and small.

site_title: India hunts hidden cash in corruption blitz
summary: India's government has cracked down on corruption, cracking hundreds of suspicious bank accounts under investigation for alleged "benami" transactions, where assets are hidden in low-paid staff's names to avoid tax. The law, part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's twin strike to flush out undeclared black money, allows investigators to question anyone and seize assets. Those caught face a seven-year jail term and hefty fines, with over half of the 235 under investigation having been frozen and properties seized.

site_title: Labour drought in Europe's east as workers go west
summary: A decade-long trend of workers migrating from eastern and central Europe to western Europe, driven by higher wages, has left a severe labour drought in the region. Companies, including Hungarian construction firm owner Geza Borgulya, are struggling to fill thousands of jobs as workers seek better pay and conditions. The exodus, coupled with low birth rates and ageing populations, has left gaping holes in job markets, affecting various sectors such as healthcare, technology, and manufacturing.

site_title: Nota Design bags projects that others only dream of
summary: Keat Ong, founder of Nota Design Group, shifted his focus to China in 2011, capitalizing on the country's rapid growth. He established partnerships in major cities like Kunming, Changsha, and Shanghai, leveraging his connections, or "guanxi," to secure high-profile projects, including government initiatives and luxury developments. By the time he entered the market, China was already the third decade of its economic boom, offering abundant opportunities for growth.

site_title: Indonesia plans WTO complaint over EU biodiesel duties
summary: Indonesia plans to file a World Trade Organization (WTO) complaint against the European Union's anti-dumping duties on biodiesel exports from the South-east Asian country. The EU duties are deemed inconsistent with the WTO's Anti-Dumping Agreement and disputed by Indonesia. The complaint is expected to be filed this month.

site_title: NY moderates in White House spark infighting and suspicion
summary: A power struggle is unfolding in the Trump White House, with Manhattan business figures-turned-advisers pitted against Republican populists driving the president's nationalist agenda. Led by Gary Cohn and Dina Powell, the group faces suspicion and jealousy from West Wing colleagues, particularly Stephen Bannon and Reince Priebus. Tensions have been escalating over policy decisions, access to the president, and White House protocol. Despite the New Yorkers' growing influence, the conservative wing has notched victories in various sectors, and the president's popularity remains a factor in the ongoing tug-of-war.

site_title: Markets adjusting to end of low interest rate era
summary: US stocks ended the week flat despite rising interest rates, as investors anticipated increased volatility due to the end of the low-interest rate era. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged was seen as a surprise, with markets adjusting to the shift. Analysts warn of a potential "Humpty Dumpty" moment, where risky stocks may experience a significant fall, but some also predict a "meltup" as the economy continues to show signs of growth. The market's reaction to the Fed's decision was characterized as complacency, with investors focusing on the "dovish" tone rather than the rate hike.

site_title: US and China agree to work together on North Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson ended his first trip to Asia with an agreement to work together with China on North Korea, putting aside differences on issues such as nuclear and missile programs. Chinese President Xi Jinping and Tillerson put aside trickier issues like Taiwan and South Korea, with Xi expressing appreciation for Tillerson's efforts to achieve a smooth transition. The two leaders agreed to strengthen coordination on regional issues, respect each other's core interests, and protect the stability of ties.

site_title: US$ stays weak but outlook still upbeat
summary: The US dollar fell to a five-week low, remaining under pressure for a third straight session, after the Federal Reserve kept a gradual rate-hiking pace. Analysts expect a potential rebound due to the Fed's continued tightening policies. The dollar's weakness may be alleviated if the Trump administration's fiscal plans materialize, but a higher US budget deficit could dampen this view. The US dollar index slipped 0.1% to 100.30, and the euro fell against the dollar after a poll showed Marine Le Pen extending her lead in France's presidential elections.

site_title: Buying by directors falls, selling rises
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) volume watch reveals a decline in buying by directors for the second straight week, with 10 companies recording 21 purchases worth S$1.45 million. However, selling by directors rose sharply, with six companies recording 13 disposals worth S$1.08 million. The bulk of significant trades were buybacks and insider sales. Companies like AnnAik and Japfa made initial buybacks after their share prices fell. iFAST Corporation saw a buyback and purchase by its directors at below their previous acquisition prices. Rowsley's executive director sold 9.33 million shares, while substantial shareholder Albert Hong Hin Kay disposed of 7.3 million shares.

site_title: Singapore investors still on long-term 'sell' on Wall Street
summary: Singapore-based investors sold a net $972 million of US NYSE shares in the fourth quarter of 2016, with a total of $5.4 billion sold in the year. This trend may be due to Singapore investors finding higher returns in stock markets closer to home, rather than profit-taking. Despite being the second-largest Asian investors on Wall Street, Singapore investors continue to withdraw from US equities, with a net $615 million sold in 2016.

site_title: Ethnic Chinese still grapple with discrimination despite generations in Indonesia
summary: In Indonesia, ethnic Chinese individuals continue to face official discrimination despite generations living in the country. A 1975 decree is being used against them unfairly, denying them ownership of land and forcing them to rent from the local sultan. Local officials claim the policy is being enforced, despite the National Commission on Human Rights recommending a change. The issue affects around three million Chinese-descendant citizens, who argue they are native Indonesians and deserve equal treatment, just like other citizens.

site_title: Different kind of 'art' needed when doing business in China
summary: Businessman George Budiman, founder of Cynosure Design, shares his experience of failing in China due to a lack of adaptability. He initially relied on his Singaporean reputation, but clients in China did not honor contracts and failed to pay. Budiman lost millions before shifting his approach, incorporating local conditions and building connections (guanxi) to secure projects. He now operates two offices, employing 50 staff and generating annual turnover of S$8-10 million. Budiman's experience highlights the need for a different "art" or mindset when doing business in China.

site_title: Welcome move all round
summary: The Singapore government has introduced tweaks to the property market cooling measures, aiming to ease curbs on the market. Experts welcome the positive signal that the government is receptive to reviewing the measures. The tweaks, although not significant, are expected to benefit retirees and those with existing property investments by increasing liquidity. The changes are also expected to stimulate demand and interest in the market, particularly for new homeowners. However, experts caution that the measures may not have a significant impact on the overall property market, and the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) remains untouched.

site_title: Your smart device could testify against you
summary: The use of data from connected devices is increasingly being used in US legal proceedings to prove or disprove claims. Examples include a case where a pacemaker data contradicted a man's claim of a house fire, and a Fitbit data that disproved a woman's account of a 2015 alleged assault. Authorities are seeking data from devices such as smart TVs, thermostats, and vehicles to obtain evidence. The US Federal Trade Commission has fined companies for secretly gathering data on viewers and selling it to marketers. Experts warn that the "always on" nature of IoT devices means huge amounts of personal information is circulating, and that privacy is becoming increasingly difficult to protect.

site_title: No, Germany doesn't owe America 'vast sums' of money for Nato
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Germany for not paying its fair share in NATO defense spending, claiming the country owes the US "vast sums" of money. However, security experts argue that increased spending in Germany does not directly benefit the US, and Germany is on track to meet its 2% NATO commitment by 2024. Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel points out that mutual security also includes development aid and contributing to regional stability, and the country plans to increase its military spending by 3 billion euros over the next eight years.

site_title: Takeaways from Janet Yellen's press conference
summary: Fed Chairman Janet Yellen announced a second rate hike in three months, raising the federal funds rate by 0.25 percentage point to 0.75-1%. The decision reflects the economy's continued progress toward employment and price stability objectives. Yellen emphasized that the hike is gradual and not a reassessment of the economic outlook or monetary policy course. The global economy is seen as doing better, but businesses remain in a wait-and-see mode due to uncertainty about fiscal policy changes.

site_title: 'America First' Trump play opens door for EU-China trade detente
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" policy has led to a thaw in EU-China trade tensions, with European leaders and Chinese President Xi Jinping affirming their commitment to free trade. However, doubts persist about China's willingness to implement trade reforms, citing issues such as subsidies for manufacturing and export policies. Despite this, EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom suggests that the EU and China may start negotiations on a free-trade agreement in the next three to five years, potentially bolstering the case for cooperation.

site_title: Hatten adds a distinct Malacca flavour on SGX
summary: The Hatten Group, a Singapore-listed property development firm, has achieved significant success in revitalizing the historic state of Malacca, Malaysia, over the past decade. With a valuation of nearly S$400 million, the company's holdings are worth S$300 million, showcasing its substantial returns on investment. Hatten Land, the firm's property development arm, has completed several high-profile projects, including the largest shopping mall and hotel in Malacca, and has a strong track record of executing developments in the state. The company's success is attributed to its focus on mid-market development and its ability to capitalize on Malacca's growing tourism industry.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
"The roughest patch was loneliness. Nobody believed we could do it. My brother and I gave up a few big things," says Mr Colin.

site_title: Each Portfolio Design project bears firm's DNA
summary: Robert Su, founder of Portfolio Design Partnership, entered China's market in 2001 and established his own business in Shanghai. He developed his own design DNA and forged close relationships with clients, saying "Every project has life, and my design also has a DNA, my characteristics." Su faced challenges meeting Chinese developers' demands, but built trust by taking on smaller projects and focusing on quality. Now, he's based mostly in China, with annual sales of S$1-2 million and employs staff in Singapore and China, tapping local joint ventures for "sophisticated projects."

site_title: India ID plan wins World Bank praise but raises fears of Big Brother
summary: India's Aadhaar biometric ID program has won praise from the World Bank for its sophistication and potential to promote digital inclusion globally. The program, which has 1.1 billion users, authenticates transactions, loans, and job seekers, and is being adopted by other countries. However, concerns about data security and the creation of a "Big Brother" surveillance state have raised questions about its long-term implications. Despite this, the World Bank sees the system as a model for widespread adoption, with the potential to provide legal IDs to 1.5 billion people by 2030.

site_title: Uber battles taxis to woo more drivers
summary: Uber has introduced a 2,800 square-meter driver centre in New York City, offering amenities such as a bathroom, coffee, and free training classes, surpassing the 280 square-meter centre for yellow taxis. This move aims to improve the experience for drivers and compete with the traditional taxi industry. The new centre is a significant upgrade from the existing yellow cab driver centre, which has utilitarian furnishings and limited facilities. By providing better working conditions, Uber hopes to attract more drivers and increase its market share.

site_title: Why grammar matters: Missing Oxford comma may cost US company millions
summary: A US court ruled in favor of three truck drivers who sued Oakhurst Dairy for overtime pay, citing a debated punctuation mark: the Oxford comma. The absence of a comma in a state law meant that the law's exemption for certain categories of workers was ambiguous, leading the court to rule in favor of the drivers. The decision could cost Oakhurst Dairy an estimated $10 million. The case highlights the importance of punctuation in high-stakes legal debates.

site_title: Post-Fed calm in Treasuries masks a raging bulls-bears debate
summary: US Treasuries have appeared calm despite a range of forecasts suggesting a debate over whether long-term yields are poised for a bear market or will remain in months-old ranges. Analysts predict 10-year yields to rise to 2.65% by the end of the next quarter, with forecasts ranging from 2.2% to 3%. The Fed's latest forecasts call for two more hikes in 2017, and traders are awaiting clarity from Fed speakers, including Chair Janet Yellen on March 23.

site_title: Hardline priest's elevation sign Modi is moving towards a Hindu India
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has sworn in Yogi Adityanath, a firebrand Hindu ascetic, as the new chief minister of Uttar Pradesh, marking a shift towards a Hindu-dominated India. Adityanath, 44, has a history of anti-Muslim rhetoric and was elected by state lawmakers after the BJP won a landslide victory in Uttar Pradesh. Modi's elevation of Adityanath signals a departure from his platform of development for all, with observers warning of a potential majoritarian agenda. The move has sparked concerns about the future of India's secular democracy.

site_title: Hammond dismisses EU condition as a 'negotiating position'
summary: UK Chancellor Philip Hammond dismissed EU suggestions that Britain would owe a £60 billion Brexit bill as a "negotiating position" and said the amounts were "deliberately inflated." Hammond stated that Britain would honour its liabilities, but the amounts being discussed were likely inflated by including contributions the UK would make while still a member of the EU. He also downplayed the chances of Britain walking away with no deal, saying it was "extraordinarily unlikely." Hammond may need to make spending cuts in his autumn budget to fill the gap in public finances created by the Brexit bill.

site_title: US 'consumer relief' ruling can enrich big banks
summary: Big US banks, including Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank, are seeking to meet consumer relief requirements in mortgage settlements by buying distressed mortgages or lending to firms that do so. However, critics argue that these deals create a profit incentive, undermining the purpose of consumer relief. Deutsche Bank, for example, can receive credit for lending to hedge funds and private equity firms, which may be required to provide documentation of their efforts. The bank's monitor has yet to issue a progress report, and its compliance with the consumer relief provision remains uncertain.

site_title: Rock 'n' roll pioneer Chuck Berry dies at 90
summary: Chuck Berry, a pioneering rock 'n' roll musician, died at 90 on March 18, 2017, at his Missouri home. Berry was a key figure in the genre's early sound and heartbeat, creating hits like "Johnny B Goode," "Roll Over Beethoven," and "Sweet Little Sixteen." Influencing many famous artists, including Keith Richards, Paul McCartney, and Bruce Springsteen, Berry's legacy was marked by controversy and a reputation for being a penny-pincher and run-in with the law. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1986 and received a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 1984.

site_title: Halfway into 2017's oil supply cut, Asia remains awash with fuel
summary: Opec's oil supply cut has had little effect in Asia, where fuel flows remain near record highs despite the 1.8 million barrel per day reduction. Benchmark crude prices are down 10% since January, and analysts warn that prices could fall further unless demand growth rebounds. The glut is fueled by record volumes from the Americas and Europe, and Opec's cuts have led to increased competition from other suppliers, including Russia and the US. The ongoing supply surplus poses a challenge for Opec, which needs higher oil prices to balance government budgets.

images.alt_text: Stiff competition and ample supplies have depressed prices for Middle East and Asia-Pacific grades, some of them to multi-month lows.

site_title: More to HK than housing, pollution issues
summary: Hong Kong dropped to 71st out of 231 cities in Mercer's quality of living rankings, largely due to traffic congestion, air pollution, and natural disasters. Despite these issues, the city still offers a vibrant society, natural landscapes, and quality food, making it a desirable place to live for many. The author argues that while housing is a significant concern, other aspects of life in Hong Kong, such as its efficient public transportation system and cultural offerings, outweigh the negatives.

site_title: Netanyahu's rift with finance minister fuels talk of early Israeli election
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's dispute with Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon over broadcast regulation has sparked speculation of an early election, potentially two years ahead of schedule. Netanyahu cited concerns over job losses to abandon the agreement, and some commentators believe he hopes to delay a decision on possible criminal charges. A snap election could also postpone US peace moves under President Donald Trump, and Netanyahu's possible indictment over suspected corruption.

site_title: Australia threatens gas majors with 'action' to avert domestic shortage
summary: Australia's resources minister, Matt Canavan, warned major gas producers that the government will take action if they don't boost domestic gas supply to avert an energy shortage. The country is on track to become the world's largest LNG exporter, but its energy market operator has warned of a domestic gas crunch starting in 2019. Producers, including Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell, have committed to ensuring gas is available for the domestic market, but Canavan said the government will act if commitments are not met, citing national interest to secure energy supplies.

site_title: Giving back - the uniquely Singapore way
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore's corporate giving approach is uniquely tied to the local community, focusing on issues specific to the country. The bank's employee volunteering program has grown significantly, with 3,632 employee volunteer days in 2016, and has led to the creation of community programs such as CreativeMINDS Thrift Shop and Silver Lining, which provide training and employment opportunities for people with intellectual disabilities and support seniors, respectively. The bank's initiatives aim to make a meaningful impact and foster a culture of giving among its employees.

site_title: Will it be just a midsummer day's (pipe) dream for Shakespeare?
summary: Leicester City, nicknamed the Foxes, is sitting six points above the relegation zone in the English Premier League after a 3-2 win over West Ham United. The team's success is likened to Shakespeare's Midsummer Night's Dream, featuring comedy, fantasy, romance, and farce. However, Leicester's Champions League aspirations are uncertain, and a relegation spot is still a possibility. The team's first away win in the top flight this season marked a turning point in their season, but their European ambitions remain uncertain.

site_title: US rural areas brace for shortage of doctors after visa policy changes
summary: The US faces a shortage of doctors in rural areas due to changes in visa policy, affecting skilled workers. The Trump administration's decision to temporarily suspend premium processing for H-1B visas has caused delays in the arrival of foreign doctors, who are essential for medical services in small towns. The program, which allows foreign physicians to work in underserved areas, has been a lifeline for rural hospitals, but its impact is uncertain as the visa process slows. The shortage could worsen, affecting families in North Dakota and rural America, with some senators urging the agency to continue the program.

site_title: Millennial stock guru with banker parents won't buy banks
summary: Millennial stock picker BAIJING Yu, raised by two generations of Chinese bankers, has decided not to invest in Chinese lenders due to the government's control over the sector and lack of transparency. Yu's Comgest Growth Greater China fund has returned 22% annually over the past three years, focusing on technology, consumer, and insurance industries instead. Despite some short-term losses, the fund has outperformed its peers over the long term, with a 29% lead over the MSCI Golden Dragon index in euro terms over the past three years.

site_title: Tesla's US$169m Australia battery play is a global prototype
summary: Tesla is set to power grids globally, with a proposed 100 MW battery project in South Australia. The project, which would alleviate energy crises, is expected to cost around $169 million, making it profitable with an internal rate of return of 18-29%. The project would supply 400 MWh of power, making it Australia's largest battery capacity project. Tesla's pricing for battery packs is $250 per kilowatt hour, a good deal for large projects, with the total price estimated to be around $422/kWh.

site_title: Interior design trade bodies act to lift standards
summary: Singapore's interior design trade bodies, including the Society of Interior Designers Singapore (Sids) and the Interior Design Confederation (Singapore) (IDCS), have set ambitious plans to advance the industry's interests. Sids has established four design outposts in China, while IDCS has re-registered its 360-strong members and updated their working experiences and education backgrounds. The organizations aim to promote professional interior design consultancy services, establish accreditation standards for interior designers, and offer pro bono legal mediation services to members. These efforts follow a decade of dormancy and aim to elevate the industry's standards and reputation.

images.alt_text: Said Keat Ong, president of Sids, who wants to make the association the bridge to the world: "We are engaging and outward-looking now to work in a more collaborative manner."

site_title: California's embrace of marijuana may face snags
summary: California's cannabis industry is facing potential challenges with high taxes and the threat of federal intervention from the Trump administration. Despite the state's recreational cannabis use being legal, growers may be pushed back underground due to the high tax burden and uncertainty about federal enforcement. Local officials are working to issue permits and create regulations, but the industry remains anxious about the potential for widespread crackdowns. The state's cannabis market is estimated to be worth $7 billion, and entrepreneurs like Sam Edwards are finding ways to innovate and thrive despite the uncertainty.

site_title: Reinsurers design tailored deals in search of higher returns
summary: Swiss Re, the second-largest reinsurer, is designing tailored deals to boost returns in a competitive market. The company is offering bespoke reinsurance schemes, such as a Chinese program to protect farmers against floods and drought, using satellite and weather data to trigger payouts. This approach is a response to fierce competition from alternative providers, including pension funds, which have increased their market share to up to 20%. Swiss Re aims to differentiate itself by offering customized products, but faces competition from rivals like Munich Re and Scor.

images.alt_text: Reinsurer Swiss Re, usually involved in mega-deals on natural disaster coverage, is branching out on its own to do individually tailored schemes to boost returns, such as one in China to protect farmers against floods or drought.

site_title: China home-price growth quickens in Feb; gains spread to smaller cities
summary: China's property market experienced a slight increase in February, with average new home prices rising 0.3% compared to the previous month. Despite government curbs, speculation remains a concern, with prices rising 11.8% from a year ago in smaller cities. Major cities such as Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing saw price growth of 13.5%, 21.1%, and 22.1% respectively. The government has vowed to keep the market stable and stem speculation, with measures including curtailed mortgage lending and increased interest rates.

site_title: Ezra news puts O&M sector, banks in spotlight
summary: Ezra Holdings, an offshore and marine company, has filed for US Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to restructure its debts, potentially affecting the O&M sector and spillover selling in banks. Meanwhile, investors will monitor the US Federal Reserve's upcoming speakers and economic data releases for direction, following the Fed's dovish signal last week. The Singapore bourse is expected to react to these events, with relatively light economic data allowing for a catch-up in trading sentiment.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Shadow banking threatens China's economy, officials warn
summary: China's top officials are sounding the alarm about the dangers of shadow banking, a highly speculative and poorly regulated lending system that threatens the country's economy. Chairman of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) Yi Huiman and China Insurance Regulatory Commission Vice-Chairman Chen Wenhui warned of the risks of unregulated investment vehicles and Internet lending platforms that are raising large sums of money from ordinary investors. Experts fear that uncontrolled shadow lending could lead to financial system instability and economic downturns.

site_title: Scottish leader set to rally troops for referendum
summary: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is set to rally her party for a second referendum on Scottish independence, citing the potential consequences of Brexit on Scotland's relationship with the EU. Sturgeon demands a new referendum by early 2019, despite British Prime Minister Theresa May's opposition, calling it "an outrage" for the British government to deny Scotland's right to choose its own future. A recent survey shows 46% of Scottish voters now back independence, the highest level since 1999.

site_title: Gateway revises convertible bonds deal with Healthway
summary: Gateway Partners has revised its convertible notes deal with Healthway Medical Corporation, removing the coupon for both tranches of notes and extending the maturity period of one tranche to five years. The revised terms aim to provide a quick liquidity solution and address concerns over a change of control. The deal, which was previously secured against the entire S$70 million principal, will now be unsecured and will require shareholder approval before Gateway can exercise its full governance rights. The move comes amid a takeover tussle for HMC, with Lippo Group offering a S$10 million loan and Make Health Connect making advance payments to cover doctors.

site_title: China Feb home prices rise 11.8% y-o-y, up 0.3% m-o-m
summary: China's average new home prices in 70 major cities rose 0.3% in February from the previous month, following a slowdown in four consecutive months. This marks a quickening of growth, despite government curbs on speculators. Year-over-year, home prices increased 11.8%, slightly less than January's 12.2% gain. The National Bureau of Statistics reported the data on Saturday, citing increased pressure on speculators.

site_title: King Salman ends Asia tour, returns to Saudi Arabia: agency
summary: King Salman has concluded his month-long tour of Asia, returning to Saudi Arabia after visiting Malaysia, Indonesia, Japan, and China. During his trip, he oversaw the signing of deals worth up to $65 billion, promoting investment opportunities in Saudi Arabia. The visit aimed to boost the kingdom's economic reform plan and military cooperation with regional countries, including Malaysia and Indonesia, which are part of the Saudi-led Islamic Military Alliance.

site_title: G20 trade wording considered a setback for export champion Germany
summary: The G20 finance ministers and central bank governors failed to agree on resisting protectionism and supporting free trade, dropping a pledge to keep global trade free and open. This marks a setback for Germany, a strong export nation, and poses a risk to its growth. Economists warn that a weakening of the World Trade Organization and more aggressive protectionist policies could follow. The German government is considering refocusing its economic policy toward Asia and adapting to the "America First" approach.

site_title: Trump endorses plan to remove 30,000 FAA workers from payroll
summary: US President Donald Trump has endorsed a plan to remove 30,000 FAA workers from the federal payroll, including 14,000 air traffic controllers and 16,000 other employees, as part of his 2018 budget. The proposal aims to privatize the FAA's NextGen programme, which aims to modernize air traffic control, by transferring it to a non-profit corporation. The move is expected to cut 65% of the FAA's workforce and shift the agency's role from operational oversight to regulation. The plan has divided the airline industry, with some airlines supporting privatization and others opposing it, citing concerns over funding and uncertainty.

site_title: Ezra bites bullet, files Chapter 11 protection with US court
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine firm, has filed for Chapter 11 protection with the US Bankruptcy Court, citing difficulties in raising funds due to the challenging operating environment in the oil and gas industry. The company, which has 17,000 shareholders and $150 million in outstanding notes due in May, aims to "optimise the scope and extent of the restructuring options available" and "protect the interests of all stakeholders." This move follows the bankruptcy filing of its associate, Emas Chiyoda Subsea, and comes after Ezra disclosed a potential $170 million writedown in February.

site_title: How close is the US to full employment? Trump and Yellen disagree
summary: US President Donald Trump and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen disagree on how close the country is to full employment. Trump hopes to achieve 25 million jobs over the next decade, but Yellen believes the economy is already close to full employment, citing a long-run increase in the labor force of 75,000-125,000 jobs per month. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari also offer differing views, with Kashkari expressing concerns about individual communities experiencing high unemployment rates.

site_title: Deutsche Bank issues 687.5m new shares at 11.65 euros each
summary: Deutsche Bank has issued 687.5 million new shares at 11.65 euros each as part of an 8 billion euro capital increase. The subscription period runs from March 21 to April 6, with the same dividend entitlement as existing shares. The new shares will be issued at a 2:1 subscription ratio.

site_title: Adani aims to start mining Australian coal in 2020
summary: The Adani Group, an Indian conglomerate, plans to start extracting coal from the Carmichael project in Australia's Galilee Basin in 2020, three months after receiving final approval from the Australian federal government. Environmental protests had delayed the project, prompting a 38% cut in underground mining capacity. The project aims to fuel power generation for 100 million Indians and create 10,000 jobs in Queensland. The Queensland premier has stated that most approvals have been granted, with environmental conditions attached, and no obstacles are expected for the final piece of legislation.

site_title: Tillerson brings tougher North Korea line to a wary China
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is set to press China to use its leverage over North Korea to rein in the rogue regime's nuclear and missile programs during talks in Beijing. The Trump administration has taken a tougher stance on North Korea, with Tillerson stating military action is "on the table" if threats escalate. China, however, is wary of the new US approach and has proposed a plan for North Korea to suspend nuclear and missile activities in exchange for US and South Korean halting military exercises. China shares US concerns but fears squeezing North Korea too hard, leading to a regime collapse.

site_title: Google to revamp ad policies after UK boycott
summary: Google announced changes to its advertising policies following a UK boycott, where major brands pulled ads from YouTube due to ads appearing alongside offensive content. The company will give clients more control over ad placement and review its policies to prevent ads from showing on objectionable websites or against extremist content. Google removed nearly 2 billion offensive ads last year and blacklisted 100,000 publishers, but admitted "we don't always get it right." The company aims to resolve issues and regain the trust of advertisers and the UK government.

site_title: Keppel Land increases stake in Saigon Centre in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: Keppel Land acquired an additional 16% stake in Saigon Centre in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam from its Vietnamese partner, Southern Waterborne Transport Corporation, for about S$53.5 million. This increases Keppel Land's stake to 53.5% in Phases One and Two, and 76.2% in subsequent phases. The acquisition reflects Keppel Land's confidence in sustainable urbanization in Vietnam, with no expected impact on earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Deep divisions in US consumer sentiment run beyond party lines
summary: US consumer sentiment is deeply divided, with gaps in sentiment by income, employment, and race. Since Donald Trump's election, the difference between Americans earning over $100,000 and those with incomes below $15,000 has reached its widest since the 2009 recession. Wealthy Americans are more confident, while the poorest are less confident than they were at the recession's nadir. Employment and racial divides also exist, with full-time workers showing the strongest confidence since 2001 and black consumers experiencing a widening gap with white consumers.

site_title: Thimble, wheelbarrow, boot kicked out of Monopoly board game
summary: Hasbro Inc, the maker of Monopoly, is replacing three classic tokens with new ones: a penguin, T-Rex, and rubber ducky. The change, which will be released in August, was determined by consumer votes during a promotional period earlier this year. Four classic pieces, including the Scottie dog and top hat, will remain unchanged. The updated tokens will be available in the new version of the game, which will retain its traditional rules and objective of dominating cardboard real estate.

site_title: Tours with Tulips
summary: The Conservatorium Hotel in Amsterdam is offering a "Conservatorium in Bloom" package, starting April 1, for €807 (S$1,215). The package includes a private driver, tulip cake, and entrance tickets to Keukenhof, the famous flower garden with seven million tulips. Guests will also receive two nights' stay at the hotel.

site_title: Yang Kee Logistics buys Aussie firm Axima for S$34m
summary: Yang Kee Logistics Pte Ltd has acquired Australian company Axima Pty Ltd for S$34 million, marking its first major international acquisition. Axima is a key player in Australia's third-party logistics market.

images.alt_text: With the Axima purchase, Yang Kee's revenue will be boosted by S$150 million, improving its overall profitability and revenue share outside of Singapore.

site_title: Works with Winds
summary: The Philharmonic Chamber Winds will perform a concert titled "From an Invalid's Workshop" on March 18 at the Esplanade Recital Studio. The show features three Kurt Weill compositions, including "Alabama Song" and "Mack the Knife," alongside Richard Strauss' "From an Invalid's Workshop." The program will also include Johann Strauss II's "Artist's Life" and vocals by Australian singer Sandra Wolf. Tickets are available for S$15 by emailing jodie@philharmonicwinds.org.

site_title: Athletics: Track stars to say so long to Bolt
summary: Usain Bolt, the world's fastest man, will compete in his final Jamaican athletics event, the Racers Track Club Grand Prix, on June 10. Britain's Mo Farah and Kenya's David Rudisha will join Bolt in the star-studded international field. Bolt, the reigning Olympic 100m and 200m champion, has announced his retirement after the World Championships in London, where he qualifies automatically as the reigning world sprint champion. The event is being dubbed "Salute to a Legend" in honor of Bolt's legacy.

site_title: Tensions show as Trump, Merkel meet for first time
summary: President Donald Trump and German Chancellor Angela Merkel met for the first time at the White House, with tensions evident as they discussed key issues like NATO, defense spending, and free trade deals. Merkel, known for her cautious approach, faced Trump's impulsive nature, while Trump criticized Washington's NATO allies for not paying their fair share. The meeting was marked by awkward moments, including an unreturned handshake and a joke about wiretapping. Merkel urged a more collaborative approach, saying it's better to talk to each other than about each other.

site_title: Jack Ma to launch Alibaba's regional distribution hub in Malaysia: sources
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Limited plans to establish a regional distribution hub in Malaysia, with Alibaba executive chairman Jack Ma and Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak set to announce the plans in Kuala Lumpur next week. The hub, located within KLIA Aeropolis, aims to cater to Alibaba's growing business in the region. The project is expected to generate significant domestic and foreign investments, with estimated investments exceeding RM7 billion.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Limited plans to set up a regional distribution hub in Malaysia to cater to its fast-growing business in the region

site_title: Europe: Shares end week with a gain; banks volatile on rate talk
summary: European shares ended the week with a gain, despite volatile banks, as the Stoxx 600 rose 0.2% and the week saw a 1.4% gain. The European Central Bank policymaker Ewald Nowotny sparked a rally in bank stocks by mentioning possible interest rate hikes, but the sector ultimately fell 0.1% due to losses in several major banks. Despite this, investors remain optimistic about the sector's prospects, citing improved regulation and the economy.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat as banks, Amgen weigh; Adobe rallies
summary: US stocks ended flat on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 indices little changed, as bank shares fell alongside Treasury yields. Adobe's strong earnings report lifted the S&P tech sector, while Amgen's disappointing earnings dragged on the Nasdaq. Analysts expect a catalyst to boost the market, citing President Trump's promises of tax cuts and a fiscal stimulus, but concerns about the healthcare bill's impact on tax reform efforts persist.

site_title: McDonald's shareholders to weigh giving franchisees board seat
summary: McDonald's shareholders are set to vote on a proposal that would give franchisees, who operate 85% of the company's restaurants, the opportunity to elect a board member. The proposal, which faces long odds, aims to increase franchisee representation on the board from 85% to 95%. If successful, it could mark a significant change in the board dynamic for McDonald's and other heavily franchised US restaurant chains, potentially impacting the company's direction.

site_title: G20 hits America First, climate change speed bumps
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin met with G20 finance ministers in Baden-Baden, Germany, to discuss global trade and climate change. Despite Washington's "America First" policy, Mnuchin engaged in negotiations, but disagreements remained on trade openness and climate change. The US delegation resisted including climate change language in the final communique, citing a lack of mandate from the Trump administration. The talks concluded with no agreement, potentially affecting the final statement and future global economic policies.

site_title: Fashion renaissance: from slick city to hip Hong Kong
summary: A new generation of independent designers in Hong Kong is revitalizing the city's fashion scene, shifting away from traditional luxury brands and towards a more unique, "Hip Hong Kong" style. They use social media and pop-up events to showcase their work, bypassing traditional advertising and store fronts. This approach has put Hong Kong on the international fashion map, offering a fresh alternative to the city's long-struggling fashion industry, which has traditionally been dominated by luxury labels and cheap knock-offs. Hong Kong's fashion scene is undergoing a renaissance, driven by innovative and forward-thinking designers.

site_title: Growth strengthening, but 'wrong' policies could halt it: IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that global growth is gaining momentum but warned that "wrong" policies could halt it. She emphasized the need for strong monetary, fiscal, and structural economic reform policies to achieve strong, sustained, and inclusive growth. The IMF is committed to supporting its members in addressing risks from excessive capital-flow volatility and enhancing global cooperation. The G-20 meeting also dropped past language rejecting protectionism and committing nations to support the Paris climate accords, amid concerns over the new US administration's stance on trade and climate change.

images.alt_text: Seeking to play down fears over the US weakening international commitments to free trade and climate change, Ms Lagarde says the new White House needed time to "adapt and learn".

site_title: China to build on disputed shoal in South China Sea
summary: China plans to begin environmental monitoring station work on Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea this year, following US warnings against land reclamation. The move comes ahead of a visit by US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who will reiterate US concerns about Chinese island building. The US has introduced a bill to impose sanctions on China's activities in the disputed waterway, which China calls "extremely grating" and claims is aimed at denying access to the waters. The US is concerned about China's island-building efforts, which it says could increase tensions and isolate China.

site_title: South Korea prosecutors to question SK Group chief in corruption probe
summary: South Korean prosecutors will question SK Group chairman Chey Tae-Won in connection with an influence-peddling scandal linked to former President Park Geun-Hye. The investigation centers on allegations that Park colluded with friend Choi Soon-Sil to pressure businesses to donate to foundations supporting her policies. Chey will be questioned on Saturday, while Park is due to appear on Tuesday. The scandal led to Park's impeachment and dismissal from office, and an election to choose a new president will take place on May 9.

site_title: Employees, get a life
summary: A Singaporean article discusses the pressure to work long hours and maintain a work-life balance in today's fast-paced economy. Despite studies showing that excessive work can lead to decreased productivity and creativity, many employees feel obligated to prioritize work over personal life. Experts argue that having a fulfilling life outside of work is not a sign of laziness, but rather a necessary aspect of overall well-being. They advise employees to communicate with their bosses, set boundaries, and demonstrate their ability to manage their time effectively. By doing so, employees can prove their value to the organization without sacrificing their personal lives.

site_title: As Yellen complains that GDP is 'noisy', the Fed makes a racket
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen criticized the accuracy of GDP estimates, citing differences between regional Fed banks' models. The New York Fed estimates growth at 2.8% and the Atlanta Fed at 0.9% due to varying data inputs and weights. Yellen sees growth between the two estimates, expecting a 2% annual growth rate. The models are research tools, not official forecasts, and have short track records. Economists disagree on the usefulness of the Atlanta GDPNow model, with some praising its accuracy.

site_title: Ezra files for US bankruptcy as marine debt crunch spreads
summary: Ezra Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-listed oilfield services group, filed for bankruptcy in the US under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code due to a slump in oil prices over the past three years. The company faces hostile actions from creditors at home and abroad, and aims to optimize restructuring options and protect stakeholder interests. An informal meeting will be held to update holders of its debt on the filing.

site_title: Birth of a Station
summary: Singapore's first TV station, Television Singapura, launched on February 15, 1963, with Minister S Rajaratnam as its first on-screen appearance. The inaugural event was attended by 300 guests and thousands more who gathered to watch the telecast on 17 TV sets set up outside the Victoria Theatre. Daily programming included short newsreels, comedies, and cartoons, lasting only three and a half hours each day. This marked the beginning of the country's television journey, which would eventually evolve into MediaCorp, the precursor to the modern television industry in Singapore.

site_title: Amgen cholesterol drug cuts heart attack, stroke risk but shares fall
summary: Amgen's cholesterol drug Repatha reduced the risk of heart attack and stroke by 20% in patients with heart disease, but fell short of investor expectations. The drug cut combined risk by 33% in the second year of the study. Despite this, two pharmacy benefit managers announced plans to increase prescriptions for Repatha due to its health benefits. Amgen acknowledged it is selling the drug at a discount, and the company plans to refund costs for eligible patients who have a heart attack or stroke.

site_title: White House intruder on grounds 16 minutes before arrest: Secret Service
summary: A 26-year-old man, Jonathan Tran, was arrested for trespassing on the White House grounds 16 minutes before his capture on March 10. Tran, from northern California, climbed over a fence, scaled a vehicle gate, and hid behind a pillar before being taken into custody without incident. He was carrying a backpack and two cans of mace. If convicted, he faces up to 10 years in prison. The incident was described as an "embarrassment" by Republican Congressman Jason Chaffetz, but President Donald Trump praised the Secret Service for their "fantastic job".

site_title: InvestingNote, a social network for investors by investors
summary: InvestingNote, a social network for investors, has launched a platform allowing users to keep their own e-journals for tracking investments. The platform, which partners with CIMB Securities, PhillipCapital, and RHB Securities, aims to educate retail investors on stock markets. Users can share ideas, follow professionals, and award points to boost reputation. Unlike traditional forums, InvestingNote organizes information neatly and verifies professionals' accreditation.
