The platform has received funding from National Research Foundation and is available online and on app stores, with plans to expand into new markets.

images.alt_text: Mr Lin says the InvestingNote organises information neatly, and ensures the credibility of professionals.

site_title: Life Cycle
summary: Poon Kng Joo, a 62-year-old businessman, opened Soek Seng 1954 Bicycle Cafe in Seletar Aerospace, Singapore, nine years ago. Inspired by his experience at OCBC's inaugural mass cycling event, he started collecting and restoring vintage bicycles. The cafe features an air-conditioned dining room and al fresco section, serving Western and Asian favorites. Poon sees the cafe as a community hangout for cyclists and an outlet to express himself through restoring bicycles, which he considers an art form.

site_title: Modi's govt said to mull luring foreign retail for Make-in-India push
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government is considering easing rules for foreign retailers in exchange for selling more locally produced goods. Companies like Amazon and Wal-mart Stores may be allowed to market made-in-India products if they agree to stock only local products. The move aims to boost local manufacturing and create jobs, but faces opposition from the Bharatiya Janata Party, which represents small traders. The government hopes to attract more foreign direct investment and alleviate the country's reliance on services-based FDI.

site_title: US dollar stays weak, but long-term outlook still upbeat
summary: The US dollar fell to a five-week low on Friday, staying under pressure for a third straight session after the Federal Reserve kept a gradual rate-hiking pace. Despite this, analysts remain bullish on the greenback, citing the Fed's active tightening of policy. The dollar's long-term outlook is seen as upbeat, with the risk of additional spending by the Trump administration potentially weakening the currency.

images.alt_text: The US dollar fell to a five-week low on Friday, remaining under pressure for a third straight session after the Federal Reserve quashed hopes for a further currency bull run by keeping a gradual rate-hiking pace.

site_title: China's capital curbs find favour as risks to stability pile up
summary: China's capital controls are seen as a necessary measure to maintain stability in the country's markets, despite controversy. The controls, which limit offshore investments and currency conversion, have helped keep volatility at bay and are backed by major banks such as UBS and Standard Chartered. Officials have pledged to maintain stability ahead of a Communist Party leadership reshuffle, and the controls have been credited with preventing a trade war with the US and a yuan depreciation. The controls are expected to continue, with experts warning that looser measures could lead to market instability.

site_title: Tesla wannabe LeEco to sell Silicon Valley site amid cash crunch: sources
summary: LeEco, a Chinese technology conglomerate, is selling a 20-hectare Silicon Valley property amid a cash crunch. The company, which aims to compete with Tesla in premium electric vehicles, purchased the site from Yahoo Inc last year. LeEco's struggles to support its goals, including beating Tesla, have prompted the sale. The move is part of the firm's efforts to ride out the financial challenges and maintain its ambitions in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Trump clings to Obama wiretapping claims - but no evidence yet
summary: US President Donald Trump refused to drop his claim that predecessor Barack Obama wiretapped him, despite no evidence to support the allegations. Trump reiterated the claim during a joint press conference with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, saying "at least we have something in common perhaps" regarding the US National Security Agency's reported tapping of Merkel's phone. The controversy has bogged down Trump's administration and strained relations with Britain, with the British GCHQ spy agency labeling the charge "utterly ridiculous".

site_title: Dine Now
summary: K TOWER in Amoy Street offers a seafood tower with fresh ingredients for S$58 (3 tiers) and S$298 (9 tiers). Brotzeit restaurant introduces a new menu, including the Wunderplatte with a whole rotisserie chicken and Bavarian honey ribs, and Bandnudeln with meatballs and mushroom sauce.

site_title: My favourite book
summary: Dale Carnegie's 1936 book "How to Win Friends and Influence People" has been praised for its timeless insights on human behavior and interaction. Jay Teo, a country manager, credits the book with helping him better understand humans, noting their irrationality and emotional motivations. The book's principles remain relevant today, offering guidance on building relationships and influencing others.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Auric Pacific's takeover offer for Sunshine has crossed the 90% mark, becoming unconditional with a closing date of April 7. F&N priced a S$160 million five-year bond at 3.09%. Keppel T&T sold its 10% interest in Asia Airfreight Terminal for HK$250 million. Chinese tycoon Gordon Tang emerged as a substantial shareholder in OUE Commercial Reit, now owning 7.68% of the company.

site_title: Top M1 shareholders in strategic review of their stakes
summary: M1's three major shareholders, Singapore Press Holdings, Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation, and Axiata Group, are exploring a sale of their stakes in the telco operator ahead of its official launch in 2018. The move comes as M1 faces increased competition from new entrant TPG Telecom and mobile virtual network operator Circles.Life. The strategic review, led by financial adviser Morgan Stanley, is expected to impact M1's earnings and market share. Analysts have been bearish on M1, citing its exposure to the Singapore mobile market and the expected entry of TPG.

site_title: Laguna set for world-ranking event
summary: The Laguna National Golf and Country Club in Singapore will host the Singapore Ladies Amateur Open, a world-ranking event, from Tuesday to Thursday next week. 132 golfers from 13 countries will compete at the Andy Dye-designed Masters course, featuring water hazards and bunkers requiring strategic course management. The event is part of Laguna's efforts to attract major golf tournaments, following renovations and upgrades to the World Classic course, set to be completed late this year. The tournament promises to be an exciting three days with a strong Singapore challenge led by local golfers.

site_title: Utah's VISTAS
summary: Land Rover launched a 300-mile drive adventure for its new Discovery luxury off-road vehicle in red rock country, starting in southwestern Utah, crossing into Arizona, and ending at the Grand Canyon. The drive takes participants through diverse landscapes, including semi-arid plateaus, deserts, and snow-covered mountains. The route features unique juxtapositions of contrasting natural beauty, including a 2,000-foot elevation plateau and a 6,000-foot mountain range. The drive culminates at the Grand Canyon, offering breathtaking views of the Colorado River and surrounding limestone cliffs.

site_title: Don't forget the other side of the investing coin
summary: A portfolio update reveals muted global markets in March, with the MSCI AC World index rising 0.9% and global bonds posting a 1.3% loss. The fund manager's portfolio gained 0.1%, driven by US and Europe equities, but detracted from performance due to emerging markets and fixed income holdings. The article emphasizes the importance of risk management in investing, highlighting that a fund manager's ability to manage risk is just as crucial as delivering returns.

site_title: Iceland considers new tax on tourists
summary: Iceland's government is considering a new tax on tourists to address overcrowding and protect the country's natural treasures, such as the Blue Lagoon and glacier lagoon. Visitor numbers have grown exponentially, with 2.3 million expected this year, despite the country's population being less than 340,000. The proposed tax could include forcing bus companies and tour operators to buy a special license or increasing the hotel tax, which generated 400 million kronur in revenue in 2016. The goal is to control the number of visitors and preserve Iceland's unique natural attractions.

site_title: Bread Haven
summary: Firebake, a new eatery, has opened in Singapore, offering an experiential destination that showcases ancient grains and baking methods. Chef Konstantino Blokbergen bakes bread from scratch using organic flour, wild yeast, and non-iodised salt. Four types of wood-fired sourdough breads are initially available, with plans to expand to include breads made with ancient grains. The restaurant features two large woodfire ovens that take six weeks to build and reach temperatures of up to 1,000 degrees Celsius. Firebake encourages diners to appreciate breads through food, with prices starting from $8 for small plates and sharing portions.

site_title: HUDC era ends with privatisation of Braddell View
summary: The HUDC era in Singapore has ended with the privatisation of Braddell View HUDC Estate, the largest of the 18 HUDC estates. The estate, comprising 918 flats and two shops, was converted into a strata-titled estate after 75% of flat owners supported the privatisation. This marks the end of the HUDC Housing Estates Act, allowing individual owners to manage and maintain their common property. With the privatisation, a total of 7,731 dwelling units have been privatised, following the initial privatisation of Pine Grove and Gillman Heights in 1996.

site_title: Wage Credit Scheme: SMEs to get bulk of payout
summary: Singapore's Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) payouts will reach S$660 million by the end of March, benefiting over 85,000 employers and 600,000 employees. SMEs will receive about 70% of the payouts, with the government co-funding 20% of qualifying wage increases from 2015 to 2017. Eligible employers will receive letters by March 31, and appeals can be filed to IRAS by June. To qualify for the last tranche in 2018, employers must pay qualifying wage increases this year or sustain them from 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Measured Fed approach sends wave of capital inflows into emerging Asia ETFs
summary: The US Federal Reserve's loose monetary policy has led to a surge in capital inflows into emerging Asian exchange-traded funds (ETFs). According to a Singapore Exchange study, six of the top-performing ETFs tracked Asian emerging equity indices, with an average month-to-date return of 4% in the first half of March. This trend is attributed to the Fed's measured approach, which has opened the gates for investors to flock to emerging markets. The study highlights the growing interest in emerging Asian equities, particularly those linked to Indian and Indonesian indices.

site_title: Sleepy behind the wheel? Some cars can tell
summary: Advanced technologies are being developed to detect drowsiness in drivers, with several companies working on sensors and algorithms to monitor heart rate, breathing patterns, and body temperature. These systems aim to provide early warnings and even take control of the vehicle to prevent accidents. Manufacturers like Audi, Mercedes, and Volvo are integrating these technologies into their vehicles, with some systems able to detect drowsiness with 80-97% accuracy. The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration estimates that drowsy driving causes 824 deaths annually, and experts emphasize the importance of raising awareness about the dangers of drowsy driving.

site_title: Singtel, StarHub hitch a ride on M1's rally
summary: Singapore's telco rivals Singtel and StarHub saw their shares rise on Friday after speculation about a possible takeover of M1. M1's major shareholders were reportedly considering selling their combined 61% stake, which would require a general offer under Singapore's corporate rules. The news sent Singtel's shares up 1.01% and StarHub's shares up 2.14%. Analysts attributed the spillover to hopes that M1's potential sale would boost the sector, but the lack of details and no clear indicative price for M1's shares limited the impact.

site_title: GIC JV buys student-housing portfolios in US for US$1.6b
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has bought three US student-housing portfolios worth US$1.6 billion, expanding its student-housing portfolio to 48 communities in 36 university markets. The joint venture, which includes Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Scion Student Communities, has deployed US$1 billion in equity capital and owns 45% of the three portfolios. The move is seen as a strategic investment in the US student-housing sector, which has strong demand fundamentals.

site_title: Q&M ties up with Malaysian startup to expand reach
summary: Q&M Dental Group has partnered with Malaysian booking platform BookDoc to expand its reach. The partnership will allow patients to search and book dental services through the app. BookDoc is integrated with various services including Google Maps, Grab, AirAsia, and TripAdvisor. This move complements Q&M's focus on offering quality services to all its patients.

site_title: AA Reit to issue S$50m 3.6% 5-year bonds
summary: AA Reit has issued S$50 million of 3.6% fixed rate notes due March 22, 2022, strengthening its debt profile and diversifying its funding sources. The issuance will extend the average debt maturity from 2.1 years to 2.5 years. The Reit's properties include warehouses, business parks, and industrial sites in Singapore and Australia, with a portfolio occupancy of 94% and net asset value per unit of S$1.48.

site_title: New US home construction rebounds in February
summary: US home construction rebounded in February with a 3% increase to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 1.29 million units, its highest level in four months. Single-family units saw a 6.5% jump to 872,000 new units, while multi-family dwellings fell 7.7% to 396,000. Analysts attribute the increase to strong demand and the unseasonably warm month of February. However, new housing permits fell 6.2% to 1.21 million, suggesting potential falling supply ahead.

site_title: Proposed new golf rules welcome
summary: The R&A and the United States Golf Association are proposing changes to golf rules to speed up play and eliminate penalties. The proposed rule changes include building golf courses with three sixes instead of two nines, reducing multi-hour rounds to three or under two hours, and allowing players to hole out at every hole in standard individual stroke play. The changes aim to make the game more accessible and enjoyable for young players who juggle sport and studies.

site_title: Wear & Tear
summary: Surrender, a boutique in Orchard Road, Singapore, has launched a new lifestyle and art-centred concept with a collaboration between LA-based artists DRx Romanelli and Cali Thornhill DeWitt. The capsule collection features up-cycled, reconstructed designs, including nine jackets that spell out the brand's name, 100 T-shirts, and textile artworks. The collection's East-meets-West theme is reflected in its use of Asian robes and Western patches. The boutique's 2,400 sq ft space features a mysterious, dramatic, and grand atmosphere, with dark concrete and textured effects.

site_title: FOMC, telco play help STI rise 1.1% over the week
summary: The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 1.1% over the week following the March 14-15 Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, which saw an interest rate hike and guidance on future hikes. The Atlanta Federal Reserve's GDP growth forecast was also downgraded to 0.9% from 1.2%.

site_title: Keisuke Takeda
summary: Chef Keisuke Takeda, founder of Keisuke Singapore, has 12 restaurants in Singapore serving authentic Japanese cuisine with a local twist. His success can be attributed to his background in French cuisine and ability to adapt to local tastes. Takeda's restaurants offer unique dishes such as lobster ramen and chicken tempura, which cater to Singaporean preferences. He plans to open two more restaurants this year, introducing new food items with a Keisuke twist. Takeda's restaurants have consistently had long queues, with prices ranging from $18.80 for a set meal. His goal is to capture the diner's heart in one spoonful of broth, showcasing his personality and heart in every bowl of ramen.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Keisuke Takeda

site_title: Hide & Sleek
summary: A Singaporean family's semi-detached home features hidden storage spaces, including a feature wall in the living room that reveals a storage area for earthenware tea cups, and a "hidden door" look in the kitchen and bedrooms that creates a sleek appearance while minimizing cleaning hassle. Interior designer Adrian Heng created the design, incorporating the family's individual preferences and needs, including a customized music keyboard shelf and a hotel-suite-inspired parents' room. The Tay family was thrilled with the result, feeling as if they were in a home makeover reality TV show.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Tribute to Survivors
summary: Renowned Singapore designer Benny Ong has created a hand-woven art collection titled Women.Shoes. Freedom, supporting Breast Cancer Foundation, with proceeds from the sale of "The Sisters Soong I" going to the foundation. The collection explores traditional and modern roles of women, symbolizing their freedom and strength, honoring Chinese women who were bound by shoes and breast cancer survivors. The exhibition runs till April 7 at UOB Art Gallery.

site_title: UniSIM renamed Singapore University of Social Sciences
summary: Singapore University of Social Sciences (SUSS) has been renamed from SIM University (UniSIM) as part of the government's effort to restructure the institution into the country's sixth autonomous university. SUSS will continue to offer existing programmes and participate in SkillsFuture, focusing on applied education in social sciences and life-long learning. The university's day-to-day operations and location remain unchanged, and it will complement the existing five autonomous universities in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Currency traders race to reform 'last look'
summary: Currency traders are racing to reform the "last look" practice, a custom allowing market makers to back out of trades, amid allegations of abuse and a growing need for transparency. Industry leaders, including top banks and proprietary traders, are working on a global code of conduct to police themselves before regulators crack down harder. The code, set to be released in May, aims to increase transparency and curb the practice, which critics say can lead to unfair market manipulation. Industry executives acknowledge the need for reform, citing a credibility crisis and scandals that have tarnished the industry's reputation.

site_title: Cathay to slash staff costs by 30% after loss
summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's flagship airline, announced a 30% staff cost reduction as part of a major overhaul to repair its financial struggles. The move follows the company's first annual net loss in eight years, attributed to intense competition and declining demand from business travelers. Middle and senior management at its Hong Kong head office will be targeted, with management changes to be announced in June. The restructuring aims to create a "leaner, simpler structure" and is part of a three-year transformation program.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The US Federal Reserve's guidance on two more hikes in 2017 is seen as positive for Singapore Reits, with prices expected to be supported in the near term. DBS Group Research recommends investors position themselves in cyclical sectors in office and industrial Reits, citing better GDP growth prospects for Singapore. Meanwhile, OCBC Investment Research downgrades M1 and StarHub to "sell" due to expected increased competition in the telecom sector, while maintaining a positive outlook for Singtel.

site_title: Military action against North Korea an 'option': Tillerson
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson says military action against North Korea is an "option on the table" if the threat escalates, signaling a change in American policy. The US has 28,000 troops in South Korea and is exploring new diplomatic, security, and economic measures. Tillerson's comments come after a missile launch by North Korea and amid concerns over China's enforcement of UN sanctions. The US has ended its "strategic patience" with North Korea, and Tillerson will press China to do more to address the issue during a visit to Beijing.

site_title: Disco HIT
summary: The fifth-generation Land Rover Discovery has been praised for its versatility and refinement, offering improved wading depth and off-road capabilities in a seven-seater luxury family SUV. Unlike its predecessor, the new model is smoother and sharper in design, retaining the stepped roof for optimal third-row headroom. Its refined features make it a standout in the market, catering to both on-road and off-road needs.

site_title: Urban programmes risk getting cut by Trump's Budget
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed budget would cut the Department of Housing and Urban Development's budget by 13% and eliminate various programs aimed at helping urban cities and vulnerable populations. These cuts include the Community Development Block Grant, which funds programs like Meals On Wheels and homeless shelters, as well as the Minority Business Development Agency, 21st Century Community Learning Centers, and low-income heating assistance. City leaders and non-profits are concerned that these cuts will disproportionately affect the urban poor and undermine efforts to improve their living conditions.

site_title: Captivating CANBERRA
summary: Canberra, the capital of Australia, is a young and vibrant city with a rich history, culture, and culinary scene. The city's coffee culture is renowned, with local baristas like Sasa Sestic winning international trophies. Must-visit attractions include the Australian War Memorial, the National Museum of Australia, and the iconic Parliament House. The city also offers a range of dining options, from fine restaurants to a wildlife lodge where guests can stay next to wild animals. Canberra is easily accessible, with Singapore Airlines operating regular international flights.

site_title: Small companies in Japan struggle with hiring as graduates vie for jobs in big firms
summary: Japan's job-to-applicant ratio reached a 25-year high of 1.43 in January, with more than two jobs available for every applicant. The low birth rate and slow economic recovery contribute to the shortage of workers, particularly affecting small companies. Large employers are loosening their hiring practices, considering foreigners and mid-career recruitment, and offering benefits to attract top talent. The hiring season for third-year university students has begun, with major firms competing for a limited number of positions, and companies are making efforts to improve diversity and inclusiveness.

site_title: OCBC sees Ezra either deferring or defaulting on its notes redemption
summary: OCBC Asia Credit has downgraded Ezra Holdings' S$150 million notes maturing in 2018 due to the company's uncertain financial future. Ezra faces contingent liabilities from its associate Emas Chiyoda Subsea's US Chapter 11 filing and ongoing refinancing efforts. Analysts project four possible options, including deferring or defaulting on note redemption, or restructuring the debt to reduce leverage. If Ezra fails to access fresh capital, it may extend note redemption or pursue a debt-to-equity swap, resulting in severe dilution of equity. The credit analyst has withdrawn his recommendation due to the high risk of poor recovery for noteholders.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: A food and drinks communications specialist shares her weekend routine, prioritizing self-care and relaxation. She starts with brisk walking and visits cafes and bakeries, such as Stamping Ground Coffee and Do.Main Bakery, to enjoy breakfast and tea. She also spends time with friends and their kittens, and enjoys single malt drams at Quaich Bar. The article highlights her appreciation for local flavors, traditional recipes, and quality drinks, showcasing her passion for food and beverages.

images.alt_text: JENNY TAN

site_title: Haute Stuff
summary: The San Pellegrino Young Chef award is now open for applicants under 30 with at least a year of restaurant experience. To participate, submit a signature dish via the website by April 30. Shortlisted chefs will be selected by June, with the South-East Asia challenge taking place in the third quarter of this year and the grand finals in Milan in 2018. Previous winners include Kirk Westaway, who represented South-East Asia in the 2015 finals and is now chef de cuisine of JAAN.

site_title: SATS to sell 51% stake in Hong Kong unit for HK$76.5m
summary: SATS, a ground-handling company at Changi Airport, will sell 51% of its Hong Kong unit, SATS HK, to Voltaire Capital Investment for HK$76.5 million (S$13.8 million). The sale is a cash transaction, marking a significant move for the company.

site_title: On the scent of the real Ivanka
summary: Ivanka Trump's self-styled image as a feminist hero is fraying, with her father's Cabinet featuring 20 men and only 4 women. This stark contrast to past administrations, where Obama and Clinton had more female representation. The Ivanka Effect, which was expected to bring about change, seems to be lacking, with Ivanka's influence on her father remaining unclear.

images.alt_text: Saturday Night Live's parody of Ivanka Trump is played out in a mock commercial in which Ivanka, played by Scarlett Johansson, hawks a new signature fragrance called Complicit. At one point, she retouches her lipstick and sees her father (played by Alec Baldwin) glowering back.

Saturday Night Live's parody of Ivanka Trump is played out in a mock commercial in which Ivanka, played by Scarlett Johansson, hawks a new signature fragrance called Complicit. At one point, she retouches her lipstick and sees her father (played by Alec Baldwin, above) glowering back.

When he behaves, word goes out that Ivanka or her husband, Jared Kushner (above), had his ear. When he doesn't, word goes out that it wasn't their fault, that they can do only so much and that if they hadn't valiantly moved to Washington, well, think about how much worse off we'd all be.

site_title: Ex-finance minister Osborne named London Standard editor
summary: Former British finance minister George Osborne, 45, has been appointed as the new editor of The London Evening Standard newspaper, taking over from an unspecified predecessor. Osborne, a conservative lawmaker, expressed his goal to make the paper "the definitive voice of the world's most exciting city" and will work four days a week. He previously served as chancellor of the Exchequer under David Cameron's government and was a prominent Remain campaigner in the EU referendum. The appointment has raised concerns about media independence, with Labour's Jeremy Corbyn's spokesman calling it "another example of the establishment revolving door".

site_title: French fund managers sanguine despite election risk
summary: French fund managers, who oversee $3 trillion, are optimistic about the outcome of France's presidential election despite concerns about Marine Le Pen's potential win. They believe a moderate candidate will prevail, and investors should focus on fundamentals like the country's economic recovery and corporate results. Polls show Le Pen losing in the second round, and global investors have withdrawn $113 billion from European funds last year, with only $1.3 billion added so far this year. Fund managers, including Amundi, AXA Investment Managers, and La Francaise, are overweight European stocks and expect a relief rally once the election is over.

site_title: Hong Kong's richest men prove resilient against property curbs
summary: Hong Kong's billionaire property tycoons, including Li Ka-shing and Lee Shau Kee, have weathered the city's real estate curbs, with property stocks and their wealth recovering. Despite a short-lived dip in November, the billionaires' fortunes have bounced back. The resilience of these individuals suggests they are well-equipped to navigate the city's property market, regardless of the incoming chief executive's stance on reining in soaring home prices.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's property market has defied any attempts to cool prices, despite a raft of measures to bring them down.

site_title: China blocks Pinterest: censorship watchdogs
summary: Pinterest has been blocked in mainland China since last Thursday, joining other social media platforms such as Instagram, Twitter, and Facebook. The move is part of China's strict internet censorship, with the ruling Communist party controlling a vast network of controls known as the Great Firewall of China. Pinterest, popular among women for non-political subjects, has been unavailable due to users maintaining boards on sensitive topics, including human rights and the Senkakus. The blockage affects an estimated 731 million internet users in China.

site_title: Kimly's IPO 8.3 times subscribed
summary: Kimly's Catalist IPO has been subscribed 8.3 times, exceeding its target of S$40 million. The company had offered 173.8 million new shares at S$0.25 apiece. Shares will begin trading on Monday.

site_title: SWIFT cuts off last North Korean banks from global finance system
summary: SWIFT, the inter-bank money transfer system, has cut off the last North Korean banks from the global finance system due to international pressure over its nuclear and ballistic missile programs. This move further isolates the country, which already faces heavy sanctions. US Secretary of State Max Tillerson warned that the North's ambitions must be halted and all options, including military action, remain on the table.

site_title: US industrial output in February flat, manufacturing gains
summary: US industrial output remained flat in February, despite a sixth consecutive increase in manufacturing, due to unseasonably warm weather. Manufacturing output rose 0.5% and mining output increased 2.7%, but utilities output fell 5.7% as demand for heating declined. This offset gains, keeping the overall Industrial Production index unchanged. Industrial capacity in use slipped to 75.4%, in line with analyst forecasts.

site_title: Singapore tops in 2016 cross-border student housing deals
summary: Singapore topped the list of cross-border investors in student housing assets globally in 2016, with US$3.3 billion invested, largely driven by GIC's massive investment in the sector. GIC's US$1.6 billion purchase of student housing portfolios in the US further solidified its position, bringing its investment to nearly US$3 billion in less than a year.

site_title: In sound and music, this modern life unravels
summary: In Singapore, music and sounds are intertwined with the city, defining its character and identity. A design festival, SingaPlural, showcased unique leitmotifs collected from various sources, including MRT announcements and street vendors. Music serves as a mnemonic tool, evoking memories and emotions, and provides solace in a chaotic urban life. Local songwriters have also contributed to the city's musical narrative, with songs addressing themes of identity, nostalgia, and the human experience. Music offers a respite from the stresses of modern life, allowing individuals to connect with their past, present, and future on their own terms.

site_title: NODX up 21.5% in February, the biggest rise in 5 years
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 21.5% year-on-year in February, the largest rise in five years, beating market expectations. The expansion, driven by electronics exports, is expected to continue by some economists, but may moderate by mid-year. Despite differing forecasts, all private-sector economists warn that trade protectionism could derail the recovery. NODX shipments to top markets, including China, the EU, and Taiwan, rose significantly, with non-monetary gold exports contributing to the growth.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 21.5 per cent year-on-year in February, beating market expectations and expanding for a fourth straight month.

site_title: Chinese tycoon becomes substantial unitholder in OUE Commercial Reit
summary: Chinese tycoon Gordon Tang has become a substantial shareholder in OUE Commercial Reit, owning 7.68% of the company after a private placement. This increase follows a regulatory filing on Friday. Tang, who heads property developer Singhaiyi Group, initially held a 4.88% stake. The raised stake is a result of the private placement, and Tang's involvement with OUE Commercial Reit dates back to its 2014 listing.

site_title: Asia's Finest
summary: Asia is gaining traction as a culinary destination, with the recent Asia's 50 Best Restaurants awards ceremony in Bangkok highlighting the region's growing fine dining scene. Chefs from Singapore, Hong Kong, Thailand, and Taiwan praised the diversity and range of Asian cuisine, with many citing the need for a unique definition of fine dining that reflects the region's cultural heritage. Experts argue that the transition from street food to fine dining requires a focus on using local produce, traditional techniques, and storytelling behind the cuisine. With the addition of Michelin guides in Asia, the region is expected to continue gaining international recognition, with chefs and restaurateurs embracing the opportunity to showcase their unique culinary traditions and experiences.

site_title: Grab to start new service with surge pricing for taxi companies
summary: Grab is introducing a dynamic fixed fare option for taxi services in Singapore, allowing fares to fluctuate based on real-time demand and supply. This comes as ComfortDelGro, Singapore's largest taxi company, will not introduce surge pricing for now, instead offering a flat-fare option based on its metered-fare structure. The new scheme will be available next week, providing commuters with upfront pricing before booking a ride.

site_title: S&P cuts troubled Toshiba's credit rating
summary: Standard & Poor's cut Toshiba's credit rating to 'CCC-' due to deteriorating finances, citing huge losses at its US nuclear unit. The downgrade warns of a growing likelihood that Toshiba will struggle to meet its financial obligations or undertake a debt restructuring. Toshiba's multi-billion-dollar losses are expected to multiply, increasing uncertainty about its prospects for restructuring and bank support. The company's shares have lost over half their value this year, and it faces the prospect of being delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

site_title: Keppel T&T sells stake in Asia Airfreight Terminal Co for HK$250m
summary: Keppel T&T has sold its 10% stake in Asia Airfreight Terminal Co for HK$250 million to Holistic Capital Investment, a unit of Hong Kong Airlines. The company plans to use the proceeds to pursue growth opportunities in its core businesses, including data centers and logistics. This sale aligns with Keppel T&T's strategy to divest non-core assets and recycle capital.

site_title: StarHub unveils S$250m innovation, operations centre
summary: StarHub has unveiled a new S$250m innovation and operations centre, Hubtricity, in Singapore. The 58,000 sq ft facility aims to accelerate service innovation and co-creation between StarHub and partners and customers in emerging technologies such as smart homes and virtual reality.

site_title: M1 shareholders exploring stake sale: SPH

The fines range from 15.4 million euros for Martinair to 182.9 million euros for Air France, with British Airways and KLM also facing significant penalties. The Commission deemed the airlines' actions as "working together in a cartel rather than competing to offer better services to customers."

summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's flagship airline, has pledged to slash staff costs by 30% as part of a major overhaul to repair its bottom line. site_title: Singapore shares finish higher; STI up 1.1% for week thanks to FOMC, telco play
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore rose 1.1% for the week, ending at 3,169.38, thanks to a relief rally following the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, which announced an interest-rate hike and guidance on future hikes. This, combined with a downgraded US GDP forecast, contributed to the market's positive sentiment. The telco sector saw a significant push, with M1's strategic review report driving gains, and investors remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Apple plans two more Chinese research hubs as iPhone sales slow
summary: Apple plans to establish two more research centers in China, along with existing facilities in Beijing and Shenzhen, to boost investment and cooperation with local partners. The new centers will help attract talent and enhance research capabilities. The announcement comes as iPhone sales slow in the Chinese market, where local rivals such as Huawei and Oppo are gaining ground. Apple aims to counter this trend with the release of its 10th-anniversary iPhone later this year. The company will spend at least 3.5 billion yuan on research institutions.

site_title: Japan court rules government liable over Fukushima
summary: A Japanese court ruled that Tokyo Electric Power (Tepco) and the government are liable for negligence in the Fukushima nuclear disaster, with the first-ever judgment holding the government accountable for the emotional distress caused by the evacuation of 137 residents. The ruling comes after courts have previously awarded damages, but this is the first time a court has recognized the government's liability.

site_title: Taxi companies get green light to implement dynamic pricing system
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Public Transport Council (PTC) have given taxi companies the green light to implement dynamic pricing, also known as surge pricing, where fares vary according to passenger demand. This system aims to manage supply and demand in the taxi market. The LTA and PTC have "no objections" to the proposals put forth by cab operators, paving the way for the introduction of dynamic pricing in Singapore's taxi industry.

site_title: HK stocks close week with gain; China sinks
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a 0.09% gain, closing at 24,309.93. This follows a previous day's rally, despite concerns over US tax reform and spending plans. In contrast, China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.96%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.81%. The mixed performance was attributed to global market uncertainty and the ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Germany has no plan to sell Deutsche Telekom shares
summary: Germany's finance ministry denied a report that the government plans to sell shares in Deutsche Telekom, stating that all holdings are under review but no sale is planned. The German government holds 14.5% of Deutsche Telekom directly and 17.5% through the KfW development bank. Shares in Deutsche Telekom fell 0.5% after the report, underperforming the DAX index.

images.alt_text: The German finance ministry rejected a magazine report on Friday that the government plans to sell shares in Deutsche Telekom.

site_title: No surge pricing now, but a flat-fare structure similar to metered fares soon: ComfortDelGro
summary: Singapore's largest taxi company, ComfortDelGro, will introduce a flat-fare structure similar to metered fares in two to three weeks for mobile app users, but will not implement surge pricing. This comes as Singapore's third-largest taxi company, SMRT, plans to introduce surge pricing, which incorporates real-time demand and supply into its fare structure. SMRT has partnered with Grab to implement the dynamic-pricing system, which will display fares upfront to users. The decision allows ComfortDelGro to differentiate itself from SMRT and introduce a flat-fare option before considering surge pricing.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters jailed for 3 years for anti-China clashes
summary: Three Hong Kong protesters were jailed for three years on "riot" charges for their part in anti-China protests in 2016, amidst tensions ahead of a vote for the city's next leader. The protesters hurled glass bottles and bamboo poles at officers during clashes in Mong Kok. The sentencing marked the harshest punishment handed down to those involved in the "fishball revolution," which reflected underlying tensions over the erosion of Hong Kong's traditions.

site_title: Britain's PM faces party faithful after bruising week
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces a challenging week after her Brexit honeymoon ended, with her party faithful rallying around her. She must navigate a complex Brexit process, Scottish independence, and internal party divisions. May's government has faced criticism over its handling of Brexit and a recent U-turn on a tax rise, with some questioning her ability to deliver a "brighter future" for the UK. The Conservative Party's slim majority in the House of Commons also raises concerns about her leadership.

Merkel's cautious approach comes after Trump criticized her refugee policies and called for increased defense spending, a sensitive issue for Germany. site_title: Airbus probed by French authorities as UK fraud case widens

site_title: First fluorescent frog found in Argentina
summary: Scientists in Argentina discovered the first naturally fluorescent frog, found among a tree-frog species common to South America. The frog's skin glows a celestial green under ultraviolet light, a trait previously unknown in amphibians. Researchers studied 200 more specimens to confirm the phenomenon, which is common in aquatic species and some insects. The discovery "radically modifies what is known about fluorescence" and may have scientific or technological applications, generating new questions about visual communication in amphibians.

summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 21.5% year-on-year in February, driven by increases in electronic and non-electronic shipments. Authorities praised the teacher's heroic actions, which they believe may have prevented more harm.

site_title: Somali pirates release captured oil tanker, hostages: NGO
summary: Somali pirates released an oil tanker and eight Sri Lankan hostages just days after capturing the vessel, the Oceans Beyond Piracy NGO reported. The ship, Aris 13, was seized on Monday while en route from Djibouti to Mogadishu. After negotiations led by former British army officer John Steed, the pirates agreed to release the vessel and hostages, and the ship was freed by the Puntland maritime police force. The release occurred just hours after the coastguard threatened to use force if negotiations failed.

site_title: China tech, Internet deals driving up valuations

site_title: Low-cost, low-tech Southwest carrier pays big bucks to fly high
summary: Southwest Airlines, known for its low-cost, low-tech operations, is investing US$300 million to upgrade its airport ramp and operations. The airline will introduce new technology, including tablets for mechanics and electronic transmissions, to improve efficiency and reduce costs. The upgrades aim to boost earnings by US$100 million annually by 2020 and will replace 30-year-old technology. The changes reflect the airline's growing complexity, with added expenses from labour contracts and expanded international services. Southwest's efforts aim to catch up with industry innovations and improve scalability for future services.

site_title: Germany, China stand up for free trade before Trump-Merkel talks
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Chinese President Xi Jinping reaffirmed their support for free trade and open markets in a phone call, hours before Merkel's meeting with US President Donald Trump in Washington. The call underscores a partnership between the world's top exporters, which has gained significance since the US election. Merkel's meeting with Trump aims to address concerns about a US shift toward protectionism, while China and Germany stand together to defend open global markets.

images.alt_text: Germany and China vowed to defend open global markets, a day before German Chancellor Angela Merkel plans to meet President Donald Trump in Washington to discuss concern about a US shift toward protectionism.

site_title: US$ down as Fed disappoints hawkish traders

Investors now look to US fiscal policy and the European Central Bank for direction.

site_title: Japan minister agrees to share Toshiba case information with US: Kyodo
summary: Japan's Industry Minister Hiroshige Seko agreed to share information about Toshiba's US nuclear affiliate Westinghouse Electric Co with US Energy Secretary Rick Perry and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. site_title: US: Stocks pressured as oil rally fizzles
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as a rally in oil prices fizzled and concerns about legislative priorities in Washington pressured sentiment. site_title: Fillon to be probed over clothing gifts: judicial source

site_title: Chun Sing calls for network effect in payment system
summary: Singapore Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of achieving a network effect in the country's payment system, rather than focusing on which payment system is better. He urged businesses to explore partnerships to bring various payment platforms together, making the system more valuable when more people use it. This will enable a unified system backed by high trust in the Singapore brand, breaking into the larger South-east Asia market. The government aims to achieve this within a short timeframe, with the goal of lowering costs and creating better quality jobs for Singaporeans.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks extend gains at open

Despite this, Trump has made some early successes, such as appointing outsiders to his inner circle, improving the stock market, and keeping his word on several commitments. site_title: Australia govt may invest A$2b to solve energy crisis

site_title: Airbus says British corruption probe extended to France
summary: Airbus has confirmed that a British corruption probe into alleged fraud, bribery, and corruption has been extended to France. images.alt_text: They say when one door closes, another opens. In the case of Prudential and Aviva, they might have had doors slammed in their faces last year, but things still panned out, well, not too shabbily considering the circumstances.

site_title: Google ramps up investment in fibre cable, training Africans
summary: Google is increasing investment in Africa by laying fibre optic cable, providing cheaper Android phones, and training digital skills. The company has trained about 1 million people in Nigeria, Kenya, and South Africa over the past year, but faces challenges due to unreliable internet coverage and high data prices. Google aims to boost connectivity to open up a new market for smartphones and services, with plans to train small businesses in web-focused skills. Facebook and other US competitors also seek to expand connectivity in the continent.

site_title: Top NYC rents need to fall 15% to absorb glut
summary: New York apartment rents need to fall by 15% to absorb the glut of high-end developments. Billionaire real estate investor Richard LeFrak stated that there's a huge demand for affordable product, citing a 26% share of concessions offered on new leases. This comes as landlords are already feeling the pinch with a 3.3% average rent cut in February, the first across-the-board decline in four years. LeFrak's comments come as the US government considers a $1 trillion infrastructure spending plan, which he is set to help spearhead.

site_title: Euro, Dutch stock markets rise as Geert Wilders' far-right PVV falls
summary: Dutch voters re-elected Prime Minister Mark Rutte's centre-right VVD party, winning 33 seats with 21% of the total MPs, despite Geert Wilders' far-right PVV party gaining five seats. The PVV's 13% of seats is a significant increase, but not enough to take power. The euro and Dutch stock market rallied in relief, with the euro up 3% against the US dollar and the Dutch market up 4%. The result was seen as a victory against extremism and a boost to the European Union, with leaders praising Rutte's openness and commitment to Europe.

site_title: An unmeaningful comparison
summary: A letter to the editor from Karen Ting, partner at August Consulting, criticizes the comparison of Kimly Limited's pro forma numbers with its audited numbers in a recent article. The comparison is deemed meaningless due to the company's restructuring exercise, which swapped minority interests for a stake in the listed company, altering the net attributable profit. Ting requests that the article refrain from referencing Kimly's audited numbers before restructuring to avoid confusion among readers.

site_title: MAS seeks views on new legal tender limits for coins
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is seeking public feedback on proposed new legal tender limits for coins, including a uniform limit of ten coins per denomination per transaction. The existing limits range from $2 to $10 per coin, and the review was prompted by two high-profile incidents involving large coin payments. The public consultation will last until April 6, 2017, and can be found on the MAS website. The goal is to minimize payee inconvenience and cost in handling large quantities of low denomination currency.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is seeking public feedback on its proposed new legal tender limit for coins.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook adds Aussie power firm to property, jewellery
summary: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises Ltd, a Hong Kong conglomerate, agreed to acquire Alinta Energy Holdings Ltd, an Australian power firm, in a multi-billion dollar deal. The transaction marks Chow Tai Fook's entry into the Australian utilities sector. Financial details of the deal were not disclosed, but it is reportedly valued over A$4 billion (S$4.3 billion). The acquisition will give Chow Tai Fook a presence in Australia's energy retailing market through power generation for industrial customers.

site_title: Tokyo Stock Exchange launches index of small-cap firms to cater to investors
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) has launched a new index of 200 small-to-mid-cap firms with high return on equity and operating profits, catering to growing investor interest in small company stocks. The JPX-Nikkei Mid and Small-Cap Index has an average return on equity of 18.2% over the past three years, outperforming larger shares. This launch comes as investors have avoided large-cap shares due to sensitivity to the yen and market volatility, with Japan's Nikkei Jasdaq Index experiencing its longest positive run since 2004.

site_title: 'Dutch Trump' loses in Netherlands election
summary: The Netherlands held a high-profile election, with Prime Minister Mark Rutte's centre-right VVD party emerging as the largest party. Geert Wilders' far-right Freedom Party, dubbed "Dutch Trump," led in polls but slipped to fifth place. The election saw a record turnout of 80% and was influenced by the diplomatic stand-off between Turkey and the Netherlands. Wilders' nativist platform and rhetoric on immigration and Islam may have contributed to his growing support, despite his party failing to become the largest single group. The election's outcome may have significant consequences for Dutch politics, with Wilders likely to remain a major player despite never becoming prime minister.

images.alt_text: Mr Wilders' nativist platform is similar to other populist, far-right leaders across Europe.

site_title: Teacher-student comedy scores an "A"
summary: The Necessary Stage's play "Those Who Can't, Teach" has been revived to critical acclaim, showcasing a refreshingly honest portrayal of teachers' burdens and challenges. The comedy-drama follows the lives of teachers and students at Marine Parade Secondary School, tackling topics such as demanding parents, school administrators, and the complexities of teaching. Directed by Alvin Tan and written by Haresh Sharma, the play is praised for its humor, humanity, and crowd-pleasing performances, resonating with both audiences and teenagers in the audience.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: She loves him, she loves him not
summary: Constellations, a play by Nick Payne, premiered in Singapore with Stephanie Street and Edward Harrison, but failed to impress critics. The play, which explores the concept of a multiverse and multiple possible outcomes of relationships, was deemed unsatisfying and non-committal due to its short, snippety scenes. Despite assured performances from the cast, the production design was criticized as plain and bare. The main issue lies with Payne's script, which fails to provide genuine engagement and catharsis, leaving the audience feeling underwhelmed.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Fed-inspired relief rally sends Hang Seng, STI to 19-month highs
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its short-term interest rates by 25 basis points to 0.75% and signaled two more hikes this year, sparking a relief rally in regional stocks. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 2.1% to a 19-month high, while Singapore's Straits Times Index also hit a 19-month high. The Dow futures suggested a firm follow-through for Wall Street. Analysts attributed the Fed's decision to a desire for clarity on fiscal stimulus and a potential slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: Clever satirical take on the horror genre
summary: Get Out, the directorial debut of Jordan Peele, is a satirical horror film that reinvents the slasher genre with a fresh spin. The movie follows Chris, an African-American photographer, as he visits his white girlfriend's family, only to discover a sinister plot. The film doubles as a subversive social satire about race, using Chris's skin color as a crucial plot device. With its original and smart approach, Get Out has become one of the year's most original and intelligent films, despite some graphic violence in the final half hour.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Impending hike in water prices is actually a good eye opener
summary: Singapore is set to raise water prices by 30% over two years, sparking controversy and protests. Despite the government's rationale for the price increase, citing rising costs and projected demand, many are upset about the sudden hike. The majority of households will receive rebates, but three-quarters will see net increases of less than $12. The government has acknowledged that the price hike is necessary due to rising costs and projected demand, but critics argue that it is a bad time to raise prices amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: Security flaw found in WhatsApp, Telegram: software firm
summary: A security firm, Check Point, revealed a flaw in WhatsApp and Telegram's encryption, allowing hackers to break into accounts using innocent-looking photos. The vulnerability posed a risk to hundreds of millions of users accessing the messaging platforms from web browsers. Hackers could gain control over accounts, access message history, and send messages on behalf of the user. Both services shifted to finding and blocking viruses before messages are encrypted to remedy the situation.

site_title: S'pore 'heartened' TPP members looking to preserve pact benefits
summary: Singapore is "heartened" by the TPP members' commitment to preserving the pact's benefits despite the US withdrawal. The 11 remaining members, including Singapore, met in Chile to discuss how to maintain momentum and explore options to preserve the pact's gains. Senior trade officials will meet again before the Apec meeting in May to discuss a way forward. Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that Singapore would sign the pact if there is a consensus among the remaining nations, but only if a consensus is reached.

site_title: Fed delivers a hike and a subtle message
summary: The Federal Reserve increased its benchmark interest rates by a quarter-point, marking the third hike in over 10 years. The central bank also signaled a shift towards a more strategic and less tactical approach, focusing on domestic and international factors influencing the economic outlook. The Fed highlighted improving business sentiment, labor market strength, and inflation towards its 2% target, with expected future rate hikes and a continued large balance sheet inventory. The move is seen as a step towards policy normalization, but the Fed acknowledges the need for other policymaking entities, such as fiscal and trade authorities, to step up and use their tools effectively.

site_title: 3 gold-mining stocks average 3.2% YTD return
summary: Three Singapore gold mining stocks - CNMC Goldmine Holdings, Wilton Resources Corporation, and Anchor Resources - averaged a 3.2% total return in 2017 year-to-date, with Wilton Resources being the strongest performer with a 12.1% return. Wilton's concession blocks in Indonesia's West Java province are set to expand production and reduce costs. CNMC Goldmine aims to increase production and minimize costs, while Anchor Resources expects gold prices to fluctuate based on global economy and interest rates.

site_title: Haute at the Cookhouse
summary: Jean-Georges Vongerichten's Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar offers world-class cooking at affordable prices. The restaurant serves a greatest hits collection of his restaurants, with dishes like toasted egg yolk caviar, black pepper crab dumpling, and spring pea soup. While some main courses, such as braised short rib and spice-crusted John Dory, are underwhelming, others like roast cod and assorted pizza toppings are well-balanced. Desserts, including the signature warm chocolate cake and salted caramel ice-cream sundae, are standouts. With attentive service and a focus on quality, Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar is a solid new entrant to the dining scene. Rating: 7.5.

site_title: Art as shaped by a city's playgrounds
summary: Artist Julia Jacquette's new book, "Playground of My Mind," explores her childhood in 1970s New York City, where she witnessed the city's playground renaissance. The playgrounds, designed by architects like Paul Friedberg and Richard Dattner, were innovative, with linked play areas and no one "correct" way for children to interact. Jacquette's art, which often features commercial products and media images, was influenced by these playgrounds' use of repetition and grids. Her book and accompanying exhibition at the Wellin Museum of Art in New York, which include her paintings and gouache originals, prompt questions about how childhood play shapes adult identity.

site_title: Federal judges block Trump's revamped travel ban
summary: Federal judges have blocked US President Donald Trump's revised travel ban, halting the 90-day ban on entry by nationals of six Muslim-majority countries and a 120-day suspension of the US refugee admissions programme. Two US District Judges ruled that the ban would cause "irreparable injury" and discriminates against Muslims. Trump vowed to fight the ruling in the Supreme Court, but the court in Honolulu indicated it would not stay its decision, meaning the ban cannot go ahead as planned.

site_title: Does ARA's delisting via a scheme of arrangement make sense?
summary: ARA Asset Management is set to privatize through a scheme of arrangement, with a proposed price of S$1.78 per share. The move aims to raise capital efficiently for the company's growth, as it requires significant funding for strategic investments and acquisitions. The privatisation is seen as a win-win situation for both the company and shareholders, allowing ARA to operate more efficiently and giving investors an opportunity to exit at a fair price. However, some shareholders may feel that they are being deprived of the opportunity to participate in the company's long-term growth.

site_title: STI hits 19-month high on Fed signal
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 26.09 points, or 0.8%, to 3,163.52, its highest closing in about 19 months, after the US Federal Reserve raised its short-term rate by 25 basis points without signaling more than two more hikes this year. Heavy turnover of 2.7 billion shares, fueled by optimism over the Fed's signal, lifted shares. Analysts expect the Fed to deliver a faster pace of tightening, with seven rate hikes by the end of 2018, potentially boosting markets.

site_title: Luxury on wheels
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The article highlights five luxury train journeys that offer unparalleled service and luxuries. The Eastern & Oriental Express travels from Singapore to Thailand, while the Blue Train in South Africa offers a 5-star experience between Cape Town and Pretoria. The Seven Stars train in Japan provides exceptional service and stunning views of Kyushu, and the Maharajas' Express in India offers a royal treatment with multiple dining options and personalized butlers. The Ghan train in Australia runs from Adelaide to Darwin, offering luxurious accommodations and excursions along the way, including helicopter flights and boat cruises.

site_title: Chinese expose TV show pares 30b yuan off Japanese shares
summary: A Chinese state-run TV show, "3.15 Gala", exposed Japanese companies Ryohin Keikaku Co and Calbee Inc for selling mislabeled products, including foods, to China. The show claimed Ryohin Keikaku sold products with ingredients from areas banned in China due to radiation contamination. The companies' shares fell, with Ryohin Keikaku's dropping as much as 4.3% and Calbee's falling 4.3% as well. The show's criticism reflects growing scrutiny of foreign companies in China, with Chinese consumers empowered by the internet and higher expectations.

site_title: Richard Li endorses Carrie Lam as next HK chief exec
summary: Hong Kong telecommunications tycoon Richard Li has endorsed Carrie Lam as the next Hong Kong chief executive, citing her track record and alignment with China's central government requirements. This move may have been intended to quell speculation about his family's support for other candidates, particularly John Tsang. Li's endorsement is seen as a strategic move to protect his family's business interests, but it may not necessarily influence other members of the Election Committee. Lam is widely seen as Beijing's preferred candidate, despite trailing Tsang in popular opinion polls.

site_title: Euronet Worldwide trumps Ant Financial's offer to buy MoneyGram
summary: Euronet Worldwide has outbid Ant Financial's offer to acquire MoneyGram International Inc for $1 billion, citing less regulatory scrutiny. Ant Financial, affiliated with Alibaba Group, remains committed to its deal but has not changed its bid of $13.25 per share. The move could enable Euronet to better compete against digital startups in the global remittance market. A Euronet deal would also avoid US inter-agency clearance, a hurdle for Ant Financial.

site_title: Over S$200m 'stolen from Indonesian ID project'
summary: Indonesia's corruption watchdog, the KPK, has identified nearly 40 suspects, including ministers, in a massive graft case involving the country's identity card program. The program, meant to replace outdated ID cards, has been marred by corruption, with roughly half of the initial S$550 million budget allegedly stolen. The KPK has interviewed over 280 witnesses and is building a case against current and former officials, potentially including Law and Human Rights minister Yasonna Laoly and Speaker of Parliament Setya Novanto. The scandal could have a significant impact on Indonesian politics, potentially exposing widespread corruption and prompting a political earthquake.

site_title: Societe Generale turns to cloud computing
summary: Societe Generale, a Paris-based bank, is working with Microsoft and Amazon to adopt cloud computing for its operations, aiming to have 80% of its infrastructure on internal and external cloud networks by 2020. The bank will start using external cloud services by June for non-client content, such as financial research and marketing data. This move is part of a trend among European banks to shift towards cloud computing to cut costs and improve efficiency, with regulatory concerns no longer a major obstacle.

site_title: Singapore to host ICC from this year till 2020
summary: Singapore has been confirmed to host the International Champions Cup (ICC) football tournament for four consecutive years from 2017 to 2020, with the first edition taking place this July at the Sports Hub.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Plenty of Disney magic in live-action remake
summary: The live-action remake of Disney's Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon, offers a visually enchanting and faithful adaptation of the classic tale. The film features an interracial screen kiss, an openly homosexual character, and four new songs written by Alan Menken and Tim Rice. Emma Watson shines as headstrong Belle, and Dan Stevens brings kindness to the Beast. The movie blends old and new elements, resulting in a magical and engaging experience.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Marks of good design
summary: The Design Business Chamber Singapore (DBCS) has awarded 36 products and solutions with the Singapore Good Design Mark (SG Mark), recognizing their holistic design practices that enhance lives. This year's winners include innovative designs such as the Oasia Hotel Downtown's green facade, the AIRMOTION Mask for air pollution protection, and the OCBC One Wealth mobile app for simplified investment management. The SG Mark aims to promote design for innovation and competitiveness, raising professional design standards and increasing awareness of good design among businesses, designers, and the public.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Romance in Canadian Rockies
summary: The Canadian Rockies, particularly Banff and Lake Louise, are ideal for a romantic getaway. Options include a private helicopter ride with a champagne toast, dog sledding through snow-covered landscapes, a meal at the Five-Diamond rated Eden Restaurant, and a stay at the luxury Fairmont Chateau Lake Louise. These activities offer a mix of adventure, scenic beauty, and relaxation, making the Rockies a top choice for couples seeking a romantic escape. With its stunning natural surroundings, luxurious accommodations, and range of activities, the Canadian Rockies are sure to leave a lasting impression.

site_title: Letter bomb at IMF's Paris office injures employee
summary: A female IMF employee was injured in the face and arms after a homemade letter bomb exploded at the organization's Paris office. The explosion was not linked to recent telephone threats, and the woman's life was not in danger. France is still in a state of emergency following recent attacks by Islamist groups, and the IMF has condemned the incident as a "cowardly act of violence". The IMF has pledged to investigate and ensure staff safety.

site_title: What keeps Asia CEOs awake at night
summary: Asian CEOs cite three main challenges impacting their organisations' success: market factors, people issues, and product/service innovation. To drive business success, CEOs are focusing on creating a competitive advantage through people, delivering a differentiated work experience, and building an agile organisation through analytics. Key findings include: 70% of Fortune 1000 companies have disappeared in the last 70 years, 63% of CEOs cite critical skills shortage, and 65% of Best Employers have a clearly articulated employer brand. CEOs are investing in digital platforms and analytics to create a differentiated work experience and make informed decisions on people and organisation investments.

site_title: Noble ends flat after initial fall over share consolidation
summary: Noble Group's proposed share consolidation of 10 shares into one sparked a 9% initial drop in its stock price to S$0.191, but recovered to close unchanged at S$0.21. The move was intended to curb speculative activity and improve liquidity, with traders seemingly overreacting to the announcement. Despite the initial volatility, the stock's value remained stable after the consolidation.

site_title: Singapore sees slowest start to M&A activity in four years
summary: Singapore's mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity saw its slowest start in four years, with Q1 deals totaling US$7.7 billion, a 21% decline from the previous year. Despite a 38% decrease in announced deals, the average deal size increased to US$88.1 million. The property sector led the market share, accounting for 41.9% of the value, with energy and power sectors also showing growth. Private equity-backed M&A declined by 90.1%, while inbound M&A fell 40%, its lowest since 2013.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Fed's cautious tone a reprieve for rate-sensitive sectors, commodities
summary: The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 0.75-1% in a surprise move that left its "dot plot" unchanged. US stocks rose, Treasury yields fell, and the dollar plummeted as investors breathed a sigh of relief that the central bank was not becoming more aggressive with its interest rate plans. The move was seen as a cautious tone, providing a reprieve for rate-sensitive sectors and commodities. The Fed anticipates two more hikes this year.

images.alt_text: Ms Yellen said the central bank would have to wait and see what the fiscal and tax policies are before making any necessary amendments to monetary policy.

site_title: Doubts over whether US reflation boost will lift S'pore banks
summary: US interest rate hikes have sparked doubts about whether Singapore banks will benefit from the reflation boost. Despite the Federal Reserve's 25 basis point rate hike, analysts note heightened competition for top-tier customers and uncertainty over future rate hikes. Jefferies believes Singapore's domestic rates will stay low due to weak private consumption and high leverage, while Fitch Ratings expects seven more rate hikes in 2017 and 2018. Some analysts, including Citi, remain positive on Singapore banks, citing a multi-year theme of global interest rate normalization.

site_title: Penang ups landed property threshold
summary: The Penang state government has set a new threshold for landed property purchases on Penang Island, restricting foreign buyers to properties priced at RM3 million (S$951,600) or less. The previous threshold was RM2 million, set in 2015. The move aims to safeguard local interests amid concerns that Malaysians are being priced out of the housing market. The state government has also halved the foreign levy for properties priced between RM1-1.5 million.

site_title: Top bank executives expose pay myths in Scandinavian example
summary: Top bank executives in the Nordic region, including CEOs of Nordea and Danske Bank, earned significantly lower salaries compared to their European counterparts, despite their banks' strong performance. The executives' total pay packages fell into the bottom third of pay rankings, with the best-paid Nordic bankers earning less than their counterparts in Greece, Cyprus, Spain, and the UK. The Scandinavian experience may lead to a reevaluation of bonus pools for bankers in the region, with the European Banking Authority suggesting that remuneration packages can influence risk-taking behavior.

site_title: Hire more workers, Trump tells US carmakers
summary: US President Donald Trump has told the CEOs of General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles that carmakers must hire more workers in exchange for a review of the Obama administration's fuel and economy rules. Trump's demand comes after the Obama administration's decision to preserve fuel economy rules, which Trump claims would have destroyed the auto industry. The companies will now get another year to dispute the rules, and Trump has vowed to eliminate industry-killing regulations and lower job-crushing taxes. In return, carmakers have promised to add jobs and invest in new plants, with GM announcing 220 new jobs in Michigan.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump speaking to auto workers at the American Center for Mobility on Wednesday in Ypsilanti, Michigan. He wants carmakers to build new plants and expand their existing plants in the US.

site_title: Tesla seeks U$1.15b to help fuel Model 3 launch
summary: Tesla plans to raise $1.15 billion in new funding to fuel production of its mass market-targeted Model 3 electric car, set for release this year. The company will offer $250 million in common stock and $750 million in convertible notes. Elon Musk will invest $25 million of the new shares. The funding will be used to strengthen Tesla's balance sheet, reduce risks, and support production ramp-up to 5,000 vehicles weekly by the end of the year.

site_title: PE firm Navis eyeing light industry in Singapore
summary: Navis Capital Partners, a South-east Asian private equity firm, is eyeing light industry companies in Singapore. The firm generally invests around $100 million in companies valued at $200 million, avoiding real estate and technology firms. Navis has invested in 10 Singapore companies since 2009, often partnering with founders to maintain a 20-40% stake. The firm sees opportunities in small and medium-size enterprise industrial firms facing challenges, and is actively investing its seventh $1.5-billion fund, which is expected to see more privatisations in Singapore due to macro uncertainties.

site_title: Meitu CEO becomes firm's second billionaire as stock surges
summary: Meitu Inc's CEO Wu Xinhong became the firm's second billionaire as the company's stock surged 5.6% to a record high, extending its 11% gain since its December debut. The stock's addition to a Hong Kong trading link led to Wu's net worth of US$1.1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. This marks the longest winning streak since the company's listing.

site_title: S'pore's carbon tax not enough to encourage energy efficiency
summary: Singapore's carbon tax, implemented from 2019, is seen as a good first step towards a carbon-free future but may not be enough to encourage energy efficiency in the transport sector. Royal Dutch Shell's downstream director John Abbott stated that a carbon price alone is not sufficient and that fiscal incentives or infrastructure investments are needed. Shell is keen to work with the Singapore government to de-carbonize the transport sector, with a focus on cleaner energy sources such as biofuels, liquefied natural gas, and hydrogen.

site_title: Glaxo to pay first female CEO less than male predecessor
summary: GlaxoSmithKline's new CEO, Emma Walmsley, will earn about a quarter less than her predecessor Andrew Witty, with an annual base salary of £1 million (S$1.7 million) compared to £1.15 million. The decision reflects her lack of experience as the first female CEO of a top 25 pharmaceutical company. This move has sparked debate on the pay gap between the sexes, with some experts suggesting it's a good opportunity to reassess executive pay structures.

site_title: Movies have to offer more than just storylines
summary: Movie theatres are evolving to incorporate new technologies, such as Virtual Reality (VR), to create immersive experiences. The Sundance Film Festival showcased nearly 50 VR projects, highlighting the growing industry's potential. Immersive storytelling and interactivity are now essential elements of entertainment. To succeed in VR, filmmakers must focus on creating immersive worlds rather than traditional storylines. Despite being off to a slow start, VR is gaining traction, particularly in Asia, where affordable options are becoming more accessible, paving the way for mass consumer adoption.

site_title: Dance drama with all the right moves
summary: The Japanese teen comedy "Let's Go, Jets" tells the true story of a group of high school girls who defy expectations by becoming international cheer-dancing champions. Led by 18-year-old Suzu Hirose, the film follows their journey as they form a new cheer dance club and compete in a US competition. With its sassy tone, tight choreography, and uplifting message, the movie is a crowd-pleaser that will charm tweens and fans of dance musicals like "Bring It On" and "Pitch Perfect." The film's formulaic feel-good nature may be predictable, but its charm and enthusiasm make it an enjoyable watch.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Current legislation on stamp duty covers all the bases
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance has proposed legislative changes to treat transactions in residential properties on the same basis, regardless of whether they are transacted directly or through a transfer of equity interest in an entity holding residential properties. The proposed change aims to address the issue of avoidance of stamp duty on such transactions, but critics argue that it may create an anomaly in the longstanding principle of separate legal personality and penalize corporate entities set up for bona fide commercial purposes. The change is seen as a revenue-raising measure, raising concerns about its impact on the country's international standing and credibility.

site_title: CapitaLand said to be eyeing Asia Sq Tower 2
summary: CapitaLand is in exclusive negotiations to acquire Asia Square Tower 2 from BlackRock, with a reported price of over S$2,700 per square foot. The deal would mark the end of BlackRock's sales process for the two-tower development, which was valued at US$3.9 billion when it closed in 2008. BlackRock sold neighboring Tower 1 to Qatar Investment Authority for S$3.4 billion last June, and a plot of land next to Asia Square set a record price for Singapore's government land sales in November 2016.

site_title: US$ steadies after worst fall in 2 months
summary: The US dollar recovered from a one-month low on Thursday after investors bought the currency following a weak statement from the US Federal Reserve on further rate rises. The euro rose 1.2% overnight after Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte won the election, easing concerns about right-wing populists in the eurozone. The dollar index recovered all its losses to stand roughly steady, while the euro and yen also saw gains. Investors are now focusing on the French election risks, which may lead to lower euro prices in the near term.

site_title: Qingdao and Nanjing to impose new property curbs
summary: China's cities Qingdao and Nanjing have implemented new property curbs to curb speculation. Qingdao limits non-residents to one property purchase, requiring at least one year of local taxes or insurance, while Nanjing suspends sales for residents with two homes in the core area. Non-residents in Nanjing must also pay at least two years of taxes and insurance. These measures aim to "mildly guide market expectations" and reduce risks in the local market.

site_title: The pendulum of skillsets swings again . . . and again
summary: The article discusses the shift in skillsets required in the job market, questioning the value of traditional education and the effectiveness of specialized skills. With the rise of new industries such as big data, fintech, and medtech, many skills are no longer embedded in formal education.
