Employers are now looking for workers with adaptable skills, and countries are investing in lifelong learning and employability-skills training. The article concludes that the traditional model of education is being reevaluated, and that a more flexible and adaptable approach to learning is needed to prepare workers for the changing job market.

site_title: Trump slashes foreign aid in 'hard power' budget blueprint
summary: President Donald Trump proposed a budget that prioritizes national security and "hard power" by slashing spending on arts, science, foreign aid, and environmental protection. The proposed budget boosts Pentagon spending by $52 billion, while cutting State Department and EPA funding by around a third. The National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities would be scrapped, and funding for the National Institutes of Health would be cut by almost $6 billion. The budget's focus on security and defense could struggle to pass Congress, with the White House describing it as "a budget that puts America first."

site_title: McDonald's, late to mobile ordering, seeks to avoid pitfalls
summary: McDonald's has begun testing its long-awaited US mobile ordering app, aiming to win back customers after four years of declining traffic. The app, currently being tested at 29 restaurants in California, aims to automate orders, reduce errors, and improve customer experience. If successful, the app will be rolled out to nearly 14,000 US restaurants and international locations by the end of this year. McDonald's is working to address potential kitchen hiccups and improve efficiency, with a focus on ensuring orders are delivered quickly and accurately.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares rose on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 19.780 points to 1,737.140. A total of 3.399 billion lots worth RM3.618 billion were traded, with 666 gainers outnumbering 286 losers.

site_title: The play's the thing, that from Oxford they bring
summary: Shakespeare's First Folio, a rare and valuable publication of his 36 plays, is on display at Singapore's National Library. The folio, compiled by his friends and colleagues in 1623, was published to preserve his work for posterity and was donated to the Bodleian Library and later the National Library. Only 230 copies are believed to have survived, with one copy on display in the exhibition "Shakespeare in Print: The First Folio". The folio features 18 plays that were never printed before and is considered a significant literary artifact.

site_title: China, Saudi Arabia eye US$65b in deals as king visits
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman signed deals worth up to $65 billion in China during his visit, cementing ties with the world's second-largest economy. Deals included a MoU between Saudi Aramco and Norinco to build refining and chemical plants in China, and a joint development of petrochemical projects in China and Saudi Arabia. These agreements are part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy and reduce its dependence on oil exports.

site_title: First SaaS-based predictive platform for life insurers
summary: TEL Aviv-based insurtech company Atidot has launched the first SaaS-based predictive analytics platform for life insurers, enabling real-time premium rate generation and data cleansing. The cloud-based platform uses Big Data modeling and decision-making tools to help insurers make informed decisions, such as policy pricing and client retention. Atidot's system can analyze unlimited data points and create profile groupings of policyholders, allowing insurers to adjust their strategy accordingly. The platform has already been adopted by two life insurers and is set to expand to Asia, with plans for further growth in the US, UK, and South Africa.

site_title: Eat, drink and be merry
summary: Waiheke Island, located off the coast of Auckland, New Zealand, has gained international attention for its wineries and scenic beauty. Travel + Leisure magazine named Waiheke the fourth best island in the world in 2016, and it was also named the top island in Australia, New Zealand, and the South Pacific. The island is home to 30 boutique wineries and vineyards, including Stonyridge and Obsidian, which produce high-quality wines. Visitors can enjoy wine tastings, gourmet dining, and accommodations at elegant inns and luxury lodges, such as The Boatshed and Enclosure Bay, making Waiheke an ideal destination for foodies and wine enthusiasts.

site_title: Museums trying out robots as tour guides
summary: Museums are experimenting with robots as tour guides to make culture more accessible and democratic. The market for telepresence robots is expected to grow from $825 million in 2015 to $7 billion by 2022. Robots like the one tested at the Musée de La Grande Guerre in Meaux, France, allow visitors to remotely pilot a robot to explore exhibits, with the goal of reducing costs and increasing accessibility. The technology is being used to attract visitors and engage with disabled visitors, and is seen as a way to build an international following and foster curiosity and imagination.

site_title: US media firms to offer ad buyers laser-sharp audience targeting
summary: US media firms Time Warner's Turner, Viacom, and 21st Century Fox's Fox Networks Group are launching OpenAP, a program allowing advertisers to target specific audiences on television. The goal is to provide a standardized approach to audience targeting, addressing advertisers' distrust of proprietary measurements. The three companies will sell most of their TV ad inventory for the next year in the upfront market, with a third-party auditor measuring ad runs. OpenAP aims to be widely adopted across the TV universe, with Nielsen planning to provide data support.

site_title: Dutch PM Rutte scores big victory over far-right Wilders
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte secured a resounding victory over far-right leader Geert Wilders in the Netherlands' election, winning 33 of 150 parliamentary seats. Rutte declared it a "stop" to the wrong kind of populism, and his victory offered relief to other European governments facing nationalist challenges. The result is seen as a test of whether the Dutch want to end decades of liberalism, and it may impact France's presidential election and the European Union.

site_title: Singapore medtech firm EndoMaster raises S$20.5m Series B funding
summary: Singapore-based medtech firm EndoMaster raised S$20.5 million in Series B funding, one of the largest for a medtech company in Singapore. The company developed a robotic-assisted surgical system that removes gastro-intestinal cancer tumours without incisions, reducing surgery time to under one hour and complications rate to below 5%. EndoMaster plans to launch its product in Europe in late 2018 and aims to surpass S$100 million in revenue within five years.

site_title: British designer Waight Keller takes over at Givenchy
summary: British designer Clare Waight Keller takes over at Givenchy, the French fashion house, replacing Riccardo Tisci who left in January. Waight Keller, 47, brings her "singular sense of elegance and modernity" to the brand after a six-year stint at Chloe. She is known for her understated style and gift for creating must-have accessories, which may have drawn Givenchy's attention. Waight Keller's appointment comes after Givenchy's turnover rocketed to $536 million during Tisci's 12-year tenure. She previously worked at Pringle of Scotland, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, and Tom Ford at Gucci.

site_title: Dutch leaders begin coalition talks after blow to anti-immigrant populists
summary: Dutch leaders began coalition talks after voters rejected anti-immigrant populist Geert Wilders, who finished second in the election despite his campaign's toxicity. Mainstream parties gained ground, and Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte held onto office despite losing nearly a fifth of his seats. Wilders vowed to continue fighting, but the result may limit his appeal. European leaders now focus on the French presidential election, where Marine Le Pen's anti-immigrant stance may be lessened by Wilders' defeat.

images.alt_text: Dutch leaders on Thursday began the difficult process of forming a ruling coalition, hours after voters dealt a blow to European anti-immigrant populists with a worse-than-expected result for the insurgent candidate Geert Wilders.

site_title: Toyota to invest £240m to upgrade UK car plant for future output
summary: Toyota is investing £240m to upgrade its UK car plant in Burnaston, Derbyshire, to increase production capacity and meet local content rules post-Brexit. The company aims to use more locally sourced components and retain tariff-free access to EU markets. The British government will contribute an additional £21m to the investment. Toyota employs over 3,000 people in Britain and has invested over £2.5 billion in the country. The upgrade is part of a global rollout of new car-building platforms, allowing for different models to be produced.

site_title: Indonesia leaves key rate unchanged
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its key policy rate unchanged at 4.75% to maintain stability amid global uncertainties, including rising US inflation and geopolitical risks. The decision aims to preserve macroeconomic and financial system stability, while monitoring the impact of higher US rates. Despite global risks, Indonesia's economy is predicted to remain strong in the first quarter of 2017, driven by stronger investment, robust consumption, and improving export performance.

site_title: Paris hit by 2 attacks
summary: Paris was hit by two attacks: a shooting at a high school in Grasse, leaving one person arrested and another on the run, and a letter bomb blast at the International Monetary Fund's Paris office, injuring one person. The explosion was caused by a homemade device, and authorities are investigating possible links to recent telephone threats. The incident occurred amid France's presidential campaign and the country remains in a state of emergency. The IMF has condemned the attack as "a cowardly act of violence" and pledged to ensure staff safety.

site_title: Update: Paris hit by 2 attacks
summary: A teenage student opened fire at a high school in southeastern France, injuring three people, including the headmaster, and a female IMF employee was injured in a letter bomb blast at the IMF building in Paris. The shooting was reportedly linked to American-style mass shootings, and the youth was arrested with two handguns and grenades. The incident comes as France remains on high alert after 230 people were killed by attackers allied to Islamic State in the past two years.

site_title: BOJ hangs loose in face of rising interest rates elsewhere
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-easy monetary policy, keeping interest rates unchanged despite the US Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the BOJ will not alter its monetary stance, citing the need to preserve a slightly positive yield curve. The BOJ aims to achieve its price target, set in 2013, through yield curve control. Kuroda acknowledged that inflation remains a concern, but emphasized that the BOJ will continue to promote powerful monetary easing to achieve its target.

site_title: YouTube makes biggest e-sports bet with FACEIT streaming deal
summary: YouTube has signed a multi-year deal with e-sports platform FACEIT to stream its Esports Championship Series (ECS) exclusively on the platform, starting with the third season on March 25. The deal is YouTube's biggest investment in the e-sports business to date, following the launch of live streaming from mobile devices for users with over 10,000 subscribers. Revenue from e-sports is expected to surge 41% to $696 million in 2017, with the global audience expected to reach 385 million. YouTube aims to introduce e-sports to the masses and attract bigger brands.

site_title: Britain to probe Fox's giant takeover bid of Sky
summary: Britain's media watchdogs, Ofcom and the Competition and Markets Authority, will probe 21st Century Fox's £11.7 billion takeover bid of Sky, citing concerns over media plurality and broadcasting standards. The deal, led by media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, could give the Murdoch family too much control over the British media landscape. The probe follows a similar controversy in 2011 when Murdoch was forced to abandon a previous takeover bid of Sky due to hacking scandal allegations. The investigation is aimed at ensuring the deal does not harm media diversity and competition in the UK.

site_title: US:Wall St edges up on gains in tech, bank stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite reaching fresh records, driven by gains in technology and financial stocks. Oracle's 8.3% rise and IBM's 1.2% gain contributed to the boost, while the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates by a quarter point for the first time this year lifted bank shares. The Fed's plan to stick to three rate hikes this year also boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Malaysia's Iskandar Waterfront to raise US$338m to shrink debt
summary: Malaysia's Iskandar Waterfront Holdings plans to raise approximately US$338 million by issuing new shares to cut debt. The company will issue around 600 million new shares at a price estimated to be 2.47 ringgit per share, a 10% discount to IWC's closing price. The merger deal is expected to be completed in six to nine months, and the company targets a secondary listing in Hong Kong, China, or Singapore within 12 months.

site_title: Food, drink giants plot fightback as India looks to tighten rules
summary: India plans to introduce draft rules requiring food manufacturers to display fat, sugar, and salt content on packaging within a month, amid rising obesity and diabetes rates. Companies like PepsiCo, Nestle, and McDonald's have met to lobby against the proposals, which could impact the $57 billion food and drink sector in India. A "fat tax" on junk foods is also being considered, although it's unlikely to be implemented soon. Industry groups and companies are urging the government to resist pressure from health advocates and proposing a unified message to engage with the government.

site_title: New US home construction rebounds in February
summary: US home construction rebounded in February, with total housing starts rising 3% to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 1.29 million units, the highest level since October. Single-family home construction jumped 6.5% to 872,000 units, its highest level in nearly 10 years. However, new housing permits dropped 6.2% to 1.21 million units, suggesting a potential slowdown in construction. The rebound is attributed to the tight housing market and builders favoring multi-unit construction to serve the rental market.

site_title: Uber wins driver-status case in France on legal technicality
summary: Uber wins a French court case on a technicality, preventing its drivers from being classified as employees. A tribunal for social security matters dismissed a request for Uber to make social security payments for drivers, citing an "irregular" recovery procedure by the URSSAF agency. The decision doesn't rule on the drivers' status, but rather on the agency's handling of evidence. The ruling could have put Uber's business model at risk in France, where authorities had sought 5 million euros in back dues for January 2012 to June 2013.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore experienced a slow start to mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity, with $7.7 billion in announced deals in the first three months of 2017, down 21% from the previous year. A two-speed economy has emerged, with brighter prospects for trade-dependent sectors and dimmer prospects at home. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) members have decided to continue exploring options to preserve pact benefits. Meanwhile, Singaporean companies like EndoMaster raised $20.5 million in Series B funding and Blackstone put Sime Darby Singapore's property on sale.

site_title: Singapore 'heartened' that TPP members exploring options to preserve pact benefits
summary: Singapore expressed relief that remaining TPP members are exploring options to preserve pact benefits, despite US President Donald Trump's executive order to withdraw from the deal. The 11-member group, including Singapore, met in Chile to discuss a way forward and preserve economic integration in the Asia-Pacific. They reiterated support for free trade and agreed to consult senior trade officials before their ministers meet again in May. The decision aims to sustain momentum on the TPP and harvest its benefits in a timely manner.

site_title: Swatch sees rebound in US, Europe as watch sales improve
summary: Swatch Group AG, the largest Swiss watchmaker, forecasts a rebound in US and European markets, with "healthy growth" expected in local currencies this year. The company expects sales to rise 7-10% and operating profit to improve, marking the industry's longest slump on record. Despite a 45% operating profit slump last year, CEO Nick Hayek remains optimistic, citing stronger consumption in China and normalization of luxury sales in Paris. The company's stock rose as much as 1% on the news.

site_title: Silver seen climbing faster than gold as Yellen wakens bulls
summary: Silver prices are rising faster than gold as investors seek the metal due to its potential for appreciation in a rising market. The Federal Reserve's dovish outlook on US monetary policy and a gradual pace of interest rate tightening have fueled the rally. Silver has risen over 9% this year, while gold has gained less than 7%. Analysts predict industrial demand for silver will remain strong, but supply may drop due to mine closures, leading to higher prices.

site_title: A-Smart Holdings back in the black in Q2
summary: A-Smart Holdings has turned a net profit of S$27,000 for the second quarter ended Jan 31, 2017, reversing a net loss of S$9 million in the previous year. Revenue declined 7.8% to S$2.11 million and earnings per share dropped 0.024 Singapore cents. CEO Lim Huan Chiang attributes the improvement to the smart technologies business, which is expected to contribute positively to the group's performance. The company plans to review its core print business and transform services to deliver a leading-edge customer experience.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise to 15-month high as reflation rally resumes
summary: European shares hit a 15-month high on Thursday, with basic resource and banking stocks rising after the US Fed raised interest rates. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.5% and Amsterdam's AEX index reached its highest level in over nine years, driven by gains in Anglo American and Lufthansa. Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte won elections in the Netherlands, while Renault fell after its CEO was targeted in a diesel cheating probe. The reflation rally in Europe resumed, with banking stocks up 1.7% following the US Fed rate hike.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher, STI at 19-month high on Fed signal
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its short-term rate by 25 basis points, signaling one hike this year, which boosted Singapore stocks to a 19-month high. The Straits Times Index rose 26.09 points, or 0.8%, to 3,163.52, driven by Wall Street's overnight gains. Turnover was heavy at 2.7 billion units worth S$1.6 billion, with 319 rises versus 181 falls. The positive sentiment was despite uncertainty over tariffs.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ekes out small gains after Fed; Fast Retailing falls
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.1% to 19,590.14 points, driven by mining shares after crude oil prices extended gains. However, financial stocks fell due to US interest rate hikes. Fast Retailing, the operator of Uniqlo, fell 1.9% after rivals planned to expand aggressively. The broader Topix index gained 0.1% to 1,572.69, largely unaffected by the Bank of Japan's decision to keep monetary policy steady.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble down after proposed share consolidation to reduce speculation
summary: Noble Group's proposed share consolidation of 10 shares into one has led to a 8.1% drop in the counter's price to S$0.193, with over 250 million shares traded. The move aims to reduce volatility and improve liquidity by reducing the bid-ask spread and speculative orders.

site_title: MAS proposes new legal tender limit for coins
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes setting a 10 coins per denomination limit for coins, starting from 5-cent coins. This means a payer can use up to 10 pieces of each coin type per transaction. The change aims to prevent abuses of large coin payments, following two reported cases in 2014. MAS is seeking public feedback on the proposal.

site_title: Asian real estate still attractive after US rate hike - LaSalle Investment
summary: Asian real estate remains attractive despite the US rate hike, according to LaSalle Investment Management. The pace of interest rate increases in the region is expected to be slow, with China identified as a market with huge business growth potential. LaSalle's head of research, Elysia Tse, downplayed concerns over currency fluctuations and regulatory uncertainty, citing high yields in the region as a buffer against rising interest rates. China's logistics real estate is seen as an attractive investment opportunity, with yields ranging from 5.75-6.25% in major cities.

images.alt_text: Asian real estate remains attractive due to relatively high yields despite US monetary tightening as the pace of interest rate increases in the region is expected to be slow, an executive at LaSalle Investment Management said on Thursday.

site_title: Japan PM did not donate money to school at heart of scandal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe did not donate money to the operator of a nationalist school at the center of a scandal, according to Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga. Suga confirmed that Abe did not make the donation himself or through a third party, including his wife Akie. The school's principal stated that Abe's donation was included in funds for an elementary school he planned to open next month. The government is investigating whether Akie made a private donation. The scandal has chipped away at the government's support ratings.

site_title: Seoul: Won surges on Fed views, stocks close at highest since April 2015
summary: The South Korean won reached its highest close in over two weeks, closing at 1,132.0 to the US dollar, driven by market players' confidence in a gradual US interest rate hike. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) ended up 0.8% at 2,150.08 points, its strongest closing level since April 2015, with foreign investors purchasing 271.6 billion won of Kospi shares for the day.

site_title: China:Shanghai share index closes at 14-week high after Fed decision
summary: China's Shanghai share index reached a 14-week high after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates, dampening expectations of more aggressive tightening. The CSI300 index rose 0.5% to 3,481.51 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index advanced 0.8% to 3,268.94 points. China's central bank also raised short-term interest rates to stabilize the yuan currency. The move was largely seen as a response to the US rate hike, with most sectors gaining ground, led by financial and energy plays.

site_title: Thai central bank says current policy rate still accommodative
summary: Thailand's central bank governor stated the policy interest rate remains accommodative at 1.50% for economic recovery. The rate has been unchanged since April 2015, with inflation returning to the target range of 1-4%. The central bank does not expect a policy change at its March 29 meeting.

site_title: Blackstone said to put Sime Darby Singapore property on sale
summary: Blackstone Group LP plans to sell the Sime Darby Centre in Singapore, acquired for under S$200 million, for about S$300 million. The 250,000 square feet office and retail asset, which Blackstone owns 70% of, is located in the Bukit Timah area. CBRE Group Inc is advising on the sale, with potential buyers including Far East Organization and City Developments Ltd. The sale is part of Sime Darby Bhd's efforts to pare debt, which has sold other property assets in Australia and Singapore.

site_title: Businesses must add value, venture out for growth: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister for Prime Minister's Office Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for businesses to focus on adding value and exploring growth opportunities overseas, rather than solely managing costs. This message was conveyed during a budget panel discussion in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Minister for Prime Minister's Office Chan Chun Sing said businesses need to look beyond cost management to also explore how to improve their value-add and venture overseas for growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally on Fed rate call
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 2% on Thursday after the Federal Reserve hiked interest rates, but signaled a slower pace of monetary tightening. The Hang Seng Index jumped 2.08% to 24,288.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The Fed's decision was seen as a positive signal for the market, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: World Bank's IFC invests US$2m in Singapore-based early stage fund SeedPlus
summary: The World Bank's International Finance Corporation (IFC) has invested US$2 million in Singapore-based early-stage fund SeedPlus to support technology entrepreneurship in Asia. SeedPlus, launched by Jungle Ventures, invests in Asian startups, including Moglix and Mimetic.ai. This investment follows IFC's previous commitment of US$10 million to Jungle Ventures' second fund, aiming to invest in early-stage technology companies in emerging South-east Asia markets.

site_title: Lufthansa cautious for year ahead after boost in 2016
summary: Lufthansa reported a 4.6% increase in net profit to 1.78 billion euros in 2016, meeting expectations. The airline attributed its success to maintaining record margins despite a demanding market environment. However, it offered modest forecasts for the current year, citing falling prices and higher costs. CEO Carsten Spohr noted the company's ability to keep margins at record levels in 2016. The airline's cautious outlook for the year ahead reflects the challenges it faces in the competitive aviation industry.

site_title: Taiwan plans military spending increase to counter rising China
summary: Taiwan plans to increase its defense spending to 3% of its GDP in 2018, a rise from 2% this year, to counter China's growing military might. The move aims to develop indigenous ships, airplanes, and unmanned aerial vehicles. This increase follows a decline in defense spending since the 1980s, when it reached 5% of GDP. The push comes amid growing tensions with China, which considers Taiwan a province that will eventually be united with the mainland, and President Tsai Ing Wen's refusal to endorse the "One China" framework.

site_title: Uniqlo turns speed demon to take on Zara for global sales crown
summary: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing Co aims to overtake Zara in global sales by leveraging speed and efficiency in its supply chain. The company plans to reduce the design-to-delivery time to about 13 days, comparable to Zara's. Uniqlo is also expanding its direct-to-consumer sales and improving same-day delivery in the Tokyo area through its new design and delivery centre. This move is expected to enhance Uniqlo's competitive edge in the global apparel market.

site_title: European car sales rise in February amid volume brand slump
summary: European new car registrations rose 2.1% in February, reaching 1,114,443 vehicles, driven by gains in Italy (6.2%), the Netherlands (15%), and Spain (0.2%). In contrast, large markets like Germany, France, and Britain saw sales fall 2.6%, 2.9%, and 0.3%, respectively. Premium brands like Mercedes-Benz (3.4%) and Renault (5.3%) outperformed, while volume brands like Volkswagen (7%), Peugeot (3.7%), and Opel/Vauxhall (1.2%) saw declines.

site_title: Chinese group Global CEO Fortune Club launches fund in Australia, eyes infrastructure
summary: A Chinese investment group, the Global CEO Fortune Club, launched its first overseas fund in Australia, aiming to invest in infrastructure projects. The group, affiliated with Shanghai Jixiang, has $4.093 billion in assets and plans to partner with the state government of Victoria on projects such as roads, train lines, and port regeneration. The move comes amid concerns over foreign investment in Australian infrastructure, following the 2015 sale of the Port of Darwin to Chinese interests. The group expects opportunities in tourism and scenic areas like the Great Ocean Road.

site_title: Singapore sees slow start to M&A activity: Thomson Reuters
summary: Singapore's mergers and acquisitions (M&A) scene has started slowly this year, with announced deals valued at $7.7 billion in the first three months, down 21% from last year. The property sector led the market, accounting for 41.9% of the value, with a 253.1% increase in deal value from the same period in 2016. Private equity-backed M&A fell 90.1% and inbound M&A fell 40%, its lowest since 2013.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Top bank executives expose pay myths in Scandinavian example
summary: Top executives of Scandinavian banks, including Nordea Bank and Danske Bank, earn significantly less than their global counterparts, with annual salaries ranging from $2.6 million to $3.7 million. Despite dominating European rankings in returns and capital adequacy, Nordic bank CEOs make roughly half as much as their peers elsewhere. The Scandinavian experience may lead to a re-evaluation of bonus pools for European bankers, with regulators considering introducing "more liability associated with significant failure" to align executive interests with those of shareholders and society.

site_title: Huge anti-laundering fine for Australian gambling firm Tabcorp
summary: Tabcorp, an Australian gambling firm, was fined A$45 million by the Federal Court for breaching anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws 108 times over five years. The fine, the largest in Australian corporate history, was imposed after Tabcorp failed to report suspicious behavior and implement a compliant AML/CTF program. The company acknowledged its shortcomings and expressed commitment to regulatory compliance, with CEO David Attenborough stating the firm would continue to cooperate with AUSTRAC, the financial intelligence body that brought the case.

site_title: Prince William and Kate visit Paris 20 years after Diana's death
summary: Prince William and Kate visited Paris, 20 years after his mother Diana's death in a car crash in the French capital. The royal couple met President Francois Hollande, launched the "Les Voisins" initiative to foster closer relations between Britain and France, and attended a rugby match. The trip coincided with the 20th anniversary of Diana's death, although no official commemoration was planned. William's visit is seen as a sign of the royal family's increasing involvement in official duties, following the queen's 91st birthday in June.

site_title: China raises short-term interest rates for 3rd time in as many months
summary: China's central bank raised short-term interest rates for the third time in as many months, increasing the rate on medium-term lending facility loans to 3.05% and open market operation reverse repos to 2.45%, 2.60%, and 2.75% respectively. The move aims to contain rising debt and follows the US Federal Reserve's benchmark policy rate hike earlier in the day. Analysts had expected this move to manage debt risks and maintain economic stability.

site_title: Yahoo cyber indictment shows Kremlin, hackers working hand-in-hand
summary: US authorities have indicted four individuals, including two Russian FSB officers and two hackers, in a 2014 cyber attack on Yahoo Inc. The indictment reveals a symbiotic relationship between Moscow's security services and private Russian hackers, with the Kremlin employing them for geostrategic purposes. The arrangement allows Moscow to maintain plausible deniability and freedom from legal troubles. The indictment coincides with mounting tensions between US intelligence agencies and Russian President Vladimir Putin's government, accused of hacking the 2016 US presidential election.

images.alt_text: The indictment charges two officers of the FSB, Russia's Federal Security Service, and two hackers who allegedly worked hand-in-hand with them to crack 500 million Yahoo user accounts.

site_title: Hong Kong family-owned Chow Tai Fook agrees to buy Alinta Energy
summary: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises Ltd, a Hong Kong family-owned conglomerate, agreed to acquire Alinta Energy Holdings Ltd in a multi-billion dollar deal. The transaction, valued at over A$4 billion, marks Chow Tai Fook's first significant investment in Australia's utilities sector. The acquisition is part of the company's expansion efforts beyond Greater China, aiming to diversify its business and increase revenue. The deal comes as the Australian government battles an increase in power failures and surge in wholesale gas prices.

site_title: Asia: Most markets boosted by Fed but US dollar sinks
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday after the Federal Reserve lifted US interest rates by a quarter of a point but gave a more dovish outlook for future hikes. The US dollar sank, while the euro was boosted by the expected victory of the incumbent party in Dutch elections. Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul advanced, with Sydney and Singapore also seeing gains. The Fed's decision signaled control over the economy, but the dollar remains under pressure due to the lack of hawkish guidance.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks surged after the Federal Reserve lifted interest rates, signaling a confident US economy outlook. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.30% to 24,101.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.17% and 0.19% respectively. The decision held off announcing a quicker pace of future interest rate hikes, maintaining investor confidence.

site_title: You look good, we look good is working for Meitu: Gadfly
summary: Meitu Inc, a Chinese beauty-app maker, has seen a 47.2% gain in its stock since it qualified for an equity-trading link between Hong Kong and Shenzhen exchanges. The company, famous for its photo editing app, has attracted a large number of retail investors in China, driving its stock to book value of around 7.9 times. Analysts expect sales to double this year, but not to expect breakeven by the end of 2017, suggesting investors may be buying the stock due to its emotional appeal rather than its financial prospects.

site_title: Prominent Australians urge India's Adani to abandon giant mine
summary: A group of 90 prominent Australians, including former cricket captains and authors, urged India's Adani Enterprises to abandon its A$21.7 billion Carmichael coal mine project near the Great Barrier Reef, citing environmental and health risks. The project, set to start construction this year, faces ongoing legal challenges and could damage bilateral ties and sporting links between Australia and India. The Australians warned that proceeding with the project would harm India's reputation and contribute to climate change.

images.alt_text: A group of prominent Australians on Thursday urged India's Adani Enterprises to abandon a giant coal mine project near the Great Barrier Reef, warning it could damage bilateral ties and even affect sporting links.

site_title: Trump puts brakes on vehicle emission targets
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced that future vehicle emission targets will be put on hold pending review, citing concerns that higher environmental standards hurt trade. The move comes after the Obama administration issued the rules without considering market realities and consumer expectations. Trump stated that he will work with auto manufacturers to create jobs, but expects them to reciprocate. The decision affects 13 US states, Japan, and European nations with stricter emission standards, and may impact US exports.

site_title: Australian shares rise for third day on strong resources, NZ gains
summary: Australian shares rose for a third consecutive day, driven by gains in resources stocks as commodity prices surged. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 0.27% to 5789.8, with the mining index rising nearly three% to its highest in over a week. Iron ore futures in China surged over five% and copper prices gained for a fourth straight session.

site_title: Lloyds poised to grow investment banking
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc is set to expand its investment banking operations, despite not using that term, as it focuses on its core strengths. The markets business, which includes bond underwriting and derivatives trading, generated a third of the revenue at its commercial bank last year. The unit's head, Andrew Bester, believes growth is possible if client demand increases, particularly as other banks in the region scale back. This move is part of the firm's effort to simplify and concentrate on its core businesses.

images.alt_text: Lloyds Banking Group Plc is ready to grow its investment bank. Just don't call it that.

site_title: Opec partners' oil supply cuts faltered in February, IEA Says
summary: Opec partners' oil supply cuts faltered in February, according to the International Energy Agency. The 11 countries, led by Russia, reduced output by 240,000 barrels a day, or 43% of their promised 558,000-barrel reduction. This is lower than the January reduction of 274,000 barrels. Opec itself implemented 91% of its pledged reduction, while its partners lagged behind, with Kazakhstan's ramp-up of the Kashagan oil field contributing to the shortfall.

images.alt_text: The 11 countries co-operating with Opec's bid to re-balance world markets faltered in their delivery of supply cuts last month, according to the International Energy Agency.

site_title: Australia jobless rate unexpectedly rises to 5.9%; Australian dollar drops
summary: Australia's jobless rate unexpectedly rose to 5.9% in February, exceeding economists' forecasts of 5.7%. Employment fell 6,400, with full-time jobs increasing 27,100 and part-time employment decreasing 33,500. The Australian dollar dropped to 76.90 US cents. The mixed labor market signals a labor market showing mixed signals, with some areas experiencing growth while others face challenges. The central bank cites forward indicators suggesting the labor market will strengthen, but the economy remains divided between regions.

site_title: Skeptical US lawmakers pressure Comey on Trump wiretap claim
summary: US lawmakers, including Republican Chairman Devin Nunes and Democratic Representative Adam Schiff, expressed skepticism about President Trump's claim that the Obama administration wiretapped Trump Tower during the 2016 election campaign. Nunes stated that there is no evidence to support the claim, while James Clapper, the former director of national intelligence, also denied any warrant to wiretap Trump Tower. The FBI Director, James Comey, will be questioned about wiretap evidence at a public hearing on Monday, and lawmakers are seeking information on leaks of classified information.

site_title: North Korean hacking group behind recent attacks on banks: Symantec
summary: A North Korean hacking group known as Lazarus is likely behind a recent cyber campaign targeting organizations in 31 countries, according to cyber security firm Symantec. The group, which has been linked to high-profile attacks on Bangladesh Bank, Sony, and South Korea, used sophisticated techniques to infect victims with "loader" software. Symantec's analysis suggests the group focused on targeting banks in 31 countries, including Poland, the US, and Mexico. The North Korean government has denied involvement, but the US Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating.

site_title: Trump vows to fight travel ban block at Supreme Court
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to fight a federal court ruling halting his revised travel ban, describing it as "judicial overreach." Trump stated his administration will take the case to the Supreme Court, promising to "win." The ban targets refugees and nationals from six Muslim-majority countries. Trump's administration is set to appeal the decision, which was made by a Hawaii court.

site_title: Oil prices extend gains after drop in US stockpiles
summary: Crude oil prices rose in early Asian trading on March 16, 2017, after US stockpiles eased from record highs. This surge followed a session of gains and market optimism that a global oil glut may be ending. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike did not signal further increases.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise tracking regional shares as Fed maintains outlook
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.91% on Thursday, tracking regional gains after the US Federal Reserve maintained its interest rate hike outlook. The Fed raised the overnight interest rate by 25 basis points to 0.75-1% per cent, with Asian investors relieved that the Fed won't accelerate rate hikes. The main Taiex index surpassed the 9,800 point benchmark, led by gains in the plastics, semiconductor, and electronics subindexes. The Taiwan dollar hit a 21-month high against the US dollar at 30.564 per dollar.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady as Fed sticks to rate-hike path
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, defying expectations of a change in response to the US Federal Reserve's second interest rate hike in three months. The BOJ's decision underscores the diverging policy paths of major global central banks amidst rising global protectionism. Investors will focus on Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's post-meeting briefing for clues on how the Fed's move affects the BOJ's stimulus programme.

site_title: Quick takes on US Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points for the second time in three months, with the Fed guiding for two more hikes in 2017. Experts expect little market reaction to the decision, as it was widely anticipated. Lee Ferridge notes that further hikes will depend on continued economic strength and wage growth, while Antoine Lesné suggests that uncertainty surrounding fiscal policy poses near-term risks. The Fed's decision is seen as a cautious move to prepare for a faster pace of tightening later this year, with Richard Jerram predicting seven rate hikes by the end of 2018.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Asia-Pacific seeks to save TPP trade deal without US
summary: Asia-Pacific ministers have agreed to move forward on a trade agreement resembling the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) without the US. The deal, negotiated under former President Barack Obama, aimed to slash tariffs and tighten trade ties between countries accounting for 40% of the world economy. The 11 remaining countries, plus China and South Korea, have decided to proceed with a new agreement, with a focus on maintaining high labor and environmental standards. A "TPP 2.0" with China has not been ruled out, but would depend on China's willingness to adopt the regulatory discipline of the original deal.

site_title: Hawaii judge halts Trump's new travel ban before it can go into effect
summary: A US federal judge in Hawaii halted President Donald Trump's revised travel ban just hours before it was set to go into effect. The order, which targeted most refugees and travelers from six Muslim-majority countries, was deemed discriminatory against Muslims by the state of Hawaii. The ban was the second revised order by Trump, following a previous one that was also halted by a federal judge. The ruling was issued by Judge Derrick Watson, who cited the establishment clause of the US Constitution, preventing religious discrimination.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.6 per cent up on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.6% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 17.86 points to 3,155.29. The gain was driven by an overnight US stock market rise, following the Federal Reserve's expected rate hike. The market was also influenced by positive investor sentiment, with gainers outnumbering losers 131 to 24. The blue-chip index has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with notable movers including Noble, Yangzijiang, and Alliance Mineral.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors call in SK Group officials for questioning
summary: South Korean prosecutors have called in three officials from SK Group for questioning as part of a corruption scandal that led to the downfall of former President Park Geun-Hye. The officials, including Kim Chang-Geun, a former chairman of SK Group's top decision-making committee, will be questioned on Thursday. A private meeting between Kim and Park in 2015 has raised suspicions, and the questioning is part of a broader investigation into influence-peddling and corruption. Park will be summoned for questioning next Tuesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Reits, property; Super offer now unconditional
summary: Asian stocks will trade on Thursday following an expected Fed rate hike, but analysts say the path of rate hikes for the rest of the year won't be as steep as feared, benefiting commodity-linked and emerging market currencies. Reits and property stocks in Singapore may see trading as rate hikes are expected to reset to three this year. Super Group's takeover offer for Jacobs Douwe Egberts has turned unconditional, with the closing date extended to April 25. Meanwhile, Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank raises interest rates after Fed move; shares watched
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority raised its base rate by 25 basis points to 1.25% in response to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The move follows steady economic growth, strong job gains, and rising inflation. Hong Kong tracks US rate moves due to its currency peg to the US dollar, and shares of banking and property companies will be closely watched for potential impact. The city's economy is increasingly dependent on the mainland, with over three-quarters of inbound tourists coming from China and more than half of trade being with the country.

site_title: Trump budget plan to propose major cuts for foreign aid, EPA: source
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to propose a budget plan for fiscal 2018 that includes major cuts for foreign aid and environmental protection, with a 28% reduction in State Department funding and up to a third cut for the Environmental Protection Agency. The plan also includes a 10% increase in defense spending and a 6% increase in funding for homeland security. To fund these increases, Trump is seeking deep reductions in programs such as public broadcasting and heating subsidies. The budget is expected to face resistance from Congress, with some moderate Republicans expressing unease over the proposed cuts.

site_title: New Zealand economy misses growth expectations on export drop
summary: New Zealand's economy grew 0.4% in the fourth quarter of 2016, below economists' forecast of 0.7% due to a sharp drop in exports, mainly caused by heavy spring rain cutting dairy production. This result may disappoint the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, which had anticipated a 1% increase from the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's economy grew more slowly than expected in 2016's fourth quarter as exports dropped sharply, mostly owing to heavy spring rain cutting dairy production.

site_title: US dollar crunched, bonds boosted as Fed goes gradual
summary: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points to a range of 0.75-1% in a gradual move, as expected, but signaled no faster tightening. The US dollar fell to a three-week low, while sovereign bonds rallied for their biggest gain in nine months. The euro rose 1.2% against the dollar, and gold, copper, and oil also increased, boosting emerging markets. The Fed stuck to its inflation target, indicating it could tolerate a quicker pace of price rises, and officials maintained their outlook for two more hikes this year and three more in 2018.

images.alt_text: The US dollar nursed bitter losses in Asia on Thursday while sovereign bonds savoured their biggest rally in nine months after the Federal Reserve hiked interest rates, as expected, but signalled no pick-up in the pace of tightening.

site_title: US charges Russian spies, hackers in massive Yahoo hack
summary: The US has charged two Russian intelligence agents and two hackers with masterminding the 2014 Yahoo hack that stole 500 million accounts. The 47-count indictment includes charges of conspiracy, computer fraud, and economic espionage, alleging the Russian security services worked with cyber criminals to further intelligence goals. This marks the first time the US government has criminally charged Russian spies for cyber offences, amid controversies over alleged Kremlin-backed hacking of the 2016 US presidential election and possible links to President Trump's associates.

site_title: Japan Inc wage gains slow as Trump, Brexit spur exporters' risk
summary: Japan's major companies, including Panasonic and Toyota, announced smaller wage increases for the next fiscal year, reflecting concerns about overseas markets due to US President Donald Trump's election and Brexit. The average monthly base pay increase rose 1,240 yen, a decline from previous years. Exporters fear trade restrictions and currency fluctuations, which have already eroded the value of Japanese companies' overseas earnings. The slower wage gains may be a mid-cycle pause, but experts predict a labor shortage will eventually lead to higher wages.

site_title: New SCCCI president Roland Ng sworn in
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) has sworn in its new president, Roland Ng, marking the beginning of the 59th council. Ng announced the establishment of a Youth Business Affairs Committee and a Trade Association Hub to promote digitalization and trade partnerships. The SCCCI will also leverage its global network to support local enterprises venturing overseas.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Mr Ng (left) receiving the SCCCI seal from Mr Chua. Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean was the guest-of-honour at the ceremony.

site_title: Fed to keep rate hikes slow even if US inflation overshoots: Yellen
summary: The Federal Reserve, led by Chair Janet Yellen, will maintain a gradual path of interest rate hikes despite potential inflation above its 2% target, signaling a willingness to use low rates to control unemployment. The Fed will hike rates by 25 basis points and likely lift them two more times this year, aiming to rein in inflation if needed. Yellen emphasized that 2% inflation is a target, not a ceiling, and the Fed has the credibility to handle inflation spikes.

site_title: US dollar tumbles after Fed signals gradual hikes, Dutch election exit poll
summary: The US dollar plummeted to a five-week low against the euro, a four-week trough versus the Swiss franc, and a two-week low against the yen and sterling after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points to a range of 0.75-1%. The Fed signaled a more gradual pace of monetary tightening than expected, with two more rate hikes in 2017 and three in 2018. The euro rose to $1.0740, bolstered by Dutch election exit polls showing Prime Minister Mark Rutte's VVD Party won the most seats, reducing the odds of Marine Le Pen's winning in France.

site_title: GoPro camera maker cuts jobs again in search of profit
summary: GoPro Inc announced its second round of job cuts, eliminating approximately 270 full-time and open positions, in an effort to reduce costs and achieve profitability. The cuts, which follow a 15% workforce reduction in November, are expected to lower full-year adjusted operating expenses to under $495 million. The company also plans to focus on international growth, simplify its product offerings, and reduce production delays. Despite the job cuts, GoPro expects to make a profit this year and forecast first-quarter revenue toward the upper end of its guidance range.

site_title: Tesla seeks US$1.15b to help fuel Model 3 launch
summary: Tesla announced plans to raise $1.15 billion in funding to support the launch of its mass-market Model 3 electric car. The company will offer $250 million in common stock and $750 million in convertible notes, with Elon Musk investing $25 million. The funds will be used to strengthen the company's balance sheet and reduce risks associated with rapid business scaling. Production of the Model 3 is expected to begin in July, with output ramping up to 5,000 vehicles weekly by the end of the year, priced at $35,000 in the US.

site_title: Parcel with explosives mailed to German finance minister from Greece: police
summary: A parcel containing explosives was mailed to German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble from Greece, but was intercepted by the German finance ministry's mail department. The parcel was sent via Greek postal service Elta and had Greek stamps on it. Greek Deputy Citizens Protection Minister Nikos Toskas has been in touch with his German counterpart. Senior conservative politician Adonis Georgiadis, who is the suspected sender, confirmed that his name was used. This incident comes after an attack on Georgiadis' bookstore in Athens the previous day, causing light damage.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb with miners on Fed and Dutch election day
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, driven by gains in mining companies ahead of Federal Reserve decisions and the Dutch general election. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rebounded from a drop on Tuesday, with raw materials producers like Rio Tinto and Glencore leading the gain. The valuation gap between US and European stocks is narrowing, with Goldman Sachs predicting European stock returns may exceed US peers in 2017. The Dutch AEX Index also rose 0.3%, while Brent crude-oil futures climbed 1.4%.

site_title: Fillon claims graft charges are to derail his bid for presidency
summary: French presidential candidate François Fillon claims his bid is being sabotaged by graft charges, despite being charged with embezzlement over his wife's allegedly fake job. Fillon insists on his innocence and argues the courts are being manipulated against him. Pollsters say the damage has already been done, with Fillon lying in a distant third in the polls. His bid for presidency seems unlikely, with front-runner Emmanuel Macron projected to win the May 7 run-off by a significant margin. Fillon vows to stay in the race despite the challenges.

site_title: 30 US cities shopping for US$10b of electric vehicles in defiance of Trump
summary: US cities, including New York and Chicago, have joined a joint effort to buy $10 billion worth of electric vehicles, with 30 cities participating in the initiative. The cities aim to purchase 114,000 electric vehicles, including police cruisers and trucks, to demonstrate demand for low-emission vehicles despite President Trump's plans to review pollution standards. The move could boost the US plug-in market, providing electric vehicle manufacturers with reliable demand as federal policies shift and gas prices fluctuate.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen jumps after Fed meet
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, March 16, 2017, as the yen rose against the US dollar following the US Federal Reserve's signal of a gradual pace for additional interest rate increases. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51%, while the Topix index dropped 0.54%. The yen's appreciation was attributed to the Fed's decision, which was seen as a sign of caution, and investors' concerns about the US dollar's value.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.600 points to 1726.340 on Thursday, with a 197-43 gain-to-lose ratio. The country's shares opened higher, following a 5-day rally in Singapore and global stock markets. Despite US trade uncertainty, investors remained positive, and the Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: US: Wall Street up as Fed raises rates but stays course
summary: US stocks rose sharply on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points, as expected, but did not signal an acceleration of monetary tightening. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.54%, the S&P 500 gained 0.84%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.74%. Energy stocks boosted the S&P 500 due to rising oil prices, while retail sales recorded their smallest gain in six months.

site_title: Ex-chief of HR tool Zenefits launches startup
summary: Former Zenefits CEO Parker Conrad launches startup Rippling, competing with his old company, offering automated employee hiring and firing services, including generating offer letters, setting up email accounts, and processing payroll. Conrad aims to be "the system of record for employee information" and has raised $7 million from investors. Rippling differs from Zenefits, which faced regulatory issues and a valuation drop, and Conrad is steering clear of insurance services. Rippling now has about 15 employees and aims to compete with the services offered by his former company.

site_title: North Korea, China in focus as Tillerson starts Asia trip in Tokyo
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson begins his first Asia trip in Tokyo, focusing on North Korea and China. He will reassure Japan and South Korea about countering North Korea's nuclear threat and press China to address the issue. The US will also discuss trade with Japan, which has been a key concern. Tillerson's visit aims to reassure Tokyo and Seoul about US policies, but no immediate specific response is expected. The US has not ruled out military options to address North Korea's growing nuclear capabilities.

site_title: Fed raises rates as job gains and firming inflation stoke confidence
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points to a range of 0.75% to 1% for the second time in three months, driven by steady economic growth, strong job gains, and rising inflation confidence. Fed Chair Janet Yellen expressed confidence in the economy's trajectory, sticking to its outlook for two additional rate increases this year and three more in 2018. The decision relieved concerns about faster rate hikes and signaled a more gradual approach to monetary tightening.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates on Wednesday for the second time in three months, a move spurred by steady economic growth, strong job gains and confidence that inflation is rising to the central bank's target.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts first loss since 2008 amid rising competition
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd reported its first loss in eight years, with a net loss of HK$575 million (S$105 million) in 2016, due to rising competition from Chinese airlines and losses from fuel hedging. The airline scrapped plans for a second-half dividend and launched a three-year transformation program to improve returns and operational efficiency. Sales dropped 9.4% to HK$92.8 billion, with passenger yields declining 9.2% to 54.1 Hong Kong cents. The airline faces structural problems from competition headwinds and expects further fuel hedging losses in 2017.

site_title: Intel's acquisition of Mobileye marks Israel as autonomous technology hub
summary: Intel has agreed to pay US$15 billion for Mobileye, a Jerusalem-based maker of chips and software for driverless cars, marking Israel as a key hub for autonomous technology. The deal is the largest takeover of an Israeli tech firm and follows investments by major car manufacturers, including Ford, Daimler, and General Motors. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hailed the deal as proof of Israel's emergence as a global technology center, with the potential to boost economic growth by 50%.

site_title: Dutch PM slaps down far-right challenge: exit polls
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte has defeated far-right challenger Geert Wilders in a key election, securing the Liberal VVD party's position as the largest party in the 150-seat parliament with 31 seats. Rutte's pro-European stance and strong economic record won over millions of Dutch voters, who turned out in a near-record turnout of 81%. Wilders' Freedom Party secured 19 seats, but his anti-immigration and anti-EU rhetoric failed to resonate with voters. Rutte is set to form a new coalition and may turn to the Christian Democratic Appeal and D66 parties to secure a majority.

images.alt_text: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte appeared Wednesday to have easily defeated a strong challenge by far-right rival Geert Wilders in a key election seen as a bellwether of populist support in Europe.

site_title: Washington Post software deal a double win for Bezos
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos scored a double win as The Washington Post signed its biggest contract to date to sell web publishing tools, mostly hosted by Amazon Web Services (AWS), in a deal with tronc Inc. The contract is a boost for The Washington Post, aiming for $100 million in annual revenue, and indirectly benefits AWS, which posted a 55% sales jump last year. The Post will host the tools with alternative vendors, but notes that using AWS is not automatic.

site_title: New UBS services for foreign residents here
summary: UBS Wealth Management has launched a new service catering to foreign residents in Singapore, offering specialised financial services such as children's education and retirement savings. The team, led by Sean Straton, aims to provide a seamless international banking experience. With four bankers on board, UBS expects to double the staff strength within a year. The move is part of the bank's strategy to support high-net worth foreign residents in Singapore, according to Eddie Gan, managing director of UBS Wealth Management in Singapore.

site_title: Govt willing to allow some flexibility on foreign labour quota
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say has offered flexibility on foreign labour quotas to help companies cope with labour shortages, but requires businesses to have a "clear action plan" to transform their sector and attract Singaporean workers. The move aims to boost industry growth, competitiveness, and worker attractiveness, as the local workforce growth is expected to slow significantly over the next 10 years due to aging and low birth rates.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Oil rebounds as US crude inventories ease off record high
summary: Oil prices rose for the first time in over a week on Wednesday, driven by a surprise drawdown in US crude inventories and data suggesting Opec cuts could create a crude deficit in the first half of 2017. Brent futures gained 1.8% to settle at $51.81 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2.4% to $48.86 per barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported a weekly decline in US crude stocks, and the International Energy Agency said global inventories rose despite Opec output cuts, potentially leading to a 500,000 barrels per day deficit in the first half of 2017.

images.alt_text: Oil prices on Wednesday climbed for the first time in more than a week on a surprise drawdown in US crude inventories and data from the International Energy Agency (IEA) suggesting Opec cuts could create a crude deficit in the first half of 2017.

site_title: Trump's ex-wife to publish memoir on raising kids
summary: Ivana Trump, Donald Trump's first ex-wife, is set to publish a memoir in September titled "Raising Trump." The book will focus on her experiences raising her three eldest children, Donald Jr, Ivanka, and Eric, and will be a "non-partisan, non-political" book about motherhood and resilience. Ivana, who was born in communist Czechoslovakia, will share stories about her childhood, marriage to Donald Trump, and her success as a businesswoman. Her children have praised her as an "amazing mom, teacher, and inspiration," and the book is expected to be released on September 12.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's first ex-wife Ivana is writing a memoir about bringing up the US president's eldest three children, slated for release in September, her publishers announced Wednesday.

site_title: Higher car, bike COE premiums
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars and motorcycles rose, with Category A cars increasing by S$49,430 to S$50,789, and Category D motorcycles rising by S$6,803 to S$7,483. Category C goods vehicles fell by S$808 to S$49,002. The increase is attributed to a tiered Additional Registration Fee for motorcycles introduced in the budget, making bigger bike models more expensive. The move may reduce demand, potentially lowering COE premiums.

site_title: Microsoft rolls out Teams software, eyes big-office customers
summary: Microsoft has officially rolled out its Teams workplace-collaboration software, integrating with Office and Outlook programs and partnering with SAP to challenge Slack for big corporate customers. Available in 181 markets, Teams has gained 50,000 Office 365 customers, including Expedia, which uses it for chat, sharing, and teleconferences. Microsoft sees Teams as a way to push clients to switch from traditional Office software to the subscription-based cloud version, Office 365, providing a more regular revenue stream and sales.

site_title: PM Lee opens SMU's S$165m School of Law building
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong officially opened the S$165 million School of Law building at the Singapore Management University, featuring a state-of-the-art library named after his mother, Kwa Geok Choo. The building also includes a moot court and was completed six years after its planned completion date. The event commemorated two outstanding members of the legal fraternity, Kwa Geok Choo and David Marshall, who was Singapore's first chief minister and a renowned criminal defence lawyer.

site_title: Developers' sales in Feb signal pick-up in momentum, say analysts
summary: Singapore developers saw a significant increase in sales in February, with 977 new private homes and 329 EC units sold, exceeding January's numbers by 2.6 and 1.8 times, respectively. This follows the recent easing of property cooling measures, which analysts attribute to a broad-based recovery in demand. The easing of seller's stamp duty and total debt servicing ratio is expected to further boost sales momentum, with top-selling projects like Seaside Residences and Parc Riviera set to headline sales in the coming months.

site_title: Airlines take proactive approach to weather woes
summary: Airlines proactively grounded planes in regions unaffected by a March 2017 blizzard in the US, resulting in over 6,000 flight cancellations. This strategy allowed airlines to avoid costly de-icing procedures and resume normal service faster. By cancelling flights ahead of time, airlines can also avoid passenger penalties and more easily notify customers of cancellations, enabling them to make alternative plans. This approach has improved the system for customers, with each storm leading to better outcomes than in the past.

site_title: Why North Korea may have halted its missile launches
summary: North Korea's apparent halt in missile launches may be attributed to the recent removal of South Korean President Park Geun-hye, who supported the deployment of Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (THAAD) missiles in South Korea. The new president-elect, Moon Jae-in, favors delaying THAAD deployment and seeking closer ties with Pyongyang, potentially reducing tensions and Kim Jong-un's desire to launch missiles. China, which was opposed to THAAD, may also be more willing to act as a restraint on North Korea's behavior under the new South Korean government.

site_title: Muirfield finally admits women as members
summary: Muirfield Golf Club, the world's oldest golf club, has finally voted to admit women as members, ending a 273-year tradition of male-only membership. The club had previously allowed women to play only as guests, but after a failed vote in 2016 and criticism from the media, it voted to allow women to join with an 80% majority. The decision is expected to take effect immediately, with a waiting list for membership, and could lead to women becoming members within two years.

site_title: London public housing scheme slammed
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan is seeking feedback on draft guidelines for development projects on social housing estates, which could demolish residents' homes. The guidelines aim to "put local people at the heart" of projects, but critics, including London Assembly member Sian Berry, say they are "worse than useless" and don't offer residents a real say in the future of their estates. The guidelines must be approved by March 14 to be eligible for funding from a £3.15 billion fund, and Khan has promised to respond to public feedback before publishing the guidelines later this year.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter could face fines in Germany over hate speech posts
summary: Germany's justice minister proposes a law that could impose fines of up to $75.1 million on Facebook and Twitter for failing to quickly remove hate speech from their platforms. The law requires social media companies to make it easy for users to report contentious material and respond promptly. A recent study found that Facebook and Twitter failed to meet the German target of removing 70% of hate speech within 24 hours. The move comes as tech companies face increasing scrutiny worldwide over how they police online material, including hate speech, and could limit individuals' digital activities.

site_title: Top US envoy Tillerson begins Asia tour amid N Korea crisis
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson begins a tour of Asian capitals amid North Korea's nuclear crisis, with Pyongyang's provocative behavior to be a key focus. He will meet with Japanese and South Korean leaders, as well as Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, to discuss trade, security, and North Korea's progress on building an intercontinental ballistic missile. Tillerson aims to test China's receptiveness to tougher measures on North Korea while attempting to calm fears of a trade dispute between the US and China.

site_title: Brighter outlook for Singapore's trade-dependent sectors, dimmer prospects at home
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow by 2.6% in the first quarter of 2017, with a median forecast of 2.3% for the full year, according to a survey of private-sector economists. The economy is divided into two speeds, with external-facing indicators showing strength, while domestic-oriented indicators, such as the labor market, are weaker. Economists attribute the upward revision to better external prospects, including China's stable growth and the US administration's fiscal stimulus, which is expected to boost non-oil domestic exports and manufacturing. However, there is division on the sustainability of this growth, with some economists warning that manufacturing-led growth may not be sustainable.

site_title: Dutch vote in test of anti-immigrant sentiment in Europe
summary: The Netherlands held a general election on March 15, 2017, with a high turnout expected amidst a charged campaign fueled by anti-immigrant sentiment. The centre-right VVD party of Prime Minister Mark Rutte and the PVV of anti-Islam firebrand Geert Wilders are vying to form the biggest party in parliament. With a tight margin of 4% between leading candidates, the outcome is unpredictable, and experts predict a coalition-building process that will take months. A Wilders victory would send shockwaves across Europe, but his party's chances of forming a government are low due to opposition from other leading parties.

site_title: Card holders who roll balances to be hit hardest by Fed rate hike
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise short-term interest rates by a quarter-point, impacting consumers with credit card holders who carry balances seeing annual interest charges rise to 16.75% from 16.5%. This increase will affect car loan and home equity loan rates over time, with mortgage rates rising in the months ahead. Experts warn that borrowing costs will steadily move higher, especially if the Fed raises rates twice more this year, with the typical credit card holder facing an additional $42 per year in costs and homeowners with home equity lines of credit facing a $6.25 monthly increase.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Triyards Holdings won US$20.64 million ferry contracts, boosting order mix diversity. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's target price is lifted to S$1.21 due to improved order momentum. Singapore banks face uncertainty over local currency rates, with some expecting higher margins and others believing domestic rates will stay low.

site_title: EU could force Britain's PM to wait until June to start Brexit talks
summary: The European Union is likely to delay the start of formal Brexit talks until June, putting pressure on UK Prime Minister Theresa May to land a deal. The EU has set a June 20 meeting of government ministers as the moment to authorise the opening of talks, potentially limiting the time for finding common ground. This could upset businesses and banks seeking early clarity on the UK's withdrawal from the EU. The delay also risks reducing the time for the UK to negotiate a separation deal, handing leverage to the EU.

site_title: Creativity the key to a cleaner energy future
summary: A Shell Eco-marathon event this weekend will showcase various electric and alternative fuel-powered vehicles, highlighting the need for creativity in developing a cleaner energy future. As Asia's economies grow, the transport sector must transition to lower-carbon forms of energy to tackle climate change, with 28% of global energy consumption attributed to transport. Mass-produced and affordable battery-electric and hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, along with improved infrastructure, are crucial for reducing emissions, with electric vehicles currently accounting for only 0.1% of the global market.

site_title: Water price changes a sign of good government
summary: Singapore's water price increase, announced at Budget 2017, reflects the cost of operating and maintaining the sophisticated water system. The 30% hike, in two phases, is necessary to cover the rising costs of collecting, treating, and producing NEWater. Economist Jochen Krauss supports the price change, stating it's a sign of a good government that values water as a strategic resource. The current price system, including a sanitary appliance fee, aims to encourage water conservation and fairness.

site_title: NTU co-develops world's first automated gondola
summary: NTU Singapore and ELID Technology International have co-developed the world's first automated gondola system, OutoBot, which can wash and paint high-rise buildings. The system, equipped with a robotic arm, camera, and high-pressure water jets, aims to improve productivity and enhance workplace safety. With wireless controls, OutoBot can halve the manpower needed to operate one gondola, saving up to 20% of paint and reducing painting time by 30%. The system also enables older workers to continue contributing despite their advanced years, addressing Singapore's rapidly ageing workforce.

site_title: Trump wins Saudi prince praise for 'turning point' in ties
summary: US President Donald Trump welcomed Saudi Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to the White House, marking a "historic turning point" in bilateral relations, according to a senior adviser to the crown prince. The meeting aimed to breathe life into the decades-old alliance, with a significant shift in relations across all fields. The adviser expressed optimism that the meeting had put things "on the right track." The move is seen as a positive development for Saudi Arabia, which seeks to strengthen its ties with the US.

site_title: Losses in heavyweights drag STI down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 5.97 points, or 0.19%, to 3,137.43, as investors paused ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Asian equities were mostly down, with heavyweights such as Jardine Matheson and DBS suffering losses. The US Fed's decision is expected to impact borrowing costs and the value of companies, with a rate hike potentially raising debt-servicing burdens and making companies less valuable.

site_title: Neiman Marcus in talks with Hudson's Bay: source
summary: Neiman Marcus, a struggling US high-end retailer, is in talks to sell itself to Hudson's Bay Co, a Canadian retail giant. A potential deal would unite Neiman Marcus with Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor, creating a luxury retail powerhouse. The discussions come as the department store industry faces unrest. The terms of the proposed sale have not been disclosed, but a deal would likely have significant implications for the US luxury retail market.

site_title: Bankers go from pariahs to hopeful politicians in Trump's capital
summary: US President Donald Trump is filling his administration with former finance executives, shifting the perception of bankers in Washington. The American Bankers Association is launching a program to groom its members for public office, hosting a two-day workshop in September for $250. The program aims to increase bankers in Congress, with only 18 of 535 members having a banking background. This move may aid Republican efforts to roll back the Dodd-Frank Act, but bankers still face public skepticism due to scandals like Wells Fargo's account opening issues.

site_title: The other Airbnbs: alternative home-sharing rentals
summary: Alternative home-sharing rentals have emerged as a response to the growing popularity of Airbnb, targeting specific niches and providing a more curated experience. Companies like OneFineStay and Oasis offer hotel-like management, vetting properties based on design, cleanliness, and location. Services catering to specific groups, such as gay travelers (Mister B&B) and travelers of color (Noirbnb), also exist. Meta search engines like Tripping.com help centralize listings, and non-commercial services like Servas International and Homestay offer affordable, free hosted home sharing options. The home rental market is expected to continue growing, with projected revenues reaching $37 billion in 2018.

images.alt_text: Many vacation rental groups focus on a specific region. Perfect Experiences, for example, offers a portfolio of apartment rentals in Paris; London; Provence, France; and Italy along with concierge services to design day trips and tours.

site_title: Fresh leak shows Trump's US$38m tax bill in 2005
summary: US President Donald Trump paid around $38 million in taxes in 2005, according to a leaked tax return. The White House confirmed the details, which showed Trump and his wife Melania paid 4% in federal income tax, but also paid an additional $31 million in the alternative minimum tax.
