To address the issue, both men and women are needed to take responsibility, with men advocating for female representation and women seeking mentors and sponsors.

site_title: Problems aplenty for deeply divided South Korea in post-Park era
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court unanimously removed President Park Geun-hye from office, making her the country's first democratically elected leader to be forced out. The removal came after a months-long scandal involving Park's ties to a friend with no security clearance, who allegedly used her influence to extort bribes from large conglomerates. The country gears up for a snap presidential election by May 9, with human rights lawyer Moon Jae-in as the likely frontrunner to address the nation's economic and political woes, including sluggish growth, rising household debt, and strained relations with North Korea and the US.

site_title: Changi Airport named world's best airport for 5th year running
summary: Changi Airport has been named the world's best airport for the fifth consecutive year, beating Tokyo's Haneda airport and South Korea's Incheon International Airport in the 2017 World Airport Awards. This marks the airport's continued success in providing an exceptional travel experience to air passengers.

site_title: Trump to announce review of vehicle emissions rules: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to announce a review of vehicle fuel efficiency rules, which were established by the Obama administration. The rules, which apply to 2022-2025 vehicles, were met with resistance from carmakers who claim they are too expensive and out of step with consumer demand. Trump will visit an autonomous vehicle testing facility in Michigan on Wednesday to meet with CEOs of major carmakers, including General Motors and Ford, to discuss the review. The move is seen as a victory for carmakers and a potential boost to employment in the sector.

site_title: Trump orders review of govt structure to cut size, cost
summary: US President Donald Trump has ordered a review of the federal government's structure to reduce its size and cost, citing duplication and redundancy. The order requires agencies to submit reorganisation plans, including proposed cuts, and comes as the administration freezes federal hiring. This marks the latest attempt by a new president to overhaul the federal government, following previous efforts by Bill Clinton and Ronald Reagan, which were met with resistance from Congress.

site_title: Morgan Stanley on tech hiring drive to help its advisers upgrade skills
summary: Morgan Stanley is hiring hundreds of tech specialists to train advisers on its new digital tools, including software that recommends customized investment ideas and apps for client communication. The effort aims to help financial advisers upgrade their skills and promote a digital presence through social media. This move reflects a broader industry push to keep wealth management relevant to younger Americans who prefer digital options, as traditional brokerages and human advisers face declining relevance.

site_title: US carrier joins South Korea drills; North Korea warns of 'merciless' strikes
summary: The US Navy's USS Carl Vinson has joined South Korean naval drills, sparking a warning from North Korea that it will launch "merciless" strikes if the carrier infringes on its sovereignty. The drills come amid rising tensions over North Korea's nuclear tests and missile launches, with the US and South Korea saying the exercises are defensive in nature. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is set to visit South Korea on Friday, as China opposes the deployment of an advanced US anti-missile system in the region.

site_title: Facebook blocks developers from using its data for spying
summary: Facebook has barred developers from using its data to create surveillance tools, following criticism from the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) over police using location data to spy on protesters. The move aims to create a safer community for users to express themselves. The change comes after Geofeedia, a data vendor, was found to have worked with law enforcement agencies to track protesters in Ferguson, Missouri. Twitter and other social media platforms have also implemented similar policies.

site_title: Oil slides as crude stocks mount, US dollar strengthens
summary: Oil prices fell 1.4% to $47.72 a barrel and 0.8% to $50.92 a barrel, amid rising crude stocks and a surprise output jump from Saudi Arabia. The US dollar strengthened ahead of a possible Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Energy shares declined 1.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.21% and the S&P 500 lost 0.34%. Investors await the Fed's decision and the outcome of Dutch elections, which may impact the US dollar and euro.

images.alt_text: Falling oil prices weighed on energy shares on Tuesday in the wake of a report of rising crude stocks, while the US dollar strengthened ahead of an expected Federal Reserve decision to raise interest rates.

site_title: The outlook for China equities is optimistic
summary: Morgan Stanley's recent Blue Paper "Why We Are Bullish on China" suggests that Chinese equities can continue to outperform emerging markets, driven by structural and cyclical factors. Over the last 15 years, MSCI China has outperformed MSCI EM by 3% per year, with a cumulative outperformance of 5,000 basis points. The paper highlights the growth of non-state-owned firms, which have higher revenue growth and less leverage, and identifies 50 Chinese "unicorns" in new economy sectors. With valuations reasonable and long-term institutional capital moving into the market, the outlook for China equities is optimistic, with a forecast of low teens earnings growth in 2017 and a potential 10% premium by the end of the year.

site_title: New tack needed for foreign firms in China as Xi boosts Party grip
summary: Multinational companies in China are shifting their government relations strategy as President Xi Jinping strengthens the Communist Party's grip on policy-making. The Conference Board research group is publishing a study on the "changing dynamic of party-state relations" to help companies navigate China's complex political landscape. With Xi centralizing power, companies are now focusing on party organs and leading small groups, bypassing the State Council and other government agencies. This shift points to a broader change in China's political landscape, with the party's role in policy design and implementation becoming more prominent.

site_title: EU court rules workplace ban on headscarves legal
summary: The European Union's top court, the European Court of Justice, has ruled that workplace bans on headscarves and other religious symbols are legal, citing neutrality and equal treatment of employees. The ruling applies to companies with internal rules banning such symbols, and rights groups have expressed disappointment, warning it could encourage further discrimination. The decision has been welcomed by some European politicians, who see it as a victory for European values.

site_title: Turkey slaps sanctions on Dutch, rejects EU criticism
summary: Turkey has downgraded relations with the Netherlands, suspending high-level ties and banning its ambassador from returning, after the Netherlands prevented two Turkish ministers from holding rallies ahead of a referendum on strengthening President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's powers. The move comes amid escalating tensions between Turkey and the EU, with Erdogan accusing German Chancellor Angela Merkel of "supporting terrorists." The dispute risks harming Turkey's EU bid, which has been ongoing for half a century.

site_title: JPMorgan notifies clients of retirement account change
summary: JPMorgan Chase has sent letters to 5% of its clients managing $1.1 trillion in assets, informing them they may be moved to the bank's self-directed platform ahead of a pending Labor Department retirement regulation. The regulation aims to eliminate potential conflicts of interest for advisers by putting the interests of retirement investors first. Clients have the option to pay a financial adviser a flat fee or manage their retirement accounts online. The move is part of JPMorgan's plan to end retirement accounts that pay financial adviser commissions, announced in November.

site_title: Intel's US$15b purchase of Mobileye shakes up driverless car sector
summary: Intel agreed to buy Israeli autonomous vehicle technology firm Mobileye for $15.3 billion, entering direct competition with Nvidia and Qualcomm in the driverless car sector. The acquisition could propel Intel into the front ranks of automotive suppliers and fuel the arms race among carmakers to acquire autonomous vehicle technology. The deal, valued at 21 times expected 2017 revenue, represents a premium of 60 times Mobileye's earnings, with shares rising 28.2% to close at $60.62.

images.alt_text: Intel will integrate its own automated driving group with Mobileye's operations under Mobileye chairman Amnon Shashua, who will lead the unit from Israel.

site_title: Kushners set to get US$400 million from Chinese firm in Manhattan office tower deal
summary: US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner's family is set to receive over $400 million from Chinese firm Anbang Insurance Group for a Manhattan office tower at 666 Fifth Ave. The $4 billion transaction includes favorable terms, such as a cash payout and an equity stake, and would slash the existing mortgage to about a fifth of its value. The deal has raised national security concerns due to Anbang's murky links to the Chinese power structure and Kushner's close ties to the Trump administration. The partnership is also seeking additional investors through the EB-5 programme.

images.alt_text: Mr Kushner is married to Mr Trump's daughter Ivanka. As one of the president's closest advisers, he could have input on a wide range of issues affecting China, from national security concerns and territorial disputes to trade matters and allegations of currency manipulation.

site_title: Study finds weak links in more than 10 devices that hackers can exploit
summary: Researchers at the University of Michigan and the University of South Carolina discovered vulnerabilities in over half of the 20 commercial accelerometer brands tested, allowing hackers to control or influence devices such as smartphones, fitness monitors, and automobiles. The flaw, which can be exploited through tiny accelerometers, enables malicious actors to add extra steps to a Fitbit monitor or control a smartphone's speaker to interfere with software. The discovery highlights the security challenges in complex systems with analogue and digital components, and potential risks in self-driving cars and medical devices.

site_title: Veteran fund manager sees potential in Asia supply chain
summary: Veteran fund manager Elizabeth Soon of PineBridge Investments sees potential in Asia supply chain manufacturers, particularly those with close relationships to well-known international brand names. She calls these companies "branded OEMs" and notes that they have consolidated due to the need for efficient and nimble supply chains. Despite rising protectionism, companies with multiple sourcing locations are expected to do better, and Soon has invested in these companies since 2010. She is selective within the OEM sector, looking for companies with strong research and development and good management quality.

site_title: MAS: Don't trade in binary options on unregulated platforms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned against trading in binary options on unregulated platforms due to high-risk and speculative nature. MAS states that investors may lose their entire investment, regardless of the platform's regulation. The regulator has received complaints from investors who lost over S$1 million to unregulated platforms based outside Singapore. MAS advises consumers to deal only with regulated entities and provides a financial institutions directory and investor alert list online to check the legitimacy of trading platforms.

site_title: VES to hurt mass-market buyers more than super-luxury
summary: The new Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) in Singapore will benefit high-end car buyers while hurting mass-market buyers, who may face higher surcharges and lose rebates. The scheme, replacing the current Carbon Emissions-based Vehicle Scheme, will lower the maximum surcharge cap from 230 g/km to 185 g/km and tighten standards for petrol engines. This may lead to a surge in COE (Certified Emissions-Based) purchases, particularly for affordable cars, as buyers seek to secure lower prices before the new scheme takes effect in 2018.

site_title: Vibrant Q3 hit by sharp drop in 'other income'
summary: Vibrant Group reported a 85.2% plunge in Q3 net profit to S$1.3 million, despite a 23.6% rise in revenue, primarily due to an 80.5% drop in "other income" to S$3.2 million. Profit from operations fell 84.8% to S$2.3 million. The sharp decline in "other income" was the chief cause of the profit drop.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: US producer prices rise broadly in February
summary: US producer prices increased 0.3% in February, the largest gain in nearly five years, driven by rising crude oil prices and a firming global economy. The year-on-year gain of 2.2% is the largest since March 2012, ahead of the 2.0% forecast. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise its overnight benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points, tracking a measure of inflation at 1.7%, as it aims to maintain its 2% inflation target.

site_title: Playing the jobs number game
summary: US President Donald Trump's response to the Labor Department's jobs report, which showed a 4.7% unemployment rate, is inconsistent with his past claims that the reports were "phony" and "a hoax." In 2015 and 2016, Trump said the unemployment rate was much higher, citing labor force participation rates and alternative measures. Trump's change in stance has raised questions about his commitment to economic facts, with critics arguing that his administration is spinning reality. The jobs report's positive numbers, including a rise in hourly earnings and employment among low-skilled workers, have boosted market confidence and driven investment.

site_title: EU reporting rule on emissions looms large
summary: The European Union's Maritime Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (EU MRV) regulation, which requires shipowners to monitor and report their carbon emissions, is set to come into effect on August 31, 2017. The regulation, which was introduced in 2015, requires ships exceeding 5,000 gross tonnage to record and report their fuel use on all voyages to, from and between EU ports. Shipowners must obtain accreditation from an independent verifier by the end of August to comply with the regulation, which has been met with skepticism by the shipping industry.

site_title: Commonwealth Games seek new 2022 host after Durban debacle
summary: The Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) is seeking a new host for the 2022 edition after South Africa's Durban bid failed to meet key obligations, including signing a contract agreement and having a local organising committee in place. The CGF had previously indicated that the South African government and the CGF had not reached agreement over costs, with a budget of 6.4 billion rand (S$685.9 million) already set aside. The mayor of Liverpool has expressed interest in hosting the Games, and the CGF will continue to explore alternative options.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers postpone vote on embattled resources minister
summary: Philippine lawmakers have postponed a vote to confirm Regina Lopez as the country's resources minister, citing a need for more information. Lopez, an environmentalist, was appointed by President Rodrigo Duterte in June to oversee the closure of over half the nation's mines to protect watersheds. The delay will allow Duterte to reappoint Lopez, with further confirmation hearings expected in May. Industry groups have expressed concerns over Lopez's actions, which have caused division among miners and affected 1.2 million people.

site_title: Five Panoil bunker tankers suspended
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has temporarily suspended the harbour craft licences of five bunker tankers operated by Panoil Petroleum Pte Ltd due to irregularities in their piping fixtures. The tankers were found to have inconsistencies between actual piping structures and submitted drawings. Panoil attributed the issue to technical deficiencies, but expects to resolve the problems in one to two weeks. The suspension affects bunker deliveries, ship-to-ship operations, and port movements. The MPA's use of automated Mass Flow Metering (MFM) systems is seen as a significant improvement for efficiency and accuracy in Singapore's bunkering business.

site_title: Banks tussle for the brightest from the Class of 2017
summary: Banks in Singapore are competing to hire 1,500-2,000 fresh graduates, with some offering permanent positions only after internships. The competition is fierce, with banks using unique recruitment strategies such as hackathons, sky picnics, and pop-up cafes. Only about 10% of applicants make it to the final stage, with the best candidates typically selected for the banks' selective graduate programmes. This year, banks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC plan to hire large numbers of graduates, with DBS aiming to hire 450 and UOB expecting 500.

images.alt_text: Investment bank JP Morgan opened a pop-up Careers Cafe on the Singapore Management University campus last week. It said that visible events like this can attract students from across multiple disciplines.

site_title: On Netflix, the borders remain open
summary: Netflix has expanded its US offerings with new TV series from Argentina, Britain, Canada, Japan, Mexico, South Korea, Spain, and Turkey, showcasing the platform's aggressive programming of foreign content. Notable additions include "Fauda" from Israel and "Nobel" from Norway, both offering gritty, naturalistic thrillers that differ from typical American TV. These shows demonstrate Netflix's potential impact and its ability to acquire high-quality content, offering viewers a more diverse and international television experience.

site_title: PropNex Realty launches regional franchise
summary: PropNex Realty, Singapore's largest homegrown agency, is launching a regional franchise model, starting with Indonesia, where it has already garnered 600 property agents across seven agencies. The company aims to cross 1,000 agents by the end of this year and 2,000 agents by next year. This move follows a 17-year history of operation in Singapore and comes after a successful introduction of Singapore projects in Indonesia last year. PropNex hopes to replicate its success in Indonesia and expand to Vietnam, leveraging a master franchise concept.

site_title: China's economy gets off to strong start in 2017 as investment rebounds
summary: China's economy started 2017 on a strong note, with fixed-asset investment expanding 8.9% in the first two months, largely due to infrastructure spending and a rebound in private investment. Growth in private investment more than doubled from 2016, while industrial output rose 6.3%. However, economists caution that the pace may slow as the central bank takes a tighter stance on credit and exporters face US protectionism. China's GDP growth is expected to accelerate to 7% year-on-year, but may eventually slow due to the fading effect of last year's stimulus.

site_title: Owners of genealogy website Ancestry.com weighing 2017 IPO: sources
summary: Private equity owners of genealogy website Ancestry.com, including Permira and Silver Lake, are weighing an initial public offering (IPO) for the company in 2017. The owners, who also include Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, have held talks with banks and are taking pitches from potential advisers. Ancestry.com, which began in 1983, was taken private in 2012 and has since seen significant investments, including a US$2.6 billion valuation. No final decision has been made, and the owners may opt to keep the business private.

site_title: STI drifts amid falls in HK, Dow futures
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) drifted 3.75 points lower to 3,143.40 on Tuesday amid a quiet trading session, awaiting the outcome of the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting. Despite gains in banks and Jardine Matheson, falls in property stocks dragged the index down. Analysts expect a 100% chance of a US rate hike this week, with some predicting multiple hikes this year, potentially impacting Singapore's banking and real estate sectors.

site_title: Dollar climbs ahead of expected Fed rate increase
summary: The US dollar rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate increase, climbing to 101.67 due to concerns over European politics and the Brexit process. The euro fell to $1.0644, while sterling slipped to $1.2110, its lowest in eight weeks. The dollar's gain was attributed to uncertainty in European politics and the Fed's potential hawkish message, with expectations of a rate hike this year increasing to four.

site_title: Hollywood gets caught up in Beijing's crackdown on overseas deals
summary: Chinese companies' overseas acquisitions, particularly in the entertainment industry, are slowing down due to increased scrutiny from the Chinese government, which aims to stem capital outflows and keep the yuan stable. Deals such as Dalian Wanda Group's $1 billion acquisition of Dick Clark Productions and MGM Holdings' $4.6 billion takeover are collapsing or stalled. US lawmakers have called for the government to slow the pace of Chinese companies buying American media targets, citing the "vice created by regulatory authorities" in both China and the US.

site_title: Banks must make tough choices now
summary: Retail banks are struggling to function as thriving businesses, eight years after the financial crisis, due to macro challenges such as regulations and sluggish economic growth. Fintech companies are disrupting the industry, forcing banks to consider new strategies. To succeed, banks must make strategic choices, including focusing on core activities, building digital platforms, or transforming into agile, innovative companies. Effective strategies include the "Relationship Master," "Back-end Utility," "Digital Category Killer," "Digital Scale Insurgent," or "Cash Conservationist" approach, as banks can no longer afford to keep all options open.

site_title: HK regulators investigating realtors over overseas property sales
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission is investigating realtors selling overseas properties for potential breaches of securities laws. The investigation follows complaints from at least 15 investors who lost money on uncompleted UK developments, with some reporting guaranteed rental income schemes. The regulator is reviewing whether real estate agencies are properly disclosing the risks and regulatory requirements associated with such deals, with existing home prices reaching an all-time high in the city.

site_title: Republican plan leaves 14m fewer with health insurance in 2018: US budget office
summary: A Congressional Budget Office analysis projects that the Republican plan to replace Obamacare would leave 14 million fewer Americans with health insurance by 2018, rising to 24 million by 2026. The plan would reduce the federal deficit by $337 billion over a decade, but average health coverage premiums would rise 15-20% for individual policy holders. The plan's phase-out of Medicaid expansion by 2020 would save $880 billion. The CBO's projection is seen as a blow to President Trump's repeal-and-replace plan, which already faces opposition from within his own party.

site_title: IMF head warns of 'self-inflicted injuries' hurting economic recovery
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that the global economy is at risk of "self-inflicted injuries" due to protectionist policies, urging G-20 leaders to promote inclusive growth and avoid measures that undermine trade and migration. Lagarde highlighted the need for targeted education programs, skills training, and employment incentives to equip lower-skilled workers for better-paying jobs. She also emphasized the importance of life-long learning to prepare citizens for technological changes, citing Singapore as a model. The IMF sees the global economy moving into a better position, but cautions that policy choices will determine its future trajectory.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings has been awarded a $44 million charter contract for its liftboat, the AOS Maintainer I, by a Middle Eastern national oil company for a one-year firm charter with two one-year extension options in the Arabian Gulf.

site_title: Resale prices for condos up for 4th month in a row: SRX report
summary: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore rose 0.9% month-on-month in February 2017, marking the fourth consecutive month-on-month gain. The Core Central Region saw a 1% increase, followed by 0.9% in the Outside Central Region, and 0.8% in the Rest of Central Region. The overall resale price index for private apartments and condos climbed 1.8% year-on-year, with 694 units likely resold in February, a 31.2% month-on-month increase.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Wall St speculators smell money as malls get mauled
summary: Wall Street speculators are betting on a US credit crisis centered on struggling malls, with hedge funds positioning to profit from potential defaults. Commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) backed by loans to mall operators have seen short positions surge to $5.3 billion, a 50% jump from last year. Analysts predict losses of up to 50% for the BBB- and BB-rated notes if mall defaults increase. Several firms, including Alder Hill Management and Deutsche Bank, have recommended buying credit protection on the securities, citing the high concentration of loans to regional malls and shopping centers.

site_title: Search for JV partners in Malaysian petrochem project continues
summary: Petronas Chemicals Bhd, a Malaysian state energy company, is in talks with petrochemical firms from Asia and Europe to invest in a US$27 billion oil refining and petrochemical project. Despite at least three previous deals falling through, companies from Japan, South Korea, and Italy have expressed interest in joining the project. The company plans to increase capital spending by up to a quarter and aims to raise production capacity of basic chemicals to 16 million tonnes a year by 2020. Saudi Arabian Oil Co has already invested US$7 billion, and talks with Saudi Aramco began in 2014.

site_title: Singapore's general insurance industry growth slows in 2016
summary: Singapore's general insurance industry experienced a 0.6% growth in total gross premiums to S$3.7 billion in 2016, slower than the 1.1% rise in 2015. The industry's growth was impacted by intense competition and economic maturity, with higher gross premiums in some segments offsetting a decline in the work injury and compensation business. The General Insurance Association attributed the slowdown to these factors.

site_title: Emerging markets aren't rattled by Trump or Fed hikes
summary: Emerging markets remain relatively resilient despite US President Donald Trump's unpredictable policies and the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes. Strategists like Kamakshya Trivedi of Goldman Sachs and Dirk Willer of Citigroup attribute this to emerging economies' strong positions to withstand higher interest rates, low inflation, and growing growth rates. Investors are optimistic about emerging markets, with flows into bond funds and equities reaching record highs, and are cautious about the potential risks of Trump's protectionist agenda.

site_title: China property sales surge despite efforts to cool market
summary: China's property sales surged 25.1% year-over-year in January and February, despite government efforts to cool the market. Real estate investment grew 8.9% in the same period, easing from a 11.1% increase in December. The surge in property sales and investment growth contrasts with government measures to curb the market, which include restrictions on buying and ownership. Authorities aim to keep the market stable, with a target of 6.5% economic growth in 2017, down from 6.9% in 2016.

site_title: Machinery for Brexit to start churning before end of March
summary: The UK has triggered Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, starting the Brexit process, with the Brexit Bill passed in parliament. The move comes after nine months of negotiations following the June 2016 referendum. The UK will begin negotiations with the EU, which faces internal divisions and economic difficulties. The pound has depreciated, boosting exports but accelerating inflation, and the UK will face uncertainty from potential referendums in Scotland and Northern Ireland. The UK's prime minister will have to navigate these challenges while negotiating with 27 EU member states, with key governments set to change.

site_title: Candidates for HK leadership race square off in heated TV debate
summary: In a heated televised debate, Hong Kong's three candidates vying for leadership squared off, with former financial secretary John Tsang emerging as the apparent winner. Tsang traded jabs with rivals Carrie Lam and Woo Kwok-hing, showcasing his deft handling of questions and remarks. A live poll showed 58% of online readers favored Tsang, while Lam received 33%. Analysts believe Tsang's performance will impact the March 26 Election Committee polls, with Lam's admission that she would resign if her views diverged from the mainstream seen as a crucial mistake.

site_title: Soaring Australia home prices could lead to more curbs
summary: Australia's soaring home prices, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne, could lead to further curbs on mortgage lending to investors, Reserve Bank assistant governor Michele Bullock said. Sydney house prices have surged 105% since 2009, while Melbourne's have also increased. Regulators are monitoring the effects of earlier measures and may consider introducing tighter debt service caps or higher buffers on serviceability rates to address system-wide risks. The Reserve Bank is also considering how monetary policy can factor in financial stability issues in a low-interest rate environment.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore retail sales rose 2% year-over-year in January, driven by supermarkets and F&B sales growth. However, retailers face high operating costs, particularly labor and rent. Consumer confidence index dropped 2 points to 86 in Q4 2016. The Singapore Exchange has introduced a new general mandate for rights issues, allowing companies to raise funds more efficiently. China Everbright Water secured a PPP project worth over S$225 million, expanding its portfolio of integrated water projects.

site_title: Bid for Super Group fair and reasonable: IFA
summary: Independent financial adviser SAC Capital advises Super Group's independent directors that the offer by Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE) to take the instant food and beverage maker private at S$1.30 per share is "fair and reasonable". The offer price represents a 62.5% premium over the counter's closing share price of 80 Singapore cents on October 4, 2016. JDE has secured acceptances from Super's major shareholders holding a combined 60% stake, and the offer closes on April 11.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: IATA still wary of protectionism after positive meeting with US officials
summary: IATA remains concerned about protectionist rhetoric from the US and other governments, despite a positive meeting with US officials. The organization sees the US administration's plans to invest in infrastructure as a positive development for the industry. However, IATA is heavily concerned about plans to raise barriers on borders for trade and travel. The organization notes that US President Trump's travel ban caused chaos and confusion, but IATA has not seen a significant impact on demand for travel to and from the US. IATA expects a decline in airline industry profits this year due to rising costs.

site_title: Modest growth in new business activity for Prudential Singapore
summary: Prudential Singapore reported modest growth in new business activity for 2016, with annual premium equivalent sales increasing by 1% to £351 million (S$603.2 million). The company's life new business profit rose 11% to £3.09 billion, driven by strong growth in Asia. Meanwhile, the group's overall profit was down 32% due to weaker UK operations and higher tax charges. Despite this, Prudential's Asian asset manager, Eastspring Investments, saw assets under management reach £117.9 billion, a new high.

site_title: Taiwan ex-leader Ma faces new charges over leaks scandal
summary: Taiwan's former president Ma Ying-jeou has been slapped with new charges over a leaks scandal just weeks before a possible conviction in a related case. Ma, who was protected by political immunity while in office, faces additional charges, following a controversy over leaked documents.

site_title: Russia's migrant workers live under the radar
summary: Russia's migrant workers, mostly from Central Asia, make up 15% of the workforce and face low pay, mistreatment, and discrimination. Despite anti-immigrant sentiment, the government relies on immigrant labor for the country's economic recovery. Immigrants play a key role in manufacturing, retail, and service sectors, but restrictive policies and lack of documentation leave them vulnerable. The government has deported some immigrants, but economic imperatives always take precedence, and populist laws are often adopted to appease public sentiment. The workers' struggles highlight the need for better labor protections and addressing the root causes of their exploitation.

site_title: Iceland lifts last capital curbs from financial crisis
summary: Iceland has lifted its last capital curbs, ending nearly 9 years of controls on businesses and citizens after its banks collapsed during the 2008 financial crisis. The move aims to attract foreign investment and improve economic prospects. However, the end of controls has led to a decline in the Icelandic crown, which dropped about 1% against the US dollar and euro. Authorities have prepared for the transition by amassing 815 billion Icelandic crowns in currency reserves. The move is expected to open the way for investment by Icelandic pension funds abroad.

site_title: Addressing weaknesess in the judicial management process
summary: Singapore's judicial management process is intended to rescue financially distressed companies, but it has failed many in the past. The system allows a court-supervised rescue plan to restore companies to financial health, but it can be biased towards major creditors and may not prioritize the interests of small investors. The process can also lead to indiscriminate sales of company assets, which can be detrimental to the company's long-term viability. With rising interest rates and trade barriers, Singapore should be prepared for more companies to resort to judicial management. The government should address these concerns to improve the process and ensure it benefits all stakeholders.

site_title: Western Canada shippers of natural gas given boost
summary: Western Canada natural gas shippers have accepted TransCanada's offer to move gas on its Mainline pipeline, granting them a boost against US shale basins. The deal includes lower tolls at a 10-year term for 1.5 petajoules of capacity per day, aiming to increase competitiveness in the Canadian market. TransCanada plans to file an application with the National Energy Board in April, with a hoped-in-service date of November 1, before rival pipelines from US shale basins come online. This move could help Western Canadian producers access the market and counter the "death spiral" of shippers leaving due to rising tolls.

site_title: India's Tata Group hires Bank of America dealmaker Ankur Verma
summary: Tata Group, India's largest conglomerate, has hired Bank of America dealmaker Ankur Verma as a senior vice president. Verma, 40, brings extensive experience in corporate planning, strategy, investment banking, and mergers and acquisitions. He joins the chairman's office after Natarajan Chandrasekaran took over as chairman last month, seeking to build a team to formulate group strategy. Verma's hire marks Tata Group's first major outside recruit since Chandrasekaran's takeover, and is part of the company's efforts to interview younger professionals with a long-term perspective.

site_title: Nigeria's plan to sell oft-bombed oil assets faces challenges: analysts
summary: Nigeria plans to sell stakes in oil fields, but analysts predict the process won't be straightforward due to the country's troubled track record with privatization and divestments. The government aims to sell stakes in joint-venture oil projects by 2020 to boost revenue and increase oil production to 2.5 million barrels per day. However, militant attacks have blighted the assets in the past year, and the proposal may face skepticism and delay. This sale could also diminish any windfall from a recovery in output and prices.

site_title: Swiber defaults on its bond coupon payout due on March 20
summary: Swiber Holdings defaults on a S$92 million bond coupon payment due on March 20, 2017. The company cited court-appointed judicial managers filing for an extension to send a statement of proposals to creditors. This comes after the company filed for an extension in court. The default is related to its Series 017 450 million yuan bond issued in 2017.

site_title: In the digital age, Paris revamps newsstands
summary: Paris has introduced a new design for its iconic newspaper kiosks, replacing the traditional domed structures that date back to the 1860s. The revamped kiosks retain the original's forest-green color and footprint while modernizing the space. This change is part of a larger effort to revamp newsstands in the city.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation gets US$44m liftboat contract
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings has secured a US$44 million contract with a Middle Eastern national oil company for its liftboat, the AOS Maintainer I. The one-year charter, with two one-year extension options, will support the NOC's operations in the Arabian Gulf. The vessel will undergo retrofitting work before deployment in early May. Despite the challenges in the oil and marine sector, the company continues to pursue its growth strategy, citing opportunities in the Middle East market. This contract follows previous long-term contracts secured in 2016, valued at about US$236 million.

site_title: Two insurers claim JPMorgan caused them over US$1b in losses
summary: Two insurance companies, Assured Guaranty and Ambac Assurance, claim JPMorgan Chase caused them over $1 billion in losses by assigning an inexperienced portfolio manager to two investment accounts filled with risky mortgage bonds in 2008. The portfolio manager, Mark Stancher, ignored guidelines to diversify holdings, despite numerous warning signs. JPMorgan argues that the selected assets had investment-grade ratings and significant due diligence was conducted. The trial is ongoing, with a New York State Supreme Court judge hearing the case without a jury.

site_title: Angels come aboard Spaceship
summary: Singapore-headquartered YCH Group's corporate venture arm, Supply Chain Angels, is investing in Spaceship, an urban logistics start-up. Spaceship offers on-demand storage services to businesses and individuals, addressing a largely untapped market in Singapore. The investment is a seven-figure amount, providing access to infrastructure, expertise, and contacts to enhance technology and product offerings. With the investment, Spaceship aims to grow rapidly and meet the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, complementing YCH's supply chain and logistic business.

site_title: Porsche clan said to consider Piech's exit after VW allegations
summary: Ferdinand Piech, a long-time influential figure at Volkswagen, is under pressure to step down from the supervisory board of Porsche Automobil Holding SE, a move that could mark the end of his storied career. Family members are discussing replacing Piech, who has held the position for over 20 years. This decision comes amid allegations against Volkswagen, potentially leading to Piech's last official role.

site_title: India's retail inflation picks up to 3.65% y/y in Feb
summary: India's annual consumer price inflation rose to 3.65% in February, driven mainly by food prices, exceeding economists' expectations of 3.58%. This marks a reversal from January's 3.17% inflation, the lowest in at least five years. Food inflation increased to 2.01% in February from 0.53% in January.

site_title: New, reimagined cruise ship to bring the outdoors in
summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd CEO Richard Fain has announced a new category of ship that brings stateroom balconies indoors, redefining the balcony experience. The Celebrity Edge-class ships, set to launch in December 2018, feature retractable floor-to-ceiling windows, expanding cabins and bathrooms, and innovative public spaces like the Magic Carpet, a mini-deck that serves different purposes throughout the day. The ships' prices have increased to $1 billion each, with suites offering luxury amenities like private plunge pools and Bulgari bath amenities.

site_title: China's new rules could spark strategy change for Forest City
summary: China's new foreign exchange policies may impact Country Garden's Forest City development in Malaysia, as the country tightly controls property sales to non-Chinese buyers. Despite 70% of buyers being from the mainland, Country Garden aims to diversify and attract other nationalities. The developer has sold US$2.1 billion worth of apartments in Forest City last year, with plans for 200,000 units. The Malaysian government has provided tax incentives and visa-friendly terms to support the project, but some locals are concerned about "ghost projects" and the development's potential impact on Malaysia's demographics.

site_title: Hedge funds exit emerging market assets as real money pours in
summary: Hedge funds are exiting emerging market assets ahead of a potential US interest rate hike, with short-term investors fleeing due to concerns over a strengthening dollar's impact on credit quality. In contrast, longer-term investors are increasing their exposure, citing undervalued equity and currency valuations. This divergence is the largest since October 2015, with Poland's zloty seeing significant real money inflows and hedge funds posting outflows. Institutional investors, however, remain optimistic about emerging markets, citing undervalued valuations and growth potential.

site_title: Toshiba puts off release of earnings
summary: Toshiba Corp has postponed the release of its earnings for the April-December 2016 period due to a huge loss from its nuclear power business. The company needs more time to investigate internal management issues at its US nuclear power business subsidiary, Westinghouse Electric. Toshiba initially postponed the announcement in February and will now submit its documents by April 11. The second postponement is related to allegations of improper pressure from Westinghouse's executive management to underestimate losses. Toshiba is likely to report a loss of $6.2 billion from its nuclear power business for the period.

site_title: Petronas warns on 2017 outlook despite swing to Q4 profit
summary: Malaysia's state-run oil company Petronas reported a fourth-quarter profit of 11.3 billion ringgit, reversing a 2.96 billion ringgit loss in the same quarter last year, driven by cost-cutting measures. Despite a cautious outlook for 2017, Petronas expects to maintain lower operating expenses and pursue cost-cutting measures to navigate the low oil price environment, with a budgeted oil price of US$45 a barrel for 2017.

site_title: China's coal consumption falls for third straight year
summary: China's coal consumption fell 4.7% in 2016, marking the third consecutive year of decline, according to official figures. The downward trend is expected to continue, with analysts attributing it to slower economic growth, international environmental commitments, and massive investments in renewables. The decline has significant implications, including billions of dollars worth of idle coal-powered plants and potential social shock due to massive unemployment. The government aims to curb coal production and meet its climate commitments, but faces the challenge of absorbing overcapacity, which is expected to persist until 2050.

site_title: VW CEO not ruling out merger talks with Fiat Chrysler boss
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller has not ruled out merger talks with Fiat Chrysler boss Sergio Marchionne, contradicting his previous statement. Mueller stated that he is open to a conversation about a possible merger, which would help share the costs of producing cleaner and technologically advanced vehicles. Mueller expressed confidence in Volkswagen's future, regardless of whether or not a merger occurs. This comes after Marchionne repeatedly expressed his desire for a merger, and Mueller acknowledged the need for Marchionne to communicate his considerations.

site_title: That fantastic parental-leave policy sweeping America? It isn't
summary: A nationwide survey found that many US companies have backed away from fully paid parental-leave policies, despite the trend of elite firms offering generous leave benefits. The percentage of companies offering full pay to new parents dropped from 17% to 10% between 2005 and 2016. Most companies now fund paid maternity leave through temporary disability insurance plans, which have a narrower scope and lower pay coverage. The lack of expansion in parental leave policies contradicts the perception of a rise in generous leave benefits among high-profile companies.

images.alt_text: Of 920 US employers with 50 or more employees that offer paid leave, the percentage offering full pay to new parents dropped from 17 to 10 per cent between 2005 and 2016.

site_title: FSL to fork out US$20m cash for loan pre-payment
summary: First Ship Lease (FSL) Trust will pre-pay US$20 million of its syndicated loan facility using available cash. The trust will also pledge a 2007 Japanese-built tanker, FSL Osaka, to the lenders as collateral. The loan prepayment is a strategic move to strengthen the trust's financial position and reduce its debt burden.

site_title: Infineon upgrades its Singapore plant into smart factory
summary: Infineon Technologies is investing 70 million euros in its Singapore plant to develop a "smart factory" by 2021. The smart factory will leverage automation, digitalisation, and data exchange to eliminate non-value-added tasks. The company aims to integrate its manufacturing value chain and adopt Industry 4.0 principles, featuring extensive use of IoT technology, cloud computing, and robotics. Infineon plans to introduce robots that can learn and reproduce process steps through observation, and will also use real-time global production networks and end-to-end digital integration.

site_title: Foreign manpower ratio not optimal: Asme's Kurt Wee
summary: Singaporean SMEs have expressed concerns over the foreign manpower ratio, with a post-Budget panel discussion revealing a majority of the audience voted to tweak the 2:1 ratio in favour of having more foreign labour. Asme president Kurt Wee proposed a ratio of 1:2 or one local to two foreigners, which he believes is still manageable and would give businesses more capacity. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Sim Ann emphasized the need for public discussion on the issue, citing the importance of business perspectives in shaping Singapore's society.

site_title: US producer prices climbed more than forecast in Feb
summary: US producer prices rose 0.3% in February, exceeding forecasts, and increased by 2.2% from February 2016, the largest year-over-year gain since March 2012. The majority of the increase was attributed to a 0.4% rise in services prices. Higher wholesale costs may lead to broader inflation, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The Fed's policy makers are expected to raise interest rates as inflation moves higher and the job market continues to improve.

site_title: Viz Branz eyeing relisting on SGX after 2013 privatisation
summary: Viz Branz, a maker of instant beverage mixes, is relisting on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after being privatized in 2013. The company, which focuses on China, aims to raise at least S$700 million to pay down debt and invest in a Myanmar joint venture. It plans to use IPO proceeds to set up a new production line in Myanmar and grow market share. The company's revenue expanded 3.8% to S$161.0 million in FY 2016, with net profit falling 30.4% to S$18.1 million.

site_title: Glencore tightens grip on zinc through deal with Canada's Trevali
summary: Glencore, a miner-trader, has tightened its grip on the global zinc market through a deal with Canada's Trevali, selling shares in two mines in Namibia and Burkina Faso for $400 million. The deal creates the first pure zinc company with a wide geographical reach, and Glencore will increase its direct holding in Trevali to 25% and secure exclusive rights to market its zinc. The move is seen as a strategic play to control zinc supply and is expected to boost production to approximately £410 million per year.

site_title: May says will notify parliament this month of Article 50 trigger
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced she will notify parliament later this month that she has triggered Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty, beginning the formal Brexit process. Legislation allowing her to trigger the divorce talks was passed by parliament on Monday. This move marks the start of the UK's formal withdrawal from the European Union.

site_title: US: Stocks fall, oil shares hit
summary: US stocks dropped early Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.1% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.2%. Oil prices fell, hitting petroleum-linked shares, and the US benchmark slipped below $50 a barrel. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates, which typically weigh on stocks. Petroleum-linked shares, including Chevron and Halliburton, plummeted, while Valeant Pharmaceuticals International fell 9.8% after an activist investor announced it was exiting the investment.

site_title: Why traders are cheering when they should be fearing
summary: Nobel Prize-winning economist Robert Shiller warns that traders are overly optimistic about the current market, citing a similar "new era story" in 2000 when investors were captivated by the Internet's transformative power. Shiller notes that today's game-changer is Donald Trump's "pro-business" agenda, which promises to slash regulations, cut taxes, and boost economic growth. This echoes the 2000 era, which ended poorly for bulls. Shiller's comments come as the S&P 500 reaches a record high, raising concerns about the market's sustainability.

site_title: Tampines plot tipped for a good turnout
summary: A 2.2-hectare private housing site in Tampines Avenue 10 is expected to draw strong interest with up to 15 bids despite its mediocre location. Developers' appetite for land and improving sentiment in the residential property market, fueled by recent sales results and eased seller's stamp duty, are driving confidence among bidders. The site is set to close on April 25 at a state tender.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Lynette Leong taking CapitaLand Commercial Trust to greater heights
summary: Singaporean businesswoman Lynette Leong, CEO of CapitaLand Commercial Trust Management, emphasizes the benefits of women in the boardroom, citing a feminine touch, attention to detail, and intuition as valuable assets. She attributes her success in a high-stakes deal to these qualities, which helped her remain calm and resolve the situation. Leong has led CapitaLand Commercial Trust to significant growth, including the development of the iconic CapitaGreen building, which garnered international awards. She plans to replicate this success with the redevelopment of the Golden Shoe Car Park, aiming to create a modern, flexible workspace for the future. Despite current market challenges, Leong expects a turnaround in the near term, driven by demand for quality office space and a potential sharp rebound in the market.

images.alt_text: Lynette Leong, the woman at the helm of CapitaLand Commercial Trust Management, believes that women should always play to their strengths.

site_title: Oil held losses below US$49 a barrel
summary: Oil prices held losses below $49 a barrel ahead of US data expected to show record crude inventories. Futures were little changed in New York after a 9.2% decline in the previous six sessions. US stockpiles likely increased by 3 million barrels for a 10th week of gains. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is set to release its February production figures, amid concerns that rising US supply is threatening the six-month output-cutting deal.

site_title: Modi's win sends Indian stocks to record, rupee to 11-month high
summary: Indian stocks reached a record high after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's victory in state elections, with the NSE Nifty 50 Index rising 1.7% to 9,087. The rupee also climbed to an 11-month high, reaching 66.1950 per dollar. Modi's win is seen as a boost to his reform agenda, with analysts predicting a continuation of his policies and a higher probability of a BJP victory in the 2019 general elections.

site_title: In headscarf ruling, EU court allows religious symbol bans
summary: The European Union's top court ruled that employers can ban staff from wearing visible religious symbols, such as the Islamic headscarf, at work. The Court of Justice stated that internal rules prohibiting the wearing of such symbols do not constitute direct discrimination, but employers can consider customer preferences if they allow employees to wear the symbols. The decision was made on the eve of the Dutch election, where Muslim immigration was a key issue.

site_title: China-South Korea spat could boost Thai tourism: travel group
summary: Thailand's tourism sector is expected to gain from China-South Korea tensions, with Chinese tourists increasing by 15-20% to 80% of last year's levels. The ban on Chinese tour groups to South Korea, set to begin March 15, could further boost tourism in Thailand, which has been a rare bright spot in the country's economy. Chinese tourists account for 3% of Thailand's GDP and 12% of the country's overall tourism sector.

site_title: Trafigura US$500m perps six times subscribed
summary: Trafigura Group successfully subscribed US$3 billion of its US$500 million perpetual resettable step-up subordinated securities, exceeding initial demand six times. Institutional investors drove the strong demand, with a yield of 6.875% and non-callability until year five. This comes as the oil trader experiences growth in its Asia-based oil and petroleum products trading business.

site_title: Offer for Super Group 'fair and reasonable': IFA
summary: Dutch company JDE has launched a S$1.45 billion offer to privatize Singapore-based Super Group, a tea and coffee company. Independent financial adviser SAC Capital deemed the offer price of S$1.30 as "fair and reasonable" and advised Super's independent directors to recommend shareholders to accept the offer, unless they can obtain a higher price in the open market. The offer closes on April 11.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.55 points to 1,722.47. The index saw a trading volume of 3.92 billion lots worth RM3.25 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 473 to 444.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at more than 20-month high, won eases
summary: South Korean stocks reached a 20-month high, closing up 0.8% at 2,133.78 points, as investors ignored concerns over the country's political problems. The won also weakened, closing down 0.4% to 1,148.8 to the dollar ahead of the Federal Reserve's March policy meeting. Despite criticism of ousted leader Park Geun-hye, investors appeared to be putting aside their concerns, with the KOSPI reaching its highest level since May 2015.

site_title: Singapore stocks close slightly weaker as traders wait for FOMC direction
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 3.75 points lower at 3,143.40 on Tuesday, as traders awaited the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting. The index was boosted by gains in banks and Jardine Matheson, but dragged down by falls in property stocks. Turnover was 2.07 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 187 rises versus 291 falls. The market's directionless trading was attributed to uncertainty over the FOMC's direction.

site_title: Singapore port authority suspends licences of five bunker tankers
summary: Singapore's Maritime Port Authority has suspended harbour craft licences of five bunker tankers operated by Panoil Petroleum due to irregularities with piping fixtures. The five vessels will be barred from conducting bunker deliveries, ship-to-ship operations, or leaving the port until the issues are resolved. This suspension comes after Singapore mandated the use of mass flow metres on all bunker vessels licensed by MPA in 2017 to boost quality and transparency in the industry.

site_title: KrisEnergy names new COO
summary: KrisEnergy Limited has appointed Kelvin Tang as its new Chief Operating Officer (COO), effective March 15, 2017. Tang will remain as president of the Cambodia operations. Other changes include Sally Ting becoming general counsel, Chrystle Kuek taking over joint company secretary, and the departure of executive directors Richard Lorentz and Chris Gibson-Robinson from the board, effective April 24, 2017.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's condo resale prices rose 0.9% in February for the fourth straight month, according to SRX. The city-state was ranked as having the best infrastructure in the world by Mercer's survey. Singapore's Maritime Port Authority suspended licenses of five bunker tankers due to irregularities, while the MAS warned investors against trading binary options on unregulated platforms. The general insurance industry saw a 0.6% growth in 2016, slower than the previous year. SIA and SilkAir also announced a codeshare agreement with Vistara.

images.alt_text: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore rose 0.9 per cent month on month in February 2017, based on SRX Property's latest flash estimate.

site_title: US Fed due to meet with a rate hike on the cards
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to meet, potentially raising the benchmark interest rate as the US economy gains steam. The decision comes amid strong job creation and accelerating inflation, and could come sooner than expected. The Fed is likely to increase the key federal funds rate, with some predicting three rate hikes this year. The move aligns with President Donald Trump's pledge to boost economic growth and could have implications for expansionary economic policies.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge up at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher, with London's FTSE 100 advancing 0.1% to 7,374.34 points, and Paris's CAC 40 growing 0.1% to 5,006.05 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 remained unchanged. The markets await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, while US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: South Korea prosecutors to summon ex-president Park for questioning
summary: South Korean prosecutors plan to summon former President Park Geun-hye for questioning as a criminal suspect in connection with a corruption scandal. Park's impeachment was confirmed by the country's highest court last week, stripping her of presidential immunity. She is suspected of bribery and abuse of power for allegedly colluding with her secret confidante to extort money from companies, including Samsung. The exact timing and format of the questioning have yet to be decided.

site_title: BoE's Hogg resigns over failure to flag conflict of interest
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Charlotte Hogg has resigned after failing to declare a potential conflict of interest regarding her brother's role at Barclays. She admitted to not disclosing her brother's job guiding the bank's response to regulation until preparing information for lawmakers. The Bank of England Governor Mark Carney expressed regret over her decision, stating her professional competence did not meet the required standards. The Treasury Committee deemed her unsuitable for her role, citing her inability to fulfill the responsibilities of Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking.

images.alt_text: Bank of England Deputy Governor Charlotte Hogg has resigned for failing to declare a potential conflict of interest about her brother's role at a leading bank which had prompted a fierce rebuke from lawmakers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down, Fed meeting in focus
summary: Tokyo stocks declined, easing off a 15-month high, ahead of a key US central bank meeting. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.12% to 19,609.50 and the Topix index fell 0.16% to 1,574.90. Investors are taking cash off the table due to uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve meeting.

site_title: HK, China: Stocks end flat ahead of Fed
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Tuesday, following two days of gains, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's next policy meeting for clues on monetary policy plans. The Hang Seng Index edged down 1.72 points to 23,827.95, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.14%. The market is waiting for the Fed's conclusion to gauge its stance on interest rates and inflation.

site_title: Myanmar may be trying to 'expel' all Rohingya: UN expert
summary: A UN rights expert, Yanghee Lee, warns that Myanmar may be trying to "expel" all Rohingya Muslims from its territory, citing institutional persecution and horrific violence. The UN special rapporteur made the statement after a military crackdown in October, which resulted in women being gang-raped and Rohingya babies being slaughtered. Lee is calling for a high-level inquiry, a Commission of Inquiry, to investigate the crackdown and other violent episodes. However, some countries, including the European Union, have expressed concern that the investigation could threaten Myanmar's fragile democracy.

site_title: French Connection reports loss for fifth year in a row
summary: French Connection Group Plc reported a loss for the fifth consecutive year, prompting activist investor Gatemore Capital Management to suggest splitting the company. The retailer has closed stores and hired new management, but Chief Executive Stephen Marks remains committed to turning the group profitable. Despite a 4.4% increase in sales at stores open for over a year in the UK and Europe, the company's full-year revenue fell 6.7% to £153.2 million. Gatemore Capital Management believes the sum of French Connection's parts is worth more than the whole, leading to calls for a potential split or sale.

site_title: UK 2017 outlook lifted after consumers beat expectations
summary: The British Chambers of Commerce upgraded their UK growth projections to 1.4% in 2017, citing stronger-than-expected household spending. However, they cut their 2018 forecast to 1.3% and expect growth to slow in 2019. Consumers' spending will be boosted by the pound's 18% slump since the Brexit vote, but inflation will erode real wages. The economy is expected to contract 0.5% in investment this year due to Brexit uncertainty. Central bank policy makers are expected to keep borrowing costs low until the second half of 2017.

site_title: Prudential posts record operating profit in 2016, shares rise
summary: British insurer Prudential reported a record 2016 operating profit of £4.3 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. The firm's Asian business saw a 15% rise in operating profit to £1.6 billion. Prudential will pay a 12% higher dividend of 43.5 pence per share, driven by its expansion in Asia. The company's shares rose following the announcement.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir to codeshare with Vistara
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SilkAir have signed an agreement to codeshare on Indian domestic flights operated by Vistara, a joint venture between SIA and Tata. SIA will add its SQ code to Vistara flights to 10 Indian cities, while SilkAir will add its code to Vistara flights to six cities, adding four new destinations to SIA's network. Members of SIA and Vistara's frequent flyer programmes will enjoy additional tier benefits, including lounge access and increased baggage allowance.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore's general insurance industry growth slows in 2016
summary: Singapore's general insurance industry saw a 0.6% increase in total gross premiums to S$3.7 billion in 2016, slower than the 1.1% rise in 2015. The underwriting profit fell 16.8% to S$258 million, driven by margin compression. The industry's offshore insurance segment saw a 40% increase in gross premiums to S$1.9 billion, while motor insurance premiums remained flat at S$1.15 billion. Despite competition from new entrants, the industry delivered a "fair performance" according to GIA president AK Cher.

site_title: Prudential Singapore's FY16 APE flat, PVNBP up a notch
summary: Prudential Singapore reported flat annual premium equivalent (APE) activity in 2016, with a one-per-cent year-on-year increase to £351 million (S$603 million). Present value of new-business premiums (PVNBP) rose five per cent to £2.63 billion. The group's IFRS profit after tax decreased 32 per cent to £1.92 billion, while ordinary dividend per share increased 12 per cent to 43.5 pence. Asia's new business profit grew 22 per cent to £2.03 billion, driven by double-digit growth in eight markets.

images.alt_text: BRITISH insurer Prudential Singapore's new business activity measured on an European embedded value (EEV) and constant-exchange-rate basis, was flat in 2016.

site_title: Realtors investigated for Hong Kong overseas property sales
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission is investigating realtors for selling overseas properties, including UK developments, as potential collective investment schemes without necessary approval. Individuals have lost money on at least 15 uncompleted UK developments, with some real estate agencies touting guaranteed rental income to attract Asian investors. The regulator is expected to make an announcement on the cases soon, amid a rise in complaints about overseas property investments, with 276 people filing complaints with the police between 2014 and 2017.

site_title: China property sales surge despite govt efforts to cool market
summary: China's property sales surged 25.1% year-on-year in January and February, exceeding the 22.5% annual gain in 2016, despite government efforts to cool the market. Real estate investment grew 8.9% in the first two months of 2017, but showed signs of easing. The government has introduced restrictions on buying and ownership to curb overheating in the property market, but property speculators expect a relaxation of curbs if economic growth falters.

site_title: Toshiba crisis shines light on Japan corporate culture
summary: Toshiba's latest crisis highlights Japan's corporate culture, where unwavering employee loyalty can lead to disaster. The company's stock has halved since December due to allegations of accounting fraud and multi-billion-dollar losses. Analysts say misplaced loyalty and a structure prioritizing company reputation over transparency contribute to the scandal. Japan's post-war economic rise was built on lifetime employment, but this system has weakened over time, leading to a lack of accountability and poor corporate governance. Toshiba's troubles may be a symptom of a broader issue, with many questioning the effectiveness of Japan's corporate governance code and the need for a mindset shift in the labor system.

images.alt_text: The troubles at crisis-hit Toshiba are the latest in a string of business scandals that highlight how the backbone of Japan's corporate culture - unwavering employee loyalty - can sometimes lead to disaster, analysts say.

site_title: URA launches tender for private housing site in Tampines Ave 10
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 99-year leasehold private residential site along Tampines Avenue 10 (Parcel C) for sale by public tender. The 2.2 ha site may yield approximately 715 housing units. The tender for the land parcel will close at noon on April 25, 2017.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed before Fed as yen strengthens
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Tuesday as investors awaited a near-certain rate hike from the Federal Reserve this week. The yen strengthened, causing Japan's Topix index to slip, while Chinese equities rose in Hong Kong. Oil fell for a seventh day. The yield on 10-year Treasuries remained steady at 2.61%, and global stocks are close to a record high as analysts expect a faster pace of interest rate hikes.

site_title: Gold steady ahead of Fed meeting, expected US rate rise
summary: Gold prices remain steady ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, where a rate hike is widely expected. Investors anticipate signs of inflation and a strong US jobs market will convince the Fed to raise interest rates. While a rate hike is expected, signs of further rate rises in 2017 could weigh on gold. Spot gold remains unchanged at $1,203.16 per ounce, with prices supported by uncertainty surrounding European elections and a lack of clarity on US President Trump's policies.

site_title: China's retail sales up 9.5% in Jan-Feb: govt
summary: China's retail sales increased 9.5% in January and February, a deceleration from the previous period. Industrial output rose 6.3% and fixed-asset investment increased 8.9% during the same period. These data suggest policymakers are working to maintain China's economic growth on a stable path.

site_title: Malaysia censors 'gay moment' in Beauty and the Beast
summary: Malaysia has censored a "gay moment" in the Disney film "Beauty and the Beast" before its release. The film's director, Bill Condon, revealed that the scene features Disney's first exclusively gay moment, but some critics deemed it mild and fleeting. Malaysian Censorship Board chairman Abdul Halim Abdul Hamid approved the film with a minor cut, rating it PG-13. The film was initially postponed pending an internal review, but its release has been approved. Homosexuality is illegal in Malaysia, where laws can result in imprisonment and fines.

site_title: China's yuan weakens a notch, market awaits Fed meeting
summary: China's yuan weakened slightly against the US dollar, trading at 6.9173 per US dollar at midday, following the People's Bank of China's midpoint rate of 6.9118. Markets await the Federal Reserve's rate hike meeting and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's annual news conference. The offshore yuan was 0.21% firmer than the onshore spot. Despite China's steady growth, retail sales disappointed after a tax break was reduced on small cars.

site_title: BOJ expected to pull back from stimulus, maybe as early as this year: poll
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to start phasing out its ultra-easy monetary policy, according to a majority of economists polled by Reuters. The BOJ is likely to raise the 10-year Japanese Government bond yield target, currently set at around zero, in a move to signal a shift away from accommodative policy. This change is driven by growing inflation expectations, a rosier global economy outlook, and more stable oil prices. The move could be made as early as this year, marking a dramatic turnaround in expectations from just two months ago.

site_title: MAS issues warning on trading binary options on unregulated platforms
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has issued a warning to investors about trading binary options on unregulated platforms, following complaints from those who suffered losses. MAS described binary options as speculative and high-risk investments, contrary to promises of low investment risks with exceptionally high returns. This warning comes after a similar police warning at the end of last year. MAS urges investors to exercise caution and consider the risks involved before investing in binary options.

images.alt_text: MAS said on Tuesday that contrary to promises of low investment risks with exceptionally high returns, binary options are speculative and risky investment instruments.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise on technical buying; transport shares up
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.5% to 9,742.96, driven by technical buying and gains in transport shares due to lower oil prices. The electronics and financials subindices also increased. EVA Airways and China Airlines led the gains, while the Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.950 per US dollar.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars brace for Fed word on rate outlook
summary: The Australian dollar edged lower, 0.1% down, after a survey on domestic business conditions disappointed, while the New Zealand dollar remained steady ahead of expected US interest rate hikes. The Reserve Bank of Australia is concerned about cooling a debt-fuelled spike in home prices, with regulators considering tougher rules on bank lending for property investment. The Federal Reserve's policy decision on Wednesday is expected to signal further interest rate hikes, potentially pushing up Treasury yields and the US dollar.

site_title: 17 killed in China coal mine accident: state media
summary: Seventeen Chinese coal miners were killed in an accident at a state-operated mine in northeast China's Heilongjiang province. A mining cage's cable caught fire, causing it to fall into a shaft, and rescue workers were unable to reach the trapped miners until Monday. Two welders have been detained and the mine's manager suspended. This incident is the latest in a series of deadly accidents in China's coal-mining industry, with at least 59 people killed in separate incidents in December and September.

site_title: Malaysia to deport fifty North Koreans despite ban: deputy PM
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi announced the deportation of 50 North Koreans working in Sarawak, Borneo island, despite a ban imposed after the assassination of Kim Jong Nam. The decision comes as an exception to the ban, triggered by the killing of the half-brother of North Korea's leader. The deportation is seen as a gesture of goodwill amid the ongoing diplomatic tensions between Malaysia and North Korea.

site_title: Australia shares steady as rising miners duel falling financials; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares remained steady, rising 0.03% to 5,759.1, as miners benefited from rising metal prices but were offset by falls in financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,759.1, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia 0.2% higher and two other 'Big 4' banks losing 0.7%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.25% to 7,177.09, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's two-day meeting expected to bring interest rate hikes.

site_title: China industrial output offers fresh sign of stability
summary: China's industrial output growth remained stable in January and February, with a 6.3% year-on-year increase, beating forecasts. Retail sales grew 9.5% over the period, down from 10.2% in the same period last year. Fixed-asset investment also rose 8.9% year-on-year. The data suggests China's economy is starting the year on a positive note, but policymakers may need to implement pro-growth policies to support consumption. China's official economic growth target for 2017 is set at around 6.5%, or higher if possible.

site_title: Different strokes: Underwater hockey makes splash in Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's amateur underwater hockey team, "HK Typhoon," has gained popularity, competing in the China Cup tournament. Founded by 28-year-old Henry Chan, a former competitive swimmer, the team of 25 players aims to secure a spot in the world cup. They practice once a week, improving their skills and endurance, and review tactics and footage to analyze their performance. The sport, which requires players to hunt and hit a heavy plastic puck with a curved stick, has built a loyal fanbase in Asia and is gaining attention in Hong Kong.

site_title: Merkel postpones trip to meet Trump due to winter storm
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel postponed her trip to Washington to meet US President Donald Trump due to a winter storm hitting the northeastern US. The storm led to thousands of flight cancellations and school closures. The visit was rescheduled for Friday, with top executives from German companies also affected. Merkel, who has experience with weather-related travel disruptions, said the postponement could provide a personal "kickstart" for discussions on complex issues, including trade and security.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.31% in early trade on Tuesday, building on previous gains, as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting for guidance on interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,903.23, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.05%. The Shenzhen Composite Index remained stable. The gains come ahead of the Fed's meeting, which may provide clarity on the US interest rate trajectory.

site_title: Trump will donate his salary 'by year's end'
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to donate his annual presidential salary of $400,000 to charity by year's end, according to White House spokesman Sean Spicer. Trump made the pledge during his presidential campaign and has since decided to proceed with the donation. This move follows a tradition set by former presidents Herbert Hoover and John F Kennedy, who also donated their salaries to charity. Trump has asked the media to help determine the worthy cause of the donation, a gesture that may be seen as unusual given the White House's past criticism of the media.

site_title: Singapore shares open unchanged on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened unchanged on Tuesday, rising 0.79 points to 3,147.94 as 52.3 million shares worth S$46.8 million changed hands. The market saw a 73-50 gain-to-lose ratio, with Swee Hong being the most actively traded counter. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with stocks extending a 5-day rally.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a 15-month high in the previous session, due to solid US jobs data and expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike this week. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.02% to 19,630.02, while the Topix index declined 0.08% to 1,576.09.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
