site_title: BlackRock vows new pressure on climate, board diversity
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to increase pressure on companies to address climate change and boardroom diversity. The firm, which manages $5.1 trillion, has identified climate risk and boardroom diversity as top priorities for meetings with corporate leaders this year. BlackRock will expect companies to explain how climate change affects their business and have diverse boards, including more women. The move is seen as a step up in BlackRock's advocacy with boards and executives, and comes after criticism from environmental and labor activists.

site_title: Goldman joins the China-equity bull party after missing rally
summary: Goldman Sachs has upgraded its forecast for the MSCI China Index, boosting its 12-month prediction to 73 points from 68, representing a 25% gain for 2017. This follows improving economic data, which have increased the appeal of Chinese assets. The MSCI China gauge has already risen 11% this year, outpacing the wider Asian region and global stocks. Goldman joins other major brokerages in upgrading their Chinese stock market outlook.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc is joining the rush on Chinese shares, becoming the latest major brokerage to upgrade the market thanks to mounting evidence of strength in the largest Asian economy.

site_title: China's yuan firms on weaker US dollar, awaits Premier Li, Fed rate clues
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar on Monday, reaching 6.8988 per dollar, as the greenback slid globally. The move came ahead of comments from policymakers at China's annual parliamentary session. The yuan's gain followed a US dollar decline after some European Central Bank policymakers raised interest rate hike possibilities. Traders are awaiting further policy cues, including potential comments from Chinese Premier Li, who is set to address the session.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8988 per US dollar prior to market open, 135 pips firmer than the previous fix of 6.9123.

site_title: UK house prices rise fastest in a year as London rebounds
summary: UK house prices rose 0.6% in February, the fastest pace in a year, driven by a rebound in London's high-value properties. The average house price reached £297,832, but annual growth softened to 2.4%, the lowest since 2013. Despite this, London home prices gained 0.4% from December, snapping a two-month decline. The property market still faces challenges, including affordability issues and Brexit-related weakness.

site_title: Asia: Markets up after US jobs but dollar struggles
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, following the US jobs report, but the US dollar struggled against other currencies ahead of the Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Japanese and British central banks also meet this week. The dollar edged up but fell against the euro and high-yielding currencies, while oil prices continued to drop. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul, rose, with Seoul jumping 1.1% and Shanghai gaining 0.1%. The expected interest rate hike and clues from the central banks' policy meetings are expected to shape the markets this week.

site_title: Malaysia Jan factory output up 3.5% y-o-y, below forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in January rose 3.5% year-over-year, below the forecasted 5.7% increase. This marks the second consecutive month of slowing growth, with factory output down from a 4.7% increase in December. The expansion was driven by strength in the manufacturing, mining, and electricity sectors.

images.alt_text: Factory output was below the 5.7 per cent rise forecast in a Reuters poll, and down from the 4.7 per cent increase in December.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.13% on Monday, driven by a better-than-expected US jobs report. The Hang Seng Index increased to 23,598.25, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.10% and 0.05% respectively. The gains followed a positive start to the week, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Canada pension funds to invest in Singapore, Indonesia warehouses
summary: Canada's two largest pension funds, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) and Ivanhoé Cambridge, have partnered with real estate logistics operator Logos to invest in warehouses in Singapore and Indonesia. The deal aims to capitalize on the growing demand for e-commerce and a burgeoning middle class in southeast Asia. CPPIB will commit S$200 million for a 48% stake in Logos Singapore Logistics Venture and US$100 million for a 48% stake in Logos Indonesia Logistics Venture. This marks CPPIB's first direct real estate investments in Singapore and Indonesia.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars at multi week lows on the euro, eye Fed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the euro, reaching a four-month high for the Kiwi dollar, as the euro rose to A$1.4183 and NZ$1.5453 due to speculation about the European Central Bank's plans to phase out its stimulus measures. The euro also rose against the US dollar, while the Aussie dollar gained against the greenback despite a strong US jobs report. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to keep its economic projections unchanged, with investors pricing in a 90% chance of a rate hike.

site_title: Ezra faces US$194.5m claim tied to Lewek Champion lease
summary: Ezra Holdings, an offshore and marine group, faces a US$194.5 million claim as guarantor for a bareboat charter on the Lewek Champion vessel. The claim was made by Hai Jiang 1401 Pte Ltd, the vessel's owner, after Ezra's associate Emas Chiyoda Subsea rejected a charter dated Feb 19, 2014. Ezra has 15 days to pay the termination sum.

site_title: Thailand says optimistic transport spending will resume
summary: Thailand's junta has approved a $40 billion transport spending plan to boost the economy, but nearly two years later, it has spent only 2% of the allocated funds, with most projects existing only on paper. Delays in feasibility studies, bidding, and procurement have contributed to the slow start. However, the government has set up a new committee to oversee large projects, aiming to disburse 240 billion baht ($7.2 billion) this year, which could help meet its growth target. Despite the slow progress, construction stocks have shown optimism, with some companies expecting increased public work and sales.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.050 points to 1716.750. Trading volume reached 121.5 million lots worth RM60.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 161 to 79.

site_title: South Korea's Park criticised over defiance, faces calls for investigation
summary: South Korea's ousted leader Park Geun-Hye faces criticism and calls for an investigation after she vowed to reveal the truth of her impeachment, which was upheld by the Constitutional Court on Friday. Park, who has denied wrongdoing, left the presidential palace and returned to her private home, sparking accusations of disobedience. The opposition party urges prosecutors to investigate her quickly, and many South Koreans interpret her statement as a protest against the court's ruling. A snap presidential election will be held by May 9, with Moon Jae-In of the Democratic Party favored in opinion polls.

site_title: AIA names Ng Keng Hooi chief executive as Tucker joins HSBC
summary: AIA Group Ltd appointed Ng Keng Hooi as chief executive officer, replacing Mark Tucker who is joining HSBC Holdings Plc as chairman. Ng, 62, joined AIA in 2010 and previously held leadership roles at Prudential Plc. He will succeed Tucker on September 1, while Tucker starts at HSBC on October 1.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic, Federer, Nadal advance at Indian Wells
summary: Novak Djokovic advanced to the third round of the Indian Wells Masters with a 6-4, 7-6 (7/5) win over Kyle Edmund. Djokovic also praised Edmund's aggressive play, saying it was a "very solid match" and "good, quality tennis." Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal also reached the third round, with Federer defeating Stephane Robert 6-2, 6-1 and Nadal beating Guido Pella 6-3, 6-2. Djokovic will face Juan Martin del Potro, whom he has a 12-4 career record against.

site_title: Japan Feb wholesale prices rise 1.0% y-o-y
summary: Japan's wholesale prices rose 1.0% in the year to February, following a 0.5% annual increase in January. Overall final goods prices fell 0.6% and domestic final goods prices rose 0.3% from a year earlier. This data suggests Japan's economy is showing signs of stabilization.

site_title: Rickmers senior lender "willing to consider material debt forgiveness"
summary: HSH Nordbank AG, the largest senior lender to Rickmers Maritime Trust, is willing to consider "material debt forgiveness" of existing loans if the trust can secure similar forgiveness from noteholders and raise additional equity. This is contingent on the trust's recovery amount being higher than an immediate winding-up. The bank will support an orderly winding-up if the debt forgiveness cannot be secured. The trust is currently in discussions to formulate a new framework for restructuring its liabilities.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at over 20-month high in wake of Park's dismissal
summary: Seoul's stocks rose to a 20-month high after President Park Geun-Hye's dismissal, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) increasing 1.1% to 2,121.26 points. The market sentiment improved following the court's dismissal of Park two days earlier, and stronger global stocks also contributed to the gains. Market analysts attributed the rise to hopes of upbeat first-quarter earnings for local companies and offshore investors purchasing Kospi shares for the sixth straight session.

site_title: Gold recovers from five-week low after US jobs data
summary: Gold prices recovered from a five-week low after the US non-farm payrolls report for February, which showed a 235,000 job increase, beating expectations but failing to satisfy those who had been boosted by a strong private payrolls number earlier in the week. The disappointing report led to a drop in the US dollar and Treasury yields, causing gold prices to rise.

images.alt_text: Gold recovered on Friday from an early drop to five-week lows after a US non-farm payrolls report for February failed to meet elevated expectations, prompting a drop in the dollar and Treasury yields.

site_title: Priceless remains lie in ruins at Mosul museum
summary: Iraqi forces have retook the Mosul museum from the Islamic State group, but the building lies in ruins after the jihadists destroyed priceless artifacts, including two ancient Assyrian statues of winged bulls, in a 2015 video. The museum, once home to priceless archaeological treasures, is now a darkened hall with a pile of rubble, twisted iron bars, and smashed stone bearing inscriptions. The destruction of artefacts is seen as a symbolic victory for Iraqi forces as they push into west Mosul to oust the jihadists.

site_title: France's Fillon under scrutiny over cash for bespoke suits
summary: French presidential candidate Francois Fillon admitted to receiving cash payments for bespoke suits from a friend, worth nearly 48,500 euros, amid scrutiny over fake jobs scandal. The payments were made through a tailor who has catered to celebrities like Andy Warhol and Yves Saint Laurent. Fillon's campaign is facing fresh criticism, and he is now in third place in the presidential election, behind Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen.

site_title: Germany hunts possible contacts of mall attack plotter
summary: German police are searching for possible contacts of an IS fighter believed to be behind a terror plot against the Limbecker Platz mall in Essen, Germany. Authorities ordered the mall's closure on Saturday due to "concrete information regarding a possible attack." Two men were detained for questioning in nearby Oberhausen. The plot is not confirmed, but authorities are taking precautions. No arms or explosives were found, but the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: UK retail has worst February sales dip for eight years: survey
summary: UK retail experienced its worst February sales dip in eight years, with a 2.2% decline in like-for-like sales, according to a survey by accountancy firm BDO. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, fueled by consumer uncertainty due to Brexit-related economic slowdown. The decline is attributed to rising prices and consumer strain after the Brexit vote.

site_title: Iceland to lift capital controls from 2008 crisis
summary: Iceland is lifting its capital controls, which were put in place during the 2008 financial crisis, allowing for the free movement of capital and paving the way for the country's economic rebuilding. The controls, which prevented foreign investors from withdrawing funds, were lifted on Tuesday. The decision follows Iceland's strong economic recovery, with 7.2% growth in 2016 and a 11.3% surge in GDP in the fourth quarter of the year. The government guarantees the stability of the economy and promises to attract foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Iceland said on Sunday that all capital controls put in place to stabilise the economy during the country's 2008 financial meltdown will end next week.

site_title: Patients take flight as medical tourism booms globally
summary: Medical tourism has grown globally, with people seeking dental work, plastic surgery, and other treatments abroad, according to experts at the ITB travel fair in Berlin. This year marks the first time the event has dedicated space to the emerging sector.

site_title: IS fighters 'trapped' in Mosul after last road cut
summary: Iraqi forces have cut the last road out of Mosul, trapping Islamic State group fighters inside, according to US envoy Brett McGurk. This move makes it difficult for IS fighters to escape or resupply, as they are now "trapped" and likely to die there. Iraqi forces have since retaken 60% of the territory lost to IS in 2014, and the group is now losing fighters faster than it can replace them, with a toll of 180 killed.

site_title: AIG CEO to resign after dismal earnings, successor unclear
summary: American International Group (AIG) CEO Peter Hancock will step down after poor financial performance, according to a statement. Hancock, 58, will remain as CEO until a successor is named. He cited "wholehearted shareholder support" as a reason for his departure. The board and Hancock did not provide any clues about who will replace him. Hancock's departure comes after AIG's dismal earnings frustrated shareholders and the insurer's board of directors.

site_title: South Korea impeached ex-president leaves Blue House
summary: South Korea's impeached ex-president Park Geun-Hye left the Blue House, vacating the presidential complex two days after the Constitutional Court's verdict removing her from office over a corruption scandal. Park issued an apology for failing to complete her term, citing the need to repair her private home before moving in. The court's ruling removed her presidential immunity, and she has been named a criminal suspect. A presidential election is set to be held within 60 days, with liberal leader Moon Jae-In expected to win.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen picks up
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on March 13, 2017, as the yen strengthened against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.33% and the Topix index declined 0.25%. The better-than-expected US jobs data failed to boost markets, instead causing investors to sell. The yen's rise against the dollar contributed to the decline.

site_title: US officials probe CIA contractors after intelligence leaks: report
summary: US officials are investigating CIA contractors after nearly 9,000 classified documents were leaked by WikiLeaks, revealing cyber-attack plans. The leak is believed to have occurred via a circle of private contractors who may have been disgruntled over job losses. Investigators are focusing on a small team of software developers with high-level security clearances who worked on hacking projects. This probe follows previous leaks from contractors, including Edward Snowden and Harold Martin, and highlights the potential for insider threats in the intelligence community.

site_title: Badminton: Lee Chong Wei wins fourth All England
summary: Lee Chong Wei, Malaysia's veteran world number one, won his fourth All-England Open title, defeating China's Shi Yuqi 21-12, 21-10. At 34, Lee is the oldest singles champion in the Open era. Women's singles champion Tai Tzu Ying, from Taiwan, became the first All-England champion in any discipline from Taiwan. China suffered their worst tournament in two decades, winning only one title, the mixed doubles. Lee credited his mental focus and injury concerns for his surprise victory.

site_title: BT donates S$18,948 to Child At Street 11
summary: BT donates S$18,948 to Child At Street 11, a not-for-profit organisation providing emotional, educational, health, and psychological support to disadvantaged children aged 18 months to six years. The donation was raised at BT's Christmas Auction event in December and presented to founding director Nirmala Murugaian by correspondents Lee U-Wen and Jacquelyn Cheok. The cheque was officially handed over by BT staff members. This donation is part of BT's efforts to support local charitable initiatives.

site_title: Oil price drop sparked by glut concerns triggers herd mentality of selling
summary: The US oil benchmark price has dropped by 9% to below $50 a barrel, its lowest point since November, due to a report of bulging oil stockpiles and concerns about a glut. However, most energy analysts expect prices to bounce back and continue to climb over the next few years, driven by rising demand and production in the US. The US Energy Department forecasts a national average price for regular petrol to be $2.40 a gallon this year, slightly above the current national average.

site_title: Saudi deputy crown prince to meet Trump
summary: Saudi Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman arrived in the US on Monday for a visit including talks with President Donald Trump, marking the first meeting between the two since Trump's inauguration in January. Prince Mohammed, who is also Saudi defence minister, will discuss reinforcing bilateral relations and regional issues with US officials. The visit is part of a month-long Asia tour by King Salman, who is seeking to build ties with major importers of Saudi crude and promote investment opportunities. The working visit is expected to start on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Saudi Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman left Saudi Arabia on Monday for the United States for a visit scheduled to include talks with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Britain plans for all options as Brexit nears
summary: Britain is preparing for all possible outcomes in its Brexit negotiations with the EU, with contingency plans in place in case talks fail. Brexit minister David Davis stated that while Prime Minister Theresa May is optimistic about a deal, the government must prepare for a range of scenarios. The cross-party parliamentary foreign affairs committee warned that failure to prepare could lead to "mutually assured damage" for both the EU and UK. A bill to trigger Article 50 is set to be debated in the House of Commons on Monday, with the process potentially starting soon.

site_title: Keen interest at 2 property launches after govt eases cooling measures
summary: Singapore's property market saw a surge in interest after the government eased cooling measures, including reducing seller's stamp duty rates and expanding the application period to three years. Two residential projects, Qingjian Realty's iNz Residence and Lendlease's Park Place Residences, attracted over 170 and 100 units sold, respectively, on their first day of booking. The eased measures were seen as a deciding factor for prospective buyers, with one buyer stating, "The latest announcement on the property cooling measures was a very good deciding factor."

site_title: Oil prices hit 3-month low as US rig count climbs
summary: Oil prices fell to a three-month low on March 13, 2017, due to US drillers adding rigs despite Opec efforts to curb crude output. Brent crude dropped 42 cents to $50.95 per barrel, its lowest since November 30, while US West Texas Intermediate crude declined 50 cents to $47.99 per barrel, its weakest since November 29. The decline was attributed to a bearish Trump tariff outlook and the continued US increase in oil production.

site_title: Tillerson on East Asia visit in shadow of North Korea threat
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is set to visit East Asia amid a North Korea nuclear threat, marking President Donald Trump's first major foreign crisis. Tillerson, with no prior government experience, will meet with Japanese, South Korean, and Chinese leaders to address the escalating tensions. The trip comes as North Korea's nuclear ambitions rapidly gain international attention, raising concerns of a catastrophic war. Tillerson's visit is seen as a crucial step in finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis.

site_title: Saudi king arrives in Tokyo for four-day visit
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman arrived in Tokyo on Sunday for a four-day visit, marking the first visit by a Saudi monarch in nearly five decades. The 81-year-old king will meet Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and visit Emperor Akihito, amidst efforts to diversify Japan's economy and increase investments. The visit is seen as an opportunity for Japan to widen its relations with Saudi Arabia, the largest oil exporter to Japan. King Salman is part of a month-long Asian tour, which also includes visits to Malaysia, Indonesia, China, and the Maldives.

site_title: Skyrocketing drug prices the key question in White House's health care reform
summary: The US is struggling to address skyrocketing drug prices, with costs often two-and-a-half times higher than in France or Britain. The lack of a central public entity to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies and the US market's complex system of multiple players and incentives hinder efforts to bring prices down. Experts say it will require a new law to make significant progress, and alternatives such as easing the path for generic drugs or rewarding effective remedies may be needed.

site_title: Tensions rise ahead of key Dutch election
summary: Tensions are high in the Netherlands ahead of Wednesday's election, where the far-right Freedom Party (PVV) led by Geert Wilders is poised to make significant gains. The election is seen as a bellwether for the rise of populist parties in Europe, with Wilders vowing to close borders to Muslim immigrants, ban the Koran, and shut mosques. Prime Minister Mark Rutte's Liberals may return as the largest party, but the election's outcome is uncertain, with multiple parties vying for seats and potential coalition governments taking months to form.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Mark Rutte, who is bidding for a third term at the helm of the lowlands country of 17 million people, is fending off a strong challenge from far-right anti-Islam MP Geert Wilders and his Freedom Party (PVV).

site_title: China admits political education formula for students is outdated
summary: China's education minister admitted that the country's political education classes for university students are outdated and unfashionable. This comes as Beijing has campaigned against the spread of "Western values" at universities. The ruling Communist Party has also been monitoring teachers for "improper" remarks in class. The admission is a rare acknowledgment of difficulties in enforcing a key government policy.

site_title: Japan Jan core machinery orders unexpectedly fall
summary: Japan's core machinery orders unexpectedly fell 3.2% in January, below economists' median estimate of a 0.5% increase. This marks a 8.2% year-over-year decline, highlighting the country's fragile economic recovery. Despite policymakers' hopes for a recovery in capital spending, inflation remains below the BOJ's 2% target, and the central bank is expected to keep its short-term interest rate at minus 0.1%. The data suggests Japan's economy is still struggling to overcome deflation and stagnation.

site_title: Singapore eases property rules in diverging path from Hong Kong
summary: Singapore has eased property rules, diverging from Hong Kong, which tightened restrictions in November. Singapore's public housing component helps keep prices in check, while Hong Kong's market is dominated by private housing, leading to rising prices and affordability concerns. The city's leaders face rising discontent due to unaffordable housing prices, ranking as the world's most expensive market for the seventh year. Singapore's relaxed regulations have prevented affordability issues from deteriorating to Hong Kong levels.

site_title: Bra parachute wins Australia flying contest
summary: Actor Samuel Johnson won the Birdman Rally in Melbourne, Australia, by flying a homemade parachute made of bras. He raised over A$20,000 for a cancer charity after his sister's diagnosis. Johnson's strategy was to intentionally crash into the water, but his colourful contraption stayed in the air for the longest time. He beat contestants dressed as a balloon horse and pterodactyl, with 15 participants in total. Johnson's charity effort was a key part of his winning performance.

site_title: We're not work-shy: France renews Brexit business push
summary: France launches an advertising campaign to attract London-based banks, dispelling stereotypes of being work-shy due to strict labour laws and high employers' payroll charges. The campaign aims to persuade banks to shift business to Paris to continue offering EU services after Britain leaves the bloc. France's labour laws and tax system are seen as deterrents, with uncertainty over the outcome of the French presidential election in April-May also affecting the move. Despite concerns, polls suggest far-right candidate Marine Le Pen will lose to centrist Emmanuel Macron.

site_title: China moves to make 64t yuan domestic bond market more global
summary: China has taken steps to make its domestic bond market more global, with Citigroup and the central bank pledging to create a more convenient environment for foreign investors. The move comes after a recent measure allowing currency hedging for bonds, and aims to lower barriers to attract foreign ownership. China's bond market is expected to expand by 27% this year, with Deutsche Bank estimating it will reach 64 trillion yuan, and investors are seeing opportunities in the growing market with attractive yields.

site_title: US malls look to grocery stores as 'survival tactic'
summary: US malls are shifting their focus to grocery stores as traditional department store anchors close. This trend is driven by convenience, with millennials preferring to combine shopping with grocery shopping. Grocery stores can bring heavy foot traffic, with Kroger potentially generating $50 million in sales compared to an ageing department store. The trend is seen as a survival tactic, as online retailers disrupt traditional shopping patterns.

site_title: Markets brace for another rate hike - a pattern set to persist
summary: US stocks are expected to drop due to a high probability of a Federal Reserve rate hike, now at 96%, following strong economic data and hawkish comments from Fed officials. The Fed's decision will be the third rate hike under Chairman Janet Yellen, establishing a pattern of regular increases. Analysts expect interest rates to remain low, with real interest rates potentially becoming negative, which could lead to a rebound in commodities and currencies. The main political risks include the French presidential election and President Trump's inability to pass economic policies.

site_title: Erdogan warns Netherlands will 'pay price' as crisis spirals
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan warned the Netherlands that it will "pay a price" for preventing top Turkish ministers from holding rallies ahead of a referendum on expanding his powers. The crisis escalated after Turkish Family Minister Fatma Betul Sayan Kaya was expelled from the Netherlands and Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu's plane was refused to land. Erdogan accused the Netherlands of "Nazism, fascism" and "Islamophobia," and vowed to travel to Europe for rallies, potentially escalating the situation.

site_title: US foreign policy experts slam Trump's revised travel ban
summary: US foreign policy experts strongly denounce President Donald Trump's revised travel ban, calling it a threat to national security and interests. The ban, set to take effect on March 16, temporarily closes US borders to refugees and citizens from six mainly-Muslim countries, and denies entry to all refugees for 120 days. The 134 experts, including former government officials, claim the ban undermines America's global leadership and jeopardizes national security interests, and argue it reinforces ISIS propaganda against Muslims. The ban's discriminatory nature is also being challenged in court by US states.

site_title: Berlin airport workers to strike again on Monday over pay
summary: Ground staff at Berlin's Tegel and Schoenefeld airports will strike for 25 hours starting Monday, canceling nearly 650 flights. The Verdi union is demanding a 12-euro-per-hour wage increase, while management offered an 8% increase over three years. The strike is part of a one-year collective agreement, with the union claiming the offer is insufficient. Lufthansa has canceled flights from Frankfurt and Munich to Berlin, and tens of thousands of passengers were stranded last week due to a similar strike.

site_title: Polar opposites in politics Trump, Merkel prepare to meet
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in the Oval Office, marking a symbolic encounter between a disruptor and the last defender of the liberal world order. Despite their differences on immigration and trade, both sides aim to avoid a clash of competing worldviews. Merkel, who has studied Trump's speeches, is expected to advise on dealing with Russian President Vladimir Putin, while Trump may seek her input on NATO. However, trade tensions remain a point of contention, with Trump criticizing Germany's trade surplus with the US.

site_title: Landslide win for Labor in Western Australia elections
summary: Western Australia elected a new government in a landslide victory for the Labor party, with Mark McGowan replacing Premier Colin Barnett. Labor won 40 of 59 seats, promising to create 50,000 jobs and boost public transport and services. The new government faces a daunting task in turning around the state's economy, weighed down by a nation's highest jobless rate and record debt.

site_title: Trump tried to call New York prosecutor before firing him: officials
summary: US President Donald Trump tried to call New York prosecutor Preet Bharara two days before firing him, in what a White House official described as a "thank you" call. Bharara declined the call, citing a desire not to speak to the president without superiors' approval. Bharara was fired after he defied a request to resign, contradicting his earlier statement that Trump had asked him to stay in the job. The move was a surprise, sparking questions about Trump's decision-making and Bharara's future.

site_title: What happened in Sweden? Trump's world view and Volvo's globalised SUV
summary: Sweden's open economy and globalized industries, such as Volvo's, have contributed to the country's prosperity despite the US President Donald Trump's views on globalization. Unlike Trump, Swedish policymakers believe that free trade and competition are key to preserving Sweden's status as a prosperous nation. The country's welfare state ensures that workers are taken care of if they lose their jobs, and the government has shored up public finances following years of mismanagement. Sweden has emerged as a major exporter of music and computer games, and its "drawbridge down" approach has helped replace old industries with international giants.

site_title: Women rule banking in Thailand
summary: Thailand has a high proportion of women in senior financial roles, with 31% of board and executive committee members in financial services being women, according to a study by Oliver Wyman. Women account for 57% of Thailand's finance and insurance workforce, but men dominate senior management and executive roles. This disparity is attributed to cultural norms and attitudes in Thailand, where women are more drawn to the math-intensive field of finance. Despite the lack of government legislation, Thailand's high representation of women in senior financial roles is a notable exception in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: All eyes on Federal Open Market Committee
summary: The US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, with financial conditions potentially signaling that policy is "behind the curve." Experts argue that the Fed's caution in raising rates last year to err on the side of caution may have led to a situation where the Fed is now grossly behind the curve on inflation. However, tighter monetary policy may be beneficial for economic growth, with emerging markets experiencing a recovery despite higher US interest rates.

site_title: Tillerson leads from shadows of State Department
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has been largely invisible in his first six weeks on the job, limiting himself to terse statements and avoiding public confrontations with the White House. Despite this, he is reportedly accomplishing significant behind-the-scenes work, including arranging a Saudi foreign minister's first trip to Iraq and developing plans to counter Russia's behavior. Defenders say he is building relationships and gathering information, but critics worry that his silence may be seen as a sign of powerlessness or a lack of confidence. His upcoming trip to Japan, South Korea, and China will be a test of his diplomatic strategy and approach.

site_title: Euro hits four-week high after report of ECB rate hike talks
summary: The euro reached a four-week high against the dollar after the European Central Bank discussed the possibility of raising interest rates before the end of its quantitative easing program. The euro rose 1.1% to $1.0698, its strongest since February 9, as investors anticipated a shift towards ending QE. The dollar index fell to its lowest since February 28, and Fed fund futures prices showed a 93% chance of a US interest rate hike this month.

site_title: Ivanka Trump is the exception to dad's 'Buy American' rule
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Buy American" rule has an exception: his daughter Ivanka Trump, whose branded shoes, bags, and clothes are being shipped from China despite his rhetoric against overseas labor. At least 82 shipments, totaling over 53.5 tonnes, have passed US Customs since his election win, with companies like G-III and Mondani Handbags manufacturing products for her fashion line in China. Trump's silence on his daughter's products has been criticized as hypocritical, but some argue that domestic production may not be feasible at the same price point.

site_title: Singapore not an ideal test-bed for global innovation
summary: Veteran entrepreneurs, including Tan Min-Liang of Razer and Isaac Ho of Venturecraft, argue that Singapore is not an ideal test-bed for global innovation due to its small domestic market. They recommend that local companies focus on global markets from the start, rather than testing ideas in Singapore first. This approach would allow companies to quickly adapt to larger volumes and more diverse markets. The government is encouraged to shift its focus from promoting entrepreneurship to exposing youths to technology and innovation from a young age, and investing in Singaporeans who are prepared to go global.

site_title: Sing Holdings sells SHR stake to S'pore entity
summary: Sing Holdings Limited sold its entire 100% stake in SHR (Robin Residences) to a Singapore entity for S$72.7 million, avoiding hefty qualifying certificate charges, additional buyer's stamp duty, and new stamp duty that came into effect on March 11. The sale was made on a willing buyer, willing seller basis and was facilitated by Knight Frank. The disposal will cease SHR's status as a subsidiary of Sing Holdings.

site_title: The 'Irish touch' that's mending Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia Airlines is experiencing a turnaround under new CEO Peter Bellew, who has refocused the airline's priorities, cut costs, and simplified its fare structure. The airline has seen a significant increase in load factor, with 90% in December 2016 and 80.9% in the final quarter of 2016. Traffic rose 5% to 3.8 million customers, and average fares dropped 3%. Despite being delisted from the Malaysian bourse and axing 6,000 jobs, the airline is now flying full, with planes carrying more passengers. Bellew aims to turn the airline back into the black by 2018 and achieve 15 million passengers this year.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Mr Bellew, who is on a three-year contract, describes himself as a man in a hurry to turn the airline back into the black by 2018, ahead of a relisting one year after.

site_title: World without Wi-Fi draws near with rise of unlimited plans
summary: US wireless carriers now offer unlimited data plans, making Wi-Fi less necessary for avoiding costly coverage charges. This shift, combined with emerging technologies, may lead to a decline in Wi-Fi's importance. Many home devices still rely on Wi-Fi for connectivity. The rise of unlimited plans and new competitive technologies pose a threat to the traditional Wi-Fi network, potentially leading to a world without Wi-Fi.

site_title: China Life makes big splash in Singapore
summary: China Life Insurance, Singapore's largest life insurer, has secured a one-year deal as the title sponsor of the China Life Insurance Singapore National Age Group (Snag) Swimming Championships. The event, running from March 10-19, features over 1,000 local and foreign swimmers and aims to promote the local sporting culture and inclusive sports. The sponsorship is part of China Life's expansion plans in Asia, including Singapore, as part of Chinese President Xi Jinping's "One Belt, One Road" strategy.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Quah Zheng Wen (above) was among the swimmers competing at this year's Snag.
Mr Chow (above) wants to leverage on the Snag sponsorship to promote swimming as an accessible and inclusive sport.

site_title: Foreign buyer tax won't cool Toronto home price gains, brokers say
summary: Toronto's average home price surged 28% in February, driven by a supply shortage, not a foreign buyers tax. The Toronto Real Estate Board suggests addressing the issue by boosting availability through land-use designations, streamlined development approvals, and incentivizing land owners to develop. Ontario Finance Minister Charles Sousa is reconsidering a foreign buyers tax, but brokers argue it won't solve the underlying problem and could create adverse effects. The provincial government should focus on increasing supply, not just cooling prices.

site_title: Japan's 'fake food' more appetising than the original
summary: In Japan, a craft of creating realistic food replicas has been perfected over six decades, with artists using simple tools and materials to mimic dishes such as sushi, hamburgers, and deep-fried pork cutlets. The practice, which dates back to the 1920s, is still in demand, particularly in high-end restaurants and for foreign tourists. Despite the rise of 3D printing technology, human artists are preferred for their creativity and ability to capture the "beautiful and appetizing" qualities of food. The replicas can be expensive, with some dishes costing hundreds of dollars, but the industry is valued at $90 million.

images.alt_text: Mr Mishima spraying paint on a plastic food replica at the company's studio in Tokorozawa, a suburb of Tokyo. He doesn't think replicas are going to fade into culinary history just yet.

site_title: Deadly dispute at car giant highlights India's labour laws, jobs malaise
summary: In a trial court in Gurgaon, India, 31 Maruti Suzuki workers were convicted of conspiracy to commit murder, arson, and rioting in a deadly labour dispute that left a manager dead in 2012. However, 117 others were acquitted, with one acquitted worker claiming he was innocent and spent over two-and-a-half years in jail. The case highlights India's labour laws and the country's struggles with job creation, with economists suggesting the quality of industrial jobs remains poor despite recent legislative changes. The incident occurred amid India's "Make in India" push, which has seen temporary employment increase while coveted factory jobs remain poor.

images.alt_text: The Maruti Suzuki case reveals the potential for violent unrest at India's manufacturing landscape.

site_title: US-Japan economic dialogue may supplant multilateral pacts: analyst
summary: Japan is set to launch moves to fend off US trade friction, ahead of a high-level bilateral economic dialogue with the US next month. Despite Japan's vulnerability on security issues, the dialogue may allow Japan to turn the talks to its advantage, particularly in setting rules for "soft" trade and cross-border exchange. Analysts believe the real substance of the negotiations will be about intellectual property protection and state-owned enterprises, with Japan seeking to follow US rules and enshrine them as the global standard.

site_title: Berli Jucker, Thailand's new supermarket giant
summary: Berli Jucker (BJC), a leading regional consumer conglomerate and integrated supply chain operator, is part of the TCC Group, which also owns Thai Beverage and F&N. BJC's core businesses include packaging supply chain, consumer supply chain, and healthcare supply chain. The company has forecast a 36% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) in earnings per share for 2017-2019. BJC's expansion plans include aggressively growing its store network, with a focus on hypermarkets. The company is expected to replicate its fully integrated business model across ASEAN countries, including Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, Myanmar, and Laos. BJC's valuation is estimated at 13 times 2018 estimated enterprise value (EV) to Ebitda for its BigC operation and 18 times 2017 estimated EV/Ebitda for its original business.

site_title: Dutch elections will set stage for polls in France, Germany
summary: The Netherlands is set to hold general elections, with Prime Minister Mark Rutte's Liberals facing off against anti-immigrant MP Geert Wilders' Freedom Party. The vote is part of a larger trend of eurosceptic and anti-immigrant sentiments in Europe, following Brexit. In France, presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron is seen as a frontrunner after scandal-plagued conservative Francois Fillon drops out. Meanwhile, Germany's September election is expected to be a close contest between the centre-left and centre-right, with the anti-immigration Alternative for Germany party gaining ground.

images.alt_text: Mr Wilders (centre) has vowed to shut mosques, ban the Quran, close the country's borders and take the Netherlands out of the EU.

site_title: Retail firms collectively post weaker quarterly earnings
summary: Singapore's retail sector reported weaker quarterly earnings, with combined profits of S$55.21 million, a 43% year-on-year decline, and nearly flat revenue at S$881.82 million. Sheng Siong posted a 5.3% rise in net profit, while Metro's profits slumped 63.3% due to lower associate contributions. Courts Asia strengthened net profit by 24%, despite an 8.6% revenue decline. Retailers face challenges from online shopping and stiff competition, with some focusing on e-commerce growth to offset weak brick-and-mortar operations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Raw sugar pivots down to 3-month low; cocoa, coffee slip
summary: Raw sugar futures plummeted to a 3-month low, falling 2.2% to 18 cents per pound. Cocoa and coffee also declined, with May London cocoa settling at £1,572 per tonne and US arabica coffee at $1.4045 per pound. The decline was attributed to a firmer pound and sell-stops. The Thomson Reuters CoreCommodity Index hit its lowest level since November, following a sharp fall in oil and US grain prices. The opening times for US sugar, coffee, and cocoa futures will be delayed by one hour from March 13 to March 24 due to daylight savings time.

site_title: Saudi king in Tokyo for four-day visit
summary: Saudi King Salman arrived in Tokyo on Sunday for a four-day visit, marking the first visit by a Saudi monarch in nearly five decades. He will meet with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and visit Emperor Akihito, amidst efforts to diversify Japan's economy and increase investments. The visit comes as Saudi Arabia is the largest oil provider to Japan, and the two countries aim to strengthen ties. King Salman's month-long tour of Asia includes stops in Malaysia, Indonesia, China, and the Maldives.

site_title: Under Trump administration, returning to the Moon regains interest
summary: The Moon has regained interest as a potential destination for future space exploration missions under the Trump administration. Private sector companies, including SpaceX and Blue Origin, are partnering with NASA to pursue a return to the Moon. Billionaire Elon Musk and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos have met with Trump's advisers, and former NASA officials believe a major space initiative involving a public-private partnership focused on the Moon could be announced within the next 12 months. NASA is currently developing the Space Launch System and Orion capsule, which will propel humans to the Moon and beyond by the 2030s.

site_title: Smaller firms can think bigger on sustainability
summary: Smaller firms can play a crucial role in sustainable growth by adopting good labour relations, ethical practices, and positive community impact. Despite the challenges, smaller companies can make a significant difference in areas such as environmental sustainability, social responsibility, and community development. By re-examining their corporate strategy, SMEs can prioritize sustainable practices that benefit both the company and the environment. Research shows that sustainable companies have outperformed their peers, with shares of the top 100 most sustainable companies increasing by 132% since 2005.

site_title: Brokers excited by manufacturers, highlight Sunningdale and AEM
summary: Brokers have initiated coverage on small-cap stocks in Singapore, highlighting Sunningdale Tech and AEM Holdings. Sunningdale Tech, a plastic components maker, has competitive advantages in manufacturing capabilities and a diversified customer base, with DBS Group Research forecasting core earnings of S$30.9 million in 2017. AEM Holdings, an equipment and components maker, has received S$130 million in orders for a new high-density test handling machine, with CIMB Research giving a target price of S$2.69, citing risks in customer and product concentration.

site_title: Hong Kong on track to join AIIB this year
summary: Hong Kong is on track to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) as early as this year, with the Chinese central government having submitted a formal application for Hong Kong's membership. The Hong Kong government plans to buy HK$1.2 billion worth of shares in AIIB, covering 0.7% of the bank's capital stock. Analysts predict that membership will bring significant economic and political benefits to Hong Kong, including access to infrastructure investment opportunities and strengthened regional growth.

site_title: Verztec selects charity partners that share its focus
summary: Verztec Consulting, a global content consulting company in Singapore, selects charity partners that share its focus and values. The company, led by CEO Nicholas Goh, partners with organizations such as Life Community Services Society (LCSS) and St Vincent's Home to support disadvantaged youth, children, and senior citizens. Verztec's partnerships include fundraising events, volunteer work, and financial support, with contributions totaling over S$100,000 over the last five years. The company aims to use its platform to make a positive impact on the lives of those in need.

site_title: Venezuela won't have to pay Exxon US$1.4b: panel
summary: A World Bank panel has overturned part of a ruling ordering Venezuela to pay ExxonMobil US$1.4 billion in compensation for nationalising a company project in 2007. The International Centre For Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) agreed with Venezuela's argument, cancelling the portion of the original award for the Cerro Negro project. This is considered the largest annulment in ICSID history, with Venezuela's representative stating that the decision is a significant victory. ExxonMobil did not immediately respond to the news.

site_title: A good move or a luxury SMEs can ill afford . . .
summary: The article discusses the government's moves to enhance childcare leave and support for working parents, a crucial factor in encouraging more couples to have children. Large companies, like the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, may be able to follow the government's lead, but small companies will face a significant challenge. Small companies already release fathers for their National Service, but implementing childcare leave policies will be a challenge. The government's support aims to strike a balance between supporting working parents and the needs of the economy.

site_title: BT Group ends feud with regulators in deal to split off network
summary: BT Group has agreed to split its Openreach network into a separate entity, resolving a year-long dispute with UK regulators. The deal, which ends a major distraction for the company, will free CEO Gavin Patterson to address other pressing issues. The split is expected to send BT shares up, marking the largest increase in nearly nine months. The agreement resolves a major distraction for the company and frees Patterson to address other pressing issues, including an accounting scandal in Italy.

site_title: Uber deal giving California drivers US$1 each fails to win over judge
summary: Uber Technologies Inc failed to persuade a Los Angeles Superior Court judge to approve a settlement offering 1.6 million California drivers an average of $1.08 each to resolve alleged labor-code violations. The deal, worth billions of dollars, was rejected by Judge Maren Nelson, who issued a tentative ruling. The decision leaves Uber facing dozens of lawsuits challenging its contractor-based business model.

site_title: Bond pioneer who outsmarted Russian sanctions flops in China
summary: Russia's efforts to sell yuan debt to onshore investors in China have stalled, despite over a year of attempts. The country's Finance Ministry head, Konstantin Vyshkovsky, says the project is "hardly ready" and that China's priority of limiting capital outflows is a major obstacle. Russia needs to borrow in yuan to pave the way for corporate issuers, but China is unwilling to allow this, instead proposing panda bonds. The failure to secure yuan debt may hinder Russia's ability to access capital with sanctions expected to remain in place for years.

site_title: Oil trading giant Vitol bets on fuel retail for growth
summary: Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trader, is betting on fuel retail for growth as major oil companies shed assets due to low global oil prices. The company secured over 23% of Turkey's retail market after buying Petrol Ofisi from OMV for $1.45 billion, adding 1,700 outlets to its portfolio. Vitol sees Turkey as a key destination due to its proximity to transport routes, and plans to invest in streamlining assets and expanding its presence in emerging markets.

site_title: Trump adviser says he had contact with Russian 'agent'
summary: Roger Stone Jr., a longtime adviser to President Donald Trump, has acknowledged contact with Guccifer 2.0, a suspected Russian intelligence front, via Twitter. Stone claimed the brief exchange was innocuous and occurred after the Democratic National Committee was hacked. He denies any knowledge of Russia's involvement in the hacking and labels allegations of collusion a "witch hunt." This is the first confirmed contact between a Trump associate and Guccifer 2.0, who is believed to be a Russian agent.

site_title: Insider buying dips after rising for 2 weeks
summary: Insider buying activity decreased after a two-week rise, with 16 companies recording 31 purchases worth S$1.38 million on the Singapore Exchange from March 6 to 10. In contrast, sellers returned with four companies recording seven disposals worth S$0.76 million. Buyback activity remained high with nine companies posting 30 repurchases worth S$7.48 million. site_title: New shades of green bonds seen as market set to double again
summary: The green bond market is expected to double in size this year, reaching $206 billion, according to Moody's Corp. Issuance of green bonds, which benefit the environment, is on track to surge as more institutions issue bonds with varying levels of environmental criteria. Investors are tracking the greenness of these securities, and some are starting to demand a premium for green bonds. The market is also expanding to include sovereign green bonds, with at least nine countries planning to issue such bonds this year, including China, Poland, and France.

site_title: The making of a global developer
summary: Oxley, a Singapore-based property developer, has transformed into a global developer with a presence in 10 markets across Asia, Australia, and the UK. The company has invested in various projects, including hotels, condominiums, and commercial developments. Oxley's CEO, Ching Chiat Kwong, attributes the company's success to its ability to mitigate single-country risk and generate growth opportunities. The company plans to adopt an asset-light model, expand its global footprint, and diversify its business model, with a focus on securing new projects and prospecting business opportunities globally.

site_title: StanChart gives S$240,000 to 'Friend-a-Senior' project
summary: Standard Chartered Bank is donating S$240,000 to the "Friend-a-Senior" programme by the South East Community Development Council over three years. The funds will support the training of 750 volunteers and their partnerships with over 450 seniors. This initiative is part of the bank's community program Silver Lining, which has engaged 5,000 staff in projects benefiting over 8,000 seniors since its inception.

site_title: Changes to Companies Act take effect March 31
summary: Singapore's Companies Act changes take effect March 31, aiming to increase transparency and reduce illicit activities. Locally and foreign incorporated companies must maintain registers of controllers, and beneficial owners must provide and update their particulars. The amendments also include record-keeping changes, such as retaining company records for at least five years. The changes follow the Financial Action Task Force's recommendation and are part of Singapore's efforts to maintain its reputation as a trusted financial hub.

"The amendments will boost Singapore's efforts to remain as a trusted and clean financial hub," says Ms Indranee.

site_title: Light at the end of the privatisation tunnel
summary: Residents of Braddell View HUDC estate in Singapore are awaiting approval from the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) for the privatisation of their estate, which has been stalled for 18 years due to a "historical quirk" involving two separate plots of land with different lease expiry dates. The management committee has applied for a strata title scheme and received over 80% consent from flat owners, but one unit has objected to the process. If approved, the privatisation could lead to an upgrade of the estate's facilities, but property consultants warn that selling the site as a collective sale would be challenging due to the site's large size and plot ratio.

site_title: China's economy set for steadier growth: state research centre
summary: China's economy has shifted from a slowing "L-shaped" growth pattern to a more stable "horizontal" growth trend, according to the head of the Development Research Center of the State Council. The country's economy grew 6.7% last year, meeting its target, and is expected to maintain steady growth this year. The government has moved to cool the housing market, reduce new credit, and tighten its purse strings, relying more on domestic consumption and private investment. Despite some short-term fluctuations, the long-term trend points to steady development, but challenges remain to resolve.

site_title: Why US anti-missile system worries China
summary: China is concerned about the effectiveness of the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) anti-missile system in South Korea, which could potentially track and disrupt its nuclear deterrent. The radar system, not designed to target Chinese missiles, could identify decoy warheads, weakening China's deterrence. China's nuclear arsenal, with around 260 warheads, is smaller than the US and Russia's, and its leaders have stuck to a "minimum means of reprisal" doctrine, avoiding a first-use policy. China may respond by spending more on its nuclear forces and introducing new, more advanced missiles.

site_title: Ex-US officials seek informal talks with N Korea as threat grows
summary: A group of former US officials, including former intelligence specialist Joseph DeTrani, plans to seek informal talks with North Korean officials amid escalating tensions in the region. These unofficial talks typically occur every six months. The move aims to address growing threats and maintain dialogue between the two nations.

site_title: Caviar infusion from Pernod Paris lab aims to refresh vodka
summary: Pernod Ricard, a French spirits company, has launched a new vodka, L'Orbe, infused with caviar, using patented technology that prevents the eggs from exploding in the liquid. The move follows declining sales of Absolut vodka and attempts by competitors to innovate, with vodka facing "flavour fatigue" in the US market. L'Orbe is set to be sold in 100,000 bottles by 2020, aiming to breathe new life into the ailing vodka category.

site_title: No-deal Brexit a 'real possibility', lawmakers warn May
summary: UK lawmakers warn Prime Minister Theresa May that a no-deal Brexit is a "real possibility" and a "dereliction of duty" not to plan for the consequences. The UK and EU disagree on the format of talks, with Britain seeking parallel negotiations on departure and future relationships, while the EU prioritizes departure arrangements first. Lawmakers urge the government to produce "no deal" plans for each department.

site_title: 'Global startup' vows autonomous car by 2020 in US
summary: Nio, a Chinese startup, unveiled plans to sell a fully autonomous electric car in the US market by 2020. The car will feature advanced AI, a human interface, and augmented vision, competing with Tesla and other premium vehicles. The company expects to have the first fully autonomous vehicle in the US market and aims to create a holistic user experience.

site_title: As Aramco audits reserves, market wonders how much oil is left?
summary: Saudi Aramco is set to release a Western audit of its oil reserves, sparking market curiosity about the reserve volumes and detail. Industry sources indicate that the audit will provide a similar level of detail to international peers, but may not reveal individual deposits. The outcome is crucial for Aramco's potential value, which could be affected by a significantly higher or lower reserve total.

site_title: Complex synthetic life nearer with new lab-made yeast chromosomes
summary: Scientists have successfully created five new artificial chromosomes of baker's yeast, representing a third of the micro-organism's genome, marking progress in the field of synthetic biology. The chromosomes were designed and constructed using computers and represent a significant step towards designing complex forms of life from scratch. This breakthrough could pave the way for the creation of new, tailored organisms with specific traits. The achievement demonstrates accelerating progress in synthetic biology.

site_title: ECB governing council considers if rates can rise before QE ends
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) governing council considered the possibility of raising interest rates before the end of its quantitative easing (QE) program, which is currently set to run until at least the end of this year. The move would mark a departure from ECB President Mario Draghi's previous guidance on timing of rate hikes, as the euro rose and euro-area bonds tumbled. site_title: Savills IM setting up more funds to tap demand

site_title: Lessons from my grandfather

Despite investors undervaluing the company, Chew prefers to remain listed to tap markets and maintain discipline.

site_title: Native American groups take oil pipeline protests to White House
summary: Thousands of Native American demonstrators and supporters marched to the White House to protest President Donald Trump's support for the Dakota Access and Keystone XL oil pipelines, which they claim threaten tribal lands. The protesters carried signs reading "Native Lives Matter" and "Protect the Water," and a White House official did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: Adult diapers help papermakers absorb print loss
summary: Demand for adult diapers is projected to grow 4% in 2017, driven by an aging population. This shift is providing relief to an industry hurt by the digital era, with prices for traditional pulp expected to rise. The baby-boomer generation, aged 65 and older, is driving growth, with the population group projected to reach 1.6 billion by 2050.

summary: A 36-year-old Kosovan national with a history of paranoid schizophrenia attacked a train station in Duesseldorf, Germany, wounding nine people. Police ruled out a terrorist motive, instead suggesting he may have intended to end his own life. The suspect was taken into custody and being treated in hospital for injuries.

site_title: Wall Street nearly unanimous on US rate hike next week: poll

site_title: Modi looks to tighten grip as India awaits results
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to tighten his grip on power as state election results are announced, with exit polls showing his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) likely to win most seats in key battlegrounds such as Uttar Pradesh. site_title: Europe: Heavyweight banks help shares as rate hike talk mounts
summary: European shares ended in positive territory on Friday, up 0.1%, despite growing concerns about central bank tightening, with banks rising 0.8% and utilities falling 0.1%. summary: US stocks rose solidly on Friday as investors welcomed strong jobs data, with the American economy generating 235,000 new jobs in February, exceeding economists' targets. site_title: No room to dock as Sydney Harbour faces parking woes
summary: A cruise liner, Radiance of the Seas, was unable to dock in Sydney Harbour due to a lack of parking space. summary: Speculators in China's Hefei are betting against government efforts to curb the city's rapidly rising property market, with new home prices increasing 48.4% in 2016, the fastest in the world. site_title: S Korea liberals likely to win power, may bring softer N Korea stance
summary: South Korea's liberal politician Moon Jae-In is likely to succeed Park Geun-Hye as president, potentially softening Seoul's stance towards North Korea and delaying deployment of a US missile-defence system. site_title: Healthway Medical gets extension for proposed notes issue

site_title: Scientists grow potato under Mars-like conditions in Peru
summary: Scientists successfully grew a potato under Mars-like conditions in Peru, a key step towards establishing a sustainable food source for future Mars missions. site_title: Hipster Fest

site_title: Del Monte back in the black in Q3 with US$8.46m profit

site_title: EU's Juncker says hopes Britain will 're-enter the boat'

site_title: Uber deal giving drivers US$1 each fails to win over judge

At least eight US attack plots since 2014 have involved people being directed by these IS entrepreneurs, who are developing innovative ways to spread jihadist ideology and encourage attacks.

site_title: ECS group files court motion to terminate charter on affiliate's vessel

site_title: Trump in showdown over Republican Obamacare repeal plan
