The move comes ahead of Brexit negotiations, with May delaying legislation to implement the tax increase until autumn. The tax, which affects 2.5 million self-employed people, was widely criticized for targeting middle- and low-income earners. May defended the move, saying it would make the tax system "simpler, fairer and more progressive," but critics argue the government needs to address unsustainable spending and rising tax rates.

site_title: Airbnb finally getting the nod in room-starved Japan
summary: Airbnb has received approval to operate in Japan, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet approving rules limiting home-sharing by private citizens to 180 days per year. The bill, which also allows local authorities to impose their own restrictions, is now up for deliberation and approval by Japan's parliament. This move comes after years of operating in grey areas of the law, marking a significant step forward for the company in the country.

site_title: Citigroup appoints new Asean head for corporate, investment banking
summary: Citigroup has appointed David Biller, 41, as the new head for corporate and investment banking (CIB) for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). Biller will replace Will McLane, who led the Asean CIB franchise for five years. Biller will relocate his family to Singapore this year, taking over from McLane. Additionally, Jonathan Quek, 37, has been appointed as the new head for investment banking in Singapore.

site_title: SEC commissioner raises questions about unequal voting rights for shareholders
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission Commissioner Kara Stein raised concerns about unequal voting rights for shareholders, citing the recent Snap Inc. IPO as an example. The shares sold to outside investors did not include voting rights, raising questions about the impact on capital formation and emergent public companies. Stein emphasized the need for regulators to address these complex issues and consider the precedent being set.

site_title: London home prices rise more than average pay
summary: London home prices have risen more than the average pay in 31% of UK local authority districts over the past two years, according to Halifax. The biggest gap was in Haringey, where house prices increased by £139,803, exceeding average take-home earnings by £91,450. This highlights regional disparities and makes it difficult for new buyers to enter the market. Only areas in the north-east, Scotland, and Northern Ireland saw earnings exceed house price increases.

site_title: Banks say loan repayment ability still key even with easing of total debt servicing ratio
summary: The Singapore government has eased the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) for mortgage equity withdrawal loans with a loan-to-value (LTV) ratio of 50% or below, allowing homeowners to monetize their properties without the TDSR restriction. This move aims to give flexibility to homeowners, especially business owners and semi-retirees, to generate cash flow. However, banks emphasize that borrowers must demonstrate their ability to repay the loan, and that loan amounts will depend on factors such as age and income stream.

site_title: Property: Don't get too excited
summary: The Singapore government announced tweaks to the residential property market, including easing seller's stamp duty (SSD) measures, allowing homeowners to wait only three years to avoid SSD when selling properties. The move aims to aid speculative activity and give a fillip to developers, but experts caution not to get too excited, as cooling measures remain in place and a rising interest rate environment may dampen sentiment. The government's priority is to prevent a sharp decline in prices while ensuring the competitiveness of Singapore's workforce in a soft economy.

site_title: Saizen Reit to be liquidated after proposed RTO falls through
summary: Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) will be liquidated after its proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal with Sime Darby Property Singapore fell through. The deal, which was twice delayed, had a long-stop date of March 31, 2017, but failed to be completed by then. The Reit's manager announced the liquidation proceedings and urged unitholders to exercise caution in trading shares. The deal was crucial for Saizen Reit, which had become a cash trust after selling its Japanese properties in 2016.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: The Fullerton Hotel's Young Hawker Series continues until March 18, featuring third-generation hawker Michael Ker showcasing family recipes of popiah and kueh pie tee. On March 19, a one-night-only Double Feasting Dinner will be held, with chef Drew Nocente collaborating with local chef Ming Tan. The dinner features 11 dishes, with seats costing S$98++ for food only or S$148++ inclusive of free-flow beer and wine.

site_title: Looking Good in the Future
summary: A recent BeautyAsia trade fair in Singapore showcased cutting-edge beauty trends and technology, including portable skincare devices, natural and organic products, and DNA treatment. Key innovations include the ionic skin care system, DeepSkin, which uses microcurrents to deliver nutrients; Italy's Skin Up, a slim mobile phone-like gadget that nebulizes hyaluronic acid; and Japanese company Primary Step's hydrogen dispenser, which converts hydrogen molecules into nano particles. Other notable products include natural and organic ranges from Miyuki Corporation, Beyond Organic Skincare, and Dermanour, as well as fermentation-based skincare from Glory International and Magic Beauty. The industry is also exploring the use of DNA testing and personalized skincare, with Imagen Labs offering customized skin and nutrition analyses.

site_title: Vallianz gets support to repay part of US$163m debt, lenders to get shared security package
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore support vessel owner-operator, has secured lenders' support to restructure its US$163.2 million debt. The new repayment term is approximately 8.2 years, with maturity extended to December 2022. In exchange, the group will grant lenders a shared security package over subsidiaries and fixed assets. This restructuring will defer principal repayments of US$103.5 million for the next two years, relieving cash flow. The move aims to position Vallianz to withstand a multi-year sectorial downturn.

site_title: Freddie Mac considering backing single-family rentals
summary: Freddie Mac is considering backing loans for single-family rental homes, a move that could help alleviate the US rental shortage. This follows a similar move by Fannie Mae, which has been experimenting with such transactions. The US government regulator is looking to allow the housing finance companies to expand their activities, with the goal of better understanding their role in the market. The move aims to address the growing housing shortage and provide more affordable rental options for Americans.

site_title: Sax and violins
summary: Grammy-winning jazz fusion band Yellowjackets released their 23rd album, Cohearance, featuring a funkier and sax-heavy sound. In contrast, iconic rock band Kansas made a comeback with their album The Prelude Implicit (TPI), marking a triumphant return after a 16-year hiatus. The album taps into Kansas's rich history, recalling their finest moments. Meanwhile, Tannoy celebrated its 90th anniversary by releasing the GRF90, a large speaker with impressive sound quality and retro styling, retailing at S$29,000.

images.alt_text: Yellowjackets: Cohearance
Kansas: The Prelude Implicit
A few quality watts are all that are needed to deliver the massive dynamics and brutal bass power for which Tannoys are famous.

site_title: A Touch of Seoul
summary: Chef Kim Dae Chun, a South Korean-born chef, has been named the Miele One To Watch at the Asia's 50 Best Restaurants awards ceremony in Bangkok. At 37, his restaurant Toc Toc received the award, which recognizes a rising star in the Asian dining scene. This is the first time the award has been presented in Asia by the German appliance maker. Kim's relationship with food began at age six when he cooked his own meals, and it has now paid off after three decades.

site_title: Pre-flight Celebrity Dining
summary: Celebrity chef Wolfgang Puck's restaurant, The Kitchen, has opened at Changi Airport's Terminal 3 Departure Transit Lounge. The restaurant serves global comfort fare, including Hot & Sour Soup, Korean Beef Short Ribs, and Chicken Salad, from 6am to 1am. This addition provides an early dining option for travelers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SBI Offshore's special investigation committee recommended commencing proceedings against Hui Choon Ho and Tan Woo Thian for breach of directors' duties. China Everbright Water secured a 956 million yuan investment in a public-private partnership project in China's Hubei province. OUE Limited exited a proposed integrated resort project in South Korea, selling its 40% stake for up to US$22.9 million. Stamford Tyres reported a 154.59% increase in net profit to S$2.3 million in its third quarter.

site_title: Country Garden shuts China showrooms amid tighter FX controls
summary: Country Garden Holdings Co Ltd has shut some China showrooms promoting its Malaysian Forest City project due to stricter foreign exchange policies. The closures are aimed at adapting to China's tighter controls on moving funds out of the country, affecting sales of Forest City apartments. The developer plans to diversify its sales strategy and set up new showrooms in countries like the Middle East, India, and Japan to expand its reach. The move comes as China's capital controls are expected to be enforced more forcefully this year.

site_title: Having the Last Laugh
summary: Patek Philippe's Calatrava Pilot Travel Time watch, launched two years ago, has become a surprise hit despite initial criticism. Critics panned it for looking too similar to other pilot watches and being too big and expensive. However, the watch's unique design and high-quality craftsmanship have won over collectors, with a two-year waiting list for the model. Patek Philippe's CEO, Thierry Stern, had anticipated the criticism but intended to surprise fans with a new release. He has confirmed that the watch is a commercial success, with limited production to maintain exclusivity.

site_title: Surprise tweaks in property cooling measures seen signalling further unwinding
summary: Singapore's government has made "calibrated adjustments" to property cooling measures, potentially signaling a further unwinding of these measures. The tweaks include removing the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework for mortgage equity withdrawal loans with loan-to-value ratios of 50% or less and paring the seller's stamp duty (SSD) for those holding properties for less than three years. However, the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and LTV limits remain unchanged, limiting the impact on the market. The tweaks are seen as a test of the market, with some experts viewing them as a release of pressure and others seeing them as a signal that the government is preparing to further ease cooling measures, potentially boosting the housing market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Swipe right on art
summary: A Singapore-based startup, ARTO, has launched an app that uses artificial intelligence to recommend artworks to users based on their preferences. The app, which combines elements of Instagram, Tinder, and Spotify, allows users to discover and buy art they love. ARTO has partnered with over 20,000 art pieces from galleries, independent artists, and museums, and takes a transaction fee for every sale. The app aims to make art more accessible to the masses and has received positive reviews from users, who praise its user-friendly interface and ability to learn users' taste in art.

images.alt_text: "With the other services, you have to search for art. ARTO has reversed the process. Don't search - we will recommend it," says Mr Oostveen.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine sector is expected to remain overweight in 2017-2021, with floating production storage and offloading vessels (FPSOs) being the largest segment. Energy Maritime Associates predicts 83-168 orders, while Sembcorp Marine has secured a new contract for a floating storage and offloading vessel. Tat Hong Holdings' tower crane rental division in China is a bright spot, with higher utilization rates, but the group's overall outlook remains mixed. Health Management International is expected to see significant revenue growth and margin expansion, leading to a "buy" rating and S$0.83 target price.

site_title: Bulls get louder on Japanese stocks
summary: Foreign investors are shifting into Tokyo stocks, with US-listed ETFs tracking the market, as Japanese equities are seen as a cheap bet due to a weaker yen and interest-rate hikes. Bond billionaire Jeffrey Gundlach reiterates his bullish stance on Tokyo equities, citing the reflation trade and potential for money managers to shift into shares from bonds. This trend is expected to benefit from dollar asset diversification and is seen as a positive development for Japan's stock market.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: Celine Tan, Chief Operating Officer of The Ate Group, shares her typical weekend routine. She starts with a long cardio and core session at Virgin Active Fitness, followed by dining out at local spots like Jean-Georges Vongerichten and The Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar. The couple also enjoys coffee at The Coffee Academics and occasionally treats themselves to Sunday Folks' Gula Melaka soft serve. They end their weekend testing new recipes and preparing healthy Sunday dinners. This consistent routine helps them stay in shape and energized for the week ahead.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Building firms eye Peru as scandal leaves void
summary: Peru's finance minister, Alfredo Thorne, announced plans to build 150,000 new public housing units, despite a graft scandal that has left a void in the construction industry. Over 25 companies from around the world have expressed interest in operating in Peru, seeking investment opportunities after some of the country's biggest builders were barred from participating in public tenders due to corruption. The government aims to stimulate growth and increase infrastructure, with a new package of measures including an additional 5.5 billion soles for public investments.

site_title: South Korean court throws President Park out of office
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court removed President Park Geun-hye from office due to a graft scandal involving conglomerates, marking the country's first democratically elected leader to be forced from office. Park, 65, had concealed the truth and cracked down on critics, violating the constitution and law. She no longer has immunity and could face criminal charges over bribery, extortion, and abuse of power. A presidential election will be held in 60 days, and Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn will serve as acting president until then.

site_title: One-litre Wonder
summary: Audi's A3 Sedan has received a mid-life upgrade, featuring a new front grille, LED headlights, and a revised interior design. The most notable change is the introduction of a 1.0-litre turbocharged three-cylinder engine, which reduces emissions and fuel consumption while maintaining 200Nm of torque. The new engine drops the A3's CO2 emissions by 37% and annual road tax by 37%. Despite the downsized engine, the A3's acceleration and responsiveness remain impressive, with a 0-100km/h time of 9.9 seconds.

images.alt_text: AUDI A3 1.0 TFSI
AUDI A3 1.0 TFSI

site_title: Singapore property market finally sees slight easing - and a new stamp duty
summary: Singapore has introduced targeted tweaks to its property market measures, including a lower seller's stamp duty and a revised Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) framework. The changes, effective March 11, aim to promote a sustainable residential property market while responding to recent economic developments. The government has also introduced the Additional Conveyance Duties to plug a loophole in property transactions. While the measures are seen as a response to the cooling of the market, industry players expect limited impact, as other curbs, such as ABSD and TDSR, remain in place.

site_title: STI ends week on firm note after property news
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week on a firm note, rising 0.4% to 3,133.35, after news that property curbs were to be loosened slightly. The index gained 14.51 points on Friday, with real estate counters surging, led by City Developments. Oil prices plunged 5% on Thursday but recovered on Friday. The week's turnover averaged S$1.05 billion, with 2.6 billion units traded on Friday.

site_title: The mother of all comebacks
summary: Barcelona stunned the football world by coming back from a 4-0 deficit in the first leg of their Champions League matchup against Paris Saint-Germain. The Spanish team scored six goals in the second leg, including three in the final minutes, to win 6-5 on aggregate and send PSG crashing out. This historic comeback, which was considered impossible, marked the first time in Champions League history a team has overcome a 4-0 deficit. Barcelona's Lionel Messi, Luis Suarez, and Neymar led the charge, with Messi scoring three goals and Neymar scoring twice, including the winning goal in the 95th minute.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Trump selling supporters a ticket to hell
summary: Donald Trump has been accused of overselling his voters, promising unrealistic results in his presidential campaign. He has a history of exaggerating his success and charm, which has alienated the elite and attracted a populist base. Trump's lack of focus, impulsiveness, and dishonesty have led to disastrous missteps and broken promises, including his healthcare and border wall plans. His supporters, who were initially drawn to his outsider image, are now facing the harsh reality of his presidency, which may lead to loss of life and financial hardship.

site_title: US jobs, wages show solid gains in Trump's first full month
summary: US employers added 235,000 jobs in February, exceeding expectations, with construction and manufacturing leading the gains. The unemployment rate fell to 4.7%, and wages grew 2.8% from February 2016, marking solid gains in the labor market under President Trump's leadership.

site_title: US tourism sector faces squeeze of strong US dollar, Trump travel ban
summary: The US tourism sector is anticipating a challenging year due to a strong US dollar and uncertainty surrounding President Donald Trump's travel ban. The revised executive order banning citizens from six Muslim-majority nations from traveling to the US may deter visitors and hurt the US image. Industry representatives expressed concern that the order could scare off tourists from other countries, despite the six countries accounting for a tiny percentage of US visitors.

site_title: It's time women settle for more
summary: A recent study by NUS Business School found that female directors in Singapore earn 56.8% of what male directors earn on average, resulting in a 43.2% gender pay gap. Despite this, many Singaporean women are unaware, nonchalant, or resigned to the disparity. Experts attribute the lack of outrage to internalized sexism, complacency, and privilege, as well as the perception of a meritocracy that fails to address the issue. To address the pay gap, women are advised to be bold, support one another, and push back against patriarchal beliefs and apathy.

site_title: Airlines demand clarity from Britain on post-Brexit flying
summary: Airlines are demanding clarity from the UK government on post-Brexit flying regulations, as the deadline for preparing flight schedules in a post-Brexit Europe approaches. The UK must renegotiate access to Europe's skies, with EU-based airlines having the right to fly to and from any country in the bloc. Airlines like Ryanair and easyJet are already curtailing growth in Britain and seeking alternative operating licenses in EU member states. The UK government has vowed to seek "liberal access," but industry experts warn that talks may be messy and emotionally charged, potentially limiting Britain's access to European skies.

site_title: US jobs, wages show solid gains in Trump's first full month
summary: US jobs and wages showed solid gains in President Trump's first full month, with 235,000 new jobs added in February, exceeding estimates. The unemployment rate fell to 4.7%, and wages grew 2.8% from February 2016. Construction and manufacturing jobs surged, while retail positions declined. The data validate recent comments from Federal Reserve officials indicating a likely interest-rate increase this month, and suggest that consumer spending remains intact despite January's slowdown.

images.alt_text: US employers added jobs at an above-average pace for a second month on outsized gains in construction and manufacturing, showing the labor market continued its steady growth in the new year.

site_title: RBS investors told to reveal funding in cash call case
summary: A High Court judge ordered Royal Bank of Scotland's (RBS) legal representatives to reveal the source of its funding to meet the risks of a £12 billion trial. The RBS Shareholder Action Group, backed by 100 institutions, must provide information on its ability to cover legal expenses by Friday. The judge expressed concerns over the group's transparency and funding, following a £100 million legal bill so far. The trial, starting in May, is over allegations RBS misled investors during a 2008 cash call.

site_title: Former DBS trader convicted in Singapore's first spoofing case
summary: A former DBS trader, Dennis Tey Thean Yang, pleaded guilty to 8 of 23 charges in Singapore's first spoofing case, convicting him of artificially moving prices through fraudulent securities orders and misusing trading accounts. Yang, 33, made a profit of S$30,239 and was a broker at DBS Vickers Securities from late 2012 to early 2013. The case marks a significant step in regulators' efforts to increase scrutiny of market misconduct, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the white-collar crime police collaborating since 2015.

site_title: Targeted approach likely to have muted market impact
summary: Singapore's government has introduced targeted adjustments to the seller's stamp duty (SSD) and total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework, aiming to minimize market impact. The changes include reducing the SSD holding period to three years and cutting rates by four percentage points. However, experts believe the move is largely a minor tweak to address market feedback, rather than a sign of unwinding property cooling measures. The government has also introduced new taxes on transfer of shares in residential-property-holding entities, which may increase transaction costs for property funds and developers.

site_title: Where are the dinosaur onesies for girls?
summary: A mother expresses frustration over the prevalence of pink and purple in girls' clothing and toys, citing stereotypes that limit her daughter's options and ambitions. She argues that these biases are perpetuated by businesses, parents, and teachers, and can be insidious and hard to detect. International Women's Day has sparked discussion on gender equality, and she believes that stereotypes can have a profound impact on children's lives, limiting their potential and opportunities.

site_title: Theresa May is told Brexit hard truths as EU readies for talks
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May is facing tough Brexit negotiations as EU leaders vow to unite and ensure the UK loses more than it gains from quitting the bloc. EU leaders, including Germany and Denmark, warn of a long and difficult process, with some suggesting the UK's trade deal could take 15 years to seal. May's hopes of a quick trade deal were also undermined by Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny, who said the UK may need to pay for its previous EU commitments.

site_title: Temasek holds annual review on CEO succession
summary: Temasek Holdings' board conducts an annual review of potential candidates for CEO succession as part of succession planning. Senior Minister of State for Finance and Law Indranee Rajah confirmed this in response to a question from non-constituency member of parliament Leon Perera.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings' board conducts an annual review of potential candidates as part of succession planning.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises as investors cheer robust jobs data
summary: US stocks rose on Friday as a strong jobs report showed 235,000 jobs added in February, beating economists' estimates. The unemployment rate fell to 4.7% and average earnings rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all increased, with technology providing the biggest boost. The odds of a rate hike by the Federal Reserve rose to 92% after the report, and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's conference next week will be closely watched for clues on future rate hikes.

site_title: Quick takes: Some property measures eased for first time since 2009, more to follow?
summary: The Singapore government has relaxed the Seller's Stamp Duty (SSD) for residential properties, a measure not seen since 2009, as part of targeted adjustments to the property cooling measures. The easing aims to make it easier for retirees to monetize their properties. Analysts predict the move will have a marginal impact on the transaction volumes and prices, and more easing is expected to follow, unless there are significant changes in the environment, such as higher interest rates and domestic unemployment.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: The Eurozone: Breaking up is hard to do
summary: The eurozone remains intact, despite ongoing concerns over potential breakup. Risks at the individual country level, particularly in the Netherlands, France, and Italy, pose a threat to the region's stability. Populist parties, such as Marine Le Pen's National Front in France, have gained support, but it's unlikely they can implement their policies due to the requirement of an act of parliament to leave the eurozone. Germany's election may pose a risk to Chancellor Angela Merkel, but a pro-euro candidate is likely to emerge, potentially strengthening the eurozone. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program is likely to continue, maintaining downward pressure on the euro.

images.alt_text: ANTI-EURO While presidential candidate Marine Le Pen advocates an exit from the eurozone, French support for the euro is relatively strong at 67 per cent.

site_title: In Praise of Poultry
summary: A Singaporean article highlights the versatility and quality of chicken as a dining option, challenging the common perception of it as cheap and tasteless. Forward-thinking farms in Malaysia offer high-tech, humane, and affordable alternatives to organic poultry. Several restaurants in Singapore, including Dragon Phoenix Restaurant, Sin Kee Famous Cantonese Chicken Rice, Arnold's Fried Chicken, Manhill Restaurant, and Birds of a Feather, showcase their expertise in preparing various chicken dishes, from steamed with ham and kailan to crispy fried chicken, paper-wrapped chicken, and spicy chicken nuggets. These establishments demonstrate that cooking chicken can be an art form, offering a range of flavors and textures that cater to different tastes and preferences.

site_title: EU plans measures to block foreign takeovers of strategic firms
summary: The European Union plans to implement measures to block "politically-motivated" foreign takeovers of strategic firms, including defense, transport infrastructure, and critical technologies. The proposal, from the European Commission's industry department, aims to scrutinize investments of strategic importance from both economic and security perspectives. The move comes after Germany, France, and Italy requested action against takeovers that could harm Europe's strategic interests, particularly in sectors affected by Chinese investments. The plan would need approval from EU states, the European Parliament, and Commission departments.

site_title: Clear survivors emerging in O&M sector: UOB Kay Hian
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) sector remains cash-flow stressed, with core EBITDA margins declining by 4.2% to 16.2% in FY16. However, certain small- to mid-cap companies, such as Dyna-mac Holdings, Mermaid Maritime, and Nordic Group, are emerging as clear survivors, driven by strong core EBITDA margins and net gearing. UOB Kay Hian maintains its preference for asset owners over yards, citing a potential rebound in 2018, but warns of ongoing risks, including oil price fluctuations and potential impairment charges.

site_title: Taiwan detains China student for alleged espionage
summary: Taiwan has detained a Chinese student, Zhou Hongxu, suspected of espionage. Zhou, a 30-year-old recent graduate from National Chengchi University, is being investigated for allegedly recruiting a spy circle and obtaining classified information. The detention comes amid worsening ties between Taipei and Beijing, with China viewing Taiwan as part of its territory. This is the latest in a string of espionage cases, following a former Taiwanese intelligence officer's 18-year prison sentence for double agent activities.

site_title: SBI advised to pursue breach of directors' duties
summary: SBI Offshore has been advised to pursue legal proceedings against Hui Choon Ho and Tan Woo Thian for breach of directors' duties related to the purchase and sale of a stake in Jiangyin Neptune Appliance Co Ltd. The recognized agreements stated SBI acquired the stake for US$350,000 and sold it for US$1.75 million, contradicting previous announcements of US$1.75 million and US$3.5 million. The company also plans to take legal action against Lau Yoke Mun, an ex-employee who allegedly lied to the board about misplacing bank tokens and misappropriating funds.

site_title: OUE exits project to build South Korea's first foreign-owned integrated resort
summary: OUE Limited is exiting its 40% investment in South Korea's first foreign-owned integrated resort project in Incheon, selling its stake to a joint venture company formed by Caesars Entertainment Corporation and Guangzhou R&F Properties Co for up to $22.9 million. The project, initially expected for the 2018 Winter Olympics, has been put on hold. OUE is also selling its adjacent land plot for $2 million.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: The case for the US$500 Beer Cooler
summary: A US$500 Beer Cooler, designed by Rovr Products, aims to balance mobility and durability for outdoor enthusiasts. The cooler features 8-inch all-terrain tires, a flip-down aluminum handle, and a rugged design, making it suitable for trips to the beach, soccer fields, or tailgating events. With a capacity to hold 60 cans of beer and 20 pounds of ice, the cooler also includes features such as cupholders, a cutting board, and a rigid popup bin. Its design prioritizes cold retention, with a three-compartment dry bin located at the lowest point for optimal performance.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day higher, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.16 points to 1,717.580. Trading volume reached 3.40 billion lots valued at RM3.19 billion, with 471 gainers outnumbering losers 435.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won firmer as sentiment improves after impeachment
summary: South Korean shares ended at a one-week high on Friday after the Constitutional Court removed President Park Geun-hye from office. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.3% to 2,097.35 points, its highest since March 2. Offshore investors bought a net 160 billion won worth of Kospi shares, driving the index up 0.9% for the week. The South Korean won also gained slightly, quoted at 1,157.4 to the US dollar. The ruling is expected to reduce market uncertainty and potentially pressure heavyweight shares like Samsung Electronics.

site_title: IranAir receives second jet under sanctions deal
summary: IranAir has received its second Western jet under a nuclear sanctions deal, an Airbus A330 long-haul aircraft, following a delivery of a medium-haul A321 earlier this year. The 238-seat aircraft was originally built for Avianca but was bought back by Airbus. IranAir has ordered 100 jets from Airbus and 80 from Boeing under the deal, with the aircraft expected to be used mainly on European routes and to Beijing and Kuala Lumpur. The delivery comes in time for Iran's new year in March, following last-minute talks over Rolls-Royce engines and spare parts.

site_title: Volkswagen, Tata Motors target strategic Indian car alliance
summary: Volkswagen AG and Tata Motors Ltd have signed a memorandum of understanding to form a strategic alliance on joint projects in India. The partnership aims to develop mobility services, vehicle components, and models, with specific projects to be disclosed in the coming months. The collaboration is seen as a way for Volkswagen to boost its presence in emerging markets, particularly in India, where it has struggled to create affordable vehicles. Tata Motors gains access to Volkswagen's global presence, while the German automaker seeks to revitalize its strategy in the region.

site_title: Everbright Water to lead water restoration project in Hubei, China
summary: Everbright Water Limited has secured a lead role in a public-private partnership project in Hubei, China, worth approximately 956 million yuan. The Suizhou High-tech Park PPP Project will focus on integrated environmental water services, including landscaping, industrial waste water treatment, and water environment restoration. Everbright Water will hold an 78.4% stake in the project, while the government will hold 20%. The project aims to address environmental issues in the region through a combination of private investment and government support.

site_title: Man killed at KL airport was Kim Jong Nam: police
summary: Malaysia's police chief confirmed that the man killed at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was Kim Jong Nam, the estranged half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The body was identified without giving details. This marks the first official confirmation of Kim Jong Nam's identity. He was traveling on a passport under the name of Kim Chol.

site_title: Stamford Tyres' net profit surges 154.6% in Q3
summary: Stamford Tyres reported a 154.6% surge in net profit to S$2.3 million in its third quarter, driven by a 25.8% rise in gross profit margin. Revenue edged up 0.26% to S$59.7 million. The company attributed the improvement to lower cost of sales and contributions from its retail chain and truck tyre centres.

site_title: Luxembourg's wooing is working as finance firms set Brexit plans
summary: Luxembourg is attracting finance firms with its post-Brexit appeal, with insurers, asset managers, and fintech companies interested in setting up shop. Finance Minister Pierre Gramegna stated that Luxembourg is a "natural choice" for companies seeking to remain in the EU. Insurance giant American International Group and Lloyd's of London have announced plans to open operations in Luxembourg. The country's swift adoption of EU laws and rules is swaying companies looking to maintain EU presence after the UK's exit.

images.alt_text: Luxembourg is becoming a serious contender among nations bidding for business to come their way after the UK's exit from the European Union, as insurers, asset managers and financial-technology companies are interested in setting up shop in the Grand Duchy.

site_title: Fervent acquires industrial land in Changshu
summary: VIBRANT Group Ltd's subsidiary, Fervent Industrial Development (Suzhou) Co, Ltd, has acquired a 50-year leasehold industrial land in Changshu High Tech Industrial Park, Jiangsu, for 76,553 square meters worth 24.1 million yuan. The leasehold is located next to Fervent's first completed Changshu Fervent Industrial Park. Vibrant's subsidiaries hold a 48% effective shareholding interest in the project, funded by internal sources.

site_title: Singapore shares finish week on firm note after property news
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week on a firm note, closing at 3,133.35 on Friday after news of slightly loosened property curbs boosted the market. The STI rose 11 points, or 0.4%, for the week, following a 5% plunge in oil prices on Thursday. Trading volume increased to 2.6 billion units worth S$1.4 billion on Friday, with the advance-decline score at 269-195.

site_title: A different Hybrid
summary: Hyundai has introduced its first petrol-electric model, the Ioniq, which offers a unique blend of features and fuel efficiency. Launched in Korea last year, the Ioniq has gained strong demand in Singapore, where it is priced at S$28,000 with a maximum rebate of S$30,000. The hybrid car boasts a 1.6-litre engine, lithium-ion polymer battery, and a 6-speed dual clutch transmission, providing a sporty and direct driving experience. With a claimed 3.9 litres per 100 km fuel efficiency, the Ioniq is positioned as a competitor to other hybrid models, offering a range of up to 1,150 km.

images.alt_text: HYUNDAI IONIQ
HYUNDAI IONIQ

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with a gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a gain, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.29% to close at 23,568.67. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.12%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.20%. Investors await US jobs data later in the day, despite early losses fueled by tumbling energy firms.

site_title: Temasek holds annual review exercise on CEO succession
summary: Temasek Holdings conducts an annual review of potential candidates for its CEO succession as part of succession planning. Senior Minister of State for Finance and Law Indranee Rajah confirmed this in Parliament, in response to a question by MP Leon Perera. No specific details were provided on the review process or the candidates being considered. The review is part of Temasek's ongoing efforts to ensure a smooth transition of leadership.

site_title: Saizen Reit to be liquidated after proposed RTO falls through
summary: Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) will be liquidated after a proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal with Sime Darby Property Singapore fell through. The RTO was intended to be completed by March 31, 2017, but further discussions led to its cancellation. The Reit's manager, Japan Residential Assets Manager Limited, will initiate liquidation proceedings and inform unitholders of next steps, urging caution in trading shares. The decision marks the end of the transaction process that began in August 2016.

site_title: Thai artisans craft for king's funeral
summary: Thai artisans are crafting intricate clay sculptures to adorn the funeral pyre of former King Bhumibol Adulaydej, who died last October. The 50-meter pyre, featuring animals, gods, and mythical creatures, will be built in Bangkok's historic heart. The sculptures, made by dozens of artisans, will be placed at the center of the pyre and set alight, carrying Bhumibol's spirit to Mount Meru, a symbol of the universe in Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain cosmology. The exact date of the funeral is yet to be determined by King Maha Vajiralongkorn.

site_title: Musk bets he can fix Aussie power woes in 100 days or it's free
summary: Billionaire Elon Musk has pledged to solve Australia's energy crisis within 100 days by deploying Tesla technology, offering a 100-megawatt power system at $25 million. The proposal comes after a state-wide blackout in September due to severe storms and a high reliance on renewable energy. Musk tweeted that if the system isn't installed within 100 days, it's free. Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has denied the blackout was connected to the state's renewable energy, but is open to discussing the Tesla proposal.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. London's FTSE 100 index advanced 0.3% to 7,335.40 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose 0.3%. The gains came ahead of key US jobs data, with investors awaiting its impact on the market.

site_title: Oil trades below US$50 after US supply glut erases Opec's gains
summary: Oil prices fell below $50 a barrel after US supply glut erased Opec's gains, wiping out a 7.6% slump in the past four sessions. US stockpiles reached a record high for four consecutive weeks, and output surged to the highest level in over a year. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has seen global inventories fall slower than expected, opening the door to extending an output-cut deal. Oil prices are set for the biggest weekly loss since November 4.

site_title: German trade surplus rises alongside US tensions
summary: Germany's trade surplus rose to 18.5 billion euros in January, up 2.7% from December, with exports increasing 11.8% and imports 3.0%. The US has criticized Germany's export strength, with President Trump promising to act, despite Germany being the US's biggest export customer in 2016. The US has accused the euro single currency of giving Germany an unfair advantage, but German leaders reject the allegations. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble will meet US counterpart Steven Mnuchin next week to discuss trade tensions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government relaxed Seller's Stamp Duty (SSD) rates for residential properties, easing property-market curbs. Real-estate stocks soared to a 2015 high, while the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) was relaxed for mortgage equity withdrawal loans with a loan-to-value ratio of 50% and below. Retail sales in January rose 2% from the previous year, and DBS priced a S$400m bond at 2.83%. A former DBS trader pleaded guilty to spoofing Singapore's securities market in the country's first case.

site_title: UK loses momentum as factories, builders reduce output
summary: The UK's economy experienced a loss of momentum in January, with factory output falling 0.9% and total industrial production declining 0.4%. Building firms also reduced output by 0.4%. Despite a strong end to 2016, the figures indicate a slowdown in economic growth, with economists expecting growth to slow to 0.6% in the first quarter. Rising prices and input costs are affecting households and firms, with the trade deficit marginally lower than in December at £10.8 billion.

site_title: Taiwan government plans NT$1 trillion stimulus package
summary: Taiwan's government plans an eight-year stimulus package of up to NT$1 trillion to boost the island's export-driven economy. The package, which needs legislative approval, aims to increase domestic investments and achieve stable economic growth through infrastructure improvement projects. Premier Lin Chuan said the proposal is close to earlier estimates of NT$800 billion to NT$1 trillion, with the goal of implementing the projects sooner rather than later.

site_title: Carmakers eye more UK suppliers to handle hard Brexit
summary: Car manufacturers in the UK are considering increasing local sourcing of parts to mitigate the impact of potential tariffs following a hard Brexit. Currently, 41% of parts in British-built cars are sourced domestically, with some firms planning to increase this to 50-55% or more. The UK government is expected to provide support to kick-start investment in local parts production, which could create jobs and boost the economy. However, concerns remain about the feasibility of meeting the required localization rate, with some firms doubting the UK's ability to attract major supplier investments.

site_title: Australia sees second year of Barrier Reef bleaching
summary: Australia's Great Barrier Reef has experienced its second consecutive year of mass coral bleaching, with temperatures being high enough to cause widespread bleaching, particularly in the central part of the reef. This is the first time the reef has not had a few years between bleaching events to recover, with scientists warning many species will struggle to recover. The back-to-back occurrence of widespread bleaching also means there is insufficient time for corals to fully recover, with many species appearing more susceptible to bleaching after sustained above-average ocean temperatures.

site_title: PSA and SIT in training tie-up for smart port technologies
summary: PSA Corp and the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) have signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate on smart port technologies. SIT will develop a 16-month training program to equip PSA engineers with skills in designing and maintaining complex integrated systems. In return, PSA will deliver guest lectures and offer scholarships and work-study positions to SIT students. The collaboration aims to develop a talent pool for the maritime industry and propel the Singapore port to excellence and productivity.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher as automakers, banks rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.48% on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index ending at 19,604.61, driven by gains in automakers and banks as the yen weakened. Toshiba erased early losses despite concerns about its US nuclear unit. The benchmark index rallied, while the Topix index of all first-section issues rose 1.24%.

site_title: US dollar hits 7-week high vs yen ahead of US jobs data
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-week high against the yen ahead of US jobs data, which is expected to support a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next week. A strong private US jobs report bolstered bets on a rate hike, with markets pricing in an almost 90% chance of a hike. This follows recent signals from Fed officials, further strengthening the case for a rate increase.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rose to seven-week highs against the yen on Friday, as investors awaited US jobs data that is likely to cement expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next week.

site_title: Gold falls below key US$1,200 level ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices fell below the US$1,200 level ahead of the US non-farm payrolls report, pressured by a stronger US dollar. Spot gold dropped 0.4% to US$1,196.21 per ounce, its weakest since January 31. Investors await the jobs data to gauge the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans, which could pressure gold prices further.

images.alt_text: Gold fell below the key level of US$1,200 an ounce on Friday and was on track for its worst week in four months, pressured by a stronger US dollar ahead of the closely-watched US non-farm payrolls report due later in the day.

site_title: Indian sugar mills want limits on government imports
summary: Indian sugar mills have recommended the government limit sugar imports to 400,000 to 500,000 tons if imports occur. The Indian Sugar Mills Association (ISMA) believes there is enough domestic sugar production, citing a 4.7% reduction in this season's sugar production estimate to 20.3 million tons. Unrestricted imports could burden the industry and farmers in the medium and long term. If imports do occur, priority should be given to mills in the country's south and west.

site_title: EU and Asean agree to put free trade pact back on agenda
summary: The European Union and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) have agreed to revive plans for a Free Trade Agreement (FTA), aiming to connect the EU to the world's seventh-largest market. The initial talks were halted in 2009 due to complexities and human rights issues, but the EU and Asean officials have established a framework for talks to restart. The goal is to create a region-to-region agreement that would benefit both blocs, particularly with strong growth in Vietnam and the Philippines. A targeted timeframe has not been set.

site_title: UBS revises 2016 profit down, cuts CEO pay and bonuses
summary: UBS lowered its 2016 profit by 102 million Swiss francs due to a settlement with the National Credit Union Association over mis-selling residential mortgage-backed securities. The bank also reduced CEO Sergio Ermotti's compensation to 13.7 million francs, down from 14.3 million in 2015. The bonus pool decreased to 2.9 billion francs from 3.5 billion in 2015.

site_title: China airlines cut some South Korea routes amid political standoff
summary: China airlines have cut some South Korea routes amid a diplomatic row over Seoul's plans to deploy a US missile defense system. Korea's Easter Jet, Costa Cruises, and Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd have stopped flights and port visits between China and South Korea. China has given travel firms a "7-point" verbal instruction to curtail or ban trips to South Korea. The move has sent a chill across South Korea's retail and tourism sectors, prompting a potential complaint to the World Trade Organization. China Eastern Airlines and Spring Airline Co Ltd have also stopped selling tickets for flights to South Korea.

site_title: RBS poised to jettison unprofitable clients, sell loan books
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) plans to sell loan books and reduce lending to Western European corporate clients to bolster its balance sheet and improve returns. The UK government-owned lender aims to reduce risk-weighted assets by 20 billion pounds by selling commercial real estate loans in chunks of £300-400 million. This move is part of a broader effort to cut £750 million of operating expenses and boost net lending growth. RBS will also reduce lending facilities for some clients, but will invest in areas where it can make better returns, such as mortgages and small- and medium-sized company loans.

site_title: Spain struggles to repopulate its deserted interior
summary: Spain's interior region, particularly the northern Aragon and southern Extremadura, struggles with depopulation, with some areas having just two people per square kilometer. The rural exodus began in the 1950s due to factory work and industrialization, and the region's agricultural industry has declined as workers moved to nearby cities for better-paying jobs. Efforts to revive deserted villages, such as Sarnago, have been met with limited success, with restoration of homes and access to basic services not leading to permanent residents. Experts argue that farming and rural tourism can help revitalize the region, but EU agricultural subsidies and outdated farming techniques are also contributing factors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.07% in opening trade on Friday, following the previous day's losses, but were limited by a slump in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,518.86. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.09%.

site_title: Singapore real-estate stocks soar to 2015 high as curbs eased
summary: Singapore's real-estate stocks surged to a 2015 high after authorities eased property-market curbs, including adjusting a borrowing framework and shortening the time to sell a property to avoid a stamp duty. The changes, effective March 11, are seen as a positive move by analysts, who expect shares to re-rate as property prices are expected to rise. The Straits Times Index, led by City Developments Ltd, CapitaLand Ltd, and UOL Group Ltd, rallied 4% or more, marking the highest since July 2015. Analysts believe the measures will buoy shares despite a weak demand outlook.

site_title: China's corporate debt levels are excessively high: central bank
summary: China's corporate debt levels are excessively high, reaching 169% of gross domestic product (GDP), according to the People's Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan. Policymakers are concerned about the risks from rapid debt build-up and an overheating housing market. While efforts to cut debt levels will take time, measures to cool the housing market may slow mortgage demand. The central bank aims to stabilize overall debt levels and slow debt growth, but specifics for tackling the problems are lacking, raising concerns about a potential banking crisis or slower growth.

site_title: Hong Kong Uber drivers found guilty of unlawful commercial car hire
summary: Five Hong Kong Uber drivers were found guilty of using their vehicles for commercial purposes without a license, dealing a blow to the company's operations in the Asian financial hub. The ruling has a chilling effect on Hong Kong drivers working for Uber, which is battling similar issues with regulators across Asia. Uber expressed disappointment with the verdict, following the company's recent exit from Taiwan.

site_title: Aussie shares end at one-week high; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares reached a one-week high, closing 0.6% higher at 5,775.60, driven by gains in financial stocks ahead of a potential US interest rate hike. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose for its fifth consecutive session, with Macquarie Group and the "big four" banks leading the gains. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.51% to a 0.23% weekly gain, driven by healthcare stocks.

site_title: Singapore January retail sales rise 2% from year earlier
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 2% in January from the previous year, driven by increases in supermarket and food and beverage sales. Supermarket sales rose 13% and food and beverage sales rose 12% compared to the same period last year. This follows a revised 0.7% increase in retail sales in the previous month.

site_title: South Korea's longtime 'princess' dethroned in disgrace
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye has been impeached and removed from office, becoming the country's first head of state to be ousted by impeachment. The 65-year-old leader was accused of colluding with her confidant Choi Soon-Sil to embezzle millions from businesses, including Samsung, in exchange for government favors. Park, who rose to power after her father's authoritarian rule, apologized for her actions but was unable to escape the scandal, which exposed corrupt ties between politics and business. Her impeachment marks a significant blow to her legacy and has raised concerns about the country's democratic institutions.

site_title: Malaysia PM Najib calls for unity amid North Korea row
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak called for unity amid tensions with North Korea over the murder of Kim Jong Nam. Nine Malaysians are stuck in North Korea after the country barred them from leaving, sparking a tit-for-tat response from Malaysia. Najib warned Pyongyang not to abuse Malaysia's hospitality and vowed to work behind closed doors to resolve the issue. Malaysia has maintained ties with North Korea despite the murder, but relations have soured, with Malaysia recalling its envoy and expelling the North Korean ambassador.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak called for unity on Friday as he tried to bring home nine Malaysians stuck in North Korea amid a growing row over the murder of Kim Jong Nam, while warning Pyongyang not to abuse Malaysia's "hospitality".

site_title: US solar soared in 2016, but investors still leery
summary: US solar installations nearly doubled to 14.8 gigawatts in 2016, with panel prices dropping 40% due to increased competition and falling costs. Despite this, investors remain cautious due to slowing demand, concerns over federal tax reform, and rising interest rates. The solar industry report forecasts a slowdown in the market this year, with utility systems expected to reach 10 GW by 2021. Residential installations grew 19% last year, but growth is slowing, and companies like SunPower and First Solar are viewing 2017 as a transition year.

site_title: South Korea's Constitutional Court upholds President Park's impeachment
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court upheld President Park Geun-Hye's impeachment, removing her from office over a graft scandal. She becomes the country's first democratically elected leader to be forced from office. A presidential election will be held in 60 days, according to the constitution.

site_title: Baidu will spin off self-driving car unit when mature: CEO
summary: Chinese internet giant Baidu plans to spin off its self-driving car unit when it reaches maturity, aiming for mass production by 2021. CEO Robin Li stated that the company will partner with traditional automakers and invest heavily in the autonomous car business. Baidu is shifting its focus to artificial intelligence and next-generation technologies, with former Microsoft AI expert Qi Lu leading the new division. The company aims to create world-leading AI services, including voice-controlled smart speakers and personal assistants, to drive growth and revenue.

images.alt_text: Chinese internet search giant Baidu Inc intends to spin off its autonomous cars division when it's reached maturity and needs to attract more funding and partners, chief executive Robin Li said.

site_title: Japan says no barriers to auto imports after US fires trade salvo
summary: Japan has rejected US demands for more access to its auto market, saying the country has already eliminated tariffs and non-tariff barriers. The US government claimed non-tariff barriers impede access to Japan's automotive market, but Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that Japan's auto market is already open. A joint dialogue between Japan and the US, led by Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso and US Vice President Mike Pence, is set to focus on infrastructure, foreign direct investment, and energy to avoid contentious issues.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; transport, plastics shares drag
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.91% on Friday, driven by declines in transport and plastics shares. The main Taiex index closed at 9,570.88. The plastics and transport indexes dropped 1.5% each, while the electronics and financial subindexes fell 0.77% and 0.26% respectively. The dollar rose to 1-1/2-month highs versus the yen ahead of the US nonfarm payrolls report, which may influence interest rate hikes this year.

site_title: South Korea's economic woes will bedevil its next president
summary: South Korea's next president will inherit a struggling economy facing heightened risks from China and the US, its biggest trading partners. The country's economy is expected to expand 2.5% this year, the slowest pace since 2012, with rising household debt and a high unemployment rate for millennials. A special election will be held within two months to choose President Park Geun-hye's successor, with opposition candidate Moon Jae-in leading the polls. The next leader will need to address trade protectionism, job creation, and household debt, with a focus on encouraging private companies to hire more workers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars sag to multi-week lows on strong greenback
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell to multi-week lows on Friday due to strong US dollar strength, tracking their second straight weekly loss. The Australian dollar held at US$0.7519, while the New Zealand dollar edged 0.25% higher to US$0.6909. Yields on Australian 10-year bonds jumped to 2.98%, and the Aussie is set to fall 1% for the week. The kiwi has fallen 4% in March, largely due to a resurgent US dollar and weak local economic data. Markets expect a US Federal Reserve rate hike next week.

site_title: Singapore introduces new stamp duty for buyers and sellers of property-holding entities
summary: Singapore introduces the Additional Conveyance Duty (ACD), a new stamp duty on the purchase and sale of equity interests in property-holding entities (PHEs), effective March 11. The ACD targets significant owners of PHEs, including partnerships, trusts, and companies with residential properties forming at least 50% of total assets. The stamp duty rates range from 1-3% on underlying residential properties and a flat 15% on these properties. The current holding period for Seller's Stamp Duty is shortened to three years for direct sales of residential properties.

site_title: China will not devalue yuan to stimulate exports: PBOC deputy governor
summary: China's PBOC deputy governor Yi Gang stated the country will not devalue its yuan to stimulate exports, dismissing concerns of a currency war. China's exports rose 4% in January and February, while imports surged 26.4%, suggesting domestic and foreign demand improvement. However, fears of US protectionism and potential interest rate hikes in the US may impact the yuan's value, with predictions of a 5% fall this year. China will maintain its managed floating exchange rate framework to keep the yuan stable.

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki chiefs meet Modi in India as VW eyes Tata tie-up
summary: Toyota and Suzuki chiefs met with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to discuss a potential alliance, promoting manufacturing in India and exporting new-technology vehicles. The partnership aims to leverage Toyota's global technology and manufacturing expertise with Suzuki's strengths in small car production, especially in India. Volkswagen AG is also in talks to team up with Tata Motors Ltd, while France's PSA Group plans to start producing vehicles in the country. The move is part of India's "Make in India" program, encouraging investments and boosting local manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp and Suzuki Motor Corp discussed their partnership and future technological developments with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi as the two Japanese carmakers accelerate their alliance talks.

site_title: Ex-DBS trader pleads guilty in Singapore's first spoofing case
summary: A former DBS trader, Dennis Tey Thean Yang, pleaded guilty to 8 out of 23 charges related to spoofing in Singapore's securities market. The case, the first jointly pursued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and white-collar crime police, involved Yang artificially moving prices through fraudulent securities orders in 2012 and 2013. Yang's trading strategy, which involved placing and deleting orders, had little market impact. The case is part of Singapore's efforts to step up policing of its financial industry and focus on cases that threaten market integrity.

site_title: One in three UK homeowners earn more from property than work
summary: In the UK, one in three homeowners earn more from property than work, according to Halifax. House prices have risen more than the average take-home pay in 31% of local authority districts, particularly in London and the South East, where the biggest gaps were found. In areas like Haringey, house prices increased by £139,803, exceeding average earnings by £91,450. Only the North East, Scotland, and Northern Ireland saw earnings exceed house price increases.

site_title: Singapore TDSR relaxed for mortgage equity withdrawal loans
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has relaxed the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) for mortgage equity withdrawal loans with a loan-to-value (LTV) ratio of 50% and below, starting March 11. This move aims to promote a sustainable residential property market and financial prudence among households. Current Additional Buyers' Stamp Duties and LTV limits remain unchanged. The decision was made in a joint statement with the Ministries of Finance and National Development.

site_title: Ex ISR Capital executive director continues disposing shares
summary: ISR Capital executive director David Rigoll sold 17.9 million shares for S$804,030, reducing his stake from 26.07% to 24.93%. The sale came a day after he sold 21.3 million shares for S$1 million, following a pay dispute with the board. ISR Capital will seek legal advice to take action against Rigoll, who is accused of breaching a moratorium on selling shares.

site_title: Singapore relaxes Seller's Stamp Duty (SSD) rates
summary: Singapore has relaxed Seller's Stamp Duty (SSD) rates for residential properties. Starting March 11, the SSD rate for holding periods up to a year will be lowered to 12% from 16%. For holding periods between one to two years, the rate will be 8%, and for periods over two years, it will be 4%. No SSD will be payable for holding periods over three years. These changes come as part of a broader set of regulatory changes, including the introduction of the Additional Conveyance Duty (ACD) and easing of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR).

site_title: US launches dumping case over China's aluminium foil exports
summary: The US has launched a trade case against China's aluminium foil exports, accusing Chinese producers of dumping products and damaging the US domestic industry. The Aluminum Association filed petitions with the Department of Commerce and International Trade Commission, citing antidumping margins of 38-134% of the imported aluminium foil's value. China's Commerce Ministry urged the US to act "cautiously", while the US industry sees the move as a commitment to enforcing trade laws and creating a level playing field for domestic producers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.08 points to 1,716.34, following a trend of losing 94 to 65 gainers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as weak yen lifts exporters
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.57% and the Topix index up 0.72%, driven by a weak yen that boosted exporters.

site_title: DBS prices S$400m 2.83% bonds due 2021 for South Beach consortium
summary: DBS priced a S$400 million, 2.83% senior secured bond for the South Beach Consortium, a joint venture between City Developments and IOI Group, to refinance existing secured bank borrowings. The bonds mature on March 17, 2021, and will be issued on March 17, 2017. DBS is the sole bookrunner for the deal.

site_title: Airbnb nears approval in room-starved Japan with tighter rules
summary: Airbnb is set to gain approval in Japan after the government approved rules limiting home-sharing to 180 days a year. The rules, which will be subject to Japan's parliament for approval, distinguish between hosts who share their own dwellings and absentee landlords. The move comes as Japan faces a tourism boom, with 24 million overseas visitors in 2016, and Airbnb is expected to continue growing, with estimates suggesting 35 million visitors by 2020. Hosts have expressed concerns about the impact on their businesses, with about 90% saying the restriction would make their businesses unfeasible.

site_title: Smoking paradise Japan tries to kick the habit
summary: Japan is moving to pass its strictest-ever smoking laws, aiming to change its image as a "puffing paradise" ahead of the 2020 Olympics. The proposed law would ban smoking in many restaurants and public facilities, with penalties of 300,000 yen for rule-breakers. However, the tobacco lobby and some business owners oppose the measures, and the government has watered down the initial proposal. The health ministry will submit the law to parliament by June, but opposition is brewing within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, with some lawmakers suggesting restaurant owners be allowed to choose whether to allow smoking.

site_title: Starbucks CEO's refugee comments sour customer views of chain: survey
summary: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz's vow to hire 10,000 refugees in response to President Trump's travel ban has led to a significant decline in customer sentiment, with a two-thirds drop in the company's Buzz score between January and February. The company's consumer perception levels have fallen from 30% to 26%, with boycott supporters calling for a boycott and urging customers to support rival Dunkin' Donuts. The negative impact on sales is uncertain, with Starbucks' latest quarter reporting an accelerated decline in traffic to established US restaurants.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.17% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 5.42 points to 3,113.42. Despite this, the overall trading volume remained high with 135.8 million shares worth S$97.2 million changing hands. In contrast, US stocks ended slightly higher on Thursday, while Tokyo stocks opened higher due to a weak yen boosting exporters.

site_title: Axe attacker injures five at German station: police
summary: A 36-year-old man from the former Yugoslavia injured seven people, including five, at the Dusseldorf train station in Germany using an axe. The attacker, who jumped from a bridge and suffered serious injuries, was not in a position to be interrogated. Police deployed special units and traffic was halted at the station. The incident comes amid heightened security concerns in Germany following a recent terror attack.

site_title: Financials, healthcare push Aussie shares higher; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,759.2, driven by a boost from financials and healthcare stocks. Banks, particularly Commonwealth Bank, rose as investors anticipate a US interest rate hike. The Republican US healthcare plan's initial hurdle clearance also supported healthcare stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% to 7,164.73, with financials and consumer stocks leading the gains.

site_title: Americans drank more bottled water than soda in 2016
summary: Americans drank more bottled water than soda in 2016, surpassing carbonated soft drinks by volume in the US. Bottled water consumption reached 39.3 gallons per capita, while soda consumption declined to 38.5 gallons. Total bottled water volume rose 9% to 12.8 billion gallons, driven by growing health concerns over sugary beverages. This shift is a significant change from the late 1990s and early 2000s, when soda consumption regularly exceeded 50 gallons per capita.

site_title: China's elderly live longer, but are less fit: study
summary: China's elderly population is growing, with more people over 80 years old, but their mental and physical fitness are declining. A study of nearly 20,000 people found that mortality rates for those 80-105 years old decreased by 1-3%, but physical and cognitive function deteriorated. Simple tasks became harder to perform, and memory scores slumped. The study highlights the need for policy changes and increased investment in healthcare and social care for the rapidly growing elderly population, both in China and globally.

images.alt_text: The number and proportion of people in China over 80 are growing, but their mental and physical fitness appear to be declining, scientists reported Friday.

site_title: Two killed in shooting at Basel cafe, one badly injured: Swiss police
summary: Two people were killed and one seriously injured in a shooting at a cafe in Basel, north-west Switzerland, on Thursday. The assailants, two men, fled the scene after firing several rounds of shots. The motive behind the attack is not yet known and is being investigated. Switzerland has a law allowing military personnel to keep their weapons at home, which has raised concerns about domestic incidents.

site_title: Toshiba's Westinghouse should decide on Chapter 11 by end-March, says govt
summary: Toshiba's Westinghouse unit needs to decide by the end of March whether to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, which is necessary for the Japanese conglomerate to compile audited third-quarter earnings. If Westinghouse misses the deadline, it will face a possible delisting from the Tokyo bourse. Finance Minister Taro Aso has added government pressure on the company to act swiftly, while a Chapter 11 filing may not be a negative step. Toshiba is also pushing forward with the sale of its prized flash memory chip business to address financial problems.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp's Westinghouse unit needs to decide by the end of the month whether to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy so the Japanese conglomerate can compile audited third-quarter earnings without further delays, Japan's Finance Minister said on Friday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Auric Pacific, Del Monte, ISR Capital, Neo Group
summary: Auric Pacific reported that Silver Creek Capital and its concert parties held 86.45% of the company's shares as of March 9, with a 3.55% threshold needed to declare the offer unconditional. Del Monte Pacific returned to profitability in the third quarter with a net profit of $8.5 million, reversing previous net losses. ISR Capital shares extended losses after its largest shareholder, David Rigoll, resigned as executive director and breached a moratorium by selling some of his stake. Neo Group plans to take a stake in food and beverage distributor Asia Farm F&B Pte Ltd.

site_title: May warns on EU budget bill as Brexit start looms
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May warned EU leaders that Britain will not continue paying into the EU budget after Brexit, estimating the financial liabilities at 60 billion euros. May stated she wants to "get on with" leaving the EU, following a deadline to trigger Article 50 by the end of March. EU officials agree that settling Britain's financial liabilities will be a priority in the negotiations.

site_title: Assange says leaks show CIA's 'devastating incompetence'
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange criticized the CIA for its "devastating incompetence" in leaking nearly 9,000 documents detailing its hacking operation. The leak, described as the largest ever publication of secret intelligence materials, has sparked a criminal probe by the FBI. Assange claimed the CIA's cyber arsenal was stored in one place, making it vulnerable to loss, and announced plans to work with tech companies to develop fixes. The CIA defended itself, saying Assange is not a bastion of truth and integrity, and warned that the leaks could damage national security and put Americans at risk.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won flat ahead of ruling on president's impeachment
summary: South Korea's share market and won trading remained subdued ahead of a Constitutional Court ruling on President Park Geun-Hye's impeachment. The court will deliver its ruling on a parliamentary vote to impeach her over an influence-peddling scandal, potentially leading to her forced removal from power. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) remained almost unchanged at 2,091.22 points, while the won dropped 0.1% to 1,159.6 against the US dollar. Analysts predict that a court upholding the impeachment could support the index by clearing up political uncertainties, while a rejection could lead to a short-term downturn.

site_title: Trump meets with US community bankers, pledges to scale back regulations
summary: President Donald Trump met with US community bankers, pledging to scale back Dodd-Frank financial regulations to ensure access to capital for small businesses. Trump, joined by National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, emphasized the importance of community banks in the US economy. The bankers discussed the need for tailored regulations and the challenges faced by smaller banking institutions. Trump promised to ease regulations, citing a decline in new bank applications and the closure of small banks since 2008.

site_title: Chinese luxury homes in demand as cities post world's best gains
summary: China's luxury homes saw the world's biggest price gains in 2016, with Shanghai, Beijing, and Guangzhou ranking top three globally. These cities posted price gains of over 26% in 2016, with Shanghai surpassing Vancouver. The Asian region led in terms of growth of wealthy individuals, with China and India expected to witness significant additions to the ranks of ultra high-net worth individuals over the next decade.

site_title: 35 Trump trademarks receive preliminary approval by China
summary: China has granted preliminary approval for at least 35 trademarks linked to Donald Trump, covering various businesses such as hotels, spas, and real estate companies. The approvals raise concerns over potential conflicts of interest for President Trump, who has a sprawling business empire worldwide. The trademarks, registered to "Donald J. Trump", were applied for in April last year and are open to be challenged for a 90-day period.

site_title: China's 'stable, solid' yuan faces five key threats in 2017
summary: China's yuan is considered "stable and solid" by officials, but faces five key threats in 2017. Analysts predict the smallest yuan move since 2012, with a median forecast of a 2.2% decline. Risks include a hawkish US Federal Reserve, potential trade tensions with the US, a struggling Chinese economy, potential relaxation of capital controls, and regional tensions, particularly over a missile defense system in South Korea. The yuan weakened 0.06% to 6.9113 against the US dollar as of March 10, 2017.

site_title: Six years on, Fukushima child evacuees face menace of school bullies
summary: In Japan, six years after the Fukushima nuclear disaster, child evacuees continue to face bullying, with nearly two-thirds experiencing prejudice or knowing someone who has. The bullying, known as "nuclear bullying," can lead to physical and emotional harm, with victims often feeling isolated and losing confidence. A government panel has urged better mental care and education for affected children, but schools and education boards have fallen short in addressing the issue, which is reminiscent of discrimination faced by survivors of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

images.alt_text: The new guidelines for disaster-stricken children supplement laws adopted four years ago requiring better measures in schools to detect, and prevent, bullying.

site_title: Australian stay-at-home moms need to get back to work, OECD says
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has reported that Australian stay-at-home moms need to get back to work, citing a 25 percentage point employment gap between women with children under five and those without. The group notes that women with children tend to work part-time, with 45% of partnered working mothers aged 25-45 working part-time due to family reasons. This results in significant economic losses, with Goldman Sachs estimating that lifting female participation rates could bring economic benefits equivalent to 11% of gross domestic product.

site_title: South Korea court to decide president's fate
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court is set to decide the fate of President Park Geun-Hye, who was impeached by parliament on charges of bribery and abuse of power. The court will issue its verdict on Friday, which is expected to take around an hour to announce. A two-thirds majority of the full bench is needed to uphold the impeachment, and if confirmed, Park would be forced out of office and potentially face criminal charges. The country's opposition leader, Moon Jae-In, is the current front-runner for the presidential election, which could take place in May or December.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise; layoffs fall in February
summary: US jobless claims rose 20,000 to 243,000 in the week ended March 4, rebounding from a 44-year low, but layoffs fell 40% to 36,957 in February. The labor market remains tight, with 105 weeks of jobless claims below the 300,000 threshold associated with a healthy labor market. The four-week moving average of claims rose to 236,500, and economists forecast a 190,000 job gain in February. The unemployment rate is expected to fall to 4.7%, potentially leading to interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.
