summary: The BBC World Service has stopped broadcasting from its major transmission station in Thailand after talks with the junta broke down over the network's uncensored coverage, particularly its Thai-language output. The station, which beamed news into tightly-controlled countries, was a sore point due to a profile of new King Maha Vajiralongkorn published by the BBC Thai service, which was seen as a threat to Thailand's lese majeste law. The BBC cited a failure to reach an agreement to re-commence transmissions, which will impact its expansion plans to increase foreign-language broadcasts.

site_title: Rovio sells animation unit, publishing to startup led by ex-CEO
summary: Rovio Entertainment, maker of Angry Birds, sold its TV animation studio and book publishing business to Kaiken Entertainment, a startup led by former CEO Mikael Hed. The sale, part of Rovio's restructuring to revive growth, was aimed at focusing on new entertainment brands and reviving growth. Rovio will keep its movie-making studio, and the sale is expected to help the company reduce its payroll by up to 10%. The new company, Kaiken, will operate out of Los Angeles, Vancouver, and Helsinki, and develop content for TV, film, apps, and publishing.

images.alt_text: Rovio Entertainment Oy, maker of the Angry Birds mobile games and movie, sold parts of its business to Kaiken Entertainment, a startup led by former chief executive officer Mikael Hed and other company veterans.

site_title: TTJ Holdings posts 43% drop in Q2 profit
summary: TTJ Holdings reported a 43% drop in Q2 net profit to S$3.1 million, with revenue slipping 30% to S$20 million due to a challenging economic environment and intense competition. The group secured S$59 million in projects, including a structural steelworks project for Funan DigitaLife Mall, partially alleviating the impact of lower margins from dormitory business. Gross profit margin dropped to 26.2% from 26.6% a year ago.

site_title: US needs better leadership to meet challenges: UN
summary: UN human rights chief Zeid bin Ra'ad Zeid al Hussein criticized US President Donald Trump, stating that the country needs better leadership to address rising xenophobia and religious discrimination. Zeid expressed concerns over Trump's handling of human rights issues, including his travel ban and remarks about the media, which he deemed intimidating and undermining. Zeid warned that expedited deportations under the revised ban could lead to collective expulsions and refoulement, breaching international law.

images.alt_text: The UN human rights chief took aim at US President Donald Trump Wednesday, saying the country needed better leadership to meet grave challenges like surging xenophobia and religious discrimination.

site_title: Online shopping delivers strong 2016 for Deutsche Post
summary: Deutsche Post, a German logistics group, reported a 71.4% increase in net profit to 2.6 billion euros in 2016, driven by strong online shopping sales. The company's eCommerce and parcels unit saw double-digit revenue growth of 11.2%, while express delivery added 6.3%. Despite anticipating "moderate growth" in the global economy, Deutsche Post aims to increase earnings "significantly" through efficiency measures, with a long-term target of an 8% average annual increase until 2020.

site_title: Silverlake to explore buying executive chairman's private entities
summary: Silverlake Axis, a software firm, is considering a proposal by its executive chairman Goh Peng Ooi to sell his private entities to the company. The proposal comes after the company was hit by a shortselling report in 2015. The company's managing director has stated that they will engage professional advisers to evaluate the proposal and keep shareholders informed of any material developments. The proposal is still at a preliminary stage, and shareholders are cautioned to exercise caution. Silverlake's shares closed at S$0.56 before the announcement.

site_title: China to formulate national intelligence law this year
summary: China will formulate a national intelligence law this year, aimed at safeguarding security, according to the head of its largely rubber-stamp parliament. The government plans to increase and guarantee national intelligence and protect national security and interests, but no details have been provided. This is the latest piece of legislation in a series of national security laws adopted by China in recent years, including a cyber security law and a national security law. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's crackdown on civil society and comes amid concerns over security threats at home and abroad.

site_title: Foxtons warns London home sales market will remain 'challenging'
summary: Foxtons Group Plc, a London-focused property broker, warns that the London home sales market will remain "challenging" this year, with sales volumes likely to be below 2016 levels if current activity continues. The company's pretax profit fell 54% to £18.8 million, missing estimates. Analysts expect a near-term recovery in the investment case, citing a 41% decline in shares since the Brexit vote.

site_title: Singapore, Abu Dhabi regulators tie-up to boost fintech cooperation
summary: Singapore and Abu Dhabi regulators have signed an agreement to foster fintech cooperation, aiming to nurture entrepreneurship and support innovation in financial services. The partnership establishes a strategic framework for joint regulatory assistance and innovation projects, focusing on digital payments, blockchain, and big data. This collaboration seeks to better understand and support startups and innovators in both jurisdictions, promoting a favorable business environment for fintech growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ease at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell slightly at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% to 7,333.89 points. In the eurozone, Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 lost 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. Germany's industrial production grew 2.8% in January, easing concerns about the country's economy. British finance minister Philip Hammond is set to unveil his budget, which is expected to exude caution ahead of the UK's Brexit trigger.

site_title: Britain's FTSE fractionally higher before UK budget
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index rose fractionally to 7,432.55 ahead of the UK budget statement, despite sterling hitting a seven-week low. Mining stocks and mid caps, including Restaurant Group and Inmarsat, boosted the market. Worldpay advanced 2.7% after JPMorgan raised its target price. Finance minister Philip Hammond is expected to express confidence in the UK economy despite Brexit risks. Analysts at UBS note that momentum may be fading, but the FTSE 100 has gained 27% since the Brexit referendum vote.

site_title: MAS obtains civil penalty judgment against two individuals for unauthorised share trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has obtained a civil penalty judgment against Wang Boon Heng and Foo Jee Chin for contravening rules under the Securities and Futures Act. Wang carried out unauthorized share trading in accounts opened in Foo's name between 2007 and 2007, deceiving brokerages DMG & Partners and UOB Kay Hian. The court ordered Wang and Foo to pay a combined S$175,636.23 in penalties and costs, and issued a warning letter to the second account holder. MAS emphasized its stance against unauthorized share trading, which can hide behind nominee accounts.

site_title: Olympic year 2016 a golden one for Adidas
summary: Adidas posted record profits in 2016, with a 60.5% increase in net profit to 1.02 billion euros, exceeding forecasts and analyst predictions. The company saw double-digit growth in most regions, driven by strong sales of its central brand, which grew 16.6%. Adidas aims for 11-13% revenue growth and 18-20% profit increase in 2017, and will pay shareholders a 2.00 euros per share dividend for 2016.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers reject Duterte's appointment of foreign minister
summary: Philippine lawmakers rejected President Rodrigo Duterte's appointment of Perfecto Yasay as foreign minister in a unanimous vote, citing "various compelling issues" over his qualifications. Yasay faced scrutiny over his citizenship status, which must be resolved before he can officially serve. This rejection is unusual, as cabinet appointments often take place without a confirmation hearing. The decision is seen as a setback for Duterte, who appointed Yasay eight months ago.

site_title: SoftBank said to sell 25% stake in ARM to Vision Fund
summary: SoftBank plans to sell a 25% stake in ARM Holdings Plc to a technology fund it's creating with Saudi Arabia for about $8 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. The deal is separate from SoftBank's $25 billion contribution to the $100 billion Vision Fund. SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son acquired ARM for $32 billion in September, betting on the future of connected devices. The transaction is part of SoftBank's efforts to create a diverse portfolio of investments through the Vision Fund, which is backed by Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, and other investors.

site_title: Monte Paschi said to seek fast sale of debt after EU consent
summary: Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA plans to accelerate the sale of approximately 28 billion euros of bad loans to European authorities once its new business proposal is approved. The bank aims to sell the debt in a single block, with bidders having a one-month analysis period before submitting offers. A sale price below 25% of the gross book value is possible, with experts citing the portfolio's familiarity among experts as a factor in a feasible deal. The bank's strategy seeks a fast sale, but the actual discount will depend on buyer demand.

site_title: Germany's industrial output rebounds led by jump in investment
summary: Germany's industrial production rebounded in January, rising 2.8% from December, driven by a 6.1% increase in investment and 2.3% growth in consumption goods. This rebound comes after factory orders plummeted at the steepest pace since 2009. The Economy Ministry in Berlin reaffirms Germany's favorable economic outlook, despite risks, with growth predicted to pick up at the start of 2017.

site_title: Trump to meet with business leaders on infrastructure
summary: President Donald Trump plans to meet with business leaders on infrastructure at the White House, following his campaign promise to push for a $1 trillion program to rebuild roads, bridges, airports, and other public works projects. The meeting comes after Trump touted the plan in an address to Congress last month, citing the need for a national rebuilding effort. The American Society of Civil Engineers estimates the country needs to invest $3.6 trillion by 2020, and US Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao has emphasized the importance of public-private partnerships in financing infrastructure projects.

site_title: Emirates invites barflies to pull up a seat with A380 makeover
summary: Emirates is upgrading its on-board lounges on its A380 superjumbos to a more comfortable setup, inspired by private yacht cabins. The new design features a table for four and soundproof curtains, accommodating 8 seats and 16 standing guests. The upgraded lounges will have a "champagne" color scheme and ambient lighting. The changes aim to make the areas more intimate and conducive for passengers to socialize. The first bar will be installed on a new A380 and is scheduled to enter service in July, with all 50 remaining A380s to receive the same treatment.

site_title: Fave acquires Groupon Singapore for undisclosed sum
summary: Fave, an online-to-offline e-commerce company, announced the acquisition of Groupon Singapore for an undisclosed sum. This follows similar acquisitions of Groupon Indonesia and Malaysia in 2016, with the aim to drive growth for Fave's local businesses across South-east Asia. The acquisition is expected to close later this week, with Groupon Singapore to be integrated into Fave by mid-2017, supporting Fave's O2O commerce strategy.

site_title: Palm oil prices seen unsustainable, likely to decline: analyst
summary: Palm oil prices are expected to decline due to unsustainable current levels, according to analyst Thomas Mielke. Benchmark palm oil prices for May were down 0.8% at RM2,837 on Wednesday morning. Production is recovering, leading to a decrease in prices.

images.alt_text: Current crude palm oil price levels are unsustainable and likely to fall, leading analyst Thomas Mielke said on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore government to call tenders soon to replace and upgrade rail assets: Khaw
summary: Singapore's government plans to call tenders for upgrading and replacing aging rail assets, including the North-South and East-West Lines' power supply system and replacing the first-generation MRT fleet with 66 new trains. The government also aims to refurbish and upgrade the first-generation trains on the North East Line and renew the Bukit Panjang Light Rail Transit. The government expects to spend S$4 billion on rail upgrades over the next five years, on top of S$20 billion for new public transport infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: 13,000 new jobs projected in Singapore's air and sea transport sectors by 2025
summary: Singapore is expected to create 13,000 new jobs in the air and sea transport sectors by 2025, according to Senior Minister of State Josephine Teo. The jobs will be knowledge-intensive, with a focus on data scientists and operations research analysts in ports and airports. This growth will be driven by the development of smarter ports and enterprise ecosystems, with the aviation and maritime sectors contributing around 10% to the country's GDP and providing nearly 250,000 jobs. The new jobs will differ from existing ones, with a greater emphasis on technology and analytics.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
SOME 13,000 new jobs are expected to be created in Singapore's air and sea transport sectors by 2025, Josephine Teo, Senior Minister of State at the Prime Minister's Office, said on Wednesday.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 1-week high; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won reached a one-week high of 1,145.5 to the dollar, closing up 0.1% from the previous day. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also rose 0.1%, ending at 2,095.41 points. This follows earlier losses, with investors selling dollars in the later session. The steady performance of South Korean shares contrasts with global market volatility.

site_title: Hot stock: Hong Fok soars 9.9%, prompting trading query
summary: Hong Fok Corporation's stock surged 9.9% to S$0.78, its highest level in 52 weeks, despite a 56% decline in net profit and revenue drop of 3% in February. The stock's sudden jump has raised questions about the company's financial health and future prospects.

site_title: Singapore to use big data, analytics for smarter, greener transport system
summary: Singapore plans to implement a smarter and greener transport system using big data and analytics. Second Minister for Transport Ng Chee Meng announced the initiative, which will improve train reliability and track public bus locations. The system will also provide motorists with real-time traffic data, enabling them to choose the fastest route and optimize traffic flow. The Electronic Road Pricing System, set to roll out from 2020, will collect comprehensive traffic data and adjust traffic light timings accordingly, helping the Land Transport Authority develop a more accurate picture of the real-time traffic situation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as Trump drug tweet hits pharma firms
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for the fourth consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 dropping 0.47% to 19,254.03, amid US President Donald Trump's repeated warnings of bringing down high drug prices. site_title: Trump to nominate Francisco as US solicitor general
summary: President Donald Trump plans to nominate Washington lawyer Noel Francisco as the US solicitor general, succeeding an acting role. Francisco, a conservative lawyer with experience at the Supreme Court, has argued three high-profile cases. He previously worked at Jones Day, a law firm with multiple administration members, and clerked for Justice Antonin Scalia. The nomination is part of Trump's efforts to install conservative voices in the administration.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch down, thanks to weak miners; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares ended marginally lower on Wednesday, down 0.03% to 5,756.4, due to weak iron ore prices and declines in China's February imports. The mining index fell for the second straight session, with BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals also experiencing losses.

site_title: Australia sues Audi, Volkswagen over emissions cheating
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog has launched court action against Volkswagen and its subsidiary Audi, alleging they engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct by installing defeat software to cheat emissions tests. Audi allegedly marketed up to 12,000 cars as complying with European standards, when in reality they produced lower levels of nitrogen oxides under normal driving conditions. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is seeking pecuniary penalties and corrective advertising.

site_title: Facebook names LinkedIn exec Susan Taylor as accounting chief
summary: Facebook appoints LinkedIn executive Susan Taylor as chief accounting officer, effective April 17. Taylor, 48, replaces Jas Athwal who resigned last year. Taylor will receive an annual base salary of $400,000 and restricted stock units valued at about $3.5 million. She will resign from LinkedIn on March 24.

site_title: China says first draft of framework for South China Sea code of conduct ready
summary: China has completed a first draft of a framework for a code of conduct for behavior in the South China Sea, aiming to reduce tensions in the disputed waterway. The framework, developed with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), has made "clear progress" and China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said tensions have "distinctly dropped" over the past year. However, the US has criticized China's construction of man-made islands and military facilities, and the US will continue to conduct freedom of navigation patrols in the region.

images.alt_text: A first draft of a framework for a code of conduct for behaviour in the disputed South China Sea has been completed, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said on Wednesday, adding tension in the waterway had eased notably.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as investors await US data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.14% and the Topix index down 0.11%. Investors are cautious ahead of key US jobs data later in the week, despite an upward revision in Japanese growth data.

site_title: 4 more pollutants added to vehicle emissions scheme
summary: The Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) will be replaced by a new scheme starting January 1, 2018, with five bands and four additional pollutants included in the rebate/surcharge criteria. The maximum rebate/surcharge has been lowered by S$10,000, and the carbon dioxide neutral band has been tightened. Petrol-electric hybrids will still qualify for the maximum rebate, but with a reduced amount of S$20,000. The new scheme aims to reduce emissions and move towards a diesel-free city.

site_title: Traditional coffee shop operator offers 173.8m shares at S$0.25 each in Singapore IPO
summary: Kimly Limited, a Singapore-based traditional coffee shop operator, is offering 173.8 million new shares at S$0.25 each for listing on the Catalist Board in its initial public offer (IPO). Kimly's revenue and net profit have grown at a compound annual growth rate of 7.6% and 9.9% respectively, with no outstanding debt. The IPO is expected to commence on March 20, 2017.

site_title: Obamacare replacement bill's burden on poor brings out critics on all sides
summary: A Republican Obamacare replacement bill has sparked opposition from both left and right due to its potential burden on the poor. Critics, including healthcare experts and analysts, warn that the measure could make health insurance unaffordable for low-income individuals and put care out of reach for older Americans. The bill's impact on the poor is expected to be significant, with many experts labeling it a "mind-boggling" approach that could collapse the individual market.

site_title: China posts rare trade deficit as Feb imports surge 44.7% in yuan terms
summary: China posted a rare trade deficit in February, with imports surging 44.7% and exports rising 4.2% in yuan-denominated terms, resulting in a deficit of 60.63 billion yuan. This unexpected move is seen as a sign of a strengthening economy, which could give policymakers confidence to implement structural reforms. Economists predict China's first-quarter growth could accelerate to 7% year-on-year, driven by domestic demand and strong imports, but warn that the current pace of import growth may not be sustainable.

site_title: NZ dollar hits 2-month low as milk prices drop, Aussie edges up
summary: The New Zealand dollar dropped to a two-month low against the US dollar, reaching US$0.6952, amid concerns over a dairy price decline and a resurgent greenback. Milk prices fell 6.3% at the Global Dairy Trade auction, and the kiwi has lost over 4.5% of its value since early February. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar jumped to a 10-month high against its New Zealand cousin, breaking chart resistance levels.

site_title: China urges US-North Korea deal to avert 'head-on collision'
summary: China urges North Korea to suspend its nuclear and missile activities in exchange for the US and South Korea halting military wargames to prevent a "head-on collision" between the two accelerating trains. Foreign Minister Wang Yi proposed the deal, which has been rejected by North Korea in the past. China is concerned about the deployment of the US's Thaad defense system in South Korea, which it sees as a threat to its own defense interests. The proposal aims to bring the US and North Korea back to the negotiating table for talks on ending Pyongyang's weapons programs.

site_title: Gold prices edge up, but US rate hike outlook drags
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,216.5 per ounce, near four-week lows, due to expectations of a US rate hike in March. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments last week reinforced plans for a rate increase, making gold sensitive to rising US interest rates. Investors await non-farm payrolls data for February, which may influence gold prices. Analysts predict a narrow trading range for gold leading up to the non-farm payroll data and the Fed meeting.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges down ahead of US jobs data; stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won decreased 0.3% to 1,149.8 against the US dollar ahead of US February employment data, which is expected to support the US Federal Reserve's rate hike next week. Despite this, offshore investors maintained demand for the won, preventing a significant decline. South Korean shares also slipped 0.1% as market heavyweight Samsung Electronics rose 1% to a record high, while Posco gained 1.7% and Hyundai Motor fell 1%.

site_title: Starving Venezuelans root through bins to survive
summary: Venezuela's economic crisis has led to extreme poverty, with 9.6 million people living on two or fewer meals a day. Desperate citizens, including 18-year-old Rebeca, are forced to rummage through trash to survive. Seven out of 10 people have lost weight, and 1.5 million rely on food from bins or handouts. The crisis has worsened since 2015, with inflation expected to reach 1,660% this year. President Maduro's government has been criticized for its handling of the crisis, and opponents blame corruption and poor economic management.

site_title: Watchdog to ask US lawmakers to probe Icahn's role with Trump
summary: A government watchdog group, Public Citizen, plans to ask US lawmakers to investigate whether billionaire investor Carl Icahn should have been subject to lobbying disclosure laws when advising President Donald Trump to overhaul the US biofuels program. Icahn owns an 82% stake in refiner CVR Energy Inc, which could benefit from the proposed change. Public Citizen argues that Icahn should have disclosed his discussions with Trump as lobbying under the 1995 Lobbying Disclosure Act. The group will submit a request for a probe to Congress later this week.

site_title: Singapore's financial sector likely to remain cyber-attack target: Fortinet
summary: Singapore's financial sector is vulnerable to cyber-attacks due to the sensitive and valuable nature of financial data. Cybersecurity firm Fortinet predicts this trend will continue in 2017, with new techniques to bypass security and evade detection being developed. The company expects five key cybersecurity trends in the financial services industry, including the exploitation of complex network environments and the use of new attack methods. The industry's reliance on digital transactions and data exchange makes it an attractive target for cybercriminals, posing significant risks to the sector's stability and security.

site_title: 'Angry' Australian summer weather smashes records
summary: Australia experienced a record-breaking summer with over 200 extreme weather records broken in 90 days, including intense heatwaves, bushfires, and flooding. Climate change is attributed to the increased frequency and severity of such events, with the country warming by approximately one degree Celsius since 1910. Experts warn that days of extreme heat and heatwaves will become more frequent and severe, posing risks to critical infrastructure, the economy, health, and ecosystems, with worsening weather phenomena expected over the next couple of decades.

site_title: US secretary of state to make first trip to Asia
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will make his first trip to Asia, starting March 15 in Japan, followed by stops in South Korea and China. The trip comes amid heightened tensions over North Korea's recent missile tests and the assassination of Kim Jong Un's half-brother. US President Donald Trump faces a test of resolve to counter Pyongyang's threats, with his aides pushing for a strategy review. The visit aims to discuss US economic and security interests in the region.

site_title: Hyundai Motor redesigns Sonata to reverse falling sales
summary: Hyundai Motor unveiled a redesigned Sonata to reverse a decline in sales of the model, which has struggled to stand out in a shrinking saloon segment. The revamped car features a sporty look to compete with rival models such as the Renault SM6 and Toyota Camry. Hyundai aims to increase domestic sales of the Sonata by 12% to 92,000 cars this year. The new design will take cues from the redesigned version and pave the way for next-generation cars with a "different flair" for marketing. The redesign aims to regain ground lost to competitors.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Hyundai Motor Co unveiled a redesigned Sonata on Wednesday, aiming to reverse a fall in sales of a model struggling to stand out in a shrinking saloon segment.

site_title: Malaysian PM Najib says no plans to cut diplomatic ties with North Korea
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak stated that the country has no plans to cut diplomatic ties with North Korea amid rising tensions following the murder of Kim Jong Nam in Kuala Lumpur. North Korea had barred Malaysians from leaving the country in response, but Malaysia took a reciprocal action. Najib described Malaysia as a "friendly" country to North Korea, indicating the country will maintain diplomatic relations.

site_title: Britain eyes cautious budget ahead of Brexit trigger
summary: British finance minister Philip Hammond is set to unveil a cautious budget ahead of Brexit, with no major surprises expected. The budget is seen as a means to maintain fiscal discipline and strengthen the economy as it exits the EU. Hammond has vowed to balance the books by 2020, but recent data suggests storm clouds on the horizon, and the government has slashed its growth forecasts. The budget is expected to reveal a £122 billion budgetary black hole, with half attributed to the Brexit decision, and a revised 2017 growth forecast is likely.

site_title: UK recruiters report strongest hiring for a year in February
summary: UK recruiters report the strongest hiring for a year in February, with demand for permanent staff growing at the fastest rate in 18 months and permanent employees hired at the fastest pace in a year. Salaries have also risen by the most in 11 months. Despite concerns about consumer spending and inflation, the robust labour market suggests the UK economy remains resilient.

site_title: Australia shares slip on weak commodities; NZ flat after technical snag
summary: Australian shares fell 8.19 points or 0.14% to 5753.2 due to losses in the materials sector, particularly iron ore miners BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals Group. New Zealand shares remained flat after a 90-minute delay in trading due to a technical glitch. Financial stocks rose, with big banks National Australia Bank and Westpac Banking Corp gaining 0.99% and 0.35% respectively. Investors await Chinese import and export data for February, which is due later today.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, mm2 Asia, Ezion
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) will mandate mainboard companies to allocate 5% of their IPO to retail investors or S$50 million, whichever is lower. mm2 Asia is updating on its proposed listing after shareholders' approval. site_title: Public transport sector to create over 8,000 jobs
summary: The Singapore public transport sector plans to create over 8,000 jobs by 2030 through the development of local capabilities and new career paths. The Land Transport Authority will build local expertise for bus captains and railway engineers, while new careers will be created for data scientists, service controllers, and engineers and technicians. Coordinating Minister Khaw Boon Wan emphasized the transport sector's importance to the economy, employing over 300,000 people and offering many well-paying job opportunities. Upgrades to the North-South and East-West Lines' power supply system and replacement of MRT trains are also planned.

images.alt_text: THE public transport sector will create more than 8,000 jobs by 2030, as current positions are developed and new careers created.

site_title: Video emerges of 'son' of assassinated Kim Jong-Nam
summary: A 40-second video has emerged of Kim Han-Sol, the 21-year-old son of assassinated North Korean exile Kim Jong-Nam, claiming to be his son and describing his father's death. site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down ahead of China trade

summary: US Senate Democrats have urged Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch to obtain President Donald Trump's tax returns as a national security issue, citing contacts between Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak and Trump associates. This is the second request for Trump's returns in two weeks, amid growing disclosures about the Trump campaign's contacts with Russia. The Democrats argue that Trump's tax returns could reveal conflicts of interest posed by his global business empire, and that national security implications are at play.

site_title: UN Security Council strongly condemns North Korea missile launches
summary: The UN Security Council strongly condemned North Korea's recent ballistic missile launches, calling them a "grave violation" of UN resolutions. The council expressed serious concern over Pyongyang's "increasingly destabilising behavior" and vowed to take further significant measures. The US-drafted statement was unanimously approved, despite tensions with China over the deployment of a missile defence system in South Korea. Council members will hold an emergency meeting to discuss the launches, which included four missiles fired on Monday, with three coming down in waters close to Japan.

summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.2% to 9,715.88 points, mirroring Asia's decline, as investors weighed the likelihood of a US interest rate hike. site_title: Subaru targets America's sun belt states despite rising costs, Trump
summary: Subaru plans to maintain its focus on the US market, particularly the sun belt states, despite rising costs and potential border taxes. The company projects increased costs due to incentives, but aims to maintain an industry-leading operating profit margin of 10%.

site_title: China 'comfort women' history buried as brothels fall

A crusade by historian Su Zhiliang to preserve these sites and remember the victims has gained momentum, with a museum opening in Shanghai and China releasing documents on the issue. site_title: South Korea culls 50,000 farm birds as 2 new bird flu cases confirmed
summary: South Korea has culled approximately 50,000 farm birds due to two confirmed cases of bird flu, bringing the country's total cull to nearly 35 million since the first case was found last year. The new cases represent a setback for South Korea's efforts to contain the virus, which had appeared to be waning since late January.

site_title: Women prefer paid jobs to housework, and men agree, research shows
summary: A recent report by the UN International Labour Organization and Gallup Inc. reveals that most women worldwide prefer paid jobs over housework, with 67% of women and 71% of men agreeing. The report suggests a shift in societal attitudes, with women increasingly valuing career opportunities over traditional domestic roles.

site_title: Japan Q4 GDP revised up as capex rises at fastest in almost 3 years
summary: Japan's Q4 GDP was revised up to 1.2% annualized growth, exceeding preliminary estimates. Capital expenditure rose 2.0% from the previous quarter, the fastest pace in almost three years. The economy's future expansion is expected to be driven by business investment, but US economic policy could impact this.

site_title: Boeing developing new mid-range plane to rival Airbus
summary: Boeing is developing a new mid-range plane, the 737 MAX 10X, to compete with Airbus's A321neo. site_title: Iflix gets US$90m to battle Netflix in emerging markets
summary: Iflix, a video-streaming service, secured a $90 million investment from Liberty Global and Zain to expand into emerging markets, particularly Africa and the Middle East, taking on Netflix and Naspers. site_title: Asia: Markets sink with Wall Street as pharma firms hit by Trump tweet
summary: Asian markets plummeted, following US and European sell-offs, after Donald Trump tweeted about boosting price competition in the pharmaceutical sector. site_title: mm2 Asia spin-off to lodge listing documents

site_title: WikiLeaks exposes alleged CIA hacking programme

site_title: Trade deficit widens to its largest since March 2012
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $48.5 billion in January, the largest since March 2012, due to a 2.3% gain in imports and a 0.6% increase in exports. site_title: Volkswagen chief seeks to regain trust after 'Dieselgate'
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller expressed confidence that the company will regain customer trust after the "Dieselgate" emissions scandal. However, the company faces pressure from EU and consumer protection agencies to fully compensate European clients, with the EU commissioner demanding coordinated action to help VW owners.

site_title: 'Friends' star Lisa Kudrow on the mother of all parts
summary: Lisa Kudrow, star of the hit TV show Friends, recalls the show's storyline featuring her character Phoebe's surrogate pregnancy, which was written into the show to accommodate her real-life baby bump 18 years ago. Kudrow's son Julian, born before the episode aired, is now preparing to attend college. The Friends series, which aired from 1994 to 2004, won numerous awards and cemented Kudrow's status as a global celebrity alongside her co-stars.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as Trump tweet hits drugmakers
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, marking the fourth straight session of losses, as US President Donald Trump's tweet about lowering drug prices hit big international drugmakers. The STOXX 600 index remained close to its 15-month peak, however. site_title: Governance review should address quality, diversity and engagement
summary: A 19-member committee reviews the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance, prioritizing quality reporting, shareholder engagement, and board diversity. site_title: At least 4 killed when freight train hits bus in Mississippi
summary: At least 4 people were killed and dozens injured when a freight train collided with a charter bus at a railroad crossing in Biloxi, Mississippi. The bus, carrying over 40 passengers from Austin, Texas, became stuck on the tracks, prompting the train to crash into it. The train's crew members were uninjured. The crossing had flashing lights and gates, but witnesses said the bus was too long for the steep angle of the hill.

site_title: Asian central banks bracing for Yellen seen holding fire for now
summary: Asian central banks are bracing for potential US interest rate hikes, but may not respond immediately. site_title: US: Pharma, hospital shares hit as stocks fall
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as hospital companies and pharmaceuticals lost ground due to the Republican health-care proposal in Congress. Universal Health Services and Tenet Healthcare declined 2.3% and 7.2%, respectively, amid worries about potential cutbacks. site_title: China's world leader desire may be blocked by America
summary: China appears to have lost interest in succeeding the US as global leader, with President Xi Jinping asserting Beijing should "guide the international community to jointly build a more just and reasonably new world order" in February. site_title: Drive to ease compliance, cut red tape continues
summary: Singapore's government continues to simplify rules and reduce red tape to make the country more business-friendly. Second Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong announced the extension of simplified corporate tax filing to more companies. The goal is to ease compliance and stay competitive.

site_title: The Trump rally: It's better to be lucky than good
summary: President Trump's first address to Congress has boosted bond market investors, with the 10-year Treasury bond yield declining in February. site_title: Designers bank on diversity on runway to reel in millennials
summary: Fashion designers are shifting their focus to millennials, who prioritize experiences and quality over luxury products. As a result, designers are incorporating more practical and sustainable elements into their designs, such as mod-Indian cuisine-inspired clothing and zero-waste fashion. This generational shift is expected to impact the fashion industry's traditional business model, with a growing emphasis on experiences and social responsibility.

site_title: ExxonMobil to invest US$20b in US Gulf Coast refining projects
summary: ExxonMobil plans to invest $20 billion through 2022 to expand its chemical and oil refining plants on the US Gulf Coast, creating 35,000 temporary and 12,000 permanent jobs. CEO Darren Woods sees the projects as a key part of the company's strategy to build a "manufacturing powerhouse" along the Gulf Coast, and to ease concerns about ExxonMobil's growth potential.

site_title: Welcome, Airbnb guest! Your neighbours are the Trumps
summary: A New York apartment in Trump Tower was listed on Airbnb for $300-$450 per night, offering a rare opportunity for travelers to stay in a building housing the president's family. The listing was removed from the platform after The New York Times inquired about it.

site_title: UK shoppers cut back on luxuries as inflation rises: surveys
summary: British consumers are cutting back on non-essential spending due to rising inflation and the impact of Brexit, with total non-food sales falling 0.2% over the three months to February, the first decline in over five years. The value of the pound's fall and global oil prices are stretching household spending power. Essential spending, however, has seen a 4% increase, while department stores and electronics have seen a 5% decline. The Bank of England is closely watching consumer spending to determine if monetary stimulus or interest rate hikes are needed to curb inflation.

site_title: OCBC to test robo-advisory online tool
summary: OCBC Bank plans to pilot a robo-advisory service, allowing accredited investors to select investments online based on their risk profile. The platform, developed in partnership with fintech firm WeInvest, will monitor portfolio performance and alert investors via SMS or email if rebalancing is needed. The service, initially available to selected investors, may later be opened to non-accredited investors and private banking clients. OCBC will absorb fees for the pilot participants, with the fee structure to be based on assets under management.

site_title: US Treasuries revolution in limbo under Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's decision will determine the fate of efforts to make government bond prices more transparent. The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (Finra) will begin collecting market data in July, which could lead to reforms benefiting the public. However, some former Treasury officials worry that Mnuchin's administration may not reform the market, citing concerns about unintended consequences and the lack of information about trades between banks and their customers. The goal of increased transparency could be hindered by the new administration's focus on limiting new rules.

site_title: Trump signs revised travel ban, exempts Iraqis
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a revised travel ban, suspending refugee admissions for 120 days and halting new visas for travellers from six Muslim-majority nations, including Syria, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Yemen, and Sudan. The revised order, set to take effect on March 16, exempts Iraqis and permanent US residents. Critics argue the ban is discriminatory and will not improve national security, while supporters say it's necessary for strengthening security.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump signed a revised ban on refugees and on travellers from six Muslim-majority nations on Monday, scaling back the order to exempt Iraqis and permanent US residents.

site_title: Multi-disciplinary accounting firms do better overseas: survey
summary: A survey of 41 accounting entities (AEs) found that those with a range of services beyond auditing and those part of regional or international networks generate more overseas revenue. 33% of AEs not reliant on audit services outperform those with a higher audit reliance, and 18% on networks generate over 15% of annual revenue from overseas. Despite growth expectations, concerns about foreign regulations, management resources, and legal restrictions hinder regionalization efforts.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: London's LCH dominates interest-rate swap market
summary: London's LCH clearinghouse dominates the interest-rate swap market, with a 25% increase in volume to $666 trillion last year. Despite this, Continental Europe questions its location on the wrong side of the English Channel, potentially threatening business. The European Central Bank has also expressed concerns about LCH's euro business, but its majority owner, London Stock Exchange Group, says business is growing. LCH's volumes and membership are expected to continue increasing, driven by regulatory incentives and Federal Reserve policy.

site_title: Hundreds accuse jewellery firm of discrimination, sexual misconduct
summary: Hundreds of former employees of Sterling Jewelers, parent of Kay Jewelers and Jared, accuse the company of discrimination and sexual misconduct. The allegations include pay discrimination against women and instances of harassment, with some employees reporting retaliation after using an anonymous hotline to report incidents. The company denies any wrongdoing, citing a lack of evidence, but experts say the documents provide insight into how corporate policies can mask workplace problems. The case is now in arbitration, with the company's no-suing policy and internal dispute system under scrutiny.

images.alt_text: These women are among the plaintiffs in a gender discrimination case against Sterling. Statements on the experiences of hundreds of ex-employees at the company were released last month.

site_title: Uber seeks a second-in-command to steady the wheel
summary: Uber is seeking a second-in-command to help stabilize the company after a series of controversies, including disclosures about sexism and evading law enforcement. CEO Travis Kalanick has faced pressure to yield control and has apologized for verbal abuse of a driver. The company's value has been impacted, with tens of thousands of users lost following a scandal involving President Donald Trump. Uber has also faced a lawsuit from Alphabet alleging stolen technology for its autonomous driving program. The company is actively searching for a chief operating officer to help steer the company forward.

site_title: Noble group is up for sale, if you believe its bond documents
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a Singapore-listed commodities trader, raised $750 million through dollar notes with a clause that could be triggered if the company is acquired, but only if it's rated investment grade. The clause effectively renders it useless, as Noble's current financial situation makes it unlikely to reach investment grade. The company's management has hinted at not prioritizing investment-grade status, suggesting the clause may have been included to avoid burdening potential buyers with extra debt, potentially indicating a sale is imminent.

site_title: Reality check for Trump: foreigners are protesting his domestic policies
summary: Foreigners are protesting US President Donald Trump's domestic policies, despite not directly impacting their lives. Millions are marching against his ban on Muslim travel, denunciations of the media, and plan to suspend women's healthcare. Similar protests occurred in the 1960s against President Lyndon Johnson's military intervention in Vietnam. Recently, 1.8 million British citizens signed a petition to cancel Trump's state visit to the UK, and Irish leaders are debating inviting him. The protests reflect a growing anti-American sentiment driven by wealthy middle classes abroad, contrasting with the poor who opposed US interventions in the 1950s.

site_title: Shorter waiting time for BTO flats, easier resale transaction process
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) aims to reduce waiting times for build-to-order (BTO) flats in non-mature estates to 2.5 years from 3-4 years, with around 1,000 units available next year. First-time homebuyers will enjoy greater priority, with at least 95% of four-room and larger flats set aside for them. The HDB will also introduce a new sales mode for unsold flats, allowing for quicker access to a flat. Additionally, the government will revise rents under its Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme and offer support for elderly buyers who wish to right-size their homes.

site_title: EY: Serving wealthy women an opportunity for wealth industry
summary: Wealthy women present a significant opportunity for the wealth management industry, with EY's study suggesting they control around half of personal wealth in leading markets. Women prioritize personal goals over market performance, and are more likely to switch providers if not satisfied with their experience. To cater to this demographic, wealth managers need to prioritize technology, talent, and processes, and provide tailored experiences that address their unique financial needs and goals. This could generate up to $100 billion in additional revenue for wealth managers.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Luxury and crossover vehicles in the spotlight
summary: The Geneva Motor Show kicked off, focusing on luxury and crossover vehicles amidst the ongoing emissions scandal in the automotive industry. European car sales have returned to pre-2008 levels, but meeting the EU's 2021 target of 95 grams of CO2 per kilometer poses significant challenges. Carmakers must develop more efficient engines and reduce vehicle weight to meet the targets, with failure resulting in significant fines. Major announcements include PSA's acquisition of General Motors' European subsidiary and Volkswagen's unveiling of its first prototype autonomous car, the electric Sedric.

site_title: STI rebounds, albeit in lower volume
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 8.93 points to 3,130.44 on March 7, 2017, but saw a significant drop in volume to 2.5 billion units worth S$1.12 billion. Analysts predict a rate hike by the US Federal Open Market Committee next week, with a growing consensus of two more hikes afterwards. This follows a sharp increase in the implied probability of a 25 basis point rise in interest rates to 96%.

site_title: Gender hardly an issue, even in the tech world
summary: Spotify's managing director for Asia, Sunita Kaur, defies traditional gender norms in the male-dominated tech industry. She attributes her success to her own experiences and education, rather than trying to fit in. Kaur emphasizes the importance of equal access to education, empowering not just women but families, businesses, and communities. She believes that technology, creativity, and collaboration are universal stepping stones to success, regardless of gender.

site_title: NUS, NTU ranked in Asia's top 20 for 34 subjects
summary: Singapore's National University of Singapore (NUS) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) ranked 34th and 6th respectively in the QS World University Rankings by Subject 2017, securing 27.6% and 10% of Asia's top-20 placements. NUS tied with the University of Tokyo for the most top-50 finishes by an Asian university. Harvard University tops 15 tables worldwide, while the University of Cambridge holds the most top-10 positions in 36 subjects.

site_title: No bidders for court-run sale of Trump tower in Toronto
summary: A Toronto court-run sale of the Trump International Hotel & Tower, a luxury hotel and condo property, received no qualified bids, making JCF Capital ULC the likely new owner. The sale process began after JCF acquired the tower's construction loan debt for C$301 million. Despite the building's struggles since 2012, the Toronto hotel market has boomed, and the property offers substantial unrealized potential, according to CBRE. A hearing to approve the sale is expected on March 30.

site_title: China's capital controls trigger backlash
summary: China's capital controls, implemented to stabilize the yuan, have triggered backlash from corporate executives, who claim the restrictions are hindering overseas acquisitions and expansion. The measures have led to a 74% drop in foreign deals announced by Chinese companies this year, with executives citing difficulties in transmitting funds abroad. The restrictions have also raised concerns about the impact on domestic companies' influence on the international stage, and the Chinese leadership faces a balancing act to avoid bad investments while maintaining control.

site_title: Transfer of home-owning entities: Government plans to apply residential stamp duties
summary: The Singapore government plans to subject "significant owners" of residential-property-holding entities to stamp duties when they transfer equity interest, similar to buying or selling properties directly. The move aims to close a regulatory loophole, but may affect developers with large unsold inventory who have sold shares in property-holding entities to avoid extension charges. The change is expected to apply to transactions involving significant owners, but not to ordinary buying and selling of shares in listed companies.

site_title: Govt stays mum on GST hike; says no to independent Budget oversight office
summary: The Singapore government has refused to comment on when a potential GST hike will occur, despite opposition efforts to pin it down in the Budget 2017 debate. The government also rejected the suggestion of an independent Budget oversight office, citing a lack of need for increased accountability. This move has been met with criticism from opposition leaders, who argue that greater transparency is necessary to ensure citizens' trust in the government's fiscal decisions.

site_title: Nomura reshuffles senior managers
summary: Nomura has appointed Vikas Sharma as head of Asia ex-Japan, effective April 1, 2017, based in Singapore and Hong Kong. Sharma, currently head of India, has over two decades of experience in banking and consulting. The bank also appointed Rig Karkhanis as head of global markets, Asia ex-Japan, continuing his role in Singapore. The moves are part of a broader senior management reshuffle at the bank.

site_title: Airbus sales chief expects some export credit cover in 2017
summary: Airbus expects to have access to European export credit financing on a "case by case" basis in 2017, following a suspension of financing in 2016 due to a UK investigation into discrepancies in paperwork over the use of intermediaries.

site_title: Circles.Life unveils largest no-contract data plan
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based digital telco, has launched the largest no-contract data plan in the local market, offering 20GB of data for S$20. The telco also plans to expand into 3-5 Asian markets over the next 3 years. Industry observers see this as a sign of healthy competition, but question the viability of digital telcos, citing concerns about scalability and infrastructure. Despite these challenges, Circles.Life aims to provide an unparalleled customer experience and innovative products for data-savvy customers.

site_title: Full steam ahead for South Africa's clinic-on-rails
summary: South Africa's Phelophepa train, a 19-car clinic-on-rails, is touring the country, providing free healthcare to thousands of patients. The train, which has treated over 24 million patients since its launch in 1994, offers general medicine, dentistry, and eye care services, as well as a pharmacy and psychology services. Students from universities across South Africa help up to 400 patients a day, with the train visiting various towns, including Pienaarsrivier and Ladysmith, over a period of two weeks.

images.alt_text: Phelophepha in Pienaarsrivier on Monday. It provides access to general medicine, dentistry, psychology services, a pharmacy and an eye clinic.

site_title: Crowded herd of lithium explorers faces culling as supplies rise
summary: The lithium exploration industry faces a significant challenge as supplies rise and prices flatten, leaving only low-cost producers and those with powerful partners standing. Despite projected demand growth, new entrants risk flooding the market, and investors are advised to exercise caution. To survive, suppliers must produce at low cost, and partnering with existing producers can be beneficial. The complexity of lithium production also sets in, making technical expertise scarce.

site_title: Funds for post-secondary bursaries to go up to S$150m a year
summary: Singapore's government will increase funding for post-secondary bursaries to S$150 million annually, a 50% increase from before. The bursary income-eligibility caps will be raised, and a new criterion of gross monthly household income will be introduced. Four bursary tiers will be implemented across all post-secondary education institutions, benefiting 71,000 students a year, with payouts increasing by up to S$400 a year for undergraduates. The government aims to support needy students and enhance financial support for post-secondary education.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Dire future painted for UK banks
summary: A draft report by law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer warns that UK banks and staff will "leach away" if Brexit results in no access to EU markets, potentially undermining the UK economy. The report, commissioned by TheCityUK, says even firms with little direct EU business will be affected, weakening Britain's financial ecosystem. The warning comes as the UK formally starts divorce talks with the EU, with a two-year timeline for no EU market access.

site_title: Wall Street watchdog braces for deep spending cuts in Trump's budget
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is bracing for deep spending cuts as part of President Donald Trump's budget proposal, which may lead to a more lenient, hands-off approach from regulators. The agency has imposed a hiring freeze, curbed non-essential travel, and reduced outside contractors, raising concerns about fewer enforcement cases. Critics warn that this shift may result in a quieter enforcement regime, with fewer cops on the beat. The SEC's acting chairman has acknowledged the need to review resource allocation, but denied directing budget cuts or curtailment of spending.

site_title: Don't take no for an answer
summary: Yeoh Choo Guan, CEO of UBS Securities, shares her journey of overcoming challenges in the male-dominated finance sector. She recounts a phone call that secured her a job at UBS after her boss slammed the phone on her, but ultimately led to her promotion. Guan attributes her success to her tenacity, confidence, and ability to build relationships with clients. She believes that women can do better in their careers if they have more confidence in themselves. Guan's advice to struggling women is to "don't take no for an answer" and recalibrate their priorities.

site_title: S'pore ranked 5th best place for women entrepreneurs
summary: Singapore ranked 5th in the Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs 2017, with strong supporting conditions and opportunities for women to thrive as entrepreneurs, but high business costs and low perceived skills remain deterrents. The country excelled in access to knowledge assets and finances, but lagged behind in countries with the greatest percentage of women business owners. Despite this, Singapore women enjoy a high level of economic participation, with 79% working compared to the regional average, and have favorable maternity leave provisions.

site_title: More land-use flexibility at district level starting with Punggol North
summary: The Singapore government is introducing greater flexibility in land use at the district level, starting with Punggol North, a designated "Enterprise District" where new planning concepts will be tested. The master developer approach will also be introduced in the new residential precinct Kampong Bugis, where a private developer will be responsible for overall planning and development by phases in line with market demand. This approach aims to support an evolving economic and manufacturing landscape, with a focus on industry calls for greater flexibility in land use.

site_title: Asia investors put aside trade war fears to bet on reflation
summary: Asian investors are shifting their focus from trade war fears to reflation, driven by US President Donald Trump's promises of tax cuts and infrastructure spending. Long-term investors are betting on a global economic stimulus, with Citigroup predicting a 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. This shift comes as the region prepares for potential US tariffs, with Vietnam and Malaysia expressing concerns about the impact on their export economies.

site_title: 39% of Singapore professionals believe there's a gender gap
summary: In a PwC survey of 4,792 professionals, 39% of Singapore respondents believe there is a gender wage gap, citing stereotypes in the recruitment process as a major barrier. Despite this, 49% of female respondents value competitive wages as a top employer trait, with flexible working arrangements and work-life balance also being important. The survey found that 40% of employees would consider moving if their employer doesn't provide sufficient career progression, with 39% of local respondents agreeing that experienced female job applicants have equal hiring opportunities as male counterparts.

site_title: US chicken, egg firms tighten security after Tyson bird flu case
summary: The US Department of Agriculture confirmed the nation's first case of avian flu at a commercial operation in southern Tennessee, killing 73,500 birds. Top US chicken and egg companies, including Tyson Foods, Pilgrim's Pride, and Sanderson Farms, have tightened security measures to prevent the spread of the virus, which is a financial blow to operators and could trigger import bans from other countries. The infected farm is near major chicken-producing states, including Georgia and Alabama, and health officials say the risk of human infection is extremely remote.

site_title: SBI's ex-CEO drops appeal against court decision
summary: Former SBI Offshore executive director and CEO Tan Woo Thian has dropped his appeal against the High Court's decision granting judgment in favor of the company, SBI Offshore, for S$624,631 plus interest and costs. Tan had paid S$648,495.41 to the company in January, and his solicitors stated he would not proceed with the appeal. The court granted leave for Tan to withdraw the appeal with costs fixed at S$1,500.

site_title: Stocks up 5% under Trump; how long will the rally last?
summary: US stocks have risen 5% since President Donald Trump's inauguration, but some hedge fund managers are bracing for a sell-off. They argue that market expectations are based on a "best-case scenario" for policy implementation, which may not materialize. Some are using options to bet on a decline of 1-2% in the S&P 500 index in the coming weeks. Others are adding factors like Trump policy implementation and potential market volatility to their lists of risks. This skepticism is reflected in online betting markets, with over 55% of odds favoring Trump's impeachment before the end of his term.

site_title: Over 80% of govt contracts go to SMEs; more help on the way
summary: The Singapore government is awarding over 80% of its contracts to small and medium enterprises (SMEs), with the aim of supporting these businesses in public tenders. In 2016, the total number of government contracts was 35,500 worth S$22.6 billion, with SMEs securing about half of the contract value. To help SMEs, the government is breaking up large public projects and providing funding, grants, and other support schemes, such as Gov-PACT and Accreditation@IMDA. The government also aims to promote fair and transparent procurement practices, ensuring that SMEs have equal opportunities to compete for contracts.

site_title: Mercedes taps rugged luxury trend with US$500,000 SUV
summary: Mercedes has unveiled the Mercedes-Maybach G-Class 650, a luxurious SUV priced at approximately US$500,000, making it the world's most expensive sport utility vehicle. The limited-edition vehicle features a V12 engine, retractable fabric roof, and thermal cupholders. The move aims to tap into the trend of ultra-luxurious all-terrain vehicles, as Daimler AG seeks to boost its research and development budget by targeting ultra-wealthy customers. The vehicle is set to go on sale after September and is part of Mercedes' strategy to expand its high-margin models.

site_title: Buyout firms hunt for fresh targets as they swop fewer assets
summary: Private equity firms are searching for fresh targets as the number of secondary buyouts, sales of companies from one firm to another, slows down. With fewer firms selling assets, buyouts are turning to publicly traded companies or carving out units from larger businesses to invest the mounting cash. The decline in secondary buyouts has led to a 23% drop in the value of buyout-backed exits globally in 2016, and firms are seeking opportunities to take companies private or invest in corporate carve-outs. Firms are working closely with target companies, using their operating expertise to increase the likelihood of a deal.

site_title: China forex reserves cross US$3 trillion
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves unexpectedly rose $6.92 billion in February to total $3.005 trillion, marking the first increase since June 2016. The rise is attributed to a regulatory crackdown and a steadying yuan, which eased fears of capital outflows. Economists had expected a decline in reserves. China's gold reserves also rose to $74.376 billion. The country's policymakers have stated they will allow bigger fluctuations in the yuan this year and will stick to a managed floating exchange rate framework to keep the currency stable.

site_title: US drops to No 7 in global ranking of 'best countries'
summary: The US ranks 7th in the world's "best countries" according to the second annual "Best Countries" ranking from US News & World Report. Switzerland takes the top spot, followed by Canada and Britain. The US dropped from 4th place in 2016 rankings due to negative perceptions, with drops in business, citizenship, education, transparency, and headquarters. The rankings reflect a global anxiety and desire for order, with countries perceived as championing neutrality and diplomacy receiving high marks. The US remains the world's most powerful nation.

site_title: Huge shipments of illegal shark fin seized in HK
summary: Hong Kong authorities have seized over a tonne of shark fins, with four containers from India, Egypt, Kenya, and Peru, as activists warn of traders mislabelling shipments to evade bans. The seized fins belong to endangered hammerhead and oceanic whitetip sharks, and traders face fines of up to HK$5 million and two years in jail. Despite carrier bans, large shipments of fins continue to arrive, according to a report by international conservation group Sea Shepherd.

site_title: Women in charge
summary: Women in Singapore embody the spirit of economic empowerment, as seen in a recent photo shoot in the Central Business District. Joint managing director Stefanie Thio attributes her success to equal opportunities in education and her supportive household. Singapore is considered a gender-equal society, allowing women to balance family and demanding careers. The country's progress in empowering women is reflected in various initiatives, including financial literacy programs and corporate purpose discussions. These women aim to drive change and inspire others to be bold for a better future.

site_title: Ascott to see better share of stable income after latest purchases
summary: CapitaLand's Ascott Reit sees a rise in stable income to 46% after completing a rights issue, acquiring Ascott Orchard Singapore, and purchasing properties in Germany. This is due to a 7% increase in gross profit from operations under master leases, now at 34%. The move aims to improve Ascott's financial stability and growth prospects.

site_title: Employees 'forced' to unplug during holidays
summary: Employees at an association for corporate in-house lawyers in Washington are being forced to unplug during holidays, with a design manager planning a four-week sabbatical. This comes after a decade of service, highlighting the need for work-life balance.

site_title: Newly named deputy CEOs of Deutsche Bank tasked with restoring growth
summary: Deutsche Bank appoints Marcus Schenck and Tan Teck Long as deputy CEOs to restore growth. Schenck, former Goldman Sachs CFO, aims to increase revenue, while Long, former DBS veteran, takes over as OCBC's CEO. The moves come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Deutsche Bank faces significant revenue challenges, and the new deputy CEOs will work to address these issues.

site_title: From a humble sauces business to a global F&B firm
summary: JR Group, a Singapore-based F&B firm, has transformed from a humble sauces business to a global company. The company launched Singapore's first vending machine cafe, VendCafe, in August 2017, which features vending machines dispensing hot meals, drinks, and desserts around the clock.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: What difference can a flag make?
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) released its annual Flag State Performance Table, evaluating the world's flag states on their adherence to international maritime conventions. The table assesses performance in areas such as port state control records, ratification of conventions, and attendance at International Maritime Organization (IMO) meetings. Countries with a high number of green squares, indicating good performance, include Singapore, the UK, and Norway. The ICS aims to encourage shipowners and operators to maintain dialogue with flag administrations to improve their performance, while discouraging those that do not meet international obligations.

site_title: Five priorities for a resurgent Russia
summary: Russia marks the 100th anniversary of the Russian Revolution, with President Vladimir Putin seeking to revise its standing with the US and EU as an equal. Five priorities for the new Russia include turning around the economy, transforming the energy sector, flexing its geopolitical muscle, dealing with demographics, and locking down leadership. Russia's economy is expected to benefit from rising oil and gas prices, and the country aims to diversify its energy sector, while also strengthening its global influence, particularly with China. However, Russia faces domestic challenges, including financial inequality, mass immigration, and high unemployment, which could lead to a new revolution if not addressed.

images.alt_text: Even though the Soviet Union rose and fell during the past 100 years, Russia itself is alive and well today. President Vladimir Putin is using his country's sense of history and proud national identity to re-establish its prominence not militarily, but economically.

site_title: Republicans unveil plan to repeal, replace Obamacare
summary: US House Republicans unveiled the American Health Care Act, a plan to repeal and replace Obamacare, largely under President Trump's framework. The bill would end subsidies, taxes, and individual insurance requirements, but preserve protections for people with pre-existing conditions and allow dependents to stay on parents' plans until age 26. The legislation has courted controversy, with some GOP lawmakers warning it's a reworked version of Obamacare's subsidies, and several Republican governors expressing concerns about the plan's impact on state budgets.

site_title: Investments in Singapore fintech firms going strong
summary: Fintech firms in Singapore received a significant boost in investments last year, totaling US$63 million, according to Accenture's analysis of CB Insights data. This marks a considerable increase from US$9 million in 2014 and slightly lower than the US$69 million in 2015. The region, including Singapore, Hong Kong, and China, attracted a record-breaking US$11.2 billion in fintech investments in 2016, surpassing North America for the first time.

site_title: Solid take-off for Asia-Pac, global air cargo in January
summary: Asia-Pacific and global air cargo experienced a 6% year-over-year growth in January, driven by increased export orders and the Lunar New Year. This growth surpassed the average annual growth rate of 3% over the past five years. All regions except Latin America saw an increase in demand, with Asia Pacific carriers reporting a 6.6% capacity increase, resulting in a freight load factor of 49.4%. The International Air Transport Association attributes the growth to the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which aims to cut red tape at borders for faster, cheaper, and easier trade.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Riady offer for Auric 'fair and reasonable', says adviser
summary: The Riady family's offer to take Auric Pacific Group private at S$1.65 cash per share is deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent financial adviser MS Corporate Finance. The offer, made through Silver Creek Capital, does not revise the price despite being a 60.8% premium to the volume-weighted average price of the shares over the past year. The offer will close on March 24, 2017, and the company's stock finished flat at S$1.655 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Swiber Holdings' court-appointed judicial managers have filed applications for an extension to send a statement of proposals to creditors and summon a creditors' meeting until July 21. Datapulse Technology reported a wider loss per share in its second quarter, while XMH Holdings experienced a 23.2% drop in net profit. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss in the second half of the year.

site_title: UBP set to hit target AUM in Asia in short term
summary: UBP is on track to meet its target of 15 billion Swiss francs (S$21 billion) in assets under management in Asia by the end of the short term, according to UBP private banking chief executive Michel Longhini. The bank has seen a 11% growth in assets since the acquisition of Coutts last April, with current assets and liabilities of around 12 billion Swiss francs in the region. This growth is attributed to the increasing demand for private debt in Asia.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Facebook doesn't understand German, at least not in court
summary: A German lawsuit against Facebook over a photo of Chancellor Angela Merkel with a Syrian refugee has highlighted the company's struggles with hate speech policies and jurisdictional issues in the country. The case, brought by a 19-year-old refugee, alleges libelous statements were posted on Facebook pages. Facebook's failure to respond to the complaint and its reliance on procedural tactics to avoid German courts has sparked criticism. The company's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, has acknowledged the need to improve its efforts to combat hate speech, but the case has also raised questions about the company's willingness to engage with German courts.

site_title: Singer George Michael died of natural causes: coroner
summary: British coroner concludes an investigation into the death of singer George Michael, 53, who died on Christmas Day last year, stating he died of natural causes due to Dilated Cardiomyopathy with Myocarditis and Fatty Liver. The initial autopsy was inconclusive, but the coroner's findings confirm a natural cause of death, ending the investigation.

site_title: US$ steadies, sterling falls to 7-week low
summary: The US dollar steadied against a basket of currencies on Tuesday, trading below highs hit in December and January, despite expectations for a rise in US interest rates this month. Sterling fell to a seven-week low, while the Australian dollar rebounded after a Reserve Bank meeting. The US dollar index rose less than 0.1% to 101.72, trading flat against the yen and euro. Sterling gained 0.3% to trade under US$1.22 for the first time since mid-January, amid concerns over Britain's planned departure from the European Union.

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise to buy Nimble Storage for US$1.09b
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) agreed to acquire data storage provider Nimble Storage Inc for $1.09 billion in cash, representing a 45.3% premium to Nimble's Monday closing price. The acquisition aims to expand HPE's storage offerings and improve its competitive position in the market. The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2017, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: With gender gap, a question on sexism
summary: A recent study by the NUS Business School found a significant gender pay gap of 43.2% in Singapore Exchange-listed companies, with female directors earning 56.8% of male directors' remuneration on average. The gap was widest in large firms, and independent directors had the smallest pay gap of 17%. Experts say the issue is not just about pay, but also about representation and leadership roles, with women underrepresented in certain sectors. The study's findings highlight the persistence of sexism in the workplace, with some politicians and companies failing to address the issue.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Reits are expected to remain stable despite a potential rate hike, with UOB Kay Hian favoring deep value and diversified Reits. TalkMed Group is expected to rebound due to its attractive dividend yield and exciting outlook, with a "buy" recommendation and target price of S$2.07. Meanwhile, Singapore Post is maintained at "hold" due to its investment strategy and lower fair value estimate of S$1.39.

site_title: Snap tumbles below IPO opening price as analysts say 'sell'
summary: Snap Inc shares dropped to US$23.77 on their first day of public trading after analysts weighed in on the company's valuation. The stock had surged 44% on its first day of trading and 11% on Friday, but fell below the opening price of US$24. The company, parent to disappearing-photo app maker Snapchat, is valued at about US$28 billion. Analysts are expressing concerns about the company's true valuation, leading to a sell signal.

site_title: Asia should go ahead with TPP trade deal without US: report
summary: Asia should pursue the Pacific trade pact (TPP) without the US, according to a report by the Asia Society Policy Institute. The 12-nation agreement covers 40% of the global economy and promotes liberalizing trade, raising standards, and promoting reforms. The report argues that regional pacts are the best way to achieve these goals, and urges negotiators to consider the growth of the digital economy and small businesses. Despite US President Donald Trump's protectionism, the report concludes that the rest of the world should not follow suit, and recommends that the WTO and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum promote free trade agreements to benefit everyday people.

site_title: US trade deficit jumps to five-year high on imports
summary: The US trade deficit surged to a five-year high in January, reaching $48.5 billion, driven by increased imports of cell phones, oil, and other goods. This jump was in line with economists' forecasts and suggests trade may weigh on economic growth in the first quarter. The wider trade gap, combined with weak housing and consumer spending data, indicates the economy may struggle to regain momentum.

site_title: Gender equality in workforce gets a leg up from digital innovation
summary: Women in Asia are making significant strides in the workforce, with a growing number of female entrepreneurs and leaders in business, technology, and government. Despite this progress, women still face challenges, including earning 30-40% less than men on average. Digital innovation has the potential to counteract these inequalities, with the Internet enabling access and reducing cost barriers for women. According to the Asian Development Bank, eliminating gender disparity in the region could increase per capita income by 70% in 60 years. The use of technology is driving inclusive growth and empowering women, with examples of women using technology to start businesses, access education, and improve healthcare.

site_title: Britain seeks to plug skills shortages sapping productivity
summary: Britain is facing a significant skills shortage, with productivity levels trailing those of other major economies. The country's finance minister plans to allocate an extra £500 million annually to fund technical education, targeting 16- to 19-year-olds.
