Experts predict sales of existing homes could flatline in 2017, and the construction sector still suffers from low capacity after the housing crisis.

site_title: RIP GOP as Trumpism routs Reaganism
summary: The Republican Party, once associated with free markets and free trade, has shifted towards economic nationalism and corporatism under President Trump. This transformation, dubbed "Trumpism," rejects the "Reaganism" of the past, which emphasized conservative fiscal principles, deregulation, and a pro-business agenda. Trump's administration now prioritizes nationalism, including economic nationalism, with a focus on protecting American workers and interests. This new agenda is reflected in the Trump administration's spending plans, including increased military spending and infrastructure development, and a more protectionist trade policy. The shift marks a significant departure from the party's traditional stance, with many long-time Reaganites and fiscal conservatives now aligning with Trump's agenda.

site_title: Ridding the world of the nuclear scourge requires everyone's support
summary: A UN conference to negotiate a legally binding treaty to prohibit nuclear weapons is set to begin on March 27, with a goal of eliminating nuclear arms. The proposal, backed by 123 countries, including all Asean members, faces resistance from the US and Russia, but will not be blocked by the Security Council. This historic meeting aims to rid the world of the nuclear scourge, with civil society organizations participating and the outcome reflecting the majority view.

site_title: Tech Mahindra to buy US healthcare IT firm CJS for US$110m
summary: Tech Mahindra to acquire US healthcare IT firm CJS Solutions Group for $110 million. The Indian company will pay an upfront cash payment of $89.5 million for 84.7% stake, with the remaining 15.3% acquired over three years. The acquisition aims to consolidate Tech Mahindra's position in the healthcare and life sciences business, which accounts for around 7% of its revenues.

site_title: Vard bags S$8m Norwegian vessel maintenance contract
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-listed yard group, secured a vessel maintenance contract worth S$8 million from the Norwegian Defence Logistics Organisation for four years with options for three more years. The framework agreement is assigned to Vard Langsten in Norway, with the company praising its long-term relationship with NDLO.

site_title: Four Lotte retail stores closed after 'inspections'
summary: Lotte Group in South Korea has closed four retail stores in China after inspections by authorities, amid Seoul's protest over China's discriminatory action following Lotte's agreement to provide land for a US missile defence system. This move affects Lotte's largest overseas market, generating annual sales of over $3.7 billion.

site_title: New FTSE ST indexes to capture consumer goods, services sector
summary: FTSE Russell launched two new indexes, the FTSE ST Consumer Goods & Services Index and the FTSE ST Consumer Goods & Services Liquid 20 Index, to track Singapore Exchange-listed firms in the consumer goods and services sector. The indexes will track constituents in the consumer goods and services industries under the FTSE ST All-Share Index. This move aims to provide a more comprehensive view of the sector's performance.

site_title: BOJ faces call to release handbrake, let longer yields rise
summary: The Bank of Japan is under pressure to release its handbrake and allow longer-term bond yields to rise, potentially above 1%, as inflation quickens for the first time in years. A rise in yields could spark investor buying, but would also put pressure on the central bank's efforts to keep 10-year borrowing costs close to zero. Fund managers and life insurers are calling for yields to rise above 1% before they consider buying, and the BOJ is considering expanding the range of acceptable yields.

site_title: Baht's strength hampers Thai drive for export-led growth
summary: Thailand's strong baht currency is hindering the country's drive for export-led growth. Foreign investors have poured $2.1 billion into the nation's debt this year, making it the top destination among South-east Asian emerging markets. The government's efforts to stem the baht's gains by selling the currency have been reflected in rising forex reserves. This development poses a challenge for policymakers relying on exports and tourism to drive economic growth.

site_title: Billionaire stocks average 7.5% gain so far this year
summary: Singapore's primary-listed stocks with a market capitalization of over S$1 billion have averaged a 7.5% gain in 2017 year-to-date, outperforming the same threshold size of stocks in Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia by 4.8%. The top 10 performers include real estate and industrial stocks, with an average total return of 27.5%. The 10 least performers averaged a 6.4% decline, with consumer staples and utilities stocks among the laggards. Valuations are consistent with past averages, and the average price-to-earnings ratio is 23.3 times.

site_title: UK panel warns of 'worst of all worlds' in migration crackdown
summary: A UK House of Lords panel warns that the government's plan to tailor post-Brexit immigration rules for specific industries could result in the "worst of all worlds," failing to reduce immigration while increasing costs and burden for employers. The panel advises a phased new immigration system and cautions against cutting off foreign skills that could harm the economy. The government aims to cut annual net immigration from near-record levels to the "tens of thousands."

site_title: Fashion designers turn to secondhand shops for inspiration
summary: French fashion designers Francisco Terra and others are turning to secondhand shops for inspiration, finding affordable and unique pieces to incorporate into their designs. Terra held his Paris fashion week show in a "friperie" (thrift store) in the city, where stylists from top labels also shop for research. The trend reflects a shift towards sustainability in the fashion industry, with designers seeking out pre-worn items to reduce waste and create new designs. This approach also challenges traditional notions of high-end fashion.

site_title: Savvy kids of Asian tycoons tap family fortunes to build edgy venture fund
summary: Asian tycoons' children are investing their family fortunes to build an edgy venture fund, RHL Ventures, with a plan to attract outside capital and become South-east Asia's leading independent investment group. The three millennial co-founders, Rachel Lau, Raja Hamzah Abidin, and Lionel Leong, have backed two start-ups since its debut last year, including Perx and Sidestep. RHL aims to fill a gap in the region for subsequent rounds of funding and take a chunk of equity and a board seat in start-ups to see them through to an initial public offering.

images.alt_text: (From left) Lionel Leong, Raja Hamzah Abidin and Rachel Lau, co-founders at RHL Ventures Sdn, with John Ng Pangilinan (far right), a partner. RHL has backed two start-ups since its debut last year. One is Singapore-based Perx. The firm has also invested in Sidestep, a Los Angeles-based start-up.

site_title: In Russia, Women's Day piles on the pressure for men
summary: In Russia, International Women's Day (March 8) is a public holiday that traditionally falls on the day before a public holiday for men, the Day of the Defender of the Fatherland (February 23). Men in offices often feel pressure to celebrate the holiday with gifts, buffets, and other festivities, despite economic constraints. The holiday is seen as a counterpart to the male-dominated Day of the Defender of the Fatherland, and some men view it as an opportunity to show respect for women. However, others feel forced to participate and may not see the holiday as meaningful.

site_title: China confirms 7% increase in 2017 defence budget
summary: China's 2017 defence budget has increased by 7% to 1.044 trillion yuan (S$213.736 billion), a relatively small rise after a nearly two-decade run of double-digit increases. The budget accounts for about one-quarter of the proposed US defence spending for the year. The 7% increase comes as China's economic growth has slowed, with a target of about 6.5% for the year, and amid concerns over the country's military build-up and territorial disputes.

site_title: Films Act, Broadcasting Act to be updated: Yaacob (Amended)
summary: Singapore's government will update the Films Act and Broadcasting Act to account for modern forms of content delivery, such as OTT broadcasts and live streaming. Minister Yaacob Ibrahim stated that the government will ensure content aligns with community values and uphold racial and religious harmony. The updates aim to address the spread of misinformation and promote responsible reporting. The government will conduct a public consultation and rationalize changes made in past years to minimize burden on businesses.

site_title: MAS to engage FIs more to help shape an ethical culture
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to engage financial institutions (FIs) to foster a positive culture that rewards good behavior, rather than just complying with regulations. MAS Assistant Managing Director Lee Boon Ngiap emphasized the importance of individual accountability and enforcement actions against those who commit misconduct. The regulator aims to promote a supportive culture that encourages employees and agents to do the right thing, and will consider implementing strategies such as remuneration policies, escalation policies, and recruitment practices to achieve this goal.

site_title: Multi-million dollar tie-up to give fly-cruise market a lift
summary: Royal Caribbean International has partnered with the Singapore Tourism Board and Changi Airport Group in a multi-million dollar deal to attract fly-cruise passengers to Singapore. The partnership aims to bring 45,000 overseas guests on ships Ovation of the Seas and Voyager of the Seas from March to June, generating S$26 million in tourism revenue. The collaboration includes marketing campaigns, research studies, and media tie-ups in Asia, Australia, Europe, and North America, with a focus on India and Indonesia as potential source markets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Ovation of the Seas docked in Singapore on Monday for its inaugural season here, with 10 sailings slated for the season. It is the biggest cruise ship to come to Singapore with a capacity of more than 4,900 guests.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on geopolitics, Trump's comments
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as rising geopolitical tensions in Asia and President Donald Trump's accusation that his predecessor Barack Obama wiretapped him weighed on investors' risk appetite. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.37%, the S&P 500 lost 0.44%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.43%. The declines were attributed to investors' risk aversion amid escalating tensions in Asia and ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Asia Week New York returns to the spotlight
summary: Asia Week New York, a 10-day festival showcasing Asian art, returns for its eighth year. Over 50 vendors are participating, offering a diverse range of traditional and modern works, including porcelain, jewelry, and textiles. Despite past raids and seizures, organizers emphasize their commitment to transparency and cooperation with authorities. The event features special exhibitions at museums and galleries, including works by renowned artists such as Sakiyama Takayuki and Ye Shuangshi. Sales are expected to reach US$130 million, down from US$360 million in previous years, but organizers remain optimistic.

site_title: Marriott to speed up expansion of Starwood brands: CEO
summary: Marriott International plans to speed up the expansion of its Starwood brands, aiming to maintain the same growth rate as before the acquisition. The company aims to open a new hotel every 15 hours in 2017, with a focus on the Aloft brand. Despite having 30 brands, Marriott is not ruling out further acquisitions, citing a desire to continue growing. The company is also exploring new concepts, such as shared communal spaces, to appeal to groups like hen parties and college reunions. This expansion is expected to add to Marriott's portfolio of over 6,000 properties in 122 countries.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore-listed companies Cacola Furniture International and Compact Metal Industries are facing delisting after the Singapore Exchange denied their requests for extra time to exit the watch-list. Both companies have been watch-listed since 2014 and 2015, respectively, due to consecutive years of losses. Cacola Furniture International will be delisted on April 3, while Compact Metal Industries' appeal is pending. Meanwhile, BlackGold Natural Resources has commenced confidential discussions for a possible fundraising exercise, and VARD Holdings secured a four-year contract for vessel maintenance with the Norwegian Defence Logistics Organisation.

site_title: EU readies cash to help Ireland cut energy dependence on Britain
summary: Ireland is set to receive EU funding for two energy projects aimed at reducing its dependence on Britain, which supplies 60% of its gas needs. The projects, EirGrid and RTE's Ireland-France electricity link, and a liquefied natural gas (LNG) import terminal, are expected to cost around €1 billion each. EU funding will help Ireland secure alternative energy sources as Brexit casts doubt on the security of its energy supplies. The European Investment Bank has expressed interest in lending money to support the projects, which will provide a boost to Ireland's energy security and help the country navigate the economic consequences of Brexit.

site_title: Against populism, the centre must hold
summary: The progressive centre must reinvent and re-energize to counter rightist populism sweeping the West. This movement is driven by economic and cultural anxieties, polarizing public discourse and threatening liberal democracy. Traditional conservatives feel uncertain about how to respond, while the left is splintering due to a shared revolt against globalization. To effectively fight back, progressives must build a new coalition from the centre, acknowledging cultural anxieties and focusing on opportunities for radical change through technology and policy reform. This requires a new policy agenda, non-partisanship, and a willingness to reach across party lines to address the needs of dispossessed voters.

site_title: Oil slips on concerns over Chinese demand, Russian output
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday due to concerns over Chinese demand and Russia's compliance with global output cuts. China lowered its growth target to 6.5% and tightened regulatory controls to tackle pollution, while Russia's energy ministry reported unchanged February oil output, casting doubt on its production cuts. Opec's compliance with promised cuts rose to 94%, but analysts warned that current figures left "no room for an annual rebalancing" unless production cuts are prolonged beyond June. Oil prices fell, with Brent crude futures down 34 US cents at $55.56 a barrel.

site_title: Wall Street cops reined in as SEC braces for Trump budget cuts
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is bracing for budget cuts under President Donald Trump's proposed spending reductions. The enforcement division, responsible for policing federal securities laws, will not attend the annual Wall Street conference in Las Vegas, a move seen as a sign of a more lenient regulatory approach. The SEC has also imposed a hiring freeze and cut spending on outside contractors. Critics warn that fewer regulators could lead to fewer enforcement cases, with law professor Urska Velikonja stating that the number of enforcement cases is likely to be down considerably going forward.

images.alt_text: When Wall Street bond dealmakers congregated in Las Vegas last week for their annual get-together, one group of folks was conspicuously absent: SEC enforcement officials.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO admits turnaround plan is a flop
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan has admitted that the bank's turnaround plan is a flop, citing a 17-month failed effort to plot a course to a more profitable future. The bank has initiated a US$8.5 billion share sale to salvage the effort, and Cryan has installed two deputy CEOs, Marcus Schenck and Christian Sewing, to focus on the German market. Despite the move, investors remain concerned about the bank's financial strength, with some warning of "enormous" shareholder dilution. The bank aims to raise another two billion euros in capital, but its stock price has fallen 29% since Cryan took over in 2015.

site_title: China Everbright Water secures three wastewater treatment upgrading projects
summary: China Everbright Water has secured three wastewater treatment upgrading projects with a total investment of about 210 million yuan (S$43 million). The projects, located in Shandong and Liaoning provinces, aim to improve existing wastewater treatment facilities with daily capacities of up to 40,000 m3. The upgrades are expected to be completed by mid-year, with adjusted wastewater treatment tariffs anticipated as a result. CEO An Xuesong expressed confidence in Everbright Water's growth prospects, citing favorable national policies and strong support from its controlling shareholder.

site_title: Goodbye spin, hello raw dishonesty
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has been marred by widespread dishonesty, with multiple high-ranking officials, including Attorney-General Jeff Sessions, Environmental Protection Agency administrator Scott Pruitt, and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, caught lying under oath. This trend is attributed to Trump's own propensity for lying and the lack of checks from his party and the media. Critics argue that the era of spin has given way to raw dishonesty, with politicians making claims that are easily verifiable, such as Trump's assertions about the murder rate. The article concludes that if this trend continues, the US is doomed to accept dishonest leadership.

site_title: Philippine Feb inflation to heat up to 27-month high: poll
summary: The Philippines' consumer inflation is expected to reach a 27-month high in February, driven by increased energy prices and transport fares, with a median forecast of 3.3% year-over-year growth. This would be the highest inflation since November 2014. Despite this, the central bank is unlikely to raise interest rates, as it remains within its 2-4% target range for this year. A weaker peso and potential US Federal Reserve rate hike may influence inflation and interest rates in the coming months.

site_title: Trump to sign travel order leaving out Iraqis, legal residents
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to sign a new executive order barring travelers from certain terrorism-prone countries, including Yemen, Syria, Iran, Sudan, Libya, and Somalia, for 90 days. Iraqis and legal residents are excluded. The order will also alter treatment of Syrian refugees, who will face a 120-day ban. The move comes after a federal court blocked Trump's original plan and after more than a month of delay. The order is intended to enhance national security measures.

site_title: Malaysian PM chides North Korea as "rude" envoy sent packing
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak expelled North Korea's envoy, Ambassador Kang Chol, after he cast doubt on the impartiality of the investigation into the murder of Kim Jong Nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Najib branded Kang "diplomatically rude" and said the decision to assassinate Kim Jong Nam on Malaysian soil could cost North Korea one of its few friends. The killing used VX nerve agent, a chemical on a UN list of weapons of mass destruction, and eight North Koreans, including a senior embassy official, are wanted for questioning in the probe.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak rebuked North Korea on Monday as his government expelled its envoy for casting doubt over the impartiality of the investigation into the murder last month of the North Korean leader's estranged half brother.

site_title: Prime London office values may fall 20% this year on Brexit
summary: London's central office values may decline by 15-20% this year due to economic slowdown and Brexit uncertainty, according to Deutsche Bank. The market has already seen a 10% drop since the Brexit vote. Increased business rates and uncertainty over the UK's future relationship with the EU are also affecting demand. Investment in London offices fell 17% last year, and some analysts predict up to 100,000 international jobs could be moved out of London in the next two years.

site_title: Singapore building costs fall 5 rungs in global ranking by Arcadis
summary: Singapore has dropped five positions in the global ranking for construction costs, ranking 15th most expensive city to build in, according to the International Construction Costs Index by Arcadis. Despite a slowdown in the construction market since 2014, Singapore's industry is expected to remain positive with a forecast output of 2% increment per year, driven by government investments in infrastructure projects. However, a shortage of labor and expertise could hinder productivity if not addressed effectively.

images.alt_text: The Building and Construction Authority puts the value of construction contracts to be awarded this year at between S$28 billion and S$35 billion.

site_title: China has the right to "step in" to Hong Kong election, top official says
summary: China's top official, Zhang Dejiang, stated that Beijing has the right to "step in" in Hong Kong's leadership contest, fuelling concerns of meddling. This came after officials downplayed rumors of interference. Hong Kong's election committee, stacked with Beijing loyalists, is responsible for choosing the chief executive. Zhang's comments followed discussions with local politicians, highlighting the potential for China to exert influence over the election.

site_title: BlackGold in talks with various parties for possible fund-raising
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources has commenced confidential discussions with various parties for a possible fund-raising exercise. The company has advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares. The shares closed up 1.3 Singapore cents, or 13.5%, to finish at 10.9 Singapore cents at the end of trading on Monday. There is no certainty that the fund-raising will materialize, and no definitive agreements have been entered.

site_title: Market treads water on expected Wall St fall
summary: The Straits Times Index ended 0.83 points lower at 3,121.51, with a sharp decline in turnover to S$1.08 billion. The market is anticipating a US interest rate hike, with the implied probability of a 25 basis point hike at the March 14-15 FOMC meeting increasing to 96%. This has led to a rally in banks, with DBS being the top pick with a target price of S$21.

site_title: 30 dead as intense fighting breaks out in Myanmar-China border town
summary: At least 30 people were killed in intense fighting in Laukkai, a town on Myanmar's border with China, after rebels dressed in police uniforms launched a surprise raid. The clashes, part of the Kokang conflict, have raised tensions with China and threaten peace efforts by Aung San Suu Kyi's government. Rebels from the Myanmar Nationalities Democratic Alliance Army (MNDAA) attacked police and military posts, killing civilians and local police, and leaving many dead and wounded, including a primary school teacher.

site_title: SingPost's top e-commerce executive resigns
summary: SingPost's top e-commerce executive, Marcelo Wesseler, has resigned as CEO of SP Commerce, effective immediately. Paul Demirdjian, president and CEO of Jagged Peak, has been appointed interim CEO for US businesses. Wesseler will assist with the transition until June 5, 2017. This change follows the integration of SP Commerce with TradeGlobal Holdings and Jagged Peak Inc.

site_title: Sterling slips to seven-weak low vs euro
summary: Sterling falls to a seven-week low against the euro due to uncertainty over the UK's Brexit process. Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to trigger Brexit was defeated in parliament, pushing back the formal departure process to around March 13. The weak UK data also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Monday, rising 18.98 points to 1,727.36. The market saw 3.01 billion lots traded worth RM2.63 billion, with gains outnumbering losses 567 to 358.

site_title: Budget 2017: How best to help SMEs go digital
summary: Singapore's government has launched the SMEs Go Digital Programme to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) adopt digital technology and boost growth. The programme has three components: Industry Digital Plans, a Technology Hub, and funding support for IT solutions. This initiative comes after a 2017 poll found that 39% of businesses had not yet adopted technological change. The government aims to increase support for SMEs to adopt digital technology and improve productivity.

site_title: Taxi companies' dynamic pricing should improve matching of supply to demand: Ng Chee Meng
summary: Singapore's Second Minister for Transport Ng Chee Meng said taxi companies' dynamic pricing should improve the matching of supply to demand, following plans to introduce dynamic pricing for booked trips. This comes as several taxi companies consider implementing dynamic pricing.

site_title: Deutsche Bank turnaround plan receives mixed investor reaction
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEO John Cryan has revised his turnaround plan, which includes an $8.5 billion rights offering, selling part of the asset-management business, and reintegrating the consumer-banking unit. The plan's reaction from investors has been mixed, with one key stakeholder signaling willingness to participate and another undecided. Cryan hopes to convince undecided investors to participate in the share sale, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: China to maintain exchange rate policy framework
summary: China will maintain its current exchange rate policy framework, focusing on currency supply and demand and the yuan's value against a basket of currencies. The country has kept the yuan stable, but it shed 6.5% of its value against the US dollar last year. China's Deputy Governor Yi Gang stated that the yuan's stable position in the global monetary system will be maintained, and its exchange rate will be further liberalized. The decision comes amid concerns over the slowing Chinese economy and capital outflows.

site_title: Cacola Furniture, Compact Metal face delisting as SGX denies watch-list extensions
summary: Cacola Furniture International and Compact Metal Industries face delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after the exchange denied their requests for extra time to exit the watch-list. The companies, which were added after three consecutive years of losses, must post a profitable year and raise their market caps above S$40 million to exit. Cacola Furniture will be delisted on April 3 and must present an exit offer by the delisting date, citing its 2016 profit and adjusted cash-flow position as supporting factors. Compact Metal's appeal details are not provided.

site_title: Volkswagen to recall over 680,000 Audis in China
summary: Volkswagen will recall nearly 680,000 Audi cars in China due to coolant pump defects that could lead to engine fires. The recall affects Audi models manufactured between 2011-2016, both in China and overseas. Blockages in the system "could cause a fire in the engine compartment" in extreme circumstances. The recall begins this Friday and is related to defects in the coolant pump system.

site_title: Value of Vietnam's "bikini airline" overtakes national carrier
summary: Vietnamese private budget airline VietJet surpassed state-owned Vietnam Airlines in market capitalization, valuing it at $1.8 billion, after its successful stock listing. The airline, known as the "bikini airline" for its flight attendants, is expected to top Vietnam Airlines' market share this year by tapping into Vietnam's fast-growing economy and young population. VietJet's shares have a lower price-to-earnings ratio, and analysts predict further growth, with shares expected to jump to over 143,000 dong per share. The airline's listing is part of Vietnam's push for privatization to boost investment.

site_title: How SMEs can trump in marketing
summary: Donald Trump's marketing strategy, which involves differentiating himself and delivering messages quickly, can be applied to Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs). By analyzing Trump's approach, SMEs can learn how to disrupt their markets and reach a wider audience. This can be achieved through viral marketing, creating a strong brand identity, and adapting to changing consumer needs. By incorporating these strategies, SMEs can increase their visibility and competitiveness in the market.

images.alt_text: Voters eventually chose Mr Trump as president, not for his arrogance but for the confidence he inspired through his messages because whether on social media or on TV, Mr Trump was consistent in his authoritative delivery.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: European stocks declined at the start of trade on Monday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dropping 0.6% to 11,956.81 points, and London's FTSE 100 index losing 0.3% to 7,351.06 points. This followed Deutsche Bank's announcement to raise 8 billion euros in fresh capital, with its shares plummeting by more than six percent. The Paris CAC 40 index also fell 0.2% to 4,983.96 points.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips to 5-week low; stocks end slightly higher
summary: The South Korean won slipped to a 5-week low against the dollar, closing at 1,158.0 to the dollar, amid increased dollar demand due to tensions with China over Seoul's US missile defense system deployment. South Korean shares reversed earlier losses, closing 0.1% higher at 2,081.36 points, supported by strong foreign stock purchases.

site_title: EU expected to approve new military HQ
summary: EU foreign and defence ministers are expected to approve a new military headquarters to coordinate the bloc's overseas security operations. The move aims to make the EU more credible and stronger in defence, with Federica Mogherini stating it's not a European army, but a more effective way to handle military work. The headquarters, known as the Military Planning and Conduct Capability (MPCC), will oversee non-executive operations such as civil-military training missions, and will be based in Brussels with a small staff. The EU has reassured that it will not undercut NATO as the primary defence for Europe.

site_title: Euro falls after France's Juppe pulls out of election race
summary: The euro fell to US$1.0591 after former French prime minister Alain Juppe announced he would not run in the country's presidential elections, potentially increasing the chances of anti-EU leader Marine Le Pen's victory. This move correlated with a decline in euro value, with investors concerned that Le Pen's win would destabilize the region. French government bond yields also rose, widening the gap between French and German yields.

site_title: Singapore shares finish weaker in line with fall in Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.83 points to 3,121.51 on Monday, tracking a decline in Dow futures. Turnover decreased to $1.07 billion, with 2.6 billion units traded. The Dow futures dropped 66 points, possibly due to rising US interest-rate expectations. The implied probability of a 25 basis-point interest-rate hike at the March 14-15 Federal Open Market Committee meeting increased to 96%.

site_title: Lian Beng secures S$435m construction contract, its biggest so far
summary: Construction and property group Lian Beng secured its largest-ever construction contract, worth S$435 million, to build a high-rise multi-user industrial complex in Singapore's Defu South area. The project, named Defu Industrial City, is part of the Housing & Development Board's initiative to redevelop the area into a "Green and Sustainable Industrial Park of Tomorrow". Construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2017 and take 36 months to complete. This contract win strengthens Lian Beng's order book to S$644 million, providing a sustainable flow of activities through FY2020.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start week on positive note
summary: Hong Kong shares began the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.18% to close at 23,596.28. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.48% and 1.18% respectively. The positive lead from New York's stock market is attributed to investors tracking the market's performance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower will increase its salary support caps for mid-level workers, encouraging employers to participate in the Professional Conversion Programme. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will engage financial institutions to shape the right culture within the industry. Singapore has dropped five places in the global ranking for construction costs, ranking 15th. Managers can expect 5% pay increases, and a new marketing partnership has been launched to promote fly-cruise travel. A public tender for a commercial and residential site has also been announced, and Emas Offshore has suspended trading on the SGX.

site_title: Australia shares rise, driven by miners; NZ up as well
summary: Australian shares rose 0.29% to 5,746.5, driven by gains in materials and financials, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.25% to 7,178.74. Global risk appetite was affected by North Korea's missile firing, while US stocks reached fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Nine dead in Japan helicopter crash
summary: Nine people died in a helicopter crash during a mountain rescue drill in Japan on Saturday. Six bodies were found in the wreckage on a snowy mountainside in the Nagano prefecture, while three others, including the pilot, were confirmed dead on Sunday. The cause of the crash is still under investigation.

site_title: Standard Life agrees to buy Aberdeen in £3.8b stock deal
summary: Standard Life Plc agreed to acquire Aberdeen Asset Management Plc for about £3.8 billion, creating one of Europe's largest fund managers. Standard Life shareholders will own 66.7% of the combined group, while Aberdeen investors will receive 0.757 new Standard Life shares for each share they own. The deal aims to combat low-cost, passive funds and will create a £660 billion asset manager. The merged companies will be headquartered in Scotland, with Keith Skeoch and Martin Gilbert as co-CEOs, and Gerry Grimstone as chairman.

site_title: MAS places emphasis on shaping right culture within financial institutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) emphasized the importance of shaping the right culture within financial institutions. MAS Assistant Managing Director Lee Boon Ngiap stated that the regulator is interested in assessing the culture beyond compliance frameworks to encourage employees and agents to act ethically. This shift in focus aims to incentivize the right behavior, rather than just compliance.

site_title: UK new car sales dip in February, pickup seen in March
summary: British new car registrations fell 0.3% to 83,115 units in February, driven by weaker demand from individuals and companies. However, sales are expected to pick up in March, with fleet sales rising 3.3%. The market is predicted to shrink by 5% in 2017 due to Brexit-related economic uncertainty. Despite this, the first two months of the year saw a 1.8% increase in registrations, with the launch of 2017 number plates expected to boost sales in March.

site_title: Indonesian, South Korean central banks renew local currency swap arrangement
summary: Indonesian and South Korean central banks have renewed a bilateral local currency swap arrangement to promote trade and financial cooperation between the two countries. The swap allows for the exchange of up to 10.7 trillion won (S$13 billion) or 115 trillion rupiah (S$12.15 billion) and is effective for three years, with the possibility of extension. The facility aims to support regional financial stability and settle trade in local currency, even in times of financial stress.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up as materials, financials gain
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% or 11.5 points to 5,741.1, driven by gains in material stocks and financials, despite losses in defensive and energy stocks. A recovery in Chinese steel futures and oil prices on Friday contributed to the material index's 1% gain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall after North Korea missile launch
summary: Tokyo shares fell on Monday after North Korea launched four ballistic missiles, including three that landed in Japanese-controlled waters. The yen rose, seen as a safe-haven currency, but its increase hit Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index ended 0.46% lower, while the Topix index lost 0.20%. The yen's rise was a global response to the missile launch, which added to uncertainty.

site_title: Peugeot maker agrees to buy GM's Opel in 2.2b euros deal
summary: PSA Group has agreed to buy General Motors Co's Opel unit in a 2.2 billion euro deal, creating Europe's second-largest carmaker. The acquisition will help PSA solidify its own turnaround by spreading development costs across a larger network, with Opel's roughly 1.2 million annual deliveries expected to boost the company's market share. The deal includes job and production cuts, but PSA will honour existing labour agreements and keep Opel's product plans. Annual savings of 1.7 billion euros are expected by 2026, with GM taking a non-cash charge of $4 billion to $4.5 billion related to the transaction.

site_title: Quona Capital raises US$141m for financial inclusion fund
summary: Quona Capital has raised US$141 million for its Accion Frontier Inclusion Fund, investing in companies providing financial services to underserved customers in emerging markets. Investors include JPMorgan Chase, Mastercard, and AXA Impact Fund. The fund will focus on Sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, and Latin America, supporting businesses like Konfio, Coins, Creditas, and NeoGrowth. Quona will manage the fund for Accion International, a non-profit micro-lender, to address society's most challenging problems through capital market solutions.

site_title: Deutsche Bank shares plunge 6% on news of capital increase
summary: Deutsche Bank shares plummeted 6% on Monday after the bank announced a capital increase, issuing 8.0 billion euros in new shares. The move comes as the bank seeks to focus on its home market in Germany and address heavy losses. Shares traded at 18.10 euros, making Deutsche the worst performer on the Dax index.

site_title: US 'strongly condemns' North Korea missile launch: State Dept
summary: The US has condemned North Korea's launch of four ballistic missiles, calling it a "growing threat" that violates UN Security Council Resolutions. The State Department vowed to "use the full range of capabilities at our disposal" to defend itself and allies. This move comes amid increasing tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Singapore to give more support to unemployed PMETs: Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower will increase its salary support caps for Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) to encourage employers to offer the programme to mid-level workers. The salary support cap for mature professionals, managers, executives, and technicans (PMETs) aged 40 and above will rise to S$6,000, supporting mid-level jobs up to S$6,700. The move aims to encourage more employers to offer PCP to PMETs, who have been facing unemployment issues.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) will raise its salary support caps to encourage more employers to offer Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) to mid-level workers.

site_title: Japan moves to highest alert level after North Korea missiles
summary: Japan has raised its alert level to the highest possible after North Korea fired four ballistic missiles into nearby waters, with three falling within Japan's exclusive economic zone. The launches are seen as a new level of threat from North Korea, prompting US officials to hold emergency phone calls with Japan and South Korea. The incident comes amid heightened tensions between China and South Korea over the deployment of a US missile-defense system, and as North Korea continues to test its missile capabilities despite international warnings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.40% to 23,646.52, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.98 points, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged 0.08% up. The gains come despite ongoing uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise as tech, financials lend support
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.1% to 9,659.90 points, driven by technology and financial shares. The US interest rate hike in March is seen as a near certainty, supporting the market. Electronics manufacturer Nanya Technology Corp rose 1.8% and DBS Group Research raised its 2017 economic growth forecast to 2.5%. The Taiwan dollar fell to NT$30.958 against the US dollar, despite China cutting its growth target and implementing reforms to address rising debt.

site_title: Singapore slides five places in global ranking for construction costs: Arcadis index
summary: Singapore has dropped five places to 15th in the global ranking for construction costs, according to Arcadis' International Construction Costs Index. Despite this, Singapore remains the third most expensive Asian city for construction, after Hong Kong and Macau. The decline is attributed to a correction in the Singapore construction market since 2014.

images.alt_text: Singapore has moved down five positions on the global ranking for construction costs, making it the 15th most expensive city in the world to build in, based on the International Construction Costs Index published by global design and consultancy firm Arcadis.

site_title: EU's big four meet to seek impetus in face of Brexit
summary: European Union leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande, meet in Versailles to discuss strengthening the EU amid Brexit and rising populism. They aim to give momentum to a "multi-speed" Europe, where faster-moving countries form their own groupings. The meeting comes ahead of key EU elections and follows the UK's decision to leave the EU. Merkel and Hollande have already expressed support for a multi-speed Europe, while other countries, including Italy, The Netherlands, and Luxembourg, have also signed on, but no concrete project is planned to be announced.

site_title: Asean haven status gives baht headache to Thai central bank
summary: Thailand's central bank is concerned about the country's strong baht, which has attracted $2.1 billion in foreign investment, making it the top destination in Southeast Asia. The currency's strength is expected to hurt exports, which account for 69% of GDP, and may make it difficult to revive economic growth. The Bank of Thailand governor has hinted at possible steps to address the baht's outperformance, but the central bank's tools can only reduce volatility and not go against market trends.

site_title: China confirms 7% increase in 2017 defence budget
summary: China has confirmed a 7% increase in its 2017 defense budget to 1.044 trillion yuan (S$213.7 billion), citing a Finance Ministry official. The 2017 defense budget is the same level as the last few years, accounting for about 1.3% of gross domestic product.

site_title: Tencent's Ma proposes Bay Area-like tech zone in South China
summary: Tencent's chairman Ma Huateng proposed a technology zone in southern China, similar to the Bay Area, to maintain stability in Hong Kong and Macau. The zone would leverage Hong Kong's capital and Shenzhen's manufacturing prowess. Ma emphasized the need for a "world-class tech bay area" to drive innovation and stability. He also called for the use of big data to build more ecological cities and protection of personal information. This move comes as China's government seeks to regulate the tech industry and increase national strategic importance on digital content.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars pressured as yields move against them
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were pressured on Monday due to the mounting risk of a US interest rate hike, eroding their yield advantage. The Aussie fell 0.25% to US$0.7575, while the New Zealand dollar dropped 0.3% to US$0.7016. The yield premium for Australian two-year debt over the US counterpart has dwindled to 54 basis points, its smallest since 2006. Market analysts expect further USD gains as the US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates in 2017.

site_title: Fly-cruise market taking off in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board, Royal Caribbean International, and Changi Airport Group have formed a multi-million dollar marketing partnership to promote fly-cruise travel out of Singapore. The partnership is expected to generate S$26 million in tourism dollars and bring in 45,000 overseas fly-cruise guests on Royal Caribbean's Ovation of the Seas and Voyager of the Seas from March to June this year. This is on top of 65,000 overseas guests projected to sail on Mariner of the Seas from October 2016 to March 2017. The partnership may be extended into subsequent years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.52% and the Topix index down 0.35%. The decline came amid a stronger yen and concerns over North Korea's recent missile firing, which landed in Japanese waters. The benchmark indexes ended at 19,368.50 and 1,552.65, respectively.

site_title: Contract work on the rise in Singapore, says Robert Walters CEO
summary: Robert Walters CEO Claudia Chong announced the recruitment agency plans to expand its contracting business in Singapore, citing its growing attractiveness to professionals. The move aims to capitalize on the trend of contract employment, which is gaining traction in the country.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Deferred Upper Serangoon site back for public tender
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has launched a mixed commercial and residential site at Upper Serangoon Road for sale by public tender. The site, part of the Bidadari Estate development, was previously deferred to allow for site requirements to be finalized. The 25,440.8 sqm plot can yield up to 89,043 sqm of gross floor area and approximately 825 housing units. The tender, which ends on June 13, 2017, was initially expected to receive 5-18 bids, with forecasts ranging from S$750 to S$920 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Ageing cheerleaders offer glimpse of world's longest-living women
summary: A 30-member cheerleading squad in South Korea, known as Cheer Mommy, is made up of women aged 75, with an average age of 75. They attribute their longevity to their active lifestyle, including cheerleading, singing, and community activities. The country's rapid aging population is expected to reach nine decades on average by 2030, with women born in 2030 potentially living the longest. South Korean experts suggest that social factors, such as informal gatherings and pursuing personal interests, contribute to the phenomenon. However, concerns have been raised about the cost of supporting the aging population, with some experts recommending raising the retirement age or introducing new policies to keep healthy seniors in the workforce.

site_title: Gold steadies on safe-haven buying, weaker US dollar
summary: Gold steadied on Monday amid rising geopolitical tensions over North Korea and a weaker US dollar. Investors sought safe-haven assets, driving gold prices to $1,234.20 per ounce. The US dollar fell 0.2% to 101.39, while US gold futures rose 0.7% to $1,234.6. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates this month, potentially boosting gold prices. Hedge funds boosted their net long position in Comex gold to the highest in over three months, suggesting a bullish outlook for the metal.

site_title: China's Xi says Shanghai should lead in reform, innovation: Xinhua
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that Shanghai should lead in reform and innovation, aiming to establish the city's free trade zone as a hub for financial reform and the "One Belt, One Road" initiative. The Shanghai free trade zone should serve as a model for other regions and facilitate Chinese entities to "step outside" the domestic market. Xi emphasized the need for steady progress despite a complex global environment and downward pressure on the domestic economy.

site_title: Chinese authorities to compulsorily acquire 13 of Oceanus' abalone farms
summary: Chinese authorities plan to compulsorily acquire 13 of Oceanus Group's abalone farms for urban planning purposes, with a gross aggregate compensation of 182.5 million yuan (S$38 million). The company will use the compensation to repay debt and fund growth strategies. The acquisition is expected to have minimal impact on operations, as Oceanus will relocate to existing farms in China. The company has received compensation agreements and has requested a trading halt to be lifted.

site_title: Hot stock: ISR Capital slumps 83% after resuming trading
summary: Shares of ISR Capital plummeted 83% to S$0.021 after resuming trading, following investigations into the 2013 penny stock crash. Investigators believe the company and its stock were influenced and manipulated by Malaysian businessman John Soh Chee Wen, who was also arrested in the case. Over 97 million shares changed hands within half an hour of trading, making it the most active stock on the market.

site_title: South Korea's Lotte says four retail stores in China closed after inspections
summary: South Korea's Lotte Group announced that four retail stores in China have been closed following inspections by Chinese authorities, amid tensions over the deployment of a US missile defense system in the region. The closures come after Lotte agreed to provide land for the system, prompting China's objections. The South Korean government has protested what it calls discriminating action by China towards South Korean companies, vowing to act accordingly to international law.

site_title: Emas suspends trading on SGX, following suspension on Norway bourse
summary: Emas Offshore suspended trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on March 6, 2017, following a similar suspension on the Oslo bourse in Norway. The Norwegian Financial Supervisory Authority ordered the Oslo bourse to halt trading in Emas Offshore shares due to the company's delayed release of its 2016 audited annual report.

site_title: Australia retail sales bounce, but consumer spending lacklustre
summary: Australian retail sales rebounded 0.4% in January, matching forecasts, after two months of sluggish growth. Despite the increase, consumer spending remains lacklustre due to record-low wages growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia is cautious, as high household debt could limit spending if consumers prioritize debt repayment. Economists warn that real consumption growth may struggle to match the fourth quarter's 0.9% rise, and core inflation remains at a record low of 1.5%.

site_title: Oil prices fall on doubts over Russian output curbs
summary: Oil prices fell in Asian trade on Monday, wiping out gains from the previous session, amid concerns over Russia's compliance with an output-cutting deal. Russia's February oil output remained unchanged at 11.11 million barrels per day, casting doubt on the country's commitment to the pact. US crude futures dropped 19 cents to $53.14 a barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 13 cents to $55.77 a barrel. A weaker dollar and supply disruptions in the Middle East also supported oil prices, but were offset by an increase in US drilling rigs.

site_title: May warned of 'worst of all worlds' in UK migration crackdown
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed sector-by-sector approach to post-Brexit immigration rules may lead to the "worst of all worlds," according to a House of Lords panel. The panel warned that such an approach could fail to deliver meaningful immigration reductions while increasing costs for employers and prospective applicants. They recommended a new immigration system phased over time, emphasizing the need to balance business needs with the economy's reliance on foreign skills. The government aims to cut annual net immigration to the "tens of thousands."

site_title: US dollar on back foot, slips from rate rise-inspired peak
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% to 113.83 yen, its lowest level since Friday, amid growing expectations of a US interest rate hike this month. The dollar's decline was also influenced by North Korea's ballistic missile tests, which bolstered the safe-haven yen. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments last week, which suggested a rate hike, were seen as cementing the Fed's decision. Speculators reduced bullish bets on the dollar, and US political developments, including President Trump's wiretapping accusations, also weighed on the currency.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EMAS Offshore, Chip Eng Seng, Mapletree Industrial Trust
summary: EMAS Offshore has requested an immediate trading suspension following a similar move by its Oslo-listed counterpart in Norway. Chip Eng Seng sold over half of its units in the Grandeur Park Residence project over the weekend. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Asia markets have been influenced by US trade tensions and a strong US stock market.

site_title: North Korea fires unidentified projectile from near missile base: South Korea
summary: North Korea fired an unidentified projectile from its Tongchang-ri region, near a missile base, early on Monday, according to South Korea's military. The projectile landed in the sea off North Korea's east coast. This incident comes after North Korea fired a long-range rocket last year that put an object into orbit, violating UN resolutions.

site_title: KL arrests seven for suspected links to militants
summary: Malaysia arrests seven individuals, including one Malaysian and six foreigners, suspected of links to militant groups such as the Islamic State (IS). The arrests, made between February 21 and 26, include a planned car bomb attack in Kuala Lumpur and connections to East Asian and Yemeni militant groups. Police seized international passports and RM270,000 in cash, and the suspects were allegedly part of an IS cell receiving instructions from a known Malaysian fighter in Syria.

site_title: Consumer prices in Japan rise for first time in a year
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.1% in January for the first time in 13 months, exceeding economists' expectations, due mainly to international energy price increases. Despite this, household spending dropped 1.2% and consumer confidence declined for the first time in three months. Analysts note that Japan's inflation target remains unmet, but some predict an uptrend in core CPI as energy costs dissipate and the yen weakens. The government and Bank of Japan will continue to work together to combat deflation.

site_title: US confirms avian influenza in Tennessee chicken flock
summary: The US Department of Agriculture confirmed a case of highly pathogenic H7 avian influenza (HPAI) in a commercial chicken breeder flock in Tennessee's Lincoln County. The 73,500 birds will be culled to prevent the virus from entering the food system. This is the first confirmed case of HPAI in commercial poultry in the US this year. The facility has been placed under quarantine, and other nearby flocks are being tested for the virus. The risk of human infection is low, but outbreaks in Asia and Europe have led to the culling of millions of birds.

site_title: North Korea fires four ballistic missiles into sea near Japan: Abe
summary: North Korea fired four ballistic missiles into the sea near Japan, with three landing in Japan's exclusive economic zone, according to Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The missiles were launched from the Tongchang-ri region near the North's border with China. South Korea and the US are conducting a close analysis of the situation. This is the latest in a series of provocative tests by the reclusive state, raising concerns about regional stability and security.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.930 points to 1706.590. Volume was 68.7 million lots worth RM16.5 million, with 117 gainers and 77 losers.

images.alt_text: Shanghai should lead China's plans to reform and advance innovation, the official Xinhua news agency has reported President Xi Jinping as saying at the annual meeting of parliament.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks at over 3-week low on China worries; won steady
summary: South Korea's stocks fell to a three-week low due to concerns over China's reaction to Seoul's decision to deploy a US missile defense system. Lotte Group, a major conglomerate, saw its shares drop 4% after four of its retail stores in China were closed. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) declined 0.1% to 2,077.35 points. Analysts predict growing tension between Seoul and Beijing will impact South Korean shares unless the issue is resolved, with some defense-related companies seeing a slight rise.

site_title: From tracking virtual tokens to containers of fresh produce
summary: IBM is using technology behind bitcoin to create a blockchain system to track shipments and transactions in supply chains. The partnership with Wal-Mart aims to improve food safety by quickly tracing the origin of contaminated ingredients. IBM's blockchain system, which is open-source and free, is being tested by companies such as Maersk and Wal-Mart, with the goal of reducing paperwork and increasing efficiency. The technology has the potential to provide a universal language for valuable data and information, but some experts are skeptical about its long-term significance and potential security risks.

site_title: Singapore managers can expect pay increases of 5% at most: survey
summary: Singaporean managers can expect pay increases of 5% at most this year, according to a survey by Michael Page. 93% of companies in Singapore plan to keep or raise headcount, while 36% plan to recruit new hires. The labour market stabilizes despite a six-year high unemployment rate of 2.2%. The digital, technology, and healthcare industries are expected to drive growth, while the financial services sector may benefit from a funding plan. The gig economy is also growing, with 68% of companies using contractors.

site_title: Director buying, buybacks surge for second week
summary: Directors and companies resumed buying shares in Singapore for the second consecutive week, with 18 companies purchasing shares worth S$5.52 million and 10 companies repurchasing shares worth S$9.13 million. Notable purchases include Yanlord Land, Amara Holdings, GSS Energy Limited, and Halcyon Agri Corporation. The buying surge follows a 14% increase in share prices since January for Yanlord Land and a 19% rise in share prices since January for Amara Holdings.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, following gains on Wall Street last Friday, with the Straits Times Index up 2.73 points or 0.09% at 3,125.07. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 21,005.36, and the S&P 500 added 0.1% to 2,383.10. In Singapore, gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 62, with top gainers including Spindex Industries, Hongkong Land, and Noble.

site_title: Trump asks US Congress to probe wiretap claims
summary: US President Donald Trump has asked Congress to investigate allegations that former President Barack Obama tapped his phone during the 2016 presidential campaign. Trump made the claim, citing "reports" of "politically motivated investigations," but provided no evidence. The White House admitted the claim is unproven, but Trump's aides are calling on Congress to look into the matter. The FBI director has also asked the Justice Department to correct the claim, stating there is no evidence to support it. The allegations come amid controversy over Trump's administration's links to Russian officials.

site_title: China lowers growth target slightly, stresses need for stability
summary: China has lowered its growth target to 6.5% for this year, amid concerns over increasing risks from domestic and external factors. Premier Li Keqiang emphasized the need for stability, vowing to implement a proactive fiscal policy and maintain a prudent monetary policy. The government aims to trim steel and coal production capacity, cut excess inventory in the real estate sector, and fight speculative buying. China will also focus on boosting domestic demand, particularly in the service sector, and defend its interests amid rising global protectionism.

site_title: Polluted environments kill 1.7m children a year: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that polluted environments, including dirty water and air, second-hand smoke, and inadequate hygiene, kill 1.7 million children under five each year. This accounts for a quarter of all global deaths in this age group. The WHO warns that exposure to pollutants in the womb and early childhood can lead to fatal cases of diarrhoea, malaria, and pneumonia, as well as lifelong risks of chronic respiratory diseases and heart disease. Governments are urged to invest in removing environmental health risks to benefit children's health.

site_title: Deutsche bank's CEO has new strategy: reverse his old strategy
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEO, John Cryan, has abandoned his 17-month-old turnaround plan, citing its failure. The bank's directors approved a $8.5 billion share sale and new measures, including naming two deputy CEOs who may succeed Cryan. The bank will sell a piece of its asset-management business and abandon plans to sell its consumer-banking unit, previously the key part of the turnaround plan. Cryan attributed the installation of the deputies to his idea, but the move indicates the bank's struggle to plot a profitable course despite job cuts.

site_title: Where do billionaires come from?
summary: Napoleon Hill's 1937 book "Think and Grow Rich" promoted the idea that qualities like grit, focus, and perseverance are key to becoming a billionaire. Eight decades later, this notion still resonates, with 57% of billionaires being self-made, up from 50% in 2014. Research firm Wealth-X found that billionaires tend to be incredibly focused, with Harvard being the most popular school among billionaires, followed by engineering and business degrees. Despite the slim chance of becoming a billionaire, reading and parental influence can play a significant role in achieving success among the ultra-wealthy.

site_title: China to relax rules to boost big insurers' expansion: sources
summary: China's insurance regulator is considering a new regulatory framework that would tailor rules to insurers' assets, solvency ratios, and risk tolerance, aiming to boost the expansion of the country's biggest and most solvent firms overseas. The plan would tighten scrutiny on smaller, riskier insurers, who have funded their expansion with opaque investment-linked products, increasing balance sheet risk. Larger insurers, including China Life and Ping An, would be more favorably viewed under the new regime, which could lead to increased overseas expansion.

site_title: Hudson's Bay bid for Macy's stumbles: sources
summary: Canada's Hudson's Bay Co has failed to secure equity financing for a bid to acquire Macy's Inc, a month after approaching the US retailer. Hudson's Bay's majority owner and executive chairman Richard Baker has been seeking to raise financing, but existing equity partners, including mall operator Simon Property Group, have been reluctant to back the bid. Macy's is skeptical of Hudson's Bay's ability to raise the necessary financing, and the deal is now uncertain, with Hudson's Bay potentially pursuing another acquisition target or putting the takeover effort on hold.

site_title: i Light Marina Bay features environment-friendly art installations
summary: The i Light Marina Bay festival in Singapore features 20 environment-friendly light art installations from local and international artists until March 26. The festival, organized by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, aims to promote sustainable habits and showcase Marina Bay's eco-friendliness. Three festival hubs - Art-Zoo, The Fantastical World of eco.me, and GastroBeats - offer interactive installations, sustainability-themed activities, and gastronomic delights, with some upcycled furniture and planters available for public adoption after the festival. The event promotes sustainability and encourages visitors to adopt eco-friendly habits.

site_title: Setting the baseline for Trump's economy
summary: US President Donald Trump has inherited a generally improving economy, with indicators suggesting a higher baseline than his promised 4% GDP growth. Despite Trump's statement that he has inherited a "mess," key economic indicators show a more positive picture. The economy's baseline, set before Trump's presidency, is higher than his 3% growth promise, making it harder for him to improve on. The current economic situation is not a "mess," contrary to Trump's claims, and his performance will be measured against this higher baseline.

site_title: Scotland's Standard Life in talks to buy Aberdeen, forming £660b European asset management giant
summary: Standard Life Plc, Scotland's largest insurer, is in talks to acquire Aberdeen Asset Management Plc, creating a £660 billion European asset management giant. The deal, valued at £3.77 billion, would see Standard Life shareholders owning 66.7% of the combined group, with co-CEOs Keith Skeoch and Martin Gilbert. The merger aims to steady Aberdeen's ship after significant outflows and achieve annual cost savings of £200 million, delivering attractive returns for shareholders.

site_title: China pledges to strengthen defences without revealing budget
summary: China has pledged to strengthen its military defences without revealing the budget for 2017, with a 7% increase expected. Defence spending accounts for 1.3% of China's GDP, similar to previous years. The government did not provide details on the defence budget, despite promising transparency. China's military build-up has raised concerns in the region, particularly in territorial disputes. The country aims to deepen military reforms and boost military training and preparedness to safeguard its sovereignty and development interests.

site_title: Brazil prosecutor plans to investigate ministers, senators for graft: source
summary: Brazil's Prosecutor General Rodrigo Janot plans to seek Supreme Court authorization to investigate senior ministers in President Michel Temer's cabinet and senators from his PMDB party for corruption. The investigation, based on recent plea bargain deals by Odebrecht construction group, includes Presidential Chief of Staff Eliseu Padilha and Wellington Moreira Franco, and may also target Temer himself. The move could further tarnish the government's image, but analysts believe it may not have an immediate impact on the government's austerity measures.

images.alt_text: According to the paper, Mr Janot is also considering whether to include Mr Temer himself in the request.

site_title: Indictment of Samsung's de facto leader a wake-up call for Korea
summary: South Korea's de facto leader, Jay Y Lee, the heir to Samsung Group, has been indicted on a charge of bribery, accused of using bribes to cement the family's control of the empire. The indictment is a wake-up call for Korea, threatening to topple the government and lead to tougher moves against big business. The scandal involves allegations of corruption, including a horse bribe, and raises concerns about the country's unique blend of business, politics, and hierarchical management. Lee's troubles may mark a shift towards a new group of leaders less inclined to treat business titans with kid gloves.

site_title: Latest bad news for Uber shows just how far it's willing to go to get its way
summary: Uber has taken extraordinary measures to evade government officials in areas where the service was restricted or banned, including using customer geolocation data and social media profiles to identify those working for city governments or rival ride-hailing services. The company's aggressive, win-at-all-costs culture and contentious relationship with government officials have led to high-profile allegations of sexual harassment, questions about customer privacy, and a "#deleteUber" campaign. Despite a video of CEO Travis Kalanick apologizing and seeking help, the company's reputation remains at risk due to the series of problems, including the use of a tool to identify and defeat government officials.

site_title: In the driver's seat
summary: Corporate leaders should draw from diverse views to drive innovation and growth. Ernst & Young's Managing Partner Max Loh emphasizes the importance of collaboration, challenging one's own views, and fostering a culture of inclusivity. He suggests looking beyond sectors for agile alliances and borrowing transferable insights to accelerate fresh thinking. Effective leadership involves listening to employees and embracing disruption, making a "fail-safe" environment that promotes intrapreneurship and diverse teams. By adopting this approach, businesses can stay competitive and thrive in uncertain times.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to hive off risk managers to separate outfit
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to create an independent risk management unit, led by chief risk officer Craig Broderick, which will be carved out from the finance division. The move, expected to take effect over the next few months, aims to increase the prominence of risk managers who are known for questioning business decisions. The unit will not change much about the way risk managers operate, but will focus on protecting against technology risks, including cyber threats and operational glitches.

site_title: South African govt to continue to pay benefits despite dispute over process
summary: South Africa's government will continue paying social security payments to 17 million people despite a dispute over the process. Minister of Social Development Bathabile Dlamini announced that payments will be made via the South African Post Office's 2,600 outlets starting April 1. The existing contract with Cash Paymaster Services expired in March, but the government has not signed a new deal. This decision comes after the resignation of the director-general of the social development ministry and criticism from the opposition Democratic Alliance over the handling of the crisis.

site_title: Sri Lanka rejects UN call for foreign judges in war probe
summary: Sri Lanka's President Maithripala Sirisena has rejected the UN's call to allow international judges to investigate alleged war-era atrocities, vowing not to prosecute soldiers. The president stated that he won't be dictated to by non-governmental organisations and will not prosecute his troops. This decision comes after the UN previously requested foreign judges to investigate the alleged war crimes committed during Sri Lanka's civil war. The rejection has sparked concerns about the country's accountability for past human rights abuses.

site_title: Q4 corporate earnings mixed, but estimates are already at trough
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported mixed Q4 results, with 172 posting profits and 65 announcing losses, as analysts expect a potential end to two years of downward earnings revisions. While reality mostly matched expectations, analysts see a slight outperformance and note that 2017 earnings are expected to remain flat. Experts warn that the worst is behind us, with earnings in the banking sector expected to recover in the second half, but caution that investors should not get overly optimistic.

site_title: Too big to fail? Some banks are too small to survive
summary: Small US banks are struggling to survive due to increased regulatory costs and a lack of access to credit for small borrowers. Despite being too small to fail, they are facing squeezed profit margins and limited lending capacity. This has led to a decrease in the number of new banks being formed, with only four new charters granted since 2011. The Dodd-Frank Act, aimed at preventing another financial crisis, has been criticized for disproportionately affecting smaller banks, while larger banks like JPMorgan Chase benefit from automated lending decisions.

site_title: Workers' rights gaining ground
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower is launching a new pro-employee Employment Claims Tribunal to handle salary disputes faster and more easily for workers. The tribunal will hear claims from employees on various issues, including unpaid salary, overtime pay, and maternity benefits, and will also hear claims from employers on notice pay. The move aims to increase worker protection, but experts warn that there are still gaps in the system, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. The government's tough stance on errant employers is seen as a positive development, but balancing worker protection with the need to nurture risk-taking and entrepreneurship is a challenge.

site_title: Tsipras warns against breakdown in talks over debt relief
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras warned that a breakdown in talks over debt relief would create uncertainty and potentially lead to the collapse of the country's bailout program. He urged creditors to trust his government to implement necessary reforms, stating that a failure to do so would result in the rescue programs failing. Tsipras emphasized the need for a stable economic situation in Europe, particularly with Brexit looming, and that returning to uncertainty would not be the smartest choice.

site_title: Is your premium credit card worth US$550 a year?
summary: American Express has increased the annual fee of its Amex Platinum card from $450 to $550, while JPMorgan Chase has maintained its $450 fee for the Chase Sapphire Reserve card. The premium card's perks, including airport lounges, travel credits, and exclusive access to events, may justify the higher fee for some users. However, others may not use enough to offset the increased cost, and may be better off with a simpler, no-fee card. The decision to keep or cancel a premium card ultimately depends on individual customer values and the benefits they can derive from the rewards structures.

site_title: Icahn lobbying Trump opens rift in US ethanol industry
summary: Billionaire Carl Icahn's relationship with President Donald Trump has sparked a rift in the US ethanol industry, with major ethanol companies opposing a proposal to shift compliance with a 12-year-old law from fuel blenders to refiners like Icahn's CVR Energy Inc. The Renewable Fuels Association, backed by Icahn, has backed the proposal, but many in the industry, including Growth Energy, oppose it. The dispute has led to public disunity and criticism of the lack of consultation with ethanol producers. White House officials are currently in talks with Icahn and ethanol producers to find a compromise.

site_title: Movies make the US$20b toy industry go round
summary: The US toy industry is experiencing a surge in movie tie-ins, with about 25 movies tied to toys this year, an unprecedented number for the $20 billion industry. This is a significant increase from a typical year, which sees 7-8 movie tie-ins. The surge is driven by studios such as Universal, Warner Bros, and Fox, which are capitalizing on the success of family-friendly movies like Despicable Me, Cars 3, and Beauty and the Beast. The trend is expected to boost toy sales, particularly in the fourth quarter, and could lead to a strong year for licensed toys, which account for 30% of all toy sales.

site_title: Britain's budget gearing for Brexit, says chancellor
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond plans to deliver a budget on Wednesday, focusing on building economic resilience ahead of Brexit. He aims to reduce the deficit and maintain fiscal discipline, while also investing in skills training for 16-19-year-olds. The government will overhaul technical education qualifications, introducing a more streamlined model from 2019-20. Hammond warns against reckless spending and urges commitment to reducing borrowing, emphasizing the need for a stronger, fairer Britain.

site_title: Zimbabwe's 'informal economy' keeps country afloat
summary: Zimbabwe's informal economy, which accounts for up to 95% of the workforce, keeps the country afloat by providing livelihoods for millions of street vendors and traders. The economy has rapidly deindustrialized, with manufacturing peaking at 30% of GDP in 1992 and declining to 11% now. A crippling shortage of US dollars has exacerbated the trade imbalance, making it difficult for companies to import critical goods. The government's inability to pay workers and secure international loans has led to widespread poverty, with many citizens forced to hustle on the streets.

site_title: Floating LNG projects benched as US shale floods market
summary: Floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) projects have been put on hold as US shale gas production surges and global prices slump. Once considered the future of gas production, FLNG allows offshore gas wells to be tapped and shipped without pipelines. Global producers now seek cheaper alternatives, relegating FLNG to the backburner.

site_title: Saudi non-oil economic growth hits 18-month high
summary: Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector experienced its fastest growth in 18 months in February, with the Emirates NBD Saudi Arabia Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 57.0. This growth was driven by a sharp increase in new orders, but employment growth slowed to a 14-month low of 50.3. Low oil prices had previously shrunk government revenues, but a rebound in oil prices and a sovereign bond issue have eased pressure on state finances, encouraging the private sector to grow.

site_title: What Warren Buffett thinks of buybacks
summary: Warren Buffett has outlined his thoughts on share buybacks in Berkshire Hathaway's latest shareholder letter. He argues that repurchases are beneficial for exiting shareholders but only make sense if the shares are bought at a price below intrinsic value. Buffett criticizes companies for not considering the purchase price when making repurchase decisions, suggesting that CEOs and boards should prioritize value-creating prices.
