site_title: Sterling edges lower ahead of UK services PMI data
summary: Sterling edged lower against the US dollar ahead of a UK services PMI data release, trading just off a 6-week low. The data is expected to confirm a slowing in Britain's dominant services sector, which contributes nearly 80% of the country's economic output. The sector's slowdown is seen as a sign of the economy finally beginning to slow in the face of the aftermath of the Brexit vote. The survey will be closely watched for further signs of economic slowdown.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines 'aggressively hedging' as carrier sees oil at US$70 per barrel
summary: Malaysia Airlines is aggressively hedging against rising oil prices, projecting oil costs to reach US$70 per barrel by the end of this year. The airline has hedged 65% of its current year's fuel costs at around US$60 per barrel. CEO Peter Bellew stated the airline is taking a prudent approach to hedging 12 months ahead, aiming to return to profitable operations. This move is seen as a strategic measure to mitigate the impact of increasing oil prices on the carrier's financial performance.

site_title: Profits rise at SocGen's car leasing arm ALD Automotive ahead of IPO
summary: ALD Automotive, the car leasing arm of Societe Generale, reported a 21% rise in net profits to 511.7 million euros in 2016. The company is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) expected in the middle of this year, which could value it at over 6 billion euros. ALD manages a worldwide fleet of 1.4 million vehicles and aims to become a global leader in the sector, with services and financial margins expected to grow annually at 8-10%. The IPO will provide the means to achieve growth targets and retain a majority holding in the company.

site_title: Fears of Chinese backlash over missile defence hit South Korean stocks
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1.1% after reports emerged that Chinese tour operators were ordered to stop selling trips to the country due to the deployment of a US missile defense system. Cosmetics makers, retailers, and automakers were among the biggest losers, with shares of Amorepacific and Hyundai Motor falling 12.7% and 4.4%, respectively. The Chinese government has denied the reports, but the backlash has raised concerns about the potential impact on South Korea's tourism industry, which relies heavily on Chinese tourists.

site_title: Taxi app Uber loses court case to stop strict new rules in London
summary: Uber lost a court case in London, allowing Transport for London to enforce strict rules requiring private hire drivers to prove their reading and writing skills in English. Uber launched a legal challenge after TfL said drivers should demonstrate English language compliance, but Judge John Mitting rejected the claim, stating that TfL has the right to set such requirements. The ruling aims to regulate the city's private hire services, which have been disrupted by technology.

site_title: Big-data disruption gets real for car insurers
summary: Mobile-phone and technology companies are poised to disrupt the auto insurance market, with Telefonica SA's O2 unit expanding its car insurance offerings to include telematics boxes that track driving habits. Analysts predict fintech companies will enter the market, using vast customer data to sell insurance and bypass traditional brokers. Google, Alphabet Inc's parent company, is seen as a potential disruptor, with CEO Oliver Baete pledging to make Allianz SE "digital by default." The industry faces pressure from record-low interest rates and rising competition, with some analysts warning of data-privacy issues and the potential to erode margins.

site_title: May slams SNP in bid to keep Scotland in UK after Brexit
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May criticized Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon for prioritizing independence from the UK over living standards and services. May accused Sturgeon of "tunnel vision nationalism" and said Scotland's interests would be harmed by another independence referendum. Sturgeon has demanded a second referendum, citing the UK's Brexit decision, but May refused to give a yes or no answer. The UK market is worth four times more to Scottish companies than the EU market, with May arguing there is no economic case for breaking up the UK.

site_title: Inspiring quotes replace names on Swedish women's football shirts
summary: The Swedish women's football team has replaced the names on their jerseys with inspirational quotes, aiming to motivate young girls. The quotes, from Swedish celebrities, include "Believe in your damn self" by Zara Larsson and "Never look down on anyone, unless it's to help her get up" by Gudrun Schyman. This initiative aims to promote empowerment and positivity among young girls, and the team hopes it will inspire a new generation of female football players.

site_title: Apple's UK suit against Qualcomm adds to global patent war
summary: Apple has sued Qualcomm in a UK court, adding to global patent disputes over licensing fees and patents. The lawsuit, filed on January 23, claims patents and registered designs, but details are not provided. This case follows Apple's separate lawsuit in California, accusing Qualcomm of monopolizing the market for wireless device chips and withholding $1 billion in retaliation. The global patent war between Apple and Qualcomm continues to escalate.

site_title: Football: AC Milan want deal sealed 'as soon as possible'
summary: AC Milan's sale to a Chinese consortium, Sino-Europe Sports (SES), has been postponed after failing to meet the March 3 deadline. The deal, valued at 740 million euros (S$1.1 billion), was agreed upon by Milan's owner Silvio Berlusconi in August 2016. The club's holding company, Fininvest, will push to conclude the sale "as soon as possible." The delay follows a failed attempt to meet the original deadline, but no new timeline has been announced.

site_title: Bali gears up for Saudi king's extravagant visit
summary: Saudi King Salman is set to arrive in Bali on Saturday, marking the first visit by a Saudi Arabian monarch to Indonesia in nearly half a century. A 1,000-strong delegation, including princes and ministers, will be accompanied by hundreds of luxury cars and 396 tons of equipment. The king will stay at five luxury hotels in the Nusa Dua resort area and will use 360 vehicles during his week-long visit. Security forces, including 2,500 police and military personnel, will be deployed around the island to ensure the king's safety.

site_title: PSA said to be close to deal to buy GM's European Opel unit
summary: PSA Group is close to acquiring General Motors' European Opel unit, potentially creating Europe's second-largest automaker. The deal, valued at 2 billion euros, aims to achieve savings through capacity reductions, joint purchasing, and overhead cost reductions. PSA CEO Carlos Tavares plans to revive Opel and Vauxhall brands, using a similar restructuring approach that brought back Peugeot and Citroen. The deal would add 1.2 million annual deliveries to PSA, helping spread development costs across a larger number of vehicles, and could serve as a growth driver beyond Europe.

site_title: Ditch computers to save democracy: ethical hacker
summary: An ethical hacker, Sijmen Ruwhof, warns that relying on computers to protect the integrity of election results is not a viable option. After discovering vulnerabilities in the Dutch election's commission software, Ruwhof advocates for returning to paper and pen for counting ballots. He believes that using computers in this process is too insecure, as it leaves room for state-sponsored hacking and manipulation. Ruwhof suggests that countries should build their own secure systems from scratch, rather than relying on existing operating systems, to prevent potential cyber threats.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 3-week closing low on growing China tensions; won slides
summary: South Korean shares hit a near three-week closing low on Friday, closing 1.1% lower at 2,078.75 points, due to growing tensions with China over the deployment of a US missile-defence system. The won also slid to its lowest closing level in more than four weeks, as investors anticipated a potential rate increase by the US Federal Reserve in March. This resulted in a 0.7% decline in the Korea Composite Stock Price Index for the week, its largest weekly fall in 17 weeks.

site_title: Pollution from tampered, German-sold Volkswagens to kill 1,200: study
summary: A study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that pollution from 2.6 million Volkswagen cars sold in Germany between 2008 and 2015, manipulated to appear less polluting, will cause 1,200 premature deaths in Europe. The excess emissions are estimated to lead to 500 deaths in Germany and the rest in neighboring countries. Volkswagen's software installed in 11 million diesel engines worldwide was designed to circumvent emissions tests, affecting health in densely populated areas. Recalling and retrofitting the affected vehicles could avert 2,600 premature deaths and 4.1 billion euros in health costs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's office rents are now triple those of Hong Kong, with the property market diverging sharply in recent years. Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The country is also exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging and has shifted its focus towards larger startups. Meanwhile, workers are advised to future-proof their careers amid a potential crisis, and Singapore has a strong relationship with China, with diplomatic ties established 35 years ago.

site_title: Harvard academics reveal blueprint for avoiding stock crashes
summary: Harvard University researchers have identified a blueprint for avoiding stock crashes by analyzing boom-and-bust cycles in publicly traded US industries since 1926. The study found that rising volatility and greater share issuance are common traits among sectorwide crashes, and that keeping out of these rallies can add 10 percentage points to an investor's long-term return. However, the researchers note that predicting the peak of a bubble is difficult, and that their methodology is not applicable in real-time, but rather after the fact.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end week with sharp loss
summary: Hong Kong shares ended a tough week with a 0.74% loss, shedding 175.35 points to close at 23,552.72. This follows an Asia-wide retreat after profit-taking on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.36%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.21%. The decline marks a sharp loss for the week, with shares down 1.53% from their previous close.

site_title: Temasek Foundation Ecosperity opens first call for social innovation proposals
summary: Temasek Foundation Ecosperity has opened its first call for social innovation proposals, offering funding for sustainable solutions to improve liveability in Singapore and beyond. The non-profit organization provides up to S$3 million for applied research and development, and will make two more calls in the coming year. This marks the start of an open cycle of funding opportunities, which will support strategic and impact-driven programs.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 2-week low; anxiety over missile-defence system deepens
summary: South Korea's stocks hit a two-week low on Friday, falling 1.2% to 2,077.26 points due to rising tensions over the deployment of the US missile-defence system in the country. China ordered tour operators to stop selling trips into South Korea amid anger over the move. Shares of cosmetics and tourism companies, such as Amorepacific and Hotel Shilla, plummeted, leading to a decline in the overall index. Offshore investors sold a net 45.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, and the South Korean won slipped 1% to its lowest in nearly three weeks.

site_title: Oil ticks up on weaker US dollar, stalled Russian output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday as the US dollar slipped from a multi-week high, but were held back by unchanged Russian output for February. Benchmark Brent crude futures rose 0.4% to $55.29 a barrel, while US WTI futures gained 0.3% to $52.77 a barrel. Russia's February oil output remained at 11.11 million barrels per day, despite a global deal to cut supplies. Opec's compliance with the deal rose to 94%, with output cuts for a second month in February.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.66% at the opening of trade on Friday, following losses across global markets due to profit-taking. The Hang Seng Index ended at 23,570.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.34% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.29%. The losses were attributed to global market trends rather than specific Hong Kong-related events.

site_title: Philippines may consider ban on exports of unprocessed minerals
summary: The Philippines may consider banning exports of unprocessed minerals to promote value addition in the mining sector, according to DENR Undersecretary Maria Paz Luna. The move is one of the options being considered for 28 mines ordered closed or suspended by the environment ministry. This effort aims to address environmental concerns and stimulate economic growth in the sector.

site_title: Broker's Take: Great expectations of Singapore banks
summary: Singapore banks are trading at premiums due to high expectations of zero oil-and-gas provisions, sharp rate hikes, or high fees. CIMB Research holds an "underweight" rating on the sector, citing high expectations of returns on equity (ROE) of 11%, but the banks closed 2016 with ROEs of 8-9%. CIMB is watchful of banks' exposure to oil-and-gas companies and notes DBS and OCBC have limited room for further provision writebacks. CIMB has replaced DBS with UOB as its top pick, citing UOB's higher headroom for provisions.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker on US rate hike worries
summary: Singapore stocks closed weaker on Friday due to US Federal Reserve warnings of imminent interest rate hikes, with the Straits Times Index falling 14.14 points to 3,122.34. The 5-point rise seen earlier in the week was attributed to "Trumponomics," but no details on stimulus were provided. The implied probability of a rate hike in two weeks is now 90%, according to federal funds futures market data. Despite this, investors remain optimistic, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Pence used private email for public business, newspaper reports
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence used a private AOL email account for public business while serving as Indiana governor, according to the Indianapolis Star. Emails showed he communicated with top state advisers on matters such as security and terror incidents. Pence's office claimed he followed Indiana law regarding email use and retention. The emails were released after his personal account was compromised by hackers in June. Pence's use of a personal email account for public business comes after criticizing Hillary Clinton for her email practices during the 2016 presidential campaign.

site_title: German retail sales fall unexpectedly in January
summary: German retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.8% in January, contrary to a forecast of a 0.2% rise, according to the Federal Statistics Office. However, on a year-over-year basis, sales edged up 2.3% in real terms. This follows a revised December figure of unchanged sales. The data suggests a shift in consumer spending power, with record-high employment and rising real wages boosting growth in a traditionally export-driven economy.

images.alt_text: German retail sales fell unexpectedly in January, data showed on Friday.

site_title: Mexican journalist shot and killed
summary: A Mexican journalist, Cecilio Pineda, was shot and killed in the state of Guerrero, Mexico, on Thursday. He was 50 years old and had directed the regional newspaper La Voz de la Tierra Caliente. Pineda had previously denounced threats on social networks and survived an attack outside his house in 2015. Guerrero ranks as one of the most violent states in Mexico, with a history of kidnappings and threats against journalists. The regional prosecutor's office is investigating the crime, which has raised concerns about the safety of journalists in Mexico.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls on profit-taking before weekend; posts 1% weekly gain
summary: Japanese stocks fell on Friday due to profit-taking before the weekend, despite reaching a 14-month high the previous day. The Nikkei dropped 0.5% to 19,469.17 points, while the Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 fell 0.4% and 0.5% respectively. The index rose 1% for the week. Investors awaited a speech by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, which could indicate a US interest rate hike in coming weeks, and were on the sidelines ahead of the speech.

site_title: Samsung chief's "trial of the century" to start next week
summary: Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee will go on trial next week for bribery and embezzlement, amid a corruption scandal that has rocked South Korea. Lee, 48, was indicted on charges including pledging 43 billion won in payments to a confidant of President Park Geun-hye. The trial, described as the "trial of the century," is expected to be watched by the world. Lee's arrest and indictment follow the impeachment of President Park, who faces a Constitutional Court decision on her powers this month. Samsung Group has denied wrongdoing, with Lee's hearing set to be held in a court accommodating over 150 people.

images.alt_text: Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee will go on trial for bribery and embezzlement on Thursday, a court said, amid a corruption scandal that has rocked South Korea and led to the impeachment of the president.

site_title: China forex regulator aims to loosen controls in FX market
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator aims to create an open and competitive domestic currency market, allowing a flexible exchange rate mechanism to regulate capital flows and balance international payments. The regulator, SAFE, plans to establish a "negative list" specifying sectors subject to controls, and gradually phase out foreign exchange conversion limits for individual and company transactions. This move is seen as a step towards market-oriented exchange rate reform, but analysts are cautious, fearing a potential devaluation of the yuan and a heavy drain on reserves.

site_title: Soaring Hong Kong office rents are now triple those of Singapore
summary: Hong Kong office rents have surged to nearly triple those in Singapore, making Singapore a more attractive business hub. The disparity is largely due to Hong Kong's scarce supply in the Central area, while Singapore faces an abundance of supply in its newer financial district. This divergence has boosted Singapore's appeal for regional headquarters, according to Cushman & Wakefield Inc.

site_title: Frustrated Malaysian police release North Korean suspect
summary: Malaysian police released North Korean suspect Ri Jong-Chol, one of eight suspects in the assassination of Kim Jong Nam, due to lack of evidence. Despite believing Ri was involved, the attorney general deemed insufficient evidence to charge him. Ri will be deported instead. The case remains unsolved, with Malaysia's frustration over the lack of cooperation from North Korea.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars at multi-week lows, set for worst week since mid-Dec
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are at multi-week lows, with the Australian dollar slipping 0.3% to US$0.7555 and the New Zealand dollar falling to a near two-month trough of US$0.7043. The decline is attributed to a strengthening US dollar, driven by rising expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike as early as this month. The Aussie is set for its worst weekly performance since mid-December, while the US dollar index is poised for its best week since late 2016.

site_title: Brexit is 'catastrophic' for Ireland: Sinn Fein's O'Neill
summary: Michelle O'Neill, Sinn Fein leader in Northern Ireland, warns that Brexit is "catastrophic" for the island of Ireland, undermining the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. O'Neill expressed concern over the impact on the border, following the snap elections in Northern Ireland.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge down on profit-taking
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.3% on Friday, tracking broader Asia's decline, as investors booked profits ahead of the weekend. The main TAIEX index closed at 9,658.61 points, with the electronics subindex falling 0.4% and the financial subindex remaining flat. The Taiwan dollar weakened against the US dollar to NT$30.918, amid growing expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

site_title: Saudi cuts light oil prices to Asia as global oversupply persists
summary: Saudi Arabia cut April prices of light crude sold to Asia for the first time in three months, aiming to boost demand in an oversupplied market. The cut, which includes a 75-US cent reduction, is seen as a bid to maintain market share. Despite Opec production cuts and a strengthened Dubai benchmark, the region remains flooded with light crude due to rising output from Nigeria and Libya, as well as increased exports from Europe and the US. Saudi Arabia is shouldering the bulk of Opec cuts to compensate for weaker adherence by other members.

site_title: Asia's ugly duckling of 2017 is the peso, thanks to Duterte
summary: The Philippine peso has hit a 10-year low against the dollar, at 50.39, due to investor concerns over President Rodrigo Duterte's involvement in unlawful killings and corruption. A fresh inquiry is set to start next week, which could further worsen the currency's decline. Technical indicators suggest the peso's decline will continue, and it remains locked out of the party with other Asian currencies strengthening against the dollar this year.

site_title: Australia shares fall on financials, materials; NZ snaps 2-week decline
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Friday, posting their biggest intraday percentage loss in over a month, amid a risk of imminent US interest rate hike. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,730.00, with materials and financials sectors leading the decline. Global miners Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton fell 4.1% and 1.4% respectively, while QBE Insurance Group rose 1.8%. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.2%, snapping a two-week decline.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall most in over a month, financials, materials weigh; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 1% on Friday, the largest decline in over a month, due to a selloff in financials and materials, as well as a strong US dollar. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 55.388 points to 5721.2. The decline was attributed to investors cashing in on Thursday's strong gains and weakness in commodities, with miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto falling. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.3%.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink with global retreat but dollar rules
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday, following a global retreat, but the dollar strengthened against most currencies as traders expect a US interest rate hike this month. The dollar surged against higher-yielding currencies, while Asian markets declined, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul. The losses followed a week of record highs in Europe and New York, as investors took profits after a surge fueled by Donald Trump's address to Congress. Fed officials' comments have cemented expectations of a rate hike, with the dollar breaking above 114 yen for the first time in two weeks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open marginally higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened marginally higher on Friday, driven by a weak yen and a retreat from records on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.11% to 19,585.95, while the Topix index rose 0.01% to 1,564.92. The gains offset the decline in Asian markets earlier in the week, as investors continue to monitor the impact of US tariffs on global trade.

site_title: Japan Jan jobless rate falls to 3.0%
summary: Japan's jobless rate dropped to 3.0% in January, matching economists' forecasts, while the availability of jobs remained unchanged from the previous month. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was lower than December's 3.1%. The jobs-to-applicants ratio remained steady at 1.43.

site_title: Hot stock: Ezra shares dive as going concern issues stick
summary: Ezra Holdings shares plummeted 31.6% to S$0.013 after the company confirmed it faces going concern issues despite a Chapter 11 filing by associated company Emas Chiyoda Subsea. Ezra has guaranteed hundreds of millions of dollars in liabilities, totaling US$0.4 billion, and has substantial contingent liabilities for ECS Group's projects. The company will continue to engage with creditors to resolve claims, but a court may wind up the company if it's unable to pay debts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.53 points to 1,715.140 on Friday, with a trading volume of 77.3 million lots worth RM32.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 90.

site_title: Nintendo shares gain after Switch debuts without a glitch
summary: Nintendo shares rose 4.1% after the successful launch of its hybrid console Switch, exceeding initial supply and reaching a goal of 2 million units by the end of the month. The console's debut was marked by long lines and high demand, with most retailers exhausting inventory within minutes. Analysts expressed optimism about the launch, citing positive reviews of the device and its games, including The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild. Despite some initial concerns about potential defects, Nintendo's late entry into mobile gaming and its biggest bet in years seems to be paying off.

site_title: China anchors market stability in face of an accelerated Fed
summary: China's stable economic growth and policy clarity have anchored emerging markets against the prospect of a US Federal Reserve interest-rate hike in March. Unlike previous instances when the Fed's quantitative easing tapering led to capital outflows, China's stability has reassured investors that emerging economies can weather a rate hike. China's strong manufacturing data and stable currency have also supported liquidity-tightening by the People's Bank of China, giving emerging markets a "anchor" and potentially mitigating the impact of a Fed rate increase.

site_title: Gold heading for worst week since Dec on rate hike worries
summary: Gold prices fell on Friday, tracking a decline in the previous session, and are on track for its first weekly decline since late January due to expectations of a US rate hike in March. Spot gold dropped 0.2% to $1,232.81 per ounce, with US gold futures rising 0.2% to $1,234.90. Analysts expect gold to hover above a support level before bouncing back, but a correction is likely to be shallow due to investors' preference for gold as a hedge against global uncertainty.

site_title: Japan Jan nationwide core CPI up 0.1% y-o-y
summary: Japan's core consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.1% year-over-year in January, marking the first increase since December 2015, according to government data. A new index excluding energy and fresh food prices rose 0.2% in January. The Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications will release this new index monthly, providing a more accurate picture of price trends. This rise is a departure from expectations of flat growth, and follows a 0.3% decline in Tokyo core consumer prices in February.

site_title: UK firms report stronger growth, inflation test awaits: CBI
summary: The UK's private sector saw stronger growth in the three months to February, with the Confederation of British Industry's Growth Indicator rising to +15 from +10 in the previous period. This suggests a slowdown in the economy's recent slowdown and that the Brexit vote's impact is still limited. Companies expect similar growth over the next three months, but inflation is expected to rise, which may slow growth later in the year.

site_title: Alibaba-rival JD to get 14.3b yuan in finance arm spinoff
summary: JD.com Inc. agreed to sell its finance arm, JD Finance, for 14.3 billion yuan (S$3 billion) in cash while retaining a 40% stake in its future profits. The sale is part of a deal to spin off the division and create a financial services powerhouse rival to Ant Financial. The spinoff will allow JD to gain necessary regulatory licenses and strengthen its business. The deal is seen as positive for JD investors, who will benefit from the cash generated by the asset and reduced financial risk.

site_title: Malaysia "strongly condemns" use of VX nerve agent in airport murder
summary: Malaysia's foreign ministry strongly condemned the use of VX nerve agent VX, a chemical weapon of mass destruction, in the murder of Kim Jong Un's half-brother at Kuala Lumpur International airport on February 13. The ministry stated that the use of such a chemical in a public place could have endangered the general public. It was in close contact with the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons regarding the incident.

site_title: Rare disclosure sheds light on plight of China's aggrieved petitioners
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Chinese petitioners travel to Beijing each year, seeking justice for grievances often sparked by local officials. The case of Wang Fengyun, a villager from Inner Mongolia, highlights the government's efforts to suppress petitioners, including detaining and charging her family with "picking quarrels." Documents reveal the county government spent 335,000 yuan on dissuading Wang's persistent petitioning over five years. Human rights lawyers argue that such actions are an abuse of power, contradicting the central government's efforts to improve the petition system and President Xi Jinping's order to resolve grievances.

site_title: Singapore shares open down 13.84 points on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 13.84 points to 3,122.64 on Friday, snapping a five-day rally. The decline came amid a weaker Wall Street close overnight. Jardine Matheson and other companies were among the top losers. The trading volume was 57.2 million shares worth S$80.2 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 65 to 49.

site_title: Update: Ezra still faces going concern, backs "substantial" liabilities of ECS under Chapter 11
summary: Ezra Holdings has confirmed it will still face going concern issues if creditors make claims against its substantial liabilities, totaling US$0.4 billion, guaranteed by the company. The embattled oil-and-gas firm's associated company Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS Group) has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Ezra has also guaranteed an additional US$0.5 billion in loans owed by ECS Group, and has substantial contingent liabilities for performance and bank guarantees. The company's shares were halted trading due to the announcements.

site_title: Brexit puts UK main political parties in sharper relief
summary: The UK's Brexit saga is driving clearer positioning among main political parties, potentially creating new electoral cleavages. The Conservative Party is unifying around a hard Brexit stance, while Labour faces a challenge in balancing its pro-Remain MPs with Leave-voting constituencies. The UKIP party's threat to Labour's seats has distracted attention, but its potential to siphon off Conservative votes remains. As the Brexit negotiations with the EU proceed, the issue is likely to frame UK domestic politics for years to come and potentially become the defining battleground in the 2020 general election.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ezra Holdings, Vard Holdings, Dairy Farm, Spackman
summary: Ezra Holdings lifted a trading halt after stating that a Chapter 11 filing by Emas Chiyoda Subsea doesn't impact its charter-hire liabilities. Vard Holdings secured a $58.5 million contract for a pelagic trawler. Dairy Farm's net profit rose 10.5% to $469 million. Spackman Entertainment Group entered a placement agreement with UOB Kay Hian to issue new shares. Jardine Matheson Holdings' net profit increased 39% to $2.5 billion due to a $1.1 billion gain from Hongkong Land's investment portfolio.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat, Melrose and Subsea impress
summary: European shares ended flat on Thursday, despite strong gains from Melrose and Subsea after positive results. The pan-European STOXX 600 index was weighed down by falls in basic resources and banking stocks. This marks the latter stages of an otherwise impressive European earnings season.

site_title: Singapore High Court grants stay order on claims against ECS
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted a stay order to Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS) and its five Singapore-incorporated subsidiaries, halting claims against the companies until a hearing on March 13. The stay order, similar to the US Chapter 11 automatic stay, provides debtor company protection from litigation. ECS had filed for Chapter 11 protection partly due to its largest bank lenders being based in Singapore. The move aims to facilitate international debt restructuring and reflects Singapore's effectiveness in supporting cross-border restructuring.

images.alt_text: The stay order that was passed after a Wednesday evening hearing also extends to four other subsidiaries of ECS, namely Lewek Constellation Pte Ltd, Lewek Falcon Pte Ltd, Emas Chiyoda ROV Pte Ltd and Emas Chiyoda Subsea Services Pte Ltd.

site_title: Britain's small companies hoard cash as Brexit looms
summary: Britain's small companies are hoarding cash and cutting investment due to Brexit uncertainty, with a 74% decline in investment plans over the past six months, according to Lloyds Banking Group. Companies with revenue under £1 million expect to invest an average of £21,690 in the next six months, down from £108,950 in July. This move may dampen economic growth prospects as it could limit business expansion and worsen the economic slowdown. The main threats to the economy are economic uncertainty, weaker UK demand, and political uncertainty, according to the survey.

site_title: Route to more power for China's Xi runs through remote Guizhou
summary: China's President Xi Jinping may promote Guizhou Communist Party boss Chen Miner to the seven-member Politburo Standing Committee, potentially giving him a two-step promotion to the powerful body. Chen, a trusted confidant of Xi, has risen through the party ranks in Zhejiang and Guizhou, and has a good relationship with Xi. If promoted, Chen would join other Xi allies, such as Li Zhanshu and Zhao Leji, and could potentially leave rivals like Hu Chunhua and Sun Zhengcai behind. The move could solidify Xi's grip on power and set Chen up for the top prize.

images.alt_text: When China rejuvenates its top leadership team towards the end of the year, sources close to senior leaders say President Xi Jinping could reveal his grip on power with a possible leapfrog promotion for Guizhou Communist Party boss Chen Miner (pictured).

site_title: MAS nod for PolicyPal's sandbox experiment
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has approved PolicyPal, a fintech firm, for its sandbox programme. This allows PolicyPal to test its insurance solutions over a six-month period, starting March 2, 2017, in partnership with NTUC Income and Etiqa Insurance. The experiment will focus on direct-purchase life insurance products and insurance against accidents or diseases caused by mosquitoes. Clients will not be able to seek dispute resolution through the Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre during this period.

site_title: Oil down more than 2% as Russian output cuts stall
summary: Oil prices fell over 2% on Thursday as Russian crude production remained unchanged in February, failing to meet its pledged cuts under a global supply deal. Russia's oil output was 11.11 million barrels per day, just a third of the levels pledged. This weak compliance tightened the oversupplied market, causing Brent futures to drop to $55.08 per barrel and US crude to settle at $52.61.

site_title: Would you like an app with your fries?
summary: McDonald's US restaurants are introducing mobile ordering and kerbside pick-up to speed up service at drive-thrus, aiming to reduce wait times and prevent customers from skipping visits due to long delays. The company plans to roll out the service in the fourth quarter and have it available at all US restaurants by year-end. This move aims to cut wait times by 20%, with 20% of drive-thru orders shifting to kerbside delivery and another 20% to drive-thru pick-up only.

site_title: Nintendo launches new Switch game console
summary: Nintendo launches its new Switch game console on Friday, aiming to reverse declining sales and compete with the PlayStation 4. The $299 console, which works both at home and on-the-go, blends Nintendo's console history with its mobile gaming strategy. The company aims to sell over two million Switch consoles in its first month, marking a key launch for the Japanese videogame giant.

site_title: Carbon tax a sign of things to come for all firms
summary: Singapore's carbon tax, set to start in 2019, will primarily affect heavy industries such as power stations and refineries, but its implications extend to all firms. The tax will increase carbon reporting requirements, potentially affecting smaller companies. Several countries, including South Korea and China, have or are implementing similar schemes. Companies in Singapore have been slow to adopt sustainability reporting, but the introduction of the carbon tax may prompt change.

site_title: SGX piles more pressure on Sabana Reit manager
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Sabana Real Estate Investment Management, the manager of Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit), over the resignation of non-executive director Ng Shin Ein, citing "internal dynamics" that allegedly hampered her contribution. The manager's response referred to these dynamics as difficulties in accessing a good pipeline of properties due to the shareholding structure. Unitholders are anxious, awaiting a special meeting to force the manager out, and are scrutinizing a potential sale of the Reit and its manager.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US attorney general recuses self from Trump campaign probes
summary: US Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself from investigations into Donald Trump's election campaign, citing ethics rules that prohibit involvement in a campaign he had a role in. Despite Trump's endorsement, Sessions stood firm and announced his recusal in a news conference. Sessions cited his role in the campaign as the reason for his decision, stating he should not be involved in investigating a campaign he had a role in.

site_title: Residents, campaigners battle to save Bangkok's 'Green Lung'
summary: Residents and campaigners in Bangkok are fighting to save the city's "Green Lung," Bang Krachao, from development. The 16 sq km artificial island is a tropical oasis in the midst of a concrete jungle, home to hundreds of plant and bird species. Despite Thailand's late King Bhumibol Adulyadej's wish to preserve it, soaring land prices and rising demand are threatening the area's wild character. A three-year plan announced by the military government aims to renovate public green spaces and ensure at least 60% remains free from development.

site_title: Airlines aim to trick passengers' taste buds
summary: Airlines are addressing the sensory gap on flights by altering food and drinks to compensate for factors such as noise, low pressure, and dry air. Studies show that the way we taste food changes at high altitude, with a 30% decrease in sensitivity to sweet and salty flavors. To counteract this, airlines are introducing beers brewed specifically for in-flight consumption, such as Cathay Pacific's new beer containing honey and "dragon eye" fruit. Experts also suggest playing background noise, using sonic seasoning, and choosing wines from high-altitude regions to enhance flavors.

site_title: A feast for the eyes and mind in BT Weekend
summary: The Business Times' Weekend magazine features a culinary tour of Bangkok and Kyoto, highlighting Singapore's top chefs and their international success. The magazine also covers the history of Singapore's libraries, innovative food catering business Elsie's Kitchen, and explores the concept of corporate purpose. Additionally, it introduces readers to two new YouTube channels and a Sun Tzu-inspired book on business. The issue is available for subscription at btsub.sg/weekend.

site_title: State Bank of India offers remittance service to India via ATMs
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) launched a remittance service to India via its ATMs in Singapore, a first in the country. The service allows customers to send up to $3,000 per day, with no commission fee during the launch period. SBI aims to sign up 5,000 more customers with the new offering, which is available at 25 ATMs in Singapore. The service is part of SBI's existing remittance channels, which include internet banking and six branches in Singapore.

site_title: France's Le Pen loses EU immunity over IS tweets
summary: Marine Le Pen, a French far-right presidential candidate, has lost her European Parliament immunity after a vote in Brussels. The ruling comes after she tweeted graphic images of Islamic State atrocities, including the decapitated body of US journalist James Foley. Le Pen can now be prosecuted for the tweets, which could lead to a fine of up to 75,000 euros and up to three years in prison. The decision has been met with criticism from Le Pen's aides, who call it a "political" attempt to derail her presidential bid.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as Snap surges in debut
summary: US stocks retreated on Thursday as investors paused after strong gains earlier in the week, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. The main focus was on the debut of Snap Inc, the parent company of Snapchat, which surged in its initial public offering. Despite the strong performance, analysts expected a pullback in the broader market after Wednesday's record gains. European equities remained little changed.

site_title: Spotify extends streaming lead with 50m subscribers
summary: Spotify has extended its lead as the world's largest streaming company with 50 million paying subscribers, surpassing Apple Music's 20 million. The update was the first from privately held Spotify since September, with the company previously stating it had 100 million users, including those on its free tier. This milestone solidifies Spotify's position in the market, with Apple Music trailing behind.

images.alt_text: Spotify has extended its lead as the world's largest streaming company as it announced on Thursday that it had 50 million paying subscribers.

site_title: Writing on the wall: big banks will get bigger, capital levels will fall
summary: The global financial system has made some progress in reducing the risk of large bank failures since the 2008 financial crisis, but policymakers are now pushing to undo these reforms. The Volcker Rule, restrictions on proprietary trading, and increased scrutiny of risk-taking have been rolled back or weakened, and capital levels are expected to fall. Powerful individuals, including those with ties to Goldman Sachs, are driving this shift, which could lead to a repeat of the 2008 crisis and increased inequality and poverty.

site_title: Chile expects February growth, copper output hit by miners strike
summary: Chile expects a 1% decline in February's economic growth due to a strike at the Escondida copper mine, which has reduced copper output by 12% year-on-year. The strike, involving 2,500 unionized workers, has boosted global copper prices. Escondida, the world's no.1 copper mine, was forecast to produce 1.2 million tonnes this year, down from 5% of world copper in 2016. The strike's impact on Chile's economy is expected to be around one percentage point.

images.alt_text: Chile expects economic activity growth to be hit by around one percentage point in February because of a strike at world no.1 copper mine Escondida, as copper output slides 12 per cent year-on-year, the government said on Thursday.

site_title: New minerals back idea of man-made epoch for Earth: study
summary: Scientists have identified over 200 man-made minerals created by human industries, suggesting that human activity has a significant impact on the Earth's geology, potentially marking a new epoch. These minerals, formed through rare chemical combinations, have been found in mines, ore dumps, and smelters, including a previously unknown mineral in a Russian nickel mine. The discovery indicates that human activity has become so prevalent that it is altering the Earth's geology, a concept previously known as the "Anthropocene."

site_title: Credit Suisse Asia-Pac raises private banking bar with aggregation feature
summary: Credit Suisse Asia-Pacific has introduced a new aggregation feature for its private banking clients, allowing them to compare the performance of their portfolios across different asset classes and banks. The feature, in partnership with fintech firm Mesitis, provides daily mark-to-market information and analytics, enabling clients to make more informed investment decisions. The move aims to differentiate Credit Suisse from competitors and improve client service, as Francesco de Ferrari, head of private banking Asia-Pacific, stated that the feature "implicitly puts more pressure on us to be the best."

site_title: Has America gone complacent?
summary: US economist Tyler Cowen argues that the country's economy is facing stagnation due to "complacency," not traditional factors like debt or government policies. Americans are less likely to move for work, fewer startups are formed, and people cluster with similar backgrounds, hindering economic flexibility and dynamism. Cowen blames this on Americans' increasing desire for security and stability, leading to a reluctance to change and innovate. However, his theory is disputed, with some arguing that it's actually "entitlement" or fear of change, rather than complacency, driving these trends.

site_title: State-of-the-art show by Cantopop king
summary: Hong Kong singer Jacky Cheung performed a high-energy concert, A Classic Tour, at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, selling out all three shows. The 56-year-old Cantopop King showcased his dancing and singing skills in a state-of-the-art production, featuring elaborate sets, moving platforms, and LED screens. The concert included a medley of his biggest hits, which drew the loudest cheers and biggest singalong from the crowd of 10,000. Cheung cited his desire to perform before he becomes too old to pull off his signature dance moves as the motivation behind the tour.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Carbon tax revenue not earmarked for specific purposes: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean stated that the carbon tax revenue in Singapore will encourage carbon mitigation and incentivize businesses and consumers to lower emissions. The tax, set to be implemented in 2019, will provide price certainty for industrial facilities investing in clean energy and energy efficiency. This measure aims to complement existing regulatory measures and promote sustainable practices in the country.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Good Class Bungalow at Garlick Ave to be sold for S$23.88 million
summary: Singapore property developer Sustained Land's boss, Douglas Ong, is buying a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) along Garlick Avenue in District 10 for S$23.88 million, translating to S$858 per square foot. The existing two-storey house is expected to be redeveloped due to site constraints and the owners' plan to vacate the property in about a year. The sale price is considered low, even by market standards, and reflects the land value.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: OCBC increases funding for charity partners
summary: OCBC unveiled a revamped CSR programme, OCBC Cares, increasing funding for charity partners. The programme now focuses on the elderly, special needs persons, and environmental sustainability, in addition to vulnerable children and education. The bank's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, will oversee the expanded CSR efforts.

site_title: ExxonMobil's new chief shifts focus to shale oil
summary: ExxonMobil's new CEO, Darren Woods, is shifting the company's focus to shale oil, diverting about one-third of its drilling budget to US shale fields that can deliver cash flow in as little as three years. Woods aims to increase US shale production by 50% of ExxonMobil's worldwide drilling budget next year and expects output from shale wells to grow 20% annually through 2025. The company is also investing heavily in the Permian Basin, the largest US oil field, with a planned acquisition worth up to $6.6 billion.

site_title: Superhero film with a human touch
summary: Logan, the final film featuring Hugh Jackman as Wolverine, has been released to critical acclaim. The movie, directed by James Mangold, offers a poignant and human take on the superhero genre, focusing on the frailties of its characters rather than superpowers. The film follows Wolverine as he reconnects with a young mutant, Laura, and her mother, and must confront his paternal instincts. With a high body count and emotional weight, Logan delivers a fitting farewell to the character and is considered a game-changer in the superhero movie genre.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Second Reit ETF on SGX launching this month
summary: A new Reit ETF, NikkoAM-StraitsTrading Asia ex-Japan Reit ETF, will be launched on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) this month, tracking the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Asia ex-Japan Net Total Return Reit index. The fund will focus on Reits listed in Singapore, Hong Kong, China, Malaysia, and Indonesia, with a historical weighted average gross dividend yield of 5.72%. The ETF will be rebalanced quarterly and will be open for subscription from March 6 to 21, with trading starting on March 29.

site_title: Grab starts app to offer new and pre-booking of shuttle routes
summary: Grab launches GrabShuttle, a beta shuttle bus service mobile app in Singapore, offering 15 new bus routes with fixed fares ranging from S$3.50 to S$5. The service aims to reduce traffic congestion and carbon emissions by encouraging shared transportation. Commuters can pre-book seats up to one month in advance and track buses in real-time. The app is a public-private collaboration between Grab and the Government Technology Agency of Singapore, with more routes to be added in the coming months.

site_title: KepReit Mgt ex-CEO Ng Hsueh Ling quits Keppel group
summary: Former Keppel Reit Management CEO Ng Hsueh Ling has left Keppel Corporation at the end of January, citing personal reasons. This comes as Keppel Reit is experiencing challenges, including a 11.9% drop in distribution per unit for the fourth quarter and a change in leadership, with Ms. Ling's successor Jesline Goh resigning. Tan Swee Yiow, current Singapore president of Keppel Land's property arm, will take over as CEO of Keppel Reit's manager from March 20.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang Estates' shares soar on research report
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' shares surged on Thursday after a research report estimated the property developer's worth at S$7.55 per share, based on marked-to-market land prices. The report predicted a potential increase in the company's net asset value to S$10.35 per share if its full development potential is realized. The estimate was made by DBS Group Research, and the shares rose in response to the positive assessment of the company's value.

site_title: US ride hailing firm Lyft seeking funds: sources
summary: Lyft, the second-largest US ride-hailing company, is seeking additional funding to increase its value to around $6 billion. The company is in talks with investors about the new fundraising, which could potentially boost its valuation to $7 billion. This move comes as Uber, its larger rival, faces questions about its culture and leadership.

site_title: ECB stimulus paying off as eurozone inflation hits target
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus appears to be paying off as eurozone inflation reached its 2% target for the first time since 2013 in February. Unemployment in the 19-country single currency area remained at 9.6% in January, the lowest rate since May 2009. Analysts expect the inflation increase to be temporary, with some predicting it could even fall to 1.6% by the end of the year, and the ECB is unlikely to change course despite the figures. The ECB's massive economic stimulus has been in place since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: S'pore must stay attractive for work, business: Heng
summary: Singapore must maintain its attractiveness for work and business despite other countries lowering corporate tax rates, said Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat. The government aims to ensure a sustainable tax system that rewards effort and enterprise, while also being fair and progressive across income groups. Enhanced corporate income tax rebates were introduced in Budget 2017, and the government will carefully consider all options before raising taxes.

site_title: Ford seeks UK cost cuts as Brexit weighs on Europe outlook
summary: Ford Motor Co is initiating labour talks to cut costs at its UK engine plant in Bridgend, where over 1,100 jobs are at risk due to Brexit and slowing European growth. The factory currently produces enough engines to guarantee current employment levels for two to three years, but may need to reduce staff if efficiency is not boosted. Ford is reviewing its staffing beyond 2020, but no job cuts are planned at this time. The move follows similar concerns from other carmakers, including Nissan and Jaguar Land Rover, which are seeking government support to ensure the UK's competitiveness after Brexit.

site_title: Public servants to get 4 more weeks of unpaid infant-care leave
summary: Singapore has announced a pilot scheme providing an extra four weeks of unpaid infant-care leave for public servants with newborns. The new policy, starting in July, increases the total parental leave to 26 weeks for couples with one spouse in the Public Service, or 30 weeks jointly. The move aims to address the "caregiving gap" and provide better workplace support for working parents, as some may not use all their paid parental leave due to work pressure. The pilot will test the viability of longer parental leave and may lead to a nationwide rollout in the future.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Jiak Kim, Toh Tuck, Owen sites top draws in GLS: consultant
summary: The Singapore government's first half government land sales (GLS) for 2017 have identified top draws, including Jiak Kim Street, Toh Tuck Road, and Owen Road. These sites offer unique features such as river views and proximity to established neighborhoods and growth clusters. Edmund Tie & Co's GLS report ranks land parcels based on scores in four criteria, with the Jiak Kim Street site expected to fetch 10-15 bids in the range of S$1,100 to S$1,300 per sq ft per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Love letter to dogs and their owners
summary: A Dog's Purpose, a film based on W Bruce Cameron's book, follows the life of a red retriever named Bailey as he reincarnates multiple times, teaching life lessons to his owners. The film, directed by Lasse Hallstrom, has been criticized by animal rights groups over a leaked rescue scene video, but is praised for its heartwarming portrayal of the human-canine bond. Despite its manipulative and sentimental nature, the film succeeds as a love letter to dogs and their owners, espousing a philosophy of loyalty and devotion.

site_title: Slice of Big Apple at Jean-Georges' new Singapore outpost
summary: Jean-Georges Vongerichten, a celebrated New York chef, is opening his first restaurant in South-east Asia, The Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, at COMO Dempsey in Singapore. The upscale restaurant features an open kitchen and communal dining space, designed by Paola Navone. This marks Vongerichten's first venture in the region and the latest addition to COMO Dempsey, which also houses a Michelin-starred Peranakan restaurant and gourmet supermarket. The restaurant's elegant interiors are set to bring a touch of Big Apple chic to Dempsey Hill.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Midday break, disciplinary guide should placate some SGX critics
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced plans to consult the public on the feasibility of reinstating a midday trading break, addressing long-standing criticisms from the local trading representative (TR) community. Additionally, the exchange has provided an insight into its disciplinary decision-making process for the first time, aiming to increase transparency. These developments are seen as a step towards placating SGX critics and improving relations with TRs. The move follows the removal of a 90-minute trading break to offer Continuous All-day Trading (CAT).

site_title: Breakfast inequality: some work 9 hours to buy first meal of the day
summary: The Bloomberg Global City Breakfast Index reveals wide affordability gaps in breakfast costs worldwide. In some cities, like Abu Dhabi and Osaka, breakfast can be purchased for under $5, while in cities like Caracas, Venezuela, it takes almost 9 hours to afford. The disparity is widest in Latin America, with Caracas having the highest breakfast cost at 111% of a day's pay. This highlights the issue of malnutrition and food riots in poorer countries due to prohibitively priced staples.

site_title: How Japan firms can sustain the M&A surge
summary: Japan's surge in mergers and acquisitions (M&As) has raised concerns about the country's ability to adapt in foreign territories. Unlike previous waves, which ended in spectacular failures, the current wave of acquisitions has been successful. However, experts attribute this to the growing importance of cultural intelligence, allowing Japanese firms to understand and work effectively across cultures. Key challenges include Japan's collectivist society, reliance on non-verbal cues, and risk-averse decision-making style. To succeed, Japanese companies must balance their unique cultural characteristics with global business needs, and study successful companies like Toyota to learn from their approaches.

site_title: EU's door remains open even as others' are closing
summary: The European Union remains open to global solutions despite rising protectionism. History shows the dangers of protectionism, which can harm millions worldwide. EU and Singapore share a commitment to open trade. This stands in contrast to the "perverse globalism" of Donald Trump, who has sparked a global shift towards protectionism. The EU and China are set to meet later this month, with Wang Yi's European tour setting the tone.

site_title: Maybank group appoints first chairwoman
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest public-listed company, appoints Mohaiyani Shamsudin as its first female chairwoman, effective April. She replaces Megat Zaharuddin Megat Mohd Nor, who steps down after 12 years on the board and 7.5 years as chairman. Shamsudin, a seasoned director with over five years of experience, will lead the bank and ensure continuity at the board. The appointment marks a significant milestone for women in the financial services industry, and bank president Abdul Farid Alias expressed confidence in her ability to lead Maybank effectively.

site_title: Booming nations in Asia grapple with rise in shantytowns
summary: Asia's booming nations, including Cambodia, Mongolia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Vietnam, China, and Indonesia, are struggling with a surge in shantytown dwellers, with 55-43% of urban populations living in slums. The rapid urbanization outpaces governments' ability to provide necessary infrastructure and services, highlighting the need for improved land use policies and affordable housing finance. World Bank expert Makiko Watanabe notes that slum-dwellers are not a burden, but rather a result of successful economic growth, and that addressing the issue can help disperse population and alleviate pressure on regional hubs.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing expands again in February but at a slower clip
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the sixth consecutive month in February, but at a slower clip, with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 50.9. The expansion was driven by inventory and stock accumulation despite higher input prices. The electronics sector PMI dipped 0.4 points, but the sector recorded its seventh consecutive month of expansion. Economists attribute the slowdown to seasonality and softening bullish sentiments, with growth forecasts still positive, including a 6.2% year-on-year growth rate in Q2 2017.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S manufacturing sector continued expanding in February for the sixth consecutive month, albeit at a marginally slower rate.

site_title: Snap IPO values company at double Facebook's worth
summary: Snap Inc, the maker of Snapchat, has raised US$3.4 billion in its initial public offering, valuing the company at at least twice the worth of Facebook Inc and four times that of Twitter Inc. The company sold 200 million shares at US$17 each, resulting in a market value of approximately US$20 billion. This is the largest social-media IPO since Twitter's offering in 2013.

site_title: Fewer workers, higher wages hurting Japan Inc
summary: Japan's labor-intensive industries, such as delivery companies and restaurants, are struggling due to a shortage of workers and rising wage costs. Average pay for temporary workers has reached a fifth monthly record, with some industries paying up to 13.8% more. Labour costs as a portion of overall sales are at their highest level in five years, despite stagnant base pay for rank-and-file workers. Companies are adapting by increasing automation and hiring foreign workers, but some are slashing their operating profit forecasts due to the impact on costs.

site_title: Guns N' Roses show hits the high notes
summary: Guns N' Roses reunited for a sold-out show in Singapore, with the band performing 27 songs over almost three hours. The "Not In This Lifetime" tour, which includes original members Axl Rose, Slash, and Duff McKagan, marked their first performance in over two decades. The band delivered a high-energy performance, with Rose hitting his signature high notes and the band performing classic hits from their iconic albums, including "Appetite for Destruction" and "Use Your Illusion I and II". The reunion was a long-awaited treat for fans, who braved a traffic jam to see the rock legends live.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Dystopian drama lacks insight
summary: The play "Prism" explores the fate of a town earmarked for redevelopment in a dystopian present, focusing on heritage, memory, identity, loss, and guilt. Directed by Rei Poh, the production features a gritty set, surreal lighting, and vivid costumes. However, the script is criticized for being thin and one-dimensional, with characters lacking complexity. Despite this, the cast delivers strong performances, particularly Alvin Chiam and Lina Yu. The play's themes and style are reminiscent of a Greek tragedy, but its execution falls short due to the dated script.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US growing modestly, signs of inflation subdued: Fed
summary: The US economy grew at a modest to moderate pace, further tightening the labor market with some districts reporting widening labor shortages. The Federal Reserve survey showed employment growth, but no significant acceleration in wages or inflation. The central bank is close to achieving its dual goals of low unemployment and 2% inflation.

site_title: Flexing culinary muscles and flavours at Morsels
summary: Morsels, a restaurant in Dempsey Village, has undergone a transformation since its opening four years ago. The eatery, run by chef-owner Petrina Loh, has shifted from quirky and rough to a rustic, farmhouse-chic atmosphere. The menu features a mix of familiar and experimental dishes, with an emphasis on presentation and making things from scratch. While some dishes, such as the devilled eggs and kurobuta char siew, impress, others, like the jackfruit, fall flat. Overall, Morsels is a promising restaurant that dares to be different, but may not please every palate. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: Enterprise and partnership needed for the future: Heng
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a pervasive sense of enterprise and partnership to mitigate risks in an uncertain future. In Budget 2017, the government aims to foster this spirit through initiatives such as the International Partnership Fund, Global Innovation Alliance, and Industry Transformation Maps. The budget also allocates S$2.4 billion over four years to implement the Committee on the Future Economy's recommendations. Heng stressed that the government will review regulations to help freelancers and review severe disability insurance schemes. The budget prioritizes targeted measures over broad-based ones to maintain a healthy economy.

site_title: Singapore to double down on globalisation: Vivian
summary: Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the country's commitment to globalization, rejecting isolationist and protectionist policies despite rising nationalistic sentiment globally. He reiterated the government's stance to "double down on globalisation," acknowledging the potential implications on Singapore's trade-dependent economy.

site_title: Bringing art to the Village
summary: OH! Open House brings art to Holland Village with guided walks, featuring doughnut-like sculptures at the Hakka Cemetery and paper installations in a home. The event showcases unexpected art in public spaces. Experimental videos play in hidden areas, transforming the village into an artistic hub. This seventh edition of OH! Open House aims to revitalize the area's artistic cred.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: DBS CEO sees wealth management business as key growth driver
summary: DBS Group, South-east Asia's largest bank by assets, plans to expand its wealth management business, aiming to reach 20% of its revenue in the next few years. The bank's wealth management business has doubled in the last five years and is now around 15% of its revenue. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expects the segment to grow as Asia's wealth gap widens, with Asia Pacific becoming the fastest-growing wealth region in the world. The bank will look for "bolt-on" acquisitions to grow its wealth business, with assets in the $10 billion to $20 billion range.

site_title: Winning fashion statement: it's really quite ephemeral
summary: Artist Yom Bo Sung, 21, won the top prize in the BAZAAR Singapore Art Prize with his sculpture "Gunny Stack," which critiques the ephemeral nature of fashion. The piece, featuring stacked clothes like a newspaper stack, was chosen from 12 shortlisted artists and received a S$10,000 award. The BAZAAR Singapore Art Prize, now in its second year, aims to merge fashion and art, with a diverse range of winners in various categories, including photography and 2D works on canvas and paper.

site_title: Singapore appoints judge ad hoc in Pedra Branca case
summary: Singapore has appointed Judge Gilbert Guillaume as a judge ad hoc in the Pedra Branca case, where Malaysia is seeking revision of an 2008 International Court of Justice (ICJ) judgment. Guillaume, a former ICJ president, will participate in the decision-making process. Singapore plans to submit comprehensive written observations on Malaysia's application by June 14, 2023, to argue the admissibility of the case.

site_title: China's top body meeting to focus on financial risks and reform
summary: China's National People's Congress, opening this weekend, will focus on financial risks and reform, rather than growth, according to analysts. The agenda includes stemming unofficial lending, financial market reforms, and cutting overcapacity. President Xi Jinping has emphasized the need to speed up economic reform and tackle "zombie companies." The congress is expected to confirm a GDP growth target of 6.5% and an inflation target of 3%. Analysts predict a shift in policy towards reining in risks and away from supporting short-run growth.

site_title: Designs that inspire
summary: Singapore Design Week, the fourth edition, takes place from March 3 to 12, featuring over 100 events at the National Design Centre and various locations. The week celebrates good design in everyday life, with events including exhibitions, conferences, and workshops. Highlights include Singaplural 2017: Stories, KYO Project, Design Trails, Design Cookout, Singapore + Wallpaper* Handmade Classics, WY-TO Connects, 9 Lives Design Show, Design, Make and Craft Fair, and Frontliners in Action. These events aim to inspire visitors, build awareness of good design, and engage businesses in the use of design in business strategy.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Shocking, sinister and so very good
summary: Pangdemonium's production of The Pillowman, a horror-comedy by Martin McDonagh, received a standing ovation from the audience. The play, set in a totalitarian state, follows writer Katurian as he is questioned about his dark and violent children's fiction, which mirrors a string of child murders. The production's dark intensity and sadism sparked some audience members to leave early, but those who stayed praised the play's potency and compelling storytelling. The Pillowman has been praised for its unique blend of horror, comedy, and tragedy, earning it a full five-star rating.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Dairy Farm FY16 profit grows 10.5% to US$469m
summary: Dairy Farm International reported a 10.5% increase in net profit to US$469.0 million in FY16, driven by improved margins in its food and Ikea businesses. Sales from subsidiaries rose 0.6% to US$11.2 billion, with home furnishings seeing a 5.1% increase. The company proposed a final dividend of 14.5 US cents per share and plans to focus on profitable business approaches, modernizing infrastructure, and improving sourcing. Despite economic uncertainty, Dairy Farm aims to continue expanding its store presence and logistics centralization.

site_title: Corporate digest (Amended)
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings reported a 66% year-on-year increase in full-year net profit to $3.3 billion, driven by a $2.5 billion gain from investment property revaluation. Mandarin Oriental posted a 38.2% fall in full-year net profit to $55.2 million, while Vard Holdings secured a $58.5 million contract for a trawler. Spackman Entertainment Group proposed a share placement to raise $5.95 million for working capital and investments.

site_title: Singapore traders go huat ah!
summary: The Singapore market closed at 3,136.48 points, up 14 points, with the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) up 8.88% year-to-date. The market saw a robust S$1.8 billion in value traded and 2.8 billion shares traded. Optimism about blue-chip counters like Jardine, Singapore banks, and major companies like Keppel Corp and CapitaLand drove the gains, with the STI outperforming other Asian markets.

site_title: Brexit spurs Ireland to woo Middle East for dairy, meat sales
summary: Ireland seeks to boost agriculture exports to the Middle East, aiming for a 19 billion euros rise by 2025, up from 11 billion euros in 2016. The UK, Ireland's largest buyer, is set to leave the EU due to Brexit, prompting Dublin to diversify sales. The country's agriculture industry, worth 21 billion dollars, currently relies heavily on the UK for 43% of its exports, including 1 billion euros worth of beef and dairy products annually.

site_title: SEC freezes suspicious traders' assets
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has frozen assets of suspicious traders who made over US$3.6 million in illegal profits by investing in Fortress shares ahead of a Softbank Group Corp buyout. The traders, believed to be overseas investors, used accounts outside the US to engage in "highly suspicious trading" involving 950,000 Fortress shares and derivatives. The SEC obtained an emergency court order to freeze the assets, preventing them from being removed while the investigation continues.

site_title: WTO ready to talk it out as US changes policy
summary: The US has announced it will not be bound by WTO decisions, citing a 1995 Congressional review of the terms under which the US joined the organization. This move could threaten the viability of the WTO's Dispute Settlement Body and lead to a global trade war, as countries may impose sanctions and tariffs in response. WTO chief Roberto Azevedo has extended an olive branch, offering to discuss concerns with the US trade team, but economists and industry groups fear this could trigger economic protectionism worldwide.

site_title: US Dollar bulls still nervous as March rate hike bakes in
summary: US dollar gains against the yen and other major currencies following comments from US Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard, who said an improving global economy and US recovery mean a rate hike "soon" is "appropriate." The US dollar rose to a two-week high of 114.40 yen and gained up to 1% against the Australian and New Zealand dollars. The euro, however, remained resilient, limiting the dollar's gains. The comments fueled concerns about a potential March interest rate hike, keeping investors on edge.

site_title: US$ bulls nervous over March rate hike signals
summary: US dollar rises against yen and other currencies as signs of a March interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve grow, with Governor Lael Brainard stating it will be "appropriate soon" to raise rates due to an improving global economy and US recovery. The dollar index gained 0.25% to 102.03, while the euro remained stable around $1.05, despite expectations of a rate hike doubling. Analysts warn that a faster pace of rate hikes could lead to a weaker dollar, similar to 2013.

site_title: Jardine Matheson's FY16 net profit up 39% at US$2.5b
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings' net profit for FY16 rose 39% to US$2.5 billion, driven by a US$1.1 billion gain from Hongkong Land's investment property portfolio. Underlying profit increased marginally to US$1.39 billion, while revenue rose 11% to US$72.4 billion. The company recommended a final dividend of US$1.12 per share, up 3% year-over-year, and reported a strong balance sheet with US$21.8 billion in shareholders' funds and gearing of 4%. The group's businesses, including Jardine Motors, Dairy Farm, and Hongkong Land, performed satisfactorily in FY16.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Singaporean food and property companies reported strong 2016 results. Food Empire Holdings declared a dividend, signaling confidence in its management, while maintaining a "buy" rating with a target price of S$0.78. QAF Limited downgraded its rating to "hold" due to potential cost pressures, but remains positive for the long term. Ho Bee Land Limited is recommended to "accumulate" with an increased target price of S$2.64, citing a narrowing discount to its peer average and a return of interest in high-end properties. Analysts express optimism about the companies' fortunes moving forward.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips as investors take profits after record day
summary: US stocks slipped on Thursday as investors took profits after a record day on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 27.9 points to 21,087.65. The decline came after President Donald Trump's more measured tone in a speech to Congress and increased chances of an interest rate hike this month. The Labor Department reported a 44-year low in jobless claims, supporting a higher interest rate hike and boosting the markets.

site_title: Let's get this party started
summary: Three musical events will push boundaries in Singapore, featuring live orchestration and unique soundscapes. "One More Time - A Tribute to Zouk" at Capitol Theatre on March 24-25 will feature 48 professional musicians playing a set of house music live, recreating the Zouk club's sound from 1991 to 2015. "Vibrational" at University Cultural Centre Hall on March 25 will showcase 30 guitars tuned slightly off-key, creating a rich and full sound. The "Quantum Music Project" at NUS University Cultural Centre on March 21-22 will feature classical musicians performing music inspired by quantum physics, using software designed according to quantum technology ideas.

site_title: Singapore jails American for child porn, underage sex
summary: An American mixed martial arts instructor, Joshua Robinson, was jailed for four years in Singapore for having sex with underage girls and possession of child pornography. Robinson met two 15-year-old girls online and pressured them into sex, filming them performing sex acts before having unprotected intercourse. He also possessed over 6,000 obscene films featuring children. Robinson pleaded guilty last month and was sentenced after the court stated that the law must deter sexual predators and vulnerable young persons.

site_title: Saudi data shows economy struggling
summary: Saudi Arabia's economy is struggling to gain momentum amid low oil prices, with data showing a 0.4% forecast growth rate from the International Monetary Fund and a shrinking net foreign asset base. The government is using savings to plug a budget deficit of US$79 billion and has turned to domestic and international bond markets to slow the pace. Despite a 2.3% drop in January, the bond issuance has been partially successful, and the government is now looking to support domestic banking sector liquidity.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom lowers value of its BT stake by $2.2b euros
summary: Deutsche Telekom has written down its stake in BT Group Plc by $2.2 billion euros, valuing it at 5.1 billion euros, and placed it in a new unit for actively managed investments. The move aims to promote strategic development and entrepreneurial freedom for the assets. The company has expressed concerns over the UK's plans to separate BT's Openreach network division, which it believes would add risk and costs. The new unit, led by M&A expert Thorsten Langheim, will also include investments in Scout24 AG and Stroeer SE.

site_title: Amazon creates Bollywood movie channel for Prime subscribers
summary: Amazon is launching a paid video channel called Heera, exclusively for Prime subscribers, offering a library of Bollywood films and TV programs. The channel will be available for under $5 a month, and will cater to Indian-speaking audiences. This move is part of Amazon's expansion into niche and premium online TV networks, following the success of original series like Transparent and The Man in the High Castle. Heera will be the second channel added to Prime, after Anime Strike.

site_title: EDBI invests in US storage vendor
summary: EDBI, the investment arm of the Singapore Economic Development Board, has invested in US storage vendor Hedvig, which provides software-defined storage solutions. Hedvig will expand its development and go-to-market resources across the Asia-Pacific region with EDBI's support.
