The company, founded in 2012, will use the $21.5 million funding to enter new markets, develop end-to-end cloud and backup solutions, and grow its teams. The funding round also includes investments from Hewlett Packard Pathfinder, Atlantic Bridge Ventures, and existing investors.

images.alt_text: Chu Swee Yeok, CEO and president of EDBI, said that as cloud adoption gains traction in Asia, companies are seeking new storage solutions that could offer cloud-like agility, scalability and cost efficiency to better manage their voluminous data.

site_title: Harvard economists face Modi's censure on India GDP surprise
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi criticized Harvard economists, including Nobel laureate Amartya Sen, who predicted India's GDP would decline by 2-4% following his cash ban. However, government data showed a 7% growth rate in October-December, contradicting the economists' estimates. Modi's remarks were seen as a sarcastic dig at critics, with the opposition Congress party labeling his actions as "political desperation." Economists and analysts have questioned the accuracy of the data, citing the impact on the informal sector and India's changed method of calculating GDP.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating losses to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks ended a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US senators draft bill to boost employee private stock ownership
summary: US Senators Mark Warner and Pat Toomey are drafting a bipartisan bill, the "Encouraging Employee Ownership Act", to promote employee private stock ownership and longer-term investing. The proposed legislation would increase the threshold for triggering disclosure requirements from $5 million to $10 million, indexed to inflation every five years. The measure aims to boost capital formation and follows the SEC's shift in focus on this issue. The bill has been endorsed by Wegmans and is part of a broader effort to loosen rules believed to stifle economic growth.

site_title: Formula 1 accelerates post-Bernie expansion with new head office
summary: Formula 1 has relocated its headquarters from Knightsbridge to a new 1,950 square-metre office in St James's Market in London, marking a break from the reign of former CEO Bernie Ecclestone. The move, completed after a $4.4 billion takeover by Liberty Media Corp, aims to grow its international fan base. The new office is expected to create more value and new races in major cities worldwide, with plans to attract 400 million viewers. The relocation is seen as a significant step in Liberty Media's growth ambitions.

images.alt_text: Liberty Media will move the headquarters of its Formula 1 racing series to the St James's district in London, another break with the reign of the motorsport's former chief Bernie Ecclestone and a reflection of its growth ambitions.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint acquires Japanese shell company
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited acquired a Japanese shell company, AIA7 GK, for approximately S$2,439. The acquisition, made through its subsidiary Frasers Hospitality Trust Management, is related to asset enhancement works for ANA Crowne Plaza Kobe. The purchase has renamed the company as Frasers Hospitality Japan Trust Management GK, and it will provide management services for the property. This move is part of Frasers Hospitality Trust's expansion into the Japanese market.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment proposes to place out 38.1m new shares at S$0.161 apiece
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group proposes to issue 38.1 million new shares at S$0.161 apiece, representing a 9.75% discount to its volume-weighted average price. The estimated net proceeds will be S$5.95 million, to be used for working capital and new business investments. The placement shares will account for 9.55% of the issued share capital and 8.72% of the enlarged issued and paid-up share capital. A 3% commission will be paid to UOB Kay Hian, the placement agent.

site_title: Jardine Strategic's full-year profit up 40%, buoyed by Hongkong Land
summary: Jardine Strategic Holdings reported a 40% year-on-year jump in net profit to US$2.7 billion for the 12 months ended Dec 31, 2016, driven by a US$1.2 billion increase in Hongkong Land's investment property portfolio value. Underlying profit rose 1% to US$1.44 billion, and revenue increased 11% to US$72.4 billion. A final dividend of 21 US cents per share was declared, representing a 5% increase. The group's businesses, including Jardine Matheson and Hongkong Land, performed well, while Jardine Lloyd Thompson faced challenging markets.

site_title: Mercedes owner invests in ChargePoint to back electric-car push
summary: Daimler AG, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, has invested US$82 million in ChargePoint Inc, a leading electric car charging station provider, as part of its push into battery-powered vehicles. The investment aims to boost charging points in Germany, France, the UK, and Scandinavia, with plans to expand its electric car lineup to at least 10 models by the middle of the next decade. ChargePoint aims to gain 70% market share in individual countries within the next 10 years, citing the growing demand for electric vehicles in Europe.

site_title: Vard bags S$58.5m pelagic trawler contract
summary: Vard Holdings secured an S$58.5 million contract for the construction of a 80-metre long pelagic trawler for Research Fishing Company. The vessel, designed by Skipsteknisk, will be built and completed in Norway, with a delivery scheduled for Q3 2018. Equipped with electrically powered winches and the world's first electric fish pump, the trawler aims to reduce oil spills and pollution.

site_title: Marine Le Pen loses EU parliament immunity
summary: Marine Le Pen, French presidential candidate and leader of the National Front party, lost EU parliamentary immunity after tweeting pictures of Islamic State violence. The EU Parliament voted to lift her immunity on Thursday, following a preliminary decision by the EU legislature's legal affairs committee. The move comes amid an investigation in France for posting graphic images of IS executions in 2015, including the beheading of American journalist James Foley.

site_title: Tesla overcomes China stumbles as sales triple, pass US$1b
summary: Tesla's revenue from China tripled to over $1 billion in 2016, accounting for 15% of the company's total revenue of $7 billion. US sales more than doubled to $4.2 billion. The company introduced converters to address charging range concerns and expanded its charging points to 4,140 locations. Tesla also acquired SolarCity, with its headcount decreasing by 20% from 15,273 to 12,243 employees. The company's automotive businesses generate 97% of its revenue.

site_title: Euro-area inflation hits 2% as ECB debates policy
summary: Euro-area inflation accelerated to 2% in February, the fastest pace since January 2013, according to the European Union's statistics agency. Rising oil prices, particularly in Germany, Spain, and Italy, are driving the inflation increase. This data provides fresh arguments for an exit from the European Central Bank's monetary stimulus program, sparking debate about policy.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing expands for 6th successive month in February, albeit slower
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the sixth consecutive month in February, albeit at a slower rate, with a PMI of 50.9. The electronics sector PMI also expanded for the seventh month, albeit at a slower pace, with a 0.4 point dip. Factory output declined 0.6 points, while new orders, new exports, and imports showed slower growth. The sector is expected to strengthen in the months ahead, according to the Singapore Institute of Purchasing & Materials Management.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental's full-year profit down 38.2%
summary: Mandarin Oriental, a British hotel group, reported a 38.2% decline in full-year net profit to US$55.2 million due to weak demand in key cities such as Hong Kong, London, and Paris. The company cited ongoing travel security concerns in Paris and softer demand in Hong Kong and Jakarta as major factors. Revenue fell 1.63% to US$597.4 million, with earnings per share dropping to 4.40 US cents from 7.44 US cents the previous year. The company is proposing a final dividend of 2.50 US cents per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.980 points to 1,715.670 on Thursday, driven by a higher volume of 3.133 billion lots worth RM3.051 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 595 to 308, marking a closing higher for the shares.

site_title: Yangzijiang shares up on decent results
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings reported decent quarterly results, with a 76% revenue rise and a big jump in fourth-quarter net profit to 607.8 million yuan. The company's gross profit margin of 24.1% was praised by analysts, with OCBC Investment Research increasing its price-earnings multiples to eight times and DBS Group Research raising its target price to S$1.12. The shipbuilder is well-placed to benefit from China's state-owned enterprise reform and a shipping recovery, according to analysts.

site_title: Chinese e-commerce firm JD.com's revenue jumps 47%
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce company, reported a 47% revenue jump in the fourth quarter, exceeding expectations with 80.3 billion yuan in revenue. The company also narrowed its net loss to 1.67 billion yuan, down from 7.63 billion yuan a year earlier. JD.com plans to dispose of its stake in JD Finance, its internet finance business.

site_title: Germany, US have mutual interest in reducing trade barriers
summary: German Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries has written to US Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross, urging both countries to minimize trade barriers between them. Zypries stressed the shared interest in reducing barriers to transatlantic trade and agreed standards for the global economy. Germany's BDI industry association and business groups have also agreed that free trade is essential, with around 670,000 US jobs resulting from German investment. Zypries plans to travel to the US in May to promote free trade and discuss future US policy.

site_title: Toshiba to sell US$134m worth of shares in molding machine affiliate
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to sell almost all its stake in Toshiba Machine Co for $134 million, a 22.37% stake worth $212 million, as it scrambles for cash. The sale is part of efforts to stave off a financial collapse. Toshiba Machine, a maker of molding machines, will conduct a buyback of its shares at Thursday's closing price of 506 yen per share. The transaction will yield a 5.5 billion yen pretax profit. This sale is part of Toshiba's efforts to raise funds from smaller units within its conglomerate.

site_title: Dairy Farm FY16 profit rises 10.5% on better food margins, contributions
summary: Dairy Farm International reported a 10.5% increase in net profit to US$469.0 million in FY16, driven by improved food margins and contributions from associates and joint ventures. Earnings per share rose to 34.69 US cents, and the company proposes a final dividend of 14.5 US cents per share. Sales from subsidiaries increased 0.6% to US$11.2 billion, with a boost from health and beauty, and home furnishings segments. Despite economic uncertainty, the company plans to focus on profitable business approaches and innovate its infrastructure.

site_title: Credit Suisse CFO sees bank's growth slowing capital improvement
summary: Credit Suisse's CFO, David Mathers, says the bank faces a challenge in strengthening its capital position this year due to its push for growth and increased risk-taking. Despite a better-than-expected result, the bank has fewer assets to offload, making it harder to reach a capital ratio of 13% by 2018. Mathers notes that the bank's common equity tier one ratio is 11.6%, up from 11.4% last year, giving it flexibility to explore other options, including an initial public offering.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower after late sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares ended down on Thursday, with a late sell-off reversing a one percent surge in the opening exchanges. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.20% to 23,728.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.52% and 0.56%, respectively.

site_title: Electrolux buys US coffee machine maker Grindmaster-Cecilware for US$108m
summary: Swedish home appliance maker Electrolux has acquired US coffee machine maker Grindmaster-Cecilware for $108 million in cash. The deal, which includes around 200 staff, will broaden Electrolux's food service business and reinforce its presence in North America. Grindmaster-Cecilware, which had sales of over $65 million last year, sells products under brands such as Grindmaster, Cecilware, and Crathco. The acquisition is expected to contribute to Electrolux's growth and profitability, with the Professional Products unit being its most profitable business area.

site_title: Singapore shares surge on upbeat expectations
summary: Singapore shares rose on March 2, 2017, driven by record highs on Wall Street and expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in April. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 13.71 points higher, or 0.44%, at 3,136.48. Trading volume was 2.8 billion units worth S$1.8 billion, with some 245 counters advancing and 239 declining.

site_title: China's new banking regulator vows to tighten supervision, curb risks
summary: China's newly appointed banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, vowed to strengthen supervision of the lending sector, curb risks, and prevent a financial crisis. He emphasized the need to remove "chaos" from the regulatory system and safeguard the health of China's banking sector. Guo announced plans to tighten oversight of banks' off-balance sheet business and wealth management products, and curb the expansion of banks' property-related lending. The regulator also warned banks to "prudently" manage loans to property developers and restrict lending that may be used for property speculation.

site_title: China's Didi said to weigh raising billions in fresh capital
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's ride-hailing giant, is considering raising billions of dollars in fresh capital to buy more time to build a profitable business model. The company, backed by Apple and Tencent, has held informal talks with investors, with some advocating for more capital to develop autonomous driving technology and others arguing it has enough cash. If a deal is struck, Didi is likely to seek at least $3 billion and may hike its valuation to $37 billion, but the company has not decided whether to proceed with the fundraising.

site_title: RHB Institutional Equity Asia head leaves amid restructuring
summary: RHB Bank Bhd's Asian head of institutional equities, Lena Yong, left the bank amid a restructuring effort. The move comes as the bank reorganizes its operations to strengthen its business focus amid cost pressures. The bank's wholesale equities division has been reorganized into a single pillar, with Azura Azman taking over as Group Wholesale Equities head. This restructuring follows similar efforts by other financial firms, including CLSA Ltd and Fidelity Investments, to adapt to the changing financial industry.

site_title: Europe: Stocks wobble at open
summary: European stock markets opened with slight fluctuations, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also down 0.1%. The Paris CAC 40 rose 0.1% in the eurozone. Despite US trade uncertainty, investors remained optimistic, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: China says supports WTO after US trade threat
summary: China's foreign ministry said it supports the World Trade Organization (WTO) after the US threatened to defy WTO rulings. The US Trade Representative's office stated it will not tolerate unfair trade practices, including currency manipulation and intellectual property theft. China has urged global leaders to reject protectionism, which US President Donald Trump has championed. China's Commerce Ministry declined to comment, but the country has consistently supported the WTO since joining in 2001, saying it benefits global economic growth and is in everyone's interests.

site_title: Inflation spike puts South-east Asian central banks on watch
summary: South-east Asian central banks are on watch due to rising inflation, primarily caused by oil price surges. Consumer prices have increased in Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand, with inflation rates reaching 3.2% in Malaysia and 4% predicted for February. Central banks, such as Malaysia's Bank Negara Malaysia, are bracing for potential interest-rate hikes to combat inflation. The region's economies, including those of Indonesia and the Philippines, are expected to grow below par, supporting calls for policy easing.

site_title: Singapore must remain attractive place for work, business: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore must maintain its attractiveness to businesses and workers despite other countries lowering corporate tax rates, said Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat. He emphasized the need for a fair and progressive tax system to ensure fiscal sustainability. Heng noted the UK and US plans to lower corporate tax rates and urged careful planning to avoid future fiscal strain. The government will study options to ensure the tax system remains sustainable and attractive for businesses and workers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group Holdings expects its wealth management operations to account for 20% of its total income over the next few years, as Asia's wealth grows. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to remain an attractive place to work and do business, despite other economies lowering corporate tax rates. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) froze assets of Maybank KE Singapore customers on insider trading suspicions, while Credit Suisse Asia Pacific partnered fintech firm Mesitis to offer an aggregation platform. Singapore shares surged on upbeat expectations, driven by Wall Street record highs and potential US interest rate hikes.

site_title: UK construction picks up pace in Jan, but new orders slow
summary: UK construction growth picked up slightly in February, driven by civil engineering, but new orders slowed. The Markit/CIPS Construction PMI rose to 52.5 from 52.2 in January, despite a six-month low in housebuilding and first contraction in four months for commercial construction. Construction companies faced increased price pressures, with input prices rising at a pace just shy of January's record. Optimism among companies declined after hitting a 13-month peak in January, as the Bank of England watches for signs of a slowdown in the economy this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend rebound at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rallied 1.23% at the start of trade on Thursday, extending a rebound from the previous day and following Wall Street's gains after Donald Trump's address to Congress. The Hang Seng Index rose to 24,068.53, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also increased. The rally follows investors' positive reaction to Trump's speech, which showed signs of calming market uncertainty.

site_title: Australian dollar rangebound, NZD near 6-week lows
summary: The Australian dollar remained rangebound, trading at US$0.7658, despite the US dollar's seven-week high, due to optimism over global growth. The Aussie rose against the yen and pound, while the New Zealand dollar fell to a six-week low at US$0.7141. This follows a smaller-than-expected trade surplus and a 25-year streak of economic expansion in Australia. China's factory activity also expanded, supporting demand from Australia's largest trading partner, according to analysts.

site_title: State Bank of India Singapore offers remittance to India via ATMs
summary: State Bank of India Singapore has launched a new service allowing remittances to India via its ATMs. The service is available on all 25 ATMs in Singapore and offers 24/7 convenience, with a maximum daily remittance limit of S$3,000. The bank aims to sign up at least 5,000 more customers and plans to place ATMs in worker dormitories. The service is part of SBI's existing channels for remittance through Internet banking, kiosk, eRemit, and its six branches in Singapore.

site_title: Under Xi, wealth of China's uber-rich lawmakers grew faster than economy
summary: China's richest lawmakers, a group of 209 dollar billionaires, have seen their combined wealth grow 64% since Xi Jinping's presidency in 2013, outpacing the wider economy and stock market. Their combined wealth is close to Belgium's GDP, totaling nearly 3.5 trillion yuan (US$507 billion). Over half of these lawmakers are dollar billionaires, with an average annual increase in their wealth of 13% compared to 7.2% economic growth. The presence of rich businessmen in parliament is a calculated move by the Communist Party to ensure loyalty and vested interest in the party's success.

site_title: Malaysia frees North Korean suspect in Kim assassination
summary: Malaysia has freed a North Korean suspect, Ri Jong Chol, in the assassination of Kim Jong Nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, after almost two weeks in police detention. Attorney General Mohamed Apandi Ali stated there was insufficient evidence to charge him, and he will be deported. The decision comes a day after two women, accused of the murder, were charged.

site_title: South Korea's Lotte Duty Free says cyber attacks from China crash website
summary: South Korea's Lotte Duty Free website crashed due to cyber attacks from China, amid heightened tensions between Seoul and Beijing over the deployment of a US missile defense system in South Korea. The attacks occurred after an affiliate company in Lotte Group approved the land swap for the system, which China objects to due to its radar capabilities. China's official news agency called for boycotts of Lotte goods over the planned deployment, prompting concerns from the South Korean government about potential retaliation. The website remained down as of Thursday.

site_title: Hongkong Land Holdings posts 66% rise in FY16 profit on revaluation gain
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings reported a 66% year-over-year increase in FY16 profit to US$3.3 billion, driven by a US$2.5 billion revaluation gain. Revenue fell 3.2% to US$2 billion, while underlying profit decreased 6% to US$848 million. The company declared a final dividend of 13 US cents per share, unchanged from the previous year. Hongkong Land's commercial property portfolio contributed to the strong performance, and the company maintains a sound balance sheet with ample liquidity, positioning it for growth in its core markets in Greater China and South-east Asia.

site_title: Bond manager with US$14b loads up to guard against Frexit
summary: A bond manager at Svenska Handelsbanken AB is positioning its funds to guard against a potential "Frexit" by loading up on French bonds, citing political uncertainty. The manager, Lena Fahlen, believes Marine Le Pen's emergence as a contender in the French election will weigh on the market, despite positive views on the economy. Fahlen's fund has returned 1.3% this year, and she expects a correction in the bond markets, with interest rates and stocks potentially rising.

site_title: Nikkei hits 14-month high as yen weakens and Wall Street soars
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average reached a 14-month peak, closing 0.9% higher at 19,564.80, driven by a weak yen and Wall Street's record highs. Financial stocks gained from rising US Treasury yields, while exporters benefited from the yen's depreciation. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rose, with 28 out of 33 Tokyo subsectors gaining ground.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS shares up amid gusto over wealth management
summary: DBS Group Holdings shares rose 34 Singapore cents to S$19.16, driven by plans to grow its wealth management business to 20% of revenue over the next few years. The ambition, set by CEO Piyush Gupta, is to increase the business from its current 15% of topline income. This move aims to further diversify the bank's revenue streams.

site_title: Malaysia to cancel visa-free entry for North Koreans
summary: Malaysia will cancel visa-free entry for North Koreans, requiring them to obtain a visa starting March 6, citing national security reasons. The move comes two weeks after Kim Jong Nam's assassination at Kuala Lumpur airport, attributed to North Korean agents by South Korea and the US. The decision aims to address concerns about potential security threats.

site_title: A magnet for unsolved mysteries, Malaysians ask 'why us?'
summary: Malaysia has become a magnet for unsolved mysteries, with the country at the center of a dramatic global story after the assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong Nam with a lethal nerve agent. The case has fueled speculation about Pyongyang's involvement, but four suspects have fled to North Korea and a fifth enjoys diplomatic immunity, leaving Malaysian police struggling to close the case. The country has become accustomed to international attention, having previously been the focus of the MH370 disappearance, and many Malaysians fear their reputation will be tarnished.

images.alt_text: Following the Cold War-style assassination of Kim Jong Nam with a lethal nerve agent, Malaysians have once again found their country the unlikely focus of a dramatic global story, embellished by speculative reports and outlandish theories.

site_title: Brics bank to lend between US$2.5-3b in 2017
summary: The New Development Bank (NDB), a Brics development bank, aims to lend $2.5-3 billion in 2017, nearly doubling last year's amount. The bank has approved seven projects and plans to raise funds by issuing rupee-denominated bonds in India. The move welcomes China's "Silk Road" initiative, which aims to open new trade routes. The bank's expansion is seen as a key step in promoting economic cooperation among Brics nations.

site_title: Australia shares snap 5-day losing streak on Trump optimism, NZ up
summary: Australian shares bounced back from a five-day losing streak, rising 1.3% to 5,776.60, driven by a surge in global manufacturing activity and US President Donald Trump's pledge to boost economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached the 21,000-point mark for the first time. Trump's less combative tone and promise of fiscal stimulus supported the market, leading to gains in financials and material stocks.

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia holds key rate at 3%, says economy on the mend
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia held its key interest rate at 3% on March 2, 2017, as expected, citing optimism that the economy is recovering from a year of tepid growth. The decision, which was forecasted by nine out of 10 economists polled by Reuters, aims to support economic activity. The central bank described the monetary policy stance as "accommodative" and expressed confidence in the economy's recovery.

site_title: SEC freezes assets of Maybank KE Singapore customers on insider trading suspicions
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has frozen assets of certain Maybank KE Singapore customers suspected of insider trading. The alleged trades resulted in approximately $1.7 million in potentially illegal profits before the February 14 announcement of Softbank Group's acquisition of Fortress Investment Group. The SEC obtained a court order to freeze the assets on February 24. The exact identities of the affected customers are unknown.

site_title: Inflation spike puts Southeast Asian central banks on watch
summary: Southeast Asian central banks are on high alert as inflation spikes, driven mainly by rising fuel costs. After a year of disinflation, prices are quickly mounting across the region, prompting economists to predict faster inflation. Central banks are bracing for potential tighter monetary policy, with the Philippines potentially being the first to tighten rates this year. Despite core inflation measures remaining contained, fuel price increases pose a risk of spreading to broader prices, forcing central banks to take action to prevent growth slowdowns.

site_title: Embrace spirit of enterprise, partnership to navigate future unknowns: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a spirit of enterprise and partnership to navigate the unknown future. The government aims to facilitate an environment that encourages companies and individuals to explore new opportunities together. This includes reviewing policies to help freelancers and reviewing the ElderShield scheme for severe disability insurance. Heng stressed the need for a flexible approach, rather than a rigid roadmap, to forge forward and find new ways to address challenges. The government will continue to review and adapt policies to support Singaporeans.

site_title: Breakfast inequality: some work nine hours to buy milk and toast
summary: A Bloomberg Global City Breakfast Index reveals stark breakfast inequality worldwide, with some cities offering affordable breakfast options in under 5 minutes, while others require nearly 9 hours to afford basic staples like milk, eggs, and toast. The index ranks 129 global financial centers, showing wide affordability gaps between top and bottom cities. The disparity is particularly pronounced in Latin America, with Caracas requiring almost 9 hours to buy a basic breakfast. The findings highlight the impact of market and regulatory forces on food affordability and the potential consequences for malnutrition and social unrest.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at one-week high; won falls
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a one-week high on Thursday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rising 0.5% to 2,102.65. The gains were attributed to improved investor sentiment following US President Donald Trump's speech, which seemed promising to the economy. However, Lotte Group-related shares declined amid heightened tensions with Beijing over a US missile defense system, while cyber attacks crashed the website of Lotte Duty Free.

site_title: Brexit vote hits Deutsche Telekom profits
summary: Deutsche Telekom reported a 18% decline in net profits to €2.67 billion in 2016 due to a 2.2-billion-euro loss from its stake in Britain's BT, mainly attributed to the Brexit vote. Despite this, underlying profit grew 8% and revenues increased 5.6% to €73 billion. The company plans to maintain dividend payouts and aims to increase revenues to achieve an operating profit of €22.2 billion in 2017.

site_title: Asia: Markets chase US, Europe surge after Trump speech
summary: Asian markets surged on Thursday, following US and European stock gains, after US President Donald Trump's conciliatory speech to Congress. The speech promised a trillion-dollar infrastructure splurge and tax cuts, boosting bullish investors. Global equity markets have risen since Trump's election win, with Asian markets jumping 1.3% in Tokyo and 1.1% in Hong Kong. The dollar strengthened against the yen, and investors expect a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Japan's Abe has shot at extended PM run, and planned charter reform
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has secured a third consecutive three-year term, allowing him to potentially serve as the country's longest-serving leader. This move gives Abe a chance to revise the post-war constitution, particularly Article 9, which limits Japan's military capabilities. The move has been welcomed by conservatives, who see it as a response to China's growing regional influence. Abe's goal of revising the constitution has been a long-standing one, and his extended term may provide him with the opportunity to achieve this objective.

images.alt_text: Already rare among Group of Seven leaders for the stability of his reign, Shinzo Abe will have a shot at becoming Japan's longest-serving prime minister after his party changes a rule allowing him to serve a third consecutive three-year term.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on signs of global reflation; NZ hits 4-month high
summary: Australian shares surged 1.2% to a 7-week high, snapping a five-day losing streak, driven by signs of global reflation and President Donald Trump's pledges to boost the US economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,772.3, with financial and material stocks leading gains. China's factory activity expanded faster than expected, and copper prices touched their highest in over a week. New Zealand's benchmark index also hit a 4-month high.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise in line with overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.6% to 9,733.35 points, following overnight US market gains and President Donald Trump's measured tone in his first speech to Congress. The financial subindex gained 1.2%, while electronics subindex rose 0.6%. Pegatron and Largan Precision, suppliers to Apple, saw significant gains. The Taiwan dollar strengthened by NT$0.025 against the US dollar. The central bank governor attributed the currency's rise to foreign fund inflows, but declined to comment on potential US concerns.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after new Wall Street records
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday after Wall Street reached fresh highs on renewed expectations for President Donald Trump's economic policies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.19% to 19,623.63, while the Topix index climbed 1.24% to 1,572.34. The rally was driven by investors' optimism about Trump's policies, despite concerns over trade tensions.

site_title: Australia trade surplus shrinks, setback seen temporary
summary: Australia's trade surplus shrank to A$1.3 billion in January, missing forecasts of A$3.8 billion, due to a sharp decline in non-monetary gold exports and a rebound in imports. Shipments of iron ore and coal fell sharply, while exports to China dropped 24% in January. Despite this, commodity prices remain strong, and economists predict a current account surplus for the first time since 1975, with a potential turnaround in the trade balance.

site_title: Taiwan navy, air force to train in South China Sea due to growing security threat
summary: Taiwan's defense minister announced plans for the island's navy and air force to conduct joint training in the South China Sea due to China's growing military power in the region. The training will focus on protecting fishermen and supply transports, as well as humanitarian rescue drills. This move comes ahead of China's new defense budget, which is expected to provide insight into Beijing's intentions. Taiwan is increasingly concerned over China's military threat, with Beijing having flown military jets over the South China Sea and sailed its aircraft carrier near Taiwan in recent months.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang shares galvanised by decent results
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings reported a 76% revenue rise and a 607.8 million yuan net profit in the fourth quarter, driven by a leap in other income due to terminated shipbuilding contracts. The company's full-year profit declined 29% to 1.75 billion yuan, but its gross profit margin improved to 24.1%. Analysts have increased their price targets, citing the company's superior execution ability, healthy margins, and solid balance sheet, with DBS Group Research raising its target price to S$1.12 and reiterating a "buy" call.

site_title: Japan PM Abe says no defence budget ceiling as 1% to GDP
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reaffirmed his commitment to increasing military spending to 1% of Japan's GDP, rejecting a ceiling on defense budget. Abe's government has already eased curbs on military exports and allowed troops to fight overseas. Japan's defense spending will rise for a fifth straight year to a record 5.1 trillion yen, aimed at countering North Korea's nuclear threats and China's moves in the East China Sea. The move contrasts with US President Donald Trump's proposed 10% increase in Pentagon spending.

site_title: French presidential candidate Macron unveils 'anti-nepotism' agenda
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron has unveiled an 'anti-nepotism' agenda, promising to ban parliamentarians from employing family members and reduce conflicts of interest. This comes as rival Francois Fillon faces charges over a fake jobs scandal, which could lead to a trial. Macron's move is seen as a strategic advantage, as analysts believe he or far-right candidate Marine le Pen could benefit from Fillon's woes. Macron's agenda aims to end nepotism in government, following a poll showing only one in four French people support Fillon's remaining bid for presidency.

site_title: Singapore shares open 25 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 25.2 points to 3,147.97, driven by gains in Wall Street following US President Donald Trump's speech to Congress. The rally marked a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data. The key market indicators show 53 million shares worth S$85 million were traded, with 104 counters up and 27 down.
