The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: BP targets US$40 break-even oil price to reassure investors
summary: BP Plc has set a target break-even oil price of around $40 per barrel by 2021, down from $60 this year, in an effort to reassure investors on the company's growth outlook and finances. The reduction in break-even price is due to BP's plan to keep capital spending at $17 billion per year and aims to raise output by 5% annually. CEO Bob Dudley is seeking to return BP to growth after a downturn, and the company is targeting returns of over 10%.

site_title: BP buys Clean Energy's US green gas business for US$155m
summary: BP agreed to buy Clean Energy Fuels Corp's US biomethane business for $155 million, expanding its US gas supply portfolio and shifting towards less carbon-intensive projects. The deal includes biomethane production sites and supply contracts, with Clean Energy signing a long-term supply contract with BP. Clean Energy captures and processes biomethane gas from landfill waste sites for use as a transport fuel. The acquisition is part of BP's efforts to diversify its energy sources and reduce its carbon footprint.

site_title: China warns against cyber "battlefield" in internet strategy
summary: China's government emphasizes the importance of strengthening cyber capabilities as part of its military modernization. The country warns that the internet should not become a "new battlefield" and calls for greater cooperation among nations in governing the internet. China also seeks to rectify "imbalances" in setting cyber standards globally, particularly through its "Great Firewall" online censorship mechanism. The government's stance reflects China's growing recognition of the internet's strategic significance and its efforts to assert its influence in shaping global cyber governance.

site_title: Key US inflation measure hits fastest pace since 2012
summary: US inflation hit its fastest monthly pace in nearly four years in January, with the Personal Consumption Expenditures price index growing at an annual rate of 1.9%. This is just below the Federal Reserve's 2% target, and may boost expectations for interest rate hikes. The increase was driven by a 0.4% jump in the PCE price index, the largest since February 2013. The core PCE index, excluding food and fuel, also rose 0.3%, beating economists' expectations. The move could prompt the Fed to raise interest rates this month.

site_title: Opec members must lower costs to compete with shale, says Nigeria's oil minister
summary: Nigeria's oil minister, Emmanuel Ibe Kachikwu, stated that Opec members must lower production costs to compete with shale producers. He expressed confidence in an output reduction agreement agreed in November, which will help hold oil prices. Nigeria's economy contracted 1.5% in 2016 due to lower oil receipts, highlighting the need for Opec to adjust its production levels.

site_title: Q&M's FY16 profit more than doubled to S$28.3m
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a net profit of S$28.3 million for FY16, more than doubling from the previous year. The gain was largely due to a one-time S$23.1 million from the spin-off of Aidite Technology. Profit before tax rose 111% to S$35.5 million, excluding one-time expenses. Revenue from dental and medical clinics increased 21% to S$118.7 million, driven by new acquisitions and revenue contributions from China.

site_title: China appoints Li Yunpeng as Sinopec deputy manager
summary: China has appointed Li Yunpeng, 56, as deputy general manager and deputy party secretary of Sinopec Group, a state-owned oil major. Li previously worked at China Ocean Shipping Company and was removed from Cosco's management after a reorganisation. The appointment aims to strengthen Sinopec's leadership and management.

site_title: Hotel Grand Central posts lower FY16 profit on absence of FY15 gain
summary: Hotel Grand Central reported a 35% year-on-year decline in full-year net profit for FY16, mainly due to a higher base in FY15 from the sale of Hotel Grand Chancellor. The company's operation profits were stronger, but the higher base offset gains from the sale of Hotel Grand Chancellor Surfers Paradise and foreign exchange gains.

site_title: German factories humming, growth near 6-year high
summary: German manufacturing expanded at its strongest rate in nearly six years in February, according to a survey, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 56.8. This marks the 27th consecutive month of growth, suggesting a strengthening in overall economic growth in the first quarter. The growth rate is likely to rise to 0.6% in the first quarter, with companies reporting increased demand from domestic and export customers. However, cost pressures intensified, with input price inflation accelerating to its highest in nearly six years.

site_title: ISR Capital posts S$8.3m loss for FY16 on impairment loss on debt securities
summary: ISR Capital reported a net loss of S$8.3 million for FY16, primarily due to an impairment loss on debt securities of S$3.7 million and trade receivables of S$2.4 million. This marked a significant shift from the previous year's profit of S$0.7 million. Revenue declined 88.3% to S$0.3 million, mainly due to the absence of management consultancy fees earned by a subsidiary in FY16.

site_title: Petrobras, Total sign US$2.25b oil production venture
summary: Petrobras and Total SA have signed a US$2.25 billion joint venture, involving the sale of assets and stakes in oilfields and thermal power stations. Petrobras will receive US$1.6 billion in cash and has the option to access a US$400 million credit facility from Total. This agreement is aimed at restructuring Petrobras' operations and reducing debt. The deal will see Total acquire a majority stake in the venture, with Petrobras retaining a minority stake. The transaction is expected to help Petrobras improve its financial stability.

site_title: UK consumer credit growth slows for a second month, mortgage approvals rise
summary: British consumers borrowed £1.416 billion in January, a slowdown from the previous month, with the annual growth rate at 10.3%. This marks the first back-to-back slowdown since 2012. Foreign investors sold British government bonds at the fastest pace in nearly three years, while mortgage approvals rose to 69,928 in January, the highest since February last year. The Bank of England expects growth to slow in 2017 due to rising inflation.

site_title: Citic Envirotech doubles profit for FY2016
summary: CITIC Envirotech reported a doubling of its net profit to S$99.3 million for FY2016, up from S$48.3 million in FY2015. Revenue jumped 62.1% to S$544.6 million, driven by improved performance of its engineering business. However, shares closed 1.5 Singapore cents down at S$0.77.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: North Korea pours scorn on 'absurd' claims over nerve agent
summary: North Korea has rejected claims that a highly lethal nerve agent was used to kill Kim Jong-Nam, half-brother of the North Korean leader, in Malaysia. The North Korean government, citing unidentified experts, called the claim "absurd" and accused South Korea and the US of running a smear campaign. North Korea claims the victim, identified as Kim Chol, was unaffected by the VX agent and that the US is introducing chemical weapons into South Korea. The US and South Korea have denied any involvement, with Washington describing the allegations as a "smear campaign" aimed at provoking a nuclear war.

site_title: China manufacturing grows modestly in March: Caixin
summary: China's manufacturing activity expanded slightly in March, with a Caixin Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) figure of 51.2, down from 51.7 in February. This marks steady but slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy. Despite this, concerns remain about the outlook for world trade due to US President Donald Trump's protectionist policies. The Chinese economy's one-year growth outlook remains strong, but signs of a weakening economy have started to emerge, with downward pressure potentially increasing in the second quarter.

site_title: Treasure International raises stake in IHC
summary: Treasure International Holdings acquired 6.36 million shares of International Healthway Corporation (IHC) at 10.6 Singapore cents apiece, increasing its stake to 62.6%. This comes as Treasure is a direct wholly owned subsidiary of developer OUE Limited, which has launched a takeover bid for IHC.

site_title: Keppel Reit's manager gets new CEO
summary: Keppel Reit's manager announced the appointment of Tan Swee Yiow as the new CEO, subject to regulatory approval, effective March 20. Tan, 56, is president of Keppel Land's Singapore operations and head of Keppel Land Hospitality Management. He will take over from outgoing CEO Jesline Goh, who left the manager to pursue other career opportunities. Audrey Chin, chairman of the manager, praised Tan's familiarity with Keppel Reit and expertise in the real estate sector, citing his potential to drive growth for the Reit.

site_title: UK factory growth slows, but still set for strong first quarter
summary: Britain's factory sector grew more slowly than expected in February, with the manufacturing PMI at 54.6, below the median forecast of 55.6. Despite this, the sector still appears set to contribute to a strong economy in the first quarter, with output growth expected to reach 1.5%. The slowdown was attributed to slower growth in new orders and backlogs, but optimism among firms, job creation, and rising export orders suggested a mild slowdown. The UK economy is expected to continue its growth momentum despite rising inflation and weaker consumer spending power.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's business confidence rose in the second quarter, driven by optimism in services and wholesale trade sectors. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that US-China tensions could put Singapore in a difficult situation. A study found female directors on SGX-listed companies earned 56.8% of male counterparts' remuneration. CITIC-PRUDENTIAL Life Insurance received approval to set up a branch in Sichuan province. The Singapore Exchange slapped a 'trade with caution' warning on ISR Capital's shares after lifting its trading suspension.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed despite STI's jump as traders wait for Wall St direction
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 26.16 points to 3,122.77 on March 1, 2017, despite a mixed trading session. The STI had fallen 41 points in the previous three sessions. The index's gain was driven by big gains in the Jardine stable and Keppel Corp. Trading was cautious due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's economic and trade policies, with traders waiting for Wall Street's reaction to his address to Congress.

site_title: Europe: Stocks forge ahead at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Wednesday, driven by investors' positive reaction to US President Donald Trump's speech to Congress, which provided some reassurance despite a lack of detail on his proposed spending and tax cuts. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.5%, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.1% and 0.7%, respectively. The rising dollar also contributed to the market's upbeat tone, with traders awaiting US Federal Reserve interest rate decisions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up after four-day sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares rose on Wednesday after a four-day sell-off, driven by a forecast-beating reading on Chinese factory activity. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.15%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.16% and 0.38% respectively. This boost came as traders brushed off new US threats to extend the stocks rally, focusing on positive economic indicators.

site_title: Zico's asset managment unit gets nod to start operations
summary: ZICO Holdings Inc announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Zico Asset Management, has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to start operations as a registered fund management company. The asset management arm plans to serve up to 30 qualified investors with assets of up to S$250 million. Zico Asset Management will initially focus on serving qualified investors and managing assets within the specified limits.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says yields to fall in H2 due to competition, weak ringgit
summary: Malaysia Airlines expects a decline in passenger yields in the second half of 2017 due to increased competition and a weak ringgit. The airline aims to offset this by reducing costs, with a goal of 400 million ringgit (S$127.032 million) in cost savings for 2017. The airline plans to maintain its focus on cost control to return to profitability by 2018.

site_title: Singapore startup will wash and press your cash
summary: Singapore-based startup Without A Trace has launched the world's first fully-automated cash-cleaning service, washing and pressing banknotes in half the time required for traditional methods. The service, founded by Ben Krawber, uses sustainable cleaning agents to remove 99.9999% of germs and contaminants from physical money. Customers can arrange for pick-up and delivery through the company's mobile app, with prices starting at 88.8 Singapore cents per S$100. The service also accepts bitcoins and is targeting offshore institutions and high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.920 points to 1,697.690 on Wednesday, closing higher. The index saw a gain in volume with 3.023 billion lots worth RM2.331 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 546 to 360, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: SIA introducing changes to KrisFlyer redemptions
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is introducing changes to its KrisFlyer frequent-flyer programme, effective March 23. Fuel and insurance surcharges will no longer apply to KrisFlyer redemptions, but a 15% discount on miles for online bookings will be removed. Additionally, fuel and insurance surcharges will be folded into base airfares, starting from March 28 and expected to be completed by May 2017, resulting in a simplified fare structure for customers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China central bank injects 413.85b yuan of liquidity in Feb, down sharply from Jan
summary: China's central bank injected 413.85 billion yuan in February, down 35% from January, to rein in rapid credit growth under its "prudent and neutral" policy. This follows a 26% drop in January from December. The People's Bank of China aims to cool debt growth without hurting economic growth, adopting a modest tightening bias.

site_title: UK watchdog proposes IPO research shake-up to level playing field
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority proposes changes to the IPO research process to create a level playing field. Under new rules, investors in planned stock market flotations will have access to independent research sooner, and analysts at banks not involved in the IPO will have more access to company information to produce research comparable to that from banks connected to the float. The aim is to increase transparency and fairness in the IPO process.

site_title: Fewer building deals hit Low Keng Huat's Q4 earnings
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singapore property developer, reported an 80% plunge in net profit to S$6.3 million in Q4 2017, driven by a decrease in third-party construction contracts. This marks a significant decline from the S$32.1 million in net profit reported a year ago. The company's Q4 earnings were impacted by a decline in building deals, resulting in a substantial decrease in revenue.

site_title: CITIC-Prudential Life gets green light to set up Sichuan branch
summary: CITIC-Prudential Life Insurance Company has received approval from the China Insurance Regulatory Commission to set up a new branch in Sichuan province, its fifth expansion in China. The move aims to capitalize on the province's growing demand for life insurance products, which increased by 43% in 2016. With this addition, CITIC-PRU Life will have a presence in the top 10 provinces in China, further solidifying its position in the Chinese life insurance market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.360 points to 1750.690. A total of 129.89 million lots were traded, worth RM35.79 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 162 to 49.

site_title: Tie-ups, strategic investments more likely than merger for SGX, observers say
summary: Market observers downplay speculation of a potential merger between Singapore Exchange (SGX) and parties including Nasdaq and CME Group, citing a more likely outcome of commercial tie-ups or narrowly targeted acquisitions. SGX shares closed 0.1% lower on Thursday following reports of potential collaborations, stake sales, and mergers.

site_title: China said to order steel, aluminum curbs to fight pollution
summary: China has ordered curbs on steel and aluminum output in 28 northern cities during the winter heating season to combat pollution. The cuts include halving steel capacity in four major cities, including Tangshan in Hebei province, and reducing output in other cities such as Shijiazhuang and Anyang. The move aims to reduce emissions and improve air quality in northern China.

site_title: Trump ups pressure on global trade 'cheaters'
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced two executive orders aimed at tackling the country's substantial trade deficit, estimated at nearly $50 billion a month. The orders task officials to identify "cheaters" responsible for the deficit and target countries that misalign their currencies or fail to enforce trade agreements. The moves are seen as a protectionist warning shot ahead of Trump's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping. The US will also review trade duties on products subsidized by foreign governments or dumped on the US market, with the goal of recovering lost revenue.

site_title: The stories we tell
summary: Storytelling has become increasingly important in Singapore, with events like Story Slam Singapore and Human Library Singapore gaining popularity. These events provide a platform for people to share their personal stories, fostering empathy and connection among participants. Research suggests that stories can shape our understanding of ourselves and the world, influencing our perceptions and actions. Effective storytelling can also be used to convey facts, emotions, and values, making it a powerful tool for personal growth and social change. By sharing their stories, individuals can break down barriers, challenge biases, and create a sense of community.

site_title: Snap IPO may lead pack of tech 'unicorns'
summary: Snap Inc., the parent company of Snapchat, is set to debut on the market as early as this week, potentially sparking a wave of initial public offerings (IPOs) from other "unicorns" in the tech sector, including Uber, Airbnb, Palantir, Dropbox, and Spotify. These companies, valued at over $1 billion, are likely to follow in Snap's footsteps, with some, such as Uber and Airbnb, already considering their IPOs. The successful IPO of Snap could lead to a surge in listings from other tech unicorns, including Palantir, which has expressed interest in going public to give employees access to their equity compensation.

site_title: Cosco (Qidong) Offshore secures vessel contract with European buyer
summary: Cosco (Qidong) Offshore has secured a vessel contract with a European buyer to build an offshore heavy lift vessel with a 3,000-tonne crane capacity. The contract's value remains undisclosed. Cosco (Qidong) Offshore, a subsidiary of Cosco Shipyard Group, will build the vessel. The two parties agreed to keep the contract details confidential.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on weak miners, Wall Street cues; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.12% on Monday, with mining stocks accounting for most of the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 6.85 points to 5,746.7. BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals fell 2.9%, 1.8%, and 3.0% respectively, amid concerns about Chinese steel and iron ore demand. New Zealand's benchmark index also declined 0.16%. The decline was partly attributed to US President Donald Trump's failure to pass a healthcare bill, raising questions about his economic agenda.

site_title: Philippines rescues 3 Malaysians held hostage by Abu Sayyaf
summary: Philippine troops rescued three Malaysians held captive by Abu Sayyaf rebels on Jolo island, marking the second such operation in four days. The three men were kidnapped eight months ago from a ship. Their rescue follows the release of two other Malaysians held hostage at sea last week. The operation is part of efforts to combat the notorious Islamist group, which has been linked to extremist groups in the Middle East. The group's kidnappings have been a national embarrassment for the Philippine government, which is concerned about the potential for Islamic State cells in the country's restive south.

site_title: Singapore SMEs slightly more optimistic: index
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) have become slightly more optimistic, with the SBF-DP SME Index rising 0.6 points to 50.4, indicating a slight expectation of growth in the next six months. This improvement follows a score of 49.8 in the previous quarter, which marked the first time the index had fallen below 50. The slight increase suggests a slight shift in sentiment, despite the ongoing sluggish outlook for sales and profits.

site_title: Singapore shares finish weaker after loss in Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day at 3,126.88, down 16.02 points, following a triple-digit loss in Dow futures. The decline came after the Trump administration failed to push ahead with healthcare reform, raising concerns about its ability to pass its upcoming budget. The STI had previously rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US spy agencies may have picked up Trump communications: lawmaker
summary: US spy agencies may have intercepted Donald Trump's communications, according to a Republican lawmaker. Devin Nunes, who worked on Trump's transition team, claims Trump's communications were swept up in intelligence gathering on suspected foreign agents late last year. However, Nunes denies evidence that President Barack Obama ordered surveillance or that Trump was the target. The claims contradict Trump's assertions that Obama ordered surveillance on him.

site_title: Shell, Anadarko likely to let Texas joint venture lapse
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc and Anadarko Petroleum Corp may let their 10-year joint venture in the Permian Basin of Texas expire, allowing each company to drill and develop at their own pace. The agreement expires this summer, and a potential breakup would give Shell an opportunity to prove its ability to grow on its own in the largest American shale oil field. Shell aims to boost its North American shale output by 140,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the next three years, with the Permian being a key focus.

site_title: Electronics ban on flights not a longterm solution: IATA boss
summary: IATA director general Alexandre de Juniac says a ban on laptops and tablets in flight cabins is not a long-term solution to security threats. The current measures are "not acceptable" and create "severe commercial distortions." He called for governments to work with the industry to find a more effective way to keep flying secure. The ban, which affects nine airlines, was implemented after the US and Britain banned electronic devices from flights to certain Middle Eastern countries. De Juniac criticized the lack of advance consultation with the airline industry and the need for more effective screening at airport checkpoints.

site_title: Didi Chuxing said to be weighing US$6b SoftBank-backed investment
summary: Chinese ride-sharing giant Didi Chuxing is considering a $6 billion investment backed by SoftBank Group Corp, which could dilute existing investors including Apple Inc and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. The company, valued at $34 billion, needs to balance the interests of its over 100 investors while preparing for its battle with Uber and Alphabet in driverless technology development. The investment, potentially from SoftBank's $100 billion Vision Fund, could aid Didi's growth amidst regulatory uncertainty and a potential delay in its initial public offering.

site_title: Soaring house prices lock Australia's homeless out
summary: Homelessness in Australia is on the rise due to unaffordable housing, despite the country's strong economy. House prices have soared, ranking cities like Sydney and Melbourne among the world's least affordable. The number of people seeking homelessness services reached a record high of 279,000 in 2015-16. Experts attribute the increase to the lack of affordable housing, with many struggling to afford a roof over their heads. Governments are taking action to fund more social and inexpensive residential projects to address the issue.

site_title: Hooked on Asia
summary: Citi's Asia-Pacific CEO Francisco Aristeguieta highlights the region's diverse growth potential, driven by rapid wealth creation and intra-regional trade. He notes the unique situation of China's oversized influence, which has generated benefits for many countries through trade and geopolitics. Aristeguieta's experience in Latin America contrasts with the diverse and dynamic Asia-Pacific, where monarchies, single-party systems, and democracies coexist. He sees opportunities for growth and success in the region, but also acknowledges the need to work with China's significant influence.

site_title: Airbus to run parcel-delivery drone trial, and maybe one for flying taxis in S'pore
summary: Airbus plans to conduct an unmanned parcel-delivery drone trial in Singapore, with the possibility of extending it to transporting passengers. The trial details will be revealed in the coming months. The city-state's Ministry of Transport is also exploring the use of human-carrying drones as a mode of transport. This move comes after Singapore's Ministry of Transport discussed potential partnerships with drone companies.

site_title: American Airlines buys China Southern stake as traffic booms
summary: American Airlines has reached a deal to buy a $200 million minority stake in China Southern, the largest airline in China, as part of a strategic cooperation. The agreement, subject to regulatory approvals, aims to increase traffic between the US and China through code sharing and staff exchanges. The deal reflects the growing business between the two countries, with Chinese airlines accounting for over 60% of assigned flight routes between China and the US. The partnership could help American capture more market share and gain access to China's large and growing market.

site_title: One pirouette on stage, a giant leap for women in ballet
summary: Ballet choreography is seeing a shift towards more women creating works, with Ashley Bouder's The Ashley Bouder Project showcasing three world premieres choreographed by women. The evening featured Bouder dancing in her own works, as well as in those of Liz Gerring and Susan Stroman. While some of the choreographers relied on conventional clichés, Gerring's Duet stood out as the most experimental and remarkable piece of the evening, featuring Bouder and Sara Mearns dancing to music composed by women. The event marked a breakthrough for women in ballet, following in the footsteps of pioneering choreographers like Wendy Whelan, who has successfully transitioned to modern dance.

site_title: UK laptop ban on flights to be introduced 'in days'
summary: Britain's ban on laptops and tablet computers in the cabin on flights from several Middle Eastern and North African countries will be introduced "in the coming days". The move follows the US government's warning of extremist plans to target passenger jets with bombs hidden in electronic devices. The ban affects flights from Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, and Turkey, and has been communicated to the 14 airlines impacted. Passengers are advised to contact their airlines for information on the new measure's effective date.

site_title: Japan secures reprieve from currency manipulation charge
summary: Japan secured a reprieve from US charges of currency manipulation during the G-20 finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Germany. Japan's trade surplus with the US is a concern, and the US may push for currency adjustment to reduce the deficit. The US has threatened border taxes on certain Japanese imports and US President Donald Trump has accused Japan of exploiting a weak yen. Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso lobbied with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to abide by G-7 and G-20 agreements on currency policy.

site_title: MVN raises stake in Vard
summary: MVN Asset Management Limited, a London-based asset manager, has increased its stake in shipbuilder Vard Holdings by buying 1.5 million shares at S$0.245, raising its stake to 6.06%. This is above the S$0.24 final offer price set by Fincantieri, Vard's parent company.

site_title: US SEC votes to shorten securities settlement time to two days
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) voted unanimously to shorten the time it takes for stock and bond trades to settle from three business days to two business days, effective in early September. The decision has wide support from Wall Street.

site_title: KSH bags S$146m contract to build research building for NUS
summary: KSH Holdings, a construction and property firm, has secured a S$145.7 million contract from the National University of Singapore (NUS) to build a 16-floor research building. The project, expected to start on April 1, 2017, and complete within 24 months, will contribute positively to KSH's financial performance from FY2018. The contract lifts KSH's order book to over S$360 million.

site_title: Newly restored shrine at Jesus's tomb reopened in Jerusalem
summary: The ornate shrine surrounding Jesus's tomb at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem was reopened after a $3.7-million renovation led by the church's three main Christian denominations. The shrine, which includes a 19th-century edicule, was painstakingly restored to its former glory, featuring a warm reddish-yellow colouring. The ceremony marked the end of months of delicate restoration work, which was delayed due to disputes between the Greek Orthodox, Armenian, and Roman Catholic denominations sharing custody of the church. The shrine's reopening comes after decades of renovations.

images.alt_text: The ornate shrine surrounding what is believed to be Jesus's tomb was reopened at a ceremony in Jerusalem on Wednesday following months of delicate restoration work.

site_title: Why not just increase water prices only for the rich?
summary: A Singaporean academic argues that increasing water prices, rather than just targeting the wealthy, is a more effective way to encourage water conservation. Currently, water prices have not been adjusted since 2000, despite a 30% increase in prices over 17 years. The academic suggests that a "users pay" principle should apply to all goods and services, including water, to avoid wastage and encourage conservation. However, they also acknowledge that this approach may exacerbate income inequality and propose alternative solutions, such as taxing the rich and promoting equality.

site_title: Can't meditate? Just l-e-t g-o . . .
summary: A writer attempts to meditate, but finds it challenging, often drifting into thoughts of the past or future. Seeking organization and supervision, they join a meditation studio, Mndfl, with locations in NYC. The writer attends sound baths and guided meditation classes, initially struggling to focus, but eventually finding moments of calm and clarity. They report that meditation helps them redirect their thoughts and emotions, with one class even inducing a sense of synesthesia. The writer finds that even short, at-home meditations can be beneficial, and notes the studio's flexibility and variety of classes.

site_title: Washington urges North Korea to pardon US student
summary: The US State Department urged North Korea to pardon American student Otto Warmbier, who was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor for stealing a propaganda banner. The US also called for special amnesty and regular consular access to Warmbier. This comes as US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is visiting Japan, South Korea, and China to discuss North Korea's nuclear ambitions. The US has previously used the detention of US citizens as a bargaining tool, with former presidents Bill Clinton and James Clapper visiting North Korea to negotiate their release.

site_title: SIA's load factor up 3.2 percentage points in February
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger load factor increased 3.2 percentage points to 80.6% in February, driven by promotional activities. Passenger carriage rose 1.3% year-over-year, while capacity decreased 2.8%. The airline attributed the improvement to boosted promotional efforts, except in the South West Pacific region, where demand outpaced capacity growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Laptop ban sparks ire among Mideast travellers
summary: A laptop ban for flights to the US and Britain from major Middle Eastern hubs has sparked frustration among travelers. The ban, set to begin March 25, requires passengers to check in devices larger than smartphones, citing intelligence on explosives planted in electronic devices. The US ban affects nine airlines from eight countries, while the British ban targets flights from six countries. Critics argue the measure is an "absurd" restriction and will have a negative impact on tourism, particularly in Tunisia. Some experts also suggest the ban may be driven by business interests, as US airlines are expected to benefit from the restrictions.

images.alt_text: Travellers across the Middle East expressed frustration Wednesday at a ban on large electronic devices for flights to the United States and Britain that has sparked confusion and speculation.

site_title: Decoding the millennial generation
summary: Garena, a South-East Asia startup, has a workforce predominantly made up of millennials, with 27-year-old Jay Ng being the middle-aged representative of the group. The company, valued as the most valuable in the region, has a youthful and loose-limbed workforce of 5,000 employees, with 550 based in Singapore. Garena's office culture, characterized by T-shirts and bright primary colors, reflects the company's focus on authenticity and embracing the millennial generation's values.

images.alt_text: Above: Garena's open plan office at its sprawling campus at Fusionopolis.
A casual dress code is the norm.
Napping is encouraged.

"Millennials don't want to be managed; they want to be inspired... The feeling that you've found something that you're uniquely qualified to do is a great source of satisfaction in life." - Nick Nash, 38

site_title: Virtu offers US$1.3b for KCG to create trading leader
summary: Virtu Financial Inc offered a US$1.3 billion bid to acquire KCG Holdings Inc, aiming to create a trading leader. The takeover proposal, valued at US$18.50 to US$20 per share, comes amid declining algorithmic trading revenue and increased costs. KCG's predecessor firm, Knight Capital Group Inc, was acquired by Virtu in 2012. The deal may help sustain margins and reduce competition in the market, with other firms potentially seeking acquisitions.

site_title: Yang Kee Logistics completes acquisition of Australian firm Axima
summary: Yang Kee Logistics has completed the acquisition of Australian freight management firm Axima, driven by a desire to expand its freight business in developed markets. The deal, supported by International Enterprise Singapore, is expected to boost revenue by S$150 million and improve overall profitability. The combined group will have over 650 employees across 11 countries, marking a significant expansion of Yang Kee's operations.

site_title: Ex-Taiwan President Ma indicted for alleged leak of probe detail
summary: Ex-Taiwan President Ma Ying-Jeou was indicted for allegedly leaking details of a judicial investigation and violating personal information protections. The former leader faces possible 3-year prison sentences for each violation. Ma, 66, maintains his innocence and has been facing several investigations since leaving office in May. The indictment follows a 2013 incident where Ma was questioned about leaking investigation details involving legislators.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rally to over 20-month high; won edges down
summary: South Korean stocks reached a 20-month high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) up 0.5% at 2,127.60 points. Foreign investors continued to buy Kospi shares, with net purchases of 179.9 billion won. The won edged down against the US dollar, while US Treasury bond futures edged up. The market is expected to gain further towards the end of March due to strong earnings from local exporters. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting will kick off later in the day.

site_title: Singaporeans helping to make the world a better place
summary: Singaporeans are leaving their comfort zone to make a positive impact in the world, with some moving abroad to work in developing countries. They are driven by a desire for meaning and fulfillment, often after feeling unfulfilled in their previous careers. Examples include Bernard Lee, who mentored young Vietnamese locals, and Sarah Tan, who worked in microfinance in Malawi. These individuals found new joy and purpose in their new lives, building relationships and contributing to their communities. Despite challenges, they have benefited more from their experiences than they have contributed, and they often downplay their heroic efforts.

site_title: Emma Watson is Belle of the ball
summary: Emma Watson stars as Belle in Disney's live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast, set for release on Friday. The film boasts a star-studded cast, including Dan Stevens, Kevin Kline, and Emma Thompson, and has generated significant expectations after a record-breaking 92 million views on its trailer. The movie's production and marketing budget was $300 million, and analysts project a $150 million opening weekend, making it the fastest-selling family film in history. The film has also sparked controversy over its casting choices, including a gay character and a revealing photo shoot by Watson.

site_title: Redesigning travel
summary: Airbnb co-founder Joe Gebbia discusses how his company is revolutionizing travel, shifting it back to its roots of community and shared experiences. With over 80 million users in 2016, Airbnb has surpassed major hotel chains in global reach and valuation. The company's success stems from its design-driven approach, focusing on building trust between strangers through user-centric features and services. Despite initial resistance, Airbnb has adapted to local regulations and collaborated with governments to create fair models for short-term accommodations. The company aims to expand beyond accommodation, introducing Trips, a service that allows users to book experiences, simplifying the travel process.

site_title: A growing disconnect between the market and economy
summary: US stocks are being supported by expectations of a strong economy and tax cuts under the Trump administration, despite a disconnect between the market and economic reality. The Federal Reserve has rushed to signal interest rate hikes, but some observers believe it is "behind the curve" and may need to scramble to play catch-up. The Atlanta Federal Reserve's forecast of Q1 US GDP growth at 1.2% is seen as weak, but markets may view it as a disappointment, potentially leading to a continued rally in stocks. This disconnect between the market and economy raises concerns about the sustainability of current stock prices.

site_title: Singapore's big businesses overtake small firms as job creators
summary: Singapore's larger companies created more jobs last year than small and medium-sized businesses, adding a net 4,300 jobs, compared to 2,100 by smaller firms. This marks the first time since 2013 that bigger companies led job creation. The economy struggled with sluggish domestic demand and a slump in global trade, leading to a six-year high in unemployment. The Ministry of Manpower reported that smaller businesses, which account for 70% of employment, were not immune to the economic slowdown.

site_title: No investor credit bubble in Australia housing, says Morrison
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison said there's no investor credit bubble in the country's housing market, despite the nation's largest bank tightening its lending criteria. The issue in housing affordability is the mismatch between supply and demand, not speculative borrowing. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia has raised its loan to value ratio to 90% and increased interest rates to curb investor lending. The government is working to address supply challenges and put downward pressure on rising prices, with new measures set to be announced in the May budget.

site_title: China ramping up controls on low-quality coal imports
summary: China is imposing stricter controls on low-quality coal imports due to concerns over smog and overcapacity. The controls, announced by a government official, aim to protect the domestic market from low-quality imports. The move may unsettle global miners and traders, who have benefited from months of high demand for Chinese coal. Delays in processing imports could further constrain supply and drive up domestic prices, undermining government efforts to keep prices stable.

site_title: Bitcoin miners signal revolt amid sluggish blockchain
summary: Bitcoin miners are signaling a potential revolt amid a congested blockchain, with influential members backing a controversial solution called Bitcoin Unlimited to ease congestion. The blockchain is experiencing a fivefold increase in unverified transactions, forcing users to pay high fees for speedier confirmations. Bitcoin Unlimited supporters, including Antpool's Wu Jihan and Roger Ver, aim to reach 60-70% miner support to activate the upgrade, while critics argue it leaves bitcoin vulnerable to governments and large organizations.

site_title: Hot stock: Property counters jump on news of cooling measure tweaks
summary: Singapore's property counters surged after tweaks to the cooling measures were announced. The holding period for seller's stamp duty was shortened to three years, and the rate was lowered by four percentage points. The Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework will no longer apply to mortgage equity withdrawal loans with 50% or below LTV ratios. These changes take effect March 11, with current rates and limits remaining in place. This move boosted FTSE ST Real Estate Holding and Development Index by 2.5% to 827.74, with companies like Wing Tai and UOL Group seeing significant gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.34 points to 1,721.92. The index saw 3.78 billion lots traded worth RM3.08 billion, with 497 losers compared to 473 gainers.

site_title: Trek 2000 International to divest 19% stake in subsidiary
summary: Trek 2000 International has agreed to sell its 19% stake in Racer Technology to CEO Koh Kee Joo Willy for S$3 million. The disposal is expected to result in a loss of US$736,000. Trek plans to focus on its core electronics and technology business, using the proceeds to capitalize on business opportunities and enhance shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Trek 2000 International has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell its 19 per cent stake in Racer Technology to Racer's chief executive for S$3 million.

site_title: STI at 18-month high amid cautious trading
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 13.8 points to an 18-month high of 3,147.15 on Monday, driven by a cautious trading session ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, where an interest rate hike is expected. Property stocks lost upward momentum, with City Developments being the exception, while OCBC Investment Research believes the government's recent tweaks to property regulations may provide some support to declining home prices.

site_title: Wood Group acquires Amec in £2.2b all-share deal
summary: Wood Group Plc agreed to acquire Amec Foster Wheeler Plc in an all-share deal valued at approximately £2.23 billion. The acquisition, which will see Wood Group shareholders owning around 44% of the combined group, aims to cut costs, extend business scope, and become more competitive. The deal is expected to be accretive on an adjusted earnings-per-share basis for both companies in the first full year, with Wood Group putting pretax cost synergies at a "run rate" of at least £110 million per year. The acquisition was unanimously recommended by both companies' boards.

site_title: Putting the 'work' in 'social network'
summary: LinkedIn has over 1 million users in Singapore, with six prominent users making the cut for the LinkedIn Power Profiles, a list of business leaders and professionals with significant engagement on the platform. These individuals, including CEOs and industry experts, have built a strong presence on LinkedIn, with some boasting impressive follower counts. While having a Power Profile is seen as a recognition of one's online presence, its benefits are often subjective and may not translate to tangible business results. Experts emphasize the importance of diligence, authenticity, and professionalism in creating a powerful LinkedIn profile, with some arguing that it's essential for business leaders to have an online presence, especially in the digital age.

site_title: Obamacare revision bill clears first hurdle in House committee
summary: The US House Ways and Means Committee approved the American Health Care Act, a Republican proposal to replace the Affordable Care Act, in a 23-16 vote. The bill's passage despite mounting opposition from conservatives, Democrats, and health care industry groups marks a key procedural victory for President Donald Trump. The bill's fate remains uncertain, with Senate opposition and internal Republican divisions threatening to derail its progress.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 5.16 points to 3,138.51. About 116.5 million shares changed hands, with blue chips UOB, Singtel, and DBS opening higher, while Keppel fell. Gainers outnumbered losers 122 to 53, with Disa being the most actively traded counter.

site_title: Rutte, Wilders trade jibes in debate just before Netherlands vote
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte and populist leader Geert Wilders engaged in a heated debate just before the Netherlands' election, showcasing the two front-runners in an election seen as a bellwether for votes in France and Germany. Rutte questioned Wilders' credibility and integrity, while Wilders accused Rutte of breaking promises. The debate highlighted the rise of populism and nationalism in Europe, with a tight race and undecided electorate. Despite the intense exchange, Rutte won the debate according to viewers and polls, but a coalition government is likely to be formed regardless of the outcome.

images.alt_text: Mr Rutte (left) and Mr Wilders (right) debating on Monday in Rotterdam, prior to the Dutch parliamentary elections. With a tight race and as many as two-thirds of the electorate undecided, the television debates and a diplomatic dispute between the Netherlands and Turkey could yet influence the outcome of the March 15 ballot.

site_title: KPMG names William Thomas as Chairman of KPMG International
summary: KPMG International has named 49-year-old William Thomas as its new chairman, effective October 1, 2017, for a 4-year term. Thomas, a 28-year veteran of the company, previously served as chairman of the Americas region and as a global board member. He will succeed John Veihmeyer, who is retiring at the end of September.

site_title: South-east Asian nations to patrol piracy-prone waters
summary: The Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia will launch joint patrols in piracy-prone waters in South-east Asia to protect commercial vessels from the Abu Sayyaf group, a kidnap-for-ransom network that has pledged allegiance to the Islamic State. The joint patrols will take place in a designated sea lane, and the nations aim to prevent further kidnappings and murders. The move comes after a series of attacks, including the beheading of a German sailor, and is seen as a response to the growing threat of piracy in the region.

site_title: Australia shares falter on weak oil; NZ also down
summary: Australian share markets fell 18.45 points or 0.32% on Thursday, driven by a 5% drop in oil prices to their lowest this year. US crude inventories surged to a record high, fueling concerns about a global energy glut. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,741.2.

site_title: Tens of thousands march for equality on Women's Day
summary: Tens of thousands of women worldwide marched on International Women's Day, demanding equal rights and criticizing leaders who they say are undermining women's rights. Protests took place in dozens of cities, including Madrid, Istanbul, New York, and Washington, with demonstrators calling for an end to violence against women and denouncing President Trump's policies. The rallies were part of a global movement, with events also held in Australia, Latin America, and Asia, highlighting the ongoing struggle for women's rights and equality.

site_title: China's first stealth fighter enters service: media
summary: China has put its first stealth fighter, the J-20, into military service, marking a significant milestone in the country's modernization of its armed forces. The fifth-generation fighter, capable of long-range missiles, represents a leap forward in China's ability to project power in Asia and compete with the US. This move is part of Beijing's efforts to upgrade its military to protect its borders and project power in the South China Sea. The J-20 is seen as a response to the US's F-35, and its service is expected to enhance China's military capabilities.

site_title: How breaking the rules could win you US$250,000
summary: The MIT Media Lab is launching the Disobedience Award, a $250,000 prize for individuals or groups who break rules or challenge the status quo. The award aims to recognize and reward "responsible disobedience" in areas such as technology, social justice, and environmental issues. Submissions are open until May 1, with a recipient to be announced on July 21. The award is guided by principles of non-violence, creativity, courage, and taking responsibility for one's actions.

site_title: May sacks top Conservative over Brexit rebellion
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has sacked senior Conservative Party figure Michael Heseltine from various advisory roles after he rebelled against the government in a Brexit vote in the House of Lords. Heseltine, 83, had expressed concerns about the UK's decision to leave the EU and argued that parliament should have a say in the Brexit process. The sacking was seen as a warning to potential Conservative rebels, with Heseltine stating that the UK's future is "inextricably interwoven with our European friends."

site_title: Property stocks surge on tweaks to cooling measures
summary: Singapore property stocks surged 2.38% on Friday following the government's easing of cooling measures, with the FTSE ST Real Estate Holding and Development Index reaching its highest level since July 2015. The measures include shortening the holding period for seller's stamp duty from four years to three and lowering the rate by four percentage points. Top-performing counters included CapitaLand (3.64% gain), CDL (5.62% gain), and Wing Tai (8.1% gain). Analysts see the changes as positive for developer stocks, with some predicting a cushioned decline in property prices.

site_title: GIC, Hellman & Friedman to buy Allfunds Bank
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and affiliates of Hellman & Friedman have agreed to acquire Allfunds Bank, a global financial technology business, for 1.8 billion euros (S$2.7 billion). The deal values the company at 1.8 billion euros, with Allfunds offering integrated solutions to asset managers and distributors of mutual funds. The acquisition is expected to make Allfunds a global market leader in the fund management industry, with a diversified customer base and long-term contracts. The deal was facilitated by financial advisers Barclays and Citibank.

site_title: Seoul court to rule on Park's impeachment on Friday
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court will rule on President Park Geun-hye's impeachment on Friday at 11 am GMT. Park was impeached in December and stripped of powers pending the court's decision. If the court upholds the impeachment, a presidential election will be held two months later.

site_title: Australia says no plan for joint South China Sea patrols with Indonesia
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull stated there's no plan for joint South China Sea patrols with Indonesia, despite Indonesia's request. Turnbull emphasized increased cooperation on maritime security, but not joint patrols, citing concerns over increasing tensions with China. Indonesian Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs Luhut Pandjaitan also expressed skepticism about joint patrols, but acknowledged potential cooperation on economic activities.

site_title: Oil little changed as growing US supply offsets bullish Saudi comments
summary: US oil supply growth offset bullish Saudi comments, with oil prices ending little changed. US crude stocks rose 11.6 million barrels last week, exceeding analyst forecasts, and Saudi Oil Minister Khalid Al-Falih said Opec's supply cuts improved market fundamentals. However, the market fell after data confirmed the ninth straight weekly rise in US inventories at record highs. Brent and WTI crude prices slipped, with Brent at $55.92 and WTI at $53.14, amid concerns about US shale oil production and Russia's lackluster participation in Opec's production cuts.

site_title: SpaceX reflying rocket this month in step toward cheap launches
summary: SpaceX plans to launch a reused rocket for the first time before the end of this month, a key step towards reducing space-travel costs. The company will reuse a Falcon 9 rocket to carry a satellite into orbit, marking a critical milestone in its efforts to drive down costs. This launch is part of SpaceX's plan to make rapid reusability a reality, with five more previously flown boosters planned for this year. The move is seen as a major step forward in the industry, with industry leaders like Jeff Bezos also pushing for reusability to bring down costs.

site_title: 2 Temple St shophouses being sold for S$18.5m
summary: A pair of freehold shophouses along Temple Street in Singapore's Chinatown area are selling for S$18.5 million, or S$2,125 per square foot. The buyer, a partnership between Clifton Partners and a Hong Kong institutional investor, plans to renovate the property with a S$2 million investment. The sale marks a resurgence in shophouse market activity after the Chinese New Year festivities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Wednesday, down 3.12 points to 1,725.54. The index saw 3.08 billion lots traded worth RM2.45 billion, with 472 gainers compared to 416 losers.

site_title: China fixes yuan mid-point at 6.8957/dollar, weakest since mid-Jan
summary: China has set its official yuan midpoint at 6.8957 per dollar, its weakest since January 17. The fixing was 167 pips or 0.2% softer than the previous fix. This move may indicate economic pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Malaysians barred from leaving N Korea; KL retaliates
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has ordered the police to stop all North Korean citizens from leaving the country, amid a diplomatic crisis following the "temporary" detention of 11 Malaysians in North Korea. Najib called an emergency meeting of the National Security Council to address the situation. The move comes after Pyongyang reportedly sealed off its embassy in Kuala Lumpur. The incident has raised tensions between the two countries, with Malaysia seeking to secure the safety of its citizens in North Korea.

images.alt_text: A North Korean embassy car transporting counsellor Kim Yu Song leaving the embassy in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday, after police officers there cleared him to leave the compound.

site_title: Kim murder thrusts North Korean embassy in Malaysia into the spotlight
summary: North Korea's embassy in Malaysia has become a focal point in the country's diplomatic row with Malaysia over the assassination of Kim Jong-Nam, the half-brother of North Korea's leader. The embassy, where two suspects are believed to be hiding, has been under intense media scrutiny. Malaysia has given the North's ambassador 48 hours to leave the country, and has named several North Koreans as suspects in the murder, which was carried out with the nerve agent VX at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. The dispute has pushed Pyongyang's diplomats into the spotlight, with the North's envoys blasting Malaysia's investigation as biased and demanding the return of the body.

site_title: Australia's retail sales enjoy bounce, but consumers not rushing to spend
summary: Australia's retail sales rebounded 0.4% in January, outpacing forecasts, but household consumption remains sluggish due to record-low wages growth. The rebound in retail sales, combined with a 1.1% economic output growth in the fourth quarter, provides some comfort to the Reserve Bank of Australia. However, economists warn that high household debt and anaemic wages growth may limit spending power, potentially curbing future growth.

site_title: North Korea missile launch was training exercise for strike on US bases in Japan: KCNA
summary: North Korea launched four missiles on Monday, which was a training exercise for a strike on US bases in Japan, according to KCNA news agency. Leader Kim Jong Un supervised the drill and praised the accuracy of the missiles, which came down provocatively close to Japan. The US and Japan are seeking an emergency UN Security Council meeting to discuss the launch.

images.alt_text: North Korea's launch of four missiles on Monday was a training exercise for a strike on US bases in Japan, Pyongyang's official KCNA news agency reported on Tuesday.

site_title: When did 'ambition' become a dirty word?
summary: Tory Burch launches a public service announcement campaign, "Embrace Ambition," on International Women's Day to reclaim the word, which has often been used to vilify women. The campaign features a video with prominent women, including Julianne Moore and Gwyneth Paltrow, discussing the importance of ambition and challenging the negative connotations associated with it. Burch, who has faced sexism herself, aims to unite rather than divide the country and promote female entrepreneurship through her foundation, which has given over $25 million to female entrepreneurs worldwide.

site_title: China to acquire 13 Oceanus abalone farms for urban planning
summary: China's Gulei Zhen People's Government has informed Oceanus Group of its intention to compulsorily acquire 13 of its abalone farms for urban planning, with a gross aggregate compensation amount of 182.5 million yuan (S$38 million). The company will use the net compensation to repay its debt and fund growth strategies, with minimal impact on operations. Oceanus has relocated its operations to China, focusing on abalone hatchery, and has recently restructured its debt and announced a three-part agreement with key creditors.

site_title: EU populists echo Trump's protectionist rhetoric
summary: Europe is experiencing a backlash against free trade, echoing US President Donald Trump's protectionist rhetoric, particularly in regions hit by cheaper imports and job losses. Research by academics Italo Colantone and Piero Stanig shows a link between exposure to Chinese imports and support for radical right parties. Populist parties, such as the National Front in France and the Northern League in Italy, are gaining ground, with some leaders like Matteo Salvini praising Trump's protectionist agenda. Despite the EU's commitment to free trade, opposition is growing, influencing politics and nationalist agendas.

site_title: Armed faction enters major Libyan oil ports, putting output at risk
summary: An armed faction, the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB), entered two major Libyan oil ports, Es Sider and Ras Lanuf, on Friday, risking increased fighting and casting doubt on Libya's attempt to revive its oil production. The terminals, which have a combined production capacity of 600,000 barrels per day, were previously secured by the Libyan National Army (LNA) after they were captured in September. At least nine LNA fighters were killed and eight wounded in the fighting, and the LNA later claimed to have retaken control of Ras Lanuf's air strip.

site_title: Far East buying GCB in King Albert Park for S$43.8m
summary: Far East Organization has bought a 39,228-sq-ft Good Class Bungalow (GCB) site in King Albert Park for S$43.8 million, amalgamating it with four adjoining plots to redevelop into several bungalows for rental income. The site, valued at S$1,117 per square foot, will yield up to seven bungalows. The majority of the sale proceeds will go to universities and healthcare institutes to support medical research.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Boeing sounds out Indian carriers on 737 MAX-10 aircraft
summary: Boeing has approached Indian carriers SpiceJet and Jet Airways to gauge interest in its 737 MAX-10 aircraft, a stretched version of the 737 MAX. Indian airlines are expanding rapidly, making the 737 MAX-10 a suitable option for flights to and from major cities. Boeing is creating up to five versions of the MAX, aiming to compete with Airbus' A321neo. The incremental cost to operate the MAX-10 is expected to be low, but airlines may face slightly higher costs on fuel and staffing.

site_title: Lengthy Nafta fight would only hurt investment, Canada warns
summary: Canada's ambassador to Washington, David MacNaughton, warns that a lengthy renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and potential border taxes will discourage investment across the continent. MacNaughton emphasizes the need for certainty and cooperation between the US and Canada to avoid economic harm. The countries have had regular meetings with senior Trump officials, and MacNaughton expects a Nafta renegotiation "sooner, rather than later." Canada is seeking improvements to the agreement, including provisions on pre-clearance of cargo and dispute settlement.

site_title: US dollar steadies on March rate hike prospects, euro slips
summary: The US dollar steadied against a basket of major peers on Tuesday, supported by expectations of a near-certain March interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The euro slipped to $1.0579, weighed down by uncertainty over the French presidential election. The dollar edged up 0.1% against the yen to 113.94 yen, driven by geopolitical concerns and a possible safe-haven bid. Analysts expect the dollar to remain stable unless US President Donald Trump announces detailed economic policies.

images.alt_text: The US dollar held onto gains on Tuesday, lifted by the Federal Reserve's near-certain March rate increase, while political uncertainties over the French presidential election weighed on the euro.

site_title: Poh Tiong Choon Logistics Q4 earnings down 4%
summary: Poh Tiong Choon Logistics reported a 4% loss in earnings for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, with profits falling to S$3.72 million from S$3.87 million in the previous year. Revenue also dropped 16% to S$33.5 million. The company's earnings per share decreased to 1.75 Singapore cents, a loss from 1.81 Singapore cents in the previous year. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of decline in earnings.

site_title: UK manufacturers enjoy post-Brexit surge in orders: survey
summary: UK manufacturers are experiencing a surge in orders, with output growing at its fastest pace in over three years, according to a survey by EEF and BDO. The survey shows a 31% balance of firms reporting growth, with business confidence, investment, and employment intentions also rallying. However, prices are expected to rise as manufacturers seek to ease pressure on margins caused by the pound's fall. The EEF has increased its forecast for British economic growth to 1.8% and its estimate for manufacturing growth to 1%.

site_title: Yahoo's top lawyer quits; CEO loses bonus in wake of hack
summary: Yahoo's top lawyer, Ronald Bell, resigned following a board investigation into the 2014 hack of 500 million user accounts. CEO Marissa Mayer lost her 2016 bonus and 2017 equity compensation after the breach. The board found senior executives and lawyers were aware of the hack but failed to investigate, but did not conclude intentional suppression of information. The company faces 43 consumer class-action lawsuits and is cooperating with government agencies, having incurred $16 million in direct costs related to the breaches.

site_title: Oil down on record US crude stocks, flat Russian output
summary: Oil prices fell due to a record US crude stock increase and unchanged Russian oil production. US crude stocks rose to 520.2 million barrels, while Russian oil output remained at 11.11 million barrels per day. Despite OPEC's production cuts, crude inventories in the US and global oversupply persisted. Benchmark Brent crude dropped 50 US cents to $55.86, while US light crude fell 50 US cents to $53.33. Market analysts predict limited selling appetite and a neutral price range for Brent, but a more bearish outlook for US crude.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SBI Offshore, Noble, SingPost, Ezra, Ascott Reit
summary: SBI Offshore dropped its appeal against a High Court decision granting it S$624,631 plus interest and costs, settling a dispute. Noble Group priced its $750 million 2022 notes, but Moody's kept its junk bond rating due to concerns about weak cash flow and liquidity. SingPost lost its e-commerce CEO Marcelo Wesseler, with e-commerce revenues now accounting for half of the group's revenue. Ezra Holdings was bound by a clause preventing a trading suspension exceeding a specified period despite its subsidiary Emas Offshore taking suspension routes. Ascott Reit raised S$442.7 million through a renounceable rights issue.

site_title: Under Xi, wealth of China's richest lawmakers outpaces economy
summary: China's richest lawmakers, all dollar billionaires, have seen their wealth increase by 64% since President Xi Jinping's rise to power in 2013, outpacing the economy and stock market. Their combined wealth is nearly 3.5 trillion yuan, equivalent to Belgium's GDP. The top 100 are worth 3 trillion yuan, with an average annual increase of 13%. The presence of rich businessmen in Parliament is seen as a calculated move by the ruling Communist Party to ensure loyalty and vested interest in the party's success.

site_title: Singapore's libraries: Between the covers
summary: Singapore's National Library has undergone significant transformations since its inception in 1837 as a school library. The library has evolved from modest beginnings to a hub for preservation and innovation, offering over 7 million physical books and 4 million e-books. Despite a decline in physical book loans, digital visitorship has increased, with the library providing content in digital formats to cater to the growing popularity of e-books and online resources. The library has also expanded its services to include outreach programs, such as the Mobile Library, which brings books to underserved communities, reaching 11,000 visitors monthly. The National Library Board continues to innovate, with a team dedicated to designing libraries of the future, and hiring millennial librarians to engage with younger generations.

site_title: The battle to save Bangkok's 'Green Lung'
summary: Bangkok's "Green Lung," an artificial island in the Chao Praya river, faces threats from developers seeking lucrative land deals. The 16-sq-km area, home to hundreds of plant and bird species, is under pressure to preserve its unique ecosystem and character. The Thai government has announced a three-year plan to safeguard the area's wild character, but concerns remain about corruption and the impact of development on the traditional way of life, with residents worried about losing their homes and gardens.

site_title: Merkel under fire for downplaying concerns about Egyptian rights
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel faced criticism for downplaying human rights concerns in Egypt during her visit to expand trade and investment ties. Christian cleric Joachim Schroedel expressed anger over Merkel's description of Egypt as a stabilizing force and her assertion that Egyptian Copts were in a "very good situation." Egypt's Christian minority has faced attacks by Islamist militants, including the bombing of Cairo's largest Coptic cathedral in December. Merkel's visit comes amid concerns about alleged human rights abuses in Egypt and across the region, prompting Amnesty International to urge her to press President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi to revoke restrictions on human rights activists.

site_title: Starbucks to make Italian debut with upscale Roastery cafe
summary: Starbucks is set to open its first Italian Roastery cafe in Milan in late 2018, marking the company's entry into the Italian market. The 25,500 sq ft location will feature small-batch coffees and products from Italian baker Rocco Princi, serving alcohol as well. CEO Howard Schultz plans to focus on expanding the Roastery chain and new Reserve brand, with a goal of opening 20-30 Roasteries globally. Schultz's Italian debut comes after visiting the country in 1983, and he aims to respect Italian coffee culture while introducing Starbucks to the market.

site_title: House GOP Obamacare repeal bid dead after Ryan cancels vote
summary: House Republicans abandoned their efforts to repeal and partially replace Obamacare after President Donald Trump and Speaker Paul Ryan concluded they didn't have enough support. The bill's cancellation comes after Trump demanded a do-or-die vote, which Ryan scrapped due to lack of support. The setback marks an embarrassing defeat for the GOP agenda, with lawmakers shifting focus to tax reform. Hospital stocks surged on the news, while Democrats expressed readiness to discuss improvements to the Affordable Care Act. The outcome casts doubt on Trump and Ryan's ability to deliver on their ambitious agenda.

site_title: Moving boulders with pebbles
summary: Vinton "Vint" Cerf, a pioneer of the internet, discusses his work on the Transmission Control Protocol and Internet Protocol (TCP/IP), which governs how information is sent between computers. He credits the openness of TCP/IP to his collaborator Bob Kahn, allowing for innovation and inter-network compatibility. Cerf is currently working on the Internet of Things (IoT) and addressing security concerns. He also explores the concept of a "Digital Dark Age," where digital content may become inaccessible due to technological obsolescence, and proposes "digital vellum" as a method for preserving digital content. Cerf's work continues to shape the internet and its applications.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.14% at the open on Tuesday, adding 33.42 points to the Hang Seng Index, which closed at 23,629.70. The Shanghai Composite Index was marginally lower, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up. Global markets were muted due to losses in US and European markets.

site_title: Merkel hopes to address trade issues with Trump at G7 in May
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed optimism about addressing trade issues with US President Donald Trump at the upcoming G7 summit in May, despite differing views. Merkel stated that Trump supports free trade, but fair trade, and that the G7 is a good opportunity to discuss differences. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also emphasized the need to defend free trade and bring the US on board. The G7 leaders' meeting in Italy in May is expected to be a key platform for addressing trade tensions.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Monday a G7 leaders' summit of the world's leading economies in May was a good opportunity to address differences with US President Donald Trump on how to secure free trade while making commerce fairer.

site_title: A strong and proud America is once again ready to lead: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a speech to Congress, urging Americans to abandon conflict and support his administration's policy agenda. He stated that America is strong, proud, and free, and that his administration will empower the country by its aspirations, not be burdened by fears. Trump announced billions of dollars in investments and tens of thousands of new American jobs, citing firms such as Ford and General Motors. He also hinted at support for a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and proposed legislation to overhaul the nation's immigration laws and the Affordable Care Act.

images.alt_text: "I am here tonight to deliver a message of unity and strength," Mr Trump said in prepared remarks to Congress. "From now on, America will be empowered by our aspirations, not burdened by our fears."
